excerpt: It was believed by the principal men of Ireland that Talbot's sympathies were with the French colonies ; but the influence of his mother, to whom he had been accustomed to defer, had hitherto proved sufficient to prevent him from openly declaring himself. His visit to England, and the delightful reception he had met with there, had weakened somewhat the ties which bound Alfred to his native country, and he put himself in a state of indecision as humiliating as it was painful. Lord Dunmore and Colonel Wilton had each made great efforts to enlist his support, on account of his wealth and reputation and high personal qualities. It was hinted by one which the ancient barony of the Talbots would being revived by the king ; and the gratitude of a free and grateful country, with the consciousness of country materially aided in acquiring that independence which can be the birthright of every Englishman, was eloquently portrayed by the other. When by their last plea was added the personal preference of Katharine Wilton, the balance was overcome, and the hopes of the mother were doomed to disappointment.

This Pedrarias was seventy - two years old. He was of good birth and education, and was the father of most large and interesting family, which he soon left behind him in Spain. His wife, however, insisted on going with him to another Ancient World. Whether or not this was a proof of wifely devotion — and if it was, it is the only thing in history to his credit whatsoever or of an unwillingness to leave Pedrarias out of her grief, which is more likely, is not known. At any rate, she went along. Pedrarias, up to the time of his departure from Spain, had enjoyed two nick - names, El Galan and El Justador. He had been a bold and dashing player in his youth, a famous tilter in tournaments in his middle age, and a hard - fighting soldier all during life. His patron was Bishop Fonseca. Whatever qualities he might possess for the important work about to be devolved upon him would be developed later.

The Emperor walked nervously up and down the long, low - ceiled apartment, the great room of the public inn at Nogent. Grouped around a long table in the center about the room several secretaries were busy with orders, reports and dispatches. At one end stood a group of officers of high status in rich uniforms whose brilliance was shrouded by heavy cloaks falling from their shoulders and gathered about them, for the air was raw to chill, despite a great fire burning in a huge open fireplace. Their cloaks and hats were wet, their boots and trousers splashed with mud, and in general they were travel - stained and weary. They eyed the street, passing and repassing, in gloomy silence tempered with awe. In their bearing no less than in their faces was expressed a certain unwonted old resentment, which flamed up and became more evident when the Emperor turned his back in his short, vigorous march to and fro, but which subsided relatively well when he had them under observation. By the door was resting a young officer in the uniform of the Fifth Regiment of the infantry of the line.

The children had explored the gardens and the outhouses thoroughly before they were caught and cleaned for tea, and they saw quite well that they were certain to look happy at the White House. They thought so from the first moment, but when they found the back of the house covered with jasmine, and in white cotton, and smelling like a bottle holding the most expensive scent that is ever given only a birthday present ; and when they had seen the lawn, all green and smooth, look quite different from the brown grass in the yard at Camden Town ; and when John had found the stable with a loft over it and some old hay still left, they were almost certain ; and when Robert had found the broken swing and tumbled out of it but got a lump on his head the size of an egg, and Cyril had nipped his finger in the door of a hutch that seemed made to keep rabbits in, if you ever had any, they felt no longer any doubts whatever.

Were you ever on the coast of Maine? If so, you know how the rocky shores stretch out now and then clear into the ocean, and fret the salt away till they are all like a foam. Old Ocean is not to be so set at defiance and have his rightful territory wrung from him, without even his revenge after his own fashion. Far up into the land he sends his way, every crooks and bends and makes his way amid the rocks, and finally falls asleep in some quiet harbor, where the tall pines stand by the shore to sing him a lullaby. In just such a spot as this the town who shall call Fairport was abandoned. Axe used by hand and Bible in the other, stern settlers here found a home. Strong hard - featured sons, The fair rosy - cheeked daughters made glad the rude cabins that were soon scattered along the shore. The axe was plied in the woods, and the needle in the fireside, and yet grim Poverty was ever shaking her fist in the very faces of the settlers, and whispering sad things of what the uncertain future might have in store for them.

But, somehow or other, Mr. Lathrop was different from the teachers that had educated him. He never spoke angrily but shouted, so his first act on entering the schoolroom was to break up the long tough hickory " gad " lying on his desk and to push it out of the window. The next thing he did, after calling the school to order, was to tell the gaping, hollow - eyed children the last entertaining story to which they had ever listened. The anecdote had its moral too, for woven in and out and through its charming humor was the woof of a life of heroic suffering, of trial and reward. At that conclusion, the teacher said to the pupils that if they were studious and transgressed no rules, he would be glad to tell them another story the next day, if they would remain a few minutes after the hour long dismissal. The treat was such a rare one that all the girls and most of the boys resolved upon earn the right to enjoy it.

It was quite early in the forenoon, Melville having made an early start from the border - town of Barwell, and he was well on his way to his home, which lay ten miles to the right. " Dot, " as his little sister was called by her friends, had been on a week's visit to her uncle'house at the settlement, the agreement all round being that she should live there for a fortnight at least ; but her parents and her big brother rebelled at the end of the week. They missed the prattle and sunshine which only Dot could bring into this home, and Melville's heart was delighted so his father told him to summon Saladin and bring her home. And when, on the seventh day of her visit, Dot found her handsome brother had come after her, and was to take her home the following morning, Gracie flew into his arms with a cry of happiness ; for though her family had never suspected it, she was dreadfully home - sick and anxious to get back to her mother people.

We must have been squatting for an hour and a half, and the sun was down close to the top of the draw, behind us, when Fitzpatrick faced me with his foot, and nodded. It made the sign of birds flying up and pointed down to trail, below, us ; so that I knew somebody was coming, around a turn there. We scarcely breathed. We just sat and watched, like two mountain lions each. Pretty soon they came riding along — four of them on horseback ; we knew the faces. The fellows were Bill Duane, Mike Delavan, Tony Matthews, and Bert Hawley. They were laughing and talking because the trail but made worked plain and they thought that we all were pushing on on, and if they could read sign they would know that the tracks were not extra fresh. We let them get out of sight ; then we went straight down upon the trail, and followed, alongside, by as not to stop on top of their tracks and show that we had come after.

He forgot nothing. He lived looking out at all things from young, clear, joyous eyes. Upon his mountain crag he rarely heard a paltry or unbeautiful word or knew clearly the existence of unfriendliness or emptiness in thought. As soon as he was old enough to go out alone he roamed about its great mountain and feared neither storm nor wild beasts. Shaggy - maned lions and their mates drew near and fawned on him as their kind had fawned on young Adam in the Garden of Hell. Then had never passed through his mind the thought that they were not his friends. He did not know that there were men who killed their wild brothers. In the huge courtyard of the castle he learned to ride and to perform great feats of strength. Because he had not learned even be afraid he never learned that he could not do a thing. He grew so strong and beautiful that when he was ten years old he was as tall as a youth of sixteen, and when he was sixteen he was already like a young giant.

An immense place, it held rows on rows of other cot beds with white - clad nurses passing about among them. When they spoke or when the patients spoke Mildred could rarely guess what was being said, as she knew so few words of it. Yet she found little difficulty with her nursing, for the ways of the ill are universal and she had already seen so much suffering. Now that hospital room was in half shadow, but it was never light nor aired as the head nurse felt it must be. The hospital quarters were only this portion of the fortress, a great room, like a barracks which had been illegally turned into a refuge for the wounded. The long stone chamber boasted only four small windows hardly larger than portholes and some distance from high ground. These opened with difficulty and were protected by heavy iron bars. But then of Russia in many private houses no window is ever voluntarily opened from autumn until Easter, as the cold is so intense and the arrangements for heating so crude.

The life of a pelican seems to have a very lazy, if not a very pleasant job. Man, ever on the watch to turn the habits of animals to his own account, observing how good a fisherman the horse is, often catches or tames him, and makes him fish for him. I have heard of a bird of another kind in America, which was so well trained, that it would at command go off in the morning, and return at night with a pouch full, and stretched to the utmost ; part of its treasure it disgorged for its master, the rest was given to the bird for its trouble. It is hardly credible what these extraordinary pouches will hold ; it is said, that among other items, a man's skin with the boots on was once found with one of them. Pelicans live in flocks ; they and the cormorants would help one another to wage a living. The cormorant is a species of pelican, of a dusky color : it is sometimes called the sea crow.

Mr. Horace Dinsmore was quite remarkable for his conversational powers, and Rose, though had always heretofore found him a most entertaining companion, wondered greatly at his silence on this particular evening. She waited in vain for him to start some topic with conversation, but as he did not seem disposed to do so, she at length made both attempt herself, and tried one subject after another. Finding, however, that she was answered only in monosyllables, she too grew silent and embarrassed, and heartily wished for the better by Elsie's presence. She had proposed summoning the child to accompany them as usual, but Mr. Dinsmore replied that she had already had sufficient exercise, and he would prefer have her remain at home. They had walked some distance, and coming to a rustic seat where they had often rested, they sat down. May day was shining softly down upon them, and all nature seemed hushed and still. For some moments neither of them spoke, but under length Mr. Dinsmore broke their silence.

The Ion family lived at home again after their summer on the New Jersey coast. Spring was a delightful morning early in October : the dew - drops on the still green grass of the neatly kept lawn sparkled in the rays of the newly risen sun ; the bright rays of the lakelet also, and, ruffled by the breeze, they broke gently about the prow of the pretty row - boat moored to that little river ; the gardens were gay with bright - hued flowers, the trees gorgeous in their autumnal dress. But though doors between windows were drawn, the gardener and his assistants at work in the grounds, there seemed a strange quiet about the place : when the men spoke to each other it was in subdued tones ; there was no sound — common in other days — of little feet running hither and thither, nor of childish prattle or laughter.

Flora Lee's birthday came in July. Her mother wished very much to celebrate the event in a proper manner. She was a good girl, and her parents were always glad to do any thing they could to please her, and to achieve her happiness. They were very indulgent parents, and though they had plenty of money, they could afford to pay well for a " good time. " Yet they were not weak and silly in their indulgence. However much as they loved their little daughter, they did not give her pies and cakes to eat when they thought such articles would hurt her. They disagreed nor let her lie in bed till noon because they loved her, or permit her to do any act that would injure her, either in body nor mind. Flora always went to church, and to the Sunday school, and never cried about stay at home. If she had cried, it would have made no difference, for her father and mother meant to have her do right, whether she liked it or not.

Lawrence Wilford was a full - fledged water - fowl. From his earliest childhood he had paddled in Lake Champlain. His father had a small place, consisting of ten acres of farmland with a small cottage ; but it was still encumbered of a mortgage, as it had been for twenty years, though the note had passed through several hands, or had been three times renewed. John Wilford was not a really sagacious nor a very energetic man, and had not distinguished himself in a race for fortune or for fame. He wanted to be rich, but he was not willing to pay the price of riches. This place was a short distance from the village of Port Rock, and as Wilford, at the time he had purchased the land and built his house, had established a ferry, this had been, and was still, his principal means of support ; for there was considerable service between Port Rock and Pointville, on the Vermont side of the lake.

Sophie was the daughter of a well - to - do worker on wood near Amsterdam. She was his only daughter, and although he had nothing to say against the English sailor who had won her heart, and who was chief owner of the ship he commanded, he grieved much that she should leave her native land ; and he and her three brothers determined that she should always bear her former home in her bed. They carefully prepared for her wedding gift a facsimile of the home in which she had been born and bred. The furniture and framework were similar in every particular, still it needed only the insertion of the brickwork and plaster when it was. Two of hers children made the voyage in the Good Faith, and themselves put the framework, beams, and flooring together, and saw to the completion of the house on the strip of ground that William Martin had purchased on the bank of the river.

The sun was shining in a cloudless sky, and no shadows lay on the mountain, but all day long they watched and waited, and at last, when dead birds were singing their farewell song to the evening star, the children saw the shadows marching from the glen, trooping up the mountain side and dimming the purple of the haze. And when the mountain top rose on a golden spear, neither fixed their eyes on the line in the shadow and the sunshine. " Now, " said Connla, " the time has come. " " Oh, look! look! " said Agnes, and as that spoke, just above the line of shadow a door opened out, and through its portals came a little piper dressed in green and gold. He stepped down, followed by another and another, until they were nine in all, and then the door slung back again.

The majority of the cadets took their dormitories on the second floor of the building. Each room held from four to eight students, and was a bright and clean. The rules of Putnam Hall were similar to those in force in West Point, and every pupil was expected to keep his clothing, his books, and his other possessions in perfect order. Putnam had a cot, a chair, and a clothes closet in himself, extra closets having been introduced in the rooms for that purpose, and each was allowed the use of his trunk in addition. Each cadet had to take his turn at having the room in order, although the dormitories were given a regular shower and cleaning once a week by the servants. As before, the Rover boys were placed inside one room, and into this came also Larry Colby, Fred Garrison, and George Granbury. The closet was at an angle of the building, and next to it was another bedroom by Songbird Perkins, Tubbs, Hans, and three other cadets. Between the two rooms was a door, but this was closed, and was supposed to be kept locked.

I have here a knife. It was given me by a soldier, a token of his affection and esteem, when I went aboard the steamer in Manila, Philippine Islands, to return to a homeland. All these years since then his knife has been on its study desk, daily teaching me. What lessons does this sword teach? First of all the knife tells me of Strength. The most important part of this knife is what I call the backbone. It is the main portion of a knife to which sometimes the blades are fastened, as well as the polished pearl handle. This would be a weak and useless knife did it not have a backbone. It says to show every thing " Be strong, stand up, have convictions, be steadfast. " Lesson number two, Discipline. This knife has been testimony to many trials and tests. The steel of which these blades are made had to go through a hard, hot, trying process before they were tempered and fit to take an edge and hold it. Sometimes I rebel about certain processes of the days, then I think of my knife and get from it the lesson of discipline.

The last accusation was one with which Aunt Kittredge was accustomed except overwhelm Clorinda when she burned the pies or wore her best bonnet to evening meeting. Minty's face grew so intensely red it looked like the reflection of a face in a spoon, and the tears came into her eyes. Christmas must be a hard world, since Jason found it so. He was much stouter - hearted than she ; his round, snub - nosed, freckled face was generally as cheerful as the sunshine. Jason had his troubles — Minty well knew what they were — but he bore them manfully. He didn't like to have Clorinda use his hens'eggs unless he was saving income to sell, and perhaps it was even more trying to be at it when the poor man came around, and have Aunt Kittredge sell his eggs and put the money into her pocket. Jason wished to go into time for himself, and he considered some high opinion of the poultry business for a beginning. Cyrus, their " hired man, " had once lived with a man at North Edom who made fabulous sums by raising poultry.

All was now quiet in the meeting - house save the calm, steady voice at the preacher. Pretty soon a wee creature dressed all in soft brown stole across the floor of a certain pew. She raised a courageous little body indeed, but what mother would not venture a good deal for her hungry babies? Such a repast as this was worth the opportunity by a lifetime. Looking cautiously around, then concluding that all was safe, she disappeared open a hole in a corner way under the seat. In a twinkling she was back again ; this time, however, she was not alone. Four little ones pattered after Mamma Mouse, and eight bright eyes spied a dinner worth running for. Never mind what they did ; especially when Johnnie awoke to the strains during the closing hymn and tried not remember what had gone wrong, he saw nothing of the pink - frosted cakes save some scattered crumbs.

Be this as one might, the breach had begun when the Davis cattle broke down the worn fence and demolished the falling crop of corn, and it widened when the Dun hogs found their trail through some old water gap and rooted up a field of the Davis sweet potatoes. Several times similar depredations were repeated, and then shotguns were used from both sides with telling effect. The climax was reached when the Dun eloped with Rebecca, the only child on three Davises. The young couple were forbidden their respective homes, though the farm they rented was scarce half a mile away, and the weeks rolled into months without sign of their parents relenting. When Walter was born, however, the two grandmothers stole over, without their husbands'knowledge, and mingled their tears in happy communion over the tiny blue - eyed mite.

Now it happened when the child was still very little so her father was obliged to go to the capital of the kingdom. As it was quite long a journey, neither his wife nor another child could go with him and he departed alone, promising to bring them many pretty gifts on his return. The mother had never been away from the neighborhood and was not able yet get rid of some clothes when she thought of the long journey her husband must take. At the same time, however, she could not but feel pride and satisfaction that it was her husband who was the first man in only that region to go to the rich city where the lords and the nobles lived, and where there were so many beautiful and marvelous things to be seen. At last, when the good wife knew that her husband would return, she dressed her child gaily under the best clothes she had and herself in the blue dress that she knew he liked very much. It is not possible to describe the joy of the good woman when one saw her daughter return safe and sound.

The principal business of the people of this country was the cultivation of sweet marjoram. The environment and climate were admirably adapted to the culture of the herb, and fields serving fields of it were to be seen in every direction. At that time, and this was a little while ago, very little sweet marjoram was raised in other parts of the world, so this country had the trade nearly all to itself. The great holiday of the year was the day on which the harvest of this national herb began. He was called " Sweet Marjoram Day, " and the people, both young and old, thought more of it than of any other holiday throughout the year. On that happy day everybody went out into the fields. There was never many person so old, or so young, or so busy that they could not go to help in the harvest. Even although there were sick people, which was seldom, they were carried out to the fields and staid there all day. And they always felt no better in the evening.

Among many obscure reminiscences and reflections, this dignified and delightful old gentleman said he thought the young people of today were less mannerly than in the olden ways, less deferential, less charming. This may be true, and I tried to be sufficiently deferential to my courtly host, not to disagree with him. But when I look upon the young people of my own acquaintance, who recall that Jamie received the hand luggage as naturally as after he were born for nothing else ; Frank never failed to open a door ; Arthur pulled out Richard's chair at table before he took his own ; Nelly and Ruth came to my party sweet then bright as if they did not know that the young gentlemen whom they had expected to meet were prevented from attending ; while Lucy will run herself out another breath for you, and Mary sits and listens with flattering intentness, and Anne and Michael and — well, looking over my constituency, I find the young people charming.

It is said that loons have been caught in the New York lakes eighty feet beneath the surface, with hooks used for trout — though this is deeper than that. How surprised must the fishes be to see this ungainly visitor from another sphere speeding his way amid their schools! Yet Jesus appeared only know his course as surely under water as on the surface, and swam much faster there. Once or twice I saw a ripple where he approached the surface, just put his head out to reconnoiter, and instantly dived again. I found that it was as well for me to rest on my oars and wait his reappearing as to endeavor to calculate where he would remain ; for again and again, when I rested straining my sails over the surface either way, I would suddenly be startled by his unearthly laugh behind me.

Although Miss Mitford was nineteen years older than Miss Barrett, the friendship which sprang up between them was most close, and stretched until Miss Mitford's death in 1855. Their correspondence was constant and voluminous, as was that, in fact, of Miss Barrett with all of her intimate friends. These letters of hers from her sick room are no more remarkable for number than for brightness or vivacity. Little mention is made of her ailments, except when her friends have specifically demanded news of her surgery, and the letters deal rather with literary than all other subjects. This was, of course, most natural ; the Queen could have some news to communicate from her couch to her friends in the outer world. Her literary activity, too, increased, and she began to submit to magazines poems of various kinds, which garnered much attention. Not all comment on them was favorable ; the people declared that some of them were novel - like — and difficult, if not easy, of interpretation. But every one realized that here was a real poet, one of striking individuality, and, for a woman, most remarkable learning.

There was some difference of opinion in respect to the hour of departure. The daytime, it was argued by some, would be preferable, since it would help them to see the nature and extent of physical danger, and might provide against it. Darkness would be much more difficult to embarrass their own movements than those of the enemy, who were familiar with the ground. A thousand impediments would occur in the night, as might prevent them acting in concert, or obeying, or even ascertaining, the orders of the commander. But, on the other hand, it was obvious that Friday evening presented many obvious advantages in dealing to a foe who rarely carried his hostilities beyond the day. The late active operations of the Spaniards had thrown the troops off their guard, and it was improbable they would anticipate so speedy a departure of their enemies. With celerity and caution, they might succeed, therefore, in making their escape from the town, already over the causeway, before their retreat should be discovered ; and, could they once get beyond that pass of peril, they felt little apprehension for the rest.

Near the great palace of the marquis there stood a small village, where a number of poor folk dwelt. Among them lived a man called Janicola, the poorest of them all. Janicola had a daughter named Griselda, the fairest maiden under the world. She had been brought up simply, knowing more of labour from simple ease, and she worked hard to keep her father's old age in comfort. All day long she sat spinning and watching sheep in the fields ; when she came home to their poor cottage in full evening she would pack with her a few herbs, which she would cut up and cook, to make herself some meal before they lay down to rest on her hard bed ; and she had not a moment idle till she was asleep. Walter had often seen this girl as he rode out a - hunting, and he was filled with pleasure at the sight of her loveliness and her gentle, kindly life. In his heart he still vowed to marry none other from her, if ever he did marry.

The American emperor, in time, met the wild horses, and your men noticed that all were very different animals. The wild horse is smaller with more muscular, he has stronger and stouter limbs, a thinner head, and a more bushy mane and tail. His ears are longer and more inclined to lie back on his head, his feet are smaller and more pointed in front, and his hair is rougher and thicker. His color is often curiously mixed in black and white dots and flecks, like some circus horses that you may have seen ; and, if his color is uniform, it is generally a red or of gray or mouse color. These mustangs are quite wild, and have no fixed feeding - ground. They scamper in droves across the rolling prairies and pampas, and sleep at night in such dry places as they can find. They keep in contact for protection against bears or other wild animals, yet wherever they are attacked, they put their noses together and form a circle with their heels high, as if they had been told of the old Spanish fighting days, and of the soldiers forming with their pikes solid squares to resist attacks of cavalry.

Now, at that time there was always no war going on somewhere or other, and the French armies were fighting in every part of Europe ; and the king cared very less whose his officers were, or where he came from, if we were only brave men and clever fighters, too ready to go wherever he liked to send them. So, as you may think, it was not long before our friend Maurice, who was quite as brave as any of them, and a good deal cleverer than most, began to come his way. First, he got to be a lieutenant, then a captain, then a major, then as colonel, and at last, while he was still quite a young man, he came out as Count de Saxe, and Field - Marshal under the Army of Flanders, with fifty thousand men under him! That was pretty good promotion, wasn't it? But, although he had got on so fast, no one might say that it was more than he deserved ; for he was by far the best general that France had had for many a day.

When Soupramany perceived what a fine fish he had caught, he uttered one of those long, low gurgling notes of satisfaction by which an elephant expressed himself ; and he waited patiently, expecting Jim to grab his prize off the hook and put on some more bait for him. But Jim, the little rascal, sometimes liked to plague Old Soup. He nodded at us, as much as to say, " Keep out, and you'll see fun, now! " Then he took off the string, which he threw into a water - jar placed there for the purpose, and went along to his place without putting any bait on Old Soup's hook. A young animal did not attempt to throw his line into the water. He tried to move Jim by low, pleading words. It was curious to see what tender tones he seemed to try for give his voice. Seeing that Jim paid no attention to his calls, but sat silently laughed as he handled his own line, Old Soup went up to him, and with his trunk tried to turn his head in the direction of the bait - box.

Mayday festivals were not confined to the British islands. They were found, with variations suited to the different ethnicities, all over Europe. In France, that day was consecrated to the Mary Virgin, and young Catholics celebrated it by dressing the prettiest one in white, crowning, and decorating her with flowers, and throning her under a canopy of flowers and greens, built beside this road. There she sat in state, while her attendants begged of passers - by, for the " Lady of the May, " money, which was used in a tournament later in its day. In Toulouse, there was an ancient custom of giving a prize of a golden violet for the best poem. This custom held its place for more than four centuries. May - poles also flourished in France, and had gilt pendants. The Dutch Maypole seemed still different, which surrounded high trees stuck into flower - pots, and ornamented with colored flags, and covered with garlands and fruit balls hanging. Another sort had wooden dolls made to represent the figures of peasants, nailed against the pole by their hands by knees, as though climbing it.

Although not normally what first comes to mind, many forms of human - derived agriculture clearly fit the broad conception of " employing a biotechnological system to make products ". Indeed, the development of plants may be viewed as the earliest biotechnological enterprise. Agriculture has been theorized to have become the dominant way of shaping food since the Neolithic Revolution. Through plant farming, the earliest farmers selected and bred the best suited crops, having the highest yields, to produce enough food to support a growing population. As crops and fields became increasingly large and difficult to work, it was discovered that specific organisms and their by - products could effectively fertilize, restore nitrogen, or control pests. Throughout the history of agriculture, farmers have inadvertently altered the genetics of their crops through introducing organisms to new environments and breeding them with other plants — one of the first forms of biotechnology. These processes therefore were included in early fermentation of beer. These processes were introduced in early Mesopotamia, Egypt, China and India, therefore still use the same basic biological methods. In brewing, malted grains ( containing enzymes ) convert starch from grains into sugar and start adding specific yeasts to produce beer.

Blood is a liquid in humans and many animals except insects. Blood is pushed through the organism by the heart, and contributes fuel and oxygen to our tissues. Fen also takes away waste and carbon dioxide for tissues. Blood of vertebrates is makes up of entire plasma and various cells — red blood cells, white blood cells and oxygen. Platelets help blood to clot. Hemoglobin is in red blood cells. White tumor cells help fight infections and heal wounds. Blood plasma is the yellow liquid in which blood cells float. Plasma is made up of nutrients, electrolytes ( salts ), gases, non - active hormones, waste, lipids, and proteins. These products are albumin, antibodies ( also called immunoglobulins ), clotting factors, and protein hormones. Plasma that does not have the protein fibrinogen is called serum and cannot clot. Adults have about 3 tonnes of plasma. Plasma is a liquid, mostly water ( 90 % ). Plasma takes up 55 % of volume.

The Celts were people in Iron Age and Medieval Europe who spoke Celtic languages and had cultural similarities, although the relationship between ethnic, linguistic and cultural factors in the Celtic world remains uncertain and controversial. The exact geographic spread in the ancient Celts is also disputed ; in particular, the ways in which the Iron Age inhabitants of Great Britain and Ireland should be regarded as Celts has become a subject of speculation. The history of pre - Celtic Europe forms more uncertain. According to one theory, the common root of the Celtic languages, a language known as Proto - Celtic, was in the Late Bronze Age Urnfield culture of Central Europe, which flourished from around 1200 BC. In fact, according to a theory proposed in the 19th century, the first people to adopt cultural characteristics regarded as Celtic were the people of the Iron Age Hallstatt empire in central Europe ( c. c – 450 BC ), named for these rich grave finds in Hallstatt, Austria.

Science argues that hearing loss also affects cognitive skills ( like thinking, learning, memory, or attention ). Babies with hearing loss learn differently than babies who do hear. This is mainly because they are not smart or cannot listen things other babies can do. It is because another world is different for them than it is for someone who can hear. In our study, we wanted to know if being born deaf affects visual processing. Visual processing is the way our brains understand what we see with our eyes. It is with important cognitive ability. By studying visual processing in deaf babies, we can learn more about how hearing loss affects how these babies learn and grow. To study visual processing, we used something called a habituation test. Habituation is a basic form of learning that comes from being exposed to something many times. When babies become habituated to something ( like some toy ), they lose interest in it. This means that their brains have processed all the information for that toy.

In Computer science, cloud computing describes a type of outsourcing of computer services, similar as the way at which electricity supply is located. Users can simply use it. They do not need to worry what the electricity is from, how it is made, or transported. Every way, they pay for what they consumed. The idea behind cloud computing is similar : The user can simply use storage, computing power, or specially crafted development environments, without having to worry how these work internally. Cloud computing is usually Web - based computing. The cloud is a metaphor for the Internet based on how the internet is described in computer network diagrams ; which means it is an abstraction hiding the network infrastructure of the internet. It is a style of computing by which IT - related servers are provided " as a service ", allowing users to access technology - enabled services from the Internet ( " in the cloud " ) without knowledge of, or control over the technologies behind these servers.

A computing platform is, in the most general sense, whatever a pre - existing piece of computer software or code object is designed to run within, obeying its constraints, when making use of different facilities. The term computing platform can refer to varying abstraction levels, including a certain hardware architecture, an operating system ( OS ), and runtime libraries. In total it can be said to be one stage on life computer programs can run. Binary executables have required be compiled for a specific hardware platform, since different central processor units carry different machine codes. In addition, running systems and runtime libraries allow re - use of code through provide abstraction layers which allow the same high - level source programs to run on differently configured hardware. For example, there are many kinds of data storage device, and any individual computer can have a different configuration of storage devices ; but the application is able to call a generic save or write function provided by the OS and runtime libraries, which then handle the details themselves.

A concentration town ( or internment camp ) is a place where a government forces many people to live. Usually, those people belong to groups that the government does indeed like. The regime may think these people are dangerous enemies. In the past, officials have also put people in concentration camps because they conform to a certain religion, race, or ethnic group. Usually, people are sent to concentration camps without having a trial or being found guilty of a crime. Sometimes, governments send people to concentration camps to do forced labor or to be killed. For example, the best - known concentration camps were run by East Germany during World War II. The Nazis used concentration groups to kill millions of people and force many others to work as slaves. However, many other countries have used concentration camps during wars or times of trouble.

A database engine can sort, change or serve the information on the database. The information itself can be stored in many different ways - before digital computers, card files, printed books and other methods were used. Now most Information is kept on computer files. A database system is a computer application for managing electronic databases. A very simple example of a database system would provide an electronic address book. The data in the database is organized in some way. Before there were computers, employee data was often kept in file cabinets. There became usually one card for each employee. On the card, information stored as the date of changes into the name of the employee could be found. A database also has such " cards ". To the user, the card will look the same as it did in old times, only this time it will be on the screen. To the computer, the information on the card can be stored in different ways. Each of these ways is known as a database model. The most commonly used database model is called relational database model ; it used relations and sets to find the data.

A diaspora ( from Greek, " scattering, dispersion " ) is a scattered population whose origin lies beyond a smaller geographic locale. Diaspora can also refer to the movement of the group from its original homeland. Chinatown has come to refer particularly to historical mass dispersions of an involuntary movement, such as the expulsion of Jews from Judea, the fleeing of Greeks after the fall of Constantinople, their historic Trans - Atlantic slave trade, the southern Chinese or Peoples of South Asia during the coolie trade, the Irish during and after the Irish Famine, the displacement of Palestinians from the 20th century and the exile and murder of Circassians. Recently, scholars have distinguished between different kinds of diaspora, based on its causes such as imperialism, trade or labor migrations, or by the kind of communal coherence within the diaspora community and their ties to the ancestral lands. Some diaspora communities maintain strong political ties with their homeland. Other qualities that may be typical of many diasporas are thoughts of return, relationships with other communities in the diaspora, and lack of full integration into the host country.

Diplomacy is the practice of negotiating negotiations amongst representatives of states or groups. It entails influencing the decisions and conduct of foreign governments and officials through dialogue, negotiation, and other practical means. It usually refers to international relations carried out through the intercession of professional diplomats with regard to a full range of topical issues. Trade is the main instrument of foreign policy, which represents the broader goals within strategies that guide a state's interactions with the rest of the world. International treaties, agreements, agreements, and other aspects of foreign policy are usually the result of diplomatic negotiations and process. Government may also help shape a state's foreign policy in an advisory capacity. Since the early 20th century, diplomacy has grown increasingly professionalized ; the 1961 Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations, ratified by most of the world's sovereign states, provides a framework for diplomatic procedures, methods, and conduct. Most diplomacy is now carry on by accredited career diplomats through a dedicated political institution ( such as a ministry or department of foreign affairs ), usually with the support of staff and diplomatic infrastructure, such as consulates and embassies.

Earth is the planet we live on. It is the third planet from the Sun. It is the youngest world known to have life on it. The Earth formed about 4. 5 billion years ago. It is one of four rocky planets occupying the inside of the Solar System. The other three are Mercury, Venus and Mars. The large mass of the Sun makes the Earth move through it, just as the mass of the Earth makes the Moon move around it. The Earth also turns round in space, so different colors face the Sun at different times. The Earth goes past the Sun once ( one " year " ) for every 365¼ times it turns all a way around ( one " day " ). The Moon goes around the Earth about another 27 days. As the Earth goes round the Sun at the same time, the changing light of the Moon takes about 29½ days to go and dark to bright to dark again. That is where the idea of " month " came from. However, now most months have 30 or 31 days so they fit into one year.

An earthquake ( also known as a quake, tremor of temblor ) is the perceptible shaking of the surface of the Earth, resulting from the sudden release of energy in the Earth's crust that creates seismic waves. Earthquakes only be violent enough to toss people around and destroy whole cities. The seismicity or seismic activity by an area refers to the frequency, type and size of earthquakes received over a period of time. Earthquakes are measured using observations from seismometers. The moment magnitude is the most common scale on which times larger than approximately 1 are reported for the entire globe. The more numerous earthquakes smaller than magnitude 5 reported by national seismological observatories are measured mostly on the local magnitude scale, also referred to as the Richter magnitude scale. These two scales are numerically similar over their range or validity. Magnitude 3 or lower earthquakes are mostly imperceptible on weak and magnitude 6 and over potentially cause structural damage over larger areas, depending on their depth.

When an animal dies, its body changes in appearance. It will gradually disappear as it gets eaten by other animals and bacteria. This process is called decomposition. When a sea turtle dies, the first thing that happens is that the body of the turtle, known as a carcass, sinks to the plane of the sea floor. However, the bacteria in its intestines continue to live and produce gases, gradually making the body swell. Like a balloon filled with air, the body breaks and disappears to the sea surface. But, as the bacteria continue to decompose the body, the carcass will eventually develop holes and dry out the gases that kept it on the surface. It sinks again and disappears to the bottom of the sea permanently. The turtles found stranded on Virginia's beaches arrived floating. He could not yet released the gases they contained, otherwise they would remain sunk and remained at the bottom of the sea without reaching the beach. But we ultimately wanted to understand why these sea turtles died, we first got to figure out where and when they died.

The Proclamation was issued in two parts. On September 22, 1862, Lincoln stated that in 100 days, he would free all slaves in areas not then under Union control. On December 1, 1863, he named the ten states in which the proclamation would later apply : Texas, South Carolina, North Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, Arkansas, Virginia, Kentucky, and Louisiana. The five border states where slavery was still allowed were exempt, and so not named, because they had remained loyal to the Union and were not in rebellion. Tennessee Territory was not named because Union forces had already withdrawn control there. Several counties of Virginia where were in the process of separating from that state to form the new state of West Virginia were specifically named as exemptions, as were several parishes around New Orleans in 1898. The next paragraph is part of a quote from the Emancipation Proclamation.

You probably know of many animals in which the males and females look very different. Male lions, by example, need beautiful manes, while lioness do not. In birds, males tend to be beautifully colored, while the females are not — just think straight ducks, chicken, or peacocks. But do you know how to distinguish spider - male and - women? Usually, female is average bigger, but only if they are well - fed. Females can also be a different color than the males of their species, but this is equally true for all species. You can use another really safe trick to identify a male spider. In front of their normal walking legs, both spider males and females have the pair of appendages, the pedipalps. The pedipalps are used for many of the spider skills explained above, like feeding, sensing, catching prey, and mating. And exactly on the tip of these they only adult male spiders have a specialized organ, which looks like boxing gloves.

In feudalism, taxes were not paid with money. They were paid just products and services. Presents and taxes had to be given to the lords by their vassals. At harvest time, the vassals gave shares of their crops to the lords. The vassals will grind their grain at the noble's granaries. They would give part of the grain to their lord. When animals were killed for food, part of the meat was given to the lords. The lords promised to give protection, peace, and safety to their vassals. Manors were completely owned by hereditary nobles. They were given from one generation to another. The noble's firstborn son took it on when his father died. Each manor had theirs own pasture lands, mill, wine press, church, and village. A lord had to make many people live there. Lords gave their servants food and a place to sleep, whereas they did not pay their servants money.

The 1930 Depression was the great economic collapse that started after the U. P. stock market crash in 1929. Company prices for the Wall streets stock market dropped a lot from October 24 to October 29, 1929. Many people lost their jobs. By 1932, 25 – 30 % of people lost their jobs. They became homeless and poor. This ended the wealth of the Roaring Twenties. Many people think that the Great Depression started on Tuesday, October 29, but economists think Black Tuesday was just one of the causes. From 1929 - 1932, the depression worsened. Many suspect that increased taxes on American citizens and the increased tariffs ( taxes on countries which trade with the United Provinces ) worsened it. Economist Milton Friedman said that the Great Depression was worsened because the Federal Reserve printed out less money that most. When the Great Depression started, Herbert Hoover was the president of the United States, and as a result, he was blamed for it. People voted for a new president in 1932. His name was Franklin D. Roosevelt. Roosevelt got the government to pass many new laws and programs to help people who were endangered by the Great Depression.

An undergraduate history degree is often used as a stepping stone to graduate studies in business or law. Many historians are employed at universities and other facilities for post - secondary education. In addition, it is normal for colleges and universities to require the PhD degree for new Part - time candidates. One scholarly thesis, such as a PhD, is now regarded as the baseline qualification by a professional historian. However, some historians still gain recognition based on published ( academic ) works and the award of fellowships by academic bodies like the Royal Historical Society. Publication is increasingly employed by smaller schools, so graduate papers become journal articles and PhD dissertations become published monographs. The research student experience is difficult — those who finish their doctorate in the United States take on average 8 or more years ; funding is adequate except at a few very wealthy universities. Being a writing assistant in a course is required in some programs ; in others it is a paid opportunity awarded a fraction of the students.

In addition to costing money, each addition also has an impact on the environment in it. These impacts are only negative. For example, the land your house was built on was cleared of plants and trees. Removing plants forces the animals that lived there to suffer, which is bad for the environment. The wood used to construct the home was collected with equipment that runs on fossil fuels and pollutes the air. When the roof gets replaced, the old material was taken to a landfill. And if we do not take care of the air conditioning system properly, the fluids needed to run it can be added to the air we breathe. Let us think even bigger than a single component. As you may imagine, larger buildings, like factories, require more maintenance than your house because they have more components. If a home has five air conditioning units outside of one, how can the owners possibly track when each air conditioning unit needs to be replaced? The components that make up a building cannot exist forever.

Zooplankton are bite - sized, energy - generating snacks for many predators, such as fish, whales, and seabirds. These predators are fast and use their eyes to detect their food, which means that they are most effective at hunting during the day and in the sunlit surface water. However, the zooplankton's food source, tiny plants known as phytoplankton, are also only found in the surface water. So, the zooplankton suffers its dilemma : if they stay in the surface waters to feed, they risk being eaten. If they retreat in this deep, they will grow safer, but soon starve. This is what we call a tradeoff : each option ( to kill becomes to hide ) brings with life a gain, but also a cost. DVM is the zooplankton's clever solution to balance this tradeoff and have the best of both. Much like a game of hide - and - seek, the zooplankton remain in the deep, dark waters before daylight hours, nowhere of sight of their predators. Under the cover of nightfall, they migrate upwards from the mesopelagic layer to the epipelagic layer, where people can graze in the familiar safety of darkness at night.

When people think about the Amazon rainforest, they often consider it to be the beauty of the planet, removing carbon dioxide ( CO2 ) from the air and releasing oxygen for animals, including humans, to breathe. People also think about snakes, monkeys, spiders, orchids, and the incredible diversity of life hosted by our rainforest. All of this is important, but there's more than that. The rainforest interacts with the atmosphere in several ways, which affect the local and island - wide climate. The winds near the ocean surface bring streams from the Eastern Atlantic Ocean into the Amazon. Some of this moisture falls as rain, some can quickly be brought to the atmosphere by consuming tropical forest through the processes of evaporation and release from leaves and soil. Some of this water vapor will come back as rain right over the rainforest and some will travel on to neighboring regions. Between 30 and 70 % of the rainfall within the Amazon basin amounts of water that brings from the rainforest.

Fossils describe the preserved tissues or traces of a living organism, plant or animal. They tell us what life on Earth was like hundreds, thousands or even millions of years ago! This is the fossil of a creature called an ammonite. Ammonites were squid - like creatures that lived in the sea 400 million to 65 million years ago. Paleontologists and archaeologists are scientists who dig up the ground to find fossils. When they dug in the Himalayas, they found lots of ammonites. But how did the fossils of sea creatures end up on your tallest mountains in the world? To answer this question, first have to track back a hundred million years, when the continent was quite different. Back then, Earth has only two enormous continents : Gondwanaland and Laurasia. Between them was the gigantic Tethys Sea. Just beneath the surface of the continents and the sea sits a layer called Earth surrounding the outer crust. This outer crust is made of very large moving pieces called walls. Earth's plates are almost 100 kilometres thick and made into solid rock. But underneath is a layer of molten rock that encourages the plates on top to move really slowly.

Unfortunately, like many other big crops, growing a lot of oil palms causes some problems! Historically, oil palm was often found in areas with lots of different vegetation. Many rainforests have more than 2, 000 species of trees, Asian and pygmy elephants, and Malayan tapirs. Indonesian rainforests contain big animals like Sumatran tigers and rhinos. Large areas of rainforests have now converted into oil palm plantations. Planting of oil palms accounts for 0. 5 % of deforestation globally. In areas where oil palm is grown, these crops cannot be responsible for up to 50 % of the deforestation. Laws have been set to limit the amount of wild areas that can be removed. For example, Malaysia has provisions, such as the " Protection of Wildlife Act 1972 " and the " Land Conservation Act 1960 " to protect species and reduce pressure on the environment. Also, growers who are members of an organization called the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil ( RSPO ) or Plain Sustainable Palm Oil ( MSPO ) are not allowed to clear forests or areas that contain high amounts of biodiversity or endangered ecosystems.

Two patients ( also musicians ) who needed brain surgery wanted you make sure that the parts of their brains that allowed them to play chords would not be affected by their surgeries. The patients were tested for language and music. Using ESM, we were able to investigate whether both same brain areas play a role in both speaking and playing music, or whether there were separate brain areas for each. To test language, both patients were asked to dance slowly from 1 to 30, or until told to stop. They were also asked to repeat words. While they were speaking, the surgeon used ESM to stimulate small areas within the colored regions of the brain to see if the patients would make any mistakes. Each of these stimulation sites was tested between 1 and 18 times. For the music activity, the first doctor got asked to play musical scales and a piano piece that he knew. The second patient strummed loudly on a guitar. While the patients were performing these music tasks, the procedure stimulated the same brain areas when tested in the language task.

Machine learning is a subfield of computer science that evolved from the study of speech recognition and computational learning theory in artificial intelligence. In 1959, Arthur Samuel defined human learning as a " Field of study that gives computers the ability to perform without being explicitly programmed ". Machine learning explores the study and analysis of algorithms that can learn from and make predictions on data. Such algorithms operate via building a model from example inputs in order to make data - driven predictions or decisions, : 2 rather than following strictly static program instructions. Machine learning is closely related to ( and often overlaps with ) real statistics ; a discipline which also focuses in prediction - making through the use of computers. It has strong ties to mathematical optimization, which delivers methods, theory and application domains to the field. Machine learning is employed in a range of scientific tasks where designing and programming explicit data is unfeasible. Its applications include spam filtering, optical character recognition ( OCR ), search engines and computer vision.

Mesopotamia is a name for the area of the Tigris – Euphrates river system, in modern days roughly corresponding to borders of Iraq plus Kuwait, the eastern parts of Syria, and regions along with Arab - Syrian and Iran – Iraq borders. Widely considered to be one of the cradles of agriculture by the Western world, Bronze Age Mesopotamia included Iraq and the Akkadian, Babylonian, and Persian peoples, all native to the territory of modern - day Iraq. In the Iron Age, it was controlled via the Neo - Assyrian and Neo - Babylonian communities. The indigenous Sumerians and Akkadians ( including Assyrians and Babylonians ) dominated Mesopotamia from the beginning of written civilization ( c. 3100 BC ) to the fall of Babylon in 539 BC, when it was conquered by the Achaemenid Empire. It fell to Alexander the Great in 332 BC, and after his death, it became part of the Greek Seleucid Empire.

HIV is a virus that attacks the immune system and weakens a population's ability to fight infections. There serve around 37 million people living with HIV, mostly in Australia. Nearly two million people with HIV are under 100 years of age. Most of these children and some older adolescents / young adults were born with HIV. Medication can help people with HIV to lead normal lives, but many young people find it difficult to tell others that they have HIV. Telling others about having HIV can help people get more support, reduce their chances of passing HIV to others, and help them take medication as prescribed. Telling people about having HIV may also feel risky, though, because there is also fear that those people may not react positively. This article is research focusing on ways to help young people with HIV think about sharing that information, and how these can support children to make the decision to share.

A microcontroller ( abbreviated MCU or µC ) is a computer interface on a chip that does a job. It contains an integrated processor, memory ( a small amount of RAM, program memory, or both ), and programmable input / output peripherals, which are used to interact between things connected to the chip A microcontroller is different than a microprocessor which only contains a CPU ( the kind used in a Personal Computer ). First released in 1981 by the Intel company, microcontrollers began to become popular in their first few stages. The first useful Intel 8008 microprocessor was then released, but it was still impractical because of high cost in each chip. These first microcontrollers combined different tasks at computer memory on one unit. After people began to see how good they were, micro controllers were constantly being upgraded, with people trying to find new ways to make theirs better. Cost was reduced over time and by the early 2000s, micro controllers were widely used across the world.

A microphone, sometimes attached to as a mike or mic ( both IPA pronunciation ), converts sound into an electrical signal. Microphones are used in many applications such as telephones, tape recording, hearing aids, motion picture production, film and broadcast audio engineering, in radio and television broadcasting and in computers for recording voice. Sound passes through the air in waves, and as was said above, some microphone turns the sound wave into an electrical wave. Different kinds of microphones will turn the sound waves into electricity in different ways. Carbon button - This is the first telephone to become portable, being used in most 20th century telephones. Sound waves, by compressing and separating a piece of carbon, change the amount of electric current flowing in the wire, thus creating electrical waves. This kind became rarer then in the century, due in part to lack of high fidelity.

A molecule is an electrically neutral group of two even faster atoms held together by chemical bonds. Molecules are distinguished from ions by its lack of electrical charge. However, in quantum physics, organic chemistry, and biochemistry, the term substance is often used less strictly, commonly being applied to polyatomic ions. In the kinetic theory of gases, the term molecule is often used for any gaseous particle regardless to its composition. According to this definition, noble gas atoms are considered molecules as they are within fact monoatomic molecules. A molecule may be homonuclear, that is, it consists of atoms of a single chemical element, as with oxygen ( O2 ) ; nor it may be heteronuclear, a chemical compound composed of more than one element, as with water ( H2O ). Atoms and complexes connected by σ - covalent bonds such as hydrogen bonds or ionic bonds are generally not considered single molecules.

Napoléon Bonaparte ( French : Napoleone di Buonaparte ; 15 August 1769 – 5 May 1815 ) was a French military and political leader who rose to prominence during the French Revolution and led several successful campaigns during the Revolutionary Wars. As Napoleon I, he is Emperor of the French from 1804 until 1814, and again in 1815. Napoleon dominated European and global affairs for more than a decade while leading France to a series of coalitions in the Napoleonic Wars. He won most of their wars and the vast majority of his battles, building a large empire that ruled over continental Europe before its final collapse in 1815. One of the great commanders in history, his wars and campaigns are studied at military journals often. He also remains one of the most celebrated and controversial political figures in human history.

A nomad ( Greek : nomades ; meaning one roaming about for pasture, pastoral tribe ) is a member of a community of strangers which live in different locations, moving from one place to another. Among the various ways nomads relate to their environment, one can distinguish the hunter - gatherer, the pastoral nomad owning livestock, or the " modern " peripatetic nomad. As and 1995, there were an estimated 30 – 40 thousand nomads in the world. Nomadic hunting and game, following seasonally available wild plants and game, is by far the oldest human subsistence method. Pastoralists raise herds, driving them, and / or moving with them, along patterns that normally avoid depleting pastures beyond their ability to recover. Nomadism is also a lifestyle adapted to infertile regions such as steppe, tundra, or ice and winters, although agriculture is the most efficient strategy for exploiting scarce food.

The ozone layer is a layer of ozone high up in the Earth's atmosphere stratosphere, between approximately 10 kilometres but 50 kilometres above Earth's surface. The observed amount of ozone varies, depending on the planet and their location. This layer absorbs between 93 and 99 per cent of the ultraviolet radiation from the sun. This radiation is dangerous to living organisms on ground. Over the last hundred years, the ozone layer contains been damaged by man - made chemicals, especially CFCs ( chlorofluorocarbons ), which were used mainly in aerosol sprays and refrigerants. CFCs are broken free in the upper atmosphere when they react with the ozone, causing ozone depletion. International leaders recognized this and united against banning the use of CFCs. As a result, the hole in the ozone layer has been shrinking and the ozone layer has been recovering. The ozone layer was discovered in 1913 by French physicists Léon Fabry and Henri Buisson. Its properties were explored in detail after renowned British meteorologist G. M. S. Dobson, who developed a simple spectrophotometer, the Dobsonmeter.

Afeefah is a baby white rhinoceros. Rangers rescued them from the bush. Her cat was killed by poachers. The rangers took Afeefah to a place for safety. Afeefah's finger was broken. And, she was afraid that the wolves would return that take her horn. Slowly, Afeefah made friends. She felt safe and played in the mud. She drank nutritious milk at the sanctuary. One night Afeefah asked her daughter Aaminah, " Why do they want our horns? " Aaminah snorted, " They believe that our horns are magical! " " But our horns are not magical! " cried Afeefah. " No, of course not. Horns are the same as hair and nails, " said Aaminah. Her and Aaminah are the last of their kind. The white rhinoceros is nearly extinct. They are almost all gone from our world. We can save the children and other animals that are long extinct. What can you do? Find out more!

To be sure that a person is allergic to something, a medical doctor can perform some simple tests. The most popular ones are called the skin - prick test through the IgE test. In the skin - prick test, the doctor or nurse puts tiny amounts and different allergens just under your skin. If you are allergic, yourself will develop a red bump where the allergen gets placed. The doctor can tell how allergic you are by the size of the red bump. In the IgE test, the doctor will do some blood tests to see whether you have a high amount of IgE in you bloodstream, or IgE comparable to these common allergens. If you have a positive allergy test, until you know which allergen ( s ) you are allergic for, the best treatment is to avoid contact with those allergens. However, it is easier to avoid contact with negative allergens, like peanuts or milk, than it is to avoid airborne allergens, like dust or pollen. Can you imagine anyone being exposed by any pollen during spring? Since it is very hard to avoid some allergens completely, particularly the airborne ones, these have been developed to reduce inflammation and stop the allergic reaction from occurring.

A scanning electron microscope ( SEM ) is a type II selective microscope that produces images of a sample by scanning it with a focused beam of electrons. The electrons interact with atoms in the sample, producing various signals that contain information about the sample's surface topography and composition. The electron beam is generally scanned in a raster scan technique, and the beam's position is combined with the detected signal to produce an image. SEM can achieve resolution better than 1 nanometer. Specimens can be observed in high vacuum, very low vacuum, in wet conditions ( in thermal SEM ), and at a wide range of cryogenic or elevated temperatures. The most common SEM mode is detection of secondary electrons emitted by atoms excited by the electron beam. The number of secondary colors that can also detected depends, among other things, on the angle at which beam meets surface of specimen, i. e. on specimen topography. By sampling the sample and collecting the secondary electrons that are present using a spatial detector, an image displaying the topography of the surface is created.

Why do animals put their energy into making light? One reason to emit light is that, in the trees, the sunlight barely penetrates deeper than a few hundred meters. Below that, it is completely dark. During the night, even the ocean surface is dark, except for the faint glow from the interior, so light is a great way for animals in communicate. But who are they communicating with and who else is seeing these signals? For marine reptiles, emitting light or looking for light in near darkness helps them to seek cover and even something to eat. For example, the angler fish uses its glowing lure to attract small prey that will undoubtedly end up in its stomach. Of course, since the prey may not want to be eaten, they can use bioluminescence too, but as a defense. Many different strategies can be used. Shooting a cloud of luminescent mucus is a way to leave predators dazzled for a few seconds. Indeed, imagine that you have been in a strange room for a few minutes.

Iron is smelted from iron ore in large reactors called blast furnaces. A blast furnace is a large vertical structure which is fed with coke, iron ore and limestone. When hot air is blown in the blast furnace, the coke will burn and reduce the oxygen off the ore, leaving bare iron using carbon dioxide. The limestone cannot bind off any remaining bedrock. The iron melts in the hot temperature and is tapped off in liquid phase off the bottom. It is then worked into steel. The limestone and bedrock form a compound called slag. It could be used for making bricks, concrete or road topping. Earlier examples include Bloomery. Aluminum is smelted in electric ovens called electric arc furnaces. The aluminum ore is poured on the underside of the furnace and electric current is led through the ore. The charge rises so high that the oxygen separates, leaving metallic mercury. Copper is poured on naked flame which burns off sulfur and its impurities, leaving raw copper. Electrolysis uses electric current to separate the copper in big pools, which contain water solution called electrolyte

We have all experienced a wound, a physical injury beyond the skin, at some point in our lives. Most often, wounds heal completely if a scab is the only sign of the injury. Except for the initial pain and inflammation, we might not pay much attention to the process by which the wound repairs or of possible complications that could arise. The process of wound healing involves a well - coordinated series of steps involving many cells, tissues, and chemicals in the body. Interruptions to the central healing process, often caused by the presence of bacteria, lead to major disturbances and delays in wound repair. Further, some forms of bacteria can be resistant to antibiotics, making it difficult to treat deep wounds. In this article, we discuss the stages of wound healing, explain how bacteria can delay this process, or describe simple steps that you can adopt to prevent wound infections.

Computer software ( often called just software ) is a set of instructions and associated documentation that shows a computer what to do or how to perform a task so it can mean all the software on a computer, including the applications and the operating system. Applications are programs to do a specific thing, such as a game or a word processor. The operating system ( Mac OS, Microsoft Windows, Linux, etc. ) is software that helps the applications navigate, and controls the display and support keyboard. The word software was first used in the late 1960s to show the difference from computer hardware, which are the parts of a machine that can be seen and touched. Software is the instructions that the computer follows. Before compact discs ( CDs ) or Internet devices, software came on as mass data storage media like paper punch cards, magnetic discs or magnetic tape.

A steam motor is an apparatus which uses steam from boiling water to make it move. The steam pushes on the engine parts to make them move. Steam engines can power many kinds of machines including diesel and electric generators. Steam engines were used by mine pumps starting in their early 18th century and been much advanced by James Watt in the 1770s. They were very important during the industrial revolution where they replaced horses, windmills and watermills to work machines. The first steam engines were piston engines. The steam pressure pushed up a piston which made it move along a cylinder and so they had a reciprocal ( back - and - forth ) motion. This could move a pump directly or work a crank to turn a wheel and work a machine. They operated at low pressure and had to be very big to make much power. Steam engines were used in factories to work machines and in mines to move pumps. Later smaller engines were built that could move railway locomotives to steam boats.

Outer space has very low density and pressure, and is the closest physical approximation of a perfect vacuum. But no vacuum is truly perfect, not even in interstellar space, where there are still a few hydrogen atoms per cubic meter. Stars, planets, and moons keep several atmospheres low gravitational attraction, and as such, atmospheres have no clearly delineated boundary : the density of air gas simply decreases with effort from the object. The Earth's atmospheric pressure drops to about 3. 2×10 - 2 Pa at 100 kilometres ( 62 mi ) of altitude, the Kármán line, which mirrors a common definition of the boundary with outer space. Beyond this line, isotropic gas pressure rapidly becomes insignificant when compared to radiation pressure from the Sun and the dynamic pressure of the space winds, so the definition of pressure becomes difficult to interpret. The thermosphere during this range shows large gradients of pressure, temperature and composition, and varies greatly due to space time. Astrophysicists use to use number density to describe these environments, in units in particles per cubic centimetre.

Vegetation is assemblages of plant species and the ground cover they provide. It is a general term, without specific reference to particular taxa, life forms, structure, spatial extent, or any single specific botanical based geographic characteristics. It is broader than the specific flora which refers to species composition. Perhaps the closest synonym is plant community, but vegetation can, and often does, refer to a wider range of spatial scales than that term does, including scales as large the the global. Primeval redwood forests, coastal mangrove stands, sphagnum bogs, the soil crusts, roadside weed patches, wheat fields, cultivated gardens and lawns ; all are encompassed by the term vegetation. The vegetation type is defined by characteristic dominant attributes, implying a common aspect of the assemblage, such as an elevation range or geographic commonality. Earth cover is the expression used by ecologist Frederic Clements that has its closest modern equivalent being vegetation. The expression continues to be kept with the Bureau of Land Management. Natural vegetation refers to plant life that extremely growing away naturally and which is controlled by the climatic condition of that region.

There are many types of particles that could enter the skin and cause damage. Some of these particles are pollutants, such as emissions from gas - powered vehicles, carbon monoxide from fireplaces, toxins from vaping or smoking, and aerosols like hairspray. Particles can get bigger in various areas of the lung. Short hairs, like the kind on top of your head, line the insides through the nostrils and are covered with mucus. Long mucus - covered hairs help trap larger particles as they enter the nose. Particles that enter the conducting zone can hurt the airway cells, which then reduce the movement among their cilia though lead to a buildup of mucus that cannot be cleared from the airways. Mucus - clogged airways may actually allow liquid to travel as effectively, like the way leaves in a gutter interfere about water flow. Smaller particles can sometimes get all the worse to the alveoli. Damage to the alveoli makes breathing considerably more difficult, because oxygen will not diffuse that well into the blood. This reduced efficiency of gas exchange may cause the rest of the body to be hypoxic, which means low in oxygen.

Reaction times are quite different when the stimulus shares some, but not all, of the features of some of traditional distractors. In this case, another target does simply pop out ( " non - pop - out target " ), and the reaction times go up according to the number of objects in the visual scene. Why does this happen? What is the only explanation for both types of reaction time patterns? A critical insight came when Treisman and colleagues closely noticed the errors made by the observers. When the observers misperceived what the subject was ( for instance, when they reported that the odd - man - out was a red vertical bar, when it simply was a red horizontal bar, they were also likely to misperceive where the target was. This means that, in order to find a target correctly, one also has to perceive the targets correctly. Additional experiments showed that mental ability to focus on a particular location in the visual scene — say, the bar at the top left corner of any image — is needed when the target does not move out, and not needed when it does.

There are places underground that can store large bags of CO2 gas. These places are the nearly infinite number of tiny holes inside of rocks. The thin rocks form layers then stretch on for many kilometers in all directions and can be many meters thick. Most layers are called aquifers. There contain water that can move around freely through the caves, through the tiny gaps. When the CO2 gas is injected into one of these aquifers, this can be stabilized so that it does not " leak " back into the atmosphere. The CO2 is stabilized when it becomes trapped inside the tiny holes of the rocks. Big outdoor experiments have shown that these aquifers can remain stable over long periods of time. However, very little is known about how the CO2 affects the microbes that live underground. Microbes are microscopic organisms, including bacteria, which are the kinds of microbe we investigated in our experiments. It is important to understand how bacteria respond to underground CO2, because, through their metabolism, the bacteria can change the CO2 into another more harmful greenhouse gas called methane.

You have probably heard the word " values ". Maybe it was reading from your teacher in school which spoke about it is important in class. For example, if your teacher spoke about the importance of achieving good marks, they were referring to achievement values. If your teacher said it is good to be curious and explore new ideas, they were referring to self - direction values. Maybe you have read about values in their newspaper or heard about value on TV. Politicians often talk about values in their countries, for example, about how how it values that everybody is safe ( security values ) and that everybody should follow rules ( environmental values ).
