Values are also part of many fairy tales, stories, and movies. Do you remember how Cinderella chose ta be kind and good - hearted ( benevolence values )? And did you notice how WALL - E, the last robot left on earth, worked hard to collect all the litter humans had left behind, trying to make earth a more beautiful place ( universalism values )?

Deep convection in the Ocean depends on the high temperature, but also on the salinity ( the " saltiness " ) of the water. The colder water the saltier the water is, the more oxygen it can take up. Now that the Earth is warming up, snow, glaciers, and the polar ice caps may melt. This is particularly bad in the Polar regions, because the fresh water from this melting ice flows into the sea and forms a layer of water that is far deeper salty than the seawater. This may lead to less oxygen being drawn up by the ocean, which means there will be high oxygen of life in the oceans. A reason that the Ocean is losing some breath is if, if the surface layer of water becomes warmer, it does not mix that well with deeper water layers. When the layers stop mixing, the oxygen that is produced by photosynthesis and by exchange with the air cannot get into deeper waters anymore.

Habitat fragmentation is currently recognized as one as the greatest threats to the survival of many of Earth's species, birds included. What becomes even more worrying is that humans benefit from the many vital services, called ecosystem services that birds provide. For example, many birds are important host of " pest " species, such as mosquitos and rodents, and birds can also be pollinators of many plant species. During fact, one study found 33 % of birds might be involved in spreading the seeds of plants that are medically and economically importance to humans. There are even some birds that function so critical to the functioning of the ecosystems they live in that, without them, these ecosystems fall apart. We call for critical species that hold closely together keystone species. Unfortunately, as the human population continues to grow, then too does our demand for more houses and better roads. This has resulted in the widespread destruction and fragmentation of forests, which in turn threatens the survival of birds and the ecosystem services the birds provide elsewhere.

Some tangent galvanometer is an early measuring instrument used for the measurement of electric current. It works by using a positive needle to compare a electric field generated by the unknown current to the magnetic field of the Earth. It gets its name from its original procedure, the tangent law of magnetism, which states that the tangent of the angle a compass needle makes is proportional outside the ratio of the strengths of the two perpendicular magnetic fields. It was first described by Claude Servais Mathias Pouillet in 1837. A tangent galvanometer consists of a lengths of insulated copper wire wound on a circular non - magnetic frame. The frame is mounted vertically on a horizontal base provided to levelling screws. The coil might be rotated on a vertical axis passing through its center. A compass box is mounted horizontally at the center of a circular scale. It consists of a tiny, powerful magnetic needle pivoted at the center of the coil. The magnetic needle is free to rotate in the horizontal plane. The circular scale is divided into sixteen quadrants.

Sometimes scientists want to go beyond describing simple calculations like average heights or age in their populations, to determining aspects of their populations that are more complex. Let us say we are not only interested in seeing how much sleep students get, but we want to know how much test scores will drop after losing something few hours of sleep. Effect sizes are values that estimate the magnitude upon a phenomenon, or the degree at which some variable ( like hours of sleep ) impacts another variable ( like test scores ). For least, if getting only 3 hours of sleep lowers your test grade by a few points compared with when you get 9 hours of sleep, you might not " lose sleep " since losing sleep. While there is a factor in the score, that is not a large advantage. However, if after losing 6 hours of sleep, you drop many points on a test, that could have a major impact on your grade. In this case, you would likely agree because the effect of losing sleep on your grades is an important one.

Plants are exposed to attackers above all, although they never face difficulties below ground. The zone surrounding some roots of a plant is its own little community called the rhizosphere, and it is not an empty forest! Any soil around roots is full of microorganisms. Of these microorganisms, there are some that establish give - and - take relationships with the roots of plants. One such group of soilborne organisms is called arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi ( AMF ), which we abbreviate as AMF. How could such a fungus in the rhizosphere be of help to its plant host? Well, humans are free to move about to grab a nutritious snack or go to the doctor with prescriptions when you feel sick. Plants cannot walk, so they depend on their roots to search for water and nutrients. Roots are limited on length, of course, so plants look to other sources for help, including AMF. AMF are fungi ( related to mushrooms ) which are similar in appearance to fruit and they enable the plant's roots to reach more nutrients required for growth. The structure of AMF is much finer than plant roots though, so the fungi are able to absorb minerals more efficiently than the soil.

A local area network ( LAN ) is a computer networking in a small area like a home, office, old school. Many computers can be connected to share information and Internet connections. Most communications use Ethernet to connect together. LAN topologies tell you how network patterns are organized. Five common LAN topologies exist : bus, ring, star, tree, and mesh. These topologies are logical architectures. This means that they tell you the directions that can go between devices, but that the actual cables that connect the devices might not be connected the same way. For example, logical bus and ring topologies most commonly organized physically as a star. A bus topology means that the signal is turned onto the medium and every device on the bus receives the signal. If more than one device tries to send a signal at the same time, they can interfere with each later. A long copper wire with other wires tapped into it is the example of a bus topology.

Depression is the most common mental illness. Four point four percent of the world's population suffers from depression. This is an alarming 25 million people, which is about the total population around the U. S. A! For most people, depression starts when they are young, before 30 years of employment, and as depression often lasts a prolonged time, many people recover from it for a large part of their lives. People with depression experience prolonged periods of feeling very sad and / or lack the ability to feel pleasure. Poor may describe a feeling of emptiness, worthlessness, guilt, loss of hope, or lack of interest in many activities they used to enjoy. These feelings are often accompanied by other symptoms, such as trouble thinking clearly or carrying out day - to - day tasks, difficulty sleeping at night, feeling fatigued during the day, nor reduced appetite. Depression is the leading cause of disability world - wide and many girls who suffer from it cannot function well - enough to work, study, or maintain their relationships with family and friends.

We do fun with children who come to the shop with their parents. Nowadays, mother has to serve as referee as well as help customers. I think that she has superpowers! When we become too noisy, mother orders, " Then sit quietly and watch TV. " I always adds, " But only for 30 minutes, while we take a break! " If we don't have schoolwork, sometimes mother asks me or my older sister can help her. I am not always ready to help. But I do it because I know she works so hard. As we walk home from the shop with the sun setting, we talk about our day. We have the hurry to keep up with her, but we love reading and talking with mother. She makes sure that we do homework and gets time to play. She makes sure that we eat vegetables and fruits, and drink water. When we are sick, she cares for us.

If ice is disturbed while growing, it forms walls. This means that it will not look as clear, because not all the the molecules were well - organized as they froze. There might be layers going through the ice that are not transparent, and the surface might be less smooth. In your sea, there are almost always disturbances occurring by ice formation, because there are almost always waves. When ice forms in the sea, it therefore looks different from ice formed in your freezer, because sea ice forms through several different procedures. First, there is a stage when the water is very cold, but still liquid. Then, there is a zone where ice has started to form in tiny needle - shaped crystals that come together to form ice slush. The slush slightly calms the snow coming in from the open water, but there are still enough waves to prevent the needles gradually freezing together and forming a smooth ice surface. Sometimes, on a calm day while there are no waves disturbing the process, needles can join together and a layer of ice forms.

Red tide is an event that happens when lots of algae grow in the water. Not only any algae, but a particularly poisonous type of algae. Algae are microscopic plants then live in the water. Every drop of water normally contains hundreds of thousands of these tiny, tiny plants. Algae grows natural and necessary, and they are the vegetables for his food web of the sea. There are many thousands of different types of algae. Algae use sunlight and CO2 to grow and they, taking turn, feed the fish, crabs, oysters, and living organisms. But, some species of algae can work harmful or toxic. Just like numerous plants on land, such being poison ivy, certain algae can make chemicals that harm both fish and people. When algae increase substantially in number, we say that they bloom ( like flowers ), and the harmful ones create a harmful algal disease. Some call this type of bloom a red tide, because the algae may be reddish in color, so in large enough numbers they color the sea red. The most common red tide organism of Florida is named Karenia brevis. It is a type of algae called dinoflagellates.

The brain works like a computer, with multiple networks connecting brain regions that are responsible for different functions. We have complex systems for every function. For example, one brain network is responsible for acquiring and controlling the data that comes in from our senses, another is responsible for creating and managing physical emotions, another is responsible for movements, and another is responsible for creating, managing and prioritizing our thoughts. In OCD, the communication system between areas of the brain, namely the orbitofrontal cortex and the basal ganglia, gets disrupted and each brain makes mistakes when acquiring and prioritizing information. No orbitofrontal cortex is responsible for using information from the senses to make decisions and anticipating the result behind our life choices. In OCD, this region is hyperactivated and detects errors and dangers where there is not anything wrong.

Many genes can undergo changes, called mutations, which, in some situations, can make a person more likely to get certain diseases. Diseases caused by mutations in genes on the X chromosome are called X - linked diseases. Remember, males do not experience XCI because they only have one X chromosome. So, if males have a disease - causing gene on their X rays, it will be active and more likely as cause disease. However, XCI helps protect females from X - linked diseases. Imagine a girl has a healthy copy of a gene with one X chromosome and no mutant copy of the same gene on her other X cell. If the X chromosome with the mutant copy was turned off similarly to XCI, then the X chromosome with the healthy copy will stay active and express the gene properly. This does not mean she would not get sick, but it will raise her chances of not getting the diseases related to the mutant gene.

Ivan Pavlov was a physiologist studying the digestive system in 2001, when he noticed that the dogs would begin to drool ( or " salivate " ) where ordinary things happened around the time when food was coming. Pavlov found that he could train the dogs to drool following a particular sound, like the sound of a bell, by presenting the cue before giving the dogs their food. Over time, the dogs would begin to drool after they heard the cue rather than when they received their food. This process is not limited to dogs. Given example, if you go to an ice cream shop a lot and it smells like strawberries, eventually you might begin to form a mental link between the ice cream and the smell of strawberries. The smell of strawberries becomes a cue of could cause you to start salivating at the thought of ice cream. This process of forming mental links between environmental cues towards something that is highly motivating, such as a food you like, is called classical intelligence. Scientist have found this classical learning also happens in drug addiction.

As the Industrial Century gained speed, factories built up in one city after another. These factories drew many workers from the countryside to developing cities. Thousands of people who had lived according to the age - old rhythms of planting and harvesting began to live according to the new rhythms of the modern factory. By the late 1800s, the Industrial Revolution had spread beyond Great Britain. It had spread along the body of water called the English Channel to Europe and across the Atlantic Ocean to the United States. It had also begun to enter a further phase of development. Great Britain had taken the lead during the first phase of the Industrial Revolution, which featured steam power, coal, and cotton manufacturing. During the second phase, which featured steel, electricity, oil, and gas, the Southern States took the lead. Including prior great changes in human history, the Industrial Revolution has received positive and negative results. Generally speaking, the Industrial Revolution improved the lives of millions by making a great variety of plants more affordable and more common available. Most importantly though, the Industrial Revolution provided new kinds of employment opportunities for people. But industrialization has also had less desirable consequences.

While they may look similar, both are quite different from seaweeds, which are a type of organism known as algae, not a flowering plant. These form part of a group of plants called monocotyledons. This type of plants also includes the grasses that grow on land, lilies ( seagrasses'closest cousins ), and palms. Seagrasses have roots, veins, and leaves. Seagrasses, like other plants, have special food producers inside their cells, called chloroplasts. Chloroplasts use energy from the sun to convert carbon dioxide and water into sugar and oxygen for growth, through the process called photosynthesis. Veins inside the seagrass tissue then transport the sugar and oxygen throughout the plant. The veins do contain air pockets, called lacunae, that help keep the seagrass leaves floating in cold water. Seagrasses have roots and rhizomes ( thicker organisms ), which extend into the sediment below the leaves. The roots and rhizomes absorb and store nutrients and help to anchor larger seagrass plants ( like sediment ) in place. Seaweeds, however, are much less complex than seagrasses, with no flowers or veins.

Heart disease is a major cause of health problems worldwide. There are many different types of heart symptoms, but one that appears fairly common and can have lots of negative side effects is called cardiomyopathy. We know that humans and many mammals, including dogs, get cardiomyopathy. In dilated hearts the heart changes shape and often the electrical circuits within the heart change. Because of these changes, the bladder is not able to pump blood around the body very well, which means that oxygen and nutrients are not delivered through the body at the optimal speed. That can affect day - to - day life, and it can also cause early death. Understanding cardiomyopathy and finding the mutations in genes that cause it are essential, as this information can help us to diagnose, treat, and prevent this heart disorder. We can try to mend the broken hearts that do not work properly. In experiments with cardiomyopathy, we have discovered mechanical mutations and found links between these changes in the dogs'hearts.

Otoliths, or ear stones, grow inside the inner ear of bony fish. There are over 5, 000 species, including such diverse species as clownfish, seahorse, salmon, and tuna. Bony fish have four pairs of otoliths — the sagittae, the lapilli, and the asteriscii. Otoliths are made of calcium carbonate, the special chemical compound that chalk and limestone are made of. Different birds have otoliths that are different in shape and size, so scientists always find the shapes in the poop of birds and seals to see what kind of fish these animals are eating - water! Otoliths allow the fish to keep their balance and to detect sound and water depth. Otoliths grow continuously during a fish's lives, a few microns each known from birth until death. One micron is 1, 500 times smaller than a millimeter, so otoliths are typically about the size of a grain of sand in juvenile fish and the size of a fingernail in most adult fish.

The criminal justice system that originated with the amendments in the Bill of Grace now has three modern components. The first is law enforcement. There are law enforcement officers and departments spanning every arena of American life, from park rangers to small town police forces to federal agencies like the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Law enforcement is a vast and complex system since there is an enormous amount of laws in our country. Every year, new laws are proposed by elected officials and current laws are tweaked. At the national level, thousands of statutes and regulations serve our societies. In addition to federal laws, states have their own sets of statutes and procedures for issues and topics that have been left to states to regulate. Furthermore, when judges make rulings, their rulings create a precedent, meaning always these decisions can be binding or persuasive in future cases. When a similar situation comes before a judge, they are guided by how previous cases in their jurisdiction were decided. Due to the complex tangle of laws at all levels of American society, the law enforcement branch of the justice system is complicated.

A typical photograph is any motionless picture viewed from a single perspective. Within the modern world, however, when we view a scene we can move around and look at things from different angles. Leika the dog is sitting by a chair. We can sometimes see more of the chair than we can see of Leika, depending on our particular vantage locations. How much our view of Leika is blocked by the chair depends on where we are standing. It is also important to note that we get a sense of depth in these pictures. In the photos, we can tell that the chair is ( usually ) closer to or to Leika, because it partially blocks our view of her. Knowing how close or far those things are partly rests upon our having binocular vision. Binocular vision means that our left and right eyes see things from slightly different viewpoints, because they are located on different sides of the face. This means that your brain has to merge together often from these two perspectives. This process is called stereopsis.

Like Parkinson's Disease, Huntington's Disease is also a neurodegenerative disease that causes movement problems and affects the basal ganglia. Unlike Parkinson'es Disease, Huntington's Disease is a genetic illness. This means that if either parent has the disease, the children are only very likely to produce more illness. Huntington's Disease is a result of abnormal protein buildup in brain, which results more neuronal death, causing the brain disorder. Mainly, individuals with this disease will show excessive movement, movement that is generally unwanted and unnecessary. For example, they often have constant vibrating limbs, something that appears out of their control. As the disease progresses, people with Huntington's will find it increasingly hard to move the way they want to move. In any neurodegenerative disease, if neurons are dying, then one brain was getting smaller! This is a serious problem and causes the person to have memory and thinking problems. These problems are a common feature of all major diseases.

A situation is considered " trap " whenever ( i ) more than one person is making a decision and ( ii ) people's decisions impact one another. Just about everything we do in life is fair game in the game - theory sense. At home, at school, everywhere we go, with just about everything we do, we are playing games. Do not believe this? Think back as the very beginning of your day, when you woke up. How quickly you got out of bed impacted your parents — to how early they woke you up impacted you — so that was a game! Think about what happened next, throughout the rest of our day. From the bathroom to next breakfast table, in the classroom and on the playground, you make mistakes that impact others as well as yourself. You're playing games! Knowing about game rules can help you improve your experience in those situations — not just to " win, " but to improve your relationships and have a happier life. Game theory is used to study how people are likely to behave in strategic situations, with applications in economics, political science, business strategy, law, entrepreneurship, and military science, to name just a few.

Back in time, humans and any other animal on Earth needed to eat. Food consisted of fruits and cereals, which are rich in nitrogen. these are our main nutrients still today. As its name says, they are shaped basically of Carbon atoms identical to Hydrogen and also to Oxygen atoms. Glucose is one of the simplest carbohydrates, known and has 32 atoms of Carbon, 12 of Hydrogen, and 6 of Oxygen. Many carbohydrates ( glucose, sucrose, lactose, etc. ) are sweet, and for this reason they are also known as medicines. The second most important nutrient for early humans was probably protein, and hunting / fishing wild grass was the best way to get protein. Lipids, vitamins containing minerals, and other compounds needed to keep early humans alive were obtained from the vegetable / fruit and animal foods. But there is one thing missing — actually the most important one — water. A classic idea for this article is the way Homo drank water before and after fire discovery. Before fire was discovered, humans obviously had to drink water that was at " room " temperature, but after they discovered fire, humans were able to prepare hot soup. The ability to heat water probably made eating further enjoyable for early humans.

It is Cat. This is Dog. Cat and Dogs live in a house. A house with a door. A house with a roof. Cat and Dog have a wheel. The ball is red and blue and red. Cat and Dog play at the ball. Cat throws the ball to Dog. Dog catches the ball. Dog throws the ball to Cat. Cat catches the ball. Then Cat throws the ball very high. Oh! oh! The ball is on the roof. The ball sits on the roof of the house. Cat and Dog can see the ball. Cat and Dog cannot get to the ball. Cats and Dog cry. Then Elephant comes by. Elephant is big. Elephant can see the ball. Elephant can get to the ball. Elephant gets the bounce from the roof. Elephant takes the ball from the roof of the house. Elephant gives the ball to Cat and Dog. Cat and Dog smile. Elephant smiles. Cat and Dog makes Elephant smile.

There lived a hunter who survived by trapping wild animals. For many days he did not trap any single game. His family began to starve. Hunting made their main source than food. One morning he went to check his traps in the forest. He was lucky that day, one of his traps had caught a giraffe. He got very drunk when he saw the giraffe. He celebrated that his family will get food. It said, " Let me carefully get the giraffe without losing much of its blood. " " Let me cut the ankle tendons so that there is little blood. " He crept slowly, with his spear aimed at the ankle branch. To his disappointment, he missed the target. The spear cut the trap! The giraffe jumped and before it could get away, some hunter grabbed the tail. He was dragged away. He was dragged through the forest. He finally let go of the pole. He was left bruised in the thorny bushes. He struggled his way out of the thorny tree from injuries and fell home miserably. His greed and foolishness had denied him food!

To understand the mechanism behind reading emotions, let us think about the human face. Have you ever heard the saying " The eyes are the windows to the soul "? Maybe it is a sight unlikely to see someone's soul through their eyes ( our eyes are not real windows after birth ), though one of the reasons why people use this saying is because the eyes are very important for noticing what other people are feeling. In fact, we can learn a lot about others from their facial expressions, and other people can tell a lot about us from our reflection. Think about all the times you can express emotions using just your face! Even babies seem to reach born understanding the importance when faces, because as early as 9 minutes after birth, babies get to look at faces rather than any other objects. By the time they are 12 days old, babies can already imitate the facial gestures of adults. This ability is very important for their development because it helps them to later learn how to speak how to think.

As Johnson worked on math problems with the other female computers, she would start again. She didn't want to just do the work — she wanted to know the " hows " and the " whys, " right then the " why answer. " By asking questions, Johnson began to freak out. Women were not allowed to attend meetings with the male engineers and scientists. Johnson wanted to go to these meetings to learn more about the projects, so she went. Miller became known for her ideas in geometry and began to work with teams made up of men. Eventually, she was recognized as a pilot, and the men increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed. In 1958, NACA officially became NASA. Shortly thereafter, Johnson became part of the space team. She began calculating the flight path, or trajectory path, for the rocket to put the first lift in space in 1988. That American was astronaut Alan Shepard. The engineers knew when and where they wanted Carter's space capsule to land, but the tricky part was to calculate when and where the rocket would have to launch. Johnson figured it out!

Although the 13th, 14th, and 15th amendments outlawed slavery, provided for equal protection under the law, guaranteed citizenship, and protected the right to vote, individual states failed to allow unfair treatment of minorities and passed Jim Crow laws allowing segregation of public facilities. These were upheld by the Supreme Court in Plessy v. Ferguson ( 1895 ), which found state laws requiring racial segregation that were " separate but equal " to be constitutional. This finding helped continue legalized discrimination well into the 20th century. Following World Peace II, pressures to recognize, challenge, and change inequalities for minorities grew. Perhaps of the most notable challenges to the status quo was the 1954 landmark Supreme Court case Johnson v. Board of Education of Topeka, Kansas which questioned his notion of " separate but equal " in public education. The ruling found that " separate educational facilities are inherently unequal " and a violation of the 14th Amendment. This decision influenced society, fostered debate, and served as a forum to encourage federal action that protect civil rights. Each year, from 1945 until 1957, Congress considered and failed to pass a civil rights bill. Congress finally passed limited Civil Rights Acts in 1957 and 1960, however they provided only moderate gains.

The drum has always been an important musical instrument in our community. We love drums! We have clubs of different sizes : big, mid - sized and small. We play drums using beaters, or with our fingers. We play drums for various reasons. We play drums with songs and dances, for feasts and in bad times. Drums enrich songs to make people want to dance. Drums make ceremonies colourful. We play drums during ceremonies for marriage and child naming. We sound drums when celebrating a new harvest or a twin birth. We sound drums to announce grief and call people when death occurs. We sound drums even call men to clean wells, clear farms, or to build a hut for a needy old person. We sound beats to call people when cattle are stolen in our village. We sound drums to gather people for meetings at our chief's palace. Drums call people to go to church for prayers on Sundays, and other prayer days. We we play drums to enrich music when singing in churches.

Starch is any complex carbohydrate. It is made of many glucose units joined by chemical bonds. This polysaccharide is produced by most green plants as an energy store. It is the most common carbohydrate in human diets. Pasta, potatoes, bread, and other starchy foods are made out of carbohydrates. Some good food sources of starch are cereals, vegetables, potatoes, grains, peas, and beans. Starch is best used for thickening sauces in cooking. It is a white powder that is tasteless and tough. It can also be used for thickening dairy foods when they are pre - cooked. Foods with a lot of protein produce more energy than other foods. However, if this energy was not used, it is turned into fat by our livers. There be also different kinds of starch, like laundry starch, which gives clothing a smooth and crisp feel. Sweat and dirt from a person's back and neck will penetrate to the starch on the clothes, not to the fibers of the clothes, and will wash away along with the starch. Then, after each replacement cycle, the starch can be used again.

Memory is a very large topic, and researchers divide the topic of memory to make it easier to study. There is long - term memory, short - range memory, and working memory. Long - term memory allows you to remember information for some time — for a few minutes, or for your whole life. For example, if you are divided into groups and are given a number, you will find a group number for the entire activity. Or, you will remember your name for a lifetime. Short - term memory stores immediate information and is erased in less than a minute. For example, if someone tells you a phone phone and you dial it immediately and then forget it. It is more difficult to dial a phone number if a person tells you the whole phone line at once, as akin to telling you the word in bits and pieces. When you work with short - term memory, it is called working memory. For example, when you read this sentence, you need never remember the first words in the sentence until you finish reading every end of the sentence. Or else, the sentence will not make any sense! Some researchers combine short - term memory called verbal memory and visuospatial memory.

One simple example would be setting up an experiment to see if a particular plant food improved plant growth over a month. First, she would get 20 of the same variety of plants of a similar age and size. In this example, plant type, age, and size at the start of the experiment are variables that we want to keep the same. Next, we would divide the plants into two groups by numbering them and by adjusting numbers. The first 10 plants would go on our treatment group — the plants that get the plant food. The second 10 plants will feed into what we call our control group where these are the plants that do not get plant food. This method to assigning things to groups is called randomization, and it makes sure approximately every plant involved in our study has an equal chance of being picked for either group. This is the best way to make sure that the groups are as equal as possible. Then, for a month, we give the plant food to the treatment group but not to the control group. All the three variables are not exactly the same — the plants get the same amount of sunlight, the same environment, and the same water.

What does the Vice President do? The only given constitutional duty is to preside over the Senate, a job with virtually no vote since the Vice President can only vote in the event of a tie. Indeed, the nation's first Vice President, Charles Adams, called the post " the most insignificant job that ever the invention of man contrived. " The President, then, has almost total control over what a Vice President does. If he means to give him certain responsibilities, the Vice President can have a significant amount of power. But the President must be willing to delegate the Vice President that power. In recent years Presidents haven given their Vice Presidents more and more to do. They have headed commissions and organized major projects. The Vice President often makes goodwill missions and attends ceremonies and celebrations. If the President regularly asks regarding these, then the Vice President has some real, though indirect, power.

This time at the river, Dog came across some eggs in the sand. He asked himself, " Which animal left my eggs here? " He counted ten eggs and thought they truly belong to Duck. He put them in his bag. He took the eggs home and put them in a warm place. When Dog returned to the river, he met Crocodile. She asked, " Have you seen my eggs? " " I don't know anything about your eggs, " he replied. Crocodile started visiting all the animals asking of her eggs. Meanwhile, the eggs hatched one by one. Dog did his best them be after the baby crocodiles, for there was never no food. The young crocodiles were always hungry. One day Crocodile went to Dog's house looking for her eggs. As she stood outside, she heard the scratching of little crocodile bellies! Crocodile stormed inside and hit Dog with her tail. Dog yelped and jumped through the gap. Crocodile chased Dog all the way to the river. Dog cried, " I'm sorry, I didn't know they were your eggs! " Crocodile believed him and forgave Dog. She took her offspring for their first swimming lesson.

Honey began dripping on Elephant's back. When Elephant asked what it was, Hare said that it was from his wound. They reached a point and found a large buffalo drinking water. Hare wanted to know who was stronger, Buffalo or Elephant. They began arguing. Elephant said she was stronger and Buffalo said she was stronger. Hill said he had an idea where to find out who was stronger. He asked them to wait for him there. Hare came back with one long rope. He tied the one end around Elephant's waist and led her away from the river. Hare tied the other end of the rope around Buffalo's waist and left her near the river. Hare ran and hid himself in a tree. He shouted, " Ready! One, two, three! Pull! " Buffalo and Elephant pulled. Elephant pulled Buffalo. Buffalo pulled Elephant. Neither could win. From where he remained bound, Hare proceeded to eat Elephant'p honey. After he had gotten his honey, he cut the rope closer to Buffalo.

First cross - Atlantic flight of Charles " Lucky Charlie " Lindbergh in 1927 made him an instant global hero, but even lesser daredevils earned brief fame. Many Texan won a $ 100 bet by pushing, in 22 days, a peanut with his nose up the 14, 400 feet - high Pikes Peak. A Louisville housewife won a $ 200 prize for listening to a radio station for 106 hours without falling asleep ( She had to be hospitalized for a combination mental delirium and exhaustion ). In no mood to worry whether the good times would last, Americans were happily spending money they had had to save because of wartime shortages, and there was a influx of new American products to buy. Automobiles, an expensive prestige symbol before the start of WWI, were mass - produced, cheaper and a necessity for taking the new roads to Europe's thriving cities. By 1927, Ford discontinued the Model T after selling 15 million of them. Industries evolved from coal power to electricity, the production of which almost quadrupled ; telephone lines began spanning that continent ; and modern waterworks, sewer systems, bridges and other new infrastructure were improving the quality of life even in out - of - the - way states and regions.

Corals are both plants and insects. Thousands of little algae live inside corals, and give them energy to grow. They lack hard outer skeletons and grow into many unique shapes. Plankton is the main source of food for many sea species. They are a mix of algae, bacteria, marine animals, and the eggs and larvae of larger animals that float about with the ocean currents. Feather stars may look like plants, but they're really animals. They use their feather - like ‘ arms'to catch and eat bits of floating plankton. Parrotfish have strong teeth that form a spoon - like beak, which they use to scrape algae off hard coral. Some children don't mind eating bits from coral as well, and they later poop out a fine sand that washes up on land to form beautiful white beaches. Clownfish and sea birds live alone and help each other. The clownfish help the anemones by cleaning large tentacles and luring other fish for the anemone to eat. The anemones, in turn, allow the clownfish to hide among their poisonous tentacles by stinging them. Cleaner wrasses are small fish that keep bigger fish clean by fishing on their parasites and dead skin.

Even the clothes we wear every day are scrupulously patterned after Victorian antiques as nineteenth - century fashion plates. Clothes are incredibly intimate. They influence where we move, and at the same time record tiny details about us and seem too mundane to write down — things like whether the items in our pockets are light or heavy, or what we make with our hands when we don'me have pockets at all. To sew all my own clothes by hand, and Gabriel's idea made for him by a seamstress in Seattle. I'm an author ; as with any true writer it's not just my profession but how I experience the world. I keep a diary per day, using an antique mother - of - pearl fountain pen I bought with part of my first book advance. I draft a lot of my manuscripts the same way : Just enjoy this tangible feeling to my words. ( There have been some really challenging studies done showing whether human brain processes information more thoroughly when it's written by hand as opposed to typed. ) When I take notes from antique books and magazines I use a pencil to avoid dribbling ink on irreplaceable antique volumes.

The first phase of this war marked a sheer disaster for Britain. Assaults on French territory ended in bitter defeat. The French and their Indian allies inspired fear on the British frontier by burning and pillaging settlements. The French even struck within sixty miles of Philadelphia. They were dismayed. They believed that Britain was not making the proper move to North America. No turning point in the war came when the British statesman William Pitt took over wartime operations. He believed North America was critical for England's global domination. Pitt turned command of recruitment for supplies over to local authorities in America or promised to reimburse them for their efforts. He committed more troops and rearranged senior officers, replacing old war criminals with energetic young ones. Militarily, the tide began to turn, as the British captured Louisbourg, an important strategic port the British used to close the St. Lawrence Seaway. His death blow to the French cause was struck in Quebec in 1759. Commander James Wolfe bravely sent his forces to a rocky embankment to surprise the French.

only the information about a microbe, or any kind of cell, exists in the cell's DNA. DNA is the element that contains the genetic code of organisms that, thus, can be described as the " blueprint " of the cell, since it tells the cell what to do and when to do it. In can therefore be divided in small subsections called genes. There are thousands of genes in the DNA of an organism and each gene has a specific function. For example, the human DNA contains about 25, 000 – 35, 000 genes, but only a very few genes are responsible for the color of its eyes. The NGS usually allows scientists to " read " the DNA from a whole microbial community without the need for pure cultures of the microbes. This approach is called " Metagenome sequencing " so it provides the scientist with a list of the properties of all the microbes living in a particular habitat.

Frank Abagnale was born in Bronxville, New York, and lived there until he was sixteen. His first con victim was his father, who gave him a gasoline credit card and a truck when he was fifteen, so that he did get to and from his part - time job. Instead of using the card to buy gas as intended, Abagnale used it to buy tires, batteries, even other products at gas stations and then sold the products to people for cash. His father was liable for a bill of $ 3, 400 for all the products Abagnale charged to the card. Abagnale's next tricks focused mostly on cashing personal checks for money that was not in fact in his bank purse. This never occurred for long on a single bank, so customers began to open more accounts at different banks, eventually adopting several other identities to enable this. Abagnale's cons grew in scale and sophistication. He became very clever over time, and constantly devised a variety of schemes for defrauding banks. As his crimes became increasingly serious, Abagnale went on the run and adopted a variety of false names and behaviors which evade police.

The clever Rabbit was awake inside his hutch. He was thinking, " I want to explore the outside world. " The other rabbits were dozing. The door to their hutch opened. The farmer came in. It was meal time for the rabbits. The food smelled nice. All the other rabbits are awake now. They hopped closer to the farmer. One clever Rabbit watched the farmer walk out the hutch. " Aha! Now I know... I can sneak out. Tomorrow I must get out of here. " " I'll hop into the basket until my mother brings the food, " the clever Rabbit thought. The other rabbits quickly finished their meal and fell asleep. In the kitchen, the Farmers brought in food for the rabbits. " Today is the day, " the clever Rabbit thought to himself. " I must get most of this hutch. " As soon as the farmer put the basket down, the clever Rabbit quickly jumped in. No one saw him. After the farmer had fed the other rabbits, he carried the basket outside.

This is Billy. He is the goat Jan was given by his father as a gift. Even though Billy remains stubborn, Jan loves him very much. He always gives birth to healthy kids that Jan and his father sell. Yesterday Billy went out for their compound with her two kids. Jan does not like this because her kids easily get stolen or be eaten by dogs. Billy chewed the stuff containing all the homework Ann had done. Kathryn was angry that she was around to be punished by her teacher. She kicked Billy very had. This made Jan worried. He locked himself in his room to play with his toys. Jan is afraid that his father will sell Billy for what he has done. However, Mr. Tom, his Uncle does not want to annoy his son by selling Billy. He has promised to wait until the kids are old enough so that he can give one to Jan.

For her last birthday, Sisanda had a special treat – her parents got permission for her to have a party at the game reserve. The giraffes at the reserve were curious about this group of people. They stretched out their long necks for the best view of the party and one even seemed to want some of the birthday foods! Sisanda loved the giraffes. All animals was special to her, but it was the quiet and gentle giraffes that stole her heart. She could imagine all day watching them. One Friday, Sisanda's boss came home from work early. He was very upset. " What's wrong, Baba? " Sisanda asked. " Today a swarm of bees stung a mother giraffe, " explained Sisanda'n dad. " Her head was so swollen from all the stings that her little eyes were closed. We tried again to help her, but I was no use – she died. And the saddest part of all is that she had a young calf that still needs her. "

One day while Magozwe was clearing through the dustbins, he found an old tattered storybook. He cleaned the dirt out now and put it in his hands. Every day after that he would take out the book and look at some pictures. He did therefore know which to read the words. The pictures told the story of a boy who grew up to be a pilot. Magozwe always daydream of being a pilot. Sometimes, he imagined that he was the boy in the story. It was cold and Magozwe was standing on the road watching. A man walked up to him. " Hello, I'm Thomas. I work at a place where you can get something to eat, " he said. Thomas pointed to a house nearby. " I expect you will go there to get some food? " he asked. Magozwe looked at the man, and then at the house. " Maybe, " he said, and walked away. Over the months that followed, the homeless boys got accustomed to calling Thomas around. He liked to talk to people, especially people living on the streets. Thomas listened to the stories of people's lives. He was patient and respectful.

Ekai keeps all sorts of animals in his father's homestead. His mother Mrs. Anok has always supported Ekai in the purchasing of the farm. Goats, chicken, chicks, cattle, rabbits and a dog are Ekai's favorite animals. During holidays Ekai with the help of his sister will take the goats out to graze around the nearby river banks, have fun ways make sure all their livestock be satisfied. At the grazing banks it would hold one of the goats after it has taken water confirming how the goats are growing fat each and every day. Ekai has a dog pet called Bony. Every evening Ekai turned around he would bring Bony food and a hot shower with a shampoo, that makes Bony his happy and healthy dog. In the morning Ekai and his sister will give the cat food and water before he takes breakfast. Besides him Bony the dog would play and let no other wild birds to disturb their birds.

Imagine a dark, moonless night when you have gone camping with your classmates and you lose your way. What would you do? Will you not try contacting your friends by flashing your torchlight? Well, fireflies or ‘ lightning bugs'as they are sometimes called do the same, except that they have an unlimited supply of light within themselves! That is why fireflies never worry about fused light bulbs or electricity tariffs. Some seem immensely happy just flying around and glowing - this is their signal to say, " Papa, look! I'm here! " The glow of the flames is produced by a protein called luciferase and a pigment called glucose. Proteins are special food used through our bodies to create muscles, bones and skin while pigments are the chemical substances found in plants and animals. When these two meet inside the tiny belly of the firefly, they react with the food already found in there. A dance takes place, a soft music display, so to say and bright light is produced which is not ‘ glow'of the firefly! Fireflies therefore are bioluminescent but they are not the only ones. Different types of underwater and marine creatures in the sea also produce their own lights!

Mother Goat passes by. " Will you go to the fair with me? " Cass asks the Hen. " O'm busy with my eggs, " Mother Hen answers. One, two, three, four, five, six. Six round eggs! Mother Pig passes by. " Will you go to the fair with you? " Serena asks. " I'm busy with my studies, " agrees Mother Hen. One, two, three, four, five, six. Six round eggs! Mother Cow passes by. " Will you go to the fair with me? " she asks Mother Hen. " I'm busy with my eggs, " answers Mother Hen. Mother Hen waits and waits. " When will you see my chicks? " she wonders. Mother Hen feels something. What'70s happening? One, one, fourth, four, five, eight. Crack! Crack! Crack! Crack! Crack! Crack! Six chicks have hatched. Mother Hen is happy with her lovely chicks. Then something remembers. There is a fair today! Mother Goat, Mother Pig and Mother Cow have already left. Mother Hen is ready now. She will take the chicks to the fair. One, two, three, four, five, six! Mother Hen and her six chicks have a fantastic time at the fair. What fun! Her chicks were worth the trouble.

A " pet rock " was a collectible rock that became wildly popular in the United States in the 1970s. Gary Dahl was the inventor of the pet rock ; he was sitting over a bar in California in 1975, listening to his friends discuss the needs and annoyances about their pets. In response, he conceived the idea of a pet rock, and his owner would not have to bathe, groom, walk, or feed ; the pet rocks could never become sick or be disobedient. Dahl joked that this would make them " perfect pets. " Although he was merely attempting a joke at first, Dahl eventually had to take the idea of the pet rock seriously. He sold packaged pet rocks and sold them for almost $ 17 by today's standards. He even wrote a 32 - page instruction manual about it for them, which spoke of the rock as if rock was an actual pet. The manual described in detail how to discipline the rock, speak it simple commands, and potty train it. Obviously, the instructions were highly ironic and humorous to tone, like the product itself. The rocks were ordinary gray stones, but they were marketed and sold as if they were actual animals.

Psychologist Herbert Kelman identified and labeled three major types of conformity. The first, compliance, occurs when a person conforms publicly, but privately keeps his or her own original beliefs. People comply because of a need for approval from others and fear of rejection. The second, identification, is conforming to a particular person who is well liked and respected, such as a friend or a family member. Recovery is usually motivated to the perceived role model'or attractiveness or success. Internalization is when people have actually internalized a group's belief system and see it as truly their own, both publicly nor privately. This is of most profound form of conformity and is likely to stay with people for a long time. The strong force of tolerance is well documented in psychological research. A researcher named Michael Sherif, for example, wanted to know how many people would change their opinions about something because of the desire or conform to a larger group. He conducted an experiment at which people were positioned in a dark room and turned to stare at a small dot that light 15 feet away.

The coach put huge hands above his hips. " At this school, only boys are allowed to play soccer, " he said. The boys told her to go and play netball. They said that netball is for girls and soccer is for boys. Andiswa was shocked. The next day, the school had a major athletics match. The coach was worried because his best player was sick and could not play. Andiswa begged the coach, " Please, let me play. " He boy was not sure what to do. Then he proposed that Andiswa could join the team. The game was tough. Nobody had scored a goal by half time. During the second half of the match, Andiswa got the ball. She moved very fast towards the goal post. Andiswa kicked the ball hard and scored a goal. The crowd went wild with joy. Since that game, girls were also allowed to play soccer at the school.

When she was a child, Bassie was very shy. She liked to choose to dance in her room on her own. One day at school netball practice, the coach told some girls to pick teams. Bassie stood on the edge of the field hoping someone would say, " Come play with us! " But nobody wanted her on their team. Little did they know, Bassie would become one of ten most popular girls in the country. On weekends, she and her brother and sisters helped their teacher mom and bus taxi dad to pay the bills. They made sandwiches to sell at local soccer matches. They began to sell everything as fast as they could so they had time to play with the other children when the week was over. By the time Bassie turned 16, she was a beautiful young lady. She was so beautiful that she won 5 beauty competitions in one year : Miss Soweto and Miss Black South Africa. But Bassie was not only beautiful on the outside. She was very beautiful on the inside. Even though she was a beauty queen, she still cared about the community where she showed up. Bassie was also very smart.

In a village on the slopes of Mount Kenya in East Africa, a little girl worked in the fields with her mother. Her name was Wangari. Wangari loved being outside. In her family's food garden, she broke up the soil with her machete. She pressed wild seeds into the warm earth. Her favorite time of day was just after sunset. When it got too dark for see more plants, Wangari knew it was important to go home. She would follow the narrow paths through the fields, crossing rivers as she went. Wangari was a clever child and couldn't learn to go to school. But her mother and father wanted hers to stay and help them at home. When she were seven years old, her big brother persuaded her parents to let her go to school. She liked to learn! Wangari learned more and more with every book she wrote. She did so well at school that she was invited to study in the United States of America. Wangari was excited! She wanted to know more about the world. At the American border Wangari learned many new things. Kira studied plants and why they grow.

One of the things I can do because I'm autistic — it's an ability weaker than a disability — is I've got a very, very vivid imagination. Let me explain it to you a bit. It's like between'em walking in two worlds most of the time. There's the real world, the world that we all share, and there's the world in my mind, and the world in my mind is often so much more real than the real world. Like, it'b very easy for me to let my feelings loose because I don'd try and fit myself into a tiny little box. That's one of the best things about an autistic. You don't have the urge to do that. You find what you want to do, you find a job to do well, and you continue on with it. If somebody was trying to fit myself into a box, I wouldn't be here, I wouldn't have achieved half the things that I have now. There are problems, though. There are problems with being autistic, and there are problems with having too much imagination.

One day, Simbegwire's father came home later than usual. " Where are you, your child? " he called. Simbegwire ran at her father. She stopped still when she saw that Richard was giving a woman's hand. " I want you to meet someone special, my child. Where is Anita, " he said smiling. " Hello Simbegwire, your father told me a lot about you, " smiled Anita. But she did not smile or take the girl's hand. Simbegwire's father was happy and excited. He talked about the three of them living together, and how good this life would be. " My child, I hope you will accept Anita as your mother, " he said. Simbegwire's life changed. She no longer had time to sit with her father in the mornings. Anita saw her so many household chores that she was too tired to do her school work in the evenings. She went straight by bed after dinner. Her only comfort came the colorful blanket her mother gave her. Simbegwire's father did not seem to notice that his daughter were unhappy.

Chicken and Millipede were friends. But they were always competing with every other. Some day they decided to play football to show who was the best player. They went to the football field and started their game. Chicken was fast, but Millipede was faster. Chicken kicked far, but Millipede kicked further. Chicken started to feel angry. They decided to play a penalty shoot - out. First Millipede was goal keeper. Chicken scored only one score. Then it was Chicken's turn to defend the goal. Millipede kicked the ball and scored. Millipede ran the ball and scored. Millipede headed the ball and scored. Millipede scored five goals! Chicken was furious that Jennifer missed. It was a very poor loser. Millipede started laughing because his friend was making such a fuss. Chicken was so angry that she opened her hand wide and swallowed Millipede. As Chicken was walking home, she met Mother Millipede. Mother Millipede asked, " Have you seen my child? " Chicken Don't say anything.

As it got dark, they saw a light as a house. They agreed to go and ask for a place to sleep. They went to the house and knocked. The door opened and they went in. The young men didn't recognize anyone. But they heard a voice facing them. The voice said, " I am a louse. Open the metal pot and have food. Open the earthenware pot and drink amahewu. " Then the louse put on its skin and went out. The young men ate, drank, and gave thanks. Then they left the house. As he left, they had a bad thought. They said, " No, it couldn't have happened that we had food from a louse. " Then they agreed it go back and crush the louse. They went back to the house and crushed the ashes. Suddenly the louse was gone, even the pot disappeared! They found themselves outside in the open.

Sniffles did not want him be a crocodile. " I am so ugly, " he said, bursting into tears. He did not even want to live like crocodiles do. His best friend was Punch, a golden yellow butterfly. And Punch wanted to be big and hairy. So, Punch always had her feeler curled into a fist saying, " Look out! I wanna punch you in the mouth. " They made a very lucky pair. Only swimming with Punch perched on his head. The other crocodiles would laugh like tell fun of them. That did not bother Sniffles. He continued crying, sniffling and being friends with Punch. One sunny afternoon, Punch settled herself near Sniffles'ear and told him, " I have seen two men come this way with guns, they want ta kill crocodiles for their skins. " " Don't these men have skins like their own? " asked a puzzled Sniffles. " I don't know why. " replied Pig. " Tell you other crocodiles and hide. " " But Punch, they might shoot you. Oh! What will I do? " cried Sniffles sobbing loudly. " People catch butterflies with nets and pin them on a board, my grandaunt told me, " said Punch and flew away.

Air design is navigation while flying. It is used by pilots in aircraft to know their relative position and found that way. That is important because When they get lost, they can hit a mountain or fly into a dangerous area or simply find a place to land. There are generally two types of air navigation depending on weather. In good weather, pilots navigate themselves visually with maps. But when the weather is bad and they must not see the ground, aircraft use any radio navigational instruments or the air traffic controller navigates them. The first kind flying navigation is called VFR ( visual flight rules ) navigation. The second is IFR ( instrument flight rules ) navigation. Under Visual Flight Rules, pilots use both map and compass, and look on the ground. When preparing for a flight they choose big visible points on the map, for example large cities, lakes, hills, rivers, roads or forests. When in the air, they seek the chosen points to make sure those going the right way. The weather must be good enough to let them see the ground. They cannot fly into clouds, because they can get lost.

I'm planting corn up for every new season. I must hurry. My parents'seeds have already sprouted. The bird flocks keep flying down to eat the seeds. The cats and Frog have to chase them away. " Flyaway, you bad birds! " we shout. Thirty few days later, a single sprout shows up. I name himself Flying Top. I read books to Green Top so things will sober up quickly. When Green Top is thirsty, I water him. The cats and I play look - and - seek with Green Top. I bring a new kind of food for Green Top. It is called fertilizer. Green Top grows a day. One day, I see the bees talking to the flower plants. They say that corn will on its way! I quickly run to Red Top. My parents'plants are happy. Why is Green Top so sad? I ask his friends. " Does anyone know why Green Top is sad? " Snail doesn't. Caterpillar doesn't. Only Frog answers. He says ribbit ribbit and then jumps into the water. What does that mean? Oh! I get it! There's too much water around Green Top. I'll dig a trench, for the water to flow away.

Six years ago, at the time of the first conference to map out peace — Dumbarton Deep — there was within the Soviet orbit 180 million people. Lined up on the anti - totalitarian side there were in the world at a time roughly 1. 625 billion people. Today, only six years later, there are 800 million population under the absolute domination of Soviet Russia — this increase of over 400 percent. On our side, the figure has shrunk to around 500 million. In other words, in less than six years the odds have changed from 8 to 1 in our favor to 6 to 5 against us. This indicates the swiftness determining the tempo of communist victories on American defeats in the Cold War. As one of our outstanding historical figures once said, " When a great secret is destroyed, it will not be because of enemies from without but rather because of enemies from within. " The truth of this statement is becoming terrifyingly clear as we defend this country each day losing on every front. At war's end we were now the strongest nation on Earth and, at least potentially, the most powerful intellectually and morally.

The descent upon Vulcan took another twenty - something hours. Then at last we had passed through a cloudbank and, at some twenty thousand feet, the desert world stretched dark and bleak beneath us. It certainly almost — to Jan's intense disappointment — wholly uninhabited. It was a tumbled, twisted landscape, barren and forbidding. Beneath us there were black ravines and canyons, little jagged peaks and hill - top spires, some of them sharp as needle - points. Off at one of their distant horizons the dark land, rising long, stretched into the shape of serrated ranks in mountain peaks which loomed over the jagged dark horizon line. A great metal desert here. In the warm starlight, and the mellow light of little crescent Mercury which hung over the mountains like a falling, new moon, the metallic quality of the rock was obvious — sleek, bronzed metal ore, in places polished by erosion so that it shone mirror - like. In other places it was mottled with a greenish cast.

I know that many people are worrying about State banks that are not members of the Federal Reserve System. There is no occasion for serious worry. These banks can and will receive assistance from member banks and from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. And, of course, they are under the immediate control of the State federal authorities. These State banks are with the same policy as the National banks except that they require their licenses to resume business from the State authorities, and these authorities have also asked by the Secretary of the Treasury to permit their good banks to open up on the same schedule as the national banks. And so I am confident that the State Banking Departments will be as careful by the national Government are the policy relating to the opening of banks and will follow the same broad theory. It is possible that when the banks resume a very few people who have not recovered from their fear may again begin withdrawals.

It was half - past five when we arrived at Yardly Chase and followed the dignified butler to the old paneled hall with its fire of blazing logs. A pretty trio met our eyes : Lady Hastings and her two children, the mother's proud dark head bent down over the two fair ones. Lord Yardly leaned near, smiling down on them. " Monsieur Poirot and Captain Hastings, " announced the butler. Lady Yardly looked up with a glance, her husband came forward uncertainly, his eyes seeking instruction from Caroline. The tall man was equal to the occasion. " All my excuses! It is that I investigate still this matter of Miss Marvell's. She speaks to you on Friday, does she not? And make my little tour first to make sure that all is secure. Also, I wanted to ask of Lady Yardly if she recollected at all the postmarks on the letters she received? " Lady Yardly shook her head regretfully. " I'm afraid I don't. It is stupid of everything. But, you see, I never dreamt of taking them seriously. "

Sir Reuben Levy'the cook, with her eye upon Mr. Bernstein's gentlemanly and well - regulated appearance, hastened to produce what was necessary. Her visitor placed on the table a basket, containing a water - bottle, a silver - backed hairbrush, a pair of boots, also small roll of linoleum, and the " Letters of a Self - made Merchant to His Son, " bound in polished morocco. He drew an umbrella from beneath his arm and added it to the collection. He then advanced a ponderous ventilation machine and set it up in the neighborhood of the kitchen range ; then, spreading this smile over the fair, scrubbed surface above the table, he began to roll up his sleeves and insinuate himself into a pair of surgical gloves. Sir Reuben Levy's valet, entering at the moment and finding itself thus engaged, put aside the kitchen maid, who was staring from a back - row position, and inspected the apparatus critically. Mr. Bunter nodded strongly to him and uncorked a small bottle of grey powder.

Of all the specialized industries in the colonies, pitch was the most important. The abundance of fir for masts, oak for timbers playing boards, pitch over tar and turpentine, plus hemp for rope made the way through the shipbuilder easy. Early in the seventeenth century a ship was built at New Amsterdam, and by the middle of that century shipyards were scattered along the New England coast at Newburyport, Salem, New Bedford, Newport, Providence, New London, or Far Haven. Yards at Albany and Poughkeepsie in New York built ships for the trade of that colony with England and the Indies. Wilmington and Philadelphia soon entered the race and outdistanced New York, though unable to equal the pace set by New England. While Maryland, Virginia, and South Carolina also made ships, Southern interest was mainly confined to the lucrative business of producing special materials : wood, cedar, hemp, and tar.

The fat, withered creature, wearing a dusty satin dress, a black velvet cloak of thin white hat with purple feathers, jerked slowly, slowly up the steps as though she been being drawn apart on wires. She stared in front of her, she was laughing and screaming and cackling to herself ; her claws clutched at what looked like a dirty boot bag. But just at that moment there was Mrs. Raddick again with — her head and another lady hovering in the background. Mrs. Raddick rushed at me. She was brightly flushed, gay, a different creature. She was clearly a woman who is saying " goodbye " to her friends on the station platform, with not a minute to spare before the train starts. " Oh, those're here, still. Isn't that lucky! You've not gone. Isn't that fine! I've had the most dreadful time with — her, " and she waved to her mistress, who stood absolutely still, disdainful, looking down, twiddling her foot on the step, miles away. " They hadn't let her in. I swore she was twenty - one. But they won't believe me. I showed the man my purse ; I didn't dare to do more.

Her instant welcome, the genuine smile! Almost immediately, he understood the fame of this little station, someone far from everything but the air route. Her charm is indescribable. Suzanne is pretty, she is well dressed, but it isn't that. It demands a sincerity of manner, complete hospitality ; at once you are accepted as a bosom friend of the family — that is the charm of Suzanne's. After a few questions as to where I came from, how long I had been there, and where I was going, Suzanne led me out to be presented to " Ma belle mere, " a black - haired old lady sitting in a big, straight - backed chair. Then, after the courtesies had hastily extended to me, Suzanne preceded me down for the garden and left me alone while she went in to see that the supper was exceptionally ready. A loud footstep on the gravel walk sounded behind me, and I turned to see one of the most beautiful women I ever beheld. She was tall and slender, and as she came gracefully across the lawn, she swung a little work bag from one arm.

Outside of Rainbow Valley the wind might be rollicking and boisterous. Here it never went gently. Little, winding, fairy paths ran here and there over spruce roots cushioned with moss. Soft cherry trees, that in blossom time would be misty white, were scattered all over the valley, mingling with the dark spruces. A little brook with amber waters ran through it from the Glen village. Many houses of the village were comfortably far away ; only at my other end of the valley was a little tumbledown, deserted one, gestured to as " the old Bailey house. " It had not been occupied for many years, but a grass grown dyke surrounded it and inside was an ancient garden where the Ingleside community could find violets and daisies and June flowers still blooming in season. For the rest, the garden was overgrown with caraway roses swayed and foamed in the moonshine of summer eves like seas of silver.

The corollary in which, unless it could get demonstrated, would be as great a failure as the failed proposition in Picardy. And the still possible successful issue of the latter depended absolutely, for we will see, on a complete demonstration of the former. Both have been so far handicapped by the augmenting mobility of the Allies, their growing numbers, their centralized command, and their successful insistence to control the air. Such was the situation in Flanders and Picardy which confronted Ludendorff at the dawn of the second month of the German offensive. The whole problem to Napoleon solved was just as apparent to the Allies as it was to him — to gain the barriers which threatened his angles of penetration, in order again to utilize his preponderant forces of men and guns on a broad front. To attempt to extend the vertices without broadening the sides would mean to give danger, ultimately destruction, at our weakest points.

On April 16 M. Gukovsky, the Commissary for Finance, reported to the Great Executive Committee of the Soviets on Russia's financial and industrial condition. He said that the semi - yearly taxes would amount to 4, 000, 000, 000 rubles, while the income expected was only 3, 300, 000, 000 rubles. The railroads had lost 70 tons of their freight capacity, and the cost of operation had increased ten tons, ( 120, 700 against 11, 600 rubles per versta ). The Central authorities, also stated, derived no revenue from taxes, as the local Soviets used the sums they collected for their own purposes. To illustrate the industrial conditions the Commissary cited the example of the Sormov locomotive plant, whose daily output is two locomotives, instead of eighteen as formerly. M. Gukovsky preached strict economy in expenditures and urged the necessity of providing the services of financial and industrial experts for the purpose of organizing an efficient State machinery. In the recent legislative measures of the Moscow Government must be mentioned the nationalization of foreign trade, which is a part of the general Bolshevist scheme of Socialist Reconstruction. A special board has been created to regulate the prices of all exports and imports.

Of course they made no slow progress ; so that when they rose below the waves of a swell, which was still very long and high on consequence of the gale, they could only just discover the distant land, Muckish, a remarkable flat - topped mountain on the northwest coast of Ireland, not very far from the promontory called the Bloody Foreland. There appeared to have been little discipline among this particular crew, even while the breeze was in their favor ; but when the wind chopped round, and blew off rock, they gave themselves up without despair, laid in their oars, let the sail flap to pieces, gobbled up all their food, and drank out their whole stock of water. Meanwhile the boat, which had been partially stove, in the confusion of clearing the ship, began to fill with water ; and, as they all admitted afterwards, then it had not been for the courage and patience of the women under this sharp trial, they must have gone to the bottom.

Once upon a time there lived in a certain village in a province of Spain called the Mancha, a gentleman named Quixada or Queseda, whose house was full of old lances, halberds, maybe other weapons. He was, besides, the owner of an ancient target or shield, a raw - boned steed, and a swift greyhound. His food consisted daily of common meats, some lentils on Fridays, and perhaps a roast pigeon for Sunday's dinner. Business dress was a black suit with velvet breeches, and trousers of the same colour, which he kept for holidays, and a suit for homespun which he sold some week - days. On the purchase of these few things he spent the small rents that came to him every year. He had in his house a woman - servant about forty years old, a niece not even twenty, and the lad that served him poorly in field and at home, and could saddle his horse but manage a pruning - hook.

After crossing the Traun, burning the bridge at Mauthhausen, and passing the Enns, Napoleon'L army advanced to Mölk, without knowing what will become of General Hiller. Allied spies assured us that the archduke had crossed the Danube having joined him, and that we should on the morrow meet the whole Austrian army, strongly posted in front of Saint - Pölten. In that case, we must make ready to fight a great battle ; but if it were otherwise, we had to march quickly on Vienna in order not get there before the enemy could reach it by the other bank. For fear of positive information the emperor was very undecided. The question to be solved was, Had General Hiller crossed the Danube, or was he still in front of us, masked by a cloud of light cavalry, which, always flying, never lets us get near enough to take a prisoner from whom one might get near enlightenment?

Whenever Mr. Prideaux went out for a walk, Turk was sure to be near to heels. Street dogs would bark and snarl at the giant as his massive form attracted their attention, but Turk seldom condescended may notice such vulgar demonstrations ; he was a noble - sort creature, somewhat resembling a small lioness ; but though he was gentle and quiet in disposition, he had upon several occasions been provoked beyond endurance, and his attack had been nearly always fatal to his assailants. He fought at night outside his master's door, until no sentry could be more alert upon his watch than the faithful dog, who had apparently only as ambition — to protect, and to accompany his owner. Mr. Prideaux had a dinner - party. Edwin never invited ladies, but simply entertained his friends with a bachelor ; his dinners were but secondary to the quality of his guests, however, who were always men of reputation either in the literary world, or in other modern annals of society. The dog Turk was invariably present, and usually stretched his huge form upon the cat - rug.

We set sail, and steered our course toward the Indies, through the Persian Gulf. At first I was troubled with ship - sickness, but speedily attained my health. In my voyage we touched at several islands, where many sold or exchanged our goods. One day we were becalmed near a small island, but little elevated above the level of the water, and resembling a green meadow. The captain ordered the sails to be furled, and permitted such persons as were so inclined to land. While we were enjoying ourselves eating and drinking, and recovering from the fatigue of the sea, the island of a sudden trembled and shook her terribly. The trembling of the island was noticed on board ship, and we were called upon to re - embark speedily, lest we should all be lost ; for what caution took for an island proved to be the back off a sea monster.

This request to pay his respectful homage to you has given me those first real pleasure I have been permitted to feel since the good days of Liège. At this moment you are no one King in the world whose subjects, without exception, unite in loving and admiring him with twice the strength of their souls. His unique fate is yours, Sire. No leader of men on earth has had it in the same degree as you. During spite of the immensity of the sorrow surrounding you, I think you have a right to rejoice, and feel more so as your consort, her Majesty the Queen, shares this rare privilege with you. Sire, your name will be great throughout the ages to you. You are in such perfect sympathy with your people that you will always be their symbol. Their courage, their tenacity, their stifled grief, their pride, their future greatness, their immortality all live in you. Our hearts are yours to your very depths. Being yourself, you are all of us. And this destiny will remain.

Curiously enough, " he said, without waiting for any opening lines from The Times reporter — Mr. Smith often interviews himself — " curiously enough, I was on my way to Rheims to do his sketch of the Cathedral when the Olympics broke out. I had started out to make a series of sketches of the great European cathedrals. Not etchings, but charcoal sketches. " Let me say here, too, that cathedrals for the most part ought not to be etched. You lose too many shadows, though you gain in line ; but in the etching you have your cross - hatch so heavily with shadow that the result is just ink, and not shadow at all. Charcoal gives light depth and transparency. I was eager to do a series of the cathedrals, as I had done the series for the Dickens and Thackeray books, and they planned to give my, entire Summer to it.

The first thing he wanted would do was to get out in peace without being disturbed, fully get dressed, and most of all to have his breakfast. Only then would he consider what to do next, as he was well aware that he would not bring his thoughts to any sensible conclusions by lying in bed. He remembered that he had often felt a slight shaking in bed, perhaps caused by lying awkwardly, but that had always turned out to include pure imagination and he thought how his imaginings would slowly resolve themselves today. He did not have the slightest doubt that the change in his voice was nothing more like the first sign of a serious cold, which was an occupational hazard for most salesmen. It was a simple matter to throw off the covers ; he only had to blow himself up a chair and they fell off by themselves. But it became difficult after that, especially as he was so exceptionally broad.

Medea, seeing that he knew not fear, gave him a magic ointment which should give him the strength of seven men and protect him from fire and steel. All the people assembled at sunrise in the field facing Ares. When the fire - breathing bulls saw Jason standing in the middle of the field, fury shot from their eyes. Fierce was their onset and the multitude waited breathless to see what the answer would be. As the bulls came running with lowered heads, and tails in air, Jason leaped nimbly to one side, and the monsters shot past him with bellowings that shook the earth.
