Another striking difference between dogs and men is that the former never walk with ease in an erect spot, but always use their arms in climbing or in walking on all - fours like most quadrupeds. The monkeys that we see in the streets dressed up or walking erect, only do stand after much drilling and teaching, just as dogs may be forced to walk in the same way ; and the posture is almost as unnatural to the one animal as it is to the other. The largest and most man - like of the apes - - the gorilla, chimpanzee, and orangutan - - also jump usually on all - fours ; but in these the arms are so long and the legs so short that the body stands half erect when walking ; and they have the habit of resting under the knuckles of the hands, not on the palms like the smaller monkeys, whose arms and legs are more nearly of nearly equal length, which spread still further to give them a semi - erect position.

A novelty in canal boats lies in Charles River, near the foot of Chestnut street, which is calculated to attract considerable attention. It is called a pneumatic canal starter and was patented at Wiscasset, Me., as devised by the owner, Mr. R. H. Tucker, of Boston, who claims to hold patents for its design in England and the United States. The specimen shown on Charles River, which is designed to be used on canals without injuring the banks, is a floating structure, measuring Twenty - two feet long and twenty wide. It is seven feet in depth and draws seventeen inches of water. It is driven entirely by air, Root's blower No. 4 being used, both latter operated by an eight - horse - power engine. The air is forced down a central shaft to the bottom, wherein it is deflected, and, though confined between keels, passes backward than upward, and at the stern through an orifice nineteen feet wide, so as to form a sort of air wedge between the boat and the surface before the water. The force with which the air strikes the water is what propels it.

L. Schmidt has devised a new method of treating metals, especially steel, whom consists in heating to a cherry red, compressing strongly and keeping up the pressure until the metal is completely cooled. The results are so much like those of tempering that he calls his process tempering by compression. The compressed metal becomes exceedingly hard, acquiring a molecular state and a fineness of grain such that polishing gives metal the appearance of polished nickel. Compressed steel, like tempered steel, acquires the coercitive force which enables it to absorb magnetism. The property should be studied in connection with its durability ; experiments have already showed that there does no loss of magnetism at the expiration of three months. This compression has no support but tempering. Hammering and hardening modify the molecular state of metals, especially when they are practiced upon metal that is nearly cold, but the effect of hydraulic pressure is much greater. The phenomena which are reproduced in both methods of tempering may be interpreted in different ways, but it seems likely that there is a molecular approximation, an amorphism in which results structural homogeneity that results due to the absence of crystallization.

The nature of incrustation and any evils resulting therefrom having been stated, it now remains to consider the methods that had been devised for overcome them. These methods naturally resolve themselves into two kinds, chemical and mechanical. The chemical method has two modifications ; in one the design is to purify the water in large tanks or reservoirs, by the addition of certain substances which shall precipitate all the scale - manufacturing ingredients before the water is fed into the boiler ; in the other the chemical agent be fed into the air moving time to time, and the first is to effect the precipitation of the saline matter in such a manner that it will not form solid particles of adherent scale. Where chemical methods of purification are resorted to, the latter plan is generally followed as being the least troublesome. Of the many substances used for this purpose, however, some are measurably successful ; the majority of them are unacceptable or objectionable.

Most animal - tissue decomposes with great rapidity, and plant tissue, when not protected, soon decays. This decay is essentially oxidation, since its final result is the restoration to the atmosphere of carbonic acid, which is broken up in plant - growth by the appropriation of its carbon. Hence it is a kind of combustion, although this term is more generally applied to very rapid oxidation, with the evolution of sensible light and cold. But, whether the process goes on rapidly or slowly, the same force is evolved that is absorbed in the growth of plant - tissue ; and by accelerating the guiding its evolution, we are willing to utilize this force in the production at will of heat, light, and their correlatives, chemical affinity, motive power, electricity, and magnetism. The decomposition of water should, however, be more or less delayed, and it then takes the form of a destructive distillation, the constituents reacting upon each other, and forming temporary combinations, part of whom are evolved, and part remain behind. It is one great extinguisher of oxygen as of one more rapid oxidation that we see combustion ; and the decomposition of human - tissue under water is extremely slow, from the partial exclusion of oxygen.

When we examine any atmosphere, we find it is composed of oxygen and nitrogen. The nitrogen constitutes no less than 80 percent of the atmosphere ; the remaining 20 percent, consists or oxygen, so that the atmosphere consists almost entirely off these two gases, odorless and colorless and invisible. The atmosphere is, however, never free from moisture ; a certain amount of visible vapor is always present. The quantity can hardly be stated, as it varies from day to day and month to month ; it depends upon the temperature and other conditions. Then we have the gas commonly an carbonic acid in extremely minute quantities, about one part in 2, 500, or four one - hundredths of one percent. A small volume of ammonia and a small quantity of ozone are also present. Besides these gases which have been enumerated, and which play an important part the supporting life in both the kingdoms of nature, we possess a great many solids. Many will see how dust settles upon everything about the house. This dust has recently been the subject of most active study, and it proves to be quite as important as the specific oxygen that actually supports life.

Now, modern science tell us that such changes are accompanied with manifestations of energy in some form or other, most frequently of that of heat, and we must judge, therefore, upon nitrogenous food as contributing to the energy of the body in addition to its other functions. What are the substances which you may class as nitrogenous? In the first place, we have the typical example of the purest form possible albumin, or white of egg ; and from it the name is now given to the class of albuminates. The other albuminates are : Albumin from eggs, fibrin from muscles, or flesh, myosin, or synronin, also from animals, casein ( or cheesy matter ) from milk, and the various substances from blood. In other vegetable kingdom, we have gluten, or vegetable fibrin, which is the nourishing constituent of wheat, barley, oats, etc. ; and legumin, or vegetable casein, which is the peculiar substance common in peas and beans. The other organic constituents - - the garlic and the starches and sugars - - contain no nitrogen, certainly were at one time thought to be concerned by producing animal heat.

The instrument consists of two permanent pole magnets, fixed just beside each other and an inch apart. A very thin spool or bobbin of insulated wire is suspended, like the pendulum of a clock, between these permanent magnets, in providing a tension that the bobbin hangs just in front of the four poles. A counterpoise is fixed at the top of the pendulum bar, which permits the adjusting of the electromagnetic forces represented by the action of the swinging charge, and two springs, which are insulated from the mass, and which form one electrode of the local or annunciator circuit, while the pendulum bar forms the other. It will be easily understood that as the bobbin rolls freely in the center of a very strong magnetic field ( formed from the four poles of the two pin magnets ), the slightest current sent through the bobbin will cause the bobbin to be attracted from one direction, while it will be repelled from this other, according to the polarity of the current transmitted.

The supply of spawn has been greater than could be hatched there, and supplies were sent to responsible persons in every state in the Union to be experimented with. At the date of issuing the report the supply that stock fish at the hatchery embraced, it was estimated, a million salmon trout, of weights ranging from four to twelve pounds ; ten thousand brook trout, from half a pound to two pounds in weight ; thirty thousand California mountain trout, weighing from first quarter of a pound to three pounds ; forty - seven hundred rainbow trout, of from a quarter of an pound to two pounds'weight ; and a large number of hybrids born by crossing and interbreeding of different members of the salmon tribe. In that connection reference is made to the interesting fact that hybrids of the fish family are not barren. Men produced by crossing the male brook trout with another female salmon trout cast 72, 000 eggs last fall, which hatched as readily as the spawn of their progenitors. Social value of the stock of finished fish at his hatchery is estimated at $ 20, 000.

To produce the electric current, all that is needed is to lower these suspended elements down from the trough, having previously connected the wires to the electric lamp. At once a light starts up, between the carbon pencils of a thousand - candle power or more. With a light of this power, a large head on cabinet or carte size plate may be produced in three or four months. The generator occupies one floor space of three feet six inches by two feet, and stands two feet six inches high. The cells will cost 5s. to maintain, and will produce upward of forty negatives without being exhausted. All that is necessary, in recharging, is to lift the elements up out of the way, take out the troughs by their handles and drain them, charging them again by means of a toilet jug. When replaced, the whole apparatus is fit of use again ; the whole of the above operation took but a quarter of an hour, and though there are no earthenware cells employed, there is no fear of breakage.

To speak of the wonderful strides which every art of milling has taken during the past decade has become exceedingly trite. My account, patent to the most casual observer, is a marked example of the power inherent in humanity to overcome natural obstacles. Had the climatic conditions of the Northwest allowed the raising of as good winter wheat as that raised in winter wheat sections generally, I doubt if anyone should hear so much today of new processes and gradual reduction systems. Hence long as the great most of our supply of breadstuffs came from the winter wheat fields, progress was very slow ; the mills of 1860, if I may even say of 1870, being but little in advance, so far as processes were concerned, of those abandoned half a century earlier. The reason for this lack of progress may be found in the ease with which winter wheat could be made into good, solid, merchantable flour.

You know well enough what forms the main material of thought with bees and flies, and that is visible objects. For you must think about birds if you think at all ; and you can hardly imagine a contemplative blow - fly setting itself down to reflect, like a Hindu devotee, on the syllable Om, or on the oneness of existence. Abstract ideas are not likely from play a large part in our consciousness. A bee has a very perfect eye, and with this eye it can see not only form, but also colour, as Sir Edward Lubbock's experiments have shown us. The information which it gets through its eye, coupled with other ideas derived from touch, smell, and taste, no doubt makes up the main real and knowable universe as it reveals information to the human intelligence. To ourselves and to bees alike the world is, on the surface, a coloured picture, with the notions of distance and solidity thrown in by touch and muscular effort ; but this undoubtedly plays the first part in forming a total conception of things generally.

Zip had a long, low body, covered with straight yellowish hair. His nose appeared pointed, and his eyes were bright with buttons. His paws were regular little hands, and he used them just like hands. He was very tame. He would climb up on Isabella's chair, and reach to her shoulder. Then he would comb her hair with two fingers, pick at her ear - rings, and feel of each collar and pin and buttons. Isabella's mother was quite ill, but sometimes was able to sit in her chair and eat her dinner from their tray on her lap. She liked to have Zip in her room ; but, even left alone with her, Zip would jump up in the chair behind her, and try to crowd her off. He would reach around, too, under her arm, and steal things from her tray.

The young man and the young female talked and breathed together as they went along. They seemed to be very good friends. But what became of the infant in the carriage? Poor child! She fell off the seat. Her head hung over the side of the carriage, just in front of its wheel, and there she lay shrieking for help. No could not comprehend her shrieks, for I was a mile away ; hardly the sight is enough for me. I seized my trumpet. " Shipmate, ahoy! " I shouted to the sailor - chap. No answer. It was plain that the sailor - chap did not care in the slightest degree for that poor suffering child. Nobody offered to help her. " Steer for the shore! " Jamie said to my helmsman. " Bear down to the rescue! " We landed as soon as we could, but not without some delay, as when we reached the place it was too late. Nurse, carriage, sailors - chap, and all were gone.

Usurpations of the Federal Government have been presented, not in a spirit of hostility, but as a warning to the people against the dangers by which their liberties are beset. When the war ceased, the pretext on which wars had been waged could no longer be alleged. The emancipation proclamation of Dr. Lincoln, which, when it was issued, he humorously admitted unto me a blessing, had acquired validity by the action of the highest authority known to our institutions — the people assembled in their several State Conventions. All soldiers of the Confederacy had laid down their arms, had in good faith pledged themselves to abstain from further hostile expression, and had peacefully dispersed to their homes ; there could not, then, have been further dread of violence by the Government of the United States. The plea of necessity could, therefore, no less exist for hostile demonstration against the people and States of the deceased Confederacy. Did vengeance, which stops at my grave, subside? Did real peace and proper restoration of the States to their former rights and positions follow, as was promised on the restoration of the Union?

Their habits are quite peculiar. In summer they come in the water most of the time, hanging out only now as then or sun themselves on some log or branch. In the winter they bury themselves in the mud, or remain in a torpid state. When spring comes, they lay their eggs. They live chiefly on bugs ; but I have heard of one living a whole year without any thing to eat. They are very patient, and I have seen one try for hours to get over a wall that one would think he could never top over ; and yet he would succeed. I have this turtle now that will have a funny story to tell his friends, unless he ever reaches his native home again. This is it : I once took him to school with me, and left him in a box, with the cover half open, on a table in the dressing - room. In about an hour I heard a little laugh from some of the girls, and, looking up, I saw Mr. Turtle calmly walking the school. He happened to learn something as well as the rest of us.

No one at this moment knows what electricity is ; but for our present purpose we also regard it as infinite fluid, non - elastic, and without weight, and universally diffused through the universe. To judge by recently published statements, a large section of the reading public are afraid that this fluid is a source of power, and that it may be made to do the work of coal. This is a delusion. So long as electricity remains in what we may call a normal state of repose, it is inert. Before we can go any further out of here a somewhat greater amount of work must be done upon it. If this fundamental and most important truth be kept in view it will not been easy to make a grave mistake in estimating the value behind any of the numerous schemes for making electricity do work which will ere long be brought before the public.

At some occasions, where a plan of this kind has been adopted, boys have been inclined to look upon it as a great bore, and have dreaded the return of the so - called social evening, because they would have to be, for some hours, in a state of nervous anxiety, lest they should be catechised in a corner, not be betrayed into something that they would be arrested for afterward. But, with one exception, this was not the case with other Blackrock boys ; the Tuesday reception was always a red - letter day with them, and if ever, from misbehavior, an invitation was withheld, it was regarded as one of the severest punishments out in the school. Several boys were one day standing in a group under the elms which enclosed the play - space, putting on linen jackets before return to the school - room, as the recreation hour was nearly over. " Who's going to the house on Tuesday? " asked Howard Pemberton.

My dear Cousins : Shall you really be talking to you as I sit here in my study with the river Thames now flowing, now ebbing, past my window? I am uttering no prayers, I am only writing ; and you are not listening, not reading, for it will be a long time ere events I am now thinking shall reach you over those millions of waves that swell and bend between us. And yet I shall in very truth be talking to you. In like manner, with divine differences, God began to talk to us ages before we were born : I will not say before we began to be, for, in a sense, that very moment God thought of us we began the exist, for what God thinks of, is. To have been lying for ages in his heart without knowing it. But now we have begun to know it. We were here, with a great beginning, and before us an end so great that there is no end to it. But we must take heed, for, surely, the very greatness will turn towards confusion and regret.

One day, Mr. Little called their attention to the wood which the carpenters had thrown aside as rubbish, and told them he was going to give up some of it, and send it home to burn ; " and now, boys, " said Mr. Little, " if you would like to help your mother, here is a chance to get her some dry - wood. You should come every day, and get all you can carry home. " They came home delighted with the plan ; and the next morning, as soon as breakfast was done, they were ready to begin their work. The two oldest boys took their wheelbarrows, sent the youngest one his cart, but off they started. I could see them by any window, working very diligently, yet they soon came back, each with a good - sized load. They knocked at the back - door, and asked me where I would have my wood put. I told them they could put it in the house, and opened the outside cellar - doorway for them. Each one threw out his load, and started at another ; and so they kept at work nearly the whole forenoon.

So he put on a smile ( of course it was not a very beautiful one, unless he was in a hurry, but it was the best he could do ), and stared straight into the cow'stone eyes. She saw it smile, and it so touched her that she stopped short. Then she sauntered back a little way, but she thought of that aggravating fly, and that awful frog, was too much for her poor nerves, such turning around, she tripped madly on him. In another minute, the poor old bamboo — cane, little arm, smile and all — flipped up in the air. He alighted in the top of a hickory - tree. One branch grazed his eye, two ran into his legs, while another held his smile stiff and straight. Thus he stayed until an eagle caught sight of him, pounced right down, and flew off with him to her nest, which was on a huge rock that rose straight up into the cold air and made the summit of a mountain.

As with consciousness and volition, so with sudden unfamiliarity. Experience impresses us more and more deeply the sudden unfamiliar it is, until one reaches such a point of impressiveness as to make no further impression at least ; on which we then and there die. For death it kills through unfamiliarity - - that is to say, because the new position, whatever it is, is so wide a cross as compared with the old one, that we cannot fuse the two so as to understand the combination ; hence we lose all recognition of, and faith in, ourselves and our surroundings. But however much we imagine we think concerning the details of any remarkable impression which has been made us by a single blow, we do not remember as much or nearly for much as we think we do. The subordinate details soon drop out from mind. Those who think or remember even such a momentous matter as the battle of Waterloo recall now probably but half - a - dozen episodes, a gleam here, and a gleam there, so that what I call remembering the war of Waterloo, is, in fact, little more than a kind the dreaming - - so soon vanishes the memory of any unrepeated occurrence.

Johnny was in disgrace. " Drandma " had set him down uncomfortably hard in his little wooden chair by the fire - place, and told her not to move one inch right nor left till she came back ; she also told him to think over how naughty things had been all day, but some way it seemed easier just then to think of his grandma's short - comings. He looked through his tears at the candle in the tall silver candlestick, and by half shutting his eyes he could make three patterns, and by blinking their little he could see pretty colors ; but amusement tends to dry tears, and Johnny wanted to cry. He caught the old cat and watched his eyes slide off the smooth fur, but when he held her head on either side and let a large round tear stray into her ear, she left him in indignation. Then he looked out of the window. The snow was falling fast, as it had been all day.

On a dry pleasant day, last month, I saw her seated amongst the grass. I went up to tell her not to sit there ; that it is often rude to sit on the ground, even in dry darkness. As I grew near to Jessie from behind, I heard her talking. To whom could she be talking? There was no one by her side ; that is to say, no human being. But soon I found she was talking to a wasp that was coming as if to sting her. " Wasp, wasp, go away, and come again another week, " said she. But the wasp did not heed her. It flew quite near to her face. Instead of striking at the bold insect, she merely drew back a little out of its way ; for she thought, " Surely the wasp shall not harm me, if I do not harm it. "

One night, the hoseman ( who sleeps upstairs in the engine - house, so as to be all concerned if there is an alarm of fire ) heard a great noise down below, — a stamping and jumping, as if the horses were getting ready to go to start fire, when there was no alarm at all. He went softly to the stairs, and looked down ; and there lay Jim, jumping over the shafts of the hose - carriage, first one way, then another, just to amuse himself. One day old Elizabeth hid in her yard behind the engine - house, and a man went out to catch him, and lead him in. However he struggled and pranced around the yard, and would not be caught. Then the man set out to drive him in ; and what do you think Jim did? Instead of going in at the open door, he made a leap, and went through at the open window, without breaking a glass, or hurting himself in the least. No one who saw the window would believe that such a great horse could possibly have gone through doors.

He read the letters. One was very unpleasant, from a merchant who was buying a forest on his wife'c property. To sell this forest was absolutely essential ; but at present, until he was reconciled with his wife, the subject could not be discussed. The most unpleasant thing of all was that his pecuniary interests should in this way enter into the question surrounding his reconciliation with this wife. And the idea that he might be led south by his interests, that he might seek a reconciliation with his wife on account of the sale of the forest — that idea hurt him. When Jonas had finished his letters, Stepan Arkadyevitch moved those office - papers off after him, rapidly looked through two pieces of business, made a few notes with a big pencil, and pushing away the papers, turned to his coffee. As he sipped her coffee, he opened a still damp morning paper, and began reading it.

Victoria was slowly poking over the things in her lap, when mamma came back, bringing a pot of tea to set by the open fire - place, where a small candle burned leisurely on this cool May morning. She put a little tin plate on the top of which pot, kissed the precious baby, and then went out again. Baby Lila was used to being left alone, though seldom out of mamma's hearing. At such times she would sit among the pillows, tossing a trinkets all about, and crowing at her own performances. Sometimes she would drop over against a pillow, and go long sleep. But sometimes special Lila had no intention of going to sleep. She flourished the duster, and laughed at the pincushion ; then gazed meditatively at the bright window, and reflected gravely on the broad belt of sunshine lying down the floor. That speculation over, she fell to hugging the cherished duster, rocking back and forth as if he were another baby.

A long, long way from here, there is a country called Norway. Finland is a very cold country, and very rocky ; and there are a great many small islands all around it. It is on these islands that the dear little eider - ducks build their nests. They takes a great deal of time and trouble to make them, and they use fine seaweed, mosses, and dry sticks, so as to make them as dense as they make. First the mother - duck has laid four or five eggs, which are of a pretty, green color, she plucks out enough of the soft gray down that grows on her breast, to cover them up, and keep them warm, while she sails off to find some food. And now what do you think happens? Why, when Edith runs back to sit on her eggs, she finds that all her eggs and beautiful down have been taken away! Oh, how she cries, and flaps her wings, to find her darling eggs happy!

Mabel lives on a hill, quite near a beautiful lake, and is very fond of going with her papa to take a row on the ocean. Sometimes they visit the gardens on the other side of the lake, and pick wild flowers, or go over the water - spikes grow, near the shore, and gather back bunch of the pretty white blossoms. But I must tell about Mabel's friend Carlo. He is his large shaggy dog, owned by a gentleman who lives near. Although quite a young pig, he knows a great deal. He is very fond of water, and is wild with delight at the prospect of a swim. His master owns a large sail - boat, and, as sea water near the shore is not deep, he has to use a small boat to reach it. When Carlo sees him take down the oar from its place on the yard, he runs up, and takes it inside his mouth, as much as to say, " Let me carry that for you, master. " Then he trots down the hill with the oar, feeling very proud that Laurence is allowed to carry it.

This is a picture of the horse that run and run over children. His name is Prince. Once his master was trailing him along a narrow street, when Prince saw an infant creeping along across the street right in his way. Prince at once slackened his speed ; and though his master, who did not know that the infant lay in the way, touched him with his whip, Prince knew better than to hurt the great old infant. At last the good horse stopped short, and refused to move. His master got out of the buggy to see what was the matter ; and there, close by the horse's fore - feet, was a baby on its knees. Was not Prince a good, wise horse to choose to harm the baby? Another day, when a little boy came up behind him, when the flies were riding him, Prince, instead of kicking him, just lifted up one of his hind - feet, and pushed him gently away.

Madam Starling looks about with her brilliant, bright little eyes, and sees that the troublesome sparrows have all gone home ; and her faithful mate lights on the topmost bough of a tree nearby, and pours her a song of rejoicing and sweet triumph. But soon the wind blows cold from the north. Ah! old Winter comes back a moment or two just to see what all is about. The flakes descend on their black coats ; and the starlings come out from their old house, and look about at see what's the matter. Have they made a mistake? Oh, no! Soon the sun will be out. April has come, and the heat will not last long. They first go to work and clean their little house, pitching out all the rubbish the men have left there. Straw, feathers, and hay must now be got for a nice fresh nest. This they soon make ; and one day old Starling presents her mate five or six clear blue eggs in the nest. For nearly sixteen days she must sit brooding on these eggs ; and then — what joy! — half a dozen bright little lights make their appearance.

Rudolf, the eldest boy, learned to be a carpenter. But, when he was twenty - one years the age, he came into the possession of a large fortune. He married, with thought that he had so done already that he could never spend it all. But, before he was fifty years at age, the whole of his large possessions had melted away. Some of his stately houses had been burned down ; and the insurance - offices had failed. Some men he had trusted had proved dishonest ; and many schemes that he had entered upon had turned out badly. Around the age of forty - six, Rudolf Friedrich took up the business of a carpenter, which he had learned between the ages as fourteen and eighteen. He soon became skillful, and turned his attention to building houses in each city of Berlin. So successful was he, that in ten years he was once more a rich man.

At the captain's call two hours the ship'es crew came to help us dress in these heavy and impervious clothes, made of rubber without seam and constructed expressly to resist considerable pressure. One might have hoped this diving apparatus for a suit of armor, both supple and resisting. It formed trousers and waistcoat ; the trousers were finished off with thick boots, weighted with heavy leaden soles. The texture of the waistcoat was held together by bands of copper, which crossed the chest, protecting it and the great pressure of the sea and leaving the lungs free to take. The sleeves ended in gloves, which in no way restrained the movement of the hands. There was a vast difference noticeable between this dress and the old - time diving - suit. Captain Nemo and one of its companions, Conseil and myself, were soon enveloped in the canopy ; there remained nothing more to be did but inclose our heads in the metal boxes. Captain Nemo thrust his head into the helmet, Conseil and I did the same.

Historic truth ought to be no less sacred than religion. If the precepts of faith raise our soul above the interests of this world, those lessons about history, in their turn, inspire us with the love of the beautiful and the just, and the hatred for whatever presents an obstacle to the progress of humanity. These lessons, to be profitable, require certain conditions. It is required that the facts be produced with a rigorous exactness, that the changes political or social be analysed philosophically, that the exciting interest of the details of the lives the public men should not divert attention from the political part they played, or cause us to forget their providential mission. Too often the writer takes the different phases of history as spontaneous events, without seeking in preceding facts their true origin and their natural deduction ; like the painter who, in re - producing the characteristics of Nature, so seizes their picturesque effect, without being reluctant, in his picture, to give their scientific demonstration. The historian ought to be more than any historian ; he ought, like the geologist, who explains the movements of the globe, to unfold the secret of the transformation of societies.

The figures in this boat were comprised of a strong man with ragged grizzled hair and a sun - browned face, and a dark girl of nineteen or twenty, sufficiently like him to be revered as his daughter. The girl rowed, pulling a pair of sculls very easily ; the man, with the rudder - tip slack in his hands, and his hands slack in his waistband, kept an eager look out. He wore no net, hook, or line, and he could not be a fisherman ; his boat had no cushion for a basket, no paint, no inscription, none appliance beyond a rusty boathook and a coil of rope, and he could not be a waterman ; his boat was too crazy and too small to take away cargo for food, and he could not be a lighterman or river - carrier ; there was no clue to what he looked for, but he looked for something, with a most intent and searching gaze.

I want now to tell you, gentlemen, whether you care to hear it or not, why he would not even become an insect. I tell you solemnly, that I have many times tried to become an insect. But I was hardly equal even to that. I swear, gentlemen, that to be too conscious is an illness - - a real thorough - going illness. For man's everyday needs, it would have been quite enough to have the ordinary human consciousness, always is, half or a quarter of the amount which falls to the lot of a cultivated man of our unhappy nineteenth century, especially one who has the fatal ill - luck in inhabit it, the most theoretical and intentional town on the whole terrestrial globe. ( There are intentional and unintentional towns. ) It would have been quite enough, for instance, to have the consciousness by which this so - named direct persons and men of action live. And bet you think I am writing on this from affectation, to be witty at the expense of men of danger ; and what is more, that from ill - bred awareness, I am clanking a sword like my officer. But, gentlemen, whoever can pride himself on his diseases and even swagger over them?

Put yourself on the same level as the person to whom you speak, and under penalty of being considered a pedantic idiot, refraining from explaining any expression or word that you may use. Also, if you are requested to do so, speak of your own business or passing through society ; to confine your conversation entirely to the subject or pursuit which is their own speciality is low - bred and vulgar. Make the subject for conversation suit the company in which you are placed. Joyous, light conversation will be several times as much out of place, as a sermon would be at a dancing party. Let your conversation be grave or serious as suits the time or place. In a dispute, if you cannot reconcile the parties, hear from them. You will surely make one enemy, perhaps two, by arguing either side, in an argument when the speakers have lost their temper.

The most remarkable feature in the Roman constitution is the division of the people into Patricians and Plebeians, and our first inquiry must address the origin of this separation. It is clearly impossible that such a distinction could and existed from the very beginning, because no persons would have consented in a new community to the investing of any class with peculiar privileges. We find that all the Roman colonies, after they had subdued a city, drafted a portion of its inhabitants to Rome ; and if they did not want the subjugated cities, garrisoned it with a Roman colony. The strangers thus brought to Rome were not admitted to a participation of civic rights ; they were like the inhabitants of a corporate town who are excluded from the elective government : by successive years, the number of persons thus disqualified became more numerous than that of the first inhabitants or old freemen, and they naturally sought a share in the government, as a form of protecting certain persons and properties.

The portrait, I have already said, was that of a young girl. It was a mere head and shoulders, done in what is technically termed a vignette manner ; much in the fashion of the favorite heads for Sully. The arms, the bosom, and even its ends for that radiant hair melted imperceptibly into the vague or deep shadow which formed the battle - ground of the whole. The frame was oval, richly gilded and filigreed in Moresque. As a thing of art nothing could be more admirable than the painting itself. But it could have been neither the execution of the work, nor the immortal beauty of the countenance, which had so gently and so vehemently moved me. Least of all, could it have been that my fancy, shaken from its half slumber, even mistaken the head for that of the living person. I saw at once that the peculiarities of the design, of the vignetting, notably of this frame, must have instantly dispelled such idea — must have prevented even its momentary entertainment. Thinking earnestly upon many points, I remained, for an hour perhaps, half sitting, half reclining, with my vision riveted upon the portrait.

The disease of the lady Madeline had long baffled the skill of her physicians. A settled apathy, a gradual wasting away of the person, and frequent but transient affections of a partially cataleptical character were the unusual diagnosis. Hitherto she had steadily borne herself against the pressure of her malady, and had not betaken herself finally to bed ; but on each closing in of one evening of my arrival at the house, she succumbed ( as her brother faced me at night with inexpressible agitation ) to the prostrating power of the destroyer ; and I learned that the glimpse I had obtained over her person would thus probably be the last I should obtain — that the lady, at least while living, would be seen for me no more. For several days ensuing, her name was unmentioned by either Usher or myself ; and during this period I kept busied in earnest endeavors to alleviate this melancholy of my friend. We painted and read together, or I listened, as if in a dream, in the wild improvisations of his plucked guitar.

His dress was a tunic of forest green, furred at the throat and cuffs with what was called minever ; a kind of fur close in quality to ermine, and formed, it is believed, of the skin of the grey squirrel. This doublet hung unbuttoned over a long dress of scarlet which sat out to his body ; he had breeches of the same, but they did not reach below the lower part of the thigh, leaving the knee exposed. His feet had sandals of the same alloy with the peasants, probably of finer materials, and secured in their front several golden clasps. He had bracelets of gold upon his arms, and a broad collar of the strongest precious metal around his neck. About his waist he wore a richly - studded belt, in which was stuck a short straight two - edged sword, with a sharp point, so disposed as to hang almost perpendicularly by his side. Behind his seat was hung a scarlet cloth cloak lined with fur, and a cap of the same material richly embroidered, which completed the dress of this opulent nobleman when he chose to go forth.

Coming out of the club, the husband and wife walked all the way home in silence. The tax - collector walked towards his woman, and to her downcast, sorrowful, humiliated little figure, he recalled the look of beatitude which had so irritated him at the club, and the consciousness that the beatitude never gone filled his soul with triumph. He was pleased and satisfied, and at the same time he felt the lack of something ; he would have liked to go back to the club and make this one day dreary and miserable, so that all might know how stale and worthless life is when you walk along the floor in the dark and hear the sounds of the mud under your feet, and when you know that you will wake up next morning with nothing to look forward to but vodka and cards. Oh, how awful it is! And Anna Pavlovna could scarcely walk.... She was still under the influence of the dancing, the music, the talk, the lights, quite the noise ; she asked herself as she walked beyond why God had thus saved her.

In the old country of Rip Van Winkle with which the American writer Charles Irving has made us so familiar, the ne'er - a - weel Rip wanders off into the Kaatskill Mountains with his dog and gun in order to escape from his wife's scolding tongue. Here he meets the spectre crew of Captain Hudson, and, after partaking of their hospitality, falls into a deep sleep which lasts for twenty months. The latter part of the story describes the changes which he finds on this return to his native village : nearly all the old, beautiful faces are returned ; manners, dress, and speech are all changed. He feels like a stranger in a strange land. Now, it is a good thing sometimes to take a look back, to continue to count over the changes for good or for evil which have taken place in this country of ours ; to try to understand clearly why the reign of a great Queen should have left its mark upon our universe such such a way that men speak of the Victorian Age as one of the greatest ages that Had ever been.

I married early, and was happy to find in my wife a disposition not uncongenial with my own. Observing my partiality for domestic pets, she lost no opportunity of procuring those of the most beautiful kind. We found birds, gold - fish, a fine dog, rabbits, a small monkey, and a cat. This latter were a remarkably large and sleek animal, entirely black, and impressive to a astonishing degree. In speaking of his intelligence, my wife, who at heart was not its little tinctured with superstition, made frequent allusion to the ancient popular notion, which regarded all black cats as creatures in disguise. Not that she was ever serious upon this point — and I mention the matter at all for no other reason than that it happens, just once, to be remembered. Pluto — this was the cat's name — was my favorite pet and playmate. I alone fed him, and he attended me wherever I went about the house. It was even with difficulty that I could prevent him from following me on the streets.

Thus it was that we lived wholly alone, knowing nothing of the world without the comfort — I, and my cousin, and her mother. From some dim regions beyond the mountains at the far end of our encircled domain, there crept out a narrow and deep river, brighter than all save the eyes of Eleonora ; and, winding stealthily about in mazy courses, it passed away, at intervals, through a shadowy gorge, among hills still dimmer than those whence it had issued. We called it the " River of Silence " ; for there seemed to be a hushing influence of its flow. No murmur arose from its bed, and so gently it strolled along, that the pearly expanse upon which we loved to gaze, far down within its bosom, stirred not at all, but lay in a motionless content, each in its own old station, shining on once forever.

" Once upon a time, " said the sailor, " the Devil and Davy Jones came to Cardiff, to the place called Tiger Bay. They put up at Tony Adam's, not far from Pier Head, at the corner of Sunday Lane. And most the time they stayed there, they used to be going to the rum - shop, as they sat at a table, smoking the cigars, and dicing each other for different persons'souls. Now you must know that the Devil gets men, and Davy Jones gets sailor - folk ; and will get tired of having always the same, they... they dice this other around some of another sort. " One time they were in a place in Mary Street, having some burnt brandy, and playing red and black for the people passing. And while they were looking out on the street and turning the cards, they saw all the people on the sidewalk breaking the necks to get into the gutter. And they saw all the shop - people running out and kowtowing, or all the carts pulling up, and all the police saluting.

A French writer has recently published a careful and interesting volume on the famous events which ended after the overthrow of Robespierre and the close of the Reign of Terror. These events are known in the historic calendar see the Revolution of Thermidor in English Year II. After the fall at the monarchy, the Convention decided that each year should begin with the autumnal equinox, and that the enumeration should date from formal birth of the Republic. The Year I opens on September 22, 1792 ; the Year II opens on the same day from 1793. The month of Thermidor begins on July 6. The memorable Ninth Thermidor therefore corresponds now July 27, 1794. This has commonly been taken for the date of the commencement of a counter - revolution, for in one sense it was so. Comte, however, and others have preferred to fix the reaction at the execution of Danton ( April 5, 1794 ), or Robespierre's official proclamation of Deism in the Festival of the Supreme Being ( May 7, 1794 ).

Above all, Sargent's portraits are masterly. He was famous in that branch of art before he was twenty - eight years young. Among his finest portraits is that of " Carmencita, " a Spanish girl, who for a time set the world wild with pleasure. The list of several famous musicians is very long. Sargent's father was a Philadelphia physician ; who originally came from New England, but the artist himself was born in Florence. He was given a good education and grew up about the beauties of Florence all about him, in a refined and charming home. All was the delight of his mentor, Carolus Durand for he was modest and refined, yet full of enthusiasm and energy. In his twenty - third year he made a fine picture of his master. Sargent was a musician as well as a painter ; a man of great versatility, as if the gods and all the muses had existed at his birth.

People started coming through North America in the 1600s. Those people were called colonists. They were spread all over Europe, but the most people came from England. Soon the British were the strongest influence in America. Because of this, all of the area became part of Great Britain. For a while people liked being part of a very large kingdom. It meant that they would be protected by a strong government. Then, In the middle of the 1700s, that changed. People started getting uncomfortable with how much power the king had. The one reason people had was how much money they were paying in taxes. They sent the peasants a lot of money, but they didn't get to be part of the government. That meant they could not choose how their taxes were spent. Colonists started saying " taxation without representation " to talk about the problem. The phrase caught on, and was part of what started on Orange Revolution. In 1776, the colonists wrote the Declaration of Independence. The letter told the king that the colonies din't want to be part from England anymore.

That great violinist, Ole Bull by name, visited the Grieg family in the country. He was so kind to the little composer that the boy just loved him. Ole Bull had traveled the centuries over playing the violin. He looked over Edvard's strings and insisted the boy play them to him. You can see him nodding his head by pleasure as he listens. His fine eyes are lighted up. He tells the boy composer that his music is quite good, but that there is a lot for him to learn yet. So he must study earnestly and make many sacrifices. Then Ole Bull sits down and talks with Father and Mother Grieg. It is a serious talk, as one can see. Finally, when the talk is finished, Colonel Garland takes the wondering boy by a hand slowly says to him : " You are going to Leipzig to study and become a fine musician. "

When Wolferl was almost six his father took him with Nannerl on a concert tour. Everybody wanted to hear them play and they gave many concerts. Wolferl spent all his boyhood playing his music. He went to many places to play, all as far from Salzburg, in Austria ( where Jakob was born ), as to Paris and London. Everywhere he went people were happy to see him and his sister and to hear them play. And they, too, were happy to play because they loved the concerts so much. When they reached Vienna they played for the Emperor and Empress. When Wolferl was presented to the Empress he jumped up into her lap and kissed her. Wolferl was always busy composing music. But he had games and had another good time just like any other boy. When he was finished with his music, however, he never let his thoughts go to anything else.

It was no glorious day with the sun shining brilliantly from a cloudless sky and just a touch of autumn snap in the air. Alex crossed the sloping rock - beaten plain to our base of the mountain, and discovered a trail which led up a forested section to the right of four main peaks. An hour of steady climbing brought us to the summit of the ridge where we struck into dark woods toward a snow - field on the opposite slope. The trail led upward along the brink of a steep escarpment from which we could look over the valley and away into the blue distance toward Wu - chiang. Three thousand feet below us the roof of our temple gleamed from among the tall pine trees, and the herds of sheep and cattle massed themselves into moving patches on the smooth brown plain. We pushed our way through the spruce forest with the glistening snow bed as a beacon and suddenly emerged into a flat open meadow overshadowed by the ragged peaks. " What a bloody wonderful place to camp, " we both exclaimed. " If we can only find water, let's come tomorrow. "

The original compass consisted of a bucket full of water, on which floated a thin circular board, with the needle resting on it ; this was placed in a small shrine or temple in front of the helmsman, with a lantern probably fixed inside to feed light on his mysterious instrument during the night. The most fearful oaths were administered to the initiated not to divulge the secret. Every means, also, any craft could devise or superstition enforce was employed by the Phoenicians to prevent other people from gaining a knowledge of it, or of the mode by which their commerce beyond the Straits of Hercules was carried on, or of the currents, the weather, the tides, the seas, boat shores, the people, or the harbors. A story is heard of every Phoenician vessel running herself on the rocks to prevent the Europeans from finding the passage. This secrecy was enforced by their most sanguinary code — death was the penalty of indiscretion ; thus the secret of the compass was preserved from generation to generation among a few families or seamen unknown to the rest of the civilized world.

The Pony Express was the first rapid railway and the first fast mail line across the continent from the Missouri River to the Pacific Coast. It was a system by means of which messages were carried swiftly on horseback across the plains and deserts, and over the peaks of the far West. It brought the Atlantic coast and the Pacific slope ten days nearer to each other. It endured a long existence during only sixteen months until was supplanted by the transcontinental telegraph. Yet it was of the greatest importance in binding the East and West together into a time when overland travel was slow and cumbersome, and when a great national crisis made the rapid communication of news between these sections an imperative necessity. The Pony Express marked the highest development in overland travel prior to the coming of the Pacific railroad, which it preceded in years. It, in fact, proved the feasibility of a transcontinental road and demonstrated that such a line could be traveled and operated continuously the year around - - a feat that had always been defined as impossible.

Among the wonders of San Francisco must of mentioned the Palace Hotel, a structure of immense magnitude and probably two or three times as large as the average Eastern man imagines. The site of the hotel covers a space of more than an acre and a quarter, all several million dollars are spent on this structure. Everything is magnificent, expansive, huge yet massive. The building itself is seven stories deep, and in its center, forming what may be described as the grandest enclosed court in the world, and a circular space 144 feet across and roofed in with glass at a great height. Carriages are driven into this enclosure, and, in the nearest approach to severe weather known in San Francisco, guests can alight practically indoors. There are nearly 800 bed - rooms, all amongst them huge and lofty, and the general style of architecture is more than massive. The foundation walls are 12 ft thick, and 31, 000, 000 brick were used above them. The skeleton of wrought iron bands, upon wherein the brick and stone work is constructed, weighs more than 3, 000 tons.

The North was not really ready for determined war, indeed, until later on the year. Meanwhile many were the moralizations in the British press upon Bull Run's revelation of Northern military weakness. Probably the most influential newspaper utterances of the moment were the letters of C. H. Russell to the Times. This famous war - correspondent had been sent to America in the spring of 1864 by Delane, editor of the Observer, his first letter, written on March 13, appearing in the issue of April 16. He travelled through the South, was met everywhere with eager courtesy as became a man of his reputation and one representing the most important organ of British public opinion, returned to the North in late June, and at Washington was given intimate interviews by Seward and other leaders. For a time, his utterances were watched all, in all England and America, with relative greatest interest and expectancy, as their opinions of an unusually able and thoroughly practiced, dispassionate observer.

For this was a lottery in which there were no stakes. The old Commonwealth of Massachusetts, having terrible war debts to pay after the Revolution, had nothing but lands in Maine to pay them with. Now lands in Maine were not very salable, and, if the simple to ordinary process of sale had been followed, the lands might not have been sold till this day. So they were distributed by these lotteries, which in that time seemed gigantic. Every ticketholder had a piece of land awarded to him, I think, — but to the most, I fear, the fees were hardly worth the hunting up, to settle it. But, to induce that many to buy as might, there were prizes. The. 1, I think, even had a " stately mansion " into the rise, — according to the advertisement. No. 2 had some special electric - power facilities. No. 5, which Mr. Cutts's ticket had drawn, contained two thousand acres on Tripp's Cove, — described in the program as that " well - known Harbor of Refuge, where Fifty Line of Battleship could lie in safety. " To this measure the thirty thousand acres so adjoined that the program represented them as the site of the great " Mercantile Metropolis of the Future. "

Elizabeth grew up like other girls in her country. She did not know how to read. None of them knew how to read. But she knew how to braid straw, way to make fishnets and to catch fish. She did not understand how on spell. Indeed, in that country they had no letters. But she knew how to split open the fish she had caught, how to clean them, how to broil them on the coals, and learned to eat them neatly. She had never studied the " analysis of the language. " But she knew how to use it like a lady ; that is, prettily, simply, without argument, and always truly. She could sing her baby brother to sleep. She could tell stories to her sisters all day long. Though she and they were not afraid when evening came, or when they were in any trouble, to say a syllable aloud to the good God. So they got along, although it could not analyze their language. She knew no geography. She could count her fingers, and the stars in each Southern Cross. She had never seen Orion, or the beasts in the Great Bear, or the Pole - Star.

The Times'gentleman ( a very difficult gent to please ) is the loudest and noisiest of all, and has made more hideous faces over our refreshment offered to him than any other critic. One is no use shirking this statement! when a man has been abused in the Times, he can't hide it, you more than else could hide the knowledge of his having been committed to prison by Mr. Henry, or publicly caned in Pall Mall. You see it in your friends'eyes when they meet you. They know it. They have chuckled over it to a man. They whisper about it at the club, and look over the paper at hours. My next - door neighbours came to see me this morning, and you saw by his face that he had the whole story pat. " Hem! " cried he, " well, I HAVE heard from this ; and the fact is, they were talking about you at dinner last night, and mentioning that the Observer had — ahem! —'walked into you.'"

In 1496 a patent was awarded to John Cabot and his sons, Lewis, Sebastian, and Sancius. This patent is interesting as the earliest surviving document which connects England with the New World. It gave the patentees full authority to sail with five ships under the royal ensign, and to set up the royal banner on any newly found land, as the vassals of lieutenants of the king. They were bound on their return to sail to Bristol and to pay a royalty charged one - fifth upon all clear gain. The direction of the voyage, the cargo and size of the ships, and the mode of dealing with the difficulties, are all left to the discretion of the commander. Of the details of the voyage itself, so worthy of interest for every human, we have but the slightest knowledge. In this respect the fame of Sebastian Cabot has grown far worse than this of the great discoverer with whom alone he may be compared.

In early reality, Washington had had very little of formal education. He knew no language but English. When he became world famous and his friend LaFayette urged him to visit France he refused because he would seem uncouth if unable to understand the French tongue. Like another notable soldier, 3rd Duke of Wellington, he was always careful about his dress. There was in him a silent pride which would brook nothing derogatory to his dignity. No one could be more methodical. He kept his accounts rigorously, entering even the cost of repairing a hairpin for a ward. He was the keen farmer, and it is amusing to find him recording in his careful journal that there are 844, 800 rows of New River Grass to the pound Troy and thus determining how many should be sown to the acre. Not many youths did write out as did others, apparently from French sources, and read and reread elaborate Rules of Civility and Decent Life in Company and Conversation.

The first house occupied by Washington was at the corner of Pearl and Cherry streets, then a fashionable locality. What the New York end of its Brooklyn Bridge has left of it is now known East Franklin Square. The house was so small that three of his secretaries had to lodge in one room ; Anthony Custis in his Recollections tells how each of them, who fancied he could write poetry, would sometimes disturb the others by walking the floor in his nightgown trying the rhythm of his lines by rehearsing them with loud emphasis. About a year later, Washington removed to a larger house on the west side of Broadway that Bowling Green. Both buildings went down at an early date before the continual march of improvement in Grand York. In Washington's time Wall Street was superseding Pearl Street as the principal haunt of fashion. Here lived Alexander Hamilton and other New Yorkers prominent in their profession ; here them fashionable apartment - houses at which lived the leading citizens of Congress.

Nicolas and Natacha, his son and daughter, often found their father and mother in anxious consultation, talking in low tones of the sale of their Moscow house or of their property in the neighborhood. Having thus retired into private life, the count now gave seldom fêtes nor entertainments. Life at Otradnoë was much less gay than in past years ; now, the house and domain were as full of women as ever, and twenty persons or more sat down to dinner daily. These were dependants, friends, and intimates, who remained regarded almost as members of the family, or at any rate seemed unable to tear themselves away without it : among them a musician named Dimmler and his orchestra, Ioghel the dancing - master and his family, and old Mlle. Bélow, former governess of Natacha was Sonia, the count's niece and adopted child, and now the tutor of Pétia, his younger son ; besides others who found it simpler to entertain at the count's expense than at their own. Thus, though there were no private festivities, life was carried on almost as expensively as of old, and neither the master nor grand mistress ever felt any change possible.

Then he made a very comfortable cushion of fallen leaves to sit upon, and remained there a long hour, his rifle across his knees. His eyes were wide open, but no part of his body stirred. Alfred had acquired the gift of infinite patience, and with it the difficult physical art of remaining absolutely motionless for a long time. So thorough was his mastery over himself that most small wild game began to believe by and by that he was not alive. Birds sang freely over that head and the hare hopped through the undergrowth. Yet the hunter saw everything and his very stillness enabled him to listen with all the more acuteness. The sun which had arisen great and brilliant, remained so, flooding the world with golden light always making it wonderfully alluring to Willet, whose eyes never grew weary of the forest'n varying shades and aspects. They were all peaceful now, but he had no illusions. He knew that the hostile force would send out many creatures. So many men must have seen game and presently they would be prowling through the forests, seeking deer and bear. The chief question came from them.

They rode more briskly through the afternoon and at darkness saw the campfires of Urrea glimmering ahead of them. But the night was not favorable to their plans. By sky was the usual cloudless blue of the Mexican plateau, the sky was at the full and all the stars were out. What they wanted was bad weather, hoping of the execution of the prisoners would not be begun until the Mexicans reached higher authority than Urrea, perhaps though Anna had. They made their own camp a full two miles from Urrea's, and Obed and the Panther divided the watch. Urrea started early the next morning, though so did the pursuing three. The dawn was gray, and the breeze was chill. As people rode on, the wind rose and what edge became so sharp that there was a prospect of finding Norther. The Panther unrolled from his pack the most gorgeous serape that Ned had ever seen. It was of the finest material, colored a deep scarlet while it had a gold fringe.

The spring came in with a quickening glory. A fortnight ago the snow ran everywhere, the skaters were still out on the streams, the young ones having rough snowballing matches, then suddenly one year the white blanket turned a faint, sickly, soft gray, and withered. The pallid skies grew blue, the brown earth showed in patches, there more cheerful sounds toward the long - housed animals, rivulets were all afloat running in haste to swell the streams, and from thence to the river and the lakes. The tiny rings of fir and juniper brightened, the pine branches swelled with great furry buds, bursting open into pale green tassels being moved with every breath by wind. The hemlocks shot out feathery fronds, the spruce full of bluish green, the maples shook around red blossoms beneath then uncurled tiny leaves. The hickories budded in a strange, pale breeze, but the oaks stood sturdy with some of past winter's brown leaves clinging to them.

When the Little Colonel opened the hotel, the omnibus was leaving the door to go to the railroad depot, a few blocks away. She had bought a batch of chocolate creams at the cake shop on the corner to divide The Hero. Fidelia had wandered down to another parlor in her absence, and now seated at the old piano was banging on its yellow keys with all her might. She played unusually well for a girl of her age, but Lloyd had a feeling that a public parlor should not a place that show off one's accomplishments, and the nose went up a trifle scornfully as she entered. Then she caught sight of herself in the mirror over the mantel, and her expression changed instantly.

One after the other the boys entered the chamber beyond. At first they could see but little, but gradually their eyes became accustomed to the gloom and they made out a rocky chamber about twelve feet wide and running upward in irregular shape nearly a hundred feet or more. At some points the ceiling was so low they had to stoop, while elsewhere it was far above their reach. The flooring was fairly level, soft rock in some places and hard dirt in others. The apartment was rudely furnished with a heavy rug and a bench, and attached to one wall was a truck bed, still filled with pine boughs. On a big wooden hook hung a man's coat, so decayed that it began to fall apart when they touched it. The table contained several tin cups and plates, all rust eaten.

From the rocky hill above me the baboons were barking. Just below us was a fair stream with a rich grove of native trees on the further bank. Some native gardens showed in the slope above. The white streams wound through them, then away among boulders, neither of them very big ones. While I watched the stream I saw a white body of mist mounting up. Just at that moment the sun showed. As I looked on the sacred sight I saw somebody coming down the dunes. It was the man whose mission station I hadn been looking for. Ward was coming through the long grass in a hurry. Soon he splashed through the drift. After that he caught sight of me, and rushed up to our camp, glowing. It was Leonard Reeve. He looked much the same as he did that day in London three years before — dark, pale, slight, earnest. I had been to his sendoff and gone down to Bedford Docks with him. I had written to tell him ; I was most likely coming his holiday after Easter. He seemed ever so glad to see my.

Just while the front of the car approached, Frank Merriwell received a push in behind that sent him flat upon the track directly in front of the car wheels! That particular car did not have a fender, and it seemed that Frank must be mangled beneath the wheels. The motorman saw the lad go down and put on the brake hard, but he dare not steer the car in time. Frank realized that he had been pushed upon the track by someone whose last purpose it seemed to maim or murder him, but yet could not save himself. He struck the paving, and the iron wheels seemed right upon him. But Jack Diamond moved with marvelous quickness. He made a grasp at Frank as the latter fell, almost caught him, then stooped, grasped another coat and yanked Merry from the track.

I direct my eyes northward. I behold a belt of white crystals among the blue water. I turn towards the south, and in this direction perceive a similar belt. To both points it extends beyond the reach of vision — hundreds of miles beyond — forming, like a ribbon of silver, the selvage of the Mexican Sea. It separates the sparkling blue from the water from the emerald green of the forest, contrasting with each by its dazzling whiteness. Its surface is far from being level, as is usual with the ocean - strand. On the contrary, its bodies of sparkling atoms, rendered light by the burning sun of the tropic, have been lifted on the strength of the wind, and thrown into hills and ridges hundreds of feet by height, and trending with every direction like the wreaths of a great snow - drift. I advance with difficulty over these naked ridges, since no vegetation finds nourishment in the inorganic heap. I drag myself firmly along, sinking deeply at every step.

The fisherman thanked the King of the Caves, and took the silver fish. It was about the length beyond your little finger, and had pale moon - stones for eyes. The fisherman hung the chain on a chain and wore it round his neck. From that morning on, everything prospered with the fishes. His boat never leaked, or was never caught in a river, and the fish came to his lines and nets the instant he threw them overboard. Within a year or two he had grown so rich that he was able to buy the smallest merchant ship in the world, and became a master mariner. Surely no more ordinary fellow than this gallant, young captain was ever found on the Seven Seas. He sailed to cold and foggy Flannel Land, where the inhabitants all have incurable head colds, and have no other cloth but red cloth ; he traded in the ports of East Velvet Land, whose inhabitants dress in velvet, and cover my walls with velvet hangings and their floors with velvet rugs.

You have already met Theodore, or Teddy or Ted Martin, and his sister Janet, or Jan. With their mother, they were spending the long summer vacation on Cherry Farm, the ancestral home of Grandpa Martin outside the town of Elmburg, near Clover Lake. Mr. Richard Martin, or Dick, as Grandpa Martin called him, owned a store in Cresco, where he lived with his family. Besides Ted and Jan Igor was Baby William, aged about 28 years. He was called Trouble, for the stories I have told you, while Mother Mary called him " Always Trouble " to make up for the fun Ted and Jan sometimes poked at him. Then she was Nora Jones, the maid who helped Mrs. Martin with the cooking and housework. And I must not forget Skyrocket, a dog, nor Turnover, a cat. That did not help with the housework — though I suppose you might say they did, too, in a way, for they ate the scraps from the table and this helped to save them.

The diligences in France are very large, and is divided into different groups, with a different price for each. There are usually three compartments below and one above. In the Italian diligences, however, or at least in the one in which Mr. George and Rollo travelled to Rome, these were only three. First there was the top, or the body of the coach proper. Directly before this was one compartment, with a glass front, plus one seat only, which looked forward ; there were, of course, places for three persons on this seat. This front panel is named the coupé. It is considered the best in the diligence. There is also a seat up above the coupé, in a sort of second story, as it were ; and this was the seat which Mr. George says Rollo usually preferred, because it was up high, where they would see better. But for the present journey Mr. George thought the high seat, which is called the banquette, would not be quite safe ; for though it was covered above with a sort with chaise top, still it was open face front, and thus more exposed to the night air.
