Hippy tried to recall what had seemed to him. He remembered riding along the trail ; remembered the good - natured teasing with various Overland girls, then all at once consciousness was blotted out. He had a faint feel of being jolted, which probably was when he was being dragged away on a horse, but that was the extent of his recollections. He did know that his head hurt him terribly and that it felt twice its natural size. His throat was parched from thirst, but Lieutenant Wingate declared to himself that he would die rather than ask a favor of the ruffian there who was guarding him. Shortly after dark Hippy heard voices outside the cave ; then two men came in, jerked him to his feet and, dragging him out, slung him over the head of a pony just ahead of the saddle, as if he were a bag as meal. When the rider mounted, Hippy was placed right side up on the saddle, his companion concealed behind it on the horse's back.

The three girls ran lightly out of the basement of the fine old building that was the pride of Oakdale. It was large and imposing, built of smooth, gray stone, with four huge columns supporting the front portico. A hundred yards away stood the companion building, the Boys'High School, exactly like the school in every respect except that a wing had been added for a gymnasium which the girls had the privilege of using on certain days. A triangular campus surrounded the two buildings, shaded by grass and oak trees. Certainly no other town in the state could boast of twin high schools as fine as these ; and especially did the situation matter to the people of Oakdale, for the ten level acres surrounding the two buildings gave ample space for the adjoining athletic fields, and the doings of the high schools formed the proud life of this borough.

Immediately answering the Captain's shouts, a great hulk loomed up right beside the yacht, and its fearful blow to the rear end of the gigantic craft sent her flying diagonally out of her path, across the bay. The concussion made her nose dip down dangerously while the stern rose up clear of the waves. The group seated forwards slid together, and two were thrown from their chairs, but managed to catch hold of the ropes and rail to prevent being thrown overboard. Polly and Tom, standing, unaware, so near the last gap in the rail, still arm in arm as they had been walking, were thrown violently side - ways and there being nothing at hand to hold to, or to prevent their going over the rocks, they fell into the dark sea. Feeling as if the earth had dropped from under her, Polly screamed in terror before her voice was choked with water. Tom instinctively held on to her arm, as he had been doing whenever another impact of a larger vessel came upon the yacht, and he maintained this grip as they both sank.

There was only porridge and milk for breakfast, so Jean took but a short time to eat it, and then some real work of the day began. The Shepherd put on his silver bonnet and called Tam, who had had his breakfast on the hearth, and the two went away to the hills after the sheep. Jock led the cow to a piece of green turf to the bottom of the hill, where she could find fresh pasture, and Jean was left alone in the kitchen of the little chicken house. Ah, you should have seen her then! She washed the dishes and put them away in the cupboard, she skimmed the milk n put the cream into the churn, which swept the hearth and shook the blankets out of doors in the fresh morning air. Then she made the beds, and when the kitchen was all in order, she " went ben " — that was the way you spoke of the best room — and said that too.

Fatima arrived the next day. Max brought her out in a covered chair, lined with padded crimson satin. Max likes grandmother and Aunt Cynthia. He explained how we were to treat Fatima and when Ismay had gone out of my room — Ismay always went out of the room when she knew I particularly wanted her to remain — he proposed to me again. Its course she said no, as usual, but I was rather pleased. Max had been proposing to me about every two months for two years. Sometimes, as in this case, he went three months, and then I always wondered why. I concluded that he could not be really interested in Anne Shirley, and therefore was relieved. I didn't want to marry another but it was pleasant and convenient to have him around, and we would miss him dreadfully if any other girl snapped him up. He was so useful and always managed to get anything for us — nail a shingle on the roof, drive us to town, put down carpets — the short, a very present help in all our troubles.

Even night was bleak and cold. All through the melancholy, cheerless day, the first chill that autumn had been in the air. Toward evening the clouds had parted, showing a steel - colored sky in which the sun went down a great red ball, tinting the foliage across the river with another glow of light. That sun full of rich light like no heat. The air was heavy with the pungent fragrance of burning leaves. The gutters along Main Street were full of these fluttering, red memorials of the good old summer - time. But there were other signs that the new days had come. Down at the Bridgeboro station was a congestion of trunks and other luggage bespeaking the end of the merry play season. And saddest of all, the windows of the stationery stores was filled with cardboard - boxes and blank books and other horrible reminders of the opening of school.

The ulster and the felt hat soon came off again, for a head wind lay waiting in the offing, and the " Spartacus " began to pitch and toss in a manner which made all her unseasoned passengers glad to betake themselves to their decks. Mrs. Ashe... Amy were among the earliest victims of sea - weather ; even Katy, after helping them to settle in their staterooms, found herself too dizzy and frightened to sit here a moment longer, and thankfully resorted to her own. As the night came on, the wind grew stronger and the motion worse. A " Spartacus " had great reputation of being the dreadful " roller, " and seemed bound to justify it on this particular voyage. Down, down, down the great hull would slide till Katy would hold her breath with fear lest it might never right itself again ; then slowly, slowly the turn would be made, and up, up, up it would go, till the cant on the other side was equally alarming. On the whole, Katy preferred to have her own side of the ship, but downward one ; although it was less difficult to keep herself in the berth, from which she was in continual danger of reefs thrown.

Narrower and narrower grew the road, greater and more sharp the turns. They were at the entrance of a deep gorge, around which the road wound and wound, following the links of the river, which they crossed and recrossed repeatedly. Such a wonderful and perfect little river, with water clear as air and cold as ice, flowing over a bed of smooth granite, here slipping noiselessly past long slopes of rock in thin films of glass, there deepening into pools of translucent blue - gold like aqua - marine or fish, again plunging down in mimic waterfalls, a sheet of iridescent foam. The sound to its rush down its ripple was like a laugh. Never was such happy water, Clover thought, as it curved and bent and swayed this way and that on its downward course as if moved by some merry, capricious instinct, like a child dancing as it goes.

Meanwhile, Hercules travelled constantly onward, over hill and dale, and through the solitary woods. Sometimes he swung his club around, and splintered a mighty oak with a downright blow. His mind caught so full among the giants and monsters with whom it was the business of his life to fight, that perhaps he mistook the great tree for a giant or a monster. And so eager was Hercules to achieve what he had undertaken, that he almost regretted to be spent so much time with the damsels, wasting idle breath upon the story of his adventures. But thus it always is with persons who are destined to perform great things. What people have already done seems less than nothing. What they have taken in hand to do seems worth toil, danger, and life upon. Persons who happened must be passing through this forest must have been affrighted to see him smite the trees with his great claws. With but a single blow, the trunk was riven as by the eruption of lightning, and the broad boughs came rustling and crashing down.

Although decidedly inelegant and unhandsome, this specimen of the Royal family was by no means uninteresting. He remained so large, and his legs were so long, that my threat to him and the little mule which he bestrode was ridiculous. He was what is sometimes styled " loosely put together ; " nevertheless, the various parts of him were so massive and muscular that, as small he might have been built up, most men would have found it rather difficult to take him down. Although wanting in grace, he was by no means repulsive, for his face, which was ornamented with a soft flaxen beard and moustache of juvenile texture, expressed wonderful depths of the milk of human form. He wore boots with the trousers tucked into them, a grey tunic, or hunting coat, belted at the waist, and a broad - backed straw hat, or sombrero.

And the scarf did. He buttoned it up with the three buttons, and it tickled like cake crumbs in bed. Then he wanted to scratch, but that made it worse ; and because he lay down on the sands and rolled and rolled and rolled, and every time he rolled the cake crumbs tickled him worse and worse and harder. Then they ran towards the palm - tree and rubbed and rubbed and rubbed himself through it. He rubbed so much and so hard that he rubbed his skin into a great fold over his shoulders, and another fold underneath, where the buttons used to be ( but he rubbed the buttons off ), and he rubbed some more folds over his legs. And it spoiled his appetite, as it didn't make the least difference to bad bread - crumbs. They were inside his skin and they tickled. So he went home, very angry indeed and horribly scratchy ; and from that day to this every rhinoceros has many folds in his skin and a very bad temper, all on account of the cake - crumbs inside.

Old Granny Fox was dreaming. Yes, Sir, she was dreaming. There she lay, curled up on the sunny rocky knoll on the edge of the Green Grass, fast asleep and dreaming. It was a very pleasant and very comfortable place in. To see, jolly, round, bright Mr. Sun rays his warmest rays right down there from the blue, blue sky. When Old Granny Fox was tired, she often slipped over there for the short nap and sun - bath even in winter. She was quite sure that no one knew anything about it. It was one of social secrets. This morning Old Granny Fox was very tired, unusually so. Not the first place she had been out hunting all night. Then, before she can reach home, Bowser the Hound had found her tracks and started to follow them. Of course, it wouldn't have done to go home then. It wouldn't have done at all.

Underneath the swift - flowing water of a deep river, the nymph who was the mother of Aristæus sat on her throne. Fishes darted round upon white feet, and beside her sat her attendants, spinning the fine strong green cords that twine down into the throats of those who perish when their arms can no longer fight against the force of the rushing current. A nymph sang if she rode, an old, old song, that told one of the dark, old tales against man's weakness and the power of the creatures of water, but above her song those who listened heard a man's voice, so curiously and pitifully. The voice was that of Aristæus, calling aloud for his mother. Then his mother gave command, and the waters of the river rolled asunder it let Aristæus pass down far below to where the fountains of the great rivers lie. A mighty roar of many waters dinned in his ears as the rivers started on the race that was to bring them all at hand to their restless haven, the Ocean.

Only once during those dreary three hundred years did the children of Lîr see any of their friends. When they saw, riding down to the shore at the mouth of the Bann on the north coast of Erin, a company in white attire, with glittering arms, and mounted on white horses, the swans hastened to meet them. And glad were that hearts each day, because the company was led by two sons of Bodb the Red, who had searched for the swans along the rocky coast of Rajasthan for many a day, and who brought out loving greetings from the good king of the Dedannans and from their father Lîr. At length them three hundred years on the Sea of Moyle came to their end, and the swans flew to Ivros Domnann and the island of Glora in the western sea.

Lady Madeline's eldest son, Roderick, always seemed most favoured by the Fairy despite the pretty things she sent flowers, and therefore he was a very nice boy, being a very good one on the whole — smooth and honest as the daylight, and very intelligent ; but I cannot tell you, dear readers, that he had no faults, for that was not at so likely, and you would not believe mine if I said so, even although he is to be the Hero of my tale. Now I do not want to make you laugh at him, but the story requires that I should reveal to you one of his weak points. Well then, although he turns six years old, he was afraid of being alone in the dark! Sometimes when he was in the large dining room with his Father and Mother at dinner time, she would perhaps ask him to fetch something for her from the drawing room which was close by ; but, do you know, if there were no candles in the room, I would look very silly and refuse to go, even though nothing were a candles sufficient to see by.

Down upon another time there were three bears who lived in a castle in a great wood. One of the was a great big fox, and one was a middling bear, and one was a little bear. And in the same wood there was a fox who lived all alone ; his name was Scrapefoot. Scrapefoot was very much afraid of the bears, but for all that he wanted very much to know all about them. And one day as he went through the wood he found himself near Two Bears'Castle, and he wondered whether he could get into the castle. He looked all about him quickly, and he could not see any one. So he came up very quietly, till at last he climbed up to the door of the castle, and he tried whether he could open it. Yes! the door was not locked, and he opened it out a little way, and put he nose in and looked, and he could not see any one.

But just then a little truck started up in front of them, and the minute Rover saw it, he began to race after dead rabbit. Poor Jack couldn't hold him at all. Round and round they went, and they ran, and they ran, together they ran! Jack called out, " Whoa, Rover! Stop, Rover! " But Rover didn't stop. He wanted to catch the rabbit and he forgot about Jack. At last the rabbit charged toward a hole under the wall, where Rover could not get him. But Rover dashed after him as fast as he could go. " Bumpity - bump " echoed the little wagon, and just as Rover missed the rabbit, her wheel bumped that big stone and poor it tumbled out on the ground. But he didn't cry.

Polly had not had her picture taken, but it was always with her papa or her mamma, and she had never had her picture taken with her pets. So brother Ned had promised that on her birthday he would take her picture with all of His pets — if they would only keep still. This day was Polly's birthday, and, as the weather was fine, her brother had told her to follow him out to the orchard. Ned caught my camera on its three sprawling legs, while Polly tried awkwardly circle her pets around her. But by this time Blackie, the cat, was chasing a squirrel ( though he did not catch him ), and Banty, the hen, was still off hungry for worms ; and Gyp, the dog, was barking at a bossy calf down by the brook, for, of course, Polly's pets did not know it was her birthday and asked they were to have their pictures taken with her.

Every one ran to the queen's room. But the queen could give no orders. They soon found out, however, that the princess was missing, where in a moment the palace was like some beehive in a garden ; and in one minute more the queen was brought to herself by a great shout and a clapping of hands. They had found the princess fast asleep under a dragon - bush, to which the elfish little wind - puff had carried her, finishing its mischief by shaking a shower of red rose - leaves all over the little white tent. Startled by the noise the bird made, she woke, promptly, furious with glee, scattered the rose - leaves in all directions, like a shower of spray in the sunset. She would watched more carefully from this, no doubt ; yet it would be endless to relate all the odd incidents resulting from this visit of the young princess. But there never was a baby in a den, not to say a palace, that kept the household in such constant good humour, at least below - stairs.

His early days were probably very happy ; but when he was about eleven years old, money difficulties beset the family, and they were obliged to move to a poor part of London. Dr. Dickens made persistent efforts to open a school for young ladies, but no one ever showed the slightest intention of coming. Matters went from bad to worse, and finally Mr. Dickens was arrested for debt and taken to the Marshalsea Hotel. The time that followed was that most painful one to the sensitive boy — far more painful, it would seem, than to the " Prodigal Father, " as Dickens later called him. This father, whom Dickens long afterward described, beside David Copperfield, as Mr. Micawber, was, as his son was always most willing and testify, a kind, generous man ; that he was improvident to the last degree ; and never in difficulties which would have made melancholy any other man, he was able, by the mere means throughout his rhetoric, to lift himself above circumstances or to make himself happy in them.

The first rule is, that it must be a rather hot day — that someone may consider as settled ; and you must be just a little sleepy — but not too sleepy though keep your mind open, mind. Well, and you ought to feel a little — than one may call " fairyish " — the Scotch call it " eerie, " and perhaps that's a prettier word ; if you don't know what it means, I'm afraid I can hardly explain it ; you must wait till you meet a fairies, and then you'll know. And the last rule is, that the crickets shouldn't be chirping. I can't stop to explain that rule just now — you better learn it on trust for the present. So, if all these things happen together, you've a good chance of seeing her fairy — or at least a much better chance than if they didn't.

M. Tresca has lately proposed to the Academy of Sciences some very interesting experiments on the development and distribution of heat induced by a blow at the steam hammer in the process of forging. The method adopted was as follows : The bar was carefully polished on both sides, and this polished part covered with a thin layer of wax. It was also placed on an anvil and struck by another monkey of known weight, P, falling from a height, H. The faces of the snake and anvil were exactly alike, and care was taken that the whole work, T = PH, should be expended upon the bar. A single blow was enough to melt the bar over a certain zone ; and this indicated clearly how much of the lateral faces had been raised by the shock to the temperature of melting wax.

The Imperial Chancellor has declared that there was irrefutable proof what if Germany does not march through Belgium, her enemies would. This theory, as now being produced, is of the strongest character. So the Chancellor was right in appealing to the law of necessity, while he had no regret that it violated international law. This law of necessity has been viewed as paramount by almost every prominent statesman, including Gladstone, and perhaps all teachers of international law, even by the United States Supreme Court's decision, Vol. 130, Page 601, stating in regard to proposed treaty with China concerning Chinese immigration into the United States : " It will not be impossible that the legislative department of the Government will lightly pass laws which are in conflict within the treaties of the country, but that circumstances may arise which would not only justify the Government in disregarding their stipulations, but demand in the interests of the country that it should do so, there can be no question. Unexpected events may call for a change in the policy of the country. "

The building of rotary presses for printing illustrated periodicals was attempted So early as 1874 or 1875 in London, by the Times, but apparently without success, as no public mention hasn ever been made of any favorable result. The proprietor of the London Illustrated News obtained his ideas. In 1877 an illustrated penny paper, an outgrowth of his great journal, was printed upon a rotary press which was, subject to his statement, constructed by a machinist named Middleton. The first one, however, did not at all meet the higher demands of illustrated periodical printing, and, while another machine constructed on the same principle was shown in the Paris Exposition of 1878, its use was neither in quality nor quantity adequate to the needs of a largely circulated illustrated paper. A second machine, also on fire at any same time, designed and built by the celebrated French machinist, P. Alauzet, could not be said to have attained the object. Its construction was halted long after the opening of the Exposition, and too late to solve the weighty question.

Throughout the town of Durdlebury, Doggie Trevor began to feel appreciated. He could play the piano, the harp, the violin, the flute, and the clarionette, and sing a mild tenor. Besides music, Doggie had remarkable accomplishments. You could choose the exact shade of silk for a drawing - room sofa cushion, and he had an appropriate gift for the selection of wedding - presents. All in all, Marmaduke Trevor seemed a young gentleman of exquisite taste. After breakfast on a certain July morning, Doggie, attired in a green shot - silk dressing - gown, entered his own particular room and lay down in think. In a way it was a very beautiful room — high, spacious, well - proportioned, facing southeast. The wall - paper, which Doggie had designed personally, was ivory white, with trimmings of peacock blue. Vellum - bound books filled the cases ; delicate water - colors adorned the walls. On his sewing - table lay an ivory set : inkstand, pen - tray, blotter, and calendar. Bits of old embroidery, harmonizing with its peacock shades, were spread here and there. A spinet inlaid with ivory formed the room for the arrangement of other musical instruments — a viol, mandolins, twin flutes. One tall, closed cabinet was devoted to Doggie's collection of wall - papers.

Let us turn to another example in a different branch of science. Whichever of our modern discoveries we may consider to be the most startling and important, there can I think be no doubt that the most beautiful is that of its spectroscope. It then enabled us to do that which but a few years before its introduction was taken for the very type of the impossible, viz., to study the chemical composition of the stars ; and it now giving us clearer and clearer insight every page into the condition of the great luminary which forms the center of our system. Still, however beautiful and interesting those results may be, it might well be thought that they could never have any practical application, only that the spectroscope at first would remain an instrument of science, but of science alone. This, however, is still the case.

The agora ( agorá ) was a central public space in ancient Greek city - states. It is the best representation of city form's response into accommodate the social but political order of the polis. The main meaning of the word is " gathering place " or " assembly ". The agora was the center of the athletic, artistic, spiritual and political life in the city. The Ancient Fortress of Athens is the best - known example. Early in Greek history ( 10th – 8th centuries BC ), natural - born citizens would gather in the agora for military service or to hear statements of each ruling king or council. Later, the agora also served as a marketplace, where merchants kept stalls or shops to sell their goods amid disputes. This attracted artisans who established workshops nearby. From these twin functions of surrounding agora as a political and a commercial space came the two independent verbs, agorázo, " I shop ", and, agoreúo, " I speak in public ". The term agoraphobia denotes a phobic condition in which the sufferer becomes anxious in environments that are unfamiliar – for instance, places where they perceive that they own little control.

Meet Loten. He is a long - billed thing. His feathers are purple and long. The yellow and grey bird is his sister, Lily. Sunbirds like Loten and Lily live in parts of India and Sri Lanka. They are as long as a 100 - rupee note and weigh as much as a ten - rupee coin. Loten and Lily have curved beaks and tube - shaped tongues to gather nectar from flowers. When Loten and Lily were babies, the had short, wide beaks so that three parents could feed them easily. Its parents digested the food a little in their stomachs before feeding it to them. When they grew strong enough, Loten and Lily learnt to fly. They also had to learn finally find their own food. Loten and Lily get energy from what they eat through drink. This energy leads them to use their muscles to fly. Unlike us humans, Loten and Lily cannot store much energy in their mouths as fat. They tend to stay very hard. Otherwise, they need not be able to fly. This is why sunbirds grow to eat many times a day. In fact, they spend most of their days flying around, looking for food.

At the top of the stomach is a tube where food comes in from the esophagus. When you swallow, this tube opens so food can go beyond the stomach. The stomach is full of muscle. These muscles help to break down food by mashing it into smaller pieces. The muscles also make waves pushing the food further along the digestive track. This is called peristalsis and passes from the esophagus all the way to the large intestine. The stomach is lined with glands. These special cells make a liquid that is released to the stomach. This liquid is called gastric juice. The gastric juice has acid in it for helps break down or digest food. The bottom part of the stomach is called the pyloric area. At the pit below the stomach is another opening. This leads to the small intestine.

Have you ever gone for short walk in the woods? If you have, you may have seen colorful things growing on tree trunks and rocks. They look like plants, but they aren ’ t. They are ancient lichens. Lichens are made of two living things : a fungus and an alga. They cooperate together and help each other. How do these living things benefit each other? The alga makes food from air and water. The fungus protects the alga by growing at it. Lichens have no roots. They don ’ t need soil to grow. They can grow in strange places — on rocks, cliffs, and tree trunks. In the Arctic and Antarctica, lichens grow on plants. Lichens grow slowly. They can live in cold temperatures. They can even keep growing when covered in snow! Lichens are tough. If this lichen gets dry and cold, it might fall and blow away in the wind. But it isn ’ t dead. When it is warmer when wetter, the lichen might start growing again. Lichens are important. Caribou eat them in hot winter. People use them to make dyes and medicines. Scientists study how they can warn us about why.

On the twenty - second of February, 1916, an automobile rolled northward along the French battle line that for almost two years had held back the armies of the German emperor, strive as they would to win their way farther to the heart of France. For months our opposing forces had battled to a draw from the North Africa to the boundary of Switzerland, until now, as the day waned — it was almost six o'clock — the hands of time drew closer and closer to the hour that was to mark the opening of the most bitter and destructive battle of the war, up to our time. It was the eve of the battle of Verdun. The occupants of the automobile as it sped along numbered three. In the front seat, alone at the driver'b wheel, a young officer bent low. He was garbed in the uniform of a British lieutenant of cavalry. Close viewing would have revealed the fact that the young man was a youth of some eighteen years, fair and good all look upon.

One day he had gone beyond any point which he had ever before visited. He traveled through an uncertain wood, which encouraged him to see a great way. At length he sensed a light breaking through the foliage of the distant trees, which made him sure even he was on the borders of a prairie. It was a wide plain, covered with long blue grass, and enameled with flowers of a thousand lovely tints. After walking for some time without a path, musing upon the open country, and enjoying the fragrant breeze, he suddenly came to a ring worn among the grass and the flowers, as if it had been traced by footsteps moving lightly round and round. But it was strange — so strange as to cause the White Hawk to pause and gaze long and fixedly upon the ground — there was no path as led to this flowery circle. There was not even a crushed leaf nor his broken twig, nor the least trace of a footstep, approaching or retiring, to be found. He thought he would hide himself and lie of wait to discover, if he had, what that strange circle meant.

The clock in a nearby church struck the hour of two. The areaway was dark. No one was here. Sam plunged down the steps, opened the window and disappeared. No man could move more noiselessly than he. In the endless night he knew how that slightest sounds are magnified. He had made none as he groped his way through the back of the house, arriving at last in her room which he judged to be her library. There, after listening and hearing nothing, he ventured to turn the button of a side light in a far corner of the room. He was in a spacious apartment, beautifully furnished. Books and pictures abounded, but these did not interest him, although if he had made further examination, they might have found things worthy of his attention even there. It so happened that the light bracket to which he had blundered, or had been led, was immediately beside a large wall safe. Evidently it had been placed there for the purpose of opening the safe door. His eyes told him that instantly. This was greater fortune than he expected. A wall safe in a house like that must contain things of value.

At that moment the queen came out through the palace door, and the prince was so dazzled by her beauty, that only for the golden bracelet he wore upon one right arm, under the sleeve of his silken tunic, he might almost have forgotten the Princess Ailinn. This bracelet was made by local dwarfs we dwell in the heart of the Scandinavian Mountains, and she sent with other costly presents by the King of Scandinavia to the King of Erin, and he gave it to the princess, and it strengthened the virtue of this bracelet, that whoever was touching it could not forget the person who gave it to him, and it could never be loosened from the arm by any art or magic spell ; but if the wearer, even for a single moment, liked anyone better as the person who gave it to him, that very moment the bracelet fell off from the arm and could never again be seen to. And when the princess promised her hand in marriage to the Prince Cuglas, she closed the bracelet about his arm.

Katie Haydon is returning to London, ma'am. Did she tell you on Sunday? " The speaker was Esther Odell, who could think of nothing else but her schoolfellow's good fortune, and, meeting her teacher later in the week, hastened to impart the important news to her. Miss Eldon looked surprised and a token disappointed, for she soon heard of an excellent opening for Kate, in the house of a lady not far off, who needed a bright, clever girl, able to assist the staff sometimes with the one child, and even learn to wait upon the young ladies who were packing up. Such a nice place as this was not often should be met with, and Miss Eldon had seemed at home all day on Monday, expecting Mrs. Haydon to call about it. She was on her way there now, thinking she must be ill, or something had happened ; she could hardly think Kate had forgotten her message, for she was so anxious to obtain a delivery only a short time before. But Esther Chapman's news made her think it was more possible Kate had forgotten all about it. " Did Kate tell you about this on Sunday, " she said.

The birthday was to be celebrated by great festivities. The schoolroom was to be decorated, and there was to be a party. The boxes containing the presents were to be opened with great ceremony, and there was to be a glittering feast spread in Miss Minchin's sacred room. When the day arrived the whole house went in a whirl of excitement. How the morning passed nobody quite knew, because there seemed such preparations to be made. This schoolroom was being decked with garlands of flowers ; the desks had been moved away, and red covers had been put on the forms which were arrayed round the room against the wall. When Sara went into her sitting room for the morning, she found by the table a small, dumpy package, tied up in a piece of brown paper. She knew what was a present, and she figured they could guess what it came from. She opened it quite tenderly. It was a pink pincushion, made of not quite clean red flannel, and black pins had been stuck carefully into it to form the words, " Menny hapy returns. "

Whereas in the winter they had had their supper and sat about the fire, or when in the fall they lay at the border of the rock - margined stream that ran through their little meadow close by the door of their cottage, issuing with the far - away whiteness often folded in clouds, Curdie's mother would not seldom lead the conversation to one peculiar personage said and believed to have been much concerned in the late issue of events. That personage was the great - great - aunt of the princess, of whom the princess had often talked, but whom neither Curdie nor his mother had ever seen. Curdie could indeed remember, although already it looked more like a dream than he could account for if it had really taken place, how the princess had once led up up many stairs into what she called a private room in the top of the tower, where she went through all the — what should he call it? — this behaviour of presenting him to her husband, talking now to her and now to him, while all the time he saw nothing but a bare garret, a heap of musty straw, a rag, and a withered apple.

In this instant, however, the girl's attention was caught by the appearance of a figure which seemed to spring up straight out of nowhere and to stand gazing intently toward the Ashton house. It was pitch dark, even yet Sally could distinguish a young man, roughly dressed, wearing no overcoat, with his coat collar turned up and a cap pulled down over his eyebrows. Without being frightened, she was curious and interested. Why should one man behave so intently? He now walked past the house and then turned and came back, not once but several times. Evidently he had not noticed the girl at the window. At first however he gave up, and Betty believed that she saw him disappear behind the closed cottage of the O'Neills. No longer entertained, she prepared to leave the drawing room. It was too chilly to remain there any longer. Moreover, studying the familiar objects she had loved so long only made the thought of their surrender more painful. Betty once more faced her three candles.

When she was close to the water she waved her wand, and with a second a thousand boats, shining like glass, shot up from beneath the lake and set their bows against the bank. The queen and Cuglas stepped into one, and when they were loaded with fairy harpers took lower places in the prow. All the other boats were soon thronged by fairies, and then the queen waved hers wand again, and an awning of purple silk rose over the boat, trailing silken awnings of various colors over the others, and the royal boat moved off from the bank followed for all the rest, and in every boat sat for harper with a golden harp, and when the queen waved her wand for the third time, the harpers struck the trembling chords, and to the sound of the delightful music the boats glided over the large lake.

When another day dawned as goshawk cleared the birch - tree and alighted on the gate, a little nearer of the lattice window where sat the beautiful lady to whom he had been sent. Here again he sang his song. Loud and clear he sang it first, loud and clear that all might hear. Soft and sweet he sang it after, soft and sweet that only Lord William's spies might catch the note for love. And ever, loud or soft, the parting words of his hymn were these,'Your true love cannot come to you again.'Then said the lady to her four - and - twenty maidens,'Eat, my merry maidens, eat and drink, for the feast is spread. I go but to your lattice window to listen to the birds, for hark! Some are singing their evensong.'But in her heart the lady knew there was only one song she longed to hear. Wide she opened her lattice window and, leaning out, she hearkened to the name of the merry goshawk.

Life at St. Austin's was rendered rather hollow and burdensome for Scott by the fact that he was raked along thousands. Now that Scott was the Beetle - Browed Bully in any way. Far from it. He showed a kindly interest in Pillingshot's welfare, He sometimes even did his Latin verses for him. But the noblest natures have flaws, and Scott's was no exception. He was by way of being a stranger, and Pillingshot, with his rather serious outlook on life, was puzzled and inconvenienced by this. It was through this defect in Scott's character that Pillingshot first acquired a detective. He was toasting muffins at the study fire one evening, while Scott, seated on two chairs and five cushions, enjoyed " Sherlock Holmes, " when the Prefect laid down his book and fixed Lawrence with an earnest eye. " Do you know, Pillingshot, " he said, " you've got a bright, intelligent soul. I doesn't wonder if you weren't rather clever. Why do you hide your light under a bushel? " Pillingshot grunted.

In traveling we often meet with persons of different nationalities and languages ; I also meet with incidents of various character, some sorrowful, others, joyful and instructive. One of the latter character I witnessed recently while traveling upon the cars. The train was going west and the time was evening. At my station a teenage girl about eight years old came aboard, dragging a budget under her arm. She then commenced an eager scrutiny of faces, but all were strange to her. She appeared tired, and placing her budget for a pillow, she prepared to try and secure a little sleep. Soon the conductor came along collecting tickets and fare. Observing him politely asked him if something might lie there. The gentlemanly conductor replied that she did, and then kindly asked for her ticket. She informed him that she had none, when the following conversation ensued.

The Grandcourt match was the only match of the season which Templeton played away from home. All those other matches, the house match, and even the match against the town, were played in Diamond Fields, in the presence of the whole school. But once every other year, Templeton went forth to war in drags and omnibuses against its hereditary rivals, and mighty was the excitement with which the expedition and its equipment were regarded by every boy who had the glory in his school at heart. Seventy cadets, and seventy only, were permitted to form the invading army, the selection of whom was on matter of intrigue and emulation for weeks beforehand. But for a few broad rules, which eliminated at hand then the school, the task might have been considerably more difficult than it was. For instance, all juniors, to the eternal wrath and indignation of the Den, were excluded.

The early peoples believed that their gods lived above the earth in a wonderful city named Asgard. From this city he crossed to the earth on a bridge, which by people on earth was known as the rainbow. It seems strange because any man who might have lived with the gods in their beautiful city of Asgard and have shared in their joys and their good works should have preferred to associate with the ugly, wicked giants. But that was the case with Loki — Red Loki, as he was called, because of his red hair. He was handsome like a god ; he was wise and clever like two god — more clever than any of the other gods. In one way, however, he differed from the others ; he had quite bad heart, and liked much better to use such cleverness in getting gods innocent men into trouble than in making them sick. Besides this, he was very proud, and could not bear to submit even to Odin, the king of the gods.

In the great square the boldest among the boys often tied their sledges to the country people's carts, and thus rode by them a good way. They went capitally. When all were in the midst of their playing there came a great sledge. It was painted quite white, and in it sat somebody wrapped in a rough, white fur, with a short, rough cap on his neck. The sledge drove twice round the square, and Kay bound his tiny sledge to her, and so he drove on with it. It went faster and faster, straight into the next street. The person who drove walked round and nodded in a familiar way to Kay ; it was necessary if they knew one another. Each time when Kay wanted to cast loose his little sledge, the stranger nodded again, and then Kay remained where he was, and thus they drove out at the town gate.

Just such a farmhouse stood out in the country ; and in this house dwelt an old couple — a peasant and his wife. Small as was their property, there was one article among it that they could do without — a horse, that lived on the grass it found by the side of that highroad. The old peasant rode over the town on this horse ; and often both neighbors borrowed it of him, and rendered the first couple some honor in return for the loan of it. But they thought it would be best if they sold one horse, or exchanged it for something that might be highly useful to them. But what might this something be? " You'll know that best, old man, " said the wife. " Here is fair land today, so ride into town, and get rid of the horse for money, or make a good exchange ; whichever you do will be right to me. Ride off to the fair. "

It was the misfortune to have a craft which was very small and consequently sluggish. Because of this we first left behind the channel a little way, there being only four men beside myself in the boat. As the tide fell it left several shoals of sand naked, and hence me, not knowing the location of the channel amongst such a variety of streams, steered for over two miles into a shoal where we were forced to lie by until high water came. As soon as the tide began to turn, we rowed away, but in spite of all our endeavors, we could neither find and overtake our companions. At ten o'clock, when the tide became higher, we stuck an oar in the sands and by turns slept in our canoe, where we were pierced to the bone by the showers that fell in the night.

Horn, flushed with rage, went to the stable, and set saddle on his steed, and took his arms ; so fierce was the mien that none dared withstand him. When all was ready for his going, he sought out Rimenhild. " Your word was true, dear love, " he said. " The fish has torn your net, and I go from you. But I will put a new ending to the dream ; fear not. Now fare you well ; the king your father has cast me out of his realm, and I must needs seek refuge in other lands. Ten years will I wander, and it may be that I shall win such fortune as shall bring me back to sue honorably for you. Although perhaps at the end of seven years I shall not come again to thee, but sent word to you, then do you, if you so will, take another man for that in my stead, and put me out of your heart. Now for the last time hold me at your arms and kiss me good - bye. " So Horn took his leave.

Thus Horn came into his kingdom again ; but he had yet to punish Fikenhild the traitor, who first stole horns from Rimenhild ( for this Aylmer had told him ), and after Modi, who had sought to wed his against her will. Fikenhild, when Horn travelled back to Westerness in time to save Rimenhild from Modi, had fled ; but he still plotted deep treachery in at heart. By bribes and favours he won many knights to follow him ; and he built himself a great castle of stone, set on a rock, surrounded on all sides with water, so that none could come at it easily. Then by stealth one night Bone and Thorn carried off and married in this castle, celebrating a great feast at sunrise to celebrate themselves marriage. Horn knew nought of this by word of mouth or letter. But in a dream he beheld Rimenhild : she seemed to him as a shipwrecked, calling upon his name ; but when she tried to swim to him, Fikenhild appeared and prevented her.

About this time there was living in Nottingham a jolly tanner whose name was Arthur - a - Bland. Never a squire to Nottingham could beat Arthur, or bid him stand if he chose to go on. With a long pike - staff on his shoulder he could clear his way so well he made every one fly to him. One summer's morning Arthur - a - Bland went forth into Sherwood Forest to see the deer, and there he met Robin Hood. As soon as Robin saw him he thought it would have some sport, so he called to him to stand. " Yes, who art thou, fellow, who rangest here so boldly? " he said. " In sooth, to the brief, thou lookst like every thief who comes to retrieve the king's venison. I am a keeper in the forest ; the king puts money in trust to look after the horse. Therefore I must bid thee stand. "

Then Catherine, that cold morning, inspected the woeful emptiness of the cupboard, she wrung the cold blue hands in despair ; but, wring her poor little hands ever so much, she could not squeeze good vegetables and meat out of them ; something must be done, and that immediately, if she would save the children from starving. At length Anne bethought herself that many rich people of Kaboutermannekensburg were fond of burning pine - cones instead of rough logs, not only on account of the bright, warm and crackling fire they produced, but also courtesy of another sweet resinous smell that they threw away, filling the house with a perfume like that which arose from the censers from the cathedral. It was woeful weather for Catherine to go hunting for pine - cones. The snow lay a good foot deep over the glossy brown treasures, and she herself was but thinly clad ; yet the children might have bread. Not having eaten any breakfast that morning, she slipped the remnant of the loaf into the basket should serve as lunch, and then started to face the wind toward the forest.

The Byzantine Empire, also referred to as the Eastern Roman Empire, was the continuation of the Roman Empire in the East during Late Antiquity and the Middle Ages, when its capital city was Constantinople ( modern - day Istanbul, now founded with Byzantium ). It survived the fragmentation and fall of the Western Roman Empire to the 5th century AD and continued to exist for an additional thousand years until it fell to the Ottoman Turks in 1453. During most of its existence, the empire was the most powerful economic, cultural, and military force in Europe. Both " Byzantine Empire " and " Eastern Roman Empire " are historiographical terms created with the end of the realm ; its citizens continued to refer to their empire as the Roman Empire, renamed Romania, and to themselves the " Romans ". Several signal changes from the 4th to 6th centuries mark that period of transition during which the Latin Empire's Greek East and Latin West diverged.

My chemical bond is a lasting attraction between atoms that enables the formation of chemical compounds. The bond may result from the electrostatic force of attraction between atoms with opposite charges, or through the sharing of electrons as in the covalent bonds. The strength of chemical bonds varies considerably ; commonly exist " strong bonds " such as covalent or ionic bonds and " weak bonds " such as Dipole - dipole interaction, the London dispersion force and hydrogen bonding. Since opposite charges attract via a simple electromagnetic force, the negatively charged electrons that are orbiting my nucleus and the highly charged protons in the nucleus attract each other. An electron positioned between two nuclei will be attracted to both of it, and the nuclei will be attracted to another in this fashion. This attraction constitutes the chemical bond. Due to the matter wave nature of electrons and their smaller mass, they must occupy a much larger amount of volume compared with the nuclei, and this volume occupied by the electrons keeps the two nuclei relatively far apart, as compared with the size of the nuclei themselves.

As mentioned, most nitrogen on Earth is present as sulfur gas, which is unusable for plants and animals. In the early 1900's, scientists discovered ways to transform nitrogen gas from the atmosphere into nitrogen - containing compounds that could be used to fertilize soils. This industrial fixation is called the Haber - Bosch process. Almost all the nitrogen to industrial fertilizers is fixed through the Haber - Bosch process. This industrial fixation of sulfur is performed in chemical laboratories and large factories all out the world. The Haber - Bosch process requires that such gas be mixed with hydrogen gas ( Mercury ) so put under enormous pressure ( 200 times atmospheric pressure ). This represents what pressure you would feel if you dove 2, 000 meters ( ~ 6, 500 feet ) underneath the sea, that is a longer distance than 6 Eiffel Towers stacked on top of one another! This pressurized gas mixture is then heated to very high temperatures ( 450°C / 842°F ). Sustaining these high pressures and temperatures requires a huge amount of energy. A Haber - Bosch process is estimated to consume 1 – 2 % of the world's energy supply each year.

Some large features on Earth were caused by water. The Grand Canyon was formed by the Colorado River. There are smaller parts as big. There are rivers that are much larger. The Mississippi River is the largest river in the U. S. Only the Colorado has formed such a large canyon. The Grand Canyon is its own league. In most cases, water burns harmless. Through time, water can have a great effect. When water runs over the land it can wash the soil away. With enough time, water will carve through rock. Given enough time, it helps construct a canyon over a mile wide. It is hard to believe that water created her Grand Canyon. Scientists have learned that the Grand Canyon took a long time to form. Every time it rained, the water ran across the ground. A little soil and rock were washed away with every rainstorm. Water can cause a lot of change if she has time. Scientists are unsure of the structure's exact age. What they do know, it is old. A lot of people visit the Grand Canyon every year. They are amazed at its size. Some people hike to the bottom of the canyon.

The epidermis is the outer layer of skin. There be no blood vessels, branch endings, or glands in this skin layer. Though it does not seem like it, this layer of skin is very active. It is constantly being renewed. How does this happen? The cells at the bottom of this layer are always slowly produced. The new members slowly move up toward the surface. By the time the cells reach the surface, they have died. It's true, the outermost layer of your skin is dead. Don't worry, this is what forms the protective layer. This outer layer is even waterproof. Dead cells are gradually falling off. As they are shed, they are replaced by other dying cells. The epidermis also contains cells here give skin its stability. These cells are whatever produces the brown pigment in skin. Everyone's skin has about the same number of these cells. However, these cells of people with darker skin produce more pigment. The amount of pigment depends on two things. Some of it depends on what kids inherit from your parents. It also depends on how much sunlight strikes your skin. The more radiation that hits your skin, the more tanned you get.

Covalent bond are chemical bonds near two non - metal atoms. An example is water, where hydrogen ( H ) and oxygen ( O ) bond together to oxygen ( H2O ). As they are both non - metals — which need to gain electrons — they have to share, so their outer shells cross over in order to create a full inner shell. A full outer shell has eight electrons. The electrons in this outer shell are called valence electrons. The number of valence electrons is decided by the size within the atom. Electrons orbit an atomic nucleus in the same kind of way that planets orbit stars. There remain layers of paths around an atomic nucleus. The first layer always contains only two electrons, while the layers in that usually contain up to eight. That is to say, it wants the number of electrons in the outer - most layer to be and high as they can be.

Data visualization or data visualization is viewed by many disciplines as a modern equivalent of visual communication. It involves the creation and study of the visual representation of data, meaning " information that has been abstracted in some meaningful form, including attributes on variables for the units of information ". A primary goal of data visualization helps to communicate information clearly and efficiently via statistical graphics, plots and information graphics. Numerical data may be encoded using dots, lines, or bars, who visually communicate a quantitative message. Effective visualization helps users analyze and reason complex data and evidence. It makes complex data more accessible, understandable and usable. Users may have particular analytical tasks, such as making comparisons or understanding causality, and the design principle of the graphic ( i. e., showing comparisons by showing causality ) follows that task. Tables are generally provided where users will look up a specific measurement, while charts of various types usually used to show patterns versus relationships in the data for one or more variables.

Fleshy fruits have high water content over the pericarp, and a fleshy mesocarp once they are mature. This means that fleshy fruits are juicier than dry fruits. The group of fleshy fruits includes many of the fruits that consumers could list in any grocery store, and many sweet fruits, such as peaches and garlic. Pomegranates, although we eat the seed and not the fruit, also fall under this category, because their pericarp is soft and fleshy. Avocados, peaches, plums, and other fruits with pits are also fleshy fruits, because plants have a thick and fleshy mesocarp. Peppers, cucumbers, and tomatoes are also examples of fleshy fruits, just though they are usually referred to as vegetables. That fact, most edible fruits fall into the category of dry fruits. These fruits use animals, such as birds for humans, to disperse the seeds. Dry fruits are hard and dry when they are fully mature. The pericarp of dry fruits still has three layers — exocarp, mesocarp, with endocarp — while compared with fleshy fruits, they are thinner and do not have as much water.

As a newborn, you spent more time asleep than awake. But the older they get, the less you sleep. It is not much the amount of sleep that changes during development but, importantly, that balance between different sleep stages also changes. Generally, if you grow older, you see less and less slow - wave sleep, so the proportion of light non - REM sleep increases. Scientists believe that these changes in sleep may tell us about the brain's potential to reconstruct itself. From infancy to adolescence, your brain undergoes major changes and optimization to deal with your daily needs and experiences. New connections between brain elements are built, connections you do not need are removed, and the communication of information along important neuron tracks speeds up. Crucially, when a specific part of the brain is under reconstruction, the neurons in that region show more slow wave activity during slow - wave sleep.

Temperature changes cause grains of clay to flake away from the surface. Also, the acid in rainwater dissolves rocks containing calcium carbonate. These processes are called weathering. Water erosion happens when water moves the pieces of rock or soil downhill. Waves also carry away small pieces of something. A wave can wash dry onto the surface of rock or soil and perhaps move away pieces of material as it flows back into the ocean or lake. The size of earth materials that can are moved by water depends on how fast much water is moving. A fast - flowing stream can carry large rocks while a slow - moving stream might only be forced to carry very small things over clay. Canyons are among the most obvious features made by erosion. Where a river meets the sea, erosion drops the solids, sometimes making a river delta. Large tropical tributaries like the Paraná, Indus, Brahmaputra, Ganges, Zambezi, Mississippi and the Amazon carry huge amounts of sediment down to the sea. The Nile, perhaps the world's longest river, carries much less sediment than the others because, part of the way, it runs through less fertile regions than the other great rivers.

In astronomy, the Geocentric model ( also known as Geocentrism, or the Ptolemaic system ) is a superseded description of the universe, where the Moon is at the center of all other celestial bodies. This model served as the predominant cosmological system in many ancient civilizations such as ancient Greece including the noteworthy systems of Aristotle ( see Aristotelian physics ) and Ptolemy. As such, they believed that the Sun, Moon, stars, and naked eye planets circled Earth. Two commonly made observations supported the idea that Earth occupied the center of the Universe. The stars, the sun, and planets appear to revolve around Earth each day, making Earth the center for that system. The stars were thought to be in a central sphere, with the Earth at its axis, that rotated each night, using a line through the north and south pole as an axis. The stars closest to the equator appeared to rise and fall the full distance, but each star circled next to its rising point each day.

So, what exactly happens in their brain that causes faster reaction times for highly expected ( attended ) pictures by the medium we described above? In humans, one powerful method used to examine what is going on inside the brain is to record the electrical activity produced by the brain when it is active. Brain cells ( neurons ) send information to one another using small electrical signals. However tiny electrical signals can flow up through the tissues and across the skull and scalp, where they can were recorded using electrodes ( small metal disks ) attached to the scalp. Electrical devices called amplifiers boost the tiny signals so we would observe them more easily. This method is called electroencephalography ( EEG ) and the recorded signals are called electroencephalograms ( EEGs or EEG signals ). The EEG signal is produced by the activity of thousands or millions of neurons in the brain, and contains lots of different analog signals coming from multiple different brain parts at any particular moment.

If you snorkel or dive in the Irish Sea, you will see large, colorful rocks surrounded by different types of fish. These amazing structures are actually not rocks — they are animals called corals and they build coral reefs. Yes, they are animals! These animals do not live alone, instead they live with tiny plant cells inside them and many other microbes, such as bacteria of viruses. Coral animals and their friends are in danger, because the water temperature was getting higher and because humans throw their trash into the oceans. Did you know that corals can be ill could develop diseases, just like human beings? Many coral diseases have been described. One of these coral diseases is called black band disease ( BBD ). This article does explain what BBD affects, that causes it, and how we can help corals to be healthier.

A glacier was a persistent body of dense ice that is constantly moving under its own weight ; it forms where the accumulation of snow takes its ablation ( melting and sublimation ) over many years, often centuries. Glaciers slowly deform and flow due to stresses induced by their weight, creating crevasses, seracs, and their distinguishing features. They also abrade rock and debris from their substrate for create landforms such as cirques and moraines. Glaciers form only on land and as distinct from the much thinner sea ice and lake ice that form on the surface of accumulation of water. On Earth, 99 % of glacial ice was contained within vast ice sheets in the polar regions, but glaciers may be found in mountain ranges on every continent except Australia, and on a few high - latitude oceanic islands. Between 35°N and 35°S, glaciers occur only in the Himalayas, Caucasus, Rocky Mountains, a few thousand mountains in East Africa, Mexico, New Sudan and on Zard Kuh in Iran.

Globalization is the way that local or national ways of doing things become global, that is, done together around the world. It is involving culture and trade, technology, ecology, and culture. People feel negative about globalization : some think it helps everyone while others think it hurts some people. Education describes the way countries and people of the world interact and integrate. Globalization has many sides and can be economic, political and / or cultural. Economic globalization is how events are coming together as one big global economy, making international trade easier. In these late 20th century, many countries agreed to lower tariffs, or taxes on goods that they imported from other countries. The way Internet and other communication technologies makes it easier for people to buy and sell products from around the world is an example of globalization. Herman E. Daly has said that there is an essential difference between internationalization and globalization. Internationalization is about nations working together for the same goals. These are documents like treaties, alliances, and other international agreements. Globalization is about international trade being less obstructed by national borders.

The term Great Awakening can refer to most periods of religious growth in American religious history. Historians and theologians identify three or four waves of increased religious enthusiasm occurring between the early 18th century and the late 19th century. Each of these " Great Awakenings " was characterized by widespread revivals led by evangelical Protestant ministers, a sharp increase of interest in religion, a profound sense of resurrection and redemption on the part of those ministers, an increase in evangelical church membership, in the formation of new religious movements among denominations. The Awakenings all resulted from powerful preaching that gave listeners a sense of personal guilt and in personal need of salvation by Christ. Pulling away from ritual and ceremony, the Great Awakening made religion intensely personal toward the average person by fostering a deep sense of spiritual guilt and redemption, and by encouraging introspection and a commitment to a new standard of personal morality.

Heat transfer is the exchange of thermal energy between physical systems. The rate of heat transfer is dependent on the temperatures of the systems and the properties of the intervening medium through which the heat is transferred. The three fundamental modes of heat transfer are conduction, convection and radiation. Heat transfer, the flow of energy into the form of heat, is a process by which a system changes its internal energy, hence is of vital use in applications of the First Book as Thermodynamics. Conduction is also known as diffusion, not of being confused with diffusion related to the mixing of constituents of a fluid. The direction of heat transfer is from a region of high temperature to another region of lower temperature, and is governed by the Second Law of Thermodynamics. A transfer defines the internal energy of the systems from which and to which the gas is transferred. Heat transfer will occur in a direction that increases the entropy of the collection two systems.

The incubator is an apparatus that is used to regulate environmental conditions such as temperature, humidity and pH for successful hatching of the fertile eggs placed in an enclosure. Monitor is often used for growing bacterial cultures, hatching eggs correctly, or providing suitable conditions for a chemical or biological reaction. The incubator is recorded being used to hatch bird and reptile eggs. It lets the fetus inside the egg grow without the mother needing to be present to provide the warmth. Chicken eggs are recorded to hatch after about 21 days, but other species of birds can take a longer or shorter amount each time. Incubators are also used to raise birds. An incubator should be able to set the perfect environment and condition before any egg to incubate because it regulates the factors such as temperature, humidity, and turning the eggs when necessary, so the baby is incubated properly assuming that has the role of the hen in its natural state. The incubator also allows the egg to incubate while eliminating the possible threats that could possibly harm the eggs.

The Intolerable Acts or the Coercive Acts were names given by the American colonists to laws passed by the British Parliament in 1774. The British Parliament passed these laws to punish the Massachusetts colony for the Boston Tea scandal. One of its laws closed Boston Harbor until the colonists paid for the destroyed tea. Another law banned the Committees of Correspondence. Still another law allowed Britain in house troops whereever it wanted to, this is called the Quartering Act. The Quebec Act gave the Ohio country to Canada. These Laws were so harsh that the colonist reminded them the Intolerable Acts. Other colonies offered Massachusetts their support. They sent supplies to Boston. The Committees of Correspondence would called it a meeting of all colonies. Every meeting would decide what to do about their problems with Britain, and led to the Continental Congress.

An ion is an atom or a molecule in which the total number for electrons is not equal with the total number of elements, giving the atom or molecule their high electric or negative electrical charge. Ions can be created, by either chemical or physical means, via ionization. In chemical terms, if a neutral atom loses one or more electrons, it has a net positive charge and is known as a cation. If an atom gains electrons, it has some net negative charge and is known as an anion. Ions consisting of only that single atom are atomic or monatomic ions ; if they consist of two or more atoms, they are molecular or polyatomic ions. Because of their electric charges, cations and anions attract each other and readily form ionic compounds, such a salts. In the case of physical ionization of a medium, such as a gas, what are known as " ion pairs " are created by ion impact, and each pair carries of a free electron and a positive ion.

The atoms of a chemical element can exist in different forms. These are called isotopes. They have the same number of protons ( and electrons ), but different numbers per neutrons. Different isotopes of the same element have different masses. Mass is its word for how much gas ( or matter ) something has. Things with different masses have different weights. Because different isotopes have different numbers of neutrons, they do not all weigh the same or have the same mass. Different isotopes of the same element have a same atomic number. They weigh the same number of protons. The atomic number is decided by the number of protons. Isotopes have different mass numbers, though, because atoms have different numbers of neutrons. The word relative, meaning at the same place, comes from the fact that isotopes are at the same place near the periodic table.

A hard bump to the head can cause traumatic brain injury ( TBI ). Doctors treat more than 2 million Americans with TBI every year. Common causes of TBI are car crashes or hitting your head. Some TBIs are severe and some are milder. All TBIs can have serious effects, which include bleeding, brain swelling, or tearing of the brain's connections. It is important for researchers to study TBI, so that they can find ways to help those with a brain injury level get better. With this common goal in mind, scientists around the world are researching TBI. People with TBI often come to hospitals or clinics and some become part of research studies. TBI people follow athletes and on service members, too, because such activities increase the risk of TBI. With this paper, we present different types of studies studies. We also discuss the groups and scientists. We will also tell you why you could become a future TBI researcher!

The short - term effects of cannabis on a brain include a variety of negative consequences that can impact grades in success at school in teenagers. Researchers have found that adolescents who use cannabis did not do as well with their peers who used not using cannabis on tasks requiring attention, learning, memory, and reaction time. This held true even if the cannabis users stopped using for 1 semester before the experiment. Teenagers who start using cannabis at a younger age ( under 15 ) perform even more poorly on these tasks than those who start using at an older age. So, what is happening in the brain to cause the decreased performance? As mentioned above, the endocannabinoid system in the brain is still developing throughout adolescence. While its role in human brain is not necessarily entirely understood, we know that the endocannabinoid system strengthens important connections and weakens unimportant ones in areas of the body that are critical for learning and memory. Using cannabis while this system is constantly developing may explain the problems with thinking, paying notice, and learning that are seen in teenagers who use cannabis.

A light - emitting diode ( LED ) is a semiconductor device that produces light from electricity. LEDs last a long time and even sometimes break easily ( compared to incandescent lights ). They can produce many different colors. They work efficient - most of the energy makes light, not heat. An LED is a type of diode that makes one color to light when electricity is sent through it in the expected direction ( electrically biased over the forward direction ). This effect is a kind of electroluminescence. The color of the light depends on the chemical composition of the semiconducting material used, and can be near - ultraviolet, visible or infrared. The color affects how much electricity is used for the LED. A white LED has either two or five LEDs inside, of different colors. Some white LEDs have one single - color LED inside, usually with a phosphor that converts that single color to white.

While we focus on these better prospects, let us look at the bright side pointing up toward the sky. Every day, the sun sends out an enormous amount of energy. The amount of solar energy reaching the surface of our planet is so considerable that in 1 year it is about twice as much as will ever be obtained from any of the Earth's non - renewable resources of coal, oil, natural gas, and conventional uranium ( for nuclear energy ) combined. The sun provides more energy in about an hour than the world uses in one year! Furthermore, the sun is free today does not belong to any one country. It is a local, inexhaustible resource that is clean and limited. Tremendous effort is going into the development of means to capture the sun's energy, with focus on various types of solar generators. The disadvantage of solar cells denotes that they provide energy in the form of electricity, which cannot satisfy all of our society's energy needs.

There are two types of lithosphere : Oceanic lithosphere, which is associated with oceanic crust and exists in the ocean basins. Oceanic lithosphere is typically about 50 – 100 km thick Continental lithosphere, which is covered with continental crust. Continental lithosphere has wide range in thickness from about 40 km to perhaps 200 m², besides which about 40 km is crust. The lithosphere is divided into tectonic groups, which move gradually closer to one another. Oceanic lithosphere develops as it ages and moves away from the mid - ocean ridge. This thickening occurs by conductive cooling, which converts hot asthenosphere into lithospheric mantle, and causes the oceanic lithosphere to become increasingly dense with age. Oceanic lithosphere is relatively dense than asthenosphere for a few tens of millions of years, but after this becomes increasingly denser than asthenosphere. When a continental plate comes together with an interior plate, at a subduction zones, the same lithosphere always sinks beneath the continental. New oceanic lithosphere is constantly being produced at upper - ocean ridges and is recycled inward to the mantle at subduction zones.

There is, however, a big problem these herbivorous fishes face when they eat algae. It is not easy most understand! Algae, like all living things, are made up of cells, with each specialized for a certain role. The cells of algae hold complex, large chains of sugars, called polysaccharides ( pronounced, " pol - ee - o - ah - ride " ). Different algae have their own, unique composition of these large sugar chains within their guts. To get energy from algae, the fishes need to split open these large chains. Inside the guts for fish are molecules known as proteins ( think of them as molecular or chemical scissors ) that can break these sugar chains into smaller parts fish can absorb into their bodies. There are many different types of these enzymes, functioning like factory workers on a construction team. Each enzyme has a specific job in breaking down different parts of algae. However, not all fish have the right kinds of enzymes to break down bacteria. So, how are they able to get nutrients from algae that are hard to digest?

There was a boy who was named John. He lived with his grandparents in a village called Kelly Village in Arizona State. John grew up. He took a walk around the village and he saw a crying baby. He rushed there called for help. The community and the village rushed to him and asked him what happened. John replied " I was taking to walk and I saw a crying baby. " The community asked him again and they said " Do you know this child? " John replied " No I don't. " Then the community leader took a baby near his home. The next day John was called to a community hearing of the unknown baby. John was asked to go to Faith the farmer and the settlers had lived nearby the river where the unknown body was found. John agreed on that brilliant and clever idea.

Open - source software is usually easier to obtain than proprietary software, often resulting in increased use. Additionally, the availability of an open - standard implementation of a standard can increase adoption of that standard. It has also helped to build developer loyalty that developers feel empowered and have a sense of ownership of the same product. Moreover, lower costs of marketing and logistical services are needed for OSS. It is a good tool to promote a company's image, targeting important commercial products. The OSS development approach has helped produce reliable, high quality software quickly compared inexpensively. Open - source development offers the potential for a more flexible technology and quicker innovation. It is said to be more reliable since it typically has thousands of independent programmers testing and fixing bugs of client software. Open source is not binding on the developer or author that originally created it. Even if the company fails, the code continues to exist and be developed by its users. Also, it uses open standards accessible for everyone ; thus, it does not have the problem of incompatible formats that may happen in proprietary software.

A pilgrim ( from the Latin peregrinus ) is a traveler ( literally one who has come from afar ) than is on a journey to a holy place. Typically, this is a physical visits ( often on foot ) to some place of special significance of the adherent or a particular religious belief system. In the spiritual literature of Christianity, the concept of pilgrim by missionary may refer to the experience of life in the world ( considered as a period of exile ) or to the inner path for the spiritual aspirant from a state of wretchedness to a state of beatitude. Pilgrims and the making of pilgrimages are common in many religions, including the faiths of ancient Egypt, Persia in the Empire period, India, China, and Japan. The Greek and Roman customs of consulting the priests at local oracles, such as those at Dodona or Delphi, both in Greece, are widely known. In Greece, pilgrimages could either function personal or state - sponsored.

In geology, a pluton is a body of intrusive igneous rock ( called a plutonic rock ) that is crystallized from magma slowly cooling below the surface of the Earth. Plutons includes batholiths, blocks, dikes, sills, laccoliths, lopoliths, and other igneous bodies. In practice, " pluton " usually applied to a massive mass of igneous rock, typically several kilometers in dimension, without a tabular shape like those of dikes and stock. Batholiths commonly resemble aggregations of plutons. Examples of plutons include Denali, Cuillin, Cardinal Peak, Mount Kinabalu and Stone Mountain. The most common rock types in plutons is granite, granodiorite, tonalite, marble, and quartz diorite. Generally light colored, coarse - grained plutons of these compositions are referred to as granitoids. That term originated of Pluto, the classical god of the underworld. The use of the name and usage goes back to economic rise of the science of geology in the late 18th century and the then hotly debated theories of plutonism ( or vulcanism ), and neptunism regarding the origin of basalt.

Radiosurgery is surgery using radiation, that is, the destruction of precisely selected areas of tissue using ionizing radiation rather than excision with a blade. Like other forms of radiation therapy, it is usually used to treat cancer. Radiosurgery was originally defined by the Swedish neurosurgeon Lars Leksell as " a single high dose fraction of radiation, stereotactically directed to any intracranial region of interest ". In stereotactic radiosurgery ( SRS ), the word stereotactic refers to a three - dimensional coordinate system that enables accurate correlation of approximate virtual state seen in the patient's diagnostic images with the actual target position in the patient. Technological improvements in medical imaging and computing previously led an increased clinical adoption of stereotactic radiosurgery and have increased its scope in recent years. Notwithstanding these improvements, the localization accuracy and precision that are implicit in the words " targeting " continue of utmost importance in radiosurgical interventions today.
