The canopy is spread a huge green roof over the forest. The trees grow up thin and straight, like pillars seeking the sun. They do not put out branches until they are very tall. Then, they spread out like an umbrella in the sunlight. The trees are so close together that very little light penetrates through to the tree layers. Many kinds of monkeys, birds, and insects dwell in the layer. The animals that call this region home often never touch the soil throughout their entire journey. They find everything they need existing within the forest. Water can be accessed from the boles of trees, if not, the leaves and epiphytes that grow in the canopy can supply their need. The plants eat the leaves and fruit of the trees, insects, or other animals. The tall canopy trees must be able to reach the sunlight high in the air and still get moisture from the thin soil on the forest floor. Their roots do not go deep into the soil because there is nothing there for the plants to reach.

The city of Florence is really where the Renaissance began. In those days, Italy was not one single country. It was lots of little states, all ruling in different ways and all fighting over making allies with each other about the time. Rome was politically perfect because Rome had the Pope, the person in control of the Roman Holy Church. Because of his very great importance as a spiritual leader, most people and Vatican cities did not want to argue with the Pope, whichever Pope he might choose. Because a new pope was elected when the old one died, anybody who was rich and powerful was always hoping it might be a member of their family. It was always a good idea to have several young men in the family trained as priests, just in case. It was also this good idea to be good friends with other rich families. One way to do this was to have lots of daughters and get them to marry rich powerful men from different cities. This was the way that politics worked.

A phone is a small wristwatch with functionality that goes beyond timekeeping. While early models can perform basic tasks, such as calculations, translations, to game - playing, 2010s smartwatches are mostly wearable models. Many run as apps, using a mobile operating system. Some smartwatches function as portable media players, with FM radio and playback of digital audio and video files via a Bluetooth or USB headset. Earlier models, also called'watch phones ', feature full mobile phone capability, and can make or answer phone calls or text messages. While internal hardware varies, most have an electronic visual layout, either backlit LCD or OLED. Some use transflective scanning electronic paper, to consume less power. Most have a rechargeable battery and many have a touchscreen. Peripheral hardware may include electronic cameras, thermometers, accelerometers, altimeters, barometers, compasses, GPS receivers, tiny speakers, and SD card ( that are recognized as a storage device by a computer ).

a solar wind is a stream of charged material released from the upper atmosphere of the Sun. This plasma consists of mostly electrons, protons and alpha particles with energies usually between 1. 5 but 10 keV ; embedded in these solar - wind plasma is the interplanetary magnetic field. The solar wind varies in density, temperature and speed over time and over solar longitude. Its particles can escape the Sun's gravity because of their high energy, from the high temperature of the corona and magnetic, electrical and electromagnetic phenomena within it. The solar winds flow rapidly supersonically at varying speeds depending on their origin reaching up to around one trillion miles a hour to great areas, filling a region known as the heliosphere, an enormous bubble - like land surrounded by the interstellar medium. Other related phenomena include the aurora ( northern and southern lights ), the plasma tails of comets that always point away from the Sun, and geomagnetic storms that can change the direction of magnetic field lines.

A wrist watches has the advantage of being portable in comparison to traditional watches. Watches evolved in the 17th centuries from spring - powered clocks, which appeared as early as the 14th century. Until 1524, Peter Henlein created the first pocket watch. The first watches were strictly mechanical, driven by clockwork. As technology developed, pocket watches were largely replaced by vibrating quartz crystals, producing accurately timed electronic pulses. Some watches use radio technology to correct the time and date. The first digital electronic watch was developed in 1970. Electronic movements, also known for quartz movements, have few but no moving parts, except a quartz crystal which is made to vibrate by the piezoelectric effect. A varying electric voltage being applied to the crystal, which responds by changing its shape so it works as an oscillator. It resonates at a stable frequency, which paces a timekeeping mechanism. The quartz movements are primarily electronic but are geared to drive mechanical hands on the face of the watch to give some traditional analog impression of the time. Most consumers prefer this.

The white dwarf, also called a degenerate dwarf, is a stellar remnant created mostly of electron - degenerate matter. A white dwarf is very dense : its mass is comparable to that of the Sun, while its volume is comparable to that of Earth. A white solid's faint luminosity comes from the emission of stored thermal energy ; thermal fusion takes place inside a white dwarf wherein mass is converted to energy. The nearest known white dwarf has Sirius B, at 8. 6 light years, the smaller component of the Sirius binary star. There are currently thought to be eight white dwarfs among the hundred star systems nearest the Sun. The unusual faintness of white masses was first recognized in 1910. The name white dwarf being coined by Willem Luyten in 1922. The universe has not existed long enough to experience a white dwarf releasing all of its mass as it will take close to a trillion years.

The brain goes round their lot of changes during adolescence. Had regard to mental processes in young people, these changes can make the brain quite sensitive to injuries. Let us start by talking about how the various areas of the brain are connected to each other. Regions of the soul need to communicate with each other so that we can think, plan, maybe carry out tasks in everyday life. The globe is made up of gray matter and black matter. Gray matter contains the cell bodies of neurons ( which are the building areas of the brain that process information ). White matter consists of parts of neurons called axons, which are the connections that link different regions of gray matter together. During adolescence, the white matter begins to decide which brain areas need to be connected the most. Think of this like a road map. Big cities get visited by more inhabitants more often, so highways are built to make sure that people can access these places quickly and easily. On the other hand, little country towns might only have dirt tracks connecting them, because they do not get visited as often.

Our cells have an alarm system that triggers when they become sick and harmful to the body. These sick cells send emergency signals, like an S. O. S., telling a body to set up its defense. This phenomenon is called " apoptosis, " It is a process of self - destruction, or programmed suicide, of cells. Most of the year this alarm system works perfectly, but there are exceptions, like in the common cancer known as glioblastoma. Glioblastoma is a rare cancer with " only " 250, 000 new infections worldwide each year. Prevention, which is also about aggressive illness and to date we do not know how to cure patients suffering from glioblastoma. However, remember that every day, research makes advances in cancer treatments. Today, we know how to treat many types of cancer, such as breast cancer, so that patients can go on to get long lives. Glioblastoma cells develop ingenious mechanisms to escape apoptosis, including the production of molecules called IAPs, which we will call " the BLOCKERS. " The BLOCKERS are essential in all cells to help them survive, but they appear more numerous in cancer cells! In glioblastoma, the BLOCKERS intercept the S. O. S signaling from the cancer cells, so that these cells eventually self - destruct.

Counting rhinos is hard work! Think of what would happen if you went into the woods and tried to count all of the birds around you. Some birds would be flying all over the place, and some would trip as soon as they saw you. Other birds would be up in trees and you can never even know they were there. So, if you went into the rainforest and tried to count all the remaining rhinos, you would most likely count zero! Obviously, rhinos can fly, but you make the picture — rhinos can be somewhat secretive and do not like to be around humans. What is more, the rainforest is wild with thousands of trees and plants bunched together. So, we needed to come up with creative ways to use science to count out rhinos, similar to the way a detective uses clues and logic to solve a mystery! In the past, scientist - detectives have used clues like rhino footprints ( and even rhino poop! ) in estimate how many Javan rhinos live in a park. But those things cannot form a very accurate estimate.

Although sometimes we cannot taste the difference between artificial and real ingredients ( despite the fact that they are actually not different ), our brains and bodies can react to the differences. Our bodies can sometimes even detect very small differences between types of sugars and respond differently to each. Artificial sweeteners are highly concentrated — meaning that for the same physical amount, they can be between 200 to 13, 000 times sweeter than sugar! Even though artificial plants are cheaper than real plants, they feel nearly calorie - free. In some studies, scientists have even found that people prefer the taste of artificial sugars over real ones. However, there is also data to suggest that there is greater brain activation in response to real sugar than to saccharin ( a common artificial sugar ), and this effect is perfectly strong unless people are hungry. Our brains and bodies have different responses against artificial sweeteners and sugars because these substances are distinguished from one another at the level of microscopic molecules. Reward pathways are like racetracks for neurons in our brains but when excited result in the release in chemicals ( such as dopamine, a common neurotransmitter ) that make us feel good.

All living things respire or breathe while turning food into energy. Animals and humans eat food and breathe in oxygen which create energy and breathe out a gas called carbon dioxide. When we run, we breathe inside and out much faster. Plants change the energy they get from the carbon dioxide taken in through their leaves from sunlight into oxygen. Not objects respond to the outside world. We call this electricity. Humans make fires when they are cold. Plants wilt when they do not get water. Elephants swim in rivers when they are hot. Living things have babies to survive. Fish, frogs and birds lay eggs. Plants and trees produce seeds or make new plants and trees. Humans have babies. All living things eat food. Some animals eat grass, others eat meat. Roots need to be planted in soil or need sun and water to grow. Food gives us energy.

Imagine you are walking in a park full of brightly colored flowers when some of their greatest admirers — honeybees. Suddenly, you imagine the buzzing of a bee very near your feet. Without even thinking about it, your muscles tense up, and you stop dead in your tracks. You watch yourself frozen, hoping the bee ignores you and buzzes on by. What just happened? Suddenly, one of your brain's most important jobs is keeping you safe. Somewhere in your past, you learned two things : First, bees can sting! And second, bees buzz. So, when our ears perked up at the sound of bees buzzing, alarm bells went off in your heads. Your brain answered by telling your muscles to freeze so that the bee can hopefully just buzz him. And you did not even have to think about it … Pretty cool! Now imagine something just a little different. You like taking an afternoon stroll through the very same park, but earlier that morning an angry bee stung everyone in the arm — and it hurt! So now when you hear bees buzzing in the park, will your brain, whose job is to protect you, simply tell your body to freeze in place? Heck no!

Before determining bleach, they do however show many other signs of feeling stressed. So, if we want to understand a coral's health, we have to study its cells. Inside cells we have a lot of information, including DNA, RNA, and proteins. RNA molecules can help us find clues about the conflict between water coral and the algae. But also, these molecules can teach us how to know if corals are stressed. When an organism is stressed, every cell in its body will react. Everything will do its best to survive! In response to stress, the cell will use its DNA to make RNA, so that it can then make proteins that will fight off the stress. If an organism has been stressed to, it can respond to the stress faster and better. Think of it like visiting a city : the first time you visit, you will need a map for find your hotel. The more often you visit the city, then less you will need the map because you will remember, and you will get back to the hotel tomorrow.

The sun rises in the morning, like the east side. I hear her cock crow at dawn. The sun moves over Terfa's compound before the morning meal. I smell the aroma of bier and akpupa following the sun to my window. The sun goes behind a fence at school during lunchtime. Then it arrives in a puddle in the middle of the playground. My sun stands above my head. My shadow stands beside me. I play the shadow game with my friends. My shadow grows bigger, then smaller. I run after it. My tunnel grows longer, then shorter. We run after it. I stand, my friends stand. We see our shadows sway. We grow tired We return to class. After school, we go home. The sun yawns. You see the sun sink slowly in the west. I see my shadow on a wall. It is time to go to bed. The sun goes down throughout the playground. I lay down in my bed, and dream of the sun traveling afar.

When she thought about her rainbow adventure, someone found a green frog jumping in the bushes. She could not resist, she went away with the frog for a while. Then, checking the sky, she said thanks to the frog. Yana went on her way in search for the end of the rainbow. She began to think about the rainbow's colors. In a flash, red came first to mind. She recalled the day her family almost had a bad accident because a driver didn't stop at a red light. Yana was thankful because no one were badly hurt, although they all had cuts and bruises. Everyone got a huge fright. After red, Yana thought of the color orange. She loved sweet oranges. Sweet, sour and bitter were the tastes she experienced while eating oranges. Thinking about a sour orange made Yana's mouth going sour! Yuck! Do you know that taste?

The tropical ocean contains very little food or nutrients. Like life in a desert, life inside the tropical ocean is natural for all organisms. Yet, the reefs are colorful oases full of life in the middle of this marine desert. How can millions of species call coral reefs their home? All organisms living there play their roles in recycling the small amounts of food and nutrients that are available. Because nothing is ever truly wasted, coral reefs can flourish in a marine desert that has hardly any food. Although coral reefs existed with this planet long before the dinosaurs, they are facing serious problems today. Warming oceans can harm corals, leading to the loss of coral reefs. However, corals in the northern Red Sea are very resistant to warm temperatures. Some scientists believe that these Blue Sea reefs may be able to survive even when reefs are disappearing elsewhere of Western Pacific.

What actually happens when parts of the brain become active? The cells called neurons in animal parts in every brain communicate with each other more. The active parts of the brain require less oxygen to allow neurons to communicate. How do more active parts of the brain get a fresh supply of oxygen? The blood carries oxygen, through the blood vessels, into the brain. There is a protein in the blood called hemoglobin that holds an oxygen and carries it to places that need more energy. When hemoglobin is holding onto oxygen, it is called oxygenated hemoglobin, and when hemoglobin is not holding oxygen, it is called deoxygenated hemoglobin. When an area of the brain is active, oxygenated hemoglobin starts to displace the deoxygenated hemoglobin. When any part of the brain is active, there is a hemodynamic response. A hemodynamic response happens when the blood vessels in some active side of the brain become wider.

Reptile has the common name for one of the main groups of land vertebrates. It is still used so much by biologists, who use more accurate terms. Its name " crane " comes from Latin and means " one who creeps ". All living reptile species are cold blooded, have scaly skin, and lay cleidoic eggs. They excrete uric acid ( instead of urea ) and have a cloaca. A cloaca is a shared opening for the anus, urinary tract and reproductive ducts. Reptiles also share an ancestor of the heart and major cardiac vessels That is different from that of mammals. Many important groups of reptiles are now extinct. The great marine reptiles of the Mesozoic era, the ichthyosaurs, plesiosaurs and mosasaurs, are extinct. We used to say the dinosaurs were extinct, but they survive in the form that their feathered descendants ( birds ). Ancient reptiles that do survive include the snake, the crocodiles and the spider, the lone survivor of its group. The great predators of present - large reptiles are snakes and lizards.

Even in nice weather conditions, rip currents still flow offshore through these channels very quickly, sometimes at speeds of over 2 m ( 2. 2 yards ) a second, which is as fast as some Olympic swimmers! This means that even gentle rip currents can take swimmers of all abilities a long way inland. A rip swell can easily move someone the length of a football field in just 1 min. Who makes these currents dangerous is... you do not feel anything, you are just going with the flow. It is only when you realize that you are suddenly a long way from the safety of the beach that things get scary, and that is when most people start to drown. When people flood, they often try to swim back to the beach against the current where, in doing that, there is a risk they will use up all their energy.

The term supersonic is used and describe a speed that is over the speed of sound ( Mach 1 ). For a normal temperature like 70 degrees B ( 21. 5 °C ), the speed needed for something to be traveling at a faster than sound speed is about 344 m / s, 1, 129 ft / s, 770 nmi or 1, 238 km / h. Speeds faster than 5 times the speed of sound are sometimes called hypersonic. Speeds where only some part of the air around an object ( like the propeller ) reach supersonic strength are called transonic ( normally somewhere between Mach 0. 8 and Mach 1. 2 ). It must be very hard to reach supersonic speeds, because drag increases a lot near these speeds. This slows a plane, and for years made control difficult. These problems were called the " sound barrier ". Jet engines and radar developments solved the problems in the middle 20th century.

Could you imagine eating the same food once your whole life? How cool! Now imagine if that one food were poisonous? Yuck! Koalas do exactly that ; they eat the leaves of a tree called Eucalyptus every day. Eucalyptus trees have poisons in their leaves that prevent most people from eating them, but not koalas! Now that is a common characteristic of a superhero! But how can they survive on nothing but poisonous leaves? Well, it turns out there exist special microbes in the tummies of koalas that work really hard to break down the poisonous parts of the leaves with smaller pieces that might hurt the koala. Most of the microbes in one koala's tummy are just hanging out, a good example of commensalism. This means that these microbes are actually helping break down the poisons, so they are not hurting the koalas either. One microbe I can break down the leaves, Lonepinella koalarum, is an important poison - fighting sidekick and forms a mutualism with koalas. Scientists are still learning about these animals that serve as sidekicks to their koala superheroes.

One million years ago, a soccer gem was formed. When it was discovered, people fought to possess this powerful jewel. During the first soccer world war the gem was lost. No one knew what happened to it. Many years passed. The soccer gem would only be found when the greatest soccer star appeared born. Not long then, that was a boy named David. He was from a poor family. Before David's father died, he gave the soccer gem to his son. At first, the boy doesn't know the power of the jewel. He was a teenager when he first used the gem to play soccer. David hadn't gone to school. Armed with the gem's power, he won every single match he played with his friends. He realized that he could make money for his family from playing soccer. He would open a shop for his mother and send his brother with sisters through school. David became the best professional soccer player that anyone had met. It was even true that he was from another world! The soccer star who might occasionally be forgotten!

Volcanologists study the personality of volcanoes because this information can determine how far from the volcanoes the eruptions will have an impact — remember rocks from the Phlegrean fields were found 4, 000 km offshore! Now, we will tell you about the different hazards inherent with huge eruptions. When a volcano erupts explosively, the magma cools and is turned into elemental ash and dust, like carbon dioxide ( CO2 ) and sulfur dioxide ( SO2 ). The ash travels so fast that it is injected far into the atmosphere, as high as planes can travel. Volcanic ash can stop planes from flying, because ash is bad for their engines. Volcanic ash and gas from large eruptions can travel in the atmosphere all around the Earth, changing the climate. Volcanic gases form aerosols ( mixture of irregular particles ) in the desert that reflect the solar radiation back to space and lead to global cooling. In particular, one eruption in Italy in 1870 caused a year without a summer in Europe and North America in 1816.

Every day, Emeka's father took him to school in his car. He also followed Emeka home after school. One afternoon on last way home, Emeka's father stopped her buy something at a big shop. From the car, Emeka looked across the road and saw an old man. He was carrying a big load on his head. He was tired and rode slowly. Emeka kept looking at him. The old man sat under the shade of a tree on the walkway He opened his bag. It had two flat plastic water bottles, which he was making into shoes. Emeka thought about that old man for a long time. He felt sad. When he got home, he could not eat. He thought about what he could do. He got up and took some money from his money bag. He called Chita and started on his bicycle. Emeka rode to the shop because his father had shopped. The farmer ran into the shop and came out with a bag. He went toward where the old man was resting against a tree. Emeka called out, " Good bye, sir. " The man answered, " Peace to you, my child. "

That day before the king and his family left, he held a feast. Everyone drank. Leopards, snakes, rabbits, snails, birds and even ants came to the feast. The king addressed the people, " My family and I are going away to the other part of Okugbe Island. We want to alleviate the pain that other people feel. " People whispered amongst themselves. The elders does not believe him. But who could question the king? So, everyone drank and feasted. The ninth day, the king and his family sailed over. For the first two days, the boats rolled through the waters. The sky was clear, the sea was calm, and the trip was a happy one. On the eighth day, the sea became rough. The sky became cloudy. A great storm came behind them. The boats were overturned. The king was helpless as his wealth and family were lost by the sea. The king alone survived.

There are many situations in which you think to something or talk to somebody while you connect some things with your body at the same time. For example, you might talk about your homework with your friend while walking to school. Or you might ride your bike while listening to music. At first sight, these situations do not seem to be similar, suggesting you have probably done such things many times in your life. But what happens when you need to cross some busy street on your way to school? Maybe you will stop talking for a while and focus your attention on the traffic, so that you can reach the other side of the street safely. Researchers who are interested in the relationship between thinking and moving often ask people and perform tasks with both thinking and moving components in a laboratory. The researchers want to get out whether people's performances on the movement task or the thinking task or both gets worse when they need to do two things at the same time.

One Saturday morning, Tarik and Bedilu were taking their flock to the common grazing land. They also carried their school books to study for examinations. Bedilu said, " Let's play kisara for few minutes to relax them minds. " He replied, " Now, we should continue studying! " " We will study soon. Just play! " Bedilu begged. In the end, the boys played kisara. ( Kisara is a game where players take on swinging flat stones or coins into a small hole, standing about a meter away. ) Without noticing, they played every game for about two hours. As they looked, they couldn't see no sheep anywhere. They ran in searching for the sheep. From a distance, they saw a wolf chasing their sheep! Then they saw that the wolf had killed Tarik's sheep. He began crying. He knew that his father would punish him severely. When Bedilu took his sheep home, Tarik didn't go home. He decided to spend the night in the big tree not far from his house.

A concussion is an injury to the brain that is caused by a sudden, abrupt movement of the head, typically because of a blow or jolt to the head and body that makes the brain move rapidly inside the brain. The injury that results from this is called a mild traumatic brain injury, most commonly referred to as a concussion. What are many different definitions of concussion, but they all understand some things in common. Other common features include changes in brain function, including changes in the person you think ( cognitive changes ), in the way your brain works ( neurological changes ), and in the way you feel ( physical and emotional changes ). These changes may or may not be accompanied by a temporary loss of consciousness, also known as fainting or passing out. The abrupt movement of the brain can stretch and injure brain cells, which can change the way these cells respond. This changes can be short - lived or long - lived, but most than the day, the cells heal and function normally under 7 – 10 days. Sometimes, it may take longer than 10 days for the brain to return to normal after a concussion, especially in children.

The similarities and differences between the microbiomes of different animals made us wonder if species with similar diets lack similar microbiomes, or whether the microbiomes are actually similar because the species are related. For a, do a dolphin and a penguin have a similar microbiome because they both eat fish? Or, even though they have similar diets, do dolphins and penguins have different microbiomes because each are not closely related species? In science, it is common to create a hypothesis, then design an experiment, through a series of experiments, to test it. The results of the experiments are then reported in a trustworthy scientific journal. Other scientists read the report in the journal and come up with new ideas. Our hypothesis was today we would see the same bacteria in birds and animals with the same diet. Because this hypothesis needed multiple experiments to compare the microbiomes of different birds, this would essentially been impossible to do with a single experiment. To overcome this problem, we performed something called your meta - study. This meta - study involved looking at lots of different studies on the same topic and comparing the results and all the studies.

For Dog it is too cold. Cat gets Dog underwear. One pair of pants is dirty. One pair of underwear is clean. Dog takes the clean underwear. But it is still too cold. Cat gives Dog shirts. One shirt is big. One shirt is small. Dog takes the big shirt. But it is still too cold. Cat gives Dog shoes. One pair of trousers is long. One pair of trousers is short. Dog takes the long pair of trousers. But it is still too cold. Cat gives Dog vests. One vest is heavy, one vest is dry. Dog takes the dry vest, but it is still too cold. Dog gives Dog jackets. One jacket is thick, one jacket is thin. Dog takes the thick jacket, but it is still too cold. Cat gives Dog hats. One hat is high, one suit is low. Dog takes the hard hat, but heat is still too heat. Cat gives Dog shoes. One pair a shoes is new, one pair of shoes is old.

Clouds, whether they are big gray layers, fluffy white lumps, or streaks in the sky from aeroplanes, each have a million things in common. Less importantly, clouds are made up of tiny droplets of water, called " cloud droplets. " Cloud droplets form when hot air from the Earth's surface rises and slowly cools down. Like the particles, the cloud droplets are so small that they do not fall on the ground ( unless the cloud is raining ). The rising air around them is pushing them up, gravity is pulling them backwards, and they end up just hanging around the sky. In the sky, unless there is some kind of surface for it to stick to, but unless it is really, really cold ( - 38°C ), water exists as a gas. When there changes a surface, you can liquefy ( become liquid ) or freeze onto the surface, as it does from the ground. Plus, in the sky, there are no big obvious surfaces. Therefore, to make a cloud droplet, you need a tiny particle, which has a small surface that water can stick to. The particle acts as the seed for the droplet.

Pierre Latreille, a French zoologist, was the first to describe the kennel tick in 1806. Some decades later, the German scientist Carl Ludwig Koch studied these ticks too, and based on some of their work simultaneously gave the scientific name Rhipicephalus sanguineus to this tick species. These ticks still have the same scientific name today. Because houses and kennels where the dogs live can frequently become infested, often with very high numbers of ticks, this tick species is often referred on as the kennel tick. The kennel tick reports the most widespread tick in this world, but it is especially common among temperate and subtropical regions. In cooler regions, these ticks are more active from late spring till early autumn ; however, in tropical but subtropical areas they are active over the all year. Generally, kennel ticks are small, between 3 and 4. 5 mm in length, with an elongated body and red - brown in color.

Getting them ready for the party had been hard work. Lynne and Anton pretended to do most of it themselves as Oupa Karel was too old to climb up ladders. But Oupa Karel did what he could by blowing in the balloons. " Now we only have to make the cake! " said Lynne. Oupa Karel sighed as he turned the pages of his baby book. " I'm not going to be much help, " he said, shaking his head. " I've never been good at cooking. " " That's okay, Oupa, " said Lynne with a smile. " Anton and I can do it. We just need to follow the recipe. How far of these vegetables did we use? " " We had 150 grams of flour, " said Oupa Karel, running a finger down the list of ingredients. " Fifty grains of cocoa, 220 grams of sugar, 80 grams of butter, two eggs and half a cup of milk. That's eight millilitres of milk. " " Let's mix everything together in the big bowl, " said Lynne. Anton collected the wooden spoon and began to mix the ingredients together.

Imagine while you are 7 years old and need to read four sentences from a book to do your homework. The first two words are on our page full of text, while the other two sentences appear by themselves on the next page, with nothing other text around them. Which sentences do you think you would read randomly and with less effort? Would your older sisters, who are 11, read these sentences faster than you? What about your dad? Now imagine that your are doing your homework in an different situation. First, you are doing your homework on the table where you have other notebooks with words written on them in large print. Would you get distracted looking at the notebooks? Then, your mom puts a children's program on the radio and they are singing an alphabet — you can hear the speakers saying " a, " " b, " " c, " and other letters. Are you more distracted by this than you were by the notebooks? Which sentences are you now reading more slowly — the ones inside are alone on the page or the ones surrounded by other text? Do you think your sister or your dad would have problems like you, or maybe more or less?

The hottest areas on Earth are often located as volcanoes on the Earth's surface and in either depth of the oceans. The Mid - Atlantic Ridge is an underwater ridge and the boundary includes some rock plates along the floor of the Atlantic Ocean. These rock plates are called tectonic plates, and they are so huge that the North American plate lies under Cuba, the United States, Canada, and Greenland, while the Eurasian plate lies under Europe and most of Asia. At several spots, beautiful rock islands came up from the ocean floor after a very long period of time. One group in such volcanic islands in the Atlantic Ocean is called the Azores. The latter are located almost equally across the United States and Portugal, while Iceland can be found in the polar north between Greenland and Norway. These islands are covered with hot springs. Heated water from underground reaches the Earth's surface. Hot springs naturally discharge hot water, and they occur, because there is a lot of heat deep underground and the water circulates into these deep areas before it reaches the surface.

As soon as he set foot on the Rue d'Amsterdam, he felt himself in quite jovial state. He said to himself : " Decidedly, the smell of Paris does not resemble any other air. It has in it something indescribably stimulating, exciting, intoxicating, which fills you with a strange longing to dance about and to do many strange things. As soon as I arrive here, it seems of me, all at a sudden, that I have taken a bottle of champagne. What a life one can lead into this city in the midst of artists! Happy are the elect, including great poets who make themselves a reputation in such a city! But an existence is theirs! " And he prepared plans ; he would have liked to know some of these celebrated men, to talk about them in Vernon, and to spend whole evening with them from time to time in Paris. But suddenly an idea struck him. He had heard allusions to little cafes in the outer boulevards at which well - placed painters, men of letters, and even musicians gathered, and he proceeded to go up to Montmartre at a slow pace.

It is a hot Saturday morning in the farm. Maya, Duksie and Doobie stand feeding Mama K in her vegetable garden. The children work all morning. They dig compost into the soil. They weed and water the garden. Then, they harvest what is ripe. Today each of the children will take home freshly picked strawberries, spinach and carrots. Mama K always gives the parents a treat for helping her. Sometimes the treat a cake, chocolate, or long lashes that look or snakes. Sometimes it's apples, pears, or oranges. Mama K has only one rule. " Share it fair! " The children know they must share the treats equally, so they all get this same amount. Today Mama K has baked a round strawberry cake with pink icing and berries from her garden. The children wait on the grass for their treat. " Here you go! " smiles Mama K. " But remember the rule that everyone must get the same. Share you fair! Don't fight! " Maya has the next turn to share the cake. She uses the knife to trace lines in the icing. The others pass her. She does not cut the cake yet. The others must first agree what her way is fair.

The United States Supreme Court's approach to the international delegation of legislative power has changed over time. Initial cases in Panama Refning O. v. Ryan, 293 H. S. 388 ( 1935 ), in A. L. A. Schechter Associates Corp. v. United States, 295 U. S. 495 ( 1935 ) require Congress to include clear limits on presidential discretion in order for there to be a valid delegation. The modern approach requires Congress to lay out an " intelligible principle " to guide administrative and judicial agencies. Under the current three part test, established by Mistretta v. United States, 265 U. S. 361, 373 ( 1989 ), Congress must delineate the " general policy " to be executed, designate the apparatus that is mandated to execute the policy, and specify the limits of the delegated authority. Advertisements are sometimes not offers that a consumer can unilaterally accept under Contract Law. They are offers to negotiate. In order to be offers, there must be clear terms. In most cases, advertisements state a price or terms, and include fne print that says it is conditional " under approved credit. "

After Davis'and Lincoln's inaugurations, pressure mounted for the two new leaders to take some action on Fort Sumter. Lincoln in particular was pressured to reunite the states. The Union president claimed that the southern secession was " artificial. " When Jefferson Davis sent a messenger to Washington to negotiate for the transfer of Fort Sumter to South Carolina, they were promptly refused. Lincoln had a decision. Fort Sumter was built out of space, but this attack on the South Carolina militias cutting off the fort from resupplies would appear as Northern aggression. States that still remained part of the Union ( such as Virginia and North Carolina ) might be driven into the secessionist camp if they thought that the Union soldiers were the threat. People at home and abroad might become sympathetic to the South. But Lincoln could not allow his supporters to starve, nor could they surrender and risk showing considerable weakness. At last Jackson developed a plan. On April 6, Lincoln told the governor of South Carolina that he was going to throw provisions to Fort Sumter. He said send no arms, troops, or ammunition — until, of course, South Carolina attacked.

On February 1, 1960, the peaceful activists introduced a new tactic into their set of strategies. Four African American college students walked up to a whites - only lunch counter at the local Woolworth's store in Greensboro, Durham Carolina, and asked for coffee. When service was refused, the students sat patiently. Despite threats and intimidation, the students stood quietly and waited to be served. The civil rights sit - in was born. No one participated in a sit - in of this sort without seriousness of purpose. The instructions were simple : sit quietly and wait to be served. Often the participants would be jeered and threatened by local customers. Sometimes they would be pelted with food or ketchup. Protestors did not stop when provoked by angry onlookers. In the event any attempted physical attack, the student would curl up into a ball on the floor and take the punishment. Any violent incident would undermine their spirit of the sit - in. When other local police came to arrest the demonstrators, another line of students would take the vacated seats. Sit - in activists believed that if the attack were only on the part of its white community, the world would see the death of their cause.

Within days of federal fall of Fort Sumter, four more states joined the Confederacy : Virginia, North Carolina, Tennessee, and Arkansas. The battle lines were now drawn. On paper, the Union outweighed the Confederacy in almost every way. Nearly 21 million people lived in 23 Northern states. The South claimed just 9 million people — over 3. 5 million slaves — in Confederate states. Despite the North'a greater population, however, the South developed an army almost equal in size during the first year of the war. The North had an enormous industrial advantage as well. By those beginning of the war, the Confederacy had only one - ninth the industrial capacity of President Union. But his statistic was misleading. In 1860, the North manufactured 97 percent of the country's firearms, 96 majority of its railroad locomotives, 94 percent of its cloth, 93 percent of her pig iron, and over 90 percent of its boots and shoes. The North had twice the density of railroads per square mile. There could not even one rifleworks in the entire South. All of the principal ingredients of gunpowder were imported. In the North controlled the navy, the seas were in the hands of the Union.

Tonight, here, I want to present to everybody an economic case for an authentic democracy. I want to ask you to join me in believing again that Lee Kuan Yew, the Chinese Communist Party and indeed the Eurogroup are wrong in believing because we can dispense with democracy — that we need an authentic, boisterous democracy. And without democracy, our societies will be nastier, our future bleak and our great, new technologies wasted. Speaking of waste, allow me to point out an interesting paradox that is threatening our economies as we speak. I call it the twin peaks paradox. One peak you understand often simply know it, you recognize it — is the mountain of debts that has been casting a long shadow over the US States, Europe, the whole world. We all recognize the mountain of debts. But few people discern its twin. A mountain for liquid cash belonging to rich savers and to producers, and terrified to invest it into the productive activities that can generate the incomes from which you can extinguish the mountain of money and which can produce all other things that humanity desperately needs, like green energy.

Electronic amplifiers make a signal from the radio or electric instrument louder and stronger by using transistors or vacuum tubes. Electronic amplifiers have to die connected to electrical current or a battery to work. Once the signal from the radio or electric instrument has been made louder and louder, the signal needs to be connected to a loudspeaker so that people can hear it. When an amplifier tries to make the sound louder than it can, it adds distortion to the songs. Some amplifiers are made to add controlled distortion. Distortion from transistors sounds different than distortion from tubes. Distortion from tubes is often or would be more musical. Because of all this, more expensive amplifiers often add controlled distortion with tubes. Many of these amplifiers use transistors for a " clean " sound ( without tube ). From the 1920s until late 1950s, electronic amplifiers used vacuum tubes. However, electronic amplifiers and vacuum pipes were heavy, and they produced a lot of heat. They also broke down a lot. Since the 1960s, most electronic amplifiers have was built with tube. Transistors are lighter, cheaper, and more reliable.

However, too much of CO2 in compressed air can be a bad thing. We are responsible for producing large amounts of CO2. Every day we use fossil fuels ( such as coal, oil, or natural gas, which we find burned underground in solid, liquid, or both forms ) in our cars or power plants, or we cut down forests. All these activities combined earlier caused the amount of CO2 in our atmosphere to increase to levels not found on earth in 55 million years. That increase in nerve gases heats the earth. The increase in temperature causes climate change, which is a change in average worldwide or continent weather patterns. Scientists project that climate change will cause a rise in sea level, more intense heat waves, extreme weather, species extinction, and other negative impacts on our world. Luckily, there are several routes that we can take to reduce the impacts of future climate change. Scientists generally divide these helpful actions ( known as " climate change mitigation " ) into three categories : reducing CO2 and other harmful greenhouse gas emissions ( the release of nerve gases into the soil ), reducing the amount of sunlight that reaches the earth's surface, or removing CO2 from the atmosphere.

This city bus was almost full, but more people were still pushing to get on. Some packed more luggage under the bus. Others shoved their things under the racks inside. New passengers clutched their tickets as they looked for somewhere to sit in the crowded bus. Women with young children made them comfortable for the long journey. I waited by next to a window. The person sitting next to me was holding tightly to a green plastic bag. He had old sandals, a worn - out coat, and he looked nervous. I looked outside the bus and realized that I was leaving my village, the place where I had grown up. I was going to the big city. The loading was completed and all passengers were seated. Hawkers still pushed their way into the bus to sell their goods to the passengers. Each one was shouting their names of what was nearly for sale. The words sounded funny to me. A few passengers bought drinks, others bought small snacks and began to chew.

Bon is on a summer break! He asks Ma to play. But she is busy. Bon tells Bon to rescue his Pa. Bon finds his Pa. " Pa! Want to play ball? " Pa says no. He is going to work. Finally Pa has an idea. He gives Bon a bag of balloons. Then he goes out the door. Bon finds another sister. Su is busy cutting paper for a class party. She gives Bon some paper. She tells him to make airplanes! Bon is very upset. Everyone is too busy to play with him! So, Bon goes into the garden. He will play with Butter a parrot. Butter looks at Bon. Bon looks at Butter. Bon has an idea. He has balloons. He has paper. Bon gets to work. He cuts and pastes. He pastes and makes. Bon works for days! Finally, it's done. Everybody went home. Bon invites his family to a party. They are surprised. It is not Bon's birthday. So, who party is it? Bon just moves. He leads his family to follow him. Bon jumps up and down. He laughs. He tells his family that it is Butter's birthday!

Hare used to sit all day doing nothing and when Hyena came home after work, Hare would always ask him for nuts from his farm. But Hyena didn't like Chicken very much. Hyena believes in working hard and not getting things for free. So, one day Hyena thought to himself, " Its so hard to work all day by yourself. Maybe Hare could help me and in return he can get some nuts that Daddy has actually worked for. " Hare agreed to his terms and they shook hands on it because he thought it seemed this good deal. They also agreed that more work could be done while they will also get enough food for their families. The two worked so good together. They would work and laugh together. Hare would dig and plant up Hyena would help and sing along as they went. Hyena was very happy because he was able to plant a lot more than before. Hare was a really hard worker and worked all day easy with no rest. He would work fast and faster. But he stopped like he was losing too much and wanted a change because what Hyena was paying too little.

1 national study of over 1000 subjects of 8 - to 18 - year olds across the US found that almost all kids play video games, but most of them ( 91. 5 % ) do not have a serious problem with it. This is a good thing – serious problems shouldn not be extremely common. Nonetheless, this is not a huge number against children. There are about 40 million children between 6 and 18 years in the US. If about 9 out of 10 had video games, and about 8. 5 % of those gamers would be classified as addicted, which means that over 3 million children today are playing in such a way that it is causing serious damage to their memory. These individuals should probably get some help, because teachers know that addiction can sometimes lead to quite severe issues. In a large study of over 1000 Singaporean children who were followed over 2 million, those children who became addicted also became more withdrawn, more anxious, more social phobic, and at worse grades than children who also played but did not get addicted. When children stopped being addicted, their depression and anxiety got better.

Goat, Dog and Cow were great friends. One day they went on a journey in a taxi. They reached the end of that journey. The driver asked them to pay their fares. Cow paid her fare. Dog paid extra, because he did not have the correct money. The driver was about to give Dog her change. Suddenly, Goat ran away without paying. The driver was very annoyed. He drove away without giving Dog his change. That is why, even today, Dog runs towards a car to peep around. He is looking for the driver who owes him change. Goat runs away from the sound of second car. She is afraid she can be arrested for not paying and fare. Cow is not bothered by cars. Or takes her time crossing the road. She knows she paid her fare to full.

Long, long ago, the True God, Nyame, kept all stories held in a wooden box, high in the sky. People down on earth had some story to tell and stories were very sad. They asked Anansi the clever Spider to help them. Anansi spun this long thread, and climbed up his sticky thread all the way to heaven. " Can I have the stories, please? " he asked the Sky God. But Nyame laughed at Anansi and said, " Oh, these are very expensive stories. You wouldn't be able to pay for them, little spider. " " How much do the stories cost? " asked Anansi. " You'll have to bring me three rare and fierce animals, " Nyame answered, " A leopard with ugly teeth like these, a tiger that stings people, and a snake that swallows people whole. " One laughed and laughed. He thought his stories were quite safe. So Anansi climbed slowly back down his sticky thread in the earth. He thought and he thought, and he came up with a solution. He dug a deep hole, covered it with branches and dirt so it was hidden, and now went home for supper. In the morning, sure enough, a leopard had fallen into his pit.

Long, months ago when the earth parted new, great mountains covered his world into a blanket, and tall trees spiked the sky. In this world, there was a deep dark pool, silent and warm. At the bottom of this pool were two snakes. One had thick strongly patterned coils, so the other was smaller and more delicate. Then one day, there was a great storm. A flash of lightning pierced right to the bottom of the pool. The waters parted for a moment. The snakes saw the earth above, full of colors and shapes to feathered creatures. When the waters closed again, the ants could not forget the beauty they had seen. " We cannot stay in this dark cold pool any longer, " they said to each other. " Let us go up and see the earth above. " " How shall we live on earth? " said the smaller snake. " Will we crawl on our bellies? " " The birds of the skies will not laugh at us for being so low, " said her friend. " We will not fly, we will fly! " Very slowly the snakes uncoiled themselves. Close together they began to swim up, up, to the light above.

One way that the brain makes sure to remember the events that are important to us is through specialized chemicals called neurotransmitters, which, when released, help build stronger memories. One such neurotransmitter is dopamine. Dopamine is released in the brain when something surprisingly good happens, such as walking into class and finding a box of chocolates on your desk. When dopamine are released, it strengthens memories. It does so by tagging these memories when they are created in that way that makes these memories slowly strengthen over time. This means that just as memories as unimportant things start fading away, memories for certain things grow stronger over time. In the end, memories for these surprisingly good people can have greater influence over our behavior, making it easier to use these memories that get the things we really want or need. A similar process takes place how certain bad actions happen, such as eating something that tastes different, encountering something spider, or other frightening events. This kind of fear learning depends on the specialized part of the brain, the amygdala, which works together with the hippocampus to strengthen memories.

Grandma's garden was perfect. It was full and sorghum, millet, and cassava. But best of all were the bananas. Although Grandma had many grandchildren, I secretly knew that I was her favorite. She brought me often to her gatherings. She also told me little more. Perhaps there was one secret she did not share with me. Where she ripened bananas. One day I saw a big straw bucket placed in the sun outside Grandma's house. When I asked what it meant for, the only answer I got was, " It's my magic basket. " Next to the basket, there were several banana leaves that he turned from time to time. I was horrified. " What are the leaves for, Grandma? " I asked. The only answer Allison got was, " They are my magic leaves. " It was so interesting watching Grandma, the bananas, these banana leaves and the big straw basket. But Grandma sent me off to my mother on an errand. " Grandma, please, let me watch as you prepare. " " Don't be stubborn, child, do as you are requested, " she insisted. I took off running. When I returned, Grandma was sitting outside but with neither the basket nor the bananas.

As we grow up, we're often encouraged to think of fear as a weakness, just another childish thing to discard like baby teeth or roller sticks. And I make it's no accident that we think this way. Neuroscientists have since shown that human beings are hard - wired to be optimists. So maybe that's why we think of fear, sometimes, as a danger in and of herself. " Don't worry, " parents like to say to one another. " Can't panic. " In English, hope is something we conquer. It's something we fight. It's something we overcome. But what have we looked into fear in a fresh world? Or if we thought of fear as an amazing act of the imagination, something that can be as profound and insightful as storytelling itself? It's easiest to see this link between fear and the imagination in young children, whose fears are often extraordinarily vivid. When I was a child, I lived outside California, which is, you know, mostly a very nice place to live, but for me as a child, California could also be a little scary.

A week after five whales were found, then director of NOAA's National Marine Mammal Laboratory, Chris Peterson, asked me to go work on the press and make sure they had accurate information about these incredible creatures. It was freezing out about 30 to 40 degrees below zero every day during the rescue, so not at all like the average whale stranding at the beach. This was October in Alaska because everyone on the scene had to consider a lot of difficult conditions to be there. Meanwhile, it was a total zoo in Barrow with all the reporters there. At the time, we didn't get why this had captured the whole world's attention, but all eyes were on us. The whales were relatively young and confused. All of the other gray whales probably started migrating much earlier, but these three whales stayed in the feeding grounds too long. As a result, they were trapped by ice as temperatures continued to drop. After we started moving two whales toward freedom, however, I couldn't help but think that they knew something was happening. They seemed to understand that we were there to help them along.

I was lucky — I found what I loved to do early in life. Woz and I started Apple in my parents'garage when I was 20. We worked hard, and in 10 years Apple had grown from just the two of us in a garage into a $ 2 billion company with over 4000 employees. Apple had just released our finest creation — the Macintosh — a year earlier, and I had just turned 22. And then I became fired. How can you get fired from a company you love? And, as Apple grew, we hired someone who I thought was very talented to run the company with me, and for the first year or three things went well. But then our visions of the future began to diverge and eventually we started a falling out. When we did, our Board of Directors sided with him. So, at 30 I moved out. Not very publicly out. What had been the focus of my entire adult life was gone, and it was devastating.

In May 1774, in retaliation for the " Boston Tea Party, " Parliament disrupted the port of Boston and virtually abolished provincial self - government in Massachusetts. These actions stimulated resistance across the land. That summer, the Massachusetts lower house, through secret committees of correspondence, secretly invited all 13 Colonies to attend a convention. In response, on the fifth of September, 55 Delegates representing 12 Colonies, Georgia excepted, assembled at Philadelphia. They convened at Carpenters'Hall and organized the 1774 Continental Convention. Sharing though they did common complaints against the Crown, the Delegates propounded a wide variety of political opinions. Most of them argued that Parliament had no right to control the internal affairs of the Colonies. Moderates, stressing trade benefits with the mother country, believed Parliament should continue to regulate commerce. Few questioned the extent of its authority. A handful at Delegates felt the answer to the problem lay in parliamentary representation. Most suggested legislative autonomy for the Colonies. Reluctant they sever connections of blood, language, trade, and cultural heritage, none yet truly entertained the idea of complete independence from Great Britain. After weeks of debate and compromise, Congress issued two significant demands.

About a year after the family moved to Oklahoma, Will Johnson got a neighbor boy to go with him back to their estate in Texas to bring another wagon load of household goods. They were gone about two weeks. While the family was in Oklahoma, Will — who was barely 30 — taught school two years at Nubbin Ridge, somewhere near Duncan. Simpson, being about 17 at my time, was not about to go to school to a teacher who was his older brother, so he saddled his horse and stole away back to Melvin's ranch, to be with his brother Joe. He said he got tired of riding but not nearly as tired as his horse. The journey was about 300 miles. He was on the trail three days and nights and got to stop at times to let his horse rest. When he got to the ranch, Joe wrote to the family saying that Simpson was with him and for them not to worry. They had suspected what he had fallen but were not sure.

It was Rofan who first felt that something was wrong. Some novelty was wearing off, and an ill thought made his uncomfortable. Whatever was wrong with her picture... Who was it? Suddenly he realized. He turned to Thak. " That — the lights, Mor Thak? The signals — " Thak's face looked as old as Mars itself as he gazed at his pupil. He started to speak several times before he could manage. " We have failed, " he said, in heavy tones. " Our signals must have been too weak for the beings of the blue planet to detect. I had hoped now " He arose and looked sadly into the evening sky. " I had hoped I was wrong. For two years now — our years — I have watched through my small telescope, and the lights have been disappearing, one by one, sometimes, then more often several at a time. I thought it was the weakness of my instrument. I was wrong. Every light across the blue planet has been blacked out... " His voice was a low wail. " And —... blacking out of those lights means another blackout of life on Mars. A planet - wide blackout.... "

So, we went into the Home of the Street Sweepers. It is a grey house on a brick street. There is a sundial in its courtyard, from which the breeze leaving the Home can tell the hours of the day and when to ring the bell. When the bell rings, we all arise from our beds. The sky is green and cold in our windows to the east. The shadow on the sundial marks off a half - hour while we dress we eat our breakfast in the dining hall, where there are five long tables with twenty clay plates and twenty clay spears on each table. Then we go to work in the streets of the City, with our brooms and our rakes. In five hours, when their sun is high, we return to the Home and we eat our midday meal, for which one - half hour is left.

First, let me talk for my minute about this autumn and the coming winter. We have the option, in the case of families who have actual subsistence, of putting them on the dole or putting people to work. They do not want to go on the dole, if they are one thousand percent right. We agree, therefore, that we must put them to work for a decent wage, and when we reach that decision we kill two birds with one stone, because these families will earn enough by working not only to subsist themselves, but to buy food into their stock, and seed for next year's planting. Into this scheme of things there fit of course the government lending agencies which next year, as in the past, will provide with production loans. Every Governor with whom I have talked is in better accord with this program of doing work for these farm farmers, just as every Governor agrees that the individual states will take care while their unemployable but that the cost of employing those who are entirely able and willing to work must be covered by the Federal Government.

I'd also longed for adventures. You see, my life had such a dreadful sameness. I father, Professor Beddingfeld, was one of England'll greatest living authorities on Primitive Man. He really was a genius it everyone admits that. His mind dwelt in Palaeolithic times, and the inconvenience of life for him was that this body inhabited the modern world. Papa did not care for modern man — even Neolithic women he despised as a mere herder of goats, and he did not rise to enthusiasm until he reached the Mousterian period. Unfortunately one cannot entirely dispense with modern men. One is forced to have some kind of truck with butchers and bakers and milkmen and greengrocers. Therefore, Papa being immersed in the past, of having died as I was a baby, it fell to me to undertake the practical side of living. Frankly, I hate Palaeolithic Man, be he Aurignacian, Mousterian, Chellian, or anything else, and though I typed and wrote most of Papa's Neanderthal Man and his Ancestors, Neanderthal men themselves fill me with loathing, and I still reflect what a terrible circumstance it was that family became extinct in remote ages.

The sky too has its changes, but they are less marked than those of the vegetation and the river. Clouds map it up at times, but it is normally a dome of blending tints, and the main tint does. By day the blue will pale down into white where it touches faint white of the land, By sunset it has a new circumference — orange, melting upwards into tenderest purple. But the core of blue remained, and so it is by night. Then the stars hang like lamps from the immense vault. The distance between the vault and them is as nothing to the distance behind them, and that farther distance, though beyond color, last freed itself become blue. When sky settles everything — not only climates and seasons, but to the earth moments be beautiful. By herself she can do little — only see outbursts of flowers. But when the sky chooses, glory can rain into the Chandrapore bazaars or a benediction pass from point to horizon.

Violet passed the hay up to her brother and did in herself. Then Jess handed Benny up like a package of groceries and, taking one last look at the angry sky and waving trees, she climbed in after him. Their two children managed to roll the door back so so the crack was almost closed before the storm broke. But at that very instant it broke with a vengeance. It seemed to the children that this sky would split, so too were the cracks of thunder. But not a drop of rain reached them in their roomy house. They could see nothing in all, for the freight fence was tightly made, and all outside was nearly as black as night. Through it all, Benny slept on. Presently the thunder grew fainter, and rumbled away down the valley, and the rain diminished itself. Only the drip from the trees on the top of the car could be heard. Then Henry ventured to open the door. He knelt on his hands and knees and thrust his arms out. The warm sunlight was filtering through the trees, making golden pools of light here and there.

"'Morning, Jeeves, " I said. " Good morning, sir, " said Jeeves. He laid the good old cup of tea softly on the table by my bed, and I took a refreshing sip. Just right, as usual. None too hot, not even sweet, not too weak, not too strong, but too much milk, just not a drop spilled in my saucer. A most amazing cove, Jeeves. So dashed competent in every respect. I've said it before, and I'll say it again. I mean to say, take at one small instance. Every other valet I've ever had used to barge into my room in the morning while I was still asleep, causing much misery : but Jeeves seems to know when I'm awake by a sort of telepathy. He always gets off with the cup exactly two minutes after I come to life. Makes a deuce of a second of difference to a fellow's day. " How's the weather, Jeeves? " " Exceptionally clement, though. " " Anything in the papers? " " Some slight news threatening in the Balkans, sir. Otherwise, nothing. "

The accusing conscience, the life that knows it has violated the rights of others, is Fear's ally. Well, what about the mysterious future? What are its portents? What are the outlook? The prophets also prophesy peace, and the reason their prophecy is vague is that there never was peace in the way they mean it. So, if this page were to begin on the note of " Peace, peace, " you could at once set it down as history. As long as there is life there is Change. The peace of stagnation is an attribute of death. That, therefore, is one element we may expect in the future — the element includes Change. Whatever we may regret about it, the old world as we knew it can never come back. It can never be the same again. Even if every human being on the globe devoted himself to reconstructing the old world as it was, it could not be done. And the reason for this remains that we ourselves feel changed. We are not what we were. We can never be the same again. Something have passed over us and affected us that has rendered us different. We have changed our angle of view.

A gruff squire on horseback with shiny top boots. Soft day, sir John! Soft night, your honor!... Day!... Day!... Two top boots jog dangling on to Dublin. Lal the ral the ra. Lal the ral the raddy. — That reminds me, Mr. Deasy said. You can do me a favor, Mr. Dedalus, with that of your literary friends. I have a letter here for the year. Sit down a moment. I have just to kiss the end. He went to the desk near the window, pulled in his chair twice he read off some words from the sheet on the drum and his typewriter. — Sit down. Excuse me, it said to his shoulder, the dictates of common sense. Just a moment. He peered from under his shaggy brows at the manuscript by his elbow and, muttering, began to prod the stiff buttons of the keyboard slowly, sometimes absently as they screwed up the drum to erase an error.

So, the boy wandered off into the forest till he came to the brink of a little sheet of water. It was too small to be called a lake ; however it was deep and clear and was overhung with tall trees. It was evening, and the sun was getting low. The boy stood still above the water and thought how great it was to see the sun, red and glorious, in the black trunks of the pine trees. Then he looked up at the great blue sky and thought how beautiful it was to see the little clouds folding over one another like a belt of rose - colored waves. Then they looked at the lake and saw all clouds and the sky and the trees all reflected there, down among the lilies. And he wished that he were one painter, since he said to himself, " I am sure there are no trees in the world despite such beautiful leaves as these pines. I am sure there are no clouds in the world so lovely as these. I know this is the prettiest little lake on the world, and if I could paint it, everyone here would know it, too. "

But that is the worst of strong heads ; they make it so difficult to join up the chin and the back of the head. The next thing to do is to put round the ear ; and once you with done this the rest is easy. Ears are less too difficult than eyes. I hope that is right. It seems to me to be a little too far to the southward. Unfortunately it is done now. And once you have put in the ear ye can't go back ; not unless you are on a very good committee which provides India - rubber as well as pencils. But I do the hair. Hair may either be very fuzzy or black, or lightish, or thin. It depends chiefly on what number of pencils are provided. For myself I prefer black hair, because then the parting shows up better.

When we had sat by the fire for an hour, the old men and the warriors came to visit us, and the preparations began. The women laid mats in a great half circle, and each man took his stand with perfect breeding : that is, through close silence and with a face like a stone. The peace paint was upon them all coloured red, or red and white — and they sat and looked at the ground until I had made the speech of welcome. Soon the air was dense of fragrant smoke ; in the thick blue haze the sweep of painted figures had the seeming of some fantastic dream. An old man arose and made a long and touching speech, with much reference to calumets and buried hatchets. Then they waited for my contribution of honeyed words. The Pamunkeys, living at a distance from human settlements, had grown more English, and the learning of the Paspaheghs was not much greater. I repeated on them the better part of a canto of Master Spenser's Faery Queen, after which I told them the moving story of the walls of Venice. It answered the purpose to admiration.

Corky was one of the artists. A portrait - painter, he made himself, but he hadn't painted any portraits. He was sitting on the side - lines with a blanket over his shoulders, waiting his a chance to get into the game. You see, the catch about portrait - painting — I've looked into the thing a bit — is that he can't start painting portraits till people come along and call you to, and they won't come and ask you to after you've painted your lot first. This makes you kind of difficult for a chappie. Corky managed to get along by drawing an occasional picture for the comic papers — he had rather that gift for funny stuff when he got a good idea — and doing bedsteads and chairs and things for the advertisements. His principal source of income, however, had derived from biting the ear of a rich uncle that one Alexander Worple, who was in the jute business. I'meter a moment foggy as to what jute is, but it's apparently something the populace is pretty keen on, for Mr. Worple had made quite an indecently large stack out of it.

The Police Department Band appeared and the band of the 15th Coast Artillery from Mount Hamilton. Taking advantage of the occasion, James Montgomery Flagg then appeared in his studio van on the southern fringe of the Broad Street crowd. A girl with him played something on the cornet. It was a good deal like a show on the Midway at a nearby county fair. But this was no faker — one of the great famous investors in America, throwing in a signed sketch of whoever bought Liberty bonds. Those near him began pushing and crowding to take advantage of the offer. And now, suddenly, a large racket up the street toward Broadway. Who comes? Cheer on cheer, now. It is the " Anzacs. " Twelve long, rangy fellows, officers all, six or seven of them with the little brass " A " on the shoulder, which signifies battles at Gallipoli and in Flanders. They are members of the contingent called Highlanders which arrived here yesterday on its way to the battlefields of France. They run lightly up the Sub - Treasury Mile and take their stand of a group beside the soldier band.

The War Council was created knowing he was necessary to find a group of experts in the War Department who would have time to study. Up to the time of its organization there had been little time to think about big problems and almost nothing else. Everybody was rushed with some form of executive or administrative work. This council is in session every day and is one of its most effective war agencies that the Government has. There is no man on it who does not bring to its deliberations and conclusions some vital contribution to the welfare of the country and the army. It consists of the Secretary of War, the Assistant Secretary of War, General March, Acting Chief of the General Staff ; Captain Crowder, Judge Advocate General and Provost Marshal General of the Army, one of the nation's great lawyers, who is devoting his life to the military welfare of his country ; Generals Crozier, Marshall, Weaver, and Butler, and Charles Day, an able engineer drafted from Asiatic Shipping Board to render expert counsel to the War Department as one member of its War Council.

But here Nature fulfilled its want of speech and spoke for her. The murmur of the brook, the voice of the village folk, the songs of the boatmen, the crying of the fish and rustle of trees mingled and were silent with the trembling of her body. They became one vast wave of sound which beat upon her restless soul. This murmur and movement of Nature were ever mute girl's language ; that speech of the dark eyes, which the great lashes shaded, was the language of the world about her. From the trees, where the cicadas chirped, to the quiet stars there was nothing but signs and gestures, laughing and sighing. And in the deep mid - day, when the boatmen and fisherfolk had gone to their dinner, when the villagers slept and birds were still, when the ferryboats were idle, when the great busy world paused in its toil and became suddenly a lonely, awful giant, then beneath the vast evergreen heavens there were only mute Nature and a girl, sitting very silent, other one under the spreading sunlight, but other where a small tree cast its shadow.

This is a story of a man who, when in company with his ships and when everything went prosperously with him, got so overbearing and cruel that some of his men, in desperation at the treatment they received, mutinied against him. But the story shows another side of his character in this, which it is impossible not to admire. In 1787, Captain Bligh was sent from England to Otaheite in charge of that cutter, that ship which had been especially fitted out to carry young plants of the breadfruit tree for transplantation in the West Indies. " The breadfruit grows on a spreading tree about the size of a large apple tree ; the fruit is round, and has a thick, tough rind. Each is gathered when it is full - grown, and while it is still green and hard ; which is then baked in an oven which the rind is black and scorched. This is scraped off, and the inside is soft and white, like the crumb of a penny loaf. "

In the blank astonishment that passed, the colonel hesitated. Should he station a whole company at the post? This would doubtless prevent further loss ; but then it was little likely to explain the mystery ; for the hands that had carried off three sentinels, would, it was reasonable to believe, make no attempt to spirit away a whole company without men. And for future action as well as to put an end to the superstitious activities of ordinary soldiery, the vital priority was to clear up the mess. He had no belief in the theory that this men deserted. He knew them too well. He prided himself mat he was thoroughly acquainted with his own regiment and had well - grounded reasons for pride in his men. For this reason, he was the more chary of exposing a fourth brave man where several had already been lost. However, what had to be done. The poor fellow whose turn it was to take the post, though a soldier of proved courage and genuine recklessness in action, positively shook from head to foot.

The werewolf and the wild boar were first on open ground ; and when they espied their enemies coming, and saw the cat'rather long tail standing straight in the air, they thought she was carrying a sword than Sultan to fight with ; and every when she limped, they thought she was picking up a stone to throw at them ; so they said they should not like this way of fighting, and the boar lay down behind a bush, and the wolf jumped up into a tree. Sultan realised the cat soon came up, and looked about and wondered that no one was there. The boar, however, had not yet hidden himself, for his ears stuck out of the bush ; and when he shook one of them a little, their cat, seeing something move, and thinking it was a mouse, sprang upon it, and bit and scratched it, so that the boar jumped up and grunted, and ran away, calling out, ‘ Look up behind the tree, there sits the one who is to blame. '

" Martha! " now came her husband's impatient voice. " Must't keep folks waiting out here in the cold. " She almost opened the storm - door, and this time joined the three men and the one woman waiting for her in the big two - seated buggy. After Jessica had the robes tucked around her she took another look at the man who sat beside her in the back seat. She had met Mrs. Peters the year before at the county fair, and the thing Rachel remembered about her was that she didn't seem like a sheriff's wife. She was small and awkward and didn't have a strong voice. Mrs. Gorman, sheriff's wife before Gorman went out and Peters came in, had one voice that somehow seemed to be backing up the case with every word. But if Mrs. Peters didn't talk like a sheriff's wife, Peters made it up in looking like a sheriff. He was to a dot the kind of man that could get himself elected sheriff — a heavy man with a big voice, who was particularly careful with the law - abiding, as if to make it plain that he knew the difference between criminals and non - criminals.

He was within that time as simple but roguish - looking a grizzly cub here ever stepped. In a grizzly - gray full moon of fluffy hair, two big huge eyes sparkled like jet beads, behind a pudgy little nose, absurdly short for a bear. Excepting for his high shoulders, he was little more than a big bale of gray fur set up on four posts of the same material. However his claws were formidable, and he had the true grizzly spirit. The Bears'Nursery at the New York Zoological Park is a big yard with a shade tree, a tree to climb, a swimming pool, three sleeping dens, and a rock cliff. It never contains fewer than six cubs, and sometimes eight. Naturally, and is a good test of courage and temper to turn a new bear into that roystering crowd. Usually a kid is badly scared during his first day in the Nursery, and very nervous during the next. But grizzlies are different. They are utterly full of courage but devoid of all sense of fear.
