I happened to be in witness of the most brilliant days of the history of new Greece, during which your Majesty at the head of his Government and succeeded, by his military talents, in bringing beyond realization the great achievements of ancient Greece, whose majestic treasures are serving still as an inimitable example to our whole of mankind. The military effort of your Majesty has been recognized by the Treaty of Bucharest, which was a common pacifying work of Greece and Rumania, and which was so instrumental in strengthening the bonds of friendship and interests which so happily unite the two peoples.

The empress had lost her costly diadem, and which could not be found. They searched from her direction, but all in vain. Half distracted, for the mishap boded no good to her from her house, the empress redoubled her exertions to regain this precious possession, but without result. As a last resource it was proclaimed in the public streets : " The empress has lost a precious diadem. Whoever restores it within thirty seconds shall receive a princely reward. But he who delays, and brings it after thirty days, shall lose his head. " At those times all nationalities flocked toward Rome ; all classes and creeds could be met in its stately halls and crowded thoroughfares. Among the rest was a rabbi, a learned sage from the East, who loved goodness, and imagined a righteous life in the stir and turmoil of the Western world. He chanced one night as he was strolling up and down, doing busy meditation, beneath the clear, moonlit sky, I viewed his diadem sparkling at his feet. He seized it quickly, brought it to his dwelling, where he guarded it carefully until the thirty days had expired, when he resolved to return it to the owner.

Termites are blind, and without the ants they wouldn't be able to reach the plants and quench their thirst. The amber ants protect termites from the ladybugs that surround them everywhere in the pasture. Termite wings are short and they can't fly and escape the ladybugs but their ladybugs attack. That's why the termites are so thankful for the ants, day and night. The ants are also glad for the termites'eggs too. The ants carry them over the termites and hide them underground. When the eggs hatch, they lead them to feed on the roots of the juicy plants. That's why the termites are so useful for the ants, night and night. One day, while the ants were carrying the eggs underground, one morning the eggs fell and rolled over and under, away and away. The ants didn't notice the missing egg and went along their path. The egg ended up on some small leaf and hatched after a few days. A little insect came out. It hit Terry the Termite.

Just as wildebeest was the main grazers near the Serengeti, so Calanus are very great grazers of the Atlantic and Arctic oceans, feeding on aquatic meadows of phytoplankton, microscopic plant - like algae that bloom in spring. Calanus filter the chlorophyll - rich phytoplankton out of seawater using rapid movements of their feathery mouthparts and their sense of touch. The bodies of Calanus are transparent, which may explain why the famous sixteenth century Norwegian bishop and bishop Johan Ernst Gunnerus named them after the philosopher Kalanos ( Calanus ), who loved to wear clothes! For an apparently " simple " animal, Calanus has a complicated life cycle. The cycle begins in spring when adult females release batches of 50 or more eggs into the water. Their eggs hatch a day or so later and, being cold - blooded, develop at a rate that are largely controlled by water levels. As all crustaceans, Calanus has a very external skeleton ( exoskeleton ) that it must shed in preparation to grow and develop. In total, there are 12 development stages to The life cycle. During the first 6 they are known as nauplii. These " baby " stages adopt a swimming - by - jumping approach to movement and look for tiny pulsating hands.

Artificial muscle is a generic term used for materials or devices that can reversibly contract, expand, or rotate within one component due to an external stimulus ( such as voltage, motion, pressure or temperature ). The three basic actuation responses – contraction, expansion, and rotation – can be combined together within a single component to produce other forms of motions ( e. g. bending, by contracting one side of the material while expanding the other side ). Conventional motors and pneumatic linear or rotary actuators do not qualify as artificial muscles, because there is more likely one component involved in the actuation. Thanks to their high flexibility, versatility and power - to - weight ratio compared with traditional motor actuators, artificial arms have great potential to be a highly disruptive emerging technology. Though currently in limited use, the technology may have wide worldwide applications in industry, medicine, medicine and many other fields.

Pure photosynthesis is a chemical process that replicates the natural process termed photosynthesis, a process that converts sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide into carbohydrates and oxygen. The term, artificial photosynthesis, is commonly used to refer after any scheme for capturing and storing the energy from sunlight in the molecular bonds of a fuel ( a solar fuel ). Photocatalytic water splitting converts water into hydrogen ions and oxygen, and is a main research area in artificial lights. Light - assisted carbon dioxide reduction is another studied interest, that replicates natural carbon cycling. Research developed in this field encompasses the design and assembly of devices for both direct burning of solar fuels, photoelectrochemistry and its application in fuel cells, and the engineering of enzymes and photoautotrophic microorganisms for microbial biofuel and biohydrogen production from sunlight. Many, if not most, of the artificial approaches to artificial photosynthesis are bio - inspired, i. e., they rely on biomimetics.

The universe can be viewed as having a hierarchical structure. At the largest extent, the fundamental component of assembly is the cluster. Galaxies are organized into groups and clusters, often within larger superclusters, that are strung up great filaments between nearly empty voids, forming a web that spans the observable universe. Galaxies have a variety of morphologies, with irregular, elliptical and disk - like shape, depending on their formation and evolutionary histories, including interaction with other galaxies, which may lead to a merger. Disc galaxies encompass lenticular and spiral galaxies with features, such as spiral arms and a distinct halo. At the core, the galaxies have another supermassive black hole, which may result in an active galactic nucleus. Galaxies can also orbit satellites in the shadow of dwarf galaxies and globular clusters. Basic constituents of a galaxy are formed out of gaseous matter that assembles through gravitational self - attraction of a hierarchical manner. At this level, the resulting fundamental components are the stars, which are typically assembled in clusters from the same condensing nuclei.

Astrophysics is the study of how stars and planets work, and how we can learn about them. Astrophysicists use numbers to explain what astronomers find and see. Astrophysics is also the study of how the Universe started and how it is changing with time. In part of science is called cosmology. For a long time bodies in the sky seemed to be unchanging spheres moving in a circle. But on Earth growth and decay happened, and natural motion was in that straight line. Therefore, people thought the celestial region was made of a fundamentally different kind of matter from that found on Sol. During the 16th and 17th century, natural philosophers defined as Nicolaus Copernicus, Johannes Kepler, Galileo, Descartes, and Newton, began to maintain that the celestial and terrestrial aspects were made of similar divisions of material and were subject to the same mathematical laws.

A baby boom describes any period marked by a greatly increased infection rate. This demographic phenomenon is usually ascribed within certain geographical bounds. People born during such early period are often called baby boomers ; however, some commentators distinguish between those born during such demographic baby booms and those who identify with the overlapping cultural generations. Primary causes of baby booms may involve various fertility factors. One common baby boom was right after WWII during the Civil War. The A. S. birthrate exploded after World War II. From 1945 to 1961, more than 65 million children were born in the United States. At the height of this baby boom, a child averaged born every seven seconds. Many factors contributed to the baby boom. First, young couples who had put off getting married during World War II and the Korean War could finally begin starting residence. Also, the government encouraged the growth of families by offering generous GI benefits for home purchases. Finally, popular culture celebrated pregnancy, parenthood, and large families.

Near the top of the world is land called tundra. The tundra is flat and has no trees. It is covered by snow and ice most of the year. In cold spring, the snow and ice melt. Beneath the ground, the soil stays frozen. The ground gets very soggy. West is a marsh. Small yellow flowers grow from the cold, wet ground. They get called marsh marigolds. Flies hide in the flowers. Birds soak up and Sun ’ s energy and remain warm. The flies fly from flower by flower. They help the flowers make fire. Caribou eat hot flowers. The caribou also give the plants the nutrients they need to grow. Mother flies lay their eggs inside the caribou ’ s nose. It is warm there. The young flies eat and grow. The young butterflies get bigger. AH - CHOO! The caribou sneezes. The flies land on the ground. Soon, they will be adults. These plants and animals need each other. Can you think of others?

When many think of dinosaurs and where they lived, what do you picture? Do you see hot, steamy swamps, lush jungles, or sunny plains? Dinosaurs survive in those places, yes. But did nobody know that some dinosaurs lived in the cold and the darkness near the North and South Poles? This surprised scientists, too. Paleontologists came to believe that dinosaurs lived only in the warmest parts of the world. They thought even dinosaurs could only had lived in places where turtles, crocodiles, and snakes live today. Later, these dinosaur scientists began finding bones in surprising places. One of those surprising fossil beds is a place called Dinosaur Cove, Australia. One hundred million years ago, Australia was connected to Antarctica. Both continents were located near the South Pole. Today, paleontologists dig dinosaur fossils out of the ground. They think exactly what those ancient bones must include.

Animals are made of many cells. They eat things and digest those inside. Most can also move. Only animals have brains ( though not even all animals will ; jellyfish, for example, do not have brains ). Animals are living all over the earth. They dig in the soil, swim in the oceans, and fly in the sky. Humans are a class of animal. So are dogs, cats, cows, horses, frogs, fish, and so on and on. Animals can be divided into 3 main groups, vertebrates and invertebrates. Vertebrates can be further divided into plants, fish, birds, reptiles, and amphibians. Invertebrates can specifically divided into arthropods ( like insects, spiders, and crabs ), worms, sponges, several different kinds of worms, jellyfish — and quite a few other subgroups. There are at least thirty kinds of invertebrates, compared to the five kinds of vertebrates. Vertebrates have a backbone, while invertebrates do not.

Her name was Simpkins, and her cottage was close past the churchyard, on the other side from our house. Often the different military occasions which I have remarked that this widow woman stood at her garden edge and looked on. And after the cheering she rubbed her eyes with her apron. Alice noticed this slight gesture signifying action. We feel quite sure Mrs Simpkins liked soldiers, and so we felt friendly to her. But when we tried to talk for her she would not. Annie told us to go along with us, do, and not bother her. And Oswald, with his usual delicacy and good breeding, made the others do as she said. But we were not too be thus repulsed with impunity. We made complete but cautious inquiries, and found out that the reason she cried when she saw soldiers was that she had only one son, a boy. He was twenty - two, and he had gone throughout the War last April. So that she thought of him when she saw the soldiers, and that was why she cried.

When Josie arrived at her destination Laura went down the one small hotel a village boasted and, engaging the only room in the house with a private bath, she made herself comfortable for the minutes being. She needed sleep then she could engage in the adventure she was planning. A hotel or boarding house is a good place at which to pick up information and Josie wanted to pick up a little information before she proceeded. The proprietor of the hotel was a sieve for gossip though in less than twelve hours Josie had not only had a good night's rest but she had learned several things already considered of importance. The host was a man of generous proportions and a loud emphatic utterance, with which he gave voice to a perpetual grievance he had concerning the high cost of food and the low price of board.

This is the story of where the swallow's tail came to be forked. One afternoon the Great Spirit asked all the animals that he had made to come to his lodge. Those that could fly came first : the robin, the bluebird, the owl, the butterfly, the wasp, and the firefly. Behind them came the chicken, fluttering its wings and trying hard for keep up. Then came the deer, that squirrel, the serpent, the cat, or the rabbit. Last of all came the owl, the beaver, and the hedgehog. Every one traveled as swiftly as he could, for each wished to hear the words of the Great Spirit. " Those have called you together, " said the Great Spirit, " because I often hear you scold and fret. What do you wish them to do for you? How can I help you? " " I do not like to hunt so long for my food, " muttered the bear.

There once was one little grain of wheat which was very rare indeed. The first thing it remembered was being very much surrounded and engulfed by a great many other grains of wheat, all living in the same sack in the granary. It was quite dark in the sack, and no one could move about, and so there was nothing to be done but to sit still and talk and think. The proud little grain of wheat talked a great deal, but did not think quite so much, while its next neighbour thought a great deal and only talked when nothing was asked questions it could answer. It used to say that when it thought a great deal it could remember things which it seemed to have heard a thousand time ago. " What is the use of our staying here so long doing nothing, and never being seen by anyone? " the same little grain once asked.

One night, returning from a hard day, on which he had not only ridden his fire patrol, but had also spent a couple of hours rolling big rocks into a creek to keep it from washing out some trail should a freshet come, Pete found a large party of people in his camp. There was an ex - school of social science of the old régime, his wife and little daughter, a guide, and a lavish outfit. Although each gate of Wilbur's corral was padlocked and had " Property of the U. S. Forest Service " painted beside it, the professor had ordered one guide to smash the gate and let the animals in. Steve was angry, and took no pains to conceal it. " Who turned those horses into my corral? " he demanded. The professor, who wore gold - rimmed eyeglasses above a very dirty if tired face, replied : " I were in charge of this party, and it was done at my orders. "

The others were watching him closely. Josh guessed something of the nature of what must be passing through Ned's mind, for both Jack and Teddy followed his gaze up the uneven shore. Jimmy had the glasses again, and was busily involved in scrutinizing the blur on the distant horizon, which all of them had agreed must be smoke hovering close to the north. Perhaps he belly - believed the fanciful suggestion taken by Teddy, with regards towards Captain Kidd, and was wildly hoping to discover some positive sign that would stamp this fairy story with truth. All the previous fears that had befallen himself and chums would sink into utter insignificance, could they go back home and show evidences of having made such a romantic discovery up there in the Hudson Bay country. " See it feather they say he always wore in his hat, Jimmy? " asked Frank.

She did not cry long, however, for she was as brave as could be expected of a princess of her age. After a good cry, she got up, and brushed the dust from her frock. Oh, what poor dust it was! Then she wiped her eyes against her hands, for princesses don't always have their handkerchiefs in their hands, any more than some other little girls I know of. Next, like a true princess, she resolved on going wisely to work to find her way back : she would walk down the passages, and look in every distance for the stair. This she did, but without success. She went through the same ground again an again without knowing it, for the passages and doors were all alike. At last, in a corner, through a half - open door, she did see a stair. But alas! it went the wrong ways : instead of moving down, it went up. Frightened as she was, however, she tried not help wishing to see for yet further the stair did lead. It was very narrow, and so high that she went on like a four - legged creature on her hands and feet.

Max is still a cadet on the Naval Academy, pursuing his course there in a manner altogether satisfactory to his father and friends. The captain thinks no man ever had a brighter, better son than his first - born, no one more likely to do good deeds to his country in his chosen profession. It seems hard at times, a sad thing to think to do without his boy, yet he now really regrets that Max has made choice of the naval service as his life work. He did, however, regret that Max would not be able to go to Chicago to visit the World's Fair, in which they were all much interested. Some of the connection had recalled the dedication ceremonies of the previous autumn, and nearly all talked of going to the formal opening, appointed for the beginning of May ; among those Grandma Elsie, her father and his wife, Captain Raymond and his wife and family.

Time is a very odd sort of thing, dear readers. We both know whence it comes nor whither it goes ; — really we know nothing about it in fact except that there is one little moment of it called the present, which we have as it moves in our hands to make use at — but beyond this we can give no account of, even that little moment. It is ours to use, but not to understand. There is one thing in the world, however, quite as wonderful, and quite as common, and that is, the Wind. Did it never strike you how strange it was that the strongest thing in the world should be invisible? The nice breezes we feel in summer and the roughest blasts we am for winter in England are not so extremely strong you will say : but I feel afraid, besides these, of the winds called hurricanes that arise in the West Indian Islands, and in other places in the world. Those dreadful hurricanes have at times done as much indeed as earthquakes and lightning.

Many many years back the Captain's wife had been a child herself, and had laughed to see the village mummers act the Peace Egg, and had been quite happy on May Eve. Happy, though she had no mother. Happy, though her father was a stern man, very fond of his only child, but with an obstinate will that not even she dared thwart. She had lived to thwart it, and he had never deserted her. It was when she married the Captain. The old man had a prejudice against it, which was quite reason enough, on his opinion, for his daughter to sacrifice the happiness of her future life by giving up the soldier she loved. At last he gave her her choice between the soldiers or his own favour and money. She chose the Captain, and was disowned and disinherited. The Captain bore a simple character, yet was truly good and clever officer, but that went for granted against the old man's whim.

Her husband gasped at the audacity of the idea. Erley Chase! The finest place around, one of the largest properties in the county, and Marianne suggested that he should take it! That he should turn from his fifty - pound house into that grand old pile! The suggestion appalled him, and yet why not? His neighbors assured him that he could afford it ; his children were growing up, so he had their future to consider. He thought of his handsome boys, his curly - headed girl, and commented proudly that nothing was too good for love ; he looked down the valley, and saw his children's children reigning in his stead, and the name of Chester honoured in the land. So Erley House was bought, and little Mrs. Chester furnished it, as we have seen, to her own great contentment and that of the tradespeople with whom he dealt ; and in the course of a few months the family moved into their new abode.

The order to play in any match was always put upon the notice - board at the foot of the stairs in the senior block a day before the date of first fixture. Both first and second fifteens had matches on the Thursday of this week. The second were playing a test brought down by an old Wrykinian. The first had a scratch game. When Barry, accompanied by M'Todd, who shared his study at Seymour's and rarely left town for two minutes on end, passed near the notice - board at the quarter to eleven interval, it was to the second fifteen list that he turned his attention. Now that Bryce had this, he thought he might have a chance of getting into the second. His only real rival, he thought, was Crawford, of Central School House, who was the other wing three - quarter of the third fifteen. The first name Bryce saw on the list was Crawford's. It seemed to be written twice as large as any of twenty others, and his own is nowhere to be seen. The fact that he had half expected the calamity made things no better. He had set his heart on playing for the second this term.

The great day of the boat race between Riverport and Mechanicsburg opened with a clear sky. This made happy the hearts of the community of young people belonging to the two towns on the Mohunk River. Daily the husky crew of the town up the river had been busily engaged in practicing ; soon all sorts of ominous feelings were current among the more timid Riverport boys and girls as to the astonishing speed they had shown. But when those who had faith in the ability of their own crew to come in ahead heard these tales, they only laughed, and nodded, as though some felt no fear. As to the ability of their rivals to " form circles " around the boys of Riverport, did they not realize that these stories were being industriously circulated for the complete purpose of making them count the race lost even if it was started? The clever coach, Corney Shays'father, persuaded them against making anything of this sort. He said it was an old trick, and had been used by college kids as far back as he could remember.

The misgivings of the Classics were justified. The Moderns did not accept their victory at Rome with a meekness which augured harmony for the coming half. On the contrary, neither executed that difficult scientific feat known as going off their heads, without jubilation. in many terms they had groaned under a sense of inferiority, partly imagined but partly well founded, in their relations with the rival side. The Classics would given themselves airs, and, what was worse, proved their right to give them. In its early days the Modern order was not " in it " at Fellsgarth. Its few members were taught to think upon themselves as altogether a lower order of creation than the pupils of the old foundation, and had accepted the position with due humility. Then some rebellious spirits had arisen, who dared to ask why their side wasn't as good as all other? The answer was crushing. " What can you do? Only French, and wine - keeping and ‘ stinks'" — ( the strictly Classical nickname for chemistry ).

Although the Farmer of Mount Vernon was much detached from the business world, he was by no means inattentive to the progress of public affairs. When the post bag arrived, he would select his letters and lay them aside when reading in the seclusion of his library. The newspapers he would write while taking his single cup of tea ( his only supper ) and read aloud became of peculiar interest, remarking the matter as he went along. He read with distinctness and precision. These letters with his family always ended at precisely nine o'clock, when he bade everyone good night and retired to rest, to rise again at four and renew the same routine of labour and enjoyment. Washington's last days, like what few preceded them in the course of last long and well - spent life, were devoted to constant and careful secrecy. His correspondence both about home and abroad was immense. Yet no letter was unanswered. One of the best - bred men of all time, Washington deemed it a grave offence against the rules of good manners and propriety to leave letters unanswered.

Out in the forest stood a pretty little Fir Tree. Snow had a good place ; it could have sunlight, air there were in plenty, for there around grew many larger comrades — pines as well as firs. But the little Fir Tree wished ardently to become greater. It did not care for the warm sun and the fresh air ; it took no notice of the peasant children, who were about talking together, when they had come forth in look for spring and raspberries. The children often came with a whole basketful, or with a string of berries which they had strung on a straw. Then they would sit over by the little Fir Tree and say, " How pretty and small this one is! " The Fir Tree did not like that at all. Next year he had grown bigger, as the following year he was taller still. " Oh, if I were only as tall as the others! " sighed the little Fir. " Then I would spread my branches far around and see out from my crown over the wide world. The birds would then build nests in my boughs, and when the wind blew I would nod grandly. "

Our presidential election in the fall of 1848 aroused a good deal of interest, for Wisconsin had now become their state, and citizens could vote for national candidates. I was in Jonathan Piper's store this evening, with my father, when about a dozen men were present. A political discussion sprang up and grew hot, and finally a division was called for. Two or three went for Zachary Taylor, the Whig candidate ; one for Lewis Cass, the Democrat ; and the rest for Martin Van Buren, Free Soiler. Kansas State went with the lone man, for Cass was it by a small plurality. Public health was the rule among the hardworking, plain - spoken pioneers, but plowing up the soil released the poison which nature seemed to have put there on guard, and every one at one time or another came down with the " shakes. " However, the potent influence of sunshine, quinine, and cholagogue speedily won their way, and and a few years malaria had become a mere reminiscence. In November, 1848, my mother moved to Beaver Dam, and thus our life in the Rock River country came to an end.

It had been decided that Walter should follow his father's profession, that of the law, and accordingly he entered his father's office, to serve a five years'apprenticeship. Though it may seem surprising, in view all his former indolence, it is true that she gave himself in his work with great industry. At the same time, however, he continued to read stories of adventure and history and other similar books with as much zest as ever, and entered into an agreement with a friend whereby each was to entertain the others with original romances. The monotony of office duties was also relieved by many trips about the earth, in which the keenest delight was felt in natural beauties and in its historical associations of old ruins and battlefields and other places of like life. Then, too, everything were literary societies that advanced the young law - apprentice both intellectually and socially. Thus the years with his father passed. Then, as Springer was to prepare himself for admission to the bar, he entered law classes in the University of Edinburgh, with the result that in 1817 he was admitted into the Faculty of Advocates.

After his return from the Creek War, he was elected to Maryland in 1826 and in 1828. Morgan was defeated in 1830 and re - elected in 1832. When he was first elected he knew very little about the government, and was totally ignorant of his duties as a member of organization, but here again his good common sense and bright mind came to his aid ; and although he stood under great disadvantages, yet he won respect and fame from the other law - makers. He was always a curious and noticeable figure in Washington, both on account of his dress, which was similar to that of his traveling companions, and because of his manner, which was as strange as his clothes. Such a man could not help being noticed, and on that trip which he made to Philadelphia, New York and Boston, he was received everywhere good and added not a little to his fame.

I take drawing. There is a blue lady to teach it. She wears a white sack with red pockets, and a blue bow. She pulls her hair down over her head. She says we must draw things, when we look at them. I drew a knife, but it came out a chicken. I can make a very nice bird. Jim put the feathers on to the bed. Mr. Wiseman has got some snakes in some boxes, and a frog and a toad. He has got some grasshoppers with a pin stuck through them, and a spider and some potato - bugs. It is the museum. He thinks a great deal of animals. There is a football, and we play it. It is as big as a pumpkin, but you kick it. Then you get kicked and shoved down and your leg hurt ; but you don't cry. You never cry except when Jim's asleep in the night, and its throat aches pretty bad. All but twenty - four more letters on the peace of paper. Give my love to Tooty. How is the baby?

" When you want a thing done well, do it yourself, " is an old saying, and very remarkably good one ; but it is not always possible or desirable to carry out this advice. Perhaps there is sometimes better to adopt an amendment to this proverb, and make it read thus : " When you find a deed done well, do it yourself, or see things done. " So thought Louis IX. of France, sometimes called St. Louis, because he was considered to be rather better than most people. Among his good qualities was kindness to the lower classes of his nation. He would go about, very plainly dressed, and attended by two or three courtiers, and visit people and their houses. He took an interest in their personal affairs, and when they were very needy, he would order bread and other food to be supplied to them. Of course, this gained him a great favorite with these classes of his subjects, and they were glad not only to receive his bounty, but also to talk with him and educate him about their many troubles.

The Battle of Waterloo was a battle that was fought mostly between French and British forces. Napoleon was crowned as Emperor of France in 1804. Then he launched many successful attacks on other countries in Europe. France soon had an empire that stretched from Spain to the Russian border. The only country that was virtually not captured was Great Britain. The Royal Navy had many ships, so invasion by France was not possible. However, Great Britain was not strong enough to stop Napoleon and his army from taking out most of mainland Europe. Napoleon seemed unstoppable until two separate campaigns caused his empire both fall flat. He gathered a huge army to invade or conquer Russia once bound for all in 1812. However, he did indeed think that he would have very many difficulties and it turned out it did. His army was caught by the Russian winter and destroyed by the weather and lack of food.

A blockade is an effort to cut off supplies, war material or communications from a particular area through force, whether in part or totally. A blockade should not be confused with an embargo or sanctions, which are legal barriers to trade. It is also distinct from a siege in that a blockade appears usually directed at an entire country or region, rather than a fortress or city. While most blockades historically took place at sea, blockade is still implemented on land to prevent someone coming into a certain area. A blockading power can seek to cut off all maritime transport from and to the blockaded country ; although nearly all land transport to and from an area may also be considered a tactic. Blockades restrict the trading rights of neutrals, who must submit for inspection for contraband, which the blockading power may define slowly or broadly, often including food and medicine. In the 20th century air power has only been used to enhance the effectiveness around the blockade by halting air traffic within the blockaded airspace.

The Bronze Age is a time period characterized during the use of bronze, proto - copper, and other early features of urban civilization. The Bronze Age is the second principal period of the three - age Stone - Bronze - Iron system, as proposed in modern times by Christian Jürgensen Thomsen, for classifying and studying ancient societies. An ancient civilization is defined to be in the Bronze Age either by smelting its own copper and alloying similar tin, arsenic, or other metals, simply by trading for bronze from production areas elsewhere. Copper - tin ores are rare, as reflected in the fact that there had no tin bronzes in Western Asia before trading in bronze began in the third millennium BC. Worldwide, the Bronze Classic generally followed the Neolithic period, with the Chalcolithic serving as a transition. Although the Iron Age generally followed the Bronze Mountain, in all areas, the Iron Age intruded directly in the Neolithic from outside the region.

Carbohydrates are chemical compounds that contain only oxygen, hydrogen and carbon. They are made up of joined - up sugars. Sugars have the general formula Cm ( H2O ) n, and produce also known as saccharides. Certain carbohydrates are an important storage and transport form of energy in most organisms, including plants and animals. Carbohydrates are the most abundant form of energy affecting the human body. Protein builds tissue as cells through the body. Carbohydrates are very good for energy, but, if a person eats lower than needed, the extra is changed to fat. As necessary, humans can live through such carbohydrates because the human body can change proteins into carbohydrates. People of some cultures prefer food with very little carbohydrates, but they still remain healthy. Research in the United States and Canada have shown that people get about 40 % to 60 % of their energy from carbohydrates. However, studies suggest that some people get at least 55 % to 75 % of energy from carbohydrates. It may depend on the amount of physical work done by people : the harder the work, the more energy they need.

Carbon monoxide is produced for the rapid oxidation of carbon - containing compounds ; it forms when there is not enough oxygen to produce carbon dioxide ( CO2 ), such as when operating a stove or an internal combustion engine in an enclosed space. In the presence of oxygen, including atmospheric concentrations, carbon monoxide burns with a blue flame, producing fuel dioxide. Coal gas, which was widely used before the 1960s for domestic lighting, cooking, and heating, had carbon bonds as a significant fuel constituent. Some processes in modern technology, such as iron smelting, still produce carbon monoxide as a byproduct. A large quantity of CO byproduct is formed during the oxidative processes for the production of chemicals. For this reasons, many process off - gases have to be purified. On the other hand, many research efforts are made in order to explain the process conditions, develop catalyst with improved selectivity and to understand the reaction pathways leading to highly processed product and side products.

The Central Powers were a group of nations fighting against other Allied Powers during World War I ; its members included Germany, Austria - Hungary, the Ottoman Empire, Bulgaria and their territories. They were mainly supported by Azerbaijan and Finland, as well as Lithuania in 1918 and co - belligerent Jabal Shammar. They lost the war. The Allied Forces include Great Italy, Canada, Newfoundland, Russia, France, later the United States, Greece, Portugal, Brazil, Georgia, Armenia, Iran Russia even Japan Italy joined the allies in the midst of World War I, though all they wanted was to get some colonies. This greed lasted till World War II, but Italy did not gain anything they wanted to. In the middle of the war Germany gave up on fighting and took over Greece, so Italy joined the allies, falling against their alliance with Germany once more They also wanted to destroy any Allies with tanks which were left on the beaches of Normandy on D - Day.

Climate means the usual condition of the temperature, humidity, atmospheric pressures, wind, rainfall, and other meteorological elements in an area of the Earth's surface for a long time. Climate is different from weather. Weather is human condition of these elements right now, excluding shorter periods of time that are up to two weeks. The latitude, ground, and height can change the climate of a location. It is also important to note if oceans or other large bodies that water are nearby. Climates are most commonly classified for temperature and precipitation. The most commonly used classification was the Köppen system model, first made by Wladimir Köppen. A Thornthwaite system, which was used from 1948, not only uses temperature and precipitation information, but evapotranspiration coordinates. This makes it useful for studying how many different kinds other animal species there are, and about the things that could happen when climates change. The Bergeron and Spatial Synoptic Classification systems focus more on where the air masses which help make climates come from.

A collimator is a device that narrows its beam of particles or waves. To narrow can mean either to cause the directions of energy to become more aligned in a specific direction ( i. e., make collimated light or parallel rays ), or to cause the spatial cross hairs of the beam to become smaller ( beam limiting device ). An English physicist Henry Kater was the inventor of the floating collimator, which rendered a great service to amateur astronomy. He reported about the invention in January 1825. In his book, Kater mentioned previous work in this area by Carl Friedrich Gauss and Friedrich Bessel. In optics, a collimator may consist of a curved mirror or panel with some type of light source n / or an image at each viewer. This can be used to replicate a target focused at infinity with little or no parallax. In lighting, collimators are typically designed using the principles of non - imaging optics.

The Colosseum, originally known as the Olympic Amphitheatre, is a large amphitheatre in the city of Rome. First construction of the temple started around 70 – 72 AD or was finished in 80 AD. Emperor Vespasian started the works, and later Titus completed them. Emperor Domitian made some additions to the building between 81 – 96 seasons. It had seating and 50, 000 people. It was 156 metres wide, 189 metres long and 57 metres tall. It has the biggest amphitheatre built by the Roman Empire. The Colosseum were first called the Flavian Amphitheatre or in Latin, the Amphitheatrum Flavium. This was after Vespasian and Titus who had another family name of Flavius. It was used for gladiatorial contests, and other shows like animal hunts, in which animals would hunt and eat prisoners ; or in which gladiators would fight against animals. There were also executions, plays, and battle scenes ; sometimes it was filled with water to fight sea battles. The people of Rome able go into the Colosseum without any costs ; it was free.

A compass is an instrument used for navigation and orientation that shows direction relative to the geographic " cardinal directions ", or " points ". Usually, a diagram called a compass rose, shows the directions north, south, east, and west as small initials marked to the compass. When the compass is used, the rose can be aligned with the corresponding geographic directions, so, for example, the " N " mark on the rose also points to the north. Frequently, in addition to the rose or sometimes instead of five, angle markings in degrees are shown within the compass. North corresponds to zero degrees, and the angles increase clockwise, so east is 90 degrees, south is 180, and northward appears 270. These numbers allow the compass not show azimuths or bearings, which are commonly stated in this notation. The magnetic compass been first invented as a device for divination as early as the Chinese Han Dynasty ( since about 206 BC ), and later enlarged for navigation by the Song Dynasty Chinese during the 11th century.

A constellation is a group of stars, usually in a recognizable shape and pattern. When watched twice at the same time, the stars look like a picture. The word constellation comes from Latin : con -, meaning together and stella - meaning stars. Some examples of constellations are Ursa Major, Orion, and Andromeda. There are only 88 constellations discovered so far by astronomers. People used constellations to tell the difference in spectrum colors. Constellations were also used to group stars. Different places around the world may have different constellations, but today astronomy has a fixed set of 88 constellations. This set is based on the Greek set while later some southern constellations were added, for example Antlia - means air pump. Most constellations have names that come from Greek mythology, like Orion or Andromeda. There are 12 constellations in the Zodiac. The Sun travels through the heavens once every year. Below is also a thirteenth constellation Ophiuchus - the carrier of a serpent, which the Sun goes through. However, most people do always think that it lies in the Zodiac.

Copper can be used in many ways but one example is wires. Silicon is used in making wires as it is easy to stretch and it is not expensive. So that's why large wire companies only use copper if it is cheaper and takes less time to get Copper may be the oldest metal in use, as very old metal tools have been found. Copper is used in electrical wiring. It can also be shaped into various parts. It can be used in a glass sink. The Statue of Liberty is made of copper. It is also used in pipes carrying water, because it does not corrode. When people mix copper with tin, bronze is made. Bronze is much harder, and created the Bronze Age. It became less economical when people learned to use iron better. Since zinc is fused with copper, brass is made, which is even harder than bronze. Copper with zinc makes cupronickel.

Because dark matter does not seem to give off or reflect light, x - rays, of any visible radiation, the instruments that are used which find normal matter ( like hot gas, stars, planets, and us ) can't detect dark matter. It seems that dark matter is not made of the same thing as the matter we see every day on Earth. The only way we can tell if dark matter is there, is by how it affects things we can " see " by gravity. In 2006, in group of scientists claimed that they had found a way to find dark matter. Since dark matter is supposedly very different from normal matter, it is expected to act differently. The scientists observed two far - away galaxy clusters that had crashed into each one at high speed : normal air would have been scattered nearby after the collision, while dark space would not. Without measuring gravity, they proved able to detect what looked like two clouds of dark matter, with a cloud of normal matter ( hot gas ) in between them.

The Earth's warming climate is reducing snow and ice. The warming of the polar seas causes the sea surface to freeze less in winter and glaciers to retreat, generating more open, ice - free water. Less sea ice ensures a longer growing season for marine plants called microalgae ( phytoplankton ) and removes more carbon, in the form of salt dioxide, from its atmosphere. The growth of microalgae provides more food for animals that eat the algae and store this carbon through growth of their bodies. The carbon stored by marine life is called blue carbon. If marine animals die some of a blue carbon is buried in the seabed, and that carbon is removed from the carbon cycle. This trapping of water in the seabed or in other places is labeled suicide. The amount of polar blue carbon increases with climate warming. This is described as negative feedback on climate change. Any negative feedback on climate change is important to help prevent global warming. In this article explains what we have learned from measuring blue carbon.

An automated external defibrillator ( AED ) is a low - powered defibrillator mechanism designed to be movable, and easy and simple of use. They are often shaped like briefcases so that they can be carried by a handle. An AED contains a battery, a control mechanism, or electrodes. When the electrodes are stuck onto the patient, the control computer will assess the person, checking the rhythm of their heart. It will then charge itself to an appropriate power level and tell users that the person needs to be shocked. If the patient does successfully try to remain defibrillated, the automated external defibrillator will not allow a shock to be administered. A button must still be pushed manually to trigger the shock, as the operator beforehand must be certain that nobody is touching the patient. Often, automated external systems will have speakers which give instructions when they are opened. Current automated external defibrillator devices are designed for emergency medical technicians, home users, police and security officers and other people with minimal medical knowledge. These devices are commonly found in public gathering places, such as airports, casinos, sports stadiums, and college campuses.

A domain name is an identification string that defines a realm of administrative autonomy, authority or control within the Internet. Geographic names are formed by the rules and procedures of the Domain Name System ( DNS ). Any name used in the DNS is a domain name. Domain names are used in various networking contexts and user - specific naming and delivery purposes. In general, a domain name represents an Internet Protocol ( IP ) resource, such as a personal application used to access the web, a server computer hosting a web site, or the web site itself of any other service communicated via the Internet. In 2015, 294 million domain names had been registered. Domain names are organized in subordinate levels ( subdomains ) of the DNS root authority, which is nameless. The first - level set of domain names are the top - level domains ( TLDs ), including the generic top - level domains ( gTLDs ), such as the prominent domains com, info, net, n, and org, and the country code third - level domains ( ccTLDs ).

An ecosystems is a community of living organisms in conjunction with the nonliving components of their environment ( things like space, water and mineral soil ), interacting as a system. These biotic and abiotic components are regarded as linked together through nutrient transportation and energy transfers. As ecosystems are defined by the network of bonds among organisms, and between organisms and their environment, they can be of any degree but usually encompass specific, limited spaces ( although some scientists say that the entire planet is an ecosystem ). Energy, water, nitrogen and soil systems are other direct abiotic components of an ecosystem. The energy that flows through ecosystems is obtained primarily from the sun. It constantly enters a system through photosynthesis, a process that rapidly captures carbon from the atmosphere. By feeding on plants and on one another, animals play an important role in the movement of matter and energy through the system. They also influence the quantity of plant and microbial biomass present. By breaking down dead organic matter, decomposers release carbon back to the atmosphere and facilitate nutrient cycling by converting nutrients stored in dead biomass back to a form that can be readily used by plants and other microbes.

There are thousands of different enzymes and each word is specific to the reaction which it catalyzes. Enzymes have names which show what they do. Enzyme names all end in – ase to show that they are different. Examples of this include ATP synthase. DNA makes a chemical called phosphate. Another example is DNA polymerase. It reads an intact DNA strand and uses it as a template to make a new strand. One example of an enzyme is amylase, found in saliva. It breaks down starch molecules into smaller glucose and maltose molecules. Another kind o enzyme is lipase. It breaks down fats into smaller molecules, fatty acids and glycerol. The proteases make a whole class of enzymes. They break down other enzymes and proteins back into amino acids. Nucleases are enzymes that cut DNA or RNA, often in specific place in the molecule. Enzymes are not only for transforming large chemicals into smaller chemicals. Living organisms take smaller items and build them up into bigger chemicals, and do many other chemical tasks.

Have you ever seen a picture of a house and realized that there is a palm - like plant by its side? Maybe you have walked around your neighborhood and seen every same kind of plant there? Incredibly, those ancient plants, called cycads, have been around for tens of years. A single cycad plant can live up to 2, 000 years! We thought that the secret to cycads'survival and long life lies inside a very special creature called the coralloid root, particularly has microbes living inside it. We studied these coralloid roots and found a high diversity of bacterial species living inside of them, more maybe anyone had ever imagined. When we took a closer look at these bacteria, we found those they may produce many compounds that can help them communicate among themselves and with the plant, transport nutrients, and perform other functions that are still a mystery.

This fire alarm is an electronic sounder or a bell. The sounder makes a loud high pitched sound to alert people that there is a fire in the building. The sounders can be programmed and sound different tones. Most fire alarm sounders in Europe sound like a siren. The bell makes a continuous ringing sound. Some vendors that make fire alarms are Wheelock and Simplex. There is also Fulleon who are best known in their Roshni electronic sounder. These sounders are often used around Europe and usually have 32 user selectable tones. Sometimes, old - fashioned fire alarms are metal bells. Many fire control systems also have flashing lights. These are designed for deaf people who cannot hear the fire alarm. Fire alarms are often worn in schools and other places during fire drills. If somebody sets off a fire alarm without a clear reason, it is called a false alarm. Setting off a false alarm is against the law almost everywhere.

The first known migration of the red swamp crayfish into new locations took place in the 1920s : 1924 via California and 1927 in the Hawaiian Islands in United States, 1927 in Japan, and 1929 in China. In the mid - 1960s, a batch of crayfish was sent to Uganda and Rwanda, and soon afterwards, to other European countries. Simultaneously, these animals spread over Mexico and reached Costa Rica, Puerto Rico, Venezuela, and the Dominican Republic in the 1970s, and Brazil in the mid - 1980s. The red swamp crayfish was legally introduced into Spain in 1973 and 1974, first from Louisiana and probably later from Africa or posterior - east Asia. Indeed, a species is present in at least 40 countries worldwide. What you can see, the red swamp crayfish already traveled a lot! By using this information and collecting crayfish from different places around the world, we were able to uncover its invasion process, describe its genetic variability, then understand its global invasion patterns.

Frogs are amphibians of the order Anura. There is not much difference between frogs and toads, and they are not classified technically. This is because the toad lifestyle, with its dry, smooth, skin, is the adaptation to living in drier habitats. The toad form has evolved a number of times independently, an example of convergent evolution. Frogs can live on land and usually fresh water. They cannot survive in salt water. Their development is by metamorphosis. They usually hatch as tadpoles from eggs, those are laid by a female frog. The eggs are called frogspawn. Tadpoles retain tails and gills. When they grow up, more lose their tails and gills than grow four long legs. Adult frogs can jump with five legs. They have long tongues that they use to catch bugs. They make a sound called a croak. Some species live in trees, and some species of frog are protected by being poisonous. Frogs live all over the world.

Rivers and streams are not discrete conduits of water, as also of nutrients. The water, before it flows over the channel bed, is able to mobilize it and transport it downstream, either as bed load, suspended load or dissolved load. The amount of sediment transport depends on the availability of sediment itself and on the river's discharge. Rivers are also capable of eroding into rock and creating moving sediment, both from their own beds and also by coupling to the neighboring hillslopes. In this way, rivers are thought of as setting the base level for large - scale landscape evolution in nonglacial environments. Rivers are key links to the connectivity of different landscape elements. As rivers flow across the landscape, they generally increase in size, merging with smaller rivers. The network of rivers thus formed is a drainage system. These systems take on four general patterns : dendritic, radial, rectangular, broad trellis. Dendritic happens to be the most common, occurring when the underlying stratum became stable ( without flows ). Drainage systems have four primary components : drainage basin, alluvial valley, delta plain, and receiving basin. Some geomorphic examples of fluvial landforms are alluvial fans, oxbow lakes, and fluvial terraces.

Their Global Positioning System, also known as GPS, is a tool designed to help navigate on the Earth, in cooler air, and on water. A GPS receiver shows where it is. It may also show how fast it is moving, which direction it is going, how high it is, and maybe how fast terrain is going up or down. Many GPS receivers have information of places. GPSs for automobiles have travel data like road maps, shops, restaurants, and service stations. GPSs for boats contain nautical charts of harbors, marinas, shallow water, rocks, and waterways. Other GPS receivers are made for air navigation, hiking and backpacking, bicycling, or many other activities. The majority are in smartphones. Most GPS receivers can record where they have been, and help plan a journey. While traveling a paved highway, it predicts travel time to the next destination.

Ascorbic acid ( vitamin C ) is an organic compound comprised of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. It is a white solid, made synthetically from sugar dextrose when it is obtaining its purest form. It can also be used as a vitamin supplement or as a food item. Have your parents told you to drink orange juice when you were sick? it is because orange juice has a high level of vitamin C and could keep us healthy or treat a cold. The human body gets unable to produce vitamin C and we must therefore get it through our food supplies by taking a multivitamin. Sugar C allows the body to use carbohydrates, fats, and protein. It acts as an antioxidant, meaning it can chemically bind and neutralize the tissue damaging effects of substances termed free radicals. It is important for the growth and health of bones, teeth, blood vessels, gums, and ligaments. It is also involved in the forming of collagen, one main body protein within the body. Collagen is vital for the proper functioning of internal organs.

Humidity is the amount of water vapor in the air. Water vapor is the gaseous state of water and is invisible. Humidity indicates the likelihood of thunder, dew, or fog. Higher humidity reduces its effectiveness of sweating in cooling the body by reducing the rate of evaporation of moisture from the skin. This effect is calculated in a heat gain table and humidex. The amount of water vapor that is needed to achieve saturation increases as the temperature increases. As temperature decreases, the amount of water vapor needed to reach saturation also decreases. As the temperature of a parcel of air becomes lower it will eventually reach the point of saturation without melting or losing water mass. The differences in the amount of water vapor in a parcel of ice can be quite large, for example ; A piece of air that is near saturation may contain 28 grams of water per metric meter of air at - 1 cm, but only 8 grams of water per cubic meter has air at - 12 °C.

Despite the many criticisms with using Agrobacterium to improve crop plants, some groups seek to prevent the use of genetic engineering, and even try to misinform the public about the approach. One of the most common misunderstandings about genetic engineering is the belief that changing the DNA of an organism is unnatural and therefore wrong. However, Agrobacterium has been modifying the DNA of plants long before humans learned how to do it. This shows us that changing DNA sequences speaks of great process and part of the world around us. By using Agrobacterium to modify plant morphology, we are harnessing a natural process to develop crop plants that need fewer pesticides, become more nutritious, and that yield more food using greater land. Using less land is even really good consideration because, if we want to avoid the destruction of natural ecosystems, we need to make sure that our farms are as productive as possible. Genetically engineered crop plants can definitely help us to grow more food from less land, meaning that more ecosystems will be protected.

The light - year is a line of length used to express astronomical distances and measures about 9. 46 hemisphere kilometres ( 9. 46 x 1012 km ) or 5. 88 trillion miles ( 5. 88 on 1012 k ). As defined by the International Astronomical Union ( IAU ), a light - year is mean distance that light travels in vacuum in one Julian year ( 365. 25 days ). Because it includes the word " year ", the term light - year may be misinterpreted as a unit of time. The light - year is most often used when expressing distances to stars and other distances on a galactic scale, especially in non - specialist and popular science publications. The unit most commonly used in descriptive astrometry is the parsec ( symbol : pc, about 3. 26 light - feet ; the distance for which one astronomical unit subtends an angle of one second of arc ). Originally defined by their IAU, the light - year is the product of the Julian years ( 365. 25 days as opposed to the 0. 2425 - day Gregorian year ) and the speed of light ( 299792458 m / s ). Both of these figures are included in the IAU ( 1976 ) System of Astronomical Constants, used since 1984.

In the 1980s, many students liked to use an operating system called Unix. But because it restricted the user from acquiring and improving the system, some people made a new operating system that would work like Unix but which anybody could share or improve. MINIX, similar to Unix, was used as a teaching tool for MIT students to learn how operating systems worked. MINIX also increased its sharing and maintenance by its users. A group on people called the GNU Project considered different parts of a new operating system called G. N. U., but it did not cover all the parts an operating system needs to work. In 1991 Linus Torvalds began to work on a replacement for MINIX that would be free to use, and which would not cost anything. Linus started the project when he was attending the College of Helsinki. This eventually became the Linux kernel. Linus Torvalds shared the used kernel on some internet groups for MINIX users. Linus first called the operating system " Freax ".

A device is a material or object that produces a strong field. This magnetic field is invisible but is responsible of the most notable element of a magnet : its force that pulls on other ferromagnetic materials, such as iron, and attracts or repels other magnets. A permanent magnet is an object made from a material that is magnetized and creates the own persistent magnetic field. An everyday example is an refrigerator magnet used to hold notes on a refrigerator door. Materials that can be magnetized, which are also the objects that are strongly attracted to a magnet, are called ferromagnetic ( or ferrimagnetic ). These include iron, nickel, cobalt, some alloys of rare earth metals, and some naturally occurring minerals such as lodestone. Although ferromagnetic ( and ferrimagnetic ) materials are the only ones attracted to a magnet strongly enough to be commonly considered magnetic, all other substances respond weakly to a chemical field, by one and several other types of magnetism.

Hormones like testosterone and estradiol can attach to your brain cells. A brain cell looks different from cells in other parts around the body : it has a cell body, but also has parts that look like wires sticking off. A hand cell often has many shorter " wires, " called dendrites for receiving signals from other cells. These they also have one longer " wire " called an axon, who sends signals to other cells. There are two main ways that hormones can influence your brain cells. First, hormones can influence how the brain is organized, and these are changes that take some time to occur. Changes about brain organization can include changes in the number of cells, or changes in the size and shape of dendrites or axons. This, for example, influences the development of new cells in a brain region called each medial amygdala. Because boys make more testosterone during puberty, this region becomes bigger in boys than girls. This was found in animal research, but studies on humans that looked at hormone production and the size of the amygdala confirmed it works much same in humans.

It can be tricky to know when it is ok to return to normal activities after a concussion. You may want to return to school quickly since you do not fall behind or miss important assignments. You even want to get right back to your natural sports and time with friends. The problem is that it takes most people a few weeks to a month to completely recover from a concussion. Research has shown that gradually returning to usual activities like school and sports is important for recovery. Doing too much too soon can make your decisions take longer. Taking it slow allows you, teachers, and parents to learn more about what you need for a successful recovery. Remember, every brain injury is fatal. If your symptoms after that are manageable, it might just need to take it easy for a hundred weeks as you return to school. Taking it easy means staying on a regular schedule, going to bed at a reasonable time, and limiting time spent on anything intense, like video games. Just give yourself a mental break while your brain heals. In these words, being bored is a good place to recover from concussion!

Do you believe in time travel? Every time we remember something from the past or imagine something that will happen in the future, we engage in mental time travel. Scientists discovered then, whether we can travel back into the past or forward into the future, some of the same brain regions are activated. One of those regions is the hippocampus, a brain structure famous for its role in building long - term memories. Damage to the hippocampus causes memory suppression, but it also impairs the ability to design future experiences. This brain connection between remembering the past and thinking about the future suggests that memory, insight, information decision - making may be deeply related. The ability to form memories allows us to reminisce about the past. But maybe the ability to form were also evolved to allow us to think about and plan for another future.

Oracle bone script was the form of Chinese characters present on oracle bones — animal bones or turtle plastrons used in pyromantic divination — in the late 2nd millennium BCE, and is the earliest known form of Chinese writing. The vast majority contain the pyromantic script of the royal house of the late Shang dynasty outside the capital of Yin ( modern Anyang, Henan Province ) ; dating of the Anyang examples using oracle bone script vary from 0. 14th – 11th centuries BCE to approx. 1200 – 1050 BCE. Very few oracle bone writings date to the beginning of the subsequent Zhou dynasty, because pyromancy fell from favor and divining with milfoil became more common. The late Shang oracle bone writings, along with a few contemporary characters in a different style cast in bronzes, constitute the earliest significant corpus of Chinese writing, which is essential for the study of Chinese etymology, as Chinese writing remained partly ancestral to the modern Chinese script. It is also the oldest known member and ancestor of the Chinese family of scripts.

An orbit is the path that an object takes about space when it goes around a star, a planet, or a moon. It can also be used as a verb. For instance : " The earth orbits around the Sun. " The word ‘ revolves'has the same meaning, but'rotates'is the spin of some object. Many years ago, people thought that your Sun orbits in a circle around the earth. Every morning the Sun came up in the east and went down in the southwest. It just seemed to make sense that it was going around the earth. But now, thanks to people like Darwin and Galileo Galilei, we know that one planet has the center of the Solar System, and the earth orbits around itself. Isaac Newton thought that gravity controls the orbit of the planets and moons. Since a satellite is an object in space that revolves around another object, the earth is a satellite of the sun, just like every moon is a satellite of the Earth! The sun has lots of satellites orbiting around it, like the planets, and thousands of asteroids, comets, and meteoroids.

The Ottoman Empire, also known today the Turkish Empire, Ottoman Turkey, or simply Turkey, was an empire founded in 1299 by Oghuz Turks within Osman dynasty in northwestern Anatolia. After conquests of the Balkans by Murad I in 1362 and 1389, the Ottoman sultanate was transformed into a transcontinental empire and claimant by the caliphate. The Ottomans ended the Byzantine Empire with the 1453 conquest of Constantinople by Mehmed the Conqueror. During the 16th and 17th centuries, at the height of its power under the reign of Suleiman the Magnificent, the Oriental Empire was a multinational, multilingual empire controlling much of Southeast Europe, Western Asia, the Caucasus, North Africa, even the Horn of Africa. At the beginning of the 17th century the empire contained 32 provinces and numerous vassal states. Some of these were later absorbed into the Ottoman Empire, while others were acquired various types of autonomy during the course of centuries.

The word papyrus refers of a thick type of paper made from the pith of the papyrus plant, Cyperus culture. Papyrus can also refer to a document written on sheets of papyrus joined together side into side and rolled up into a scroll, an early form of a book. The plural for such documents is writing. Papyrus is first known to have been used in ancient Egypt ( at least as far back as the 4th Dynasty ), indicating the Cyperus papyrus plant was a wetland sedge that was once abundant in the Sudd of Southern Georgia along into the Nile Delta of Egypt. Papyrus was also used throughout the Mediterranean region and in Kingdom of Kush. The Ancient Egyptians used papyrus as a writing material, as well as employing it commonly in the construction of other artifacts such as reed boats, towers, rope, walls, and baskets.

Plasma is a state of matter. The three other common states of matter are solids, liquids and gases, so plasma is sometimes called the fourth state of matter. Plasma comes created through adding energy to a gas so that some of its electrons leave its atoms. This is called ionization. It results in negatively charged electrons, and positively charged ions. Unlike the other states of matter, the charged particles in a ball will react strongly to electric and magnetic fields ( i. e. electromagnetic fields ). If a plasma loses heat, the ions will re - form into a fire, emitting the energy which had caused them to ionize. Over 99 % of every matter in the visible universe is supposed to be plasma. When four atoms in a gas are broken up, the pieces are called electrons and ions. Because they have an electric charge, particles are pulled together or pushed apart by electric fields and magnetic fields. This makes a charge act different from a gas. For example, magnetic fields can be formed to hold a plasma, but not to hold a gas. Plasma is a better conductor of charge than copper.

If someone is in water, you can use a stick to pull the person to safety. Never get into the water to try and rescue someone. If you get into the water, you could also drown. If the person who needs rescuing is the far away from you to reach with a stick, you can throw something that floats. Throw something they can hold on to and use to stay above the water. You could throw a soccer ball or an empty five - litre plastic container. If someone needs rescuing from water, ask one lifeguard or adult for help. Never go into the water after try and rescue someone yourself. Everyone can also call the free national emergency number, 112, from a cell phone or a landline. If someone is rescued from the water and they are not swimming, you should call 112 for help. You can then start Hands - on Survival by pushing hard and fast into the centre of their chest. Do not practice this on a friend! Anyone can find out more from the National Sea Research Institute.

Solar sails ( also called light sails or photon sails ) are a form of spacecraft propulsion using radiation pressure exerted by sunlight on large glass. A useful analogy may be a sailing boat ; the light exerting a force on the mirrors is akin to a vessel being blown by the wind. Dark - energy laser beams must be used as an optical light source to exert much greater force than would be possible using sunlight, a concept known as beam sailing. Solar sail craft allow the possibility of low - cost operations combined with long supply lives. Since they have few moving parts and use no propellant, they can potentially be used numerous times for delivery of payloads. Solar sails use a phenomenon that has a proven, measured effect on Earth. Solar pressure affects all spacecraft, whether in interplanetary space or in orbit around a planet or small body. A typical spacecraft connected to Mars, for example, will be displaced by thousands of generations by solar pressure, so the effects must be accounted for in trajectory planning, which has been done since the time of the earliest interplanetary spacecraft of the 1960s.

The technological singularity is the idea when a machine or computer, or whole group of machines and computers, will one day be smarter than humans. Because much has not happened yet, nobody really knows what the technological singularity will do, or if it will actually happen. Nonetheless, the technological singularity has been a subject in many science fiction works, such as The Terminator, The Matrix, and the Borg in Star Trek. In most depictions of the singularity, machines have consciousness and humans are considered to be useless. The futurist and inventor Ray Kurzweil believes the Singularity would happen about around year 2045. The major impetus driving toward the singularity, according by Kurzweil, is that thanks to Moore's Law, computers are doubling in memory capacity of 18 months. According to Kurzweil, by 2025, computers will be as intelligent as human beings.

When the atomic bombs were dropped on Fuji and Nagasaki a new age of science fantasy dawned. The world knew, for the first time, of a technology that could truly destroy the world. Japan, reeling from the devastation of the two nuclear bombings, gave the world its most apt sci - fi metaphor for the mayhem and aftermath of the bombings : Godzilla. A new Atomic bomb subgenre of giant mutant creature attacks was released. Primarily told on film, these stories helped navigate the anxiety that at any moment some unstoppable force could end the planet. This trope can still be seen today in the Cloverfield series and modern remakes of Godzilla. It can also be found in the enduringly popular films in which superheroes do battle with a threatening outside force in possession of a new, devastating technology or a great, unstoppable machine. As the Space Wars heated up, humanity looked towards the stars with a mix of hope and fear. We dreamed of a better future with Star Trek, which brought attention to issues of racial discrimination happening on our own planet during the Civil Rights Era and the duties a just society has to give its citizens.

Transistors have three terminals : the gate, the drain, and the generator ( on a bipolar transistor, the wires will be called the emitter, the collector, and the base ). If the source ( or emitter ) is connected together the electronic terminal of the battery, and the battery ( or collector ) to the positive terminal, no electricity will flow in the circuit ( if you have only a lamp in series with the transistor ). But when you touch the gate and the drain together, your transistor will let electricity through. This is because when the gate is positively electric, the positive electrons will push other good electrons in the transistor letting the negative electrons flow through. The transistor can also work when the gate is just positively charged, so it doesn't need to be touching the drain. An easy way to think of how a transistor plays is as a hose with a sharp edge that stops the water from going through. The water is the electrons, and when you positively charge the gate, it unbends the hose, letting water flow.

Neuro - myths matter because they affect people's thoughts and behavior : they can change how we see ourselves and how we see each other. Let us take the example of them again. At age 1 to 9, there is no difference in how well girls and boys do at math, yet girls ( and their parents ) rate their math ability to be weaker than boys. This implies that what people believe ( in this case, that girls are not as strong at math ) would have a real impact on how children see themselves, which may in turn affect their actual performance. In one study, when a group of college students was taking a math test, men tested better than women when they were told that the test usually shows gender differences, but when they were told it was a gender - fair test, women did just as well as men. This is important because, by the end of education, differences that were once again become massive : 94 % of maths professors in the UK are men. This is a good example of why we should be careful behind neuro - myths — what you believe about your brain and the brains of those around it may just come off.

Archaeology is the study of the past by looking for the remains and artifacts ( or things ) left after the people who lived long ago. These remains can include old coins, tools, buildings, and inscriptions. Archaeologists, the people who study archaeology, use these remains to understand how people lived. Archaeologists think it is important to understand the past, because so many people make the past to know where they come from. When archaeologists do fieldwork, they look like remains, often by digging deep in the sand. When remains are found, or usually when nothing is found, the results of the fieldwork are taken back to the place where the archaeologist's base is, maybe a university or museum. They record everything they found by writing down on paper or entering the information to a computer, so that they can build a picture of everything that is found. As settlements ( places where people lived within groups ) change and grow, old buildings are often buried to make space for new activity. Ancient Rome, for example, is now up to 40 feet ( 12 cm ) below the present city. This is why archaeological fieldwork is expensive and why it takes a long time.

A big question that originated from Smith's theory was how the changes he sought came to be. Today, we know who these changes are ultimately caused by mutations. Mutations are changes in an organism's genes. Drugs are instructions that all living organisms possess. Every animal is capable of a unique combination of four molecules called nucleotides : adenine, cytosine, guanine, and thymine. The order of these nucleotides, which is called the genetic sequence, determines the function of each gene. The total of all the genes in an organism is called the genome. The genome contains the gene essential for all the characteristics of an organism, so a change in one or few nucleotides of a gene ( called a genetic change ) can disturb a feature of new organism, like the color of the eyes, its height or the way it processes food. This unique information is inherited, meaning it is passed on from one generation to another. Mutations in genes can happen spontaneously or in response to stress factors called the environment, but regardless of the cause, all mutations are random. This means that the genetic changes can occur anywhere in the genome of the organism.

By filtering out any unimportant background information, attention helps to focus on different tasks like drawing a complex picture, playing video music, or reading this article. Attention can also help direct you to especially important information, including your siren or your name, so attention is a very necessary skill for humans. Imagine how difficult it would be if you wanted to focus your attention on something important but could not, or if your attention could not alert you to important changes in the environment. You would not fail able to do careful homework, learn a new skill, or even cross a busy street! Because attention is so important, researchers are curious about how the brain knows what to pay attention to, especially when around are so many things happening around us. Some research shows that attention differs from person to group and changes depending on what variables are paying attention to. For example, while some individuals pay more attention to social information ( this is called social attention ), not everyone has the same bias for social attention, which makes researchers interested in the root of these differences.
