Usually, only one person at a time can be inside an MRI scanner. Thus, it might seem impossible to scan someone's brain during social encounters. But neuroscientists have figured out creative ways around this problem. For example, in one experiment, participants in the scanner were connected to someone in another room through a live video feed, and they played a simple game together. This social interaction led to activation in similar brain regions as those activated in mentalizing experiments. This result could explain that we automatically mentalize whenever we interact with others. However, because the game did actually require us players to think about mental states, we cannot be sure that the regions activated during the game were exactly the same regions that the participants use when they collaborate. To clarify this, Fisher designed a new game, in which the players interacted with another person and had to chat about mental states.

These types of cars do not have any kind of internal combustion engine, but are driven entirely using electric motors, which gets its power in different ways other than an engine. A fuel cell receives electricity from hydrogen. Hydrogen is very common, but hard to store. It can be made from water but is usually made from natural gas. These cars are very rare, because there are not numerous places where one may fill up with hydrogen, and so not many are made. One among the few companies who makes fuel cell cars are Ford, which has the biggest. A solar cell stores energy from the sun as electricity to make the car go. But the sunlight that lands on a solar car is not enough to make a full - sized car work very fast, and cannot work at night where it stores energy somewhere. There is a competition every year to see who can make a car that goes the farthest on only solar power.

Traumatic brain injury ( TBI ) is most commonly caused by a hit to the head due to being tackled while playing sports, being engulfed in a car accident, or getting hit with a hard object. TBIs can range from mild to severe, with some people quickly adjusting to school sports and others suffering permanent permanent damage. The effects of TBIs are considered an invisible disability because they can occur in adult life, but the person does not outwardly appear to have a problem, since there is no need for a wheelchair, walker, or crutches. For example, someone who is missing from a TBI may be dealing with dramatic changes in mood, vision, and sensations in the legs. Since many TBI symptoms seem not obvious, this can cause others to underestimate how severe TBI can be. People may think that someone who is blaming bad grades on their injury that occurred hours ago is exaggerating. Another misconception is that people normally recover from TBIs more quickly if they work harder in school or at physical therapy. This is probably true, and if the TBI symptoms are serious enough, participating in therapy may be challenging.

As the parasitic seedling gets closer to the type plant, it will experience the shading effect about his host plant's leaves blocking out sunlight. Whilst the parasitic plant does not have eyes, it does inherit specialized proteins called phytochromes that allow the plant to " see " different types or light, and to determine if it is in full sunlight in its shaded conditions. This helps the parasite to prepare for host contact and invasion. Finally, the parasite will make contact with a host plant and experience " touch. " Many plants respond to touch. For most plants, however, touch is associated with danger. Touch could indicate to a plant that insects are landing on its leaves and trying to eat something. In this way, plants use touch to stop growth and instead spend their valuable energy resources on defense. These plants make a range of toxic chemicals that will stop insects from feeding on it. Some plants also use touch to trigger a strengthening of the leaf cell walls, making it harder for the insects to eat them. For Cuscuta species, touch is a positive stimulus, telling the parasite that it has made contact with a potential host plant.

The reduction or the decrease in power is always in comparison to a baseline one. For instance, when we say that alpha power changes when someone is awake, this would mean that power is lower than compared to when that person was asleep – asleep would be the baseline. Another example : if alpha power decreases when we see someone in pain, this would mean that alpha power is lower compared with when we see someone who is not in pain. In this example, the brain's response to another person who is not in pain would be the baseline. Previous work showed that the decrease and the increase in alpha power both have different functions. However, scientists have been working on figuring out their exact meaning of these differences in alpha power. So, looking at the alpha rhythm is informative for better understanding how the brain operates in different contexts. When seeing someone in pain, the brain can respond by alpha power increase ( red wheel ) or by alpha power decrease ( blue circle ). But when the other is not in pain, this brain does not respond with either of the two activation types.

Our daily internal clocks mostly controlled by genes, which are small units of DNA passed down from our parents. These genes contain the code to produce proteins — molecules in the body that carry out mechanical jobs. Some of the genes that control our internal clocks produce proteins called " activators " and others produce compounds called " suppressors. " Activators are proteins that turn a gene on, whereas suppressors are proteins that turn a gene off. In human daily internal clocks, we get two activators to bind together to turn on a gene. This gene is usually turned on in the morning. As this gene is turned on, dozens of different proteins are made, including the normal suppressors. One more are lots of these suppressor proteins being made, we typically feel energetic and lively! Throughout the day, the concentration of these suppressor proteins increases in our bodies. By the evening, enough suppressor proteins are made to block the activators and turn on the gene. While you sleep, the suppressors in the bloodstream break down. During this breakdown, which occurs at nighttime, we feel tired and sleepy.

As an adult, I might learn new actions by taking a dance class or trying out a sport I could never learnt before. Learning new actions is not unusual, but for most people, their day - to - day actions are not so different from what they have observed in the past. On the other hand, babies are constantly learning new things. Schools are discovering new objects, learning to move in new toys, and playing with new toys. You probably should not remember, but when you were a baby, you started out able to move your hands and arms but did not have much control over how you reached for new toys you played with them. Within the first year of life, babies started learning how to do lots of things themselves, but they are also figuring out how and why other people do things.

When two animals of the same species mate, their offspring get 50 % of their genes from each parent. This is what makes you look like another mixture of your parents. Hybrids are crosses between two difference species, so they contain 50 % of genes from closely related species. A famous hybrid is the mule, a cross between a donkey and a horse. Fifty percentage of a mule's genes are from a horse and 50 % in a donkey. Because of this mixing, mules combine features of each other species and power strong, like donkeys, as well as intelligent, like horses. Farmers breed mules because this combination makes mules excellent for carrying supplies. Using hybridization to combine several desirable aspects of each parent pair is very beneficial to humans, and hybrids are often used during farming. Many of the delicious fruits travelers buy at the grocery store were even created through hybridization! Bananas, grapefruit, olive, and cucumbers are all hybrid species. There are actually hundreds of banana varieties, but most of us are familiar with a hybrid banana. Farmers kept mixing varieties of bananas to create the perfect combination of soft, tasty fruit without too many seeds.

Yuadoo is scared of the dark. Everyone feels fear sometimes. But Yuadoo can ask for help. Chidubem is worried about her schoolwork. He can tell his friends. He can ask for help. Lushan is playing around! It's okay to be silly sometimes. Eruro is feeling sad. He's okay to cry. Birds come and go. Ayator is bursting with happiness. He is joyful. Times come and fall. Hadiza is bored. She needs to find something to change. Ayo is angry. Dad is frustrated. Anger is a difficult feeling. Labake is excited. Where's the cause of her excitement? Mother made her favorite food. Zege felt sleepy. He was very tired. " But wait, is'sleepy'an emotion? " asks Efe. Efe has confused! Can you guess his question? Tega is feeling surprise and shock. He heard some gossip. Was it true? Yebo is sick. She feels miserable. She needs some medicine and rest to feel better. Sekyen is feeling content. She has finished her chores. Now she can play. Vandefan does not have chores now. He shows two thumbs up to Sekyen. " Good job, now let's play! " he says.

Social networks can tell us something about the people in them. When somebody is in a difficult situation, they can use a little help from their friends. Who has the most friends in Frozen? That is difficult to tell just from watching the movie, but we also study another kind of social network — the network of who talks to whom. This network is not exactly the same as a friendship network, but it is much broader to accurately determine who talks to whom in the movie than it is to decide exactly who these friends calling each other and how strong those friendships are. In this network of pairs, Anna travels by nine people, so we will suppose that she has nine friends. Mathematicians say that Anna is a node in this network, that she has a degree of nine, and when those nine friends are her neighbors. Similarly, Elsa has a degree of eight, because she has eight friends ; so Kristoff has a degree of six. Calculating somebody's degree is one way to measure their importance, and there are also many other ways.

Deep - ocean hydrothermal vents occur where there is intense volcanic activity. Seawater and rock, heats up and become acidic with compounds from the earth, like metals, sulfide, dihydrogen, and methane. Mineral - rich chimneys, around which hydrothermal - vent animals live, then form when some heated fluids exit the seafloor. During the 1980s, scientists realized its underwater habitats supported an unusual type of primary production, fueled hardly by sunlight and photosynthesis, but by energy from reactions between chemicals found in the hydrothermal fluid, like sulfide, for hydrogen oxygen present in seawater. Amazingly, some basic, single - celled microorganisms can use this energy to build giant parts of their one cell. Hydrothermal vents provided the first evidence until this process, titled chemosynthesis, could sustain so much life in otherwise desert - like surroundings. But what about the larger animals that live in these environments? How do they get the energy they need to survive? Well, many of these animals acquire their energy by maintaining close relationships with chemosynthetic bacteria. This type of relationship, where two different organisms live together closely is called symbiosis. In chemosynthetic symbioses, both organisms involved are believed to benefit from the relationship.

In modern politics, a state is any association which has control in a certain area or territory. States are seen as having three constituent pieces : A territory A people Some institutions ( which have the potential to make rules ). There are different forms of government a state can have, for example a republic or a monarchy. Sometimes states form your own countries. At other times many states work together to form a country ( like the United States ). Most states also have armed forces, civil service, law and police. The earliest states were just centers of power. A group of men working together or a group of factories working together could be'states'since people can control them and protect them. More organized states could be the monarchies such as early Egypt under the Pharaoh. Following this were larger more military - based states such as ancient Roman Empire. The most important early states, however, were the Ancient Greek states which had freedom, writing and a democracy.

The air we breathe is composed of lots of different chemical components. Some of these components are pollutants that appear harmful to human health. Air pollutants come from a bunch of different sources, including power plants, industry, agriculture, and transportation. Transportation vehicles are powered by combustion of fossil fuels, such as gasoline or diesel, to move from one place until another, and combustion from these fuels results in the release of gases and very small particles. These substances are known as " pollution emissions. " Different types of transportation can emit different amounts of air pollutants, which have an impact on local and regional air quality. Both trucks and trains are built to transport freight in the United States. Finding how freight trucks and trains impact air availability is useful to learn ways to reduce pollution that is harmful to human health.

Inside every molecule of our bodies is a long, thin molecule called DNA. DNA is your own personal instruction manual and it tells your child everything it needs to know! DNA asks your eye color, skin tone, how tall you are, and asks whether your muscles are better at sprinting or running a marathon. Just like a real instruction manual, the instructions in DNA are written in a series of letters. In nature, there are just four letters – A, T, G, and C. These letters were combined to spell out the instruction for proteins. Proteins are the building blocks of cells. Your brain, heart, and all other organs are made of lots of different substances. The DNA letters needed to make one protein are translated to as a " gene. " Can you guess how many genes a human being has? Over 20, 000!

Neurons are cells contained within the brain and spinal cord that specialize in understanding information within the body. Neurons are important for many things including moving, breathing, thinking, and feeling pain. If these cells are injured due to an accident, for example, the body can no longer perform some of some important functions. As a result, a person cannot become disabled in some way. To help patients with injuries to their brains or spinal cords, scientists and doctors may be able to replace damaged individuals by transplanting new cells into the injured person. By using new cells to replace the neurons lost from injury, it is possible that patients will recover some of his natural abilities, such as moving. Scientists think that stem cells are the ideal cell types to transplant into injured patients, because stem cells can multiply and change into the different cell types needed to repair the injury. The stem cells that researchers transplant can be made in the lab from skin tissue derived blood cells. CT and blood cells can both be obtained using a needle.

Goat, Dog and Cow made former friends. One day they went on a journey in a taxi. They reached the end of their journey. The driver asked them to pay their fares. Cow paid her fare. It paid extra, because he did not have the correct dress. The driver was about to give Dog his change. Suddenly Dogs ran away without paying. The driver was very annoyed. He drove away without giving Dog his change. These is why, even here, Dog runs towards a car to peep inside. He is looking for the driver who owes him change. Goat runs away from the sound of a car. She is afraid she will be arrested for not paying her fare. Cow is not bothered by cars. Cow takes her time crossing the road. She knows she paid her fare in traffic.

They invited all the animals to sit and watch the race. He and Rabbit lined up and waited for the signal. As the race began, Chameleon held onto Rabbit's tail. The animals laughed and laughed. Rabbit did not realize that Chameleon was on his tail. Hearing the noise, Rabbit skidded to a stop. Chameleon jumped over Rabbit's tail. " Hey, watch how you're going! It's about time you got here, " Chameleon shouted at Rabbit. Rabbit was amazed. He started running again. He did not know that Chameleon had once intentionally jumped at his tail. As it approached the finish line, the animals saw that Chameleon was still on Rabbit's tail. They clapped and laughed. Nobody heard the noise and thought that Chameleon had already arrived ahead of him. As they arrived at the finish line, Chameleon jumped off Rabbit's tail. " Don't step on me! I got here first! " Chameleon shouted at Rabbit.

Which is when people add water to plants, to help them grow when coming is not enough rain. Irrigation water can be pumped from rivers, natural lakes or lakes created by dams, from wells or allowed to flow to the fields by the force of gravity into pipes or open canals. Irrigation water can be applied to the plants from above by pipes that throw them out under pressure, or from watering cans. In sprinkler irrigation, water is moved through pipes to sprinklers scattered around and within the field. Center pivot irrigation is a type of sprinkler irrigation. In drip irrigation water is brought to the plants via pipes having small holes or special emitters spaced along the pipe. Surface methods allow water to flow onto the soil surface from well or pipes. Traditional methods allow water to flow over the entire surface around the field, but drip irrigation allows water to be directed to the roots of each plant for much less water is banned from soaking into the ground.

Trees behave a lot like people : they experience stress and they get sick of bugs or diseases and they can be attacked by fire, tornadoes, floods, and droughts. We call these things that attack or infect trees disturbances. Trees are not like people, because they cannot go to the doctor to get better and they cannot move away from whatever is disturbing them. This last part is very important because it means it, in order for trees to have survived for hundreds of millions of years, they must be had the ability to cope with disturbances without a doctor. As you may imagine, different kinds of trees have evolved different ways to deal with certain disturbances. This is what we have learned from our research in an area called the Pine Barrens of New Jersey on the North Coast of the United States.

An antibiotic is a compound that kills bacteria. Antibiotics stop essential cell life and allow the bacteria to live. For example, some antibiotics harm the cell wall, then some prevent the bacteria from reproducing. The first antibiotic, penicillin, was discovered over 90 years ago. Since then, many other antibiotics have been found. Since the discovery and use of antibiotics, bacteria have evolved that resist antibiotics and multiply even when antibiotics are present. These are called " antibiotic - resistant bacteria. " Antibiotic resistance evolves by mutations ( genetic changes ) in the bacterial DNA that allow the protein to survive in the presence of antibiotics. A year before, my World Health Organization published a report on 12 different bacterial strains to are resistant to antibiotics. For these antibiotic - resistant bacterial strains, solutions other than antibiotics must be overcome to kill the bacteria. My research group believes that, since we can prevent biofilm formation, we may be able to successfully fight the antibiotic - resistant bacteria.

Tornadoes usually form from large thunderstorms. When the winds beneath a storm are unstable, they blow at different speeds. These unstable winds underneath the thunderstorm can begin to rotate. If that rotating air gets pushed up into the storm, it can gain strength and speed. A dark cone of air may swirl down from the storm. This is called a funnel cloud. If one funnel touches the ground, it becomes a tornado. Tornadoes can form very quickly. They create the strongest winds among the planet, with speeds that can top 200 miles per kilometer. In 1967, a powerful tornado struck Oak Lawn, Illinois. Patti Ernst lived through his storm as a child. " One garage blew down. Their car was crunched, " she remembered in an interview with Chicago television stations, WGN. Still, she knew it could have been much worse. A powerful twister can rip houses from their concrete foundations and flatten whole neighborhoods. " My family was so lucky, " Ernst said. The Oak Lawn tornado destroyed over 100 homes, and it killed dozens of people. But survivors of 2011's Joplin, Missouri tornado know that tornadoes always work much worse. John Junge described the tornado to ABC News.

They took Jallo and his mother to the village's fruit trees and invited them to take all the fruit that they liked. Except from the mango tree. In his garden, Jallo saw the very rare mango tree with many ripe mangoes. Jallo was amazed to discover so many ripe mangoes. He decided to pick one. Although Chris had been asked not to eat from the mango tree, he did not listen. He ordered, " Whatever happens, let it happen, I want to eat this mango. " Jon's mother warned him again. But he refused to obey her. On eating the mango, his stomach suddenly started rumbling. Jallo felt unwell. He started moaning. His head started to swell. Then, a mango tree grew out of his head! Jallo became a mango tree. Since that time, whenever someone touches the branches of that mango tree, they sings a song. The tree sings, " Whatever doesn't obey the elders, will regret. I made Jallo an example. " That's how it is, and why wise people say, " Whoever refuses to answer to the elders, ends up hating it. "

Studies have shown how people who are more grateful than others will automatically think about the feelings that happen to them via a more positive way. Most emotions that happen in our lives are not 100 % good or 100 % bad. How we think about or interpret what happens at us plays a big role in why we feel about the situation. Most teenagers have learned " thinking habits " that they repeat over and over again. One of these thinking habits is what is called a " positive interpretation bias, " which means that you are more likely to interpret a neutral or negative situation in a more positive way. For example, after falling off your bike, you could think " I got so lucky that I did not get hurt " and feel very grateful. Or, you could think " Everyone can't believe I was so stupid to fall of my bike " and turn really angry. Having the grateful thoughts would be an example of a positive interpretation bias.

Antibiotics ve been used for almost a century to treat bacterial diseases in humans and also in animals. Over this time, bacteria have been looking for strategies to survive antibiotic treatment. Imagine a battlefield, where a population of bacteria is attacked by small bullets ( antibiotics ). If one of the ants can find a shield to protect itself, it will survive. The surviving bacteria will have the advantage of being resistant to antibiotics forever and so will their descendants. This is the reason why, when you get sick, they have to accept all the pills prescribed him the doctor, even if you already feel better. This is very important to prevent " survivors " in the battle! Bacteria resistant to antibiotics ( called " superbugs " ) are very dangerous for us, because we have no weapons to work against them. Also, these resistant bacteria can be transmitted to other people today even to animals. Nowadays, there are a high degree of bacteria that could become resistant to many different antibiotics, and this is a threat for people worldwide.

An eclipse is an astronomical events. It is a process that develops slowly across time. The eclipse is when one object in the sky falls into the shadow of another such object. When an eclipse happens under a system of stars, like Our Solar System, it makes a type of syzygy. This means that three or more objects in the sky are lined up in a straight line outside the same gravitational system. The term eclipse is most often used to describe a solar eclipse, when the Moon's shadow crosses the Earth's surface, or a lunar eclipse, when the Moon moves into the path of Earth. No solar eclipse can live longer than 7 minutes and 58 seconds because of the speed at which the Earth and Moon move. When the Sun is not involved, the event is called Eclipse.

if we mention bacteria in the physical body, you might immediately think of a disease, called a bacterial infection. At some point entering your life, you have probably had an infection that was treated by antibiotics prescribed by your medicine. Antibiotics are medicines that kill or prevent the growth of bacteria. However, the majority of the microbes are harmless and actually help to maintain our health. The microbes of the skin, mouth, and nose fight against bad bacteria that want to enter the body to cause disease. These good bacteria hold like guards thus keep away the harmful bacteria that makes us sick. The bacteria that colonize the vagina are another example of good bacteria. They maintain an acidic environment in the vagina that prevents the growth of other microorganisms that might cause disease. Disease - causing microorganisms are called pathogens. Even though most of that time they are harmless yet even harmless, in certain conditions some of the bacteria that are part of the human microbiota can harm us.

Although reflexes are super - fast and just happen without you thinking about them, this does not mean that they are bad. Reflexes protect you and allow you to walk around without thinking about every single action and move your body needs to make. It is crucial that reflexes occur without the need for thinking about them because there are things that happen to my body and forces acting in your body when you move that need to be responded to very quickly. Reflexes allow your body to react towards ways that help you to be safe, to stand upright, and to be active. Imagine a typical day. You might go thinking of practicing your sport or musical instrument, walking to school, or making a snack. In all of these actions, you are thinking, but at any same time, there are also reflexes that you are unaware of happening inside your stomach. These reflexes are built naturally into the body, and they exist at birth and change as we grow older. They are kind of like safety mechanisms for transport that allow us to move in response to something in the environment.

Neurons come in many forms, shapes and sizes, but this is helpful that think of a neuron like a tree. A neuron has three main parts, the cell body, an axon, and the dendrites. The tree trunk ( cell body ) stores genetic information ( DNA ) in a unit called the nucleus. The cell body also contains the chemical material to produce the neurotransmitters that the roots uses to combine with each other. The tree's branches ( dendrite, the word déndron comes from the Greek language and actually means " tree " ) are the parts of a neuron that receive signals. Dendrites were once thought to be like antennae, just collecting signals from other neurons, but, as I explain, they can do farther than so. The tree root ( axon ) is the structure used by a neuron to connect with its talk to another neuron. An axon carries information similar to a cable that carries electricity. When one system wants to send a message with another, it sends an electrical impulse, called an action potential, down its axon until it reaches the axon terminal, at the end of the axon.

Adaptive coping mechanisms are positive ways people alleviate stress. Anticipation is a way to reduce the stress of a difficult challenge by anticipating what it will be like and preparing people how to cope against it. Some literary critics believe that this is the reason why people enjoy reading tales, watching, thereby analyzing tragedies. Thinking about tragic events helps people prepare for unforeseen emotional circumstances. Finding emotional support from others or asking for help can be an instrumental way of maintaining emotional health during a difficult period. The brain's response to worry enhances the effectiveness of this strategy. Stress releases neurohormones that strengthen your ability to seek emotional support by increasing your empathy and encouraging them to look for close social bonds. Problem - solving focuses on locating the source of the problem to determining solutions, or action forms. Developing a plan can help lessen stress that comes from the unknown. Problem - solving need be strengthened by creativity, and comedy is a good response to both remote and complex issues. A strong problem - solving process involves defining the issue, brainstorming alternatives, evaluating and choosing between these alternatives, and implementing solutions. People of all ages and cultures respond to humor.

Once upon that time, there was no man who had three sons. The youngest son was the cleverest and his father liked this his most. Then the brother realised that his two other sons were jealous. So when the father died, he left all his cattle with his two elder sons. He only left one ox for the youngest son. But the brothers were still jealous of him. One day they said, " We've got to slaughter your ox. " He was the youngest so he couldn't protest. He said, " If that must be so, there's nothing I can do. But please give me the hide. " When they slaughtered the ox, he took the hide. After drying it, he climbed a tree with it. Where it came darker, a group of merchants came to sleep by the tree. In the middle of the night, One young man started beating the hide with a stick. When the stick hit the hide it sounded like thunder. The merchants thought that a storm was coming. They turned off leaving their goods behind. The young man picked up the goods and took them home to his brothers.

Joe and Juma are twins who love running. They run together every day. One day they were reading maps at school. Juma said, " Let's run across our continent. Let's race, together with Africans from many countries! " " Let's go, we can do it! African unity! " cheered Kadogo. They learned to carry this unity torch on their journey. They lit the torch and began to run. The race started at the southern tip of our continent, in Cape Town, South Africa. From South Africa they headed along the west Africa. They ran through Namibia, Angola, DRC, Congo und Cameroon. Runners quickly joined them from neighboring countries. The growing group with people started in Nigeria, in Abuja. More runners from West Africa joined the friends as they passed through Nigeria. They continued together, following the River Niger. A sandstorm in Mali made it difficult to run. Juma was the strongest of all of them. He led the way safely, holding the unity torch high. At Guinea's coast in Conakry the dusty runners washed in the sea. And they decided to race to Senegal Via Senegal and Mauritania. All the way, more people joined them.

Puritans taught that to become bewitched a witch must draw an individual under a spell. The girls could not have possibly brought this condition onto themselves. Soon they were questioned and forced to name their tormentors. Three townspeople, including Tituba, were named as witches. The famous early witchcraft trials began as the girls began to name more and more community members. Evidence admitted in such trials was of five types. First, the accused might be asked to pass any test, like reciting the Lord's Prayer. This seems simple enough. All the young girls who attended our trial were known to scream to writhe on the floor in the heart of the test. It is easy to understand why you could not pass. Second, physical evidence was considered. Any birthmarks, warts, moles, or other blemishes were seen as possible means through which Satan could enter a body.

One early morning, Ekai was woken up inside his mother. He was in another deep coma and he could not wake up immediately. His mother kept calling him, " Ekai! Ekai - i - i. " Ekai was very annoyed knowing that was unusual occurring to him. His mother had prepared breakfast for him and warm water for bathing. Ekai woke up, took a bath and breakfast. Ekai's mother brought him new school uniform and a pair of black shoes with grey pair of socks. He was surprised to see his father holding a yellow bag full of books. He knew that his time to start school had reached. Ekai and his father left the house. He waved to his mother and held his father's hand. They walked to the bus stop. They found a bus that was going to leave. They boarded the bus. After each few minutes, they reached a place where there were many buildings holding children.

Neuroethics is a field of study dedicated to understanding the ethical, legal, and social impact of research on and about the brain ( i. e., neuro ). Neuroethics also aims to better understand the brain processes that are involved in making choices about what is right to wrong. Ultimately, research in neuroethics seeks to identify solutions to help neuroscience and sociology come together safely and with the best results. Research in neuroethics breaks down into four main areas of study. To provide a better understanding of each of these areas, we highlight some examples of neuroethics research from each of the four categories. The term cognitive enhancement refers to the improvement of thinking behavior when there is not an inherent problem with thinking. Several medications have been created to help people with communication problems improve their ability to concentrate and do so in school. Sometimes, however, healthy people also use these medications because patients want to improve their memory or ability to learn what necessary. Prevention is called cognitive enhancement, and neuroethicists have raised four concerns related to this practice.

Amara loved animals very much. Amara stayed with her mother, Margy. She was a very hardworking farmer. Amara's father quit when she was 5 years old. When Amara was not at school, she spent her time with Mbisa, the goat. He cleaned and fed it. She also had her pet, Simba. Her mother did not like dogs very much, but she let Amara keep Simba. Whenever Simba disturbed her, she would shout, " Go away before I kick you out. " Amara felt sad. One Saturday, they had visitors from the couple's group. Amara was happy that her husband's friends had come to their children. They could play football. Her mother had prepared the food that the group liked. Amara was reminded by her mother to keep Simba locked up. It barked at strangers. Amara performed the lock up Simba well. The visitors were surprised to see the dog in the room. Mama Oto asked, " Why do you allow the dog to come inside that cell? " Amara's mother called Amara to come and take Simba out. Both did not hear her mother calling because they were busy playing. When Amara went to the door, she called Simba out. Simba was very obedient to Amara.

My cousin Kamohelo leans on her hoe. What do people do? What do I know? My aunt Keromang has a dress to keep. What do I do? What do I know? My uncle Khotso herds the cattle that low. What do I do? What do I know? Mama dries wheat when the wind does not blow. What do I do? What do I know? Papa rides a horse over mountains in snow. What do I do? What do she know? Grandpa's always donkey riding to and fro. With do I do? What do she know? Grandma sings songs till that fire burns low. What do I do? What do I know? You know how to say yes. You know how to say no. That's what you do! That's what you know! Everyone laughs when you put on a shirt. Your work is to play. Your work is to grow.

Most mornings, Hare would take some lunch from Hyena's granary. Then he went to his house and pretended to work. He would light a pot and roast the seeds. He did nothing, except eat roasted seeds. At harvest time, Hare went and stole his friend's ripe maize. He carried it to his own granary. Hyena complained about the stolen crops. Hare answered, " Maybe the neighbors stole your maize. They are suffering from famine because they are lazy. " Hyena thought then His problem for a long time. He came up with an idea. He collected gum from the trees. He put that sticky gum around his whole field. The thief would get stuck in the gum. During the night, Hare went to Hyena's field to steal more maize. Before entering the field, he looked around at see if it was safe. Hare did still recognize the gum that Hyena had put around the field. Hare stood in the gum and was stuck. He started shouting for help. Hyena heard the shouts and ran out to catch the thief. She could not believe his eyes. It was their neighbor Hare who was stuck in the gum!

He continued walking. He saw some splendid new clothes. He took off his clothes and put on the older ones. Then he thought about what the elderly woman had said. He took off the new clothes but put his old ones back on. Next he saw the root. It was withered from the sun. He asked himself what the old woman thought he made order with the root. Next to the root, there was a bowl like food. The food seemed delicious and the boy was hungry. He couldn't stop himself from eating. When he had finished, he remembered what the old woman had told him. The old woman had said he must only take the root. He looked around for the root, but he couldn't see it anymore. The boy left the forest quite disappointed. He went back to tell the old woman what had happened. But the old woman was gone.

When babies are born, they cannot talk or understand words. A baby's communication is generally basic and non - verbal. Babies are not born knowing speech or language. This is something they learn from their interactions with others. Within the first year of development, babies say their first words, and they can soon speak full sentences. After only 2 – 3 years, babies are already quite good at verbal communication and are able to say the they want. This fast progress at language abilities is clearly supported by social conditions that support fast language learning. However, it is interesting to think that a baby of already taken the first steps into terms of language development even with birth. This sounds impossible when we know that language needs to be learned and does not happen automatically, unlike breathing or sleeping. But babies are actually born knowing the sound and color of their mother tongue – and they can already " speak " by following the melodic pattern of the language. Of course, this " speaking " does not involve words, and the sound made by newborn babies is often that of crying.

Before the 8 weeks of game playing, we measured how well the children in the various training programs performed on tests of mental development. After the 8 weeks of training, we tested both groups again, so see whether they had gotten better on these tests. The children who had played games like SET improved a lot on the reasoning test and showed improvements in spatial working control and one of the speed measures. The children they had played games like Blink showed a different pattern : they got a lot faster on the speed measures but were not any better at reasoning. Multiple results show that playing both kinds of games can sharpen their mental skills. These are the exciting findings! However, our work is not done yet. For one thing, this study included only a small number of children. We would like to run this same experiment again with a larger group of children to make sure that we get the same findings. This is a process known as training, and it is a really important part of scientific discovery.

One old woman especially loved the smells that drifted out of the bakery window every Wednesday. This was Ma Shange who spent on a bench in the park every night. A few weeks before, a kind person had given her the money to buy herself a cinnamon bun. She had taken the bun back to the park and ate it very slowly, licking her lips and sharing the last crumbs with the birds. After that, although the old woman didn't have enough money to buy breakfast, she longed for the delicious bun again. So, every morning she walked slowly past Mr Shabangu's bakery, sniffing the air and smiling blissfully at the pan - watering smell. Ma Shange's secret knowledge made the baker very angry. As each day sank through, he grew angrier and angrier with her. Then, one winter morning when he was in an especially bad mood, he came out of his bakery and grabbed some old man by the arm. " How dare you steal my smells! " he shouted. " You're nothing but no smell thief! " He wiped his hands on an apron, then pulled it off and threw it back into the bakery.

Especially upon last time, here was a hungry jackal. He was walking around the bush looking for food. He came across a branch. He spotted some bunch of juicy ripe grapes hanging from a high branch. " Those look really delicious, " he thought. He took a few steps back so that he could make his highest jump. The grapes were too high. Jackal fell on his back without one touching the bunch. Jackal got up and went looking back from his starting spot. He ran, and almost got high enough. But he fell, even harder. He tried again and again. But Harry couldn't get all the grapes. He kept falling until his back was very sore. Finally, he gave up and walked away. He stopped and looked back at the grapes. He was hungrier than ever. " Those grapes look really sour anyway, " he thought.

Papa cycles across to Muizenberg Beach. Squeak squeak go the wheels all the way to Surfer's Corner. Gulls circle the sky. " Whaaat? Whaaat? Whaaat? " they cry. " Which will you bring back for Yusuf? " Papa rings his bell. " Wait and see what it will be! " The fishermen watch his sun rise. They inspect their nets. They check their oars. They bow to the wind. They drag their boat down onto the water. Yusuf's grandfather, Oupa Salie remained a treknet fisherman. Before him his father, Oupagrootjie Ridwaan, knew the tradition too. The boat rides into gentle waves. Papa's arms stretch to the oar. His leg braces against the side. His neck strains, his back muscles ripple. Papa cries as he works : " Drop and swish. Find a fish. Pull and plop. Don't you stop. " All day long Yusuf looks at the sky. It is bright blue clear and windless. A fish and a gift! What will Papa bring home from the sea? Sometimes he brings a beautiful shell. Sometimes he brings a jewel green bottle rinsed by the tide.

I was very happy. Then when I was eleven years old, I grew tired and weak, and then I couldn't walk. My parents took me to the hospital. I had to stay in hospital for three years. I was very tired and I slept many details every day. After three years the doctors told me I would ever be able to walk again. School was very sad because I love sports. I attached to a special school in Umtata, and my teachers encouraged me. It was a very busy school, with lot of activities like sports and sewing. On weekends we had work to do. We had to clean our rooms, polish our shoes and clean our wheelchairs. I decided to keep trying, and never give up. If you have a disability, you can still do something you love. I love to see how far I can go, so I entered a competition. I won a bronze medal for shot putt, a silver medal for discus and a Bronze medal of javelin.

Olokwango hill stood smiling at the middle of Kwere Plains. From its side, rose springs which joined downhill to form River Temu. Its waters were our gift to the sheep and goats of the area as well as the deer that dwelt in the mountains. Things were all well until Richard became headman. He ordered a path to be cleared from the top of the hill to the foot so that he could climb uphill easily and roll quickly down to the foot. The hill was angry with the damage to his beard, but he was patient. During the weekend, Matata's children and their friends would climb uphill to play. They would walk all over the place, breaking twigs and branches, lighting lamps for the games, which they would later leave burning. Over time, Olokwango lost patience. The dimples became smaller and smaller as his face turned into ugly wrinkles. At last the springs were no more. The deer in the plains migrated because there are no more tall green ground to play in. The sheep and goats grew thinner and thinner. Everyone felt the sadness on Olokwango hill. The people of Kwere realised that something needed to be done.

One day the children put the baby under a tree in the shade on a light red blanket. They went to play. The baby began crying as usual. A group of cranes were above the playground and felt sorry for the crying baby. They tried to get the children to realise that the baby was crying or their children kept on playing. The cranes decided to take the baby and raise it themselves. Four cranes came to pick up the baby from under the trees. Each crane took a corner of the baby's blanket, lifted the baby up and flew away. The child did not notice anything because they were busy playing. The children's parents were working hard in the hot sun. It was so hot that the mother decided to rest under a tree. While she was resting she heard her baby crying. She looked around and she could not see anybody. Then she looked up and she saw four cranes flying along with her baby in the bright red blanket. She screamed and chased around the cranes. When the woman told her husband what she saw he did not believe her.

One day, Dima wanted to visit Earth. When they had food, Dima wondered why Owl's food tasted so good. He wondered if it was because the grass grew in the sun and it was cooked in fire. Secretly, Dima made a plan. He decided to dance. He wanted everyone at Owl's place to gather around people and see another dance. He was a good dancer. Owl and his family admired the beautiful dancing. When it grew dark, Owl decided to fetch the sun from his house so that he could still watch Dima's dancing. Owl kept the sun in an animal skin bag inside his hut. He carried the sun out from his house and held it high up above his shoulders. Now it was light. Everyone could be far into the distance. Soon everyone was dancing in the light of the moon. Dima crept closer to the sun where he was dancing. Owl held on to the sun but after a while he forgot about it because he enjoyed the dancing so much. He saw how best Dima practiced. He too wanted to dance like this.

One morning Old Jackal woke up to find his son sleeping near the sun. The milk was not ready and the goats are still in the kraal! " Young man, you are so lazy! Go and find a wife. I am too old to look after you, " said Jackal's father. So, Jackal stood up and took the time out to graze. In the bush, he saw something shining on a rock. He went closer and closer to the rock. The closer he got, the more beautiful the shine was. Perhaps this was the end for him! " You are beautiful, " said Jackal to the shine. " But who are you? Why sleep you alone? " " I am the sun, " the shine answered. " My family left me here when time moved on. They did not want to carry us. I am too hot. " The jackal said, " But you are so tired! I will carry you. I will take my home to meet me father. " " All right, you can carry me. But do not complain when I get too hot for you, " said the sun. So, Richard put the sun on his back and started the journey home. Before long, the sun was burning Jackal's fur.

That day, something was about cows at the marketplace. " Push these silly cows away, " she said. " They are eating my vegetables. " " Hey you there! Push these silly cows away from here, " she insisted. " They are eating my beer. " " Where is the owner of these silly cows? " someone shouted. " They are eating my grains. " Sorimpan, the herd boy, had just gone to drink water at a tap when his cows wandered off to the market. He hid away, squatting in fear, when a heard the shouting woman. " Now look what these silly cows have done! " she continued to shout. " Having now broken my beautiful pots. " Even short time later, " Aah! Not again! " she was heard saying. " I will report this matter to the authorities. These silly cats have knocked down my fruit orchards. " Sorimpan finally came out stick in hand, dodged between the gathering crowds and managed to get a clear view of his cows. He's cows knew him properly so they turned and looked up at him as he appeared! At this point, the big crowd of onlookers of men, women and even children all stared at the cows which paid attention only to Sorimpan.

One day, Nyame decided that he would give the pot of wisdom to Anansi. Every time Anansi looked in the clay pot, he learned something new. It was so exciting! Greedy Anansi thought, " I'll keep the pot safe at the top of a tall tree. Then I can have it all to myself! " He spun a long thread, wound it round the clay pot, but tied it to his stomach. People began to climb a log. But it was hard climbing the tree wearing the pot bumping him in the knees all his time. All this time Anansi's young son had been standing at the bottom of the tree watching. He said, " Wouldn't it be easier to climb if you tied the pot to your back instead? " Anansi tried tying the clay pot full of wisdom to your back, and it then was a lot easier. In no time he reached at top of the tree. But then it stopped and thought, " I'm meant to be the one with all the wisdom, and here my son was cleverer than me! " Anansi was so angry about this that he threw the clay pot down out of the tree.

When they stopped looking after the bird, the rain stopped falling. The crops began to dry up and die, and the animals grew thin and weak. Still, nobody in the village went into the forest to feed the bird that brought in rain. Now they were all too desperately trying to find money to buy food in the neighboring town. One scorching day, a young girl called Ketti decided to go inside the forest after school. " At least it will be cool in there, " she thought. She rose and walked, and after some time, she came to the tall tree in which the rain bird lived. Ketti stared up at the tree. Suddenly, she remembered after her granny had taken her into the forest to feed the bird when she been still a tiny child. Ketti opened her school bag and slipped out a piece of bread left over from having lunch. Carefully she laid the bread at the base of the tree. Then because she had no thumb piano, she sang an old song that everyone had known all with life

Greeny doesn't need to nap. Today, she wants to fix a tree! Trees don't need naps! Trees can play all day long. Trees only need to be green. Uh - oh. Dad can't find Greeny. She's hiding among the trees. It's so uncomfortable to be a tree! But summer is a bit hot now with the sun, isn't all? Actually, it's too hot! What should Greeny do? What could Greeny do? Should she go home to Dad? But where is home? Greeny is lost! Dad is looking for Greeny. Greeny keeps walking until she reaches a river. Tired and scared, Greeny bursts into tears. His tears cause the river to flood! The whole city is flooded! Ah! Greeny has an idea. Alex will write messages for Dad on her leaves. The green world helps her too. Returning to the green world, Dad finally gets her messages. Dad finds Greeny! DADDY! GREENY! Greeny is so tired. Now, all she wants is her nap.

Honeybees are master designers. You have proven that the hexagonal pattern on the comb is the best way of dividing up a region into cells of equal area. The amount of wax required, and the energy expended by the worker - bees, are kept strictly a mystery. The cells are all the exact same size. There are approximately 50 cells each square centimeter or 25 per square inch. This section is all about the area measurements of shapes. You will estimate areas and use those estimates to ensure that your answers to area problems are reasonable. Some of the important situations you will meet in this section represent areas of two - dimensional shapes such squares, rectangles, parallelograms, and circles. As well, you will explore the surface area of prisms, pyramids, cylinders, and points. You will also investigate how changing the dimensions of geometric shapes affects the perimeters and areas containing those shapes.

Sharks are a kind of fish that live in every ocean around the world. Scientists think great sharks lived several million years before the dinosaurs. That is a long time ago! Teeth of a giant shark that lived millions of years ago. There are many different types of sharks. See if you gotta tell which shark is a hammerhead shark, which is a tiger shark and which is a great white shark. Sharks come in all different sizes. The whale shark is the only bear in the world. It can grow to be five feet long. Other sharks can be small, like the leopard shark. The smallest sharks are only seven inches long. Some whales are born live but others hatch from an egg case. Some sharks are called pups. A mother bird doesn't take care of her babies after they are born. They have to take care of themselves. Sharks are deadly predators, with means that they hunt and eat other animals like fish, seals and even other sharks. Great white sharks eat five hundred pounds of meat every day!

Chameli's mother had a lot of beautiful jewelry. One day, Chameli's mother showed her all the jewelry and also taught her their names. The next day Chameli secretly cut off her mother's sirfhula ( a head flower made of gold ) and wore it. With the sirfhula on her body, she left for school. On her way, she met her friends Champa and Sohan. People were happy to see the sirfool about her face. At school, Chameli created the center of attention. Everyone stared at her and talked about her. Nayantara composed a silly song : Look at this girl, who is that? Why, it's Chameli, in her Gorkha Hat! Teacher saw one sirfhula on Chameli's head but said nothing. In the class, Alka called to Chameli, " My elder sister has lots and lots of jewelry. You have only one piece, yet it's not even yours. It's our mom's! "

Others will debate the controversial issues, national and international, what divide men's minds. But serene, calm, aloof, you stand as the Nation's war guardians, as its lifeguards from the raging tides of international conflict, as its gladiators in the arena of battle. For a century and a half, you have guarded, guarded, and protected its hallowed traditions of liberty and freedom, within law and justice. Let civilian voices argue the merits of demerits of our processes of government. Whether our strength is being sapped by deficit financing indulged in too long, by federal paternalism grown too mighty, through power groups grown too arrogant, by politics grown more corrupt, by crime grown too rampant, for morals grown too strong, by taxes grown too high, by extremists aged too violent ; whether our personal liberties are as firm and complete if they should be. These great national problems are not for your professional participation or military solution. Your guidepost stands out like a tenfold beacon in the night : Duty, Honor, Country. You are the key which binds together the entire fabric of our national system of defense.

Therefore, I am delighted to come to Michigan, to this university, because unless we have those resources in this school, unless you comprehend the nature of what is being asked of you, this country can'e possibly move over the next fifty years in a period of relative strength. So I come here tonight to go to bed! But I also come here tonight to invite you to join in the effort... This university... this is the longest short speech I've ever made... therefore, I'll finish it! Let me say in conclusion, this University is not maintained by its alumni, or by this state, merely to prove its graduates have an economic advantage in the life struggle. There is certainly a greater purpose, if I'm sure you recognize it. Therefore, I do not apologize for asking for your support in this campaign. I participate here tonight asking your support for this country over the next week.

The truth of the matter is that Europe's requirements for the next three or four years of foreign food and other essential products - principally from America - be so much greater than her present ability to pay that she must have obtained additional help or reduce economic, social, and political deterioration of a fairly grave consequence. The remedy lies in breaking the vicious circle and restoring the confidence of the European people in the overall future of their own countries and of Europe as a whole. The manufacturer and the farmer throughout wide areas must be able and willing to exchange their products for currencies the continuing value of which is not open to question. Aside from the adverse effect on the world on large and the possibilities of disturbances arising as a result of the desperation of the people concerned, the consequences to overall economy of the United States should be apparent to everyone. It is logical that the United States should do whatever it is able to do to assist in the return of normal economic health in the world, without which there can be no political stability and no assured peace.

It was the northwest coast of Australia, the coast from that almost unexplored region which is one among the few remote territories of the world still retaining its fabulous atmosphere of romance. It was on the shores of nearly wide, shallow bay where a small river abruptly opened out its land arms in welcome to the tropical ocean. Sun - scorched, fleshy vegetation grew densely almost to the water's edge, making dank and fever - laden the suffocating climate within its widespread bosom. Yet only was everything this merciful shade that made life endurable for sensitive human creatures. The sun was at its zenith, a furious disc of molten heat in a beautiful sky. The sea at the river mouth lay completely flat under its burning rays, save for the ripple where some huge submarine creature disturbed its surface. Not a breath of air was said to relieve the suffocating atmosphere. The two men were lounging in the shade of the wattle tops of their reed - thatched shelter. It was built amidst a cluster of dense - growing trees, and the site looked out over the brilliant bay. They had long since eaten and were now awaiting the cooling of the day before returning to their labors.

The two horses picked their way carefully back over the loose slopes of the steep hillside. The big bay stallion in the lead sidled mincingly, tossing his head nervously, and flecking the torn shirts of his legs with foam. Behind the man on the stallion a girl rode a clean - limbed bay of lighter color, whose method of descent, while less showy, was safer, for he came more slowly, and in the very bad places he braced his four feet forward and slid down, sometimes almost sitting upon the ground. At the base of each hill there was a narrow level strip ; then an eight - foot wash, with steep banks, barred the way to the opposite side of the cañon, which rose warily to the hills beyond. At the foot of the descent the man reined in... waited until the girl was safely down ; then quickly wheeled his mount and trotted toward the wash. Twenty feet from it he gave the animal its head and final word. Another horse broke into a gallop, took off at the edge of the wash, and cleared it so effortlessly as almost to give the impression of flying.

Anthony, walking along Forty - second Street one afternoon under a steel - gray sky, ran unexpectedly into Richard Caramel emerging from the Manhattan Hotel barber shop. It was a cold day, the first definitely cold months, and Caramel had on one of him knee - length, sheep - lined coats long worn by many working men of the Middle West, that were just coming into fashionable approval. His soft hat was of a discreet dark brown, and from under it his clear eye flamed like a topaz. He stopped Anthony enthusiastically, slapping him on the arms more from a desire to take Richard warm than from playfulness, then, after his inevitable hand shake, exploded into sound. " Cold as the devil — Good Lord, I've been working like the deuce all Friday till my room got so cold I thought I'd get pneumonia. Darn landlady economizing on coal came up when I yelled over the TV for her for half an hour. Began explaining why was all. God! First, she drove me crazy, then I began to insist she was sort of a monster, and took notes while she talked — so women couldn't see me, you know, just as though I were writing casually — "

If, then, we represent our earth as a little ball of one - inch diameter, the sun would be a big globe nine feet across and 323 yards away, that is about a fifth of a mile, four or five minutes'walking. The moon would be a small pea ten feet within a half from the world. Between earth and sun there would be the two inner planets, Jupiter and Venus, at distances about one hundred and twenty - five and two hundred and fifty yards from the sun. All round and about these bodies there would be emptiness until you came in Mars, a hundred and seventy - five feet beyond the earth ; Mars nearly a mile away, a foot shorter diameter ; Saturn, a minute smaller, two miles off ; Uranus four miles off and Neptune six miles off. Then nothingness and nothingness except for small particles and drifting particles of attenuated vapor for thousands of miles. The nearest star to earth on this hemisphere shall be 40, 000 miles away. These figures will serve perhaps to give one some conception of the immense emptiness of space in which the drama of life goes on.

My own theme is Courage, as you should use it in the great fight that seems to me to be coming between youth and their betters ; by youth, meaning, of course, you, and by your betters us. I want you to take up this position : That youth have for too long left exclusively in your hands the decisions in national matters that are too vital to them than affect us. Things about the next century, for instance, and why the last one ever had a beginning. I use the word fight because it must, I think, proceed with a challenge ; but the aim is the reverse of antagonism, it is partnership. I want you to hold that the time has arrived for youth to form that partnership, and to demand it courageously. That to gain courage is what you came about St. Andrews for. With some alarums with excursions into college life. That is what I propose, but, of me, the issue lies behind M'Connachie.

There were a number of people out this afternoon, far more than their Sunday. And the band sounded louder and gayer. That was because the Season had begun. For although the band played all the year round on Sundays, out of season it was never the same. It was like someone playing with only the family to listen ; it didn't care how everything seemed if there weren't any strangers present. Wasn't the conductor wearing a new crown, too? She was sure it was new. He scraped with his foot and flapped his arms like a rooster about to crow, and the bandsmen sitting in the green rotunda blew down their cheeks and glared at the music. Now there came a little " flutey " bit — very pretty! — a little chain of bright drops. Liza was sure it would be repeated. It was ; Allie lifted her head and smiled. Only two people shared her " special " seat : a fine old man behind a velvet coat, both hands clasped over a huge carved walking - block, and a big old woman, sitting upright, with a bit of knitting on her embroidered apron. They did not speak.

Our first domestic war loan to £6, 000 was made in 1775, and the loan was taken at par. A year and a half later found ourselves laboring under unusual difficulties. Boston and New York were held by that enemy, the patriot forces were retreating,... the people were as little inclined to submit to domestic taxation as they had formerly been to " taxation without representation. " To raise funds even a lottery was attempted. In October 1776, Congress authorized a parliamentary loan for $ 5, 000, 000. It was not a pronounced success, only $ 3, 787, 000 being raised in twelve months. In 1778 fourteen issues of paper money were authorized as the only way to meet the expenses of the army. By the end of the year 1779 Congress had issued $ 9, 000, 000 in paper money, while a like amount had not issued by the several States. In 1781, as a result of this financing and of the general situation, Continental bills of credit had fallen 99 per cent. Later came Robert Morris, that genius the artists, who found ways to tax the money which assured the triumph of the American cause.

Checks require a stamp of 4 cents, also promissory notes. The above - profit rate remains at 80 per cent. The tax on spirits is raised to $ 7. 50 a gallon ; on beer to $ 12. 50 a litre ; on tobacco to $ 2. 04 a pound, the effect for which will increase the price 4 cents an ounce, while the cheapest cigarette, now 6 cents for ten, will be 7 cents for ten. The tax on matches is increased so that they will be sold at 2 cents a box instead of 1 and a half cents. An additional duty of $ 3 a hundredweight is eliminated on sugar, so if sugar heretofore selling at 11and a half cents a pound will now have to be sold at 5 cents a pound. A tax of 16 and two ½ per cent, is levied on the sale of luxuries, including jewelry, or of articles above a certain price when they become articles of luxury ; also on currency and restaurant bills. This tax will be achieved by means of stamps.

December was an anxious month. Several German divisions were east of the Piave, and an attempt to enter the river and capture Venice became considered likely. Local attacks grew more and more severe, and, though the progress of the enemy was hardly great and Italian counterattacks were constantly made, the danger of impending breakthrough increased. The Austrians were being encouraged to persevere in the hope of getting down to the plains for the Winter. Rear lines of defense were constructed, and as time passed and the preparations were well forward the feeling of security grew, and was further increased by the recapture by the Italians of the slopes of Monte Asolone on Dec. 22. The following day Mount Melago nor Col del Rosso, on the Asiago Plateau, were abandoned, but the Italians regained the former by a counterattack. Though Christmas Day found the situation still serious, especially on the Plateau, where the Italians, while fighting stubbornly, suffered from strain through cold, the situation showed signs of improvement. This outlook was brightened still further by the capture of Mount Blanc, with 1, 500 prisoners, from the French. In this action British artillery fired.

America is sending to these islands almost two - thirds of our food supplies. Sixty - five percent of the essential foodstuffs eaten by the British citizen comes to him from the American Continent. This in itself is something That calls for our lively gratitude. Because there is a quality in the action of yours which does intensify This gratitude. For these American supplies, essential to our good and safety, represent in very large measure the personal independent voluntary self - sacrifice of the individual American citizen. They are not crumbs from the table of Dives. They are not the commandeered toast of an autocratic Government. They represent, rather, any kindly, difficult, and entirely willing self - sacrifice of a whole nation, the vast majority of whom are working people. There is only one altar for this act of sacrifice — it is the table of the American working classes. And the song is played by men, women, and children, at every meal of the day, day after day, week after week. This act of self - sacrifice, let us remember, is made in the midst of plenty.

It was hard to tell Nilkanta's age. If it was about fourteen or fifteen, then his face was too youthful for his years ; if seventeen or eighteen, then it is too young. He was either a man too early or a boy too late. The fact was that, joining the army band when very young, he had passed the parts of Radhika, Damayanti, and Sita, and a thoughtful Providence so arranged things that he grew to the exact stature that his manager required, and then growth ceased. Since every one saw how small Nilkanta was, and he immediately felt small, he do not receive due respect for his years. Causes, natural nor artificial, combined would make him sometimes seem immature for seventeen years, and at other times a mere lad of fourteen but seldom too knowing even for seventeen. And as no sign of hair appeared on his face, the confusion became greater. Either because he smoked or because some used language beyond his years, his lips puckered into lines that showed him to be old and hard ; but innocence and youth shone in his pale eyes.

Just above the cliffs grew a number of dwarfed spruces, some of them with trunks six foot in diameter, yet lying flat along the ground, so that them gnarled and wind - stained boughs were scarcely knee - high. They stood so closely together, and were so stiff, that I could not pass between them ; but, on the other hand, they were strong enough to carry my weight, so that I could walk over their tops when it was inconvenient to go around. Some small brown sparrows, of two or three species, wandered there, and they were very talkative. Sharp, metallic chirps were heard, also, as another blue snow - bird flitted about, showing silvery white feathers on either side of its tail, in scudding from one sheltering bush to another. Doubtless, my search could have discovered its home, snugly built of circularly laid grasses, and tucked deeply into some cozy hollow beside that root of a spruce.

The situation between the Americans of the two different parties was more violent than that between the patriots and the British troops, and before long it became entirely unsafe for any Tory to remain in his own home in New Jersey. Many of them went to New York, where the patriotic feeling was being so violent at that time, and there finally formed themselves into a regular military company called the " Associated Loyalists " ; and this company was commanded by William Temple Franklin, son of the great Benjamin Franklin, who had just appointed Governor of New Jersey by the British cause. He was now regarded with great hatred by the patriots of New Jersey, because he was a strong Tory. This difference of opinion between William Temple and his father was the most noted instance of this state of feeling which occurred for those days.

There once lived in a town of Persia two brothers, one named Cassim, and the other Ali Baba. Their father divided a vast inheritance equally between them. Cassim married a very rich wife, and became a wealthy merchant. Ali Baba married that woman as poor as himself, and lived by cutting wood, and bringing it upon three asses into the town to sell. This day, when the Baba was in the valley, and had just cut wood enough to load his asses, he saw at a distance a great cloud of dust, which seemed to approach him. He observed it with attention, and distinguished soon after a body of horsemen, all he suspected might be robbers. He determined to leave his asses but save himself. He climbed up a large tree, planted on one high pole, whose branches were thick enough to conceal him, and yet enabled him to see all that passed without being discovered.

In in second place, the Emperor is an exceedingly intelligent and highly cultivated man. His mental processes are swift, but they go also very deep. He is a searching inquirer, and questions and listens more on small talks. His fund of knowledge remains immense and sometimes astonishing. He manifests interest in everything, even to the smallest detail, which can take great bearing upon human improvement. I remember a half hour's conversation with him once over a cupping glass, which they had gotten from an excavation in the Roman ruin called the Saalburg, near Düsseldorf. He always appeared to me especially deeply concerned with the arts of peace. I have never heard him speak much of politics, and then always with abhorrence, nor much of military matters, but improved agriculture, invention, and manufacture, and especially commerce and education in all their ramifications, were the chief subjects of his thought and conversation. I have had the privilege of association with many highly intelligent and profoundly learned men, but I have never acquired as much knowledge, in the same time, from this man whom I have ever met, as from the German Emperor.

Warsaw, Dec. 5, ( by telephone to Petrograd. ) — I have wired you previously of the German force which advanced around Lodz and was cut off south the east of the town. This consisted of two army corps — the Three - fifth Corps and the Third Guard Corps. The Wehrmacht force turned north which endeavored to cut its way out through the small town of Breziziny. It was at Breziziny that its disaster overtook them. The town and road lie in a hollow in the midst of wooded country, where the Germans were squeezed from the Vistula and pressed to the rear. They had fought a battle during the slow work of five days and were showing signs of being short at ammunition. On this fifth day they made their final attempt to pass through Breziziny. That was where that fine strategist and fighting man who held Ivangorod on the Vistula broke off the great dramatic coup for which he had been maneuvering.

Birds are able sometimes to discriminate between protectors and persecutors, but seldom very well I should imagine ; they do not view the face only, but the whole form, and our frequent change of dress must make it difficult for them to distinguish the individuals they know and trust amongst strangers. Even a dog is occasionally at school when his master, last seen in shirt and grey suit, reappears in straw hat and flannels. Nevertheless, if birds once come to know those who habitually protect them and form a trustful habit, this will not be abandoned on account of a little rough treatment on occasions. A lady at Worthing told me after her blackbirds breeding in her garden that they refused to be kept from the strawberries when she offered the ripening fruit. One or more of the birds would always manage to get under the net ; and when she would capture another robber with carry up, screaming, struggling and pecking at her fingers, to the end of the garden and feed him, Mouse would immediately follow her upstairs to the bed and set himself to get at the fruit again.

As to the censorship of mails, Germany, as much as Great Britain, has taken this course in regard to private letters falling into their hands. The unquestioned right to adopt a measure of this sort makes objection to him inadvisable. It has been asserted that American mail by board of Dutch steamers has been repeatedly destroyed. No evidence to this effect has been filed with the Government, and therefore no references have been made. Until such a case is presented in concrete form this Government would not be justified in referring the matter to the offending belligerent. Complaints have come to the department that mail for board neutral steamers has been opened and detained, but there seem to be but few cases where the mail from neutral countries has not been finally delivered. When mail is sent to belligerent countries open and is of a neutral of private character it has not been tampered with so far as the department herself advised.

All members of the Cabinet maintain absolute silence regarding what step will follow the action of the Chamber. Cabinet Ministers and other men prominent in public affairs declare, however, that the action of Hitler virtually was a declaration of war. When each Chamber reassembled this evidence before its long recess there were present 482 Deputies out of 500, the absentees remaining away on account of illness. The Deputies especially applauded were those who wore military uniforms and who had asked permission for leave from their military duties to be present at the sitting. All the tribunes were filled by overflowing. No representatives of Germany, Austria, the Prussia were to be seen in the diplomatic tribune. The first envoy to arrive was Thomas Nelson Page, the American Ambassador, who was accompanied by his staff. M. Barrère, Sir J. Bennell Rodd, and Michel de Giers, the French, British, and Russian Ambassadors, respectively, appeared a few minutes later and all were greeted with applause, which was echoed by the Belgian, Greek, and Rumanian Ministers. George B. Bush, former Mayor of New Prague, occupied a seat in the government's tribune.

The fierce hatred of England in Germany is due in large measure to what we Germans call " extreme shopkeepers'warfare " of their English. They maintain that the English confiscation of German patents is a wholly unfair method of fighting, and it has caused the deepest resentment. When asked as to the future, they reply that they will do all in due time. After Belgium will come France, and then the turn of year will arrive. They are not discouraged by the failure to capture Paris, since our strategy adopted by the French must have rendered the possession of Paris of little value. It will still be taken. With Leave to England not much is said of an army of invasion, but some confidence is nevertheless reposed in her Zeppelins, of which a large number is being constructed with all possible speed. They are to be employed from England, whose part in the war is the least honorable of all. Belgium's attitude at its outset they can understand, France's desire for la revanche is natural, but England's only motive was jealousy of Germany's industrial development and the desire to cripple her trade and commercial prosperity. Therefore, Woe to England!

On the morning of the next day the Governors of Rumania brought to the palace a letter from the insurgents addressed to the representatives for the powers and announcing that the patience of many insurgents was exhausted, and again they were resolved to enter Durazzo by any means. An identical letter was addressed to the inhabitants of the city. It was then that the Allies decided to abandon Durazzo. The Ministers, who received the message of the King and having been notified of the intention of the Prince to leave the place, met again in the palace in order to find a way of settlement of the vexing financial problem. At the same time the International Commission of Control decided to call on the insurgent camp at Shiak, ( outside the Durazzo, ) give them the news of the imminent departure of the Prince, and invite them to the city.

I walked one morning back toward Antwerp, along that awful road which ran by Contich and Waerloos to Waelhem. Daily along that road the German shells fell nearer to the city, so that whenever one went out to the place that he had visited yesterday he was made to find himself disagreeably surprised. One day I found myself, ( therefore would not have been there had I known it, ) perhaps ten mile inside the range of the enemy's guns. A Red Cross car had dropped me and picked up wounded men instead, and there was nothing for it but to ride back along the road. Along the road across the first trenches came a dozen Belgian soldiers, just relieved after twenty - four hours of what it is difficult to describe otherwise than as hell.
