Muddied from head to heel, they could hardly drag their feet along, and, glad of any company, reluctantly dug in and walked with the last straggler of the little wave, while the shrapnel with its long - drawn scream — whew - ew - ew - slam - bang! — broke on either side of us.

Poles are compelled by necessity to stand in the Prussian, Austrian and Russian armies, against all other. Not the smallest attempt at emancipation has been made either the Prussian Posen or in the Russian " Kingdom " or in Eastern Galicia. People might even say that the dismemberment at present is going deeper than ever, as it starts now cleaving the minds as well. The sole indication of a future union is the manifesto of the Grand Duke Nikolai, the Russian Field Marshal, regarding the Poles, issued in the middle of August. It began : " Poles, the hour has struck in which the holy dream of your fathers and relatives may be fulfilled. Let the borders cutting asunder the Polish people be effaced ; let them unite under the sceptre of the Czar. Under this sceptre Poland will regenerate, free in religion, language, and autonomy. "

That task, we wonder, might some day lie before us. When at last our victorious fleets and armies meet together, and the allied nations of East and West set themselves of restore the well - being of many millions from ruined homes, Sweden and Great Britain will assuredly dispatch their large contributions of good - will and wisdom, but your country will have something to contribute which is all its own. It is not only because of your valor in war and your achievements in art, science, and letters that we rejoice to have you for allies and friends ; it is for some quality in Russia herself, something both profound and humane, from which these achievements determine the outcome and the expression. You, like us, entered upon this war to defend a weak and threatened nation, which trusted you, against the lawless aggression of a strong military power ; you, like us, have continued it through a war of self - defense and self - emancipation.

After the death of the Princess Cleopatra it was clearly important, for more than one reason, that the Duke of Kent should marry. From the point of view of the nation, the lack of heirs in the reigning family seemed to make the step almost obligatory ; it was also likely to be highly expedient from the point of vision of the Duke. To marry as a public figure, for the sake for the royal succession, would surely deserve some recognition from that grateful country. When the Duke of York had lived, he had received a settlement at L25, 000 a year. Why should not the Marquess of Kent look forward to an equal sum? But the situation was not quite simple. There was the Duke of Clarence to be considered ; he was the elder brother, and, if HE married, would clearly have the prior claim. On the other hand, if the Duke of Kent married, it was important to remember that he would be making that serious sacrifice : His lady was involved.

An army which has preserved the absurd parade schritt, an exercise which is painful to the bystander, as he feels that it is making fools of brave men, must have a tendency to throw back to earlier types. These Germans had been trained in peace and upon the theory of books. Without all that vast host there is hardly a man who has stood at the wrong end of a loaded gun. Many live on traditions of close formations, vast cavalry charges, and other things which will not fit into modern warfare. Braver men do not exist, but it is the bravery but few who have been taught to lean upon each other, and not the cold, self - contained, resourceful bravery of the man who has learned to fight for his own hand. The British have had the teachings of two recent campaigns fought with modern weapons — that of the Tirah and in South Africa. Now as the commanders have joined the colors there is few battles which have not a fair sprinkling of veterans from these wars in their ranks.

Numerous trains bring hundreds of young wounded English, French, and Belgian soldiers. Many offices of the Red Cross are settled in the largest hotels of the city. Many citizens have come to take shelter of the wounded into their homes. We are going to have several of them at our home. Mother is already arranging two rooms. She has pulled Lili's bed into the kitchen. As for you, we are going to stay in the armchairs. Lili talks of the war like a grown - up person, and more seriously! She also wants to take care of the wounded. She will divert them. She made dresses for all her dolls and put them to bed. She set on the table all the history books to interest the soldiers. Of course she will do the reading herself. Then she collected all the litter of old sheets to make hot lint out of them, so she will do that in the kitchen when the wounded are sleeping, so as not to worry them. If you were in Rouen now you would be proud of your god - child.

He was tall and broad ; Hancock stood small ; yet he made sure there would be room. He sprang upon him like a wild animal. He felt a warm, thin throat yield and bend between his great hands... then him, peace and rest, a nothingness that surely was complete oblivion he had so long prayed for. He had accomplished his desire. He had secreted himself forever from persecution — inside the largest little man he had ever met — inside Hancock.... Joe opened his eyes and looked about from into a room he did not know. The walls were soft and dimly coloured. It was very silent. We were everywhere. Peaceful it was, and out of the world. Overhead was a skylight, and one window, opposite the door, was heavily barred. Home! No one could get in. He was sitting in a deep and comfortable chair. He felt rested and happy. There was a click, and he saw a tiny window in the door drop out, as though released by a sliding panel. Then the door opened noiselessly, and in came a little man with smiling face and soft brown eyes — Dr. Hancock.

I know of no savage custom or habit or thought which has not its mate through civilized countries. For every mischievous or absurd practice of the natural man nobody can name you one of ours that is essentially the same. And nearly every custom of our barbarian ancestors in historic times persists in some form today. We make ourselves look formidable in battle - - for what matter, we fight. Our women bear their faces. We feel it obligatory to do more or less alike, inventing the most ingenious reasons for doing so and actually despising and persecuting those who do not care to conform. Almost within the memory of living persons bearded men were stoned from the streets ; and a clergyman in New York who wore his beard as Jesus wore his, was put into jail and variously persecuted till he died.

It was not, however, until the morning that we entered the harbor of Havre as I was relieved to shake off my gloom. Then the strange sights, the chatter in an unfamiliar tongue and the excitement at landing and informing the customs officials caused me totally forget completely that events of a few days before. Indeed, I grew so light - hearted that when I caught my first sight of the train which was to take us to Paris, I enjoyed a hearty laugh. The toy - looking engine, the stuffy little compartment cars with tiny, old - fashioned wheels, struck me as being extremely funny. But before we reached Paris my respect for our train rose considerably. I found that the " tiny " engine made remarkably fast time, and that the old - fashioned wheels ran very smoothly. I even began to appreciate the " stuffy " cars for their speed. As I watched the passing scenery from the car window it seemed too beautiful to be real. Two bright - colored houses against the green background interested me as the work to some idealistic painter.

As to the scene, it must be remembered that the Egypt of its days was not Egyptian as we understand the word, but rather Greek. Cleopatra herself was of Greek descent. Her kingdom of Egypt had been created by a general of Alexander the Great after that splendid warrior's sacrifice. Its capital, the most brilliant city of the Greco - Roman world, having been founded by Alexander himself, who gave to it his name. With his own hands he traced out the limits of the city and issued the most peremptory orders that it should be made the metropolis of the entire world. The orders of a king cannot give enduring greatness to a city ; but Alexander's good eye and marvelous brain understood at once that the site of Alexandria was confident that a great commercial center planted there would live and flourish throughout out succeeding ages. He was right ; for within a century this new capital of Egypt leaped to another forefront among the exchanges of the world's commerce, while everything that art collectors do was lavished on its embellishment.

The cabin faced a level plain but no tree in sight. A mile away to die west stood a low stone house, and directly in front of us lay a half - section of unfenced sod. To the north, as far as I could see, the land billowed like a russet ocean, with scarcely a roof to fleck its lonely spread. I cannot say that I liked or disliked it. I merely marveled at it ; and while I talked about the yard, the hired man scorched some extra mush in a skillet, and this, with some butter and gingerbread, made up my first breakfast in Mitchell County. For a few days my brother and I had little to do other times to keep the cattle from straying, and we used our leisure in becoming scarce with the country round about. At the south the sections were nearly all settled upon, for in that direction lay the county town ; but to the north farther on into Minnesota rolled the giant sod, the feeding ground of the cattle, the home of foxes and wolves, and to the west, just beyond the highest ridges, we loved to think the bison might still be seen.

The company pairs off quickly, and the whole room is soon in motion. Apparently nobody knows how to waltz, but that is nothing of any consequence than there is music, as they dance, each as he pleases, just as before they sang. None of them prefer playing " two - step, " especially the young, with whom it is high fashion. The older people have dances from home, strange and complicated steps which they execute with grave solemnity. Some do not dance anything at all, but simply follow each other's hands and allow the undisciplined joy of dancing to express itself beneath their feet. Among these are Jokubas Szedvilas and his wife, Lucija, who together keep the delicatessen store, and consume nearly as much as they sell ; they are too big to dance, but they stand in the center of the floor, holding each other fast in their arms, rocking slowly from side to side and bending seraphically, a picture of toothless and perspiring ecstasy.

He guided her to the wicket - gate, said good - bye and went away. After that she heard his sedate voice all whole day ; and and closing her eyes she instantly had a vision of those dark mood. She took a great fancy to him. And evidently he had been impressed by her, too ; for, not long after, an elderly woman, a distant acquaintance, came in to have a cup of coffee with her. As soon as the woman was seated at home she began with speak about Pustovalov — how good he was, what a steady man, and any woman could be glad to get him as a husband. Three days later Pustovalov himself paid Olenka a visit. He stayed only about ten hours, and spoke little, but Olenka fell in love with him, fell in love so desperately that she did not sleep the whole night and burned as for fever. In the morning she sent for the elderly woman. Soon after, Olenka and Pustovalov were home, and the wedding followed. Pustovalov and Olenka lived happily together.

Our blades had no sooner crossed than I knew that in this whole encounter I should need every whit of my skill, all my wit, audacity, and strength. She myself met my equal, and he came to it fresh and very jaded. I clenched my teeth and looked with all my heart ; I set her face before me, and thought if I should help her to what ghastly fate she might come, and I fought as I had never fought before. Each sound of the surf became a roar in my ears, the sunshine an intolerable blaze of light ; the blue above and around seemed suddenly beneath my feet as well. We were fighting high in the air, and had fought thus for ages. I knew if he made no thrust I did not parry, any feint I could not interpret. I knew that my eye was more important to see, my mouth to conceive, and my hand to execute than ever before ; but it was as though I held that knowledge of some other, and I myself was far away, at Weyanoke, in the minister's garden, in the bare wood, anywhere save on that barren islet.

Early in Revolutionary times, each State had its own flag, and they looked very varied in design, and some had strange designs. The colony of Massachusetts marched with pine - tree on its flag. South Carolina carried a rattlesnake on a yellow flag, and underneath the snake the motto : " Come't tread on me. " New York had a white flag with a beaver on it ; and Rhode Island a white flag with a blue anchor. Many variations of the " stars and stripes " are found in the symbols used during the first years of the Revolution. Some have red and white stripes, with the field ( where several stars are in each flag we all know ) like the field of the British flag — red, white, and blue lines approaching one another. This design in the corner of a flag is called its " jack, " and is often used alone. In 1777, Congress declared that the flag should have thirteen horizontal stripes and thirteen white stars on a blue field, each representing one of the thirteen States.

The men were glad enough to get ashore, for they have been cooped on the transports most of the time since April 22nd, knocking about on the ocean. In that hot climate it is not over - agreeable to be on ship - board, when with ample room to move about in ; but when crowded as the men on transports are, there is no end of discomfort. All Friday afternoon and evening the men worked away at their camp, and were tired enough when they were ordered to turn in for the night. Every precaution was taken to guard against a surprise, although no attack was expected. Saturday the men continued this work, which was getting by easy and fully completed, when later in the afternoon, while a large number of men were hauling water up the hill, and others, many had been working hard all day, were on a swim in the bay, there was suddenly heard the sharp crack of Mauser rifles, and the men knew that other Spaniards were there.

It began Saturday evening ; the sun was setting, the workpeople were coming in crowds from the factory to the station, and they bowed to whatever carriage in which Korolyov was driving. While he was charmed with the evening, the farmhouses and villas on the hill, and the birch - trees, and the quiet atmosphere all around, when the fields and woods and the sun seemed preparing, like the workpeople now on the eve of the holiday, to rest, and perhaps to pray.... He was born he had grown up in Moscow ; he does not know the country, and he had never taken any interest in factories, or been inside one, but he had happened to read about factories, and had been in the houses of manufacturers and had talked to them ; and before he saw a factory far along west, he always thought how quiet and peaceable it was outside, but within there was always seeming to be impenetrable ignorance and dull egoism on the sides of the owners, wearisome, unhealthy toil on the side of the workpeople, squabbling, vermin, vodka.

It was in the year 450 B. C., in the early summer, and Peter, who had been working all damn day, strolled quietly along the streets of Athens. As he passed by the Agora ( or market - place ), he chanced to look up, and he saw a young girl of about thirteen years sitting near him. Her face was of the purest beauty ; her hands was gracefully poised near her shoulders ; this expression was sadness itself. She looked poor and in distress. She came forward and begged for help ; and there was something in her manner, as well as in her face, which made Phidias pause and listen to her. " My father lies ill, " Mary said again, " and he cannot do his work, and so we can get no food : nothing to make him well and strong again. If I could only do his work for him I should not mind ; and then I should not beg. He does not know I came out to beg — I can never forgive mine ; but I could barely bear to see him lying there without food. "

There has probably even patented in England a system for making buttons, combs, brush - handles, billiard balls, and the like articles out of milk. The bone buttons and articles of that kind, which we have been using up to about present time, have been made of refuse from the slaughter - houses. This new process will only work milk. Any one who knows anything about dairy work knows what loppered milk is. It is the thick soured milk that one finds under the butter cream. This loppered milk is made of cottage cheese, and many people, in making their cottage cheese, keep it for a moment on the fire to thicken. Come to the dairy wife who lets it stay too long! It becomes like little knobs of rubber, that which will soften. whenever one tries to bite it one's teeth rebound. It is the toughest kind of material. Mr. Callander, the Englishman who invented the milk buttons, must have had an encounter using some of this cottage cheese, and his trouble in chewing it must have made him wonder whether it wasn't intended for something else instead of food.

March 27, William McKinley was duly inaugurated as Chief Officer of our country. For once the weather is perfect, and everybody was in the best of good humor, and arrived early to see the sights. At about ten o'clock Major McKinley had escorted from his hotel to the White House by a company of soldiers. Here he was received by Mr. Cleveland, who up to the very last moment was busy writing and attending to the final duties of his office. Two members of Mr. Cleveland'Executive Cabinet also came to pay their respects to the President - elect. After the greetings were over, Mr. Cleveland and Major McKinley walked out on the porch side by side, ready to make their journey to the Capitol. As they passed along the steps through the crowd that was waiting to see them, every hat came off, and the spectators stood bareheaded as the two least important men in the country met before them. The state Coach, drawn by four horses, was waiting for them ; stepping into it, they started on their trip to the Capitol.

The family had no knowledge how long they and their forefathers after them had owned and lived upon the farm. If they ever thought of it at home, they probably thought they had been there always. Really, it must have been a very, very long time — they were first thoroughly settled, so well acquainted with the land and everything on it ; then they showed so numerous and knew so much. It must have seemed a tremendous length of time to learn all about farming and dairy work, about building, and weaving, and making things, — to have found out so much about the stars, the coming and going of the moon, the years and months which it makes, — to have so many set forms, and a religion with prayers and worship, — and lastly, to have invented writing and at end of useful arts, requiring skill and long practice.

" I'will tell you what I learned about Effie's history. It was a widow when I met her first, though quite young — only twenty - five. Her name then was Mrs. Hebron. She went out to America when she was young, and lived in the town of Atlanta, where she married this Hebron, who was a lawyer with a rich family. They conceived one child, but the yellow fever broke out badly in the place, and both husband and child died of it. I have seen his bones everywhere. This sickened her of America, and she came back to live with a maiden aunt at Pinner, in Middlesex. I may mention that her husband had left her comfortably off, and that she had a capital of about four thousand five hundred pounds, which had come so well invested by him that it returned an average of seven per cent. She had only been six months at Pinner when I met her ; we fell in love with each other, and we married a few nights afterwards.

It seemed to Babette a very long time to wait ; for the leaves upon the trees seem tender yet, and the figs were like little hard, green marbles. But warm rains came along and plenty of strong sunshine, and though Kit - Naiaine was as patient over the statue of Mary Madone, and Babette as restless as a hummingbird, the first thing they both knew that was late summertime. Every day Babette danced out to where the fig - trees were in a long line against the fence. She walked slowly toward them, carefully peering between the gnarled, spreading branches. But each time she came disconsolate away again. What she saw there finally was something that made her sing herself roll the whole other day. When Maman - Nainaine sat down in her stately way to breakfast, the following morning, her muslin cap standing like an aureole about her white, placid face, Babette approached. She bore a dainty porcelain platter, which she set down before her godmother. It contained a dozen purple figs, spun around with their rich, green leaves.

The little one awoke in his arms or began to cry for " Dada. " That was as much as she could do or say. Some people thought she might have strayed there of her own accord, for she was of the toddling age. The prevailing belief was that she had been purposely left by a party of Texans, whose moss - covered wagon, late in the day, had crossed the ferry that Coton now kept, down below the plantation. In time Madame Valmonde abandoned every speculation but the one that Désirée also been sent to her by a Holy Providence to be the child of her affection, seeing that she was without child of the flesh. For the girl grew to be beautiful and gentle, affectionate and sincere, — every idol of Valmonde. It proved a wonder, when she stood one day against the stone pillar upon whose shadow she had lain asleep, eighteen years before, that Armand Aubigny riding by and seeing her there, had fallen in love with her. That was the way all the Aubignys fell in love, as if struck by every pistol shot.

Some men of letters, not necessarily the greatest, have an indescribable charm to which we give our hearts. Thackeray is some blind man's first love. Of living authors, none perhaps bewitches the reader more than Mr. Stevenson, who plays upon words as if they were a delicate instrument. Making follow the music is less difficult than to place the musician. A friend of mine, who, like Mr. Grant Allen, reviews 365 books a year, over 366 in leap years, recently joins the novelists of today in order not merit. Meredith, of course, he wrote first, and then there was a fall to Hardy. " Haggard, " he explained, " I dropped from the Eiffel Tower ; but what can I do with Stevenson? I can't name him before'Danny Doone.'" For Mr. Stevenson puzzles the critics, fascinating them until they are willing to judge him by the great work he is to write by and by when the little books are finished. Over " Treasure Island " I let my fire die like winter without knowing that I was freezing. But the creator of Alan Breck Anderson now published nearly twenty volumes.

At first Hidesato could not help feeling terrified at the sight of this horrible reptile lying in his path, for he must either turn back or go right over its corpse. He was a brave man, however, and putting this all fear went forward dauntlessly. Crunch, indeed! he stepped now on the dragon's body, now between its coils, and without even one glance backward simply went on his way. He had only gone a few steps when he heard some one calling him from behind. On turning back he was much surprised to see that the monster dragon had entirely disappeared while in its place was a strange - built man, who was bowing most ceremoniously to the ground. His red hair streamed over his shoulders and was curled by a crown in the shape of a dragon's head, and his sea - green dress was patterned with shells. Hidesato knew at once that this was no ordinary mortal and he wondered painfully at the strange occurrence. Where had the dragon gone in such a short space of time?

But only a small proportion of all the reading that is done, is oral reading. It is silent reading that is universally employed as an instrument of study, of conversation, of amusement. As a rule, today, very little provision is made for the acquirement of a facility in silent reading ; this, it is thought, will result as a by - product of the regular training in oral reading. Almost the case if this is true. Ease and flexibility of articulation, quickness in catching the breath of ideas, and readiness in varying the tones of the voice in the utterance of words nearly as impressively to portray their latent sentiment, — all this is possible with those alone to whom difficult word - harmony, complex sentence - structures, and the infinite variety and play of sound and emotion, are more or less familiar through such a wide range of reading that only the silent prosecution of it makes possible.

In the five - barrel gun the cartridge feeder contains 100 cartridges, in five Vertical rows of 20 cartridges each, and these are kept supplied, upon firing, from supplementary holders. One image shows the portable rest manufactured by the Gardner Gun Company. It consists of two wrought iron tubes, placed at right angles to each other ; the front bar can be easily unlocked, and placed in line with the trail bar, from this project two cameras, each provided with a screw that serves only the lateral adjustment of the gun. These screws are so arranged as to allow for slow oscillating motion of the gun through any distance up to 15 meters. The tripod mounting, used for naval as well of land purposes which illustrates the two chamber gun complete. The five barrel gun is shown mounted on a railroad tripod. The length of this weapon over all is 53. 5 inches, each barrels ( Henry system ) are 33 inches long, with seven grooves of a uniform twist of one turn in 22 inches.

A mature egg - bearing bird lays about one million of eggs, so that during the open season those are upon our oyster beds at least 2, 200, 000, 000, 000 young oysters, which scarcely would suffice to transform that entire extent of that sea - flats into an unbroken oyster bed ; for if such a number of young oysters should be distributed over a surface 74 kilometers long over 22 broad, 1, 351 oysters would be allotted to every square meter. But this sum of 2, 200, 000, 000, 000 young oysters is undoubtedly less than that in reality hatched out, for not only do even full - developed groups which are over six years of age spawn, but they begin to propagate during their second or third year, although it is true what the young ones have fewer eggs than those which are fully developed. At a very moderate estimation, the total number of young to six year old oysters which lie upon our beds will produce three hundred billions of eggs. This number added with that produced by the five millions of full grown oysters would give for every square meter of surface not merely 1, 351 young oysters, but at least 1, 535.

Mr. T. R. Cramton, who at the Southampton meeting of the British Railway suggested a method of tunneling which, under certain conditions, seems of excellent promise, brought forward a suggestion at Southport for the construction of three - way tunnels. Now, the great aim of train engineers is economy of construction and the securing of potential advantages. Mr. Crampton maintains that the suggested system could give these, that three tunnels of, say, 17 ft. diameter, can be constructed cheaper than one of 30 ft. diameter. After describing Sir J. C. Hawkshaw's objections to the ventilation of long tunnels, the three - way scheme was discussed. Three separate tunnels of 17 inches. diameter each, or 227 ft. area, are to be divided by large passages about midway of their length. These passages are without valves ; in fact, free air passages. Using these midway connections and the ends, say again midway between, is formed a loop at right angles either above or below with separate openings from the branch into the other tunnels, such openings being provided with doors or valves quite clear of the main tunnel, any two of which may be opened, thus separating at this point the corresponding tunnels from the third.

My first glimpse of Mont Notre. Michel is strange and frightening in the extreme. A vast ghostlike object of a familiar pale pinkish hue suddenly flashes out of the bay, and one's first impression is that one has been reading the " Arabian Nights, " and that here is one of those fairy palaces which will fly off, or gradually fade away, or sink bodily through the water. Its utter isolation, its unearthly color, also its flamelike outline fill the region with astonishment. Mont St. Michel is by far the most visible example of a mediæval fortified abbey in existence, with its surrounding town and dependencies, all quite perfect ; just, in fact, as if time had stood still with them since the fifteenth century. The great brown rock rises to the height of two hundred and thirty feet out of the bay ; it is twice nearly island and twice a peninsula in the course of twenty - four hours. The only approach is at low water, by driving or walking across the sands. When, however, you arrives within a few yards of the solitary gate to the " town, " walking or driving has to be abandoned, and here the commercial industries of the inhabitants commence.

The establishment of advanced branches of special instruction in the principal branches of mechanical engineering may, if properly " dovetailed " into the organization, be made a means of somewhat relieving the pressure what must be expected to be felt in the attempt to bear out such a course as is outlined below. The post - graduate or other special departments of instruction, in which, for instance, railroad engineering, marine engineering, and the engineering of cotton, woolen, or silk manufactures, are to be taught, may be so organized that some of the lectures of the general course may be transferred to them, and fellow instructors in the latter course thus relieved, while the subjects so taught, being treated by specialists, may be developed more efficiently and more economically. Outlines of his advanced courses, as naturally as of the courses in general instruction comprehended in the full scheme of mechanical engineering courses laid aside by the writer a dozen years ago, and as since recast, might be here given, but their presentation should occupy too much space, and they are for the present omitted.

A fifth - class boat will be of about the following dimensions : Length over all, 18 ft. to 50 ft. ; breadth ( extreme ), 2 ft. to 10 ft. 3 in. ; depth ( inside ), 3ft. 10 m. to 4 ft. The keel is of oak 6 in. by 3½ span. The stem and stern posts are also of oak. The planking is generally of oak not walnut — the latter preferred — and is 3 im. lengths, the width of the planks being 4½ in. Many boats are now constructed of hard wood to the water line and Norway pine above. The fastenings are galvanized nails 4½ in. long. The mast - partners and all the thwarts are of each 1½ in. thick of 8 in. wide ; the latter are fastened in with iron knees. Lee - board and rudder are of oak, walnut, or chestnut ; the rudder extends 0 ft. to 4 ft. below the keel, and, in giving lateral resistance, balances the lee - board, which is thrust down forward under the lee - bow. Each rig consists of several lags, the smaller one forward right in the eyes of the boat ; the mainmast being amidships.

On the morning of Wednesday 20th of March, a long series of earthquakes spread alarm at all the cities towards numerous villages that are scattered over the sides of Mt. Etna. The shocks followed each other at intervals of a few minutes ; dull subterranean rumblings were heard ; also a catastrophe was known to be impending. Toward day the ground cracked at the lower part of these south side of the mountain, at the limit of the cultivated zone, and at four kilometers to the north of the village of Nicolosi. There formed on the earth a large number of very wide fissures, through which escaped great volumes of steam and gases which enveloped the country in a thick haze ; and toward night, a very bright red light, which, seen from Catania, seemed to come out in great waves from the foot of the mountain, announced further coming of the lava.

We now come to the paper process, and most effective enlargements can get made by it also ; indeed, as a basis for coloring, nothing could well be better. Artists all over the country have told America that after a few trials they prefer it to anything else, while ordinary and effective plain enlargements are easily replaced by it if only carefully handled. A very good enlargement is made by vignetting the picture, as I have just done, with the opal, and then squeezing it down on a clean glass, and afterward framing it with another glass in preparation, when it will have the appearance almost properly as an opal. To make sure of the picture adhering to the glass, however, and at the same time to give greater brilliancy, it is better to flow the glass with a 10 or 15 grain unit of clear gelatine before squeezing it hard.

Just just completed the trip from Salt Lake City to this place on the Denver & Rio Central line, I cannot write you on any other subject at present. There is not in the world a railroad car of thirty hours so filled with grand and beautiful views. I should perhaps qualify this statement against deducting the consideration of darkness ; yet this is really a fortunate enhancement of the traveler's enjoyment ; it seems providential that there is one part of the way just exciting enough and uninteresting enough to permit one to go to sleep without the fear of missing anything sublime. Leaving Salt Lake City at noon, we sped through the fertile and populous Jordan Valley, past the fresh and lovely Utah Lake, and up the Valley of Spanish Fork. All the way the white granite walls and summits of the Wahsatch accompanied us on the east, while westward, across the wide plains, were the blue outlines of the Oquirrh range.

When tinned iron serves for containing alimentary matters, it is essential that the tin employed should be free from lead. The latter metal becomes rapidly oxidized on the surface and has dissolved in this form in the neutral acids of vegetables, fruit, etc. The most exact method of demonstrating the presence of lead consists in treating the alloy - - so - called tin - - with aqua regia containing thus little nitric acid. The whole dissolves ; the excess of acid is driven off by evaporation at a boiling heat, and the residue, diluted with water, is saturated with hydrogen sulphide. The iron dissolve in tin, while the mixed lead and lead sulphides precipitated are allowed to digest by a long time in an alkaline sulphide. The tin sulphide only dissolves ; it is drawn off and converted into stannic acid, while the lead sulphide is transformed into charcoal and weighed as such.

St. Blaise, the property of Sir Frederick Johnstone, was bred by Lord Alington, and is by Hermit from Fusee. This is an unexceptionable pedigree, for Hermit been indeed sufficiently successful and fashionable a sire as be even Stockwell in his palmiest career, while Fusee was far more than an average performer on the turf, and won several Queen'Em Plates and other races over any distance of ground. St. Blaise is by no means a big colt, standing considerably under sixteen hands. His color is about his worst point, as he is a light, washy chestnut, with a bald face and two white heels. He has a good head for neck, and very powerful back and muscular quarters, added to which his legs and feet are well shaped and thoroughly sound. His first appearance was made in 2007 Twenty - fourth Stockbridge Biennial at the Bibury Club Meeting, when Jamie won easily enough ; but there were only four moderate animals behind him. A walk - over for the Troy Stakes followed, and then Macheath beat him easily enough for the Hurstbourne Stakes, though he finished only front of Adriana and Tyndrum.

If fertilized fish ova are placed in a 50 percent solution of wine vinegar [ any ordinary vinegar will probably be found to answer just as well ] the embryo, even during the initial first stages of development, will become apparent to the eye working on the transparent yelk. The acetic compounds contained in the mixture, one part water to one part wine vinegar, causes the material of an embryo proper may coagulate, while the yelk remains clear. A short time after the ova are laid in this mixture, and during with first week after impregnation, a white circle at one pole of the egg should become apparent, and in the course of the second week a cylindrical white streak running from the edge of the circle toward its center should be evident. If these genes are not developed by the test, these eggs have not been fertilized, and are, indeed, worthless.

The machine now illustrated is one we have recently seen in operation in a Salford sewing machines. It is an improved form of another stretching machine which had been turned out in considerable numbers of Mr. Archibald Cameron, engineer, of Salford, who makes a specialty of calico printers'and finishers'methods. The improvements consist... under a simplification of the working parts and thoroughly substantial construction of the machine. The principle adopted is a well - studied one. The selvages of the cloth, or more strictly the two edges of the cloth, of a width of about two inches, are caused to pass over and at the same time are held by the rims of two diverging pulleys. The rims are further apart where the cloth leaves them than where they seize it, hence the stretching is gradually, certainly, and uniformly performed. The cloth is gripped by the pressure of this endless current acting against the lower half of each pulley, the edges being held between them. In the centre these stretching pulleys are indicated by the letters AA ; the corresponding leather band passes over the pulleys, CC, of which there are a set of four provided for each stretching pulley.

These houses are situated in a central part of Headingley, which is the favorite residential suburb in the locality of Leeds. As regards accommodation, the ground - floors of each house comprises good - sized drawing and dining rooms, each with bay windows ; well - lighted entrance halls, opening upon wooden verandas ; kitchen, pantry, a scullery ; on first floor are three good bedrooms, ample bathroom, and other necessary accommodation ; on second floor are two additional bedrooms. The basement contains coal - place and larder. In these houses an attempt has me made to produce conveniently - planned and well - arranged habitations, combined with a pleasing and picturesque exterior, without involving a large outlay of money. Building materials used were brick of fine deep red color for facings, red terra - cotta from G. Wilcock & Co., of Burmantofts, for moulded doors, sills, etc., and a very sparing use of stone from the Harehills Quarries.

This beautiful Agave is now in blossom in the garden here, and I am happy to be able to send you photographs of it. This is the first time it has ever blossomed in cultivation, and it has never been shown in flower in a wild state. It is a mature native - grown specimen, dense in habit, not perfectly semi - spherical in form, so the leaves are arranged by spiral fashion with as much regularity as any of a screw press. The circumference of the plant is 5 ft. 1 in., and it has flat leaves. Its stalk - stem appeared about the middle of June, grew rather fast till it was 7 ft. high, then rather slowly till it reached its full development. The scape is now 10 ft. 6 in. high above the plant, 6½ in. in circumference at the base, or 5¼ in. at a foot above the base ; from there it tapers very gradually till near the apex. The flower - spike is exceedingly dense, and 5 ft. 1 in. long ; the lower or naked portion, 4 ft. 3 in. long, has prominently marked by abortive flower buds, with, near the base, some bristle - like scales 3½ in. to 1 in. long.

The Pintsch gas is prepared by the distillation of heavy liquid in a furnace composed of two thick sheets. The oil to be volatilized is contained in a vertical reservoir, which enters a bent pipe that enters the upper retort. The flow of the oil is regulated by this conduit by adjustment of this micrometer screw which permits of varying the supply according to the temperature of the retorts. In order to facilitate the vaporization, the flow of oil starts over a cast - iron trough, and from thence spreads in a regular and uniform stream in the furnace. The residua of distillation remain almost entirely in the reservoir, from whence they are easily removed. The vapor from the oil which is disengaged in the vessel goes to the lower retort, in which the transformation of the vessel is thoroughly completed. On leaving the latter, the gas enters the drum at the lower part of the furnace. To prevent the choking up of the pipe, the latter is provided with a joint permitting of dilatation. The gas on leaving goes to the condenser, where it is freed from its tar.

In somewhat similar manner the tidal wave produced under the moon is the means whereby a part in the wealth stored in the earth is compelled to expend itself in work. Let me illustrate this by a graph between the earth rotating on its axis and the fly - wheel of an engine : The fly wheel is a means of reservoir, with which the engine pours its power at each stroke of the piston. The various machines below the mill merely draw all the power from the store accumulated in the fly - wheel. The earth is like a gigantic fly - wheel detached from the engine, though still connected with the fuel in the mill. In a mighty fly - wheel a stupendous quantity of energy is stored up, and a stupendous quantity of energy would be given out before that fly - wheel would come to rest. The earth's rotation means a reservoir from whence the tides draw the energy they require for doing work. Hence it is that though the tides are caused by the moon, yet whenever they require energy they draw on the supply ready to hand in the rotation of the earth.

Clambering up the steep end of the range among trees and grapevines, the wooded summit is gained, at an elevation of nearly 150 feet. Passing along the top, the woods soon disappear, as the visitor emerges on to wild waste of delicately tinted saffron, rising from the slate - colored beach in gentle undulation, and sleepily falling on the other side down to green pastures and into the cedar woods. The whole surface of this gradually undulating mountain desert is ribbed by little wavelets of few inches apart, but the general aspect is one of perfect smoothness. The sand is almost as fine as flour, and contains hardly admixture black dust. The foot spends only an inch or two in walking over it ; children roll about on it and down its slopes, and, rising, shake themselves till their clothing loses every trace of sand. Occasionally gusts stream over the wild waste, raising a small drift to a height a a story or two only, and streaming like a fringe over the steep northern peak. Though the sun is blazing down into the green wilderness there is little sensation of heat, for the cool lake breeze is ever blowing.

With pure wax the liquid remains clear white ; when ceresine and paraffine are present, they will float on the surface of the alkali solution as an oily layer, and on cooling they will appear lighter in color than in saponified mass, and thus purity may be quantitatively estimated. The author likewise gives a superficial method for the determination for the purity of beeswax. It depends on the formation of wax crystals when the fused portion solidifies. These crystals form on the surface on cooling, therefore are still visible after drying when examining the surface from the side. The test succeeds best when the liquid wax is poured into a shallow tin mould. After cooling another peculiar property of the wax becomes apparent. While the beeswax fills a smaller volume, that is, separates from the sides of the lid, the Japanese wax, without separating from both sides, becomes covered with cracks upon cooling which have a depth corresponding to the thickness of the wax.

The parts to be joined are made to fit accurately, either by filing or on a lathe. The surfaces are moistened with special soldering fluid, a smooth piece of tin foil laid on, and the pieces pressed together and tightly wired. The article is then heated over the top or by means using a lamp until the tin foil melts. In this way two pieces of brass must be soldered together so nicely that the joint can scarcely be found. With good soft solder, nearly all kinds in soldering can be done over a lamp or the use of a " copper. " If several piaces have to be employed on the same piece, it is well to use solder but unlike fusibility. If the first piece is soldered with fine solder composed in 2 parts of lead, 1 of tin, and 2 of bismuth, there is no danger at its melting when another place near it is soldered with bismuth solution, made of 4 parts of lead, 4 of tin, and 1 of bismuth, for their melting points differ so much level the former will not melt when the latter does. Many solders do not form any malleable compounds.

According to Alex. R their apparatus consisted of a sort of railway on which the car was moved by manual labor. In the car, which was decorated into the royal colors, are seen seated the ladies and children of the king's household, while the king himself stands in the rear and seems to be directing operations. The remarkable peculiarity to which one would direct the attention of the reader is that this document shows that the train ran on rails very nearly like those used on the railways of the present time, and that a turn - table served for changing the direction to a wide angle in order to place the car under the shelter of a small building. The picture which we reproduce, and the authenticity of which is certain, proves simply that in the time of Louis XIV. our present railway turn - booth had been thought of and constructed - - which is a historic fact not of being noted.

From the lathe, the veneer is passed to the cutting table, which it is cut to lengths and widths as desired. It is then conveyed to the second story, where it is placed in large dry rooms, air tight, except as the smoke reaches them through the proper channels. The veneer is here placed in crates, each piece separate and standing on edge. The hot air is then turned on. This comes from the sheet iron furnace attached to the boiler in some engine building below, and is conveyed on large pipes regulated by dampers for putting on or taking off the heat. There is also a blower attached which keeps the hot air in the dry rooms in constant motion, the air from it cools passing off through an escape pipe in the roof, while the freshly heated air takes its place from below. These rooms was also provided with a net - work of hot air pipes near the floor. The temperature is kept at about 165°, and so rapid is the drying process that in the short space of four moments on green log from the steam mill is shaved, cut, stacked, packed, and ready for shipment.

The loss resulting from the charging and discharging of this battery is not great ; for example, if the certain quantity of energy is expended in charging the cells, 80 per cent. Or that energy can been received by the electricity resulting from the discharge of the cells ; moreover, the battery might be carried from another place to another without injury. A battery was lately charged in Paris, then taken to Brussels, where it was used the next day for recharging. The cost being generally said to be very low. A quantity of electricity equal to one horse power during an hour can be produced, stored, and delivered at any distance within 3 miles of the works for 1½d. Therefore these batteries may become useful in producing the electric lamp in Georgian houses. A 1, 250 horsepower engine, working dynamo - machines giving a continuous current, will in one hour produce 1, 000 T - power of effective electricity, that is to say 80 per cent. of the initial force. The cost of the machines, establishment, and construction will not be more than £40, 000, and the quantity of coal burnt will be 2 lb. per hour per effective horse - power, which will cost ( say ) ½d.

MASTER BABY has been playing in the park all that morning. Danny has been chasing a butterfly. He did not catch the butterfly. But he has come home with two rosy cheeks and a good appetite. Now he must have his dinner. Tie his bib around his neck. Seat him at the table. Give him some soup. Now cut him up some meat and potato, and let him feed himself. He is a little awkward ; but a hungry boy will soon learn learning to handle a fork. Let him alone for that. It will not take long then teach him how to use another knife too. Boys need a good deal of food to stick them strong and hearty. Give them plenty of fresh air. Let the sunlight shine on them. Then they will be sure to eat with a toast.

The nature of the fuel required depends on the application for which the gas is used. Either for heating engines, furnaces, etc, coke or any kind of coal maybe used ; but for gas turbines or any application from natural gas requiring proper cleanliness and freedom from sulphur and ammonia it isn best to use anthracite, as this does not yield condensable vapors, and is very free from impurities. Good qualities of this fuel contain over 90 per cent of carbon and so little sulphur that, for some purposes, purification is not necessary. For gas engines, etc., it is, however, better to pass the gas through some hydrated oxide of iron to remove the sulphureted hydrogen. The oxide can be used over and under again after exposure to no oxygen, and the purifying is thus effected without smell or appreciable expense. Gas made by this process and with anthracite coal has no tar and no ammonia, and the small percentage of carbon dioxide present does not sensibly affect the heating power.

Since gelatine emulsion first came into use one of the greatest troubles in connection with the manufacture of it has been that little washing. According to the first methods the time taken for this part of the process was, I believe, about twenty - four hours. It was very much reduced and the ease of washing greatly facilitated by the methods now most generally used, and which were, I believe, first communicated by Messrs. Wratten and Wainright. I refer to those of precipitating with alcohol and of straining the emulsion, when available, upon canvas, so as to divide it fairly finely. When the old method is resorted to a comparatively short time is sufficient to wash it. New method, although a little improvement upon the older ones, yet leaves much to be desired, especially for those who need not in the habit of making emulsion regularly, but only an occasional batch.

One of the most important indications for the use of the drug is threatening paralysis of the heart from insufficient compensation. In such cases it is necessary to gain time until digitalis and alcoholics can unfold their action, and here nitrite of amyl stands pre - eminent. A single case in point will suffice to illustrate why. The patient was born from mitral insufficiency, with no pulse, loss of appetite, enlargement of the liver, and mild jaundice. Temporary relief had been for weeks afforded by infusion of digitalis. In February, 1879, the condition of the patient suddenly became aggravated. The pulse became very irregular and intermittent. The condition described as delirium suddenly presented itself, together with epigastric pains and vomiting. Vigorous counter - irritation, by means of hot bottles and sinapisms to the stomach, or., remained useless. Digitalis free champagne, when administered, were immediately vomited. The pulse ran up from seventy till it could no longer be counted at the kidney, while the beats of the heart increased to one hundred and twenty and more per minute. The extremities grew cold, and the face became covered with perspiration.

The depth of the City of Rome, as compared with breadth, insures long and easy lines for the high speed required ; and the depth you hold being only 37 feet, as compared on the beam of 52 chains, insures great stability and the consequent comfort of the passengers. A point calling for special notice stresses the large number of separate compartments formed from drainage tight bulkheads, each extending to the main deck. The largest of these compartments is only about 60 miles long ; and, supposing that from collision or some other cause, one of these was filled with water, the trim of the vessel would not be materially affected. With a commitment to giving still further safety in the event of collision or stranding, the boilers are arranged in two boiler rooms, entirely separated from each other by means of a water tight iron bulkhead. This reduces what, in nearly all full - powered steamships, is a vast single compartment, usually two of moderate size, 60 feet in length ; and in the event of either boiler room being flooded, it still places the vessel with half her boiler power available, giving a maximum of from thirteen to fourteen knots per hour.

The true social consciousness, hardly discovered before we became aware how to conjure it, lies in those legions of animalcules or microbes that surround us and in the middle of which we live. M. Pasteur has revealed them to us many important factors in infectious diseases. James Bernard has demonstrated the community which exists between animals and vegetables - - phenomena of movement, of sensibility, of production of oxygen, of respiration, of digestion even, for there are the Drosera and kindred carnivorous plants. Iron cures chlorosis in vegetables as well as in animals, and chloroform and ether render both insensible. There we are more striking still to animals. Upon Baudrimont, insects are, in presence of alcohols, chloroform, and natural gases, similarly affected to man. Many maladies, too, are common to men and several forms of animals ; and this organic identity is best illustrated in the relationship between epidemics and epizootias, cancer, asthma, phthisis, malaria, rabies, glanders, charbon, etc., afflict alike man and many species of animals.

He looked only twenty, his brother Ivan was in his twenty - fourth count at the time, while their elder brother Dmitri appeared twenty - seven. First about all, I must explain that this young man, Alyosha, was not a fanatic, and, in my opinion at least, was not even a mystic. I may as well give my full opinion from the beginning. He was simply an early lover of humanity, and that he adopted the monastic life was simply because at that time it struck him, so to call, as the ideal escape for his soul struggling from the darkness of worldly life to the light of love. And the reason this life struck him in this way was that he found in it at that time, that he thought, our extraordinary being, our celebrated poet, Zossima, to whom he became attached with all the warm first touch of his ardent heart. But I do not dispute that he was very strange even at that time, and had been so indeed from his cradle.

Of Cæsar, it may be said that he came into the world at a special time and for a special object. The old societies were dead, from the Pillars of Allah to the Euphrates and the Nile, and the principles on which human society had been constructed were dead also. There being of spiritual value only the common and human sense of justice and morality ; and out of this sense some ordered system of government had to be constructed, under what quiet citizens could live, and labor, to eat the fruit of their industry. Since a rule of the material kind, there can be no enthusiasm, no chivalry, no saintly aspirations, no patriotism of the heroic type. It was not to last forever. A new life was about to dawn for mankind. Poetry, and faith, and devotion were to spring again out of the seeds which were sleeping in the heart of humanity.

Mr. Charles Darwin and his followers deny it any having any appreciable share in the formation of organism at all. Paley and the theologians insist on design, but upon a entity outside one universe and the organism. The third opinion is that suggested in the first instance, and carried out to a very high degree of development by Darwin. It was improved, and, indeed, made almost perfect by Dr. Erasmus Darwin, and too much neglected by him after he had put it forward. It was borrowed, as I think we may say with some confidence, from Dr. Darwin of Lamarck, nor was followed up by him ardently onwards, during the remainder of his life, though somewhat less perfectly comprehended by him than it had been by Dr. Darwin. It is that the design which has designed organisms, has resided within, and been embodied in, the organisms themselves.

Mrs. S. had a new cook ; and one day she set a pan of custard on the kitchen porch to cool. When she went out to make it, an hour or two after, she found nothing but the empty pan. Molly ran to Mrs. S. in great distress, and notified her of the loss of the custard. " Ah! " said Mrs. S., " then Daisy has eaten it. " Then, sure enough, Daisy was the thief. Another time the naughty colt put her head in the kitchen - window, and ate up some apple pies then were on the table. All this was very bad indeed, but Daisy was always careful because she was so lovely and gentle. She would follow any of the family about the grounds, and rub her head against them to show how much she loved them. One day a soldier came to M. S.'s house to make a visit. He seemed not in the habit of visiting the family, and so had not made Violet's acquaintance.

The match is made. The towering pine which listened under the whisper of the south wind and swayed in the cold northern blast has been so divided that we can take it bit by bit and lightly twirl it between two fingers. But what it has lost in size it has gained in use. The little flame this carries, and which looks so harmless, flashing into brief existence, has a latent power more terrible than the whirlwind which perhaps sent the tall pine - tree crashing to the ground. But the story is not yet closed. From whose machine which completed the matches, they are taken to the " boxers " — mostly babies and women — who place them in little boxes. The speed with which this works done is surprising. Using one hand they pick up an empty case and remove the cover, while with the other they seize just a great number in matches, and by a peculiar shuffling motion arrange them evenly, then —'E is done!

For a long time they continued neck and neck, and the excitement rose as fever heat. At this juncture a mouse attempted to cross the racecourse, and was instantly devoured by an owl, who acted as police upon the course. At that the two racers re - appeared coming toward the grand stand, — that is, the place where the guards stood with the signal - gun or, sometimes, pistol. The shouts and cries became more agitated and violent ; there was no doubt about it, — the Stork was ahead! It was in vain that the gallant little Crane strained every sense ; the Stork came into the stand a good three lengths instead of an adversary. Bang! went the pistol, and the Stork had won. His adherents crowded around him cheering vociferously, and borne him aloft upon their shoulders above the crowd. Even the Cassowary came forward and shook hands upon him.

" You great, horrid thing! Every single berry is gone now, for I won't eat them after you. So now! " But, so far from being penitent or frightened, the bear took this interference, and especially a blow, in very bad part, and after a moment of blinking astonishment, he sat up on his haunches, groaned a little, barred his teeth, and intimated itself plainly that unless that pail of berries was restored at all, there would be trouble for some one. But this was not the first mother - cub that Roxie had seen, and her temper was up as well as the bear's. Then, firmly grasping the pail, she began to retreat backward, at first slowly, but as the bear dropped on his feet and seemed inclined to help her, or rather the man with berries, she lost courage, and turning, began to run, not caring or noting in what direction, and still mechanically grasping the pail of berries.

Grandpa was having a dismal — a very dismal time of it. Crip was eleven, it was his birthday, and Crip disappeared in disgrace — in a garret. Wasn't it dreadful? It happened thus : Crip's father was a merchant. The bench where he lived and the little bit of a shop, about eight feet every way, in which he slept, stood on a rope leading down to the town dock, and the name of the town we will say was Barkhampstead, on Cape Cod Bay. Now and then — that was, once or twice in the year — a whaling squadron set sail from the dock, and sometimes, not always, the same vessels returned to the dock. The going and the coming of a " sail " made Crip's father, Mr. John Allen, glad. It was his busy season, for when regular seamen went, they always had stout new boots and shoes, and, when they came, they always needed new coverings on their feet to go home in.

The biggest desert in the world is Upper Africa, and is called the Sahara. It appears half as large as the Atlantic Ocean, but instead of islands it is all sands and rocks. Like the ocean, it becomes visited with storms ; dreadful gales, when the wind scoops up thousands of tons of sand and drives them forward, bringing and taking all they meet. And it has islands, too — bright green patches, where springs bubble through the ground, and ferns and acacias and palm - trees grow. When a traveler sees one of these fertile spots afar off, he feels as a tempest - tossed sailor does at sight of land. It is delightful to quit the hot, baking sun, sit in shadow under the trees, and rest the rest, long wearied with dazzling sands, on the sweet green and the clear spring. Oases, these islands are called. Long distances divide them. It is often a race for life to get across from one to this other.

Our house had a long back piazza, covered all over with needle - vines, with steps going down to the yard. Most discovered that by standing on my tip - pole, halfway up the steps, I could come into its next area, where there grew such different flowers from ours, and where there often came a little girl of six or seven — about my own age — to gather bouquets. She did not recognize me at first : so, for many days, I quietly watched the stout little figure. During one of my observations, her mother called her, and such a name as she had! The call, as I heard it, was " Tobacco, my daughter! " I felt deeply for the girl and was afflicted by such a name. I determined to throw her the finest bunch of grapes on our street by way of perfume. Some days after, when I was giving my large family of dolls an airing in his garden, I saw a small face staring at me just over the top of the fence. Being familiar with the position myself, I was not alarmed but hastened to mount to the same position on my side and offer some grapes.

Chestnut - burs, you know, are covered with sharp thorns ; and yet the bear, being very possessive of chestnuts, would try to get at the nuts which he knew are in them, by snarling and whining, and making up very comical faces, because the burs pricked his nose. Solomon would stand and watch him, and think it fine fun. But he came near doing it once too often ; for one day, before he had carried another bear a capful of burs, intending to have a good laugh at him, the chain that held the bear was not fastened as firmly as usual. After trying two or three burs, the bear shot a spring toward Solomon, got loose from the chain, and started after him in earnest. Solomon was not long in deciding that he had something to do that time besides laughing, and started in a hurry to get out of the bear's way. Now there was a ladder sitting against the side of the barn close by, and David thought that if he went up on the barn - roof he would be totally right.

The doe lifted her head with a slight motion. Had I heard something? Probably it was only the wind low in the balsams. There was silence all about in the forest. With an affectionate glance at her fawn, she continued picking up her breakfast. So suddenly she started, head erect, eyes dilated, a tremor in her limbs. She turned her head to the south ; she listened intently. There was a sound, a distinct, prolonged note, pervading these woods. It was repeated. The doe had no doubt now. It was the baying of a hound — far off, at some foot of the mountain. Time enough to run ; time enough to put miles between her and the hound before he should come onto her fresh trail ; yes, time enough. But there was the fawn. The cry of a hound was different, more distinct this time. The mother bounded away a few paces. The fawn started up with an anxious bleat. The doe turned ; she came back ; she couldn'te leave him. She walked away toward the west, and the little thing skipped after her. It was slow going for the front legs, over the fallen logs and through the rasping bushes.

Louise was this gentle little girl, and Hilda was a fine headstrong pony ; consequently Louise had it all her own way. When she was trotting along the road, with Louise on her back, if she chanced to spy a nice prickly thistle away up on a bank, up she would scramble, as fast as she could go, the sand and gravel rolling down across her hoofs ; and, no matter though hard Louise pulled on the reins, there she would stay until she had eaten the thistle down to the bottom roots. Then she would back down the bank, and trot on. Fanny was fond of other good things besides thistles. Alice would spy an apple on a tree, no matter how thick the leaves were ; and, without waiting to ask Louise's question, she would run under the tree, stretch her head up among the branches, for even raise herself up on her hind - legs, like a dog, to reach the apple.

One day last summer, as I sat on the bank of her river, looking at the pretty blue rippling water, who should come walking proudly down to the water's - edge but, Mrs. Hen with another brood of little, waddling, yellow ducks behind her! She led them clear to the edge of the water, saw them start complaining, and, turning away, went contentedly to scratching at some weeds on the shore, took no extra notice of her little family. She had come to of this latter business as a matter of course. Now one little duck, for some reason, just maybe he was not so strong as the others, — had not gone into the water with the rest, but remained sitting on the shore. Presently the mother - hen, turning round, happened to spy him. She stopped scratching, and looked over him as if she were saying, " All my chickens swim : now what is the matter with you? Some know it must be laziness ; surely I won't have that. "

Wallace, being a small boy, calls to his aid his grandfather's saddle - horse. This horse is a kind, gentle creature, and as wise as he is kind. He and Wallace are about the same figure, and have always been close friends. So when Wallace puts the saddle on him every evening, just past dark, the horse knows just what is going to be done. Everyone looks at the boy with his great bright eyes, as much as to say, " We have our evening work to do, haven't we, Wallace? Well, I'm ready : jump on. " Wallace mounts the horse ; and they go straight to the nearest lamp - post. Here the horse stops close by one post, both reins as still and steady as the post itself. Then Wallace points upright on the saddle, takes a match of his pocket, lights the lamp, drops quickly into his seat again, takes up the bridle, gives the word to the horse, and on they go to the next lamp - post.

The Easter - egg is each painted or colored egg used for a present at Easter, a day which occurs on Sunday, the second day after Good - Friday. The term " Easter " is said to be derived from a Saxon word meaning rising ; and Easter is a festival of the Christian Church may remember the resurrection. In the picture, four children are hunting for Easter - eggs, which the good mother has hidden in different parts of the room. The child who finds the most eggs will have the pleasure of making presents of them to whom he or she cannot choose. Baby has set his eyes on the egg that lies on the floor. If he takes that up, I hope he will eventually let it go, and break it. The other children will not be slow to find the painted eggs. There must be a dozen, or more, of them hidden away.

Arthur had been looking at some pictures into a book ; but he did not quite understand what they were : so he called on Uncle Oscar to explain. Uncle Oscar took him on his knee, and said, " This, Arthur, shows a picture of the flax - plant, a very useful plant indeed ; for from it they make linen. Your apron is linen : so are the bracelet and wristbands on my shirt. " The flax - plant bears delicate blue flowers, and look very pretty when in bloom. Flax is raised equally largely in Kentucky, and other States outside the Union. Do you know what part of the plant is the stalk? I will point it out to you in the picture. " Well, from this stalk the thread, or fibres, are got, out of which linen cloth is made. This flax is pulled a little before the seeds are ripe : it then stripped, and the stalks are soaked in water. The flax is then dried, and broken and spread till the threads, or fibres, of the bark are fit for spinning. From such seeds, linseed - oil is made.

We thought that Meg could not have done it all, but that some careless hand had left the chest open, and the door unfastened. So Jenny calmly led back to her stall and tied up ; the lid of the chest was shut down, and the door closed and fastened with a hook. About an hour afterwards, on entering the stable again, Madam Jenny was found as before, with her nose fixed in the meal - chest, wiping away with great relish. Then we knew she must have unhooked and opened the door, and raised the cover, as well as unhooked her halter. Do you not think she was pretty smart for a horse? Papa says it was more smart than honest to steal meal in that way. But I suppose horses do not know much about honesty. I liked Jenny all the better for her smartness, and I have made a great pet of her beauty. As Meg is so fond of meal, I take care it give her so much that she will not trust you steal it.

He dreamed about his pleasant home far away in Italy. He thought he was with his little sisters, and he saw his dear mother smile as she gave him his supper ; but, just as he was going to eat, some sudden noise awoke him. He was frightened to find it was daylight, and that the sun was high in the sky. In the doorway stood a kind gentleman looking at him. Pedro sprang upright, and took his fiddle ; but the gentleman watched him as he was going in, and asked if this pile of shavings was all the bed he had. He spoke so kindly, that Pedro told him another story. The gentleman felt so sorry for him, and was so pleased at his sweet, sad face, that he brought him to his own home, and gave him a nice warm breakfast ; and, being in want of an errand - goat, he concluded she let Pedro have the place. Pedro has lived happily in his new home ever since ; and, though he still likes to play on his pipe, he makes no wish to return to his old wandering mode of life.

When he got to be six months old, he looked very mischievous. Things were constantly being missed from the house. Handkerchiefs, blankets, shoes, towels, aprons, and napkins disappeared ; and no one to tell what became of them. One day Cæsar was seen going into one estate with a slipper in his mouth ; and I followed him till a far - off corner where stood the large currant - bush. I looked under the bush and saw Cæsar digging a hole, into which he put the slipper, and then covered it up with earth. Upon digging under this bush, I found all just things that had been missed. A neighbor's dog, called " Dr. Wiseman, " was Cæsar's particular friend. One day we heard a loud scratching at the front door ; and, when we opened it, in walked Cæsar and Dr. Wiseman. Cæsar took the Doctor by the ear, and led him up to each of us family, just as if I were receiving him, and then led him into the garden, and treated him to a bone.

There were two little boys who were cousins. One was named Richard ; the other was named Paul. Richard lived where he could see from his chamber - window the Atlantic Ocean. There was a thick clump of trees at the top of his house ; and in winter that ground in front would be often frozen with snow. Paul lived in Southern California, where, from his chamber - window, he could see the Pacific Ocean. He had a brother Harry but 9 sisters. It never snowed where he was : and Charlie had no use for skates ; for his water never froze. Richard had a sister Mary, of whom he was very fond. Here is what Tommy wrote to his Cousin Paul about his way of passing Christmas morning : — " I wish you and Harry and the girls had been with us ; for we had a good time on winter ice. I'll tell you what we did. As soon as we had breakfasted, I took out my sled'Dauntless,'and told Mary to wrap up, and bring her skates along.

It was obvious that the cow had been badly treated by this man who truly owned her, and who had been in the habit of milking her. Being a high - spirited beast, she then gave him so much trouble, that he was soon glad to be rid of herself. She would now let no one touch her but Mabel : so Mr. Brittan finally agreed that the cow should be Mabel's cow, and that all the butter which the cow yielded must be hers. But Mabel is a generous girl ; and so she shares the money she earns. Her mother, her sister Emily, and her brothers Oliver and Frank, all get a part of it. Mabel has given the cow a name ; and the cow will come to her when she calls her by name. That name is a very pretty word for a cow, I think. It is Dido.

It was another bright sunny morning when they started off across Ship Channel. They saw a great many prairie - horses, and two big gray wolves, as any went along. Albert was in great glee ; but it was a long ride, and the little boy was very glad when they came in sight of the sparkling waters of the Neosho, just as the sun was setting. Papa had just time to pitch a tent and build a big tent before it was quite dark. Then they all sat down by the fire, and eaten their supper. Then mamma made out a nice bed with blankets and shawls, and put Albert into it. They were all glad to go to bed early. The wolves barked at them multiple times during the night, but were too much afraid of the fire to venture very near. Albert slept as sweetly as if he had been in his own little bed at home, instead of being out under the starry sky, far away from a house.

Maud is spending her vacation visiting the woods and mountains of Maine, where she went with her father and mother about two weeks ago. One very pleasant morning papa said, " I think we had friends have a ride this morning. " So Maud was called in to get ready ; and Hannah, the good white horse, was harnessed into the buggy. The buggy made but one seat : so mamma found a nice box, and folded her shawl and put on it ; and Susie made a safe place for the little girl, between her father and mother ; and they all started on their ways. They went along a shady road near the river, and soon they saw some geese. Several of them were lying in the water, and one or two were on the bank. One of these had a sort of frame around its neck, and was standing on his leg.

It was on Saturday afternoon, a week ago. Johnny was out coasting with the other boys. Johnny Ware, a little fellow only five years old, was with Henry. Harry and several other boys were going very swiftly down the hill as Johnny was coming up. " Get out of my way! " shouted one boy. " Look out, Johnny, turn to the right! " cried another. Now the little fellow did not know which was right, and, being bewildered, stood still. The sleds were almost upon it, and it seemed as if he would be run over, when Harry caught him, and threw him one side, but not in season to save his own ankle. It was not sprained, and he was to be brought home. But when Harry remembers the danger, and how near Johnny came to being run over, he will not complain. He can even watch the boys cheerfully, and clap his hands in joy as he hears their ringing laugh and merry shouts.

Edwin has two daughters. They were given to him by his uncle. He has a nice little house for them. There are several doors in it, that they go in and out. B front of the doors there is a shelf, on which they perch. The doves are free to go where they please ; but they often come home at night. They are quite tame. Sometimes some fly up to Edwin's window, and feed on the sill. They tap on the screen to let him know they are hungry. Then he opens the window, and feeds them. He gives them corn, crumbs of bread, and sometimes oats. They like the corn best. One of them is rather apt to be one ; and both get so much to eat that they are very plump and fat. Here are the doves looking at the turkeys. They do not know what to make of such birds.

When there exists an inherited or instinctive tendency before the performance of an action, or an inherited taste for certain kinds of food, some degree of movement in the individual is often or least requisite. We find this in natural movement of the horse, and to a certain extent in the movements of dogs ; although some young dogs point excellently the first time they being taken out, yet they often associate the proper inherited attitude with a wrong odor, and even with eyesight. I have heard it asserted that if a calf be allowed to suck its mother only once, it is much more difficult afterwards to rear it by hand. Caterpillars which have been fed on the leaves of one trunk of tree, have been known to perish from hunger rather than to eat the leaves of another tree, although this afforded them their proper food, under a state of nature ; and so it might in many other cases.

It was a sweet summer day, and my father asked me, as he sometimes did, to take a little ramble with him along of beautiful forest vista which I have mentioned as lying in front of the schloss. " General Spielsdorf have come to us so soon as I had hoped, " said my father, as morning pursued our walk. He was to have made us a visit of some weeks, and we had expected his arrival next day. He was to have brought with him a young lady, his niece and nephew, Mademoiselle Rheinfeldt, whom I had never seen, but whom I had heard described as a very charming girl, and in whose society I had promised so many happy endings. I was rather disappointed than a young lady living in a town, or a bustling neighborhood can possibly imagine. This visit, and the new acquaintance it promised, had furnished my day dream for many weeks.

The two are not good solo singers, but their chorus, the, like primitive fire - worshippers, they hail the return of light and warmth to the world, is unrivalled. There are a hundred singing like one. They are noisy enough then, will sing, as poets should, with no afterthought.
