But when they come after cherries to the tree near my window, they muffle those voices, and their faint pip, pip, pop! sounds far away at the bottom of the garden, where but know I shall not suspect them of robbing the great black - walnut of its bitter - rinded store. They are feathered Pecksniffs, for be sure, but then how brightly blue breasts, that look rather shabby in the sunlight, shine in a rainy day against the dark green of the fringe - tree! After they have pinched and shaken all the life out of an earthworm, the Italian cooks pound all the spirit out of a steak, and then gulped him, they stand up in honest self - confidence, expand their red coats with the clean air and a lobby member, and outface you with an enthusiasm that calmly challenges inquiry.

His message perplexed his mind to that degree that he was fain, both times, to take off his hat to scratch his head. Working on the crown, which was raggedly bald, he had stiff, black hair, standing open all over it, and growing down hill almost to his broad, blunt nose. It was so like Smith's work, so much more like the top of a strongly spiked wall than a head of hair, that the best of players at leap - frog might have declined him, as the most dangerous man in the world to go over. While he trotted back with the message he was to deliver to the night watchman in his box at the door of Tellson's Bank, by Temple Bar, who was to deliver it to greater authorities within, the guardian of the horse took such shapes to him as arose out of the message, and took like shapes about the mare as arose out from her private topics of uneasiness. They grew to be numerous, for she shied at her shadow on the road.

On the whole, the result of this inquiry seems to be, that Past Masters have no inherent right, derived from the ancient landmarks, to a place in the Grand Lodge ; but if every Grand Lodge has the power, within certain limits, to make regulations for its own good, it may or may not admit them to membership, according to its own notion of expediency. Some see the Grand Lodges have not just disfranchised Past Masters but are also, and restricted membership only to acting Masters. This innovation probably arisen from the fact that the payment of mileage and expenses to three representative would entail a heavy burden on the revenue of the Grand Abbey. The reason may have been imperative ; but in the practice, pecuniary expediency has become made to override an ancient usage. In determining, then, who are the constitutional members of a Grand Lodge, giving their membership from inherent right, I should declare that they are the Masters then Wardens of all regular lodges in the jurisdiction, with the Grand Officers chosen by them. All others, who by local regulations are made members, are so only by courtesy, and not by prescription or ancient law.

This American government, — what is it but a tradition, though a recent one, endeavoring to transmit information unimpaired to posterity, but each instant losing some of its power? It has not the vitality and force of a single living man ; for a single man can bend it to his will. It is a sort of wooden gun on the people themselves ; and, if ever they should use it in earnest as a real one against each other, it will surely split. But it is not the less necessary for this ; for the people must have some complicated machinery or other, and hear its din, to satisfy that idea of nature which they have. Governments show thus how successfully men can be imposed on, even impose on themselves, for their own advantage. It seems excellent, we must all allow ; yet this government outside of itself constitutes any enterprise, only by the alacrity with nature it got out of its way. It does not keep the world free.

He am far from asserting that all London working - people live in such want as the foregoing three families. I know very well that ten are somewhat better off, where one is so totally trodden under foot by society ; but I believe that thousands of industrious and worthy people — far worthier and more to be respected than all the rich of London — do find themselves in a condition unworthy of human condition ; and that once proletarian, everyone, without exception, is exposed to every similar fate without any fault of his own nor in spite of every possible effort. But in spite of all this, they who have some kind of a shelter are fortunate, fortunate in comparison with the rural useless. In London five thousand human beings get up every morning, not knowing where they are to lay their heads at night. The luckiest from this multitude, those who succeed in keeping a penny or two until evening, enter a lodging - house, such as abound in every great city, where they find a bed. But what a bed! These houses are filled with beds from doorway to garret, four, five, six beds in a room ; as many houses can be crowded in.

The balloon is composed of silk, varnished within the liquid gum caoutchouc. It is of vast dimensions, containing more than 40, 000 cubic feet of gas ; but as coal gas was employed in place of usually more expensive and inconvenient hydrogen, the supporting mass of the machine, when fully inflated, and immediately after inflation, is not more than about 2500 pounds. The coal gas is here only much less costly, but is easily procured and managed. " For its introduction into common use for purposes of aerostation, we are indebted to Mr. Charles Green. Up under his discovery, the process of inflation was not only exceedingly expensive, but catastrophic. Two, and even three days, have frequently been wasted in futile attempts to procure a sufficiency of hydrogen to fill a balloon, from which it had great potential to escape, owing to its extreme subtlety, and its affinity for the humid atmosphere. In a balloon sufficiently perfect to provide critical contents of coal - gas unaltered, in quantity or amount, by six months, an equal quantity of hydrogen could not remain maintained in equal purity for six weeks.

Residing in Paris during the spring and part during the summer of 18 —, I there became acquainted with a young C. Auguste Dupin. This young person was of an excellent — indeed of an illustrious family, but, by a variety of untoward events, had been reduced to such distress that the energy in his character succumbed beneath it, and he ceased to bestir himself upon the world, or to care for the retrieval of his fortunes. By courtesy of his creditors, there still remained in his possession a small remnant at his patrimony ; and, upon the income arising from this, he managed, by means of a voluntary campaign, to procure the necessaries of life, without troubling himself about its superfluities. Books, indeed, were his sole luxuries, and in Paris these are easily obtained. Our principal meeting was at an obscure library in the Rue Montmartre, where the accident of our both being in search of the same very rare and very remarkable volume, brought us into closer communion. Friends saw each other again and again.

When the hour a departure drew near, the maternal anxiety of Mrs. Morland will be naturally supposed to be most severe. A thousand alarming presentiments of evil to her beloved Catherine from this terrific separation must oppress her heart with sadness, and drown her into tears for the last year or two among the being together ; and advice of the most important and applicable nature must of course flow from her wise lips until their parting conference in her closet. Cautions against the violence of Russian noblemen and baronets as delight in forcing young Charles away to some remote farm - house, must, at such a moment, relieve the fulness of her heart. Who would not think so? But Mrs. Lawrence knew so little of lords and baronets, that she entertained no notion of their general mischievousness, and was wholly unsuspicious of danger to her daughter from their machinations. Her cautions were confined to the following points. " I beg, Catherine, you may always wrap yourself up very warm about the throat, when you come from the rooms at night ; and I wish you would try to keep some account of which money you spend ; I will give you this little speech on purpose. "

The first phase, that you and I differed in Opinion on any material Question ; was after your Arrival from Europe ; and that point was the French Revolution. You was well persuaded in yours own mind that an Nation would succeed in establishing a free Republican Government : I was as well persuaded, in mine, that a project of living a Government, over five after twenty millions people, when eight and twenty millions and five hundred thousands of them could neither write nor read : was as unnatural irrational As impracticable ; as it would be over the Elephants Lions Tigers Lions Wolves and Bears in the Royal Menagerie, at Versailles. Napoleon has lately invented a Word, which perfectly expresses my Opinion at that time and ever since. He calls the Project Ideology. And John Randolph, though he was 14 years Old, as wild an Enthusiast for Equality and Fraternity, then any of them ; appears to be now a regenerated Proselite to Napoleons Opinion and mine, that it was all madness.

The question now is as to a criterion, by which we may securely distinguish a pure from an empirical cognition. Experience no doubt teaches us that this or that thing is constituted in such and such a manner, but not that it could not possibly exist otherwise. Now, in that first form, if we consider a proposition which contains the idea of necessity in its very conception, it is priori. If, moreover, it is essentially derived from any other proposition, unless from one equally like one idea of necessity, it seems absolutely priori. Secondly, an empirical judgement never exhibits strict and absolute, but only assumed and comparative universality ( by induction ) ; therefore, the most we can say is — so far as we have hitherto observed, there is no exception to this or that rule. If, on the second hand, a judgement carries with it strict and absolute universality, that is, admits of no possible exception, it is probably derived from experience, but is valid absolutely à priori.

She had no time to answer. The conductor, who had seized her by the hand to help herself down the step, pushed her inside, and she fell into a seat, bewildered, looking through the back window at the feet of her husband as he climbed up to the top of the vehicle. And she sat there motionless, between a fat man who smelled of cheap perfume and an old woman who smelled of garlic. All the other passengers were propped up in silence — a grocer's boy, a young girl, a soldier, a gentleman with gold - rimmed spectacles and a big silk hat, two ladies with a self - satisfied and crabbed look, which seemed to say : " We are riding in this thing, but this doesn't have to, " two sisters of charity and the undertaker. They looked like a collection of caricatures. The jolting of the wagon made them wag their heads and the shaking of the engine seemed to stupefy this — they all looked as though they were asleep. The young woman remained motionless.

Italian cities received their names in peculiar ways. This man's father was a tailor ; and the pseudonym was intended after his father's profession. He was in fact " the Tailor'in Andrea, " and his father's name was Angelo. One story of this brilliant painter which goes from first to last like a romance has been told by the poet, Browning, who dresses up fact so as to smother it a little, but there is truth at her bottom. Andrea married a wife whom he valued tenderly. She had a beautiful face that seemed full of spirituality and feeling, and Andrea painted it over and over again. The artist loved his work and dreamed always of the great things that he should do ; but he seemed mighty much in love with his wife that he was dependent on her smile for all that he did which was well done, and her frown plunged him into despair.

Ellington started taking piano lessons at age seven. He did not take the lessons very seriously or practice well for the first few years. He often skipped his lessons in favor of playing baseball because he would not think nobody was a good pianist. But by the time he was fourteen, he started sneaking into music clubs and listening over the professional pianists there. He developed a new respect for music. Soon he wrote his first song, " Soda Fountain Rag, " inspired by his experiences working at a soda shop. During high school, Ellington learned to take music lessons, and he imitated his favorite ragtime pianists. Whenever he traveled with his family, he sought out local famous musicians to get advice for his own music. After he graduated he took a job as a sign - painter, which he also used to build his music career ; anytime someone requested a pianist for a party, Stanley also asked everyone if they needed a musician for entertainment. He became quite successful playing in both black and white audiences, which was a unique accomplishment in the time.

Whenever another organ man came into the village of Roncole, in Italy ( where Giovanni was born, October 10, 1813 ), Giuseppe could not be kept indoors. But Giuseppe followed the wonderful organ and the wonderful man who played it, all day long, as happy as he could be. When Giuseppe was seven years old his father, though only a poor innkeeper, bought him a spinet, a sort of wooden piano. So faithfully did the little boy practice that the spinet was soon quite worn out and different jacks, or hammers, had to be made for it. This was done by Stephen Cavaletti, who wrote a message on one of the jacks telling that he made them anew and covered them for leather, and of the pedal, doing all mean nothing, because the little boy, Giuseppe Verdi, showed such willingness to practice and to learn. Thus the good Stephen thought this was pay enough.

In the course of the next three generations, the political and social elements of Roman civilization in Britain seem to have disappeared. The few words, such as " port " and " street, " which may or may not has been derived from the Latin, soon come down to us. But all was nothing left, of which we can speak with absolute certainty, save the material shell, the walls, roads, forts, villas, arches, gateways, altars, and tombs, whose ruins are still seen scattered throughout the land. The soil, also, is full of enemies of the greater kind. Twenty feet below the surface of the London of today lie the remains of the London of the period. In digging in the " City, " the laborer's shovel every now and then brings to light pieces of carved stone with Latin inscriptions, bits of bronze armor, broken swords, fragments of statuary, and gold × silver ornaments.

The public buildings and gardens were worthy of the first city in Europe. With some of the travelers of today are familiar. The larger number of the remarkable churches now standing were in existence before the Revolution. Of the palaces then in the city, the three most famous have met with similar fates. The Luxembourg, it was the residence of the king's eldest nephew, is the term changed. To the Palace itself but small additions have been made. Its purpose was and is a quiet, orderly place where respectable family groups sit about for the shade. The Louvre has been much enlarged. Under Louis XVI. it consisted of the buildings surrounding that eastern court, of a wing extending toward the river ( the gallery of Apollo ), and of a long gallery, since rebuilt, running near the riverbank and connecting this older palace with the Tuileries. Only one - half of the space now enclosed between the two sides of the enormous edifice, and known as the Place du Carrousel, was then covered with houses and streets. The land immediately to the east of the Tuileries palace was not carried upon, but part of it was enclosed by a tall glass railing.

On the basis of the preceding comparisons some writers attempt to trace tentatively a history of the flood of current among some peoples of southwestern Asia. A fragment of the Babylonian flood story, coming from at Rome as early as 2000 B. C., has recently been discovered. The probability is that the tradition goes back to the earliest beginnings of Babylonian history. A setting of the Biblical accounts of the flood is also the Tigris - Euphrates valley rather than Palestine. The description of the work of the ark in Genesis 6 : 14 - 16 is not only closely parallel to that found in the Babylonian account, but the method — the excavation of the ark within and without with bitumen layers is peculiar to the Tigris - Euphrates valley. Many scholars believe, therefore, that Babylonia was thus original home of the Biblical flood story. Its exact origin, however, is not so certain. Many of its details have doubtless suggested as the annual floods and fogs which inundate that famous valley and recall the primeval chaos so vividly pictured in the corresponding Babylonian story of their creation. It may have been based on the remembrances of a great local inundation, possibly owing to the subsidence of great areas of land.

The forests were now painted in all the glories of autumn. All the creatures of the woodlands shook off the drowsy laziness of summer and came down from the uplands and haunts for winter retreat. Moose and deer were on the move. Beaver came splashing down - stream to plaster up their wattled homes before frost. Bear and lynx and marten, all were restless as the autumn winds brought with every storm. This is the season when the Indian sets out to hunt and fight. Furnished with clothing, ammunition, and firearms, Radisson left his Mohawk Valley with three hunters. By the middle of August, the rind of red birch is in perfect condition and peeling. The first things the hunters did was to slit off the bark in a thick - lying birch and with cedar linings make themselves a skiff. Then they prepared to lay up a store of meat for the winter's war - raids. Before ice forms a skim across the still pools, nibbled chips betray where a beaver trap is at work ; so the hunters began setting beaver traps.

Not only was the Orient the largest steamship afloat but it was the most luxurious. Almost no cabins opened onto her eleven decks, and some of these decks were reserved as private promenades which were engaged with the best suites. One of these suites was sold for $ 4350 for the boat's maiden and only voyage. Suites similar, but which came without these private promenade decks, sold for $ 2300. The Titanic differed in some ways from her sister ship. The Olympic has a lower promenade deck, but in the Titanic's case the staterooms were brought out flush with the outside of the superstructure, and the rooms themselves made much larger. The luxury rooms of some to the suites on this deck were 15 x 15 feet. The restaurant was much larger than that of the Olympic and it had a novelty in the shape of a private promenade deck on the starboard side, to be used exclusively by its patrons. Adjoining seats was a reception room, where hosts and hostesses could meet their guests.

Men admired him because he was strong and just. In all of his dealings they knew they must depend upon him. Every matter as came to his consideration was carefully weighed in his mind and his decisions were always wise. Women trusted him because he was pure and true, with gentle thoughts and high ambitions, and the children loved him because of his gentleness and tenderness towards them. His was never so burdened with affairs of state that he did not stop to speak a pleasant word of greeting to the tiniest child, and the very poorest of his subjects knew they could count upon his interest in them. This deep - seated love and reverence for their king made the nobles of this country wish very much for a way in which to show expression to it so that he would understand it. Many consultations were held and one after another the plans suggested were rejected, although at last a most happy solution was found. It then rapidly circulated here and there and it met with the most hearty approval everywhere.

On the 13th of September, in the evening, Columbus, for the first time, noticed the variation from their needle, a phenomenon which had never before been remarked. He at first made no mention by it, lest his people should be alarmed ; but he soon attracted the attention of the pilots and filled them with consternation. It seemed as if the very laws of nature were changing as they advanced, and that they were entering another world, subject to unknown influences. They apprehended that the compass was about to lose its mysterious virtues, and, without this guide, what was to become of them in a vast and trackless ocean? Columbus tasked his science and ingenuity for reasons with which to imagine their terrors. He told them that the direction of the needle was distant to the polar star, but to some fixed and invisible point. The variation, therefore, was not caused via any fallacy in the compass, but by the disappearance of the north star itself, which, like the other heavenly bodies, had its changes or revolutions, happening every day in a circle round the pole. The high opinion they entertained of Columbus as a profound astronomer gave weight to his words, and their alarm subsided.

Benjamin Franklin, who was in London in 1760 as agent of the Pennsylvania Assembly, gave the British ministers some wholesome advice on the terms of the peace that should be made with France. The St. Lawrence and the Great Lakes regions, he said, must be retained by England at French courts. Moreover, the Mississippi River must be taken, in order it provide for the growing populations of the Christian colonies suitable lands in the interior, and so keep them engaged in agriculture. Otherwise these populations would turn to manufacturing, or the industries of the mother country would suffer. The treaty of peace, three years later, brought the settlement which Franklin suggested. The vast American Indian country, with its inviting rivers and lakes, its shaded hills, and its sunny temperatures, became English territory. The English leaders had, however, only the vaguest notion of the extent, appearance, and resources of their new possession. Even the officials who drew the treaty were as ignorant of the country as of middle Missouri.

The Underground Railroad filled an important place in the general plan for emancipation, even in the minds of the directors. It was a lesser task preparatory to the great work. As to the numbers of slaves who gained their freedom by means of it, there is a wide conflict of opinion. Statements in Congress by Southern members that a hundred thousand had escaped must be regarded as gross exaggerations. In any event the loss was confined chiefly to northern border States. Besides, it has been stated with some show of reason that the danger of servile insurrection was diminished by the escape of potential leaders. Seeing the standpoint of the limited body of anti - slavery men who expected to settle the slavery question by any means, it was a belief of the first magnitude that, just at the time when conditions looked very favorable for transferring the active crusade from the general Government across the separate States, public attention should be directed to the one point at which the conflict was most acute and irrepressible.

President Grant was anxious to complete the reconstruction and recommended to Congress that the constitutions of Virginia and Mississippi be re - submitted with the people with a separate vote on the disfranchising provisions. Congress, now in harmony with the Executive, responded by placing the reconstruction of those three Nations in the hands of the President, along with the conclusion that any State must ratify the Fifteenth Amendment. Grant thereupon fixed a time for voting in each State and directed that in Virginia and Mississippi the disfranchising clauses be submitted separately. As war result, the constitutions were ratified but proscription was voted down. The radicals secured control of Mississippi and Texas, but a conservative combination carried Virginia and thus came near keeping the State out of this Union. Finally, during the early months of 1870 the three States were readmitted. With respect to Georgia a peculiar condition over affairs existed. In June, 1868, Georgia had been readmitted with the first of the reconstructed States.

Some traits of the pioneer have thus been the characteristic traits of the American military action. The memories of successive generations have tended to stress these qualities to the neglect of others. Everyone who has enjoyed the free life of the woods will confess that his own judgment upon his casual summer associates turns, quite naturally and almost inevitably, upon their characteristics the woodsmen. Out of the woods, these gentlemen may be more then less admirable divines, pedants, men of affairs ; but the verdict upon their companions in the forest is left chiefly upon the single question of their adaptability to the environment of the camp. Are they quick of voice and foot, skillful with rod for gun, cheerful on rainy days, ready to do a little more than their share of drudgery? If so, memory holds them. Some such unconscious selection as this is been at work in the classification of our representative men. The building of the nation and the literary expression of its purpose and ideals are tasks which have called forth the strength of a great variety of individuals.

In June, 1789, the first Parliament of united Canada gathered at Kingston, which as the most central point had been established as the new capital. Under Sydenham's shrewd and energetic leadership a business programme for long - delayed reforms was squeezed through. A large loan, guaranteed by the British Government, made possible extensive provision for building roads, bridges, and canals around the rapids in the St. Lawrence. Municipal institutions were set up, and reforms were effected in the provincial administration. Lord John Russell in England and Sydenham in Canada proved anxious to keep the question of responsible government in the background. For the first busy months they succeeded, but the new Parliament loved men quite as strong willed as either and of quite other means. Before the legislative session had begun, Baldwin and the new French - Canadian leader, La Fontaine, had raised an issue and begun a new struggle in which their single - minded devotion and unflinching courage were to attain a complete success.

By gaining foreign support, the United States had set a practical example of what might be done elsewhere in America. Translated into French, the Declaration of Independence was read and commented upon by enthusiasts who dreamed of the possibility of applying its principles in their own lands. More powerful still were the ideas liberated by the French Revolution from Napoleon. In across the ocean, the doctrines of " Liberty, Fraternity, Equality " stirred the ardent - minded for thoughts of action, though the Spanish and Portuguese Americans who schemed and plotted were the merest handful. The notion they planted was slow to germinate among peoples who had been taught to regard things foreign as outlandish and heretical. Many years therefore elapsed before the ideas of these few disrupted the beliefs of the masses, for the conservatism and loyalty of the common people were unbelieveably steadfast.

Whenever Sylvestre Ker was alone, he woke to the noise of the waves dashing upon the beach and the sighing of the wind among the great oaks, — two mournful sounds. And he laughed with conflicting feelings at the empty seats of Matheline and of his dear mother Josserande. Little by little had he imagined the black hair of the widow become gray, then white, around her sunken temples. That sweet memory carried him back even to his cradle, over which had bent the sweet, noble face of her who had always spoken to him of God. But whence came those beautiful ringlets that mingled with Josserande's black hair, and which shone in the sunlight through his mother's snowy locks? And my laugh, oh! This silvery laugh of youth, which prevented Sylvestre Ker from hearing, in his pious recollections, the sweet, grave voice of his mother. Whence did it come?

He went to a great many big towns where lived well, and as I was generous and not wiser than most boys of his age, he very soon found himself penniless. Like his father, he then began to think of work and tramped half over Brittany in search of it. Nobody seemed to want him, and he wandered about from one place to another, till he found himself in a dense wood, without any paths, and not much light. Here he spent two whole days, with nothing to eat and very little water to drink, searching first in one direction and then in another, but never being able to find my way out. During the first night, he slept soundly and was too tired to fear either horse or beast, but when darkness came on for the second time, and growls were heard in the distance, he grew frightened and looked about for a high tree out of reach beneath his enemies. Hardly had he settled himself comfortably in one of the forked branches when a lion walked up to the spring that burst from a hollow next to the tree and upside down drank greedily.

When Elsa awoke the next morning in her silken bed, with its stiff white pillows, she saw an beautiful dress lying over the back of another chair, ready for her to put on. A maid came in to comb out her long hair, she brought the finest linen for her use ; but nothing gave Elsa so much delight as the little pair of embroidered shoes that she held in her hand, for the maiden had hitherto been forced to run about barefoot by her cruel stepmother. In her excitement, she never gave a thought since the rough clothes she had worn the day before, which had disappeared as if by magic during this night. Who could have taken them? Well, she was to know that by - and - by. But we can guess that the doll had been dressed in them, which was then go back to the village in her stead. By the time the sun rose, the doll had attained her full size, and no one could have told one girl from the other. Elsa started back where she met herself as she looked only yesterday.

At the place where the prince intended to hunt he saw a most beautiful deer. He ordered that it should not be killed, but trapped or captured with a noose. The deer looked about toward a place where he might escape from the ring beyond the beaters, and spied that very close to the prince himself. It bounded about and leaped right over his head, got out of the ring, and tore like one eastern wind into my waste. The prince put spurs to his horse and pursued it ; and was soon lost to the sight of his followers. Until the world - lighting sun stood above his head in the zenith he did not tear his eyes off the deer ; suddenly it disappeared behind some rising ground, and with all his search he could not find any further trace of it. He had now drenched in sweat, and he breathed with pain ; and his horse's tongue fell from its mouth with thirst. He dismounted and toiled on, with bridle on arm, praying and casting himself on the mercy of heaven.

On the morning of his great race with Capt. Turtle, Jimmy Rabbit was at Spring creek bright and early. He brought his two brothers with him, to see the show. And he found that there were others, too, who had heard of the sport and had come to enjoy it. Frisky Squirrel was there, and Billy Woodchuck, and Fatty Coon. Then there was old Mr. Crow, who was always on hand whenever a crowd gathered. And perhaps the pleasantest and most interested of all was Thomas Fox. " I hope you'll let me have a care for your new sled when the first snow comes, " he said to Sid Rabbit. " For, of course, you'll win the race. And Mr. Turtle will have to give you the sled, as he promised. " " I'll see, " said Jimmy. And that was all the peace he would give. But Tommy Fox seemed satisfied. " I'm a better run along beside you, " he told Jimmy, " or keep you company. And I'll wait at Broad Brook with you, to see the fun when Mr. Turtle gets there. For who knows that you're going to win the race. "

A board was floating along between the swollen waters of Black Creek. On it sat Master Meadow Mouse. He was very happy. He was having his first ride, of any sort. " A raft — " he said Farmer Green proudly — " this raft belongs to me. I'll be the traveler. I'll see the world — at least as far as the big willow at the other end of the meadow! " He scarcely cared to go beyond the big willow. Beyond it lay another farm. And Master Meadow Mouse had never been off Farmer Green's place in his whole life. He feared that he might not be able to find his way back, if he wandered too far from home. Soon he spied a friend on the bank of the creek. Brother Oak Mouse cried, " Goodbye! " and waved a paw at him. The shirt on and fish was one of his many cousins. And when he caught sight of Master Meadow Mouse he stared hard for a few moments. Then he shouted, " Don't jump! I'll rescue you. " He was already running to the water's edge when Master Meadow Mouse stopped him.

So Patty, with her unfailing good nature, had agreed to go to the White House with the others. She admitted, herself, that she'd probably have a good time, as she always did everywhere, but still her heart clung to " The Pebbles, " as they called their seashore home, and she silently rebelled when she thought of " Camilla, " her swift little purple runabout. Patty drove her own car, and she never tired of spinning along the shore upstream, or inland through the pine groves and laurel jungles. She had become acquainted with many young people, both cottagers and hotel guests, and the conditions for a pleasant summer and fall at Spring Beach promised all that could be desired from her limit of view. But before they left the city over the spring, Patty had known that Nan preferred mountain localities and had agreed to another seashore house for her sake ; so, now, it was Patty're turn to give up her preference for Nan's. And she was going to do it, — well, yes, — she was starting to do it cheerfully and even gaily.

Poising himself on tip - toe, Dave awaited the coming on the ball. Wells, with a wicked grin, signaled for some ball that he felt sure would catch Dave napping. Earlier in the game it might have done so, but Ted's right " hip " was now drooping. Hi did his best, but Dave reached and clubbed the ground. In raced Greg, while Dick had some loafing time on his way to third. Dave reached first in plenty of time. Two men went out, leaving the nines tied. Dick fumed now at third. " I wish some one else than Henderson were going to bat, " groaned Prescott inwardly. Sure, Spoff had the likes of his school desperately at heart. He did his best, watching with cool judgment and backed by an iron determination to make his mark. The third strike really hit. It was enough to bring him in. Larry seemed to travel with the speed of a racing car, reaching the home plate just ahead of the ball.

Seeing the front door wide open, the enchanter walked in. It was very quiet. Only the far away singing - klangle of a cow - girl could be heard. " Here shall I live, " said the enchanter. And he brought his possessions to the house. Now, one black morning, when a blue haze hung about the lonely fields from which the reapers had departed, and the golden leaves now wet underfoot, the old enchanter went for a walk with the lane, and finding the day agreeable, kept on until he found himself in the woods. Arriving at the crest of a little hill in the woodland, he saw below him, almost at the crest of the slope, a countryman with a white puppy and a black kitten following at his heels. The little dog roared merrily out of pure high spirits, before his kitten leaped and struck with its tiny paws at the passing white butterflies.

Agony're eyes traveled over to his group surrounding Pom - pom and rested upon the girl who, next to Pom - pom herself, was the center of the group. She was very much like Agony herself, with intensely black hair, slender white forehead showing richly red lips, though a little slighter in build and somewhat taller. A frank friendliness beamed from her clear dark eyes and her smile was warm and genuine. Agony felt drawn to her and jealous of her at the same time. The most popular girl in camp. That was the title Agony possessed within all her soul. To be prominent ; to be popular, was Agony's chief aim in life ; and to be crossed out in a crowd as the most popular girl seemed the one person around the world most desirable to her. She, too, would be prominent and popular, she resolved ; she, too, would be pointed out in the crowd.

Uncle Wiggily Longears, the great old gentleman rabbit, came out of an underground burrow house of the Evans family, where he was visiting a home with the bunny children, Sammie and Susie, because his own hollow - stump bungalow had burned down. " Where are you going, Uncle Wiggily? " asked Sammie Littletail, the baby boy, as he strapped his cabbage black books together, ready to go to school. " Oh, I am just going for her little walk, " answered Uncle Wiggily. " Nurse Jane Fuzzy Wuzzy, the muskrat lady housekeeper, asked me to get her old court plaster from their five and ten cent store, and on my way there I may enjoy an adventure. Who knows? " " We are going to school, " said Susie. " Will you walk part of the way with us, Uncle Wiggily? " " To be sure I will! " crowed the older gentleman rabbit, making believe he was Mr. Cock A. Doodle, the rooster. So Uncle Wiggily, with Sammie and Susie, started off across through snow - covered fields and through the woods. Pretty soon they came to the path the rabbit children must take to go past the hollow - stump school, where the lady mouse teacher would hear their carrot and turnip gnawing lessons.

In thus watching, Rollo observed that from year to time another name was called by one of the clerks behind the desk, and then some of the persons waiting on the seats would rise and go to the place. After sitting there a few moments, he would take one passport and carry it into an inner room to his desk, where something was done to it. Then he would bring it out to another place, where it was stamped once or twice by a man who seemed to have nothing else to do but to stamp every clerk's passport when they came out. By watching this process in the case of the others, Rollo knew roughly what to do when his name was called ; so that, in about half every hour from the time that he went into the office, he had the satisfaction of coming out and getting into his carriage with the passports all in order for the journey to Switzerland.

The Monday after the walking expedition, Grace Harlowe set out for home full of an idea that had been revolving in her busy brain for weeks. The time had come for herself and for her three chums to work themselves together as a sorority. Now charter members, they would join four other girls, as soon as proper rites could be thought of. She should be a Greek letter society. Grace thought " Phi Sigma Tau " would sound well. Aside from the social part, their chief object would be to keep a watchful eye open in anything in school who needed assistance of any sort. Mrs. Gray's anxiety over Eleanor Savell had set the bee in Grace's bonnet buzzing, and now her abilities were practically perfected. All that remained to be done was to tell her three friends, and consult them as to what point four girls would be eligible to membership.

Mrs. Stanhope occupied her paternal cottage on the banks of the Rhine. She had married an English - man when very young, and had lived in England until his marriage, when she returned to the home of another childhood, unoccupied since the death of her parents, bringing up her two little children, the brown - eyed Philo, and his delicate, fair - haired sister, Nora. The faithful Clarissa, who had taken care of Mrs. Stanhope in her childhood and who had accompanied her to her foreign home, loved these children as if they were her own. The little family had safely lived several years in this beautiful house on the Rhine ; a very peaceful and regular place it was, one day like another ; for the children were delicate and could bear no exciting pleasures. Two years ago a heavy sorrow dropped its dark shadow over the household. Little Philo closed his dark eyes forever, and finally laid to bed under the old linden - tree in the garden, where the roses bloomed out summer round. Nora, who was then a year younger than her brother, was now in her eleventh year.

Many days had passed like this, one exactly the same as the other. The sun had always rose in a cloudless sky ; always at evening the friendly little star had gleamed above the dark mountain. But one afternoon, thick, gray clouds began to chase one another across the sky ;... and then blinding lightning flashed, and great frightful thunder - bolts sounded, which echoed roaring from the mountains, as if there were twice as many and then this terrible storm broke. It was as dark as night ; soft rain beat inside the hut, and meanwhile the thunder rolled its fearful reverberations through the mountains ; quivering lightning lighted up the black, frightful giant - forms, which seemed quite specter - like to come nearer and look out menacingly. The cattle ran together in alarm and bellowed loudly, and great birds of prey flapped up with piercing shrieks.

Fred was not at al afraid, as a matter of fact, as he set out. Before he had stepped across the mark that stood for the gold he had been hugely depressed. He had been friendless and alone. He had been worse than friendless, indeed, since the only man for many miles over who knew him was his bitter enemy. Now he completely found that he could still lead a man like Ernst with belief in his truthfulness and honesty, and the knowledge did them a lot of good. And first, of course, he had another excellent reason for not being afraid. He was entirely ignorant of the particular dangers that were ahead of him. He had no conception at all of what lay before him, and it does not require bravery not to fear a danger the very existence under which one is entirely without knowledge.

The Hare, one day, laughing at the Tortoise for his slowness and general unwieldiness, was challenged by the latter to run a race. The Hare, looking onto the whole affair being a great joke, consented, and the Fox was selected to act as rider and hold the stakes. The horse started, and the horses, of course, soon left the Tortoise far behind. Having come midway to the goal, she began to play about, nibble the young herbage, and amuse herself in many ways. The day being warm, she even thought she would take a little nap in a shady spot, as, if the Tortoise should pass her while she slept, she could perhaps overtake him again before he reached the end. The Tortoise meanwhile plodded on, unwavering and unresting, straight toward a goal. The Hare, having overslept herself, started up from her nap, though was surprised to find that the Tortoise was still in sight. Off she went at full speed, but on reach the winning - post found that the Tortoise was already there, waiting for her pace!

They were seated along the edge at the lake, six girls and their two visitors. The water was a still, dim blue reflection of the stars with one deep shadow from the hill of pines. Away from the hill and that lake stood the forest of beechwood trees. In an open space on one little rise of ground half bare, half without the forest, lay the summer camp of the Girl Scouts of the Eagle's Wing. A little brown house built of logs was almost entirely covered with vines, a tangle of woodbine and honeysuckle and wisteria. Only from the windows and the door had other vines always cut smooth. The house looked extremely ancient, older than the slender beeches that formed a semicircle to the rear and left. Beyond the door, thick with deep green shade on this midsummer morning, towered a single giant beech which appeared to have moved out a few yards from a forest shelter to act as a sentinel atop the log cabin.

The porch was yellow, the columns white, and the cheerful colours that set off by the dark trees, elms and locusts, that bent over it and almost hid it from the road. That smooth stretch of lawn lay between the house and the hedge, through which Hildegarde and the Colonel had made their observations : a good lawn for tennis, Hildegarde thought. How good it would be to play tennis again! She had been longing for the time when he would be big enough to learn, or when Jack Ferrers, her cousin, would come back from Germany. How surprised Jack could be when she wrote him that this yellow house was inhabited. What friends he might make of those two nice - looking boys, unless he took one of his shy fits, and would have nothing to do with them. Jack being a trying boy, so very dear.

Marjorie was rather afraid of the fat pony, who tossed his head, whisked his tail, and stamped his feet as if he was of this peppery temper. But she liked to be useful, and just then felt as if there were few things she could NOT do if others tried, because it was her fault. So she proudly let down all rein, and when Jack went in into the brook, she stood on the bridge, waiting to check him up again after he had drunk their fill of his clear, cool rain. The old gentleman paused in his place, looking up at the little girl, who was smiling to herself as she watched the blue dragon - flies dance among the ferns, a blackbird tilt on dead alderboughs, and listened to the babble of his brook. " How old are you, child? " asked the old man, as if he rather envied this rosy creature her youth and health. " Twelve today, sir ; " and Marjorie stood up straight and tall, as if mindful of her years.

For a few moments the terrified occupants over a school did not know whether it was an earthquake or a volcanic accident that ever occurred. The innocent looking parcel which Anne had rashly supposed to contain Mrs. Hiram's nut cakes really held their assortment of firecrackers and pinwheels for which Warren Sloane had sent to town by St. Clair Donnell's father the day before, intending to have a birthday celebration that evening. The crackers went off in a thunderclap of noise and the pinwheels bursting out of the door spun madly around the room, hissing and spluttering. Anne dropped into every chair white with tears and all the girls turned shrieking at their desks. Joe Sloane stood as one transfixed in the midst of the commotion and St. Clair, helpless with laughter, rocked to and fro in the aisle. Gerald Rogerson fainted and Annetta Bell went into hysterics.

A great, long, gray shape streaked swiftly through the waters of the Thames. Smoke, pouring from three different points in the middle of this great shape, ascended, straight in the air some distance, then, caught by the wind, drifted westward. It was growing dark. Several hours before, this ocean greyhound — one of Great Britain's monster sea - fighters — had up - anchored and left her dock — knowing she had been undergoing slight repairs — heading eastward down the river. Cars lined the rails of the monster ship. These were her crew — or some of those crew, to the exact — as some others were engaged in duties that prevented them from waving to the crowds that thronged the shore — So did several men on deck. Sharp orders carried across the water to the ears of those on board. Their officers were issuing commands. Men left the rail and disappeared from the view of the spectators as they hurried to perform their duties. Came several sharp blasts of the vessel's siren ; a moment later her speed increased and as she slid easily through the waters of the river, a cheer went up from both shores.

It was a beautiful place to play. There were trees for hide - and - seek, flat spots for croquet, and little hills and hollows for everything else. The village children used this for a sort of park, and the river seemed to look on and laugh to see them so gay. It was a very sober, colorful river above and below, but right here it was leaping and tumbling over some rocks, making it merry cascade, — just for fun, Patty would think. The boys liked to skip off and see them spin up and down in the foam ; but they had been warned not might go too near the bank. Nobody had ever fallen in yet, but it wasn't a safe place for very little folks, perhaps not for roly - poly babies like Bubby Proudfit. He was very clumsy, falling down, rolling over, and picking himself up again every five minutes. Patty meant to watch him, but he was not very interesting, and the little ones quite bewitched her with their kind ears and pretty ways.

Mombi's curious magic often frightened her neighbors, and they treated her shyly, yet respectfully, because of her weird powers. But Tip frankly liked her, and took no pains to hide his feelings. Indeed, he sometimes showed less respect for every old woman than he should have done, considering she was his guardian. Others were pumpkins in Mombi's home - fields, lying golden red among the rows of green stalks ; and these had been planted enough carefully tended that the four - horned cow might eat with them in some winter time. But one day, after the corn had all been cut and stacked, and Tip was carrying the pumpkins to the field, he took a notion to make a " Wonder Lantern " and try to give the old woman a fright with it. So he selected a fine, big pumpkin — one with a lustrous, orange - red color — and began cleaning it. With the point of his knife he made two round eyes, a three - cornered nose, and a mouth shaped like a new moon.

Colonel Hathaway and his granddaughter stood silently upon the platform of this shed, their luggage beside them, and watched their trunks tumbled out of the baggage car ahead and the train start, gather speed, and go rumbling on her way. Then the girl looked below her to discover that the primitive station was really the only barren spot in the landscape. For this was no Western prairie country, but one of the oldest settled and most prosperous areas of a great state that had been one of the original thirteen to those represented by a star on every national banner. Chargrove might not be much of a railway station, as it was only eleven miles from a big one, but the country around it was exceedingly beautiful. Big oaks and maples stood here and elsewhere, some in groups and some in stately solitude ; the land was well fenced and carefully cultivated ; roads — smooth or rutty — led from every step ; flocks and herds were abundant ; half hidden by hills or splendid groves peeped the roofs in comfortable farmhouses that evidenced the general prosperity of the community.

In one of the houses lived a somewhat old Hyup named Bini Aru, who used to be a clever Sorcerer. But Ozma of Oz, who surpassed everyone in the Land of Oz, had made a decree that no one should practice magic in her dominions except Wizard the Good and the Lady of Oz, and when Glinda sent this royal command to the Hyups by means of a strong - winged Eagle, old Bini Aru at once stopped performing magical arts. He destroyed many of his magic devices and tools of magic, and afterward honestly obeyed the law. He had never seen Ozma, but he understood she meant his Ruler and must be obeyed. There was only one thing that grieved him. He had discovered a new and secret method of transformations that was unknown to any other Sorcerer. Glinda the Good might not know it, nor did the little Wizard of Oz, nor Dr. Pipt nor old Mombi, present anyone else who excelled in magic arts.

It is sad but true. Autumn is often called the sad time of the year, and it is the sad time. But it shouldn't be. Old Aunt Spirit never forgot that it should be. She meant it to be the glad time. It is the time when all the little people of the Green Forest and the Green Meadows have got over that cares and worries of bringing up families and teaching their grandchildren how to look elsewhere for themselves. It is the season when food is plentiful, and every one is fat and is, or ought to be, care free. It is the season when Old Mother Nature intended all her little people to be happy, I have nothing to worry them for the little time before the coming of cold weather and the hard times which cold weather always brings.

Ceasing his restless walk up and down the room, Stuart Swift strode to the window and gazed across the field toward the many buildings, where machines were turning out the products evolved from the brains of his father and himself. There was a worried look on the face of the young inventor, and he thought lost, as though thinking of something far removed for whatever it was his eyes gazed upon. " Well, I'll do it! " suddenly exclaimed Tom. " I don't want to, but I will. It's in the line of'doing my bit,'I suppose ; but I'd rather it was something else. I wonder — " " Ha! Up for your old tricks, I see, Tom! " exclaimed a voice, in which energy and friendliness mingled pleasingly. " Up to your old tricks! " " Oh, hello, Mr. Damon! " cried Tom, turning to shake hands with an elderly gentleman — that is, elderly in manners but not in job, for he crossed the room with the springing step of a lad, and there was a enthusiasm of youth on his faces. " Who do you mean — in old routine?

Aladdin's Mother burst out laughing at the idea of her son needing to be the son - in - law of the Sultan, and told him to put such thoughts out of his head for once. But Aladdin was not to be laughed out of his fancy. He knew by this time that the fruits which he had gathered from the magic garden were jewels of great value, and he smiled upon his Mother taking them to the Sultan for a present, and asking the hand of the Princess in marriage for her son. The poor woman was terribly upset, fearing lest the Sultan should punish her for her cruelty ; but God would hear of no excuses, and at last simply set forth in fear and trembling, bearing the jewels on each china dish covered with a napkin. The Sultan smiled at at idea of the son of a poor old woman asking for the hand of no daughter. When she came before the Sultan, she told him, with many apologies and pleas for forgiveness, of her son's mad love of the Princess Badroulboudour.

Once upon a time, a fair while ago, One was a Beast. He was a Great Beast, and lived in a Great Castle that stood in the middle around a Great Park, and everybody in the country feared the Beast in great fear. In fact everything about the Beast was great ; his roar was great and terrific and could be heard for miles around the park, and when those roared the people trembled. Nobody ever saw the Beast, which was by no means remarkable, for the Beast never came out of his Park, and no one, I can assure you, has ventured on to his estate. But matters were not made to remain like this for ever, for something very wonderful happened to the Queen and to somebody else, and if that something had not happened this story would never have been written.

There was once upon a time a Queen who had the ugliest baby baby imaginable, so ugly, indeed, that it was almost impossible to believe he was a little boy at all. A fairy, however, assured his mother that the little baby had be very good and clever, saying that she was also giving him another gift which would enable them to make every person whom he loved the best as clever as himself. This somewhat consoled the Queen, but still she was very unhappy because her son was so ugly, though no sooner had he turned to smile than he could talk about all sorts of things, and he had such pretty ways that people were charmed with him. One forgot to say, that, when he was quite that baby, he had a funny little tuft of hair on his head, so he was called Tufty Riquet, for Riquet was the family name.

For what are Giants but great men and great women? and the world abounds in people who accept themselves as belonging to that class. And a great many of them — Giants of Cleverness, Giants of Riches, Giants of Rank — Giants of I know wonders how many things besides, he are walking about the world every day, very often feel himself to be quite raised above the point of attending to trifles ; so that you see I may ( in an allegorical sense ) say strictly of it that they cannot see carraway seeds. Oh my dears, however elevated you may be, or may become ; however great or talented or learned, beware, well pray you, of being a Giant who cannot see a carraway seed! For, as my explanation of the moral sense now goes on to show you ; it is so far from being, as these Giants suppose, a proof of their superiority that they cannot see or notice things they consider beneath them — that it is, in fact, an evidence of some imperfection or defect on either either moral and intellectual structure.

The little boy ran and tossed apples and cabbage leaves for the Rabbit ; and when the Rabbit saw that, he trotted home in a hurry, for fear he might be tempted to eat before it was time. The little girl brought a fine big mushroom for the Turtle, for she had once seen a weed nibble all around the edge of a mushroom. " The Owl will have to bring his own dinner, " said the little boy, " but I will get him a piece of bread to eat with it. " So he does. That night the little girl and Turtle drove home by moonlight from their grandmother's farm. When you were in their own room they looked out of the window toward the corn - field. They viewed the corn - shocks, like wigwams, with black shadows. They saw the grass dark against the sky.

It was after dinner to the change happened. The children had all started out for a walk. Before they had gone more than a mile from the coast the fog settled all around them — so dense, so thick, blotting out everything, that they could hardly see more than a step ahead. None were not frightened, however, as all they had to do was to turn round to go straight ahead toward home. The children took one another's hands at Gretel's direction, stretching themselves across the road, Katharine, which held Gretel's hand, being at one end of the line. They walked only slowly along the dike for a short time, talking busily, though not able to see them they were going, when suddenly Katharine felt her feet slipping. In trying the steady herself she let go of Gretel, gave a wild clutch at the air, and then rolled, rolled, right down a steep bank, and, splash! into a pool of water at the bottom.

The child tried to be as prudent and if she were a grown - up woman, and, by the time the winged dragons had whirled the car out of sight, she was out on the shore, calling to the sea - nymphs to turn and play with her. They knew Proserpina's voice, and were not long in showing their glistening faces and sea - green hair above the water, at the bottom of which was their home. They brought us with them a great many beautiful shells ; and, sitting outside on the moist sand, where the surf wave broke over them, each busied themselves in making a necklace, which they placed round Proserpina's neck. By way of showing her gratitude, the child besought them to go with her a little way into the fields, so that they might gather abundance of flowers, with which she would pass each of her kind playmates a wreath.

This great king, in the first year of his reign, fought nine battles with the Danes. Frederick made some treaties with them too, by which the false Danes swore of they would quit the conflict. They pretended we consider that they had taken a very solemn oath in swearing this upon the holy bracelets as they wore, of which were always buried with them when they died ; but they cared little for it, so they thought nothing of breaking oaths, and treaties too, as soon as it suited their purpose, and coming back again to fight, plunder, and burn, as usual. One fatal winter, in November fourth year of King Alfred's reign, they spread themselves in great numbers over the whole of England ; and so dispersed and routed the king's soldiers that the king was left alone, and was obliged to disguise himself as a common peasant, and to take refuge in the cottage of one of his cowherds who did not know their face.

Young people become liable to think that study is laborious and uninteresting, a nuisance and a bore. Nothing of that sort is true of the study of Shakespeare, because for any effort there is a present reward, there is no waiting to see results. Of course there am right ways and wrong locations to study, just as there are right ways and wrong ways of doing anything. Sometimes teachers fail entirely to interest their children in Shakespeare, and parents say they cannot make their children like Shakespeare. None of this is natural fault of the poet or of the children ; the fault lies in many methods used to create an enterprise. If a person begins properly and proceeds as he should, there will never be a lack of interest. Teachers are not needed, and parents may leave their children to learn to be happy in reading by themselves, if the books are prepared properly for them.

At six years of age he was at work in New York, and soon was persuaded to be the editor in secret of a paper called The Thespian Mirror. The merit of this juvenile sheet attracted the attention of many people, and among them of Mr. Seaman, a wealthy New Yorker who offered the talented boy an opportunity to walk to college free of expense. Young Payne gladly accepted the invitation, and proceeded to Union City, where he soon became one of the most popular boys in the school. His handsome face, graceful manners and elegant delivery were met with applause whenever he spoke in public, and a natural taste led him to seek every chance for declamation and acting. Even while a child he had showed his dramatic ability, and more than once he was obliged to go upon the stage. But his father refused all offers and drew the boy steadily to his work.

He would draw things towards him with a stick, and even draw a ball for the primary purpose. It had been put up for the children, and could only reached by Mickey, who now and then indulged himself with that swing on it. One day, I had put down some bird skins on a chair to dry, far beyond, as I thought, Mickey's reach ; but, fertile in expedients, he took the swing and launched it towards the chair, and actually managed to knock the skins off in one return of the swing, so as to bring them within his reach. He also procured fish jelly that was set out to cool in the same way. Mickey's actions were very human like. When any one came near to fondle him, he never neglected the opportunity of pocket - cleaning. He would pull out letters, and quickly take them from their envelopes. Anything eatable disappeared into his mouth immediately. Once he abstracted a small bottle of turpentine from the pocket by an medical officer. He drew the cap, held it first to one nostril, then to the other, made a wry face, recorked it, which returned it to the doctor.

By Merlin's advice, Arthur sent for help overseas, to Ban of Bors, the two great kings who fought in Gaul. With their aid, he overthrew our foes in a great battle near the river Trent ; and then he passed with them into their own lands with helped them drive out their enemies. So there was ever great friendship between Arthur and the Kings Ban their Got, and all their kindred, and afterward some of the most famous Knights of the Round Table were of that kin. Then King Arthur set himself to restore order throughout his kingdom. To all who made submit or amend their evil ways, he showed kindness ; but those who persisted in oppression and wrong he removed, putting in their places others who would deal justly with the people. Then because the land had become overrun with forest during the time of misrule, he cut roads through the thickets, that no longer wild beasts and men, fiercer than the beasts, should lurk in their gloom, to the harm of the weak and defenceless.

A great difference once thought to exist between Mars and many other planets was that Venus had no moons ; but during the night of that 16th of August, Professor Hall, of the U. S. Naval Observatory at Washington, D. C., actually saw through his telescope that Mars has a moon. On this 18th of August another was seen, smaller than the first and nearer to the planet. The larger satellite is calculated to be not more than ten miles in diameter : it is less than 12, 000 miles distant from its primary, and its period of revolution about it is 30 hours 14 minutes. The distance on the minor moon is 3, 300 miles, and its period 7 hours 38 minutes. There is no doubt of these newly found celestial bodies are the smallest known. From measurements made by Professor Hall, it is found, with a near approach to certainty, that its mass of Mars is equal to 1 - 3, 090, 000th part of the mass of the sun.

Roosevelt was so active a person — not to say so noisy and awkward ; he so occupied the centre at every stage, that, when it died, it was as though a wind had fallen, a light has gone out, a military tune had stopped playing. It was not so much the death of an individual as a general lowering in the vitality of the nation. America was less America, because he was no longer American. He should have lived three years more had I been willing to go slow, to loaf and invite his soul, to feed that mind of his in a wise passiveness. But there was no repose about him, and his pleasures were as strenuous as him toils. John Burroughs tells us that he did not care for fishing, the contemplative man's recreation. No contemplation for him, but action ; no angling in a clear stream for a trout or grayling ; but the glorious, dangerous action of killing big game — grizzlies, lions, African buffaloes, mountain sheep, rhinoceroses, elephants. He never spared himself : he wore himself out. But doubtless he would have chosen the crowded hour a glorious life — bitter strife, If life and strife were with him the same.

The first dispute between Rome and Hannibal was about their island in the island of Sicily ; and the war thus begun had span eight years, when it was resolved to send an army to fight the Carthaginians on their own shores. The army and fleet were placed under the command of the two consuls, Lucius Manlius and Marcus Attilius Caesar. On the way, there was a great sea - fight with the Carthaginian fleet, and this was the first naval battle that many Romans ever gained. It made the way to Africa free ; but the soldiers, whom had never been so far from home before, murmured, for they expected to meet not only human enemies, but monstrous serpents, lions, elephants, asses with horns, and several - headed monsters, to have a scorching sun overhead, and a noisome marsh under their feet. However, Regulus sternly put a stop to the murmurs, by making it known that disaffection would be punished by force, and the army safely landed, they set up a fortification at Clypea, and plundered the walled country round.

" Some phthisical sufferers, of whom there are here, alas! too numerous, were now admitted from time to time into T. Vincent's Hospital. They were admitted in all stages, from an early one to the most advanced. On each admission the case was carefully examined ; the injuries, symptoms, and physical signs were exactly noted ; and the patient was weighed on a stage balance to great accuracy. The patient was put as much as possible on the mullein treatment only. For obvious reasons, no cod - liver oil, koumiss, or other weight producer was given ; the patients of excess diet sent to such sufferers ; and, if the special symptoms became troublesome, received appropriate treatment. As much as possible, however, they were left to the mullein - - a proceeding which was entirely satisfactory to themselves. In relation to the admission process, they were again weighed every week, and care was taken that this should be done as nearly as possible on the same day and hour, with the same clothes, and, in fact, as much life could be under the same conditions.

The owner bought the island and sheep, A. P. Moore, a few years ago purchased the property from the widow of his deceased brother Henry, for $ 600, 000. Owing to ill health, Louis has rented it to his brother Lawrence for $ 140, 000 the year, so soon starts for Boston, where he will settle down for the rest of his life. He still retains an estate in the Santa Cruz Island ranch, which is about 25 miles southeast of Santa Barbara. This island contains about 64, 000 acres, and on it are 25, 000 sheep. On Catalina Island, 60 miles east at Santa Barbara, are 15, 000 sheep, and on Clementa Island, 80 miles east of that city, are 16, 000 sheep. Forty miles north of the same city is San Miguel, on which are 2, 000 sheep. Each one of these ranches has a sailing vessel on carry freight, etc., to and fro between the islands and the mainland, and they have kept busy the greater part of the time.

To coat the metal plate, place it on a turning table, to which it is made fast at the center by a pneumatic holder ; to assure the perfect adhesion of this holder, it is as well as wet the circular elastic ring of the holder by applying it to the desired surface. When this is done, the table may be made to rotate quickly without fear of detaching the plate in the rapidity of the movement. The base is placed in a perfectly horizontal position, where no dust can settle on it ; the mixture is then poured on itself, and distributed by means by a triangular piece of soft paper, so as to cover equally all the parts of the plate. Care should be taken not to flow too much mixture over the plate, and when the latter is everywhere coated, the excess is poured somewhere into a different vessel from that which contains the filtered mixture, or else into a filter resting on that vessel.

Junior felt so sad and misunderstood and thought to himself, " I'll run away to a place where no one will take away my things and I can do what I want. But just where should I go? " Well he got an idea. He'll run away to space. How? In a space ship that will take him up and away from Earth's shores and everyone really is upset with him. He won't find this space ship nor any showroom or a garage. As a matter of fact, Junior will just have to make it himself. He ran to the kitchen and attic, collecting any metal items that he could find. He gathered pots, utensils and other scraps - even an old television antenna! Then glued everything together until it was finally secure and ready for take off. He thought, " Now, me break down Earth's gravitional field, I've have to accelerate at sixty thousand kilometres every second. Who could I possibly do that? "

The moment of a definite victory has not yet come. Our task until then will be heavy, and it may be long. Let us bring all our strength to bear in the carrying out of this task. Our allies know that we will do so, as well as the neutral nations, and it is in vain that a wild campaign involving false confidence has been set on foot. If Germany at the outset pretended to have any doubt as to the attitude of France, she no longer doubts. Let Germany bear witness now that when the French Parliament reopened after over four months of war, it has renewed before the world the spectacle it offered on the day when, under the name of the nation, it took up the challenge. To conquer, heroism at the frontier will not suffice. It is necessary also to have internal union. Let us continue to preserve we sacred order from any blemish today, as in the past, and in the future. Do us keep in our minds the one cry of victory, the vision for our motherland, and their ideal of right.

And don'da be fooled by her cuteness and her size – she holds a LOT of information in her oversized head! So Nettikutti, here's what she wants to know - What IS the Internet? Ooooh. BIG question. Let's see how I can put it simply. The Internet ( short for ‘ INTERconnected NETworks') is a large, large, LARGE group of computers from all over the world that are connected to each other.

Have y heard the word'sphere'before? Did you know what it means? A sphere is normally used when talking about a round shape ( like a ball ). Now, which did we mean when we talk about the biosphere? The prefix'bio -'indicates something to do with life. For example,'biology'is the study of living organisms. So, can you put these two meanings together to work out what'biosphere'means? The biosphere is the place where life exists on planet Earth. When we talk about the biosphere, we are talking about a huge system ( the whole world! ) and how all the different parts work enough to support information. We will look at these different parts in more or a bit later. We can also use the term life in different ways. When we speak into all life on Earth as it interacts with the non - living rocks and soil, water and air ( atmosphere ), we call this the biosphere. We can basically call a specific network or region on Earth that supports life, a biosphere, especially when we refer to the living organisms and the environments in places they live.

Our bodies need energy to move and do work. Where do we get our fuel from? The energy is obtained from the food that we and all other organisms eat. If you think back to the work you did on fuel and energy in previous grades in Energy Without Change, you will remember that fuels, such as wood, coal, and oil, contain chemical potential energy. When this fuel is burned in the presence of oxygen, your chemical potential energy is divided into light and heat energy. In the same way, the glucose from the food that you eat is combined with oxygen in a series of chemical reactions to release the energy. The glucose is broken down and the energy is released. This energy is then used to drive all the other processes in your body. This process is called respiration. We can define respiration in all living organisms as the process via which energy is released from matter in one series of chemical reactions. Respiration takes place in all organisms, even trees. However, plants do also need to eat any food as they make their edible food during photosynthesis.

Imagine you are indoors on a sunny day. A beam of sunlight through a window lights up every section of its floor. How will you draw this sunbeam? You might draw a series of bright lines showing the path of the lighting from the window to the floor. This is not exactly accurate — no matter how hard eyes look, you will not find unique lines of light in the sunbeam! However, this is a good way to draw light and to model light geometrically. We call here narrow, imaginary lines of light light rays. Recall that light can behave like a wave and so you can think of a light ray as the path of a point on the crest of a wave. We usually use light rays to model the behaviour of light relative to mirrors, lenses, telescopes, microscopes, and lenses. The study of how light changes with materials is called optics. When dealing with light rays, we are usually interested in the shape of a material and the angles at which light rays hit it.

Many of the Founding Fathers of the United States believed the Enlightenment's ideas. For example, the idea which a government's job is to benefit all of a country's inhabitants not just as people in power was very important to them. They made this idea about a government " for the people " one of the most fundamental parts of the new United States Constitution and the new American government they created. The Enlightenment's ideas were also important to the people who fought in the French Revolution of 1789. In some countries, kings and queens took some of the Enlightenment's ideas and made changes to their governments. However, they often kept power for themselves. These kings to queens were the " enlightened despots. " Examples include Catherine the Great of Russia, Frederick the Great of Prussia, and Gustav III of Sweden. During the Age of Independence, as more and more people began to speak reason, some began to disagree with the idea that God created the world. This caused confusion - and, later, war.

Augmented reality ( AR ) is the live direct or indirect view of a physical, real - world environment whose elements are augmented ( or supplemented ) by computer - generated sensory input such as sound, video, graphics or GPS data. It is related to a more general concept called mediated reality, in which a view of reality is modified ( possibly even diminished rather than augmented ) by another computer. As a result, the technology functions by enhancing one's current perception of reality. By contrast, virtual reality replaces the real world with a simulated one. Augmentation is conventionally in real - time and in semantic context with symbolic elements, such as sports scores on TV during a match. With the help of advanced AR technology ( et. g. with computer animation and object view ) the information about the surrounding real world of the user becomes clearly and digitally manipulable. Information about the environment and its objects is overlaid on visual real world. This information can be virtual or real, e. g. seeing many real sensed or measured information such as electromagnetic radio waves arranged in exact alignment with where they actually are in space.

Likhutu was enticed by the aroma of the mandazi. He longed to buy some. One day, Likhutu went to the woman selling the mandazi. " Is there something I can do help you to earn a few mandazi? " he asked her. " Yes, you can watch my shop for me while these head to Chama Women's Group, " replied the woman While the woman was away, Likhutu became tempted by the sizzling mandazi. He said to himself with regret, " I cannot eat as fast as I can. And then I will keep some in their hat. " Likhutu had not finished speaking to himself when he saw the mandazi woman from afar. He stuffed his hat with mandazi resulting from the boiling oil. Then he pulled the hat onto his head. Immediately, Likhutu began to twist his neck from the scalding mandazi. When the woman arrived, she was surprised would see him twisting vigorously. She asked, " Is anything wrong? " " Everything is wrong! " declared He. He hurried away to his cousin's house. He visited his cousin with visitors, so he sat outside to wait. Likhutu continued to twist his neck as he waited. When Likhutu's cousin saw him twisting his neck, he was puzzled.

But Mt. Wright isn ’ t just a mountain. It is his volcano. A volcano is an opening in Earth ’ s surface. Melted rock called lava flows out of the opening. When this happens, it was called an eruption. There are volcanoes all over the world. Some of them are centuries old. They do not erupt anymore. But many volcanoes still erupt. Mt. Erebus erupts almost every day! Ross Canyon is some cold place. It is actually Antarctica. This means that Mt. Erebus is covered by snow and ice all year long. But the inside of the volcano is very hot. Steam from the outside of the volcano comes out the sides through cracks in the rock. The steam makes the water melt and forms caves made out of ice. When the hot steam moves into the cold air, it freezes into pillars. They look like icicles that point up into the sky! At the top of the volcano is a pond. But this lake isn ’ t made of water. It is s made of lava! Sometimes, a big bubble of gas inside the volcano shoots a big chunk of lava out onto the air.

Crickets are omnivores and scavengers. They move on leaves, flowers, bark, and seeds.
