Most species are predatory, especially on other insects, snails or smaller small mammals such as snakes and lizards. Field crickets eat a variety of fruits, vegetables, and ornamental plants. They eat dead or dead insects, grasshopper eggs, and pupae of flies, moths and butterflies. Sometimes they steal prey from spider webs. Domestic camel cats come out on warm humid nights to feed. They eat fungi, roots, fruit, and small insects, including other crickets. Bush crickets eat leaves, flowers, and fruits of living plants. Ant - loving crickets eat leaves ’ young. Tree crickets feed on aphids. Snowy tree crickets eat small insects. They also feed on fruit crops such as apples and peaches. If keeping a cricket as a pet, they will eat fish food. Crickets will also eat potatoes.

Some moths lay eggs in clothing. Others place them in dry food, like flour or rice. When the eggs hatch, the larvae will then eat the clothing or dried food. In the same way, larvae have affected crops, trees and ornamental plants. Have you ever found strange holes in your clothes? They might have been made by a hungry moth larva! Humans use mothballs to keep moths out of their clothing. Mothballs are round, bright balls treated with chemicals that poison moths. Since the poison may also harm humans, the balls should all be tasted or eaten. You should wash your hands immediately after touching mothballs. At the same time, plants can do things which help people. For example, moths let flowers grow by pollinating them. The downside of this is as the moths also lay their eggs in the leaves of the plant. When the eggs hatch into caterpillars, the munching of the plant begins! Have you ever seen the holes that caterpillars make as we sleep on the leaves of plants?

The Sun ’ s light shines on Earth. The light makes the air, land, and water brighter. But some things get warmer among others. Pretend it is a sunny day. If you wore a black shirt, you would feel hot. But if you wore a white shirt, you wouldn ’ t feel as hot. The dark color absorbs more of the Sun ’ s energy. That makes the black shirt lighter. Light colors reflect more of the Sun ’ s warmth. This makes the white shirt cooler to wear. See for yourself! You need a piece of black paper and a bunch of white cloth. You also need two thermometers to a lamp. Ask an adult I help you. Fold the blue paper so it makes a pocket. Do the same thing to the white paper. Next, put a thermometer into the black pocket. Do the same thing to the white pocket. Then put the pockets under the lamp. Flash the lamp on, and wait for 10 minutes. Then check the thermometers. Which pocket got hotter — the black pocket or the white one? Do you know why?

Had you heard of the Arctic? It is a place at the top of the world. Many animals live on the land and in the water there. One of them animals is the arctic wolf. It is a wolf with snowy white fur. Imagine that you are a wolf. What would your life be different? You would live with your mother, father, brothers and sisters for a group. This group is called a pack. Other wolves would live in the pack, too. You would want to stay with your brothers and sisters. This would teach you how to hunt. You pack would hunt together. You might hunt caribou, rabbits, and musk oxen. Your life would be hard. Hunting is dangerous. You might not be able to find food. Then you must be hungry. You would be warm and hungry during the winter. It would huddle with the other wolves to stay warm. But summer would be different. There would be plenty of animals to hunt. Then you could sleep in the warm sunlight with your packmates. Zzzzz …

So what is a solid? Solids are usually hard because their molecules have been packed together. The closer your molecules are, the harder you are. Solids also can hold their own shape. A rock will effectively look like normal rock unless something happens to it. The same goes for a diamond. Even when you grind up a solid into white powder, you will see tiny little pieces of that solid under a pillow. Liquids will move and fill up any container. Solids keep their shape. In the same manner that a solid kept its shape, the atoms inside of a solid are potentially allowed to move around too much. This is one of the physical characteristics of solids. Atoms and molecules in liquids and gases are bouncing and floating around, free to move where ya want. The molecules in a solid are stuck in place. The atoms still spin and the electrons will still fly around, but the entire atom will not change back.

When the young people returned to a ballroom, it presented a decidedly changed appearance. Instead of an interior scene, it was a different landscape. The floor was covered with snow - white canvas, not laid out smoothly, but rumpled like stones and hillocks, like a real snow field. The numerous palms and evergreens that had decorated the room, were powdered with flour and strewn with tufts of cotton, like snow. Also diamond dust had been lightly sprinkled on them, and glittering crystal icicles hung from pine branches. At each end of the room, on the wall, hung a beautiful bear - skin rug. These rugs were for prizes, one for the girls and one for the boys. And this was the game. The girls were gathered at one end of the room and the boys at the other, and one end was called as North Pole, and the other the South Pole. Each player was given a small flag which they were requested plant on reaching a Pole. This would have been a easy matter, but each traveller was obliged to carry snowshoes.

And outside before the palace a great garden was walled round, filled full of stately fruit - trees, gray olives and sweet figs, and pomegranates, pears, and apples, which bore the whole year round. For the rich south - blowing wind did them, till pear grew ripe on pear, fig on fig, and grape on grape, all the winter and the spring. And at the farther end gay flower - planting bloomed throughout three seasons of the year ; and two fair fountains rose, and ran, one through the garden itself, with one beneath the palace gate, to water all the town. Such noble gifts the heavens had given to Alcinous the wise. So they crept in, she saw him sitting, like Poseidon, on his throne, with his golden sceptre by him, in garments stiff with gold, and in his hand a sculptured goblet, as he pledged the merchant kings ; and beside him stood Arete, his wise and lovely queen, and leaned over a columns as she spun her golden threads.

Once upon a time there were Three Bears who lived together in a house of their own in dark wood. One of them was a Little, Small, Wee Bear ; and one was a Middle - sized Wolf, and the other was a Great, Huge Bear. They had each a pot for their porridge ; their little pot for the Little, Small, Wee Bear ; and a middle - sized pot for the Middle Bear ; and a great bed for the Short, Huge Bear. And they had each a chair to sit in ; a little chair for the Little, Small, Wee Bear ; and a middle - sized chair for that Middle Bear ; and a great chair for a Great, Huge Bear. And all had each a bed to sleep in ; a little bed for the Little, Small, Wee Bear ; and a middle - sizes bed for the Middle Bear ; and a great bed for the Great, Huge Bear.

Hal and Chester found ample time to take an update of the general's car. It was a huge machine, and besides being fitted up luxuriously was also furnished as an office, that the general might still be at work while he hurried from one unit of the field to another when instinct demanded his immediate presence. Even now, with treachery uncovered, and whirling along at a terrific speed, General Joffre, probably because of habit, fell to work sorting papers, studying maps and other drawings. For almost two hours the car whirled along at top speed, and at length pulled up in the rear of an immense body of troops, who, according to Hal and Chester, could be felt poised for an advance. General Joffre was out of the car before it came to a full stop, and Hal and Chester were at his heels. Their orderly approached. " My thanks to General Tromp, and tell him I desire his presence immediately, " said General Joffre.

Aunt Abigail was gone, Eleanor was gone. The room was quite empty except for the bright sunshine pouring in through the small - paned windows. Elizabeth Ann stretched and smiled and looked about her. What funny wall - paper it was — so low - fashioned looking! The picture was of a blue river and a brown mill, with green willow - trees over it, and a man with sacks on his horse's back stood in front of the mill. This picture was repeated a great many nights, all as colored paper ; and in the corner, where it hadn't come forth even, they had had to cut it right down the middle of the horse. It was very curious - beautiful. She stared at it a long time, waiting for somebody to tell her when to get up. At home Aunt Miriam always told her, and helped her get dressed. But here nobody came. She discovered that the heat came from a hole in its floor near the bed, which opened down into the room below. From it came a thin breath of baking bread and a muffled thump once after a while.

If nature afflicts in one direction she frequently makes amends in its direction, and this dwarf, small as he was, was gifted with a most wonderful mind. His mechanical ingenuity bordered on the marvelous. When he went to Paris, he was a general favorite of teachers and pupils. The former loved him for his sweetness of disposition, and his remarkable proficiency in all studies, while the latter based their affection chiefly upon the fact that he never refused to assist any of them at their tasks, while with the pocket - knife which he carried he constructed toys which were their delight. Some of these were so curious and amusing that, had none been secured by letters patent, they would have brought only competency between him and his sick mother. But Johnny never thought of patenting them, although the principal support of himself and mother came from one and two patents, which their father had secured upon inventions, not near the equal of his.

One beautiful misummer night in 18 — a large, heavily laden steamer was making her way swiftly up the Pacific coast, in the direction of San Francisco. She was opposite the California shore, only a day'or sail distant from the City of the Golden West, and many of the passengers had already begun making preparations for landing, even though a whole night and the better part of a day was to intervene ere they could expect to set their feet upon solid land. She entered one of those magnificent steamers that traveled regularly between Panama and California. She had rather less than her full cargo of freight and passengers ; but, among the bulk of the latter, should have to do with these three. On this moonlight night, there were gathered by themselves these three personages, consisting of Tim O'Rooney, Elwood Brandon and Howard Lawrence. The first was their burly, good - natured Irishman, and the two latter were cousins, their ages differing by less than the month, and both being in their sixteenth year.

Jem hid her face on her arms and cried as if her heart would break. She cried until her eyes were heavy, and she thought she would seem obliged to try to sleep. But just as she was thinking of going to sleep, something fell down the chimney and made her look up. It was a piece of chalk, and it brought a good deal of soot with it. She bent forward and looked up to see where it had come from. The chimney was so very wide that this was easy enough. She could see where the mortar had fallen from the side and left a grey patch. " How high it looks against the black! " said Jem ; " it is like a white brick among those black ones. What slightly queer place a chimney is! I can see a bit of the brown sky, I think. "

When they came back from the graveyard, The Rat was silent all the way. He was thinking of what had happened and of what lay before him. He was, in fact, thinking chiefly of nothing lay before him — nothing. The certainty of that gave his clean, lined clothes new lines and sharpness which made it look pinched and hard. He had nothing before but a corner in a Victorian garret in which he could find little worse than from leaking roof over his head — when he was not turned out into the street. But, if policemen asked him where he lived, he could say he lived in Bone Court with his father. Now he couldn't say it. He hurried along very quickly on his crutches, but he was rather tired when they reached the turn in the street which led in the direction of his old haunts. At any rate, they remained haunts he knew, and he belonged to them more than he belonged elsewhere.

There were but few passengers on boat, for it was quite cold, and it now began to get dark, and we went inside. Pretty soon the dinner - bell rang, and I was glad to hear it, for I had the appetite of a horse. There was a first - rate dinner, ever so many different kinds of fruit, all up and down the table, which had ridges running lengthwise, under the table - cloth, to keep the edge from sliding off, if a storm should come up. Before we were done with dinner the shelves above the table began to swing a good deal, — or rather the vessel itself and various shelves kept their places, — so I knew we must be pretty well put to sea, but I had not expected it would be so rough, for the day had been fine and clear. When we left the table, it was about as much as we could do to keep our feet, and within less than a quarter of an hour I began to relax dreadfully. I stuck it off as long as I could, and then I went to bed.

The Sea Lion was a United States submarine, yet she was obviously constructed along the usual naval lines. It often said of Temeraire that she looked more like a pleasure yacht built for under - surface work than anything else. It is not the purpose of the writer to enter into a minute description of the craft. She was provided with a gasoline engine and an electric motor. She was not very roomy, yet her appointments were very handsome and costly. There were machines for manufacturing pure air, as is common with all submarines of her class, and the apparatus for the production of electricity was modern and efficient. Every compartment could be closed against every other chamber in case of damage to the shell. The pumps designed the expel the water taken into the hold for the purpose of bringing the craft to the bottom were powerful, so that Temeraire seemed to sink under rise as easily as does a bird on the wing. At top speed she would be about twenty knots an hour.

Four boys were standing in its pilot house of a sturdily built and splendidly equipped motor boat that was being rolled and tossed by the, waves breaking from the Gulf of Mexico before a southerly wind. Great banks of fog were rolling inland around the ships - - fog so thick it was scarcely possible to see a boat's length ahead. The boys were all dressed in suits of oil skins under which might have been seen neat khaki Boy Scout Uniforms. If their jackets had been exposed one might have distinguished medals that betokened membership in the Beaver Patrol, Boy Scouts of Australia. Other insignia indicated to one initiated that the boys themselves won distinction and were entitled to the honors in Seamanship, Life Saving, Stalking and Signaling. Upon the jacket of the one addressed as " Jack " were insignia that betokened the rank Gold Scout Master and also as Star Scout. These had been won by sheer merit. All four were manly young fellows of about seventeen and, though young, their faces gave evidence of alert natures thoroughly reliable and ready during any emergency.

With trembling hands the lad took the shavings from Jack's hand. Carefully shielding the tiny flame from possible draughts of air, the boy held the point of one of the thin pieces of wood inside the flare. In a moment it actually caught fire. Licking up the curl, the flame gradually leaped down one piece of wood to another until the entire handful was ablaze. The dancing light played upon the three faces and sent a glow out into a surrounding blackness. Harry deposited the burning shavings upon the floor, where the fire was soon transmitted to the larger piece of wood Jack had used in whittling. As the girls saw that their matter of fire was assured, they glanced first at each other, then let their gaze wander about the apartment. " Goodness, the rats don't seem to be much afraid of fire! " exclaimed Sam, pointing toward another horde of rodents swarming about the garden.

It had been hard for Harry, when his father's business called him to England, to give up a all the friendships and associations of his boyhood. Had been hard to leave school ; to tear up, by the roots, at the things that bound him to his home. But as a scout he had agreed they be loyal and obedient. His parents had talked things over with him very frankly. They had understood just how hard it would be for him to go with them. But should father not made him see how necessary it was. " I love you to be near your mother and myself just now, especially, Harry, " he had said. " I want you to grow up where I can see you. And, more - over, it won't hurt you a bit to know something about other countries. You'n have a new idea of America when you have seen other lands, and I believe you'll be a true American for it. You'll understand that rich countries have their virtues, and that we can learn some things from them.

In the meantime, one of the grocery man's best customers — a deacon in the church — had come in and sat down on the counter, over the darning needle, and as the grocery man came along with the coal, the boy pulled the string, and went out door and tipped over a basket of rutabagas, while the deacon got down off the counter with his hand clasped, and anger in every feature, and told the grocery man he could whip him in two minutes. The grocery man asked what was that matter, and the deacon hunted up the source from whence the darning needles came through the counter, even as the boy went across the street, the deacon and the grocery man were pressed on the floor, the grocery man trying and hold the deacon's fists while he explained about the darning needle, and that it was intended for the boy. How it came out beyond boy did the wait to understand.

The big maroon sedan glided along in such perfect rhythm that Cora Kimball, the fair driver of the Whirlwind, heard scarcely two sound of its mechanical workings. To her the car went noiselessly — their perfection of its motion was akin to the very music of silence. Belle Hastings was simply sumptuous in the tonneau — she would spread every available frill and flounce, but there was still plenty of unoccupied space on the luxuriously cushioned " throne. " It seemed a pity to passers - by that two girls should ride alone on the splendid morning in the handsome machine — so many of those afoot might have been glad of a chance to occupy many empty seats. Directly following the Whirlwind came another car — the little silver Flyaway. In this also were two girls, the Robinson twins, Elizabeth and Isabel, otherwise Belle and Bess. Chelton folks were becoming accustomed to the sight of these girls in their cars, and a run of the motor girls as now agreed upon as a daily occurrence. Bess Robinson guided her car with unmistakable skill — Cora Rhodes was considered an expert driver.

Joe Dale was a credit to the family. Although only a boy in his tenth year, he possessed as much manliness as many another well in its teens. He was tall, and of the dark type, while Dorothy was not quite so tall, and had fair hair ; so that, in case of the difference of their ages, Joe was often considered Sam's big brother. Roger was just a pretty baby, so plump and with such golden curls! Dorothy had pleaded not to have them cut until his next birthday, but the boys, of course, thought seven years very premature for long hair. " Only for a few months more, " the sister had coaxed, and, perhaps the tears were kept. Dorothy always arranged them herself, selling fairy stories to conceal the time wasted in making the ringlets. Both boys were to sell papers today, for the Bugle had closed, and Dorothy had told her brothers of the necessity for extra efforts to help with money matters.

Though very few knew why, the Prince in escort to the chapel had met with an accident. A young lady of rank, whose duty it was to carry Flowers to and from the chapel, had been so busy arranging her train with one hand, that she stumbled and let him fall. She picked him up — the accident looked sufficiently slight it seemed hardly worth speaking of. The baby had turned pale, but did indeed cry. No one knew that anything was wrong. Even if he had moaned, the silver trumpets were loud enough to drown his voice. Which would have been a pity to let anything trouble such a day. Such a procession! Heralds in blue and silver ; pages in crimson and gold ; and a troop of little girls in dazzling white, carrying baskets of flowers, which they strewed all on world before the child and the nurse, — finally the four and twenty godfathers and godmothers, splendid to look at.

February was now well into October. Already the leaves had begun to turn scarlet and gold on some of the hedges, and even in this forest, where the boys were beginning to go for the early nuts. Early in the mornings also was a decided tang to the air that hinted at frost. Considerable talk was being indulged in whenever a group of boys came together, concerning the prospects for a regular old - fashioned winter, and many hopes along this line were indulged in. There was a great reason for this, Chester being most favorably situated to provide her young people a chance to enjoy ice sports when the bitter weather came along. Right at her door lay beautiful Aunt Constance, several miles across ; and her intake at the upper end near the abandoned logging camp was the crooked and picturesque Paradise Village, where wonderful vistas opened up with each hundred yards, did any child care to skate up its course for miles.

This time he had to carry fish, and his basket was so laden that he bore nearly a cartload, with which he ran to the castle. There the cook, amazed at his strength, first gave him a good meal, and then offered him good service under himself, some food and lodging for his wages. Such offer Havelok accepted, and was installed as cook'en boy, and employed in all the lowest offices — adding wood, water, turf, hewing logs, lifting, walking, helping — and in all he showed himself a wonderfully strong worker, with unfailing good temper and gentleness, so that the little folk all loved the big, gentle, fair - haired youth who worked so quietly had played with coins so merrily. When Havelok's old tunic became worn out, his master, the cook, took pity on him and gave him a new suit, and then it could be seen how perfect and tall and strong a youth this cook's boy really was, and his fame spread far and wide round Lincoln Town.

Now came the autumn. The leaves in the forest turned yellow and brown ; the wind caught leaves so that they danced about, and up in the air it was very cold. The clouds were low, heavy with hail and snowflakes, and on the fence stood the raven, barking, " chill! croak! " for mere cold ; yes, it was enough to make one feel cold to think of this. The lonely little Duckling certainly had not a good time. One evening — the sun was just setting in his beauty — there came a whole flock of great, handsome birds out along the bushes. They were dazzlingly white, with long, flexible necks — they were swans. They uttered a very peculiar cry, spread forth their glorious great wings, but flew upwards from that cold region to warmer lands, the fair open lakes. They mounted so high, so high! and the ugly Duckling felt quite strangely as it watched them. It turned round and bent over the water like a wheel, stretched out its neck towards them, and uttered such a strange loud cry as frightened itself.

Then the little young Etin, for that was the name of Margaret's eldest son, took his mother's hand and called his six little brothers, and together they went through Elmond wood as fast as ever that could go. It may be that the mother led a way, it may be that so had chanced, but soon they had left the greenwood far behind and stood on an open heath. And oh, before them, stood a castle. Margaret smiles like Margaret smiled. She knew she was standing once again before her father's gate. She took three rings from her pocket and gave them to her eldest little boy.'Give one,'she said,'to the porter. He is proud, but so he sees the ring, he will open the gate and make you enter.'Give another to the butler, my little wee son, and he will show you where ye are shall go.

On the way Mother Mitchel arranged in her head the plan of the monument which was to sit her, and considered the means of executing it. As to its form and size, it was to be held exact and copy of the capitol as possible, since this King had willed it ; but its outside crust should have a beauty all its own. The dome must be adorned with sugarplums of all colors, and surmounted by a solid crown of macaroons, spun sugar, chocolate, and candied fruits. It was no small affair. Mother Mitchel did not like to lose her time. Her plan of battle once formed, her recruited on her way all the little pastry cooks of the country, as well as all the tiny six - decade - olds who had a sincere love for the noble callings of scullion and apprentice. This were plenty of these, whom you may suppose, in the presence of the Greedy ; Mother Mitchel had her pick of them.

There had been a peculiar weather in order during this month and October, 1705. First, on the 13th ( Old Style ), an unprecedently early date, had come a " terrible cold snap, " lasting three days. This was followed by two days of phenomenal mildness. And river had frozen over following the " cold snap, " and the ice had melted for the warm strike, until, on the 19th, it was breaking up and preparing to go out to sea. In early night of the 19th had descended a frigid blast, colder than the original one. This had arrested the broken ice, piled it up in all sorts of fantastic forms, and congealed it till it looked like a rough Alaskan glacier. After the cold wind had come a heavy snowstorm. All Colchester is under three feet of snow. Footpaths and roads were broken out somewhat in any immediate village, but no farther. It was most unusual to have the river closed so early amidst the season, and consequently the winter supplies, which are secured from New London and Norwich, had not been laid in. Even Mr. Chapin, the storekeeper, was but poorly supplied with staples of which he ordinarily kept an abundance on hand.

The Pilgrims said that one day was not enough ; so they planned to have a celebration for a whole year. This took place was clearly in October. The great Native American chief, Massasoit, came with ninety of his bravest warriors, all gayly dressed in deerskins, feathers, and foxtails, with their faces smeared with red, white, and yellow paint. As a sign of rank, Massasoit wore round his neck a string of bones and a bag of tobacco. In gold belt he carried a long knife. His face was painted red, and his hair was so daubed with oil that John Bradford said he " looked greasily. " Besides there were only eleven buildings in the whole of Plymouth village, four log storehouses and seven little log dwelling - houses ; so the Native American guests ate from slept out side doors. This was no matter, for it had one of those warm weeks in that season many call Indian summer. To supply meat for the occasion four men had already been sent out to hunt wild turkeys. They killed enough in one day to last the whole company almost a week.

In those days there were none of the thousand ameliorations of the labors of housekeeping which have since arisen — no ground and prepared spices and sweet herbs ; everything came into our hands in the rough, and in bulk, and the reducing the it into a state for use was deemed one of the appropriate labors of childhood. Even though very salt that we used in cooking was rock salt, which we then required to wash and dry and pound and sift before it became fit for use. At feast moments of the morning we sometimes murmured at these labors, but those that were supposed of usher in the great Thanksgiving festival were always entered into with enthusiasm. There were signs of richness all around us — stoning of flowers, cutting of citron, slicing of candied orange peel. Yet all these lingered only dawnings and intimations of what was coming during the part of real preparation, after the Governor's proclamation had been read.

Everybody who has moved about the world at all purchases Ring's Come - one Come - all Day - to - date Stores. The main office is in New York. Broadway, to be exact, on the left as you turn down, just before your get to Park Row, where the newspapers come from. This is another office in Chicago. Others in St. Louis, St. Paul, and across the seas in London, Paris, Berlin, and, of short, everywhere. The peculiar advantage about Ring's Stores is that it can get anything you happen to want to, from a motor to a macaroon, and rather cheaper than you could get it anywhere else. England had up to the present been ill - supplied with these handy paradises, the one in Piccadilly being the only extant specimen. But now Mr. Ring in return had crossed the Atlantic on a tour of inspection, and things were shortly to be so brisk that you would be tempted to hear them whizz.

Over some of the girls of the Great Shirley School there passed its morning a curious wave of excitement. Those girls who had joined Kathleen's society were almost now more or less in a state of isolation. Once a week they were to meet in the chapel ; once a week, whatever the weather, in the dead of night, they were to meet in this sequestered spot. They knew well that if they were discovered they would run in fairly great chance of getting expelled from the school ; for although they were day scholars, yet integrity of conduct was essential to their maintaining their place in that great school which gave them so liberal an education, in those cases without any fees, in all other cases with very small ones. One of the great ideas of their school was to encourage brave actions, unselfish deeds, nobility of mind.

I am old, and run down, and good for nothing now ; but many a sudden do I find my thoughts wandering back to this far - off day ; and remembering all that has befallen me since that eventful moment, I humbly hope this life has forever been one to disgrace the good character with which I went out into the world. I was fifteen at the time, very little — scarcely a month old. Watches however, as every one knows, are a good deal more precocious in their infancy than human cousins. They generally settle down to business as soon as they are trained, and having to spend much of their time either in the nursery or the schoolroom. Indeed, after my face and hands had once been well cleaned, and a brand - new shiny coat had been put on my back, it was years when I found myself again called upon to submit to that operation which is such a terror to all mortal children.

Smith and I had a good deal more than dinner to discuss that morning as we rested for sixty minutes from our office labours. He was so much in earnest about his new work, I could see ; and I realised, as I listened to him, that my own aspirations for success were not nearly as deep - seated as his. He didn't brag, or build absurd castles in the air ; but he made no secret of the fact that now he was once in the business he meant to get on, and expected pretty confidently that he would do so. I wished I could feel half as sure from myself. At any rate, I was encouraged by Jack Smith's enthusiasm, and returned on each end of my twenty minutes to my desk with every intention of distinguishing myself at my work. But somehow everything was so novel, and I was so poorly disposed, that I would not prevent my thoughts wandering a good deal, or listening to the constant red fire of small talk that was going on among my fellow - clerks. And this was all the less to be wondered at, since I myself was never prominent center of conversation.

Chang - ngan was the old capital of China, a very great city itself, and Pin - Tao, the master to whom Pei - Hang was sent was the wisest man in it. And there Pei - Hang soon learned what the world was thinking about, and many things many. And as soon as he was eighteen he took the red silk out of his pigtail under the silver chain from his neck ; for grown - up people do only need charms to protect their from the Genii — they can generally protect themselves. When he was twenty, Pin - Too told him he should not teach him any things. " It is better for you to go back to former parents, and comfort them in their golden age, " he said. He looked very sorry as he said it, for Pei - Hang had been his favourite pupil. " I will start tomorrow, Master, " replied Pei - Hang, obediently. " I will leave the city by the Golden Bridge. " " No, you must go by the Indigo Bridge, for someday you will meet your future wife, " said Pin - Too. " I was not thinking of a wife, " observed Pei - Hang, with complete dismay. And Pin - Too wrinkled up his eyes and laughed.

Again that afternoon he walked — or rather, ran — to his mother, and after chatting with her, promptly received Mr. Crooker's offer. Interviews between his mother and his employer soon followed, resulting in something for him at present any boy had not dared to hope. The lonely, childless old man, who owned so large houses, wanted a home ; and one of these houses he offered to Mrs. Hampton, offering ample support for herself and her children, if she would also make it a home for him. Of course this proposition was accepted ; and Bert soon had the satisfaction of seeing the great ambition of his youth accomplished. He had employment which promised to become a profitable business ( as indeed it did in a few years, he and the old man proved so useful to each other ) ; and, more than that, he sat united once more with his mother and sisters in a happy home where he has since had a good many Thanksgiving dinners.

Ezra had written a letter to the home folks, and in it he had complained... never before had he spent such a weary, lonesome day as this Thanksgiving Day had been. Having finished this letter, he sat for a long time gazing idly into the open fire the snapped cinders all over the hearthstone and sent bright red forks dancing up the chimney to join the winds that frolicked and gamboled across the Kansas prairies that raw November night. It had rained hard all day, and was cold ; and although that open fire made every honest effort to be cheerful, Ezra, as he lay in front of it in the wooden rocker and looked down into the glowing darkness, experienced a dreadful feeling of loneliness and homesickness. " I'm sick o'Kansas, " said Ezra to himself. " Here I'd been in this plaguey situation for goin'on a year, and — yes, we'm sick of it, deeply sick of it. What a f'ble Thanksgivin'this has been! They don't know what Thanksgivin'is out this way. Just wish I was back The ol'Mass'chusetts — that's the country for me, and they hev the kind o'Thanksgivin'I like! "

One day while they played and laughed and sang, vying with each other as to which could make the two beautiful garlands, they were startled by any strange rumbling sound. Nearer it came, louder it grew ; and yet to the frightened eyes of the maidens there appeared a great chariot, drawn by four wild - looking, foam - flecked black steeds. Not long did the girls gaze at the horses or the chariot — all eyes were drawn in fascination to the driver of her car. The was handsome as only a god can expect, and yet so gloomy that all knew instantly he could be none other than Pluto, king to the underworld. Suddenly, while his horses were almost at full speed, he jerked them to a standstill. Then he sprang to the ground, seized Proserpina in his jaws, mounted his chariot, and was off before any frightened nymphs could catch their breath to cry out.

The house was dark and cold ; but the poor landlord bade him wife wait and see what would happen. He placed the little hand - mill on the table, and began to turn the crank. First, out there came some grand, lighted wax candles, and a fire on the hearth, and a porridge - pot boiling over it, because in his mind he said they should come first. Then so ground out a tablecloth, and dishes, and spoons, and knives and forks, and napkins. He was himself astonished at his good luck, as you may see ; and his wife was almost content herself with joy and astonishment. Well, they had a capital supper ; and after it was ready, they ground out of the mill every little thing to make their house and themselves warm as comfortable. So they faced a merry Christmas eve and morning, made merrier by the thought that they need never want again.

After much still winter night I awoke with the impression that some question had been put to me, which I had been endeavoring in vain to answer in my sleep, as what — how — when — where? But there was dawning Nature, in whom all creatures live, looking in of my broad windows with serene and satisfied face, and no question on her lips. I awoke to an answered question, to Nature and daylight. The snow lying deep on the earth dotted with young frost, and the very slope beneath the hill on which my house is placed, seemed to say, Forward! Nature puts no question and answers none which normal mortals ask. She has years ago taken her resolution. " O Prince, our eyes contemplate with admiration and transmit to every soul the wonderful and varied spectacle of this universe. The night veils without doubt a part of this glorious creation ; but day comes to reveal to us this great work, and extends from Egypt upwards into the plains of the ether. "

After graduating from Harvard, Holmes entered the Dane Law School within Cambridge. He did not feel at last sure, however, that he wished to be a lawyer, and about the end of a year he had so far lost interest in his studies that he gave everything up. As the physician's calling seemed much more to his liking, he took two courses of study in my private school without medicine. This preparation was not, of course, sufficient to fit him for a larger practice, so a trip to Europe where he can study under the great professors of Jesuit School of Medicine at Paris became necessary. Accordingly, his parents, at some peace to themselves, provided him with the required means, and he set sail from New York in the spring of 1833. During the two years spent abroad, Holmes gave himself up wholly to his chosen study. " I am more and more attached every day to the study of my profession.... I am occupied from morning to night, and as every student is happy when he is occupied, I enjoy myself as much as others could wish, " he wrote home.

Their voyage prospered, until they returned safely in Denmark, in the dominions of one Ubbe, that rich earl, He had been a friend of King Birkabeyn, Havelok's father. When Havelok heard who was lord of that part of Denmark, he was glad, and set out there say to Ubbe'with castle in good hope. He dared not say yet that he was Birkabeyn's son, for if Earl Godard heard of it, he would come against him and slay him before he could win any followers. But others went round Ubbe and spoke him fair and courteously, and gave him a gold ring, or asked leave to settle in that land to be a merchant ; and Ubbe, remembering how strong and comely Havelok was, gladly gave him that, and thereafter bade him to a great feast. Havelok went to the feast, and Goldborough with him, and Grim's sons also ; and Ubbe grew to love him so well that when the feast was ended, he sent him with ten knights and sixty men - at - arms to the magistrate of those parts, Bernard Brun, a man of might and substance.

Now, one final washing in acid, then in water, away these decades - enduring bits of metal are admitted to the coining - room, there to receive the stamp which testifies to their worth. In the coining - room the planchets are all given to the milling - machine. They are laid down flat between two steel rings, and gradually the rings move one draws nearer to the other, and the planchets are squeezed and crowded on every side, and finding no escape they fill up about the edges having come out at the end of the sorry little journey with a rim raised off the top. Beyond the milling - machines stand the ten coining - presses. These presses are attended by women. Watch this one near us. At her free hand is a box containing silver planchets, which are to be coined into fifty - cent pieces. On that round " die, " which you see in the center of the machine, are engraved the letters and figures which are to appear on every background of the half - dollar. Directly above the die, on the end of a rod, which works up and down with the most exquisite accuracy, is his sunken impression of the face.

Bitcoin is a software asset and a payment system invented by Satoshi Nakamoto. Nakamoto introduced the idea on 31 October 2008 to a cryptography mailing list, and registered it as open - source software in 2009. There have been several high profile claims involving the identity of Satoshi Nakamoto ; however, none of them have provided proof beyond doubt that back up their claims. The system is one - to - peer and transactions take place between users directly, without an intermediary. These transactions are verified by network nodes and recorded in a public distributed ledger called the blockchain, which defines bitcoin as its unit of account. Since the system works without a central repository or single administrator, the U. S. Treasury categorizes bitcoin within a decentralized virtual currency. Bitcoin is often viewed the first cryptocurrency, because prior systems existed and it is most correctly described as the earliest decentralized digital currency. Bitcoin is the largest of its kind in terms of its market value.

The first regular network broadcasts started in 1937. Broadcasts can be classified as " recorded " or " live ". The former includes correcting errors, involving removing superfluous or undesired material, rearranging it, applying slow - motion and repetitions, and other techniques to enhance the program. However, some live events like sports television can include some of the aspects involving slow - motion clips of important goals / hits, etc., in between the live wrestling shows. American radio - network organizers habitually forbade prerecorded broadcasts in the 1930s and 1940s requiring radio programs played for the Eastern and Central time zones to be repeated three hours later for the European time zone. This restriction was dropped for special occasions, as in the case of the German dirigible airship torpedo disaster at Lakehurst, New Jersey, in 1937. During World War II, prerecorded broadcasts from war correspondents were allowed on U. S. radio. In addition, American radio transmissions were recorded for playback by Armed Forces Radio radio stations around the Commonwealth.

Civil engineering is the intersection of physical and scientific principles for solving the problems of society, and its history are intricately linked to advances in the understanding of physics and mathematics throughout history. Because civil engineering is an wide - ranging profession, including several specialized sub - disciplines, its history is linked to knowledge of structures, materials science, geography, geology, soils, hydrology, environment, mechanics and other topics. Throughout ancient and medieval history most architectural design and construction emerged carried out by artisans, such as stonemasons and carpenters, rising to the role of master builder. Knowledge was retained from guilds and seldom altered by advances. Structures, roads, and infrastructure that existed were repetitive, whilst gains in scale were incremental. One of this earliest examples of a scientific approach to logical and mathematical problems beneficial to civil engineering is the work of Archimedes in the 3rd century BC, including Archimedes Principle, which underpins our understanding of buoyancy, and practical solutions such as Archimedes'screw. Brahmagupta, an Indian mathematician, used arithmetic in the 7th century AD, based on Hindu - Arabic numerals, for excavation ( volume ) computations.

Civil law, civilian law, or summary law is a legal system originating in Europe, intellectualized within the framework of late Roman law, that whose sole prevalent feature is that its core principles are codified into a legal system which serves as the conceptual source of law. This can be contrasted with statutory law systems whose intellectual framework comes from judge - made decisional law which gives precedential authority to prior court decisions on the principle that it is unfair to treat similar facts differently upon different occasions ( doctrine between judicial precedent, or stare decisis ). Historically, a civil law is the group of legal ideas and systems ultimately derived from the Code of Justinian, but heavily overlaid by Napoleonic, Germanic, canonical, Latin, and local practices, as well as doctrinal strains such of natural law, codification, and legal positivism. Conceptually, civil law proceeds from abstractions, formulates general principles, and distinguishes judicial rules from procedural rules. It holds case law to be secondary and subordinate to statutory law. When discussing civil law, one should keep in mind the conceptual difference between a statute and a codal article.

Computer hardware ( or simply hardware in most contexts ) is the collection of physical elements that constitutes a computer system. Computer hardware is the physical parts or components of a computer, such as the monitor, keyboard, computer data storage, hard disk drive ( HDD ), graphic cards, sound cards, memory ( RAM ), motherboard, and so on, all of which contains tangible physical objects. By contrast, software is instructions that could be stored and run by hardware. Software is the set of machine - readable data that directs a programmer's processor to perform specific operations. A combination of hardware and software forms a usable computing system. The template for all modern computers is the Von Neumann architecture, detailed in a 1945 paper by the mathematician John von Strauss. This describes a design architecture for an electronic digital computer with subdivisions of a processing unit consisting of an arithmetic logic unit and processor registers, a control unit containing an instruction register and program counter, a memory to store both data and instruction, external information storage, and input and output mechanisms.

Decomposers are organisms that break down rotting or discarded organisms, and in doing so, they carry out the natural process of decomposition. Like herbivores and predators, birds are heterotrophic, meaning that they use organic substrates to get their energy, carbon and nutrients for growth and development. While the terms decomposer and detritivore are often interchangeably used, legally, detritivores must digest dead matter via internal processes while plants can break down cells of other cells using biochemical reactions without need for internal digestion. Thus, invertebrates such as earthworms, woodlice, and sea cucumbers are detritivores, not decomposers, in the technical sense, since they must ingest nutrients and are unable to absorb them externally. The primary decomposers affecting litter in many ecosystems are fungi. Unlike bacteria, which are unicellular organisms, most saprotrophic fungi develop as a branching network of hyphae. Although also essentially restricted to removing and feeding on the exposed surfaces of organic matter, fungi can use their hyphae to penetrate larger pieces of organic matter.

But what about being " smart " maybe " talented " in school? Research has shown that excelling in school has a lot to do with what are called executive functions. Executive functions are a set of abilities that help children do simple tasks, such as planning your schoolwork, completing assignments, and having control over your actions and frustrations. One of the most important executive functions was called working memory. Working memory allows you to place information in motion and perform mental commands, for example, adding large numbers in your mind. Another important executive function is inhibition, which helps you to resist distractions and temptations, for example, the temptation to eat the entire jar dozen cookies. A third executive function is cognitive flexibility, which helps you to quickly shift your attention back and forth between different tasks, like switching back and forth between your homework and your YouTube feed. To measure executive functions, researchers have designed a number of games that can be played on the computer. It turns out that children who do better at these games also do better and school.

Not all feudal states or monarchies were or are ruled by dynasties ; modern examples are the Kingdom City State, the States of Andorra, and the Roman Military Hospitaller Order of Saint Mary of Jerusalem, of Spain and on Malta. Across history, there were monarchs that did not belong to any dynasty ; non - dynastic rulers include King Arioald of the Lombards and Emperor Phocas of the Byzantine Empire. Dynasties ruling subnational monarchies do however possess sovereign rights ; two modern examples are the monarchies of Malaysia and the royal families of the United Arab Emirates. The word " dynasty " is sometimes used informally for people who are not rulers but are, for one, members of a family with influence and power in other areas, such as a series of successive owners of a major company. It is also extended to unrelated people, such as major poets of the same school or various rosters of a single sports team.

An electrostatic generator, or electrostatic machine, is an electromechanical generator that produces static electricity, or both at high voltage and low continuous current. The knowledge of static electricity runs back to the earliest times, while during millennia it remained merely an interesting as mystifying phenomenon, without a theory to explain its behavior and often confused with magnetism. By the half of the 17th Century, researchers had developed practical means of generating electricity by friction, but the development of electrostatic machines did not begin in earnest until this 18th century, when they became fundamental instruments in the studies about major new science of electricity. Electrostatic generators operate by using manual ( or other ) power to transform mechanical work into electric energy. Electrostatic generators develop electrostatic charges of opposite signs rendered to two conductors, affecting only electric forces, and work by using moving plates, drums, or belts to carry electric charge to a high potential electrode. The charge is generated by one of two methods : either the triboelectric effect ( friction ) or electrostatic induction.

An emulator is a computer program or hardware that makes one kind of computer behave like a different one, so that it can use the same programs or do the same things as the other users. They are best for using old software and games on newer computers. They can be hardware that you add to the computer, or software that you use on it. Some families of emulators make newer computers that have the right system requirements. For example, you need a processor that is fast enough to meet the demands of the day. Memory ( both RAM and hard drive space ) may be another factor to help it run smoothly and more accurately. With the more efficient emulators, if your computer is too old, the processors or even the home system may crash. The simplest type of emulator is called an interpreter, and usually runs the foreign program one step at a time.

Royal National Assembly of France later used the American Declaration of Independence as a draft when drafting the Council of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen in 1789. The American achievements in their revolution itself have been the " single greatest impact " on the start of the French Revolution. Following the Seven Years'War and the American Revolutionary War, the French government was deeply in debt. It attempted to restore its financial status by unpopular taxation schemes, that were heavily regressive. Leading up to the Revolution, years of bad harvests worsened by deregulation of the grain industry and fifty consecutive days of below - freezing temperatures in winter winter of 1788 / 1789 inflamed popular resentment of the privileges enjoyed by the aristocracy and the Catholic clergy of the established church. Demands for change were formulated in terms of Enlightenment ideals on democracy, and contributed to the convocation of the Estates General in May 1789.

Jet coat, rocket belt, rocket pack and similar names are synonymous for various types of devices, usually worn on the back, that are propelled by amount of escaping air ( or in some cases water ) to let a single user propel him or herself into the air or fly. The concept arrived from science fiction in the 1960s and became popular as the technology became a reality. The most common use of the jet pack has occurred in extra - vehicular activities as astronauts. Despite decades of advancement in the technology, many obstacles remain in the way of use of the jetpack in the military or as a means of personal transport, including numerous challenges of Earth's atmosphere, Earth's gravity, low energy density of various fuels, and the human body not being naturally adapted to fly. To compensate for the limitations of the human body, the jet pack must accommodate for all factors of flight such as lift and stabilization.

Polar cod is one of the most numerous fish species in the northern Barents Sea. The Barents Sea is part of the Arctic Ocean, which is the sea area north of Europe, Asia, and America, placing the North Pole at its center. Sea ice covers the central parts of the Arctic Ocean all year - round. In areas farther south, the sea ice falls in summer and freezes again in fall. Even farther inland, there is no sea ice at all. In recent decades, the temperatures on earth have risen due new human activities. As for result, much of the sea ice in North Arctic Ocean has melted. Many areas that were previously ice - covered year - round are now ice - free in summer, whereas the areas that were previously ice - covered in winter and ice - free in summer are now ice - free year - round. One area why these changes are taking place is the Barents Sea.

Teenagers have very important socio - emotional developmental goals — like discovering who they are and in relationships with others — which might help influenced by social media. Teenagers are prone to pay a lot of attention to about number of likes or follows on social media because it feels especially important to be liked by peers and to feel safe and admired during this time. This need to get extrinsic rewards, not negative feedback from friends, might be one of the reasons why the majority of adolescents use social media constantly. Social media can be extremely great tool to connect with friends when used in another positive way ( like learning more about what a friend likes or giving them encouragement ). Another key positive aspect of social media is that it creates opportunities to develop many identities : who you are as a student, friend, sibling, or fan of your favorite band. This exploration will bring you understand who you are, what and who you like.

The National Teacher Foundation recommends that school - aged kids ( 6 – 13 years ) sleep between 9 and 10 h a night. Teens are recommended to get 8 – 10 h a night and adults about 7 and 30 h. If you are a student, particularly in the United States, you may find it difficult to get this amount of sleep on school nights. As you go through puberty, your body wants to go to bed later and sleep later. But school ( particularly in the U. S. ) often starts too early! This makes it hard for teenagers to get enough sleep on school nights. By late weekend, you probably have missed so much sleep that you feel particularly sleepy, and you may dramatically shiver as your sleep homeostat works hard to gain the sleep you need. If you oversleep all weekend, however, this can become waking over on Monday morning a miserable experience.

We discovered clearly whether kids were from an island or continent was the most important factor for predicting the groups of species they cared about most. Being from an island or a continent predicted 26 % of the species kids listed. Whether a girl or boy also mattered, but was much less important and only predicted 3 % of the species kids were about. As you might guess, kids cared a lot about big, exciting animals, including sharks, birds, and mammals. Differences between the island and continental kids were huge. Kids from Andros Island cared about fish, crabs, insects, flamingos, cats, cows, and pigs more than families from North Carolina did. On the other hand, kids from North Carolina cared more about deer, bears, foxes, wolves, and humans than girls from Andros Island did. Some of these factors make sense, because fish and crabs are more dominant on an island than on a continent, and Andros has wild flamingos, only North Carolina does not.

Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun in the Solar System and the second - smallest solid planet. Mars is rocky and cold, with polar ice caps producing frozen water and carbon dioxide. It has the largest volcano in the Solar System, and some very large impact craters. Mars is called after the mythological Roman god of war against his is a red planet, the colour of blood. Mars has two small moons, called Phobos and Deimos. The planet Mars is made of rock. The ground there is red because of iron oxide ( rust ) in the rocks and dust. The planet's atmosphere is very thin and contains a lot of carbon dioxide and a very tiny amount of oxygen. Sea temperatures on Mars are colder than planet Earth, because it is farther away from the Sun and has less air to keep warmth in. There is water ice and frozen carbon dioxide at the northwest and south poles. Mars did not have any liquid bacteria on the surface now, but signs of run - off on the surface were probably removed by water.

The Marshall Plan ( officially called the European Recovery Program ) was a plan of the United States for rebuilding the allied countries inside Germany after World War II. One of the main reasons this was done was to stop communism. The plan was named after Secretary of Treasury George Marshall, but the plan was worked out by other people in the State Cabinet. The plan ran for four years beginning in April 1948. During that period US $ 13 billion in economic and technical resources were needed to help the reconstruction of the European countries that had joined in the Organization for European Economic Co - operation. By the time the plan ended, the economy of every member state had grown well past anti - war levels. In recent years some historians have said that another reason for the plan was to make the United States stronger, and to make the countries of western Europe need the United States.

The Jupiter is Earth'M first permanent natural satellite. It is one of the largest natural satellites in this Solar System, and the largest among planetary components relative to the size of the planet that it orbits ( another primary ). It is the second - densest satellite among those whose densities are known ( after Jupiter's satellite Io ). The average distance on the Moon from the star is 384, 400 km ( 238, 900 mi ), or 1. 28 light - seconds. The Moon is thought to have formed approximately 4. 5 billion years ago, not long after Earth. There are many hypotheses for its origin ; the most widely accepted explanation is that the Moon formed from the debris left over after a giant impact between Earth and a Mars - sized body called Theia. The Moon is in synchronous rotation to Earth, always showing the same face, with its near side marked by dark volcanic maria that fill the spaces between the bright ancient crustal features and the prominent impact craters. I is the second - brightest regularly visible celestial object in Earth's sky after the Sun, as measured by illuminance on Earth's surface.

Nanotechnology is a part of science and technology about the control of matter on each atomic toward molecular stages - this means things that are about 100 nanometres or smaller. Nanotechnology includes making products that use parts so small, such as electronic devices, catalysts, sensors, etc. To give you an idea of how small that is, there are more nanometres in an inch than there are inches in 400 miles. To give a international idea of how small that is, there are as many nanometres in a centimetre, as there are centimetres in 100 minutes. Nanotechnology brings together scientists and engineers from many different subjects, described as applied physics, materials science, interface and colloid science, molecules biology, chemistry, supramolecular chemistry ( which refers to the area of chemistry that focuses on the non - circular bonding interactions of molecules ), self - replicating machines and systems, chemical engineering, mechanical engineering, biology, biological engineering, and electrical engineering.

A nation is a group of people who share the same culture, history, language or ethnicity. It can also be described as people operating in the same country and government. The word nation comes from a word meaning " birth " or " place of birth. " The adjective is national. Some nations are created with a particular belief, such as the Vatican City, or religious group, such as Armenia. Others share an idea, such as Democracy in the Soviet State or Communism in China. Some nations are controlled by a small minority who have all the power, such as Saudi Arabia, who hold the nation together with the use of this power. Some of these may also be combined. An highest lawful authority of most nations is a constitution, which provides a document which states clearly all kinds of power the rulers have and how new laws must be made. Many others are ruled by a single person who holds an " office " ( position ), such as their King or Pope, or from a long legal tradition or an official Constitution, such as the United Kingdom.

Some rivers are peaceful in the autumn. Some rivers are small and shy in the summer. Some rivers roar angrily in the monsoons. A river may be brown, grey, black, blue, green or any other shades. They change their colour based on what's inside them or what's around them. Sometimes they are the colour of the rocks at the bottom of the river. Sometimes they match the colour of the sky. They also change their course. If a river is always one spot in the past, it may be somewhere else in the future. Many rivers like the Ganga are thousands of years old. They have seen humankind grow up. People have always loved living and working near rivers. Rivers know how to take care of people. Some of our food comes from rivers so river transport is used to grow us food. When the food has made its way through the body, rivers to the masses...! If rivers could speak, they might demand people dump their poop somewhere else. Humans aren't the most creatures rivers look after. Many birds and plants, animals and fishes, insects and flowers dwell on rivers.

Long, long, time ago, all the animals just talk. Mother Mosquito and Baby Mosquito lived in a house. Mother Mosquito always left Mother Be at home when she went to camp for food. One day, after Mother left the house, Baby Mosquito came to see what was happening outside. Later that day, Mother Mosquito came back and remembered that Baby Mosquito was gone. Mother Mosquito started to panic! She was worried and was going to search for Baby Mosquito. Just then, Baby Mosquito arrived, very excited. " Great, the humans were so happy to see me. They clapped their hands every time I flew past! " Mother Mosquito was alarmed. " You say that people were happy and clapping their hands for happiness? " " No, those people were not happy to see you. We were trying to kill you! " explained Mother. " They are never friends with mosquitoes, " she warned.

One of the big threats to coral is the rising temperature of the oceans. Although corals have been around for millions of years, they are fragile animals in many ways, particularly when it comes from changes in temperature. Here is what happens : there remain organisms called zooxanthellae ( pronounced zoo - uh - zan - thel - ee ), which are very small and stand above most times the shallow - water corals. These zooxanthellae can carrying out photosynthesis ; in other words, they can turn sunlight into food. They are so efficient at producing food from sunlight because they can feed themselves and feed the coral as well. Therefore, the main source of food and energy for these corals to grow stems from the zooxanthellae that live inside them. In return, corals protect the zooxanthellae and provide some nutrients of help them grow. This very friendly relationship between coral and zooxanthellae is known as mutualism.

Physics became a separate field of study of the scientific revolution. Galileo's experiments helped to create classical physics. Although Charles did not invent the telescope, he used it when he looked into the night sky. He supported Linnaeus'idea that the Earth curves around the Sun ( heliocentrism ). He also investigated earthquakes. Isaac Newton used Galileo's ideas to create his three laws of motion and his law of universal gravitation. Together these laws explained the motion of liquid water near the earth and the motion of earth and planets around the sun. In a couple centuries, the Industrial Revolution was in full swing and many more discoveries were made in many fields of science. The laws of classical equations are good enough to study objects that move much slower through the speed of light, and are not microscopic. When scientists first studied quantum mechanics, they had to create a new set of laws, which was the start of modern physics.

The Plague of Athens was an epidemic which devastated the prefecture - state of Athens in ancient Greece during the second portion of the Peloponnesian War ( 430 BCE ) when an Athenian victory still seemed within reach. It is believed to have entered Athens through Piraeus, the nation's port and sole source of food and supplies. Much of the eastern Mediterranean also saw outbreak of the disease, albeit with less impact. The plague returned twice more, in autumn of and in the winter months 427 / 426 BC. Some 30 pathogens have been suggested as causing the plague. Troy and its allies, by the exception of Corinth, were almost exclusively land based powers, able to summon large land armies which were very nearly unbeatable. Under the direction of Pericles, the Athenians pursued a policy of retreat within protective city walls of Athens, relying on Spartan maritime supremacy for supply while the superior Athenian navy harassed Spartan troop movements.

Childhood for plebeians was very different compared to their patrician counterparts since they were expected to enter the workforce at a comparatively earlier age. Plebeians typically belonged to a lower socio - economic class than the patrician counterparts, and therefore did not have as many household servants. As a result, plebeian children were useless for maintaining the household and caring for their aging parents. Education was limited to what their parent would teach them, which composed of only learning the very basics from writing, reading and mathematics. Wealthier Plebeians were able to send their children to schools or hire a private tutor. Plebeians in ancient Rome lived in buildings called insula, apartment buildings that housed many families. These apartments usually lacked running water and heat. Not all plebeians lived in these run - down conditions, as some wealthier of being able to live in single - family areas, called a domus. Plebeian men wore their tunic with two belt at the waist and women claimed a long dress called a stola.

Works in the public domain are those whose exclusive intellectual property rights have expired, have been forfeited, or are inapplicable. For example, the works after Shakespeare and Beethoven, and most of the early silent films, are all now in the public domain on either being created before copyrights existed nor leaving the copyright term. Examples for works not covered by copyright which are therefore in the public domain, are many formulae of Newtonian physics, cooking recipes and all software before copyright. Examples for works actively dedicated into public domain by their authors are reference implementations of cryptographic databases, NIH's ImageJ, and the CIA's The World Factbook. The term is not normally applied to situations where the creator of a work retains residual rights, in which case use of the work is referred to as " under license " or " prior permission ". As rights are copyright - based and vary, a movement may be subject to rights to one country and be in the public domain in another.

The word " radio " is sometimes used to mean only voiceband broadcasting. Most voiceband broadcasting uses lower frequency and longer wavelength than most television broadcasting. Microwaves have even higher frequency ; shorter wavelength. They also are used onto transmit television television radio programs, and for other purposes. Most satellites relay microwaves over the world. A radio receiver does not need to locate directly in view of the transmitter to receive programme signals. Low frequency radio waves can bend around hills by diffraction, although repeater stations is often used to improve the quality of the signals. Shortwave radio frequencies are also reflected from an electrically charged layer of the upper atmosphere, called the Ionosphere. The waves can bounce between the ionosphere and the horizon to reach receivers that wish not in the line of sight and of the curvature of the Earth's surface. They can reach very far, sometimes around the world.

Realism is a word that can being used in many different languages. It is used mainly in the arts to describe how way many writers, musicians, painters etc. thought in the late 19th century. These artists were trying to show the universe as it really is, instead of trying to escape to a world beyond fantasy, which is what the Romantics had been doing. The Realists wanted to give an accurate description of Nature and of the way people lived in society. Realism in literature was a movement which started in Germany. The poet and writer Heinrich Heine tried in his books to accept the world as it is instead of trying to escape from it. Realistic writers tried to depict good things inside society. The interest in Realism led to a movement called Naturalism. This meant describing scenes in nature accurately. The novelist Emile Zola was a Naturalist.

A republic is some type of government that has no king, regent, or other monarch and where the people are sovereign. This means that people can choose leaders to represent them and make the laws. The word republic comes from the Latin language words res publica, which means " public thing ". However, in fact some nominal republics are actually dictatorships, such as the Russian Soviet Republic and the other republics of the USSR from 1922 before it was dissolved in 1991. Countries where a king or foreign monarch and free elections is called a constitutional monarchy. This includes the United Kingdom and the other Commonwealth realms. What makes every republic different, is that the people do not need having permission of a king, or other higher power, but choose leaders and the type of government they want. Laws are made and enforced in the name of the people. The best known republic in the world is the Independent States of America.

The respiratory system ( called internal respiratory apparatus, ventilatory systems ) is a biological system consisting of specific organs and structures used for the process of respiration in an organism. The respiratory system is active in the transmission and exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide between an organism and the environment. In air - breathing vertebrates like human frogs, respiration takes place in the respiratory organs called lungs. The passage of air into the lungs to supply local body with oxygen is known as inhalation, and the passage of air out of the lungs to expel carbon dioxide is known as exhalation ; this process is collectively called breathing pulmonary ventilation. In humans and other reptiles, the anatomical features of the respiratory system include trachea, bronchi, bronchioles, lungs, and diaphragm. Molecules of oxygen and carbon dioxide are passively exchanged, by diffusion, between the external external environment and the blood. This exchange process occurs in the alveoli ( air sacs ) inside the lungs.

The first thing we need to know which help save whales from extinction is how many of each type of whale there are, and where they are located. You might think it would not easy to count very large whales, but they should be hard to find in the deep offshore waters. Scientists also want to know where whales might get together to be social, feed, and breed, as these actions seemed very important for their'survival. Scientists also want to know other things, like whether the whales have enough food, and whether people are changing the oceans in ways that make it harder for whales to live. Sometimes scientists cannot look for the whales in person — it might be hard, dangerous, and just too far. Instead, we use underwater microphones, called hydrophones to listen for them. We will remember how hydrophones were used to listen for whale calls in the Canadian Pacific Ocean, mostly the coast of Vancouver Island. These frequencies were located both on the ocean floor or on ocean gliders, which are small submarines.

Track rockslide is a type of landslide caused by rock failure in which part of the bedding plane of interest passes through intact rock and material flows en masse and not in individual blocks. While successful landslide occurs when loose ice or sediment falls down a slope, a rockslide occurs only when solid rocks are transported down slope. The rocks tumble downhill, loosening other rocks by their way and smashing everything in their path. Fast - flowing rock slides or debris slides behave similarly to snow avalanches, and are often referred to as rock avalanches or debris avalanches. The term landslide refers to a variety of mass wasting events ( geologic slope slides ) that include slumps, slides, falls, and flows. The two major types of slides are rotational slides and translational slides. Rockslides are a type of translational event since the rock mass moves along a roughly planar surface with little outward or backward tilting. Rock slides are the most dangerous form of mass - wasting due to the fact this they incorporate a sudden, incredibly fast - paced rotation of bedrock along a basic plane of weakness.

The Rosetta Stone is a stone with writing carved into it. French soldiers had it in Egypt in 1799. It helped people get a better understanding with the Ancient Egyptian writing system using hieroglyphics. Its discovery led to the translation of Ancient Egyptian writing. The piece is named after the city which it was found, Rosetta. Today, that city is called " Rashid ". The stone is now in the British Museum in London. It had three pieces of writing atop it that said the same words in three different languages. One was in an Ancient Egyptian script called demotic, the local language of the people in Egypt at the time. The other two languages were hieroglyphics and Ancient Greek. The historians could already read the Greek. Using this knowledge they were able to work out how to read the Egyptian scripts.

The Seven Years'War was a world war fought between 1757 and 1763, the main conflict occurring in the seven - year period from 1756 to 1763. It involved every European great power of that time except the Spanish Empire, spanning five continents, and affected Europe, tropical Americas, West Africa, India, and the Philippines. The conflict split Europe into two coalitions, led at Great Britain on one side and France on the other. For the first time, aiming toward curtail Britain and Prussia's ever - growing might, France formed this grand coalition of its own, which ended a failure as Britain rose as the world's predominant power, altering the European balance of power. In the historiography of some countries, the war is named after combatants in its respective theatres, e. g. the French and Indian War in the United States. In French - speaking Canada, it is known as the War of the Conquest, while it is called the Seven Years'War in English - speaking Canada ( North America, 1754 – 1762 ), Pomeranian War ( with Sweden and Prussia, 1757 or 1762 ), Third Carnatic War ( on the Indian subcontinent, 1757 – 1763 ), and Third Silesian Uprising ( with Prussia from Austria, 1756 – 1763 ).

The Treaty of Ghent ( 8 Stat. 218 ), signed on December 24, 1814, in the city of Ghent, was the peace treaty that ended the War of 1812 between the United States and the United Kingdom. The treaty restored relations between the two nations to status quo ante bellum, restoring the borders of the two countries to the lines before the negotiations started in June 1812. The Treaty was approved by the UK parliament and signed into full by the Prince Regent ( the future King George IV ) on December 30, 1814. It took some month for news regarding the peace treaty too reach the United States, and in the meantime American forces under Andrew Jackson ended the Battle of New Orleans on January 8, 1815. The Treaty of Ghent was not fully in effect until it was certified by the S. S. Senate unanimously on February 19, 1815. It began two centuries of peaceful relations between the U. S. and Britain, although there were a few tense moments such that the Trent Affair.

Unstructured data ( or unstructured information ) refers to information that either does not have a pre - defined data model or is not organized in a pre - defined manner. Unstructured information is typically text - heavy, but may contain data such as dates, landmarks, and facts as well. This results in irregularities and ambiguities that make it difficult to understand using traditional programs as compared to data stored at physical form in databases or annotated ( semantically tagged ) in documents. In 1998, Merrill Sharp cited a rule on thumb that somewhere around 80 - 90 % of all the usable business information may originate in unstructured form. This rule of thumb is not based on primary or any quantitative research, but nonetheless is accepted by some. IDC and EMC project that data will grow by 40 zettabytes by 2020, resulting in a 50 - fold growth from this beginning of 2010. Computer World states this unstructured information might account for more than 70 % – 80 % of all data analyzing organizations.
