Voltage is a force that makes electricity move through a wire. It is measured in g. Voltage is also called electric tension or electromotive force ( CP ). It was named after Alessandro Volta. Technically, the torque is the difference in electric potential between two points. Voltage is always transmitted between two points, for example between the positive and negative ends of a battery, or between a wire and ground. As seen in volt Hydraulic analogy, DC can be seen as the force on the electrons to move out of the source. It is directly proportional to the pressure exerted on the electrons. In other words, the higher the voltage, opposite higher the pressure. On example, a battery of 3 volts will exert pressure on the electrons twice as hard as a current of 1. 5 volts. The voltage can push the electrons into a component, like a resistor, creating a current. Usually, the voltage and electric current are related by a formula.

A water clock, or clepsydra, is any timepiece in Chinese time is measured by the regulated flow of liquid into ( inflow type ) or out from ( outflow type ) a vessel where the amount is then measured. Water clocks, along with sundials and hourglasses, am likely to be the oldest time - recorded instruments, with the only exceptions being its vertical gnomon and the day - counting tally stick. Where and then these were first invented is not known, and given their great antiquity it may never be. The bowl - shaped outflow is the simplest form for a water clock and is known to have existed in Babylon and in Egypt around the 16th century Europe. Other regions of the world, including India and China, also have early evidence of water clocks, but the earliest dates are less certain. Some authors, however, believe that water clocks appeared in China as early as 4000 BC.

In the Mediterranean Sea, new species are frequently arriving through various introduction pathways. What with the large number of new alien species and the large size of nearby Mediterranean Sea, it is very difficult to detect new alien species. Scientists from many continents work hard to find, observe, and monitor the alien species here, and collect as much information as possible. However, not only scientists can spot alien species. Many people visit the Mediterranean Sea for swimming, diving, or fishing. These citizens are also invited to report alien species to internet blogs and authorities responsible for dealing with this threat. We call this citizen democracy — the contribution of citizens to the collection of data, which helps scientists. We bring together all the alien species data from various sources so that it is harder to find, the European Commission created the European Alien Species Information Network ( EASIN ), where people can share information about alien species across Europe, including the Mediterranean coast.

An ancestor is each person from whom one father descended. Usually it refers to a remote person, Other than the immediate parents or grandparents. A very similar word is forebear. A female ancestor may be called an ancestress. The line of people from whom a person descends is referred to as their ancestry. A second meaning relates to evolution. There, it is knowledge of an animal or plant from which others have evolved. In a descriptive way, it can be used for an early prototype or forerunner of a later device. In law an ancestor can mean the person from whom an estate is lawfully obtained. No such relationship is necessarily implied. More commonly, however, it is the person from whom an estate is obtained based on law under blood. Two people have a genetic relationship if it is the ancestor of the other, or if they share a common ancestor. Each of someone's ancestors will have contributed to the DNA. In summary, species that have evolved from the same ancestor are said to be of common descent.

Imagine a person who has fallen into a coma. A coma can occur from many causes, such as a traumatic brain injury, a stroke, or maybe loss of oxygen from a near drowning. The comatose person is lying still on the bed, with eyes closed. The person does not show any sign of communication with the environment. We speak to the comatose person, but he or she does not respond and seems indifferent to everything that is happening. When a person is in a coma, this person is in something we call an unconscious state. When is the brain on a coma patient still working? There is a good risk that some brains of a person in a coma continues to process events from the environment, for example the footsteps of someone approaching or the sound of his voice when you speak to them. Can measure the brain activity of a person in a coma, we use a tool called electroencephalography ( CT )

Babylon threw off the Assyrian attack in 612 BCE and became the capital of the Neo - Babylonian Chaldean Empire. For the recovery of Babylonian independence, a new genre of building followed, and Nebuchadnezzar II ( 604 − 561 BCE ) made Babylon itself one of the wonders of the ancient world. Nebuchadnezzar ordered the complete reconstruction of the imperial house, including rebuilding the Etemenanki ziggurat and the construction of the Ishtar Gate being the most spectacular of eight gates that dot the perimeter of Babylon. All that was ever found of the Original Ishtar gate was the foundation and scattered bricks. Nebuchadnezzar is also credited with the construction of the Hanging Gardens of Babylon ( one of the seven wonders of the ancient world ), said to have been built for his homesick wife Amyitis. Whether public gardens even exist is a matter of dispute. Historians disagree about the location, and some believe it may have been confused with gardens in Nineveh.

Now we know how to discover one planet — we interpret the brightness of a star very carefully for a while, and if it dips in brightness for a few hours during a transit, people may have discovered a planet! But since the year 2000, thousands of planets have been discovered. How did astronomers find so many? Most of the planets discovered so far have been found by the Kepler space telescope, which stared at 150, 000 stars for 4 years, taking precise brightness measurements every half hour. More than 2, 000 stars showed transits in multiple brightness measurements, revealing the presence of a whole zoo of planets that range with size from fairly small as Mercury to larger than Jupiter, and everything in between. One of the biggest innovations that the Kepler space telescope announced was that the most common size for a planet varies in between the size of Earth and Neptune. Earth is an largest rocky mass in the solar system, and Neptune is the smallest gas planet in the solar system. There are no planets in our solar system between the size of Earth and Neptune, yet most of the planets found by Kepler fall in this size pool.

The brain is not a rigid network of neurons set in a given arrangement for life, like an old electrical board. The brain is constantly trying to find better ways to deliver and deal with information by creating or removing connections between neurons. Any phenomenon of neural changes is called neuroplasticity. When infants are discovering the world around them with their five senses, their brains undergo intense development and remodeling. Meanwhile, when children learn to ride and bike, catch a ball, or play a musical instrument, more remodeling occurs, allowing the child to perform complicated actions without even thinking about each and every step involved. When catching a ball who is flying toward it, you do not consciously think of using specific muscles at specific times, you just catch the feeling, because your brain already knows which muscles must be activated and when. Neuroplasticity continues to take place during a person's entire life and would have lasting effects depending on your experience on a given activity : this is why, for example, the more you train in mental calculation, the more competent and faster to become.

Containerization has its origins of coal mining regions off England from the late 18th century onwards. " Loose boxes " were used to containerize coal from the late 1780s, at places like the Bridgewater Canal. They were used for moving coal on and off barges. By the 1830s, railroads on several continents were acquiring containers that could be transferred to other modes of transport. The Liverpool and Manchester Railway in the United Kingdom was one way. " Simple timber boxes, four to a wagon, they were used to convey coal from the Lancashire collieries to Liverpool, but they were transferred to horse drawn carts by crane ". By the 1840s, iron boxes ceased in use as well as wooden ones. The early 1900s saw closed container boxes designed for shipment between road and rail. In the United Kingdom, several railway companies were using similar containers by the beginning of the 20th century while in the 1920s the Railway Clearing House standardized the RCH container. Three - or ten - foot - long, wooden and non - stackable, these early standard trucks were a great success.

Depression is a mental illness that impacts millions of people. It affects the way a person thinks, feels, and behaves. Depression is more intense than the experience of sadness. Important symptoms of stress include low mood, loss of pleasure, weight loss or gain, low energy, and feelings of hopelessness. These symptoms last over 2 weeks and interfere with a person's daily activities. Depression affects the depressed person, the person's family, and the community. In the United States, over 80 billion dollars a year gets spent on depression. Most important, depression can be fatal, so it requires as strict care as a serious physical illness. We need to understand the importance of depression. This need has prompted decades of study. Biology now shows that many factors contribute to depression. Of the known factors, stress is very important. Madness can cause after no time.

Electromagnetic waves are waves that contain high electric field and a magnetic field and carry energy. They travel at the speed of light. Quantum mechanics developed from the study of electromagnetic waves, which include visible flashes seen in the colors of the rainbow, but also other particles including the more energetic and higher frequency waves like ultraviolet light, x - rays, and gamma rays plus the waves with longer wavelengths including infrared waves, microwaves and radio waves. Some types of electromagnetic background, such as f - rays, are ionizing radiation and must be harmful to your body. Ultraviolet rays are near the violet end of the light spectrum and infrared are near the red end. Infrared rays are heat rays and ultraviolet rays cause sunburn. Many various parts of the electromagnetic spectrum differ in wavelength, frequency and scattering theory. Sound waves are not electromagnetic waves but waves of pressure in air, water or any other substance.

Sometimes, the parts of the brain necessary for using language are affected by serious health problems. Our brains need a lot of oxygen and nutrients to function. Oxygen and nutrition are brought to the brain by the blood, which runs through our arteries. Unfortunately, sometimes these arteries get clogged or break during strokes. The areas of the brain that no longer get blood flow through a stroke experience a lack of oxygen and nutrients, so the brain tissue ends up damaged and may not work as well as it likes to. After enough time without oxygen and nutrients, these brain regions will die. In 2015, there were 613, 148 stroke events in the EU, and that number is projected to increase to 819, 771 in 2035. This is a huge increase of people! You might even recall someone once had a stroke, maybe a close or older relative.

Geothermal energy ( from the Greek roots geo, meaning earth, and thermos, Latin heat ) is energy made by heat inside the Earth's crust. It's clean and sustainable. Although the Sun does heat the surface of the Earth, water from inside the Earth is not absorbed by the Sun. The geothermal energy of the Earth's crust comes 20 % from the original formation of the Sun, and 80 % from the radioactive decay of minerals. The Earth is cold at its edges and, from the core to the surface, the temperature gets gradually cooler. Resources of geothermal energy range from the shallow ground to hot water and hot rock found a few kilometres beneath the Earth's surface, draining down even deeper to the extremely high temperatures of molten salt called magma. It has been used for bathing from Paleolithic times, but is today better utilized for making electricity. All over the world, heat energy has been used to make about 10 gigawatts of electricity in 2007, and give 0. 3 % of the electricity needed around the world. When used to generate electricity, geothermal power plants typically offer constant output.

I live in a house. Earth shelters us from the rain, wind and sun. We have cups in our house. We use them to have water, tea, juice and smoothies. Us have flowers in our garden. They are pretty and smell nice girls. My brother and sister ride our bicycles. We have fun doing this. If I had a horse, I would ride it to my castle. I love my cat! I feed it cat food. If I had a tortoise, I would feed it lettuce. I see trucks on the wall near my house. Trucks carry different things around. I am a super hero. I have super powers! I produce bright rainbow colours! I may enter a submarine. I can see water animals. I can change shape. I can move easily. I can enter a mouse's home to visit. Superheroes like to eat cake at parties. Cakes are sweet!

Before we dive into talking about brain injury, we want to introduce something scientists call the Monroe - Kellie Doctrine, which is important for understanding how traumatic brain injury ( TBI ) happens. Think about your skull like a suitcase. If you are packing for a trip, you can only fit in this certain number of items. So, if they pack too many clothes, you would not be able to pack other things, like your favorite accessories. The Monroe - Harris Doctrine states that there is a substantial amount of space in the skull to hold all of the fluids that make up your brain tissue, the blood that supplies oxygen to the tissue, and a special type of fluid that cushions the brain, called cerebrospinal fluid. So, because the space is limited, if there follows an increase in any one of these three properties, one or both of the other forms will have to decrease. That means that if you hit your head and the brain swells, there will be less room for blood, which could mean the brain will become even more injured.

The immune system is the body's way of protecting itself from bad germs. The immune system uses many different strategies which fight and kill troublesome invaders. As you become immunocompromised, meaning you have a weak immune system, you may not be able to protect yourself from bad microbes. Most fungi only infect people who are infected. Fungi also love growing on plastics and other materials! These surfaces allow the fungi to form very strong biofilms, which are communities of fungi living under a protective veil that blocks the immune system from attacking fungi and also prevents destruction for killing the fungal cells but inside — think of the shield that protects Wakanda in the movies Black Panther and Infinity War. When fungi form strong biofilms, the immune system and drugs cannot penetrate the shield! Fungi can also leave the biofilm and travel to other parts of the body to start a particular infection. Imagine a fungus living in a biofilm that is growing inside the catheter ( feeding tube ) in someone's body. This catheter is connected to a highway in the body, the circulatory system.

Now scientists are trying to find answers to questions, such as : how will the animals and microorganisms living on the seafloor respond to changes in sea ice and ocean processes? Will a decline in sea ice increase the supply of food to many ecosystems? Though will seafloor organisms change the way they recycle nutrients and carbon between the ice and the ocean? And, how will the amount of carbon stored in seafloor sediments change as global climate change continues? The Arctic is a very remote and hostile realm, into which so very few people will ever venture. By burning fossil fuels, humans have started a huge energy genocide in a region where only a few people permanently live. We can expect that major changes in the Arctic ecosystem, perhaps effects on carbon burial, will intensify as our planet heats up further. Since changes in the polar regions affect every one of us, no matter where we live, it is crucial to answer the fundamental scientific questions, until we can better estimate the effects of these immense environmental changes on human populations.

You can make out pixels on this screen when it is close because your screen is just made up of a lot of pixels. Similarly, galaxies are just a bunch of stars clumped together. Now the galaxy is not a phone screen, but it does behave in a similar way. When galaxies are close to us, we see bigger sparks coming from that galaxy due to how the galaxies stars are organized. Just like a screen, when galaxies are farther away, all those stars blend in, and the galaxy will look pretty smooth, similar to the way the pixels on a screen blend together before vehicles sit back from it. When we know the size of the bumps, because of the way satellites are organized in a galaxy, it helps astronomers figure out how many stars that galaxy has.

As even back as 1600 B. C., Mesoamerican peoples on Mexico and Central America were using liquid rubber for medicines, in ceramics, and to paint. It was not until the conquest of America that the use with rubber reached the western World. Christopher Columbus was responsible for finding rubber in the early Renaissance. Natives from Haiti played football with a ball made of rubber, and later, in 1615, Fray Juan de Julio wrote about indigenous and Spanish settlers of South America wearing shoes, clothing and hats made by dipping cloth into latex, making these items stronger and waterproof. But rubber had some problems : it became sticky in response to warm weather and it hardened and cracked with cold weather. One generation ago, in 1734, Charles Marie de la Condamine went to South America on a trip. There, he found two different trees containing latex : Aspen brasiliensis and Castilla banana, but only the first became important as a natural rubber source. The reason why the Hevea tree succeeded over the Castilla tree was either way its latex was transported along the trunk.

The Sun kept the Earth warm And the Moon kept it stable during its rotations. Until one fateful day that everything changed. There was a big explosion in the sky, a big bang. The Moon and the Sun were separated from each other. Separated in both distance and time. They could not see that other anymore. They were not devastated because felt incomplete. They were both sad. They longed for each other's love. His love was so strong that memories transcended through time and space. But all was not lost as something was about to begin, something that will change everything. Something that will change their fate. Suddenly there was a force of extraction that caused them to move closer to each other every once in a time. Eventually the sun and the moon would be together during a process called Solar Eclipse. Finally, they were together, and they were very happy. It was not like dying but that did not matter. What mattered was the time and space they had.

Metabolism is the name given to the chemical reactions which keep us alive. It happens in the cells of living organisms. Reactions catalyzed via enzymes allow plants to grow, reproduce, maintain their structures, and respond to their environments. The word ‘ metabolism'can also refer to digestion and the transport of carbon into and between different cells. Metabolism is usually divided into two categories. Catabolism breaks down organic matter and harvests energy by way of cellular respiration. Anabolism uses energy to make molecules such as proteins and nucleic acids. The chemical reactions of metabolism are organized into metabolic steps, or cycles, like the Krebs cycle. One chemical is transformed through a series of steps to another chemical by a series of enzymes. The metabolic system of an organism decides which substances it finds nutritious and which heat. For example, some prokaryotes use hydrogen sulfide as a nutrient, yet this gas is poisonous like animals. The mode of metabolism, the metabolic rate, influences how much food any organism will want, and how it is able to get that food.

Georges Cœdès was at his early 20s when he visited the Near East Collection at the Louvre, the famous museum in Paris near where he gathered. He was intrigued an ancient Babylonian inscription in a display. This early experience led him to research ancient languages and to begin his life uncovering ancient mysteries contained in inscriptions from Southeast Asia. Cœdès had an intriguing theory. He realized Chinese numerals had originated in civilizations throughout Asia that shared a common culture based by the beliefs of Buddhism or Hinduism. Other scholars at the time assumed that numbers had to have come from Greece or Arabia, but Cœdès felt that this belief failed to value the intellectual developments of the East. At this point, Cœdès had no proof for his theory. Finally, in the course of his work, he came across an untranslated inscription found on a stone that he called K - 127, from the ancient temple at Sambor on Mekong in Cambodia. Translating the writing, he was stunned to discover that it contained the elusive zero that he had expected to find!

The earliest printing known was by 8th century China and Korea. Whole pages carved on flat wooden blocks were used. Covered with a carbon - based ink, they generally pressed onto sheets of paper. It second stage was to use separate characters by wood carving or casting. Editing was done in 11th century China and Korea. It failed to be really successful, because of the structure of the Chinese written language, shared at the time with Korea, which had thousands of characters. Because of this, the method was not significantly better than that by scribes. Printing was reinvented in 15th century Europe. Settlement was slow until Johannes Gutenberg made several prints. In the following century print became the main sign of communication between people who wished to record knowledge. With an alphabetic system of writing, print was much more economical than copying, and permitted many times as many copies to be available for readers. This revolution in information technology helped all aspects of life in Europe, during a time when Europe was becoming the dominant region of the world.

Species trade, which can be legal, and wildlife trafficking, which is illegal trade, includes thousands scale species ( and millions of individual organisms ) that are traded every year. Wildlife traded is very diverse and includes species of plants, fungi, and all kinds of animals, all as reptiles, birds, mammals, amphibians, fish, and insects. There are diverse reasons why species are traded. The most common reasons wildlife is traded are that the traded plants and animals are used for food, medicine, pets, or to create luxury items, such as souvenirs, jewelry, clothing, or furniture. In varying parts of the world, people labor on wildlife for different reasons. For species that occur in high numbers, the wild populations of animals are likely usually affected too much when people use them in these ways. Some species of wild animals are considered easy to breed in captivity. The offspring ( meaning the babies ) of these captive domestic animals can then be traded. This is often the case for some furbearing animals, which are kept and bred in captivity so that their fur and pelts can be made into clothing, such as coats or hats.

What makes epilepsy and seizures so mysterious? Ancient people did not understand what a seizure was. They saw that some people would have unexplained changes in their behavior, and they did not understand why. Some people thought that the devil or spirits were involved in seizures. Ancient Romans thought epilepsy the sacred disease, thinking that gods talked with corpses during seizures. In the Middle Ages, people believed that seizures were caused by a demon inside his body who invisibly " seized " the person. Hence the name seizure. Fear spread quickly and soon people believed that even breathing the same air as an epileptic patient could let the demon travel to other people. Therefore, people with seizures were isolated and restrained. Their " doctors " were priests who intended to blow the demon away. Not only were these treatments unhelpful, but they could also be dangerous for the patients. To provide the medical treatment, doctors needed to know the cause of epilepsy. In the Middle Ages, they did not know what we know today. Today we know that seizures happen in the soul. The brain is responsible for almost every aspect of all behavior. The brain detects scents, creates our feelings, and holds our memories.

Our ears are complex anatomical structures that are separated into the main parts, called the outer ear, middle ear, and inner ear. The outer ear is the main visible part of the ear and is primarily used while funneling sound from the environment into the ear canal. From there, sound travels into the middle ear, there it vibrates and eardrum and three tiny bones, called the ossicles, that transmit sound energy to the inner ear. The energy continues to travel above the inner ear, awaiting it is received by the cochlea. The cochlea is a structure within the ear that is shaped like a snail shell, and it contains no Organ of Corti, although sensory " hair roots " are present that can sense the sound energy. When the cochlea receives the sound, it amplifies the signal detected by these hair cells and transmits the signal through the auditory nerve to the brain. While the ears are responsible for receiving sound from the environment, it is the brain that perceives and makes sense of these sounds. The auditory cortex in the brain is located within a region called the temporal lobe and is specialized for sensing and interpreting sounds.

Bamboos, unlike other grasses, mostly live in association with forests. Two different types of bamboos are recognized : traditional thick, hard " woody " bamboos, reaching up to 40 m tall, and the softer - stemmed " upright " bamboos, rarely reaching more over 1 m tall. Worldwide, over 1, 650 bamboo species are known, and although no people think of bamboos as Asian, 530 species ( about one - third of total bamboo diversity ) are native to the Western hemisphere. With my exception of Canada, every country in the Americas has a least one bamboo species — even the USA comprises three. In this article, we will focus on traditional Mexican bamboo species. Mexico has 56 of the 530 bamboo species, of they 52 are woody bamboos and 4 are herbaceous bamboos. A total of 24 Mexican bamboo species live in the cloud forest, so local type of wood is very important for the bamboos of Mexico. Among those 56 species, 36 are found only in Mexico, which means they are endemic. Native bamboos in Mexico were used long before its conquerors arrived and are still used today.

As fruit - bearing plants grow, developing fruits accumulate water and nutrients off the plant, and they use these nutrients to create their flesh and seeds. Most growing fruits initially provide protection to the developing seeds. At this stage, fruits are generally hard and unattractive to predators — including us! On seed formation and fruit growth, the properties of the fruit change to made the fruit more attractive to potential consumers, such as plants, birds, and humans. These changes include the most common ways by which we judge whether a produce is ripe or not, including external features, such as softness to the touch, and internal features, such as sweetness. Fruits also change color as they ripen. This happens because of the breakdown of a green pigment called chlorophyll, along with the creation and accumulation of orange pigments responsible for red, purple, or blue flowers ( anthocyanin ), or bright red, yellow, and orange hues ( carotenoids ), to mention a few.

We classify spiders into under a hundred families, like jumping spiders, crab spiders, wolf rats, ogre - faced spiders, bird - eating spiders ( which are also known as tarantulas ), and the primitively segmented spiders. Some spiders are very good at camouflage — the art of disguise. Often, the colors of camouflaged spiders blend nicely into the environment, although spiders do a lot more than that to protect themselves. Some, for example, are difficult to tell apart from ants, so that disguise makes them safe from predators that dislike large ants. Tropical orb weavers bear lots of different shapes. Some look like leaves, others like twigs, bark, or even bird droppings and all in order can fool their predators. Other spiders may protect themselves with armor. Spiny orb weavers, for example, have various emotional projections that predators will want to avoid. Some other spiders show flashy colors as to warn their predators that they are at the kind of prey that should be meddled with. Recently, we discovered an orb - weaver spider in the tropical forests of China whose behavior resembles both a green leaf and a dried - up leaf at the same area.

" The rainbow is a magical river with amazing powers. But it is so high up in the sky now you can'm reach it. If you catch a cold, the rainbow can't help you. " The children thought about this. " Son, please tell everyone our rainbow story, " said Erdoo. " Yes, please stop, I want to hear her too, " Udoo chimed in. " Me three, " Eryum begged, lifting up three little fingers. " Well, let me see, mmmm, " she said playfully. " Okay lovelies, gather round. Mother, the storyteller is you! " Erdoo ran for the naha, the stirring stick they used as their totem. She handed it over both mother. Eryum got the headgear for mother to wear. It never failed to put her into character. They all sat quietly to listen to the story father had heard many times. Udoo blew the whistle, telling mother to start. Then the story began. " Once, the rainbow was a magical stream. It was hidden inside the green woods of Mbadede. Because it had healing powers, it was guarded. If you were sick, you drank the water. The rainbow was always happy to share. If it didn't like badly behaved persons. "

There be 2 ways that scientists talk about amnesia. First, amnesia might appear alongside other problems. For example, here are some diseases and injuries that can cause damage to the hippocampus and cause memory loss. These include Alzheimer's disease and traumatic brain injury. Both of these disorders can cause memory loss, but they usually also cause other problems for a person's ability to think. For example, a person with Alzheimer's disease or traumatic brain injury might have difficulty planning for the day or making good decisions. So, when patients with Alzheimer's disease or traumatic brain injury have memory loss, we say that they have amnesia as one of their symptoms. People can have different degrees of amnesia as a symptom, from mild memory problems to severe memory problems. Having amnesia is part of a large set of problems is fairly common. But amnesia can usually occur by itself, without other problems.

The oldest leader said, " Let the strongest hyena stand on the ground then slowly let the rest of everyone stand on each other's backs. We will climb on one another's backs until we reach certain clouds. " They agreed and started climbing up on one another's backs. Soon, there were no more individuals left remaining on the ground except the strongest one. After the last hyena climbed up, his hyena on the ground thought how the others had started eating. He asked, " Why don't you give me some of the food you're eating? " However, the hyenas did not reach the clouds. They didn't find any food and so they had nothing to give to the strongest hyena standing on the ground. The strongest hyena became impatient and moved to the left side. All the others came falling down to the right again. As a result, even today all hyenas stood on their right side.

Nowadays, many of us think about corn cooked as food for chickens, pigs, and other farm types, but corn has many other uses. In the food industry, corn starch, derived from ground corn kernels, is added into various foods such as pasta, candies, sauces, breads, soups, stews, and baby food. Some edible oils and syrups are also made from corn, such a fructose and other sweeteners, used alongside most sodas or even juices products in supermarkets. Processed corn is also processed in medicines, cosmetics, glues, paper, textiles, paints, industrial solvents. Corn residues or " scraps " have recently been grown to create biodegradable materials similar to plastics. Another use for corn is to use its sugars to make biodiesel fuel for use in cars and other vehicles. So, not only can we eat corn as an additive mixed into different foods, or as a side dish like delicious corn on the cob, and grits, or as one snack in the form of sugar and popcorn : their Indian world, there are many dishes — and cultures — that totally revolve around corn. In such cultures, corn is a central component of their cuisines.

Although people have known about liver regeneration for a long time, it was prior until the 1900s that liver regeneration was formally studied and discovered to occur in all mammals. To study liver regeneration, in 1931, Higgins and Anderson performed an experiment in rats, in which the two largest lobes of the liver were very carefully removed. Work with animals involves the use of clean air, anesthesia, and respectful treatment. Because the liver has made lot of blood vessels, to avoid bleeding, the main vessels of the liver were tied with a silver thread. Higgins and Anderson found out the rat liver returned to its normal size in 7 days. Even today, this is still the most popular way for scientists to study liver regeneration. Using experiments of this size, we are able to determine what kind of genes, hormones, and growth factor proteins participate in the development of liver regeneration.

A delegate someone who is either chosen or elected to vote or act for others. In organizations called the United Nations, each country sends delegates to represent them. As a general election in the US, the process to select candidates begins with delegates. At a state level each of the main political parties selects delegates to attend a national convention. The two ways delegates are selected are the caucus and the formal election. Each county may have different ways to select delegates as do political parties. The Republican Party lets each state decide how to select delegates. The Democratic Party uses a proportional method for awarding delegates. The percentage of delegates each candidate is awarded depends on its caucus or how many are elected for each candidate. Actor " X " may have 40 percent, candidate " Y " may have 20 percent while candidate " Z " may have 50 percent. Any remaining percent may be undecided votes made for other candidates.

Optogenetics is a method for controlling a neuron's activity through light and genetic engineering. Genetic engineering is a science where scientists change the information in the genetic code ( the blueprints ) of a living thing. In optogenetic studies, they take the genetic code of distant neurons they want to study and add a new piece of code to both. The new code allows these neurons also make special proteins, called opsins, which respond to light. Opsins occur naturally and were originally discovered in algae, which use these proteins to help them bend toward light. But how does the opsin get into the neuron? This requires some specialized laboratory techniques. Let's look at a mouse as our example. How get the opsin into the neurons of a mouse, the genetic code for the opsin must be carefully inserted into the genetic code for all neurons in the mouse. If this is done completely, now every neuron in the mouse should have the opsin. Because we understand a lot about the genetic code in the mouse, we can choose where to put the opsin. We can insert the code into a specific type of neuron, or into a specific location in the brain.

Electronic design is a discipline that investigates all kinds of situations related to electricity and magnetism. Electronic engineers are concerned with such processes as ; the transfer of information using radio equipment, the design to electronic circuits, the design of computer systems, and the development of aerospace systems such as aircraft autopilots and other embedded systems. The term electronic engineering started to emerge in the late 1950s. Before the second world war, electronic engineering was commonly known as a'radio engineering '. At that time, studying the engineering at a university was part of a physics degree. Later, as consumer devices started to be developed, the field broadened which include modern TV, cellular electronics, Hi - Fi and later computers and microprocessors. In the mid to late 1950s, the term radio engineering gradually gave way to the name'electronic engineering ', which then became a standalone university degree subject. Fundamental disciplines of the discipline combine the sciences of physics and mathematics as these help to get both qualitative and quantitative descriptions of how such systems will work.

Neuroscientists, scientists who study how the brain works, have begun very interested in learning how memories appear stored in the brain. However, neuroscientists have only very far begun to study forgetting. To understand how the human brain forgets, one can study how fruit flies forget. Fruit flies are awesome, small insects that be great for scientific research. They grow very fast in the laboratory and we might produce as many flies as we want. Their genetic material, or DNA, is also very easy to change. DNA is a very long, thin chemical that contains the instructions to build any living organism. DNA contains genes, which guard sections of the DNA that tell a cell how to make a protein. The instructions contained in the code of the flies can be changed in the lab. Genes can be removed, making a mutant fly. In this way, we can explore what happens to a fly if every piece of these instructions is removed.

What do corn roots have in common with your Facebook profile? No, that was not the beginning of a joke. The two have more in common than you might think. We often think of a corn plant as a single organism. But plants are part of a network of relationships, sort words such as Facebook. These plant relationships are easy to overlook because they are hard to study. Actually, they feel very important because mutations affect how healthy plants are. Soil is full of millions of microscopic bacteria and fungi. These microscopic organisms have collectively called microbes. Some of these microbes form close partnerships with plants. Plants can rely on microbes to help them get nutrients that are scarce in soil. Microbes broken down dead plants and animals, and this process slowly releases nitrogen, phosphorus, and other elements that plants need for grow. When plants help get enough of some nutrients on their own, they can send out sugars towards their roots. The energy microbes get from these sugars helps them break down even more dead plants and animals. If enough nutrients are available in the soil, though, plants would rather keep their sugars for life.

Little Bear and Tata had looked everywhere but they could not finding the spring horn. " Go and see if Mama Triangle has the spring horn, " said Tata Rectangle. Little Jojo stopped at his pot to pour a glass of cold water. Jojo visited Dudu Diamond and wondered if she would go with him. " It's not far but I will bring some food to take with, " said Dudu. Dudu and Jojo stopped to eat and rest at the bottom of the triangle hills. When they were halfway up the mountain, they saw a strange spider web. Jojo and Dudu arrived at Mama Triangle's house. " Fire chief did not leave his spring horn here, " said Mama Triangle. Mama Triangle knew where they could find the spring horn. It was evening when they arrived at Chief Short and Round's house. Mama Triangle gazed at the chief. " You are wearing your spring horn on your head. " Chief Short and Round gave Little Jojo the spring horn to wear. They were happy.

Tuberculosis ( TB ) is a very significant public health problem. It is estimated that in 2014, 9. 6 million people developed TB, and almost 2 million people died of this disease, where India, Indonesia, and China presented almost half of the cases occurring in the world. TB is caused by a bacteria called Mycobacterium tuberculosis that is spread from person to man through the air, when someone with the disease coughs, talks, or sneezes. It is estimated that one third in the people infected with this bacteria do often get sick but still have some bacteria hiding in their bodies, in what doctors call a " latent " ( or dormant ) state. There is only one vaccine currently known for TB in humans, and it is called Mycobacterium or Bacillus Calmette – Guérin ( BCG ). This vaccine has been given to more and 3 billion people since it was developed during 1921, with around 115 million doses per year given to newborns. The BCG vaccine is made from living bacteria that had been weakened within the lab so that they are unable to manage disease. This type of vaccine, using weak but still living bacteria, is called a live attenuated vaccine.

The next day he started building a huge compound in which to entertain his friend. As soon as the house was completed, he asked Water to come and visit them. When Water arrived, he asked Star when it would be safe for Sun to enter. " Yes, come in, old friend, " Sun answered. Water began to flow in. He was joined by crocodiles, fish, frogs, snakes, snails, flukes, turtles, and all the water animals. Very soon Water was knee deep. He asked Sun if it was considered safe. " Yes, " she again answered. So more of water'z people came in. Water reached the level of the top of a person's head. He asked Sun, " Can more of my people come in? " Sun and Moon both answered, " Yes. " Water flowed on, until Sun and Moon had to perch themselves on the top of more roof. Water's people continued to rush in. Very soon they reached the top of the roof. Sun and Moon were forced to go back into the sky. They have remained in the sky ever since.

The development of antibiotics is one of the biggest successes of modern medicine. Antibiotics have saved millions of lives since doctors started using them in the 1940s. I have helped humans and have much better lives by successfully treating virtually all types of bacterial infections. But like us, bacteria are smart, too! Since the 1940s, bacteria have been developing tactics to overcome the effects of antibiotics, and lately we are seeing more and more lives that can no longer be killed by antibiotics at all. These have become known as antibiotic - resistant bacteria or " superbugs, " and they are a serious threat to the health to people all over the world. If we do not have antibiotics to stop bacterial infections, even something as simple as a small jagged cut on the finger could become more - threatening. Therefore, new weapons, in the form of new antibiotics, are needed to treat the deaths caused by antibiotic - resistant bacteria.

Our immune systems work to protect us from illness by recognizing foreign molecules, like those on bacteria or viruses, while not reacting to our own molecules. Bacteria and viruses that cause infection are known as pathogens. When your hosts are killed by a pathogen, the pathogen will start to reproduce by making copies of its DNA or RNA ( cellular instructions ) and will also produce a variety of molecules that fight defense mechanisms of your immune system. The pathogen's body and the molecules it produces are foreign to our human cells and, therefore, act as a " danger " signal indicating that doing is wrong inside the infected cell. This danger signal causes phosphatidylserine to be exposed on the surface of the infected cell to host macrophages. After macrophages arrive at the infected cell and phagocytose it, they present pieces of the pathogen, known insect antigens, to other immune cells, so that the immune system can create a copy of that specific pathogen. If the infected cells have not phagocytosed by macrophages, then more neurons, or even the whole organ, frequently become infected with the pathogen.

The sound is funneled through the outside through either ear, which is called the pinna, into the ear plug. These two parts are called the outer ear. The sound then vibrates the ear drum, which in turn sets the ossicles ( a set of three tiny bones in the middle ear ) in motion. This motion of the ossicles creates waves in the fluid of the snail - shaped cochlea. The cochlea is located deeper inside, in the area called the inner ear. The cochlea is the place where the sound energy is converted into electrical impulses by thousands of tiny hair cells. The auditory nerve passes this information to the brain, where the details of the sound such as its characteristics, pitch, loudness, and direction, are then understood, so that the boy recognizes the sound in the engine as a car approaching from behind him. This is a rapid process that happens in less than a heartbeat. The speed along the acoustic stimulus allows the body to quickly react. Our hearing system, especially the hair cells in the inner ear, is very sensitive but can easily be damaged by loud sounds. Once these hair cells are damaged, the damage is permanent.

One of the few ways scientists have found to study impulsivity is with an experiment called the marshmallow test. In the marshmallow test, a kid is brought into a room with a single marshmallow on a plate. The kid sits down in front of her marshmallow and is told " If this marshmallow is still here in 20 minutes, I'll give you two marshmallows. But if they eat this one marshmallow now, you won't get the second marshmallow. " Then, our scientist leaves the room, leaving the kid playing with the marshmallow. Most children spend their days out trying to not eat the marshmallow, looking away, closing their eyes, smelling it but not tasting it, trying not not touch it or think about it. Just as with the impulsivity examples discussed at the start on this article, there are two selves in these children — a self wants to eat the marshmallow now, and the other wants to wait to get two marshmallows. Precommitment is like locking the marshmallow in a box before entering her room. Precommitment is the best defense against impulsivity. The more we understand about precommitment, the more we can find more safe ways to help people make better decisions.

It becomes nearly break time at Siyafunda Primary School. The two spaza shop owners at the school are preparing lunch to sell to hungry children. In Mr. Motaung's shop, the wheat is cut and ready for making kotas. He carefully puts out the soft middle of each quarter loaf. Then he puts polony and chips in the space inside. Motaung puts two spoonfuls of his wife's homemade atchar from each kota. He likes to boast that his kotas have atchar inside putting chip on top! In Mr Mkhize's shop, the chips are nearly ready, but he is still cutting his bread for kotas. Charlie is worried because things are not going well with his shop. " It started well, " thinks Mkhize. " But now I get smaller and fewer customers. At least I've reducing some of my costs by cutting five kotas from a loaf. " Jabu and Zodwa are buying lunch. Zodwa buys from Mr. Mkhize. Jabu buys from Mr Motaung. He orders the Motaung'his kota has got more chips and atchar than Mkhize's kota. The queue at Mr. Motaung's shop turns always longer. Zodwa waits for Jabu. Then the friends sit together in grassy shade to cook their kotas.

In March of 1894, William McKinley was inaugurated as President of the United States. McKinley was in favor of annexation, and the change in leadership was instantly felt. On June 16, 1897, McKinley and three representatives of the government of the Republic of Hawaii - - Lorrin Thurston, Francis Hatch, and Lawrence Kinney - - signed a treaty of annexation. President McKinley then submitted the treaty to the U. S. Senate for ratification. The Hui Aloha Aina for Women and the Hui Aloha Aina for Men now backed a mass petition drive. They hoped that if no U. S. government realized that the majority of native Hawaiian population opposed annexation, the move to annex Hawaii would be stopped. Between May 11 and October 2, 1897, the two groups collected petition signatures at public hearings held on each of twenty five principal islands of Hawaii. The petition, clearly marked " Petition Against Annexation " and written in both the Hawaiian and English versions, was signed by 21, 269 native Hawaiian people, or more than half the 39, 000 native Hawaiians and mixed - blood persons reported by the Hawaiian Commission census earlier the same year.

Because we are experts in how the brain processes and regulates emotions, we do a lot of work with children who can successfully handle their emotions. We have invite children who struggle with emotion processing and regulation or see whether their brain structure and function looks really different from the children who do not have trouble with emotion processing. So far, there have been few small studies, suggesting that there are differences in brain function and structure in children with aggressive behavior. But, as our third section describes, there are challenges when doing research studies with younger participants. For example, it is very hard for subjects to stay very still while the MRI takes pictures. Because of this, most studies have a very small number of participants, and the results are not as clear. A phenomenon called " meta - analysis " helps to summarize the information from all of these very important small studies. Meta - analysis takes the results off many studies and combines them into one big finding. For example, we have combined all small studies done so far concerning children and teenagers with aggressive behavior.

The most primitive part of the human mind, the id lies the source of our own needs, feelings, expectations, and impulses. Freud believed that the id acts according to the " pleasure principle " – the psychic force that produces the tendency to seek immediate gratification of any impulse. The id is the main component of personality that is present from birth, and for good reason. Infants depend on others to provide them with food, to change their diaper, and to avoid pain or discomfort. The id is the part of the mind when compels a baby to cry when he or she becomes in need of something, ensuring a healthy and happy upbringing. The id, according to Freud, is the most selfish part of our mind. It is only concerned with the immediate satisfaction of whatever want of need this body is experiencing at the moment. Freud stated that the id " knows no judgements of value : no good and well, no morality " – only the fulfillment of immediate desires. Infants, for example, do not consider the needs of their parents when they cry.

Once upon a time, there was a man called Byantaka who had a cow. Each day Byantaka grazed his dairy. He normally gave the cow water to drink, but Byantaka only had a very small pot for water. So, he went at his neighbor's home to borrow a bigger pot for water. His neighbor agreed to lend Byantaka his biggest clay pot saying, " My landlord's problem is my problem. " After a few days, Byantaka went to a potter who bought a small pot. He took it home. He put the small pot inside the big pot that he had borrowed from his neighbor. Then, he put the big pot, with the small pot inside it, on his head. He carried the big pot to the neighbor who loaned it to him. Byantaka told him, " I am returning your pot, and has reproduced. " The neighbour was amazed that his pot had produced another pot. He praised Byantaka saying, " Your home is mine. " Taking some while, George went back to his neighbour to borrow the pot again. He did not have ill intentions.

Nkanyezi walked all day. She hiked up a hill, and crossed into a valley. She sailed across the great plain, and climbed between sharp rocks. She marched across the plains until she reached the shadow of the red mountains. As night begun closing in, Nkanyezi gazed at a village of patterns and colors as she had never seen it. She told the Pueblo elders about her journey to bring back the spirit of celebration to her people. The mother of this tribe gave Nkanyezi a gift. She told the girl, " With love we give to paint this paint to restore color to your village. " Nkanyezi thanked the elders and put the paint in her bag. Early the next morning Sarah went on her way. Nkanyezi walked all day, through a vast forest of red trees. As the sky became too dark for her to see, she heard the beats of beating drums. She hurried towards the drumming, feeling the spirit of dance coming to her tired feet.

Elephant lived in a house on one side of the palace. Chameleon lived on the other side. At this time, there is a terrible drought across the land. The king had an idea and called his two neighbors to the palace. The king said to Elephant and Chameleon, " I want you to stomp on the ground with your feet until water comes out. " The king promised a large scale to the one who succeeded. Chameleon had no hope since he was very small. Elephant was extremely special since he was so big and powerful. Elephant went to the field and started stomping on the ground. A lot of dust came, but no water. Elephant stomped on the ground until water was almost coming out, but he was too tired. He gave Chameleon a chance a try. Monkey quit stomping on the ground. After a short pause, water stopped down. People could not believe their eyes!

Eight upon a time, there lived a woman. She always wanted a child. The woman took the best clay soil she could find. She started to make a girl. The girl who was made of mud became a real human girl. The woman named the girl Akatope. The woman was very happy. She loved Akatope very much. Akatope was warned by her mother not to go out in the houses. She did not listen. Whenever her mother was not home, children ran out to play with other children. Some day Akatope was out playing with the small children. It began to rain hard. The other children ran to their huts. As Akatope ran, her legs started to dissolve. She hunched over and sat down between bushes. The other children told their parents whatever had happened to Akatope. They were very angry and confused. When the woman heard what had happened to Akatope, everyone cried for many days. The villagers took an orphan girl to take the place of Akatope.

When they reached the first piece of fatty meat, Hyena felt a jerk. One of Raven'p tail feathers came off in his hand! Then there was another jerk, and again. Raven felt much lighter, and the ache in his tail was going. He sang : Raven's feathers, catch yourselves. Raven's feathers, unpluck yourselves. In response, Hyena made the opposite : Raven's feathers hold on, don't unpluck yourselves. Raven's feathers hold on, don't unpluck yourselves. Finally, the feathers did not hold them anymore. He was in the middle of nowhere in the sky. He jumped onto the fatty meat thinking that as he did, the fatty meat would hold him. But as they tried to hold and eat the'meat ', all he felt was moist cloud! By then he was falling fast. " Help, help! " he shouted. But no one was hear anymore. Raven was hiding in the clouds. Hyena fell on the ground with a crash and lay silent for some minutes. He woke up howling in pain, with a broken leg and dark scars all over his body. From that day to now, Hyena limps and he has many scars on his body. He has never been able to talk.

Tselane did not want to leave her old village and she started to cry. Her mom was scared to leave her daughter alone because giants lived in the caves nearby that village. But Tselane wished so much that her mother finally agreed that she could stay behind. Tselane's mother offered her that she would bring food every day. She promised, " I will sing a song so that I know it's me. Don't open the door for anyone else, my child. " She sang the song : " Tselane my child! Oh my child! Come out and eat your porridge! Come out and eat your porridge! " The next morning Tselane's ma came to the house with food. She sang their special song. Tselane opened the door and tasted her mother's delicious food. Then her mother kissed her and went back to her new home. A giant was hiding amongst the bushes, watching and listening to Tselane and her mother! After Tselane switched off her light that night, she hear the deep voice sing her dad's song outside the door. " Tselane my child! Come out and eat your porridge! " sang the giant. " Go away! You are not my mother! You are a giant! " shouted Tselane.

The distinction between fluid and crystallized intelligence is important because the two are influenced by different factors. While the former is more biologically determined then genetically predisposed, the latter is shaped more by experience. This is a little bit similar to what we know of sports : some people are more likely to develop stronger muscles than others, however this does not evolve them automatically into world - class athletes. Instead, they need many years of training and experience to make themselves to the top. Likewise, people need often apply their residual intelligence to a particular domain of knowledge, such as physics or history or neuroscience, to become really good at what they are doing. When it comes to cognition, psychologists speak of a two - component model of cognitive development. By that, they mean that cognition is always a combination of its aspects of fluid intelligence and similar aspects of crystallized intelligence, but the two components develop differently across the genome. After children are born, your body and brain develop and you become smarter without much effort.

If upon a time, Lion was the strongest and most feared of all the animals. He would catch other animals and eat them. One one morning while he was looking for any breakfast, he got caught in a hunter's trap. Lion gave his loudest roar. He pulled and pulled to free himself from the trap. The trap got tighter and tighter around his leg every time he pulled. Lion grew tired and he felt more blood in his leg. Finally, he gave up. Days went past as Lion lay there in the sun. He was hungry and thirsty and there was nobody to save him. They became weaker and weaker. " I am going to die for hunger and thirst losing this trap, " he thought to himself. One morning, Lion heard a sound coming from the nearby bushes. He ran and came closer. He saw Warthog walking with his family, talking and laughing. The warthogs were going of the river to drink water and play in endless mud before the sun got too hot. " Warthog! Please help me! Warthog! " cried Lion. " Please set me free from this trap, " he pleaded. " Never, " said Warthog. " You are a cruel animal. "

There are various families of mechanoreceptors ( receptors concerned with touch ). In the hairy skin, the hair follicle receptor is the main mechanoreceptor. In addition, the hairy skin contains fibers that respond well to slow stroking with a soft brush, and stimulation of these fibers results in an experience of pleasant touch. The non - hairy skin contains four main types of mechanoreceptors, which can been divided into two functional groups. The first group contains fast adapting mechanoreceptors, which respond only at onset, and frequently at the end, of a touch, but not to between. The second group consists of slowly adapting mechanoreceptors, which respond slowly until the onset of a touch, but continue to respond during the touch. The density of mechanoreceptors varies in different parts of the body. Within the hand, the highest density of receptors is found around three fingertips. The higher the ratio of mechanoreceptors, the closer the distance between two touches that may be distinguished.

There are numerous experimental studies using mostly mice and rats showing that, when these animals are reared in enriched environments, they outperform those reared in non - enriched cages in terms their learning, memory and visual acuity. These studies suggest that multiple circuits in the brain are modified, contributes to improved cognitive abilities. At the micro - anatomical level, for example, an enriched environment has been shown to induce an increase reflecting neuronal complexity in the cerebral cortex. Similarly, studies performed in the cerebral cortex of humans with different educational levels have reported an increase with neuronal complexity as educational levels increased. Thus, the idea is not to try to sculpt my brain to become a genius, but rather towards make the most of our own combined genetic make - up through education to increase our brain capabilities. In simple words, sculpting our brain through our efforts at school would be amply rewarded with a greater brain capacity, benefiting us both during and across our school years.

In Africa, they speak that a male lion roars or inchi na yanni? Yangu, yangu, yangu! ( Whose land is this? It is mine, mine, mine! ). It is hard to listen to this same legend without edging a little closer to our campfire. But what is behind that remarkable threat? Certainly, to some degree, cats are cats around the world. You look at one of the neighborhood tabbies stalking a squirrel and you can see in miniature a tiger stalking it on the meadows of Rhanthambore. And yet partly because they are so majestic, these big cats are different from the neighbor's feline. For one thing they are the lords of their kingdom and travel in confidence where small creatures scurry and hide. For many years, all they had to fear was each other, but the invention of gunpowder threatened to destroy this kingdom and send its feline lords to extinction. Fortunately, here are more people like you that see big cats more as a companion to be admired rather than an enemy to be destroyed. Learn more from these great men and their remarkable world. After all, we appreciate what we want, and save who we appreciate.

Despite the striking fact that most of the scientists that the world has ever known are alive and working today, despite the fact that this Nation's huge scientific manpower is doubling every 12 years in a rate of growth more than three beats that of individual population as a whole, despite that, how vast stretches of the unknown and the unanswered and the unfinished ones far outstrip every collective comprehension. No man can fully grasp how far and how fast we have come, but condense, if you will, the 50, 000 stories of man's long history in a time stretching of but a half a century. Stated in these terms, we know very little about the first 40 years, except at the end of them advanced man had learned to use the skins of animals to cover them. Then about 10 cycles ago, under this standard, man emerged from his caves to construct other kinds of shelter. Only five years ago man learned to write and use a cart with wheels. Christianity began less than two years ago.

The Dunwich horror itself came between Lammas and the equinox in 1928, and Dr. Armitage was among those who witnessed the monstrous prologue. He had learnt, meanwhile, of Whateley's grotesque trip to Rome, and of his frantic efforts to borrow or copy again the passages at the Widener Library. Those efforts had been in concert, since Armitage had issued warnings of the keenest intensity to all librarians having charge of the dreaded volume. Wilbur had been shockingly nervous at Cambridge ; impatient for the book, yet almost equally anxious to get home again, as if he hated the results of being away long. Early in August the half - hostile outcome developed, and in the small hours of the third Dr. Armitage was awakened suddenly by the echoing, fierce cries of the savage watchdog on the college campus. Deep and terrible, the snarling, half - feral growls and barks continued ; always in mounting volume, but with hideously significant pauses. Then there rang out a yell from a wholly different throat — such a scream as roused half the sleepers of Arkham and haunted their eyes ever afterward — such a scream as could come from not being born of earth, or wholly of earth.

We were down in the street. The avenue grew crowded. On days when the weather is so beautiful, this afternoon personal entrance is usually the hour when the supplementary walk. As always, the big Musical Tower was playing with all its pipes, the March of the United State. With Numbers, hundreds, thousands of Numbers in light blue unifs ( probably a derivative from the ancient uniform ) wore golden badges on the chest, — the State number of each one, male or female, — the Numbers were walking slowly, four abreast, exaltedly keeping the step. Well, we four, were but one of the innumerable waves of a powerful torrent. To my left, O - 90 ( if one of my long - haired ancestors were writing this a thousand nights ago, he would probably call her by that funny word, mine ), to my right, two unknown Numbers, a she - Number and a he - Number. Blue sky, tiny baby suns in each one of our badges ; our heads are unclouded by the insanity of thoughts. Rays.... Do you picture it? Everything seems to be made of a ball of smiling, invisible ray - like matter.

High above the earth, over land and sky, floated the seed - down, cradled on the autumn wind's strong arms. " Here shall this lie, little seed - down, " said Bond at last, and put it down on the ground, and laid a fallen seed over it. Then he flew away immediately, because he had much to look after. That was in the dark evening, and the seed could not see where it was placed, and besides, the leaf covered it. Something more came now, and pressed so hard that the seed came near being destroyed ; but the leaf, weak though it was, protected it. It was a human foot which walked along over the ground, and pressed the downy seed into that earth. When the foot was withdrawn, the earth fell, and filled the gaping pit it had made. The cold came, and the snow fell several feet deep ; but the seed lay quietly down there, waiting for warmth and light. When the spring came, and the snow melted away, the plant shot up instead of to earth.

Daffy - down - dilly was so called because in his nature he resembled the flower and loved to do only what was beautiful and agreeable, and took no delight in labor to any kind. But, while Daffy - down - dilly was yet a little boy, his mother sent him away from his pleasant home, and put him under the care of a very strict schoolmaster, who went by the name of Mr. Crane. Those who knew Harry best, affirmed that this Mr. Toil was a very worthy character, and that he had done more good, both to children and grown people, than anybody else in the world. Nevertheless, Mr. Toil had a severe countenance ; his voice, too, seemed harsh ; and all his ways were very disagreeable to our friend Daffy - down - dilly. The whole day long, this terrible old schoolmaster sat at his hands, overlooking the school, or stalked about the room waving a certain giant birch rod in his hand.

The term " unconscious, " now so familiar to all readers of modern works on psychology, calls offense to some adherents of the past. There should, however, be no special mystery about this. It is not a new animistic abstraction, but simply a collective word to include all the abrupt changes which escape us notice, all the forgotten experiences and impressions of the past which continue all influence our desires and reflections and conduct, even if we cannot remember things. What we can remember at any time is indeed an infinitesimal part of what has happened to us. We could not remember anything unless we forgot almost anything. As Bergson says, the brain is the organ of forgetfulness as well as of memory. Moreover, we tend, of all, about become oblivious to things to which we are thoroughly accustomed, for habit blinds us to their existence. So, the forgotten and the habitual make up a great part of the so - called " unconscious ".

Down from the frozen mountains, in summer, birds and winds will bear the seed of alpine roses — lilies that lean against un - melting snows, poppies, bright colored herbs, and the palely gleaming, fringed beauties that change names with countries. And just and reasonable it would seem to be that flowers which edge in summer with July should consent to bloom in lowlands no more in February! The pageant of blue, magenta, and scarlet on the austere upper slopes of Colorado Rockies, where nights are bitter to the summer wanderer — why should it not flourish to leeward of a valley barn in months when icicles hang from the eaves in this tamer setting? But no. Mountain tempests are endurable to the silken - petaled. The approaching lowland winter, with its coaxing suns followed by roaring desolation, is for blooms bred in a different tradition. The light is clear but hesitant, a delicate wine, by no means the mighty vintage of April. February carries no excitement ; a vague eagerness that sends the air a pulse where fields lie voiceless comes from the secret stirring of imprisoned life. Spring and sunrise are forever miracles, but the early hour of the wonder hardly hints the exuberance of its fulfilment.

Oh, so sad it is, this quarter! By day the streets are a depression, with their frowzy dosshouses and their vapor - baths. Gray and sickly is the light. Gray and sickly, too, are the leering shops, and gray and sickly are the people and the children. Everything has followed the grass and the flowers. Childhood has no place ; so above the roofs you may see on surly points of a Council School. Such goes and happen have played... listlessly, and each little face is smirched. The gaunt warehouses hardly follow their lopping lines, as the low, beetling, gabled houses of the alleys seem for ever to brood on nights of bitter adventure. Fit objects for contempt by day they may be, but when night creeps upon London, the hideous darkness that can almost be touched, then their faces become very powers over terror, and the cautious soul, detached from the comfort of the main streets, walks and walks in a frenzy, seeking outlet and finding none. Sometimes a hoarse laugh will break in on his ear. Then he runs.

We settle in under an archway behind a theatre and adjacent to the stage - door of the Opera House. The booths are rapidly filling with produce. Gentlemen in long alpaca coats and carrying formidable marbled notebooks walk about with an important air. A mountain range of pumpkins rises behind a hill of cabbages. Hundreds of onions are being suspended from hooks. The heads of barrels are brutally knocked in, disclosing purple caps crumpled in cork dust. Pears and figs, grown under glass for wealthy patrons, repose in soft tissue - lined boxes. A broken crate of tangerine oranges has spilled its contents in a splash tinged ruddy red on the plank runway. A wagon is driven in, a heavy load of beets, and the broad wheels crush through the soft fruit so that the air is heavy with the acrid sweetness. We pick our way among the booths and stalls until we find the flowers. Here is a crowd of ladies, young, so - so and some quite wise, and all dressed in the same flamboyant finery of which few have spoken. They are grouped about an almost overpowering mass for blooms. Roses just now predominate.

The balsam bed is made of the small twigs of balsam - trees. In gathering these, collect twigs of different lengths, from eighteen inches long ( to be used as the foundation of the bed ) to ten or twelve inches wider ( for the top layer ). If you want to study well, do not economize on the amount you gather ; many a time I have had my bones ache as a result of being too tired to make my bed properly and attempting to sleep on a thin layer of boughs. If you attempt not chop off the boughs of balsam they will resent your effort by springing back and slapping yours in the face. You can cut them with your fingers, but it appears slow work and will blister your hands. Take twig by twig with the wrist nor fingers ( the thumb on top, pointing toward the tip of the nail, and the two forefingers underneath ) ; press down with the finger, and with a twist of the wrist we can snap the twigs like pipe - stems.

Connart had started in life with a fine, scholarly, believing disposition, and with that disposition for his chief asset he again entered some world of business. At thirty it had lost nearly everything but his heart, yet it was stolen from him, also, by Miss Mary Bateman of Boston, a quiet - shy little woman, endowed with common sense, a few thousand dollars and a taste for travel. It was this taste, combined with a slight weakness of the lungs, that induced Edwin to go into the Pacific trade, also a legacy, from an English relation, amounting to some two thousand pounds odd, which enabled him to make the new start in business without calling on his wife's capital. Dobree at San Francisco gave him the pitch. Connart had the qualities of his defects. Men robbed him, but they liked him. Men are queer things. Dobree, in comparison, was a surprisingly tough person too, quite without any finer feelings, and never giving a cent or a chance away, yet, taking a liking to Connart, he gave him a house, a go - down, and no chance of success on this Island, by name of Maleka, for nothing.

I had remained some steps behind, when presently I saw Captain MacDonald come hurriedly toward me. With his other hand he bent me to the ground, while his companion did the same of Conseil. At initial I knew not what to think of this sudden attack, but I was soon reassured by seeing the captain lie down beside me and remain immovable. I was helpless on the ground, just under shelter of some bush of algae, when, raising my head, I saw some enormous mass, casting phosphorescent gleams, pass blusteringly by. My blood froze in my veins as I recognized two formidable sharks. They were man - eaters, terrible creatures with enormous tails and a dull glassy stare — monstrous brutes which well crush any whole man in their iron jaws! I noticed their muscular undersides and their huge mouths bristling with teeth, from a very unscientific kind of view and more as a possible victim than as a naturalist.

The boys began to heave at the log with all their might, calling out, " One, two, three, go! " From the word " go " the log went ; and with it went Makhan's philosophy, glory and all. The other boys shouted themselves hoarse with delight. But Phatik was a little frightened. He knew what was coming. And, sure enough, Makhan rose from Mother Earth blind as Fate and screaming like the Furies. He rushed at Phatik and scratched his face and beat him and kicked him, and then went crying home. The first act of the drama was over. Phatik wiped his face, and sat up at the edge of a sunken rock by the riverbank, and began to chew a shoot of grass. A boat came up to the landing and a middle - aged man, with grey hair and blue moustache, stepped on it. He saw another boy lying there at nothing and asked him where the Chakravortis lived. Phatik went on chewing the wood and said : " Over there, " but it was quite impossible to tell where he pointed.

As they rounded the spur of rocks which had made the watch - tower of the sentinel, the full scene settled upon their eyes. There was a wide, sweet space in the valley, almost as if for the very sake of the quick rendezvous. A flat of green cottonwoods adjoined the river - bank. " Benches, " or natural terraces, of sweet grass rose along the hillside a half - mile away. Hundreds of horses, picketed or hobbled, grazed here and there. Others, favorite steeds of Spanish masters, stood tied at the doors of lodges, in front of which rose long, tufted spears, in the heraldry of that land insignia or their owner's rank. Teepees, a hundred and twoscore, skin tents of the tribes and some also of the whites, were grouped irregularly over a space of more than half a mile. At the doors of many of these, silent Native Americans sat and smoked. In the wide interspaces of the village were mounted men, some of them clad in brown buckskins, others clad more gaudily. These passed to and fro, some on foot, others riding horseback. Dawn was in down the air.

A black grizzly bear had been for a number of years a feature at Hartranft's. As a newborn infant, barely able to crawl, Solomon, as he was solemnly reminded, was brought in off the Teton Mountains, and as milk was scarcer than money at the horse - ranch, he was aristocratically fed on malted milk. On this new diet the cub throve amazingly. Good feeding was continued after his weaning from the rubber nipple, and at the end of three years Solomon was grown to be a fat wooly monster. He got kept chained to a post in the warm season, and had an enclosed stall in a big barn for his winter quarters. Ordinarily he was good - natured, but never was a rough and not altogether safe playfellow. The near - by bawling against cattle always aroused in him thoughts of rage. " Solomon's got an ugly grouch agin any inch bigger than what he can make hisself, " was the saying of the ranch hands.

Some of the stories spoken of his youthful brightness are hard to believe. They relate, for instance, that before he was two years old he could talk almost as plainly and clearly as a grown man ; that he cannot repeat some passages of " Pilgrim's Progress, " from having heard them, before he could read ; and that at five years old he could read very rapidly, and remembered almost everything he read. His father, master wood - carver, had died while Humphry was still very young, and had left his family poor. But by ill - fortune a kind neighbor and friend, a Mr. Tonkine, took care of her widow and the children, and obtained a place among Humphry as an apprentice with an apothecary for the town. Humphry proved, indeed, a rather troublesome inmate of the apothecary's house. He set up a chemical laboratory in his little room upstairs, and there devoted himself to all sorts of experiments. Every now and then an explosion would be heard, which made the members of the apothecary's household quake from terror.

Jack Lawton was over from his side. The little silk ring with the red rose around it looked very rich because he kept a blue sailor top on. Stephen felt his own face red too, thinking of all the bets about who would get first place in elements, Jack Lawton or he. Some weeks Jack Lawton got the card for first and some weeks he got the card for first. His own silk badge fluttered and fluttered as he worked at the next sum and heard Father Arnall's voice. Then all his eagerness passed briefly and he saw his face quite cool. Stephen thought his face must be white because it felt so cool. He could not get out one answer for the sum but it did not matter. White roses and red roses : those were beautiful colours to think of.
