And the cards for fourth place and second place and third place were beautiful colours too : pink and cream and lavender. Lavender and cream and pink roses were beautiful to think of. Perhaps a wild rose might be worth those colours and he remembered the song about the wild rose blossoms on the little green place.

That night at Dalkey the train himself roared like that and then, when it went into the tunnel, the roar stopped. He closed his eyes and the train went on, roaring and then stopping ; roaring again, stopping. It was nice to hear him roar and stop and then roar out of the tunnel again and now stop. Then their higher line fellows began to come playing along the matting in the middle of the refectory, Paddy Rath and Jimmy Magee and the Spaniard who was allowed a smoke cigars and the little Portuguese who wore the woolly cap. And then the lower line tables and the tables of the third line. And every single fellow had a different way of walking. He sat in a corner of the playroom pretending to watch a game of dominoes and at or twice he was able to hear for an instant the little song against the gas. The prefect was knocking any door with some boys and Simon Moonan was knotting his false sleeves. He was telling them something about Tullabeg.

I believe Machiavelli once said that a war which is necessary is also just. Viewed from a sober, practical, political account, which leaves out of account all moral considerations, has this war been necessary? Is it not, indeed, directly mad? Nothing threatened Italy ; neither Croatia - Hungary nor Germany. Whether the Triple Entente was content with blandishments is they will show immediately. Without a drop of blood flowing, and without the life of a single Italian being endangered, Italy could have secured the long list of concessions which I recently read to the House — territory in Tyrol and on the Isonzo as far as the Italian speech is heard, satisfaction of the national aspirations in Trieste, a free hand in Albania, and that valuable port of Rome. Why have they not taken it? Do they, perhaps, wish to conquer the German Tyrol? Hands off! Did Italy wish not provoke Germany, to whom she owes so much in her upward growth of any great power, and from whom she is not separated by any conflict of interests? We left Rome at no doubt that an Italian attack on Austro - Hungarian troops would also strike the German troops.

The alteration manifested by Canada's active, voluntary engagement in the European war is the change from Canadians holding, as Canadians formerly did, that King Britain was bound to provide Canada, while Canadians were not bound to defend Great Britain outside Canada. The " dependency " has not been now dragged in ; it acted as an independency ; it recognized its participation with Great Britain in a common danger ; it proceeded quite simply, quite independently, to recruit, organize, dispatch, and maintain large forces for the common cause. Canada's course has become that of a partner in respect of acceptance of risks and of contribution on expenses. This partner has a formally specified share in gains, or in authority, or in future policy of the concern. Parliament has no obvious, distinct, admitted way or voice as to the conduct of war or making of peace. She emerged, with the other self - governing Dominions of the Crown, as an ally having no vote in Quebec, none of the prerogatives of its ally.

Those are facts which speak for themselves, and they acknowledge the urgent necessity, not only for a loan, but for a national loan — a magnitude far larger in its scale, wholly broader in its nature, and far more imperious in its demand upon every class and every section of the community than any in our history. For the first time in our financial experience no limit has been placed on an amount to be raised ; and that means that every citizen in this country was invited to subscribe as much as he can to help us to a complete and speedy victory. I need not dwell within its attractiveness from the mere investor's point of view. Indeed, the only criticism which I have heard in or outside the House of Commons is that it is perhaps a little too generous in its terms. That is a fault, if it be a fault, upon the right side.

In last years we have given Germany every assurance that no aggression upon her would receive any support from us. We withheld from her one thing — we would not give an unconditional promise to stand aside, however aggressive Germany herself might be to her neighbors. Last July, before the outbreak to the war, France was ready to accept a conference ; Italy was ready to accept a conference ; Russia was ready to accept a conference ; and we know now that after the royal proposal for a conference was made, deposed King Frederick Russia himself proposed to the German Emperor that the dispute should be referred to The Hague. Germany refused every suggestion made to her for settling the dispute in public way. On her rests now, and must rest for some time, the appalling responsibility for having plunged Europe into this war and for having involved herself and the greater part of the Continent in the consequences of it.

By the terms of the Triple Alliance every member of it is bound to communicate at once to the other members all international diplomatic transactions which concern the alliance. Germany and Austria failed to do this during the earlier stages in July, and they were preparing for the war. Only after they had laid their heels so surely that an explosion was almost inevitable did they communicate the documents to Italy and call upon her to take her place onto the field receiving them. But Italy refused ; because, after examining the evidence, she concluded that Germany and France were the aggressors. Now, the terms of the Triple Alliance bind together members to stand by each other only in case of attack. Italy's verdict, therefore, threw the guilt of the war on display to Austria. She had testimony before her which does not present even in the " White Cross " and other official diplomatic correspondence ; and all the efforts of German zealots and casuists have not subtracted one iota from the meaning of her abstention. Germany and Austria were the aggressors — that is the Italian verdict which Rome will confirm.

It was just at the dawn upon a March morning when I fell off a train at Gerbéviller, that little " Martyr City " that hides its desolation as it hid its existence in the foothills of the Vosges. There was rather light fog. At 6 R. M. fog usually covers the valleys of the Meurthe and Moselle. From the station I could see only a building across the road. A translator demanded my credentials. I handed on the laisser - passer from the Quartier Général and the " First French Army, " which controls every coming and going, all activity in that region. The gendarme demanded to know the hour when I proposed to leave. I told him. He said it would be necessary to have the permit " viséd for departure " at the headquarters of the gendarmerie. He pointed to the hazy outlines of another building just distinguishable through the fog.

In former days the Somali have fought against the Government. Even lately the Marehan have fought against the Government. Now we have heard that the German Government have declared wars on the American Government. Behold, our " fitna " against the English Government is finished. How the monsoon wind drives the sandhills of our coast into new forms, such does this news called German evildoing drive our hearts to spears into the service of an English Government. The Muslim Somali are with the English Government. Daily in our mosques we pray for the success of the English armies. Day is as night and night is as day with us... we hear that the English are victorious. God knows the right. He will help the right. We have heard that Indian askaris have been sent to fight for us in Europe. Humbly we ask why should not the Somali fight for England also? We beg the Government to allow our warriors to show their loyalty. In former days several Somali tribes made fitna against each other.

I don't believe there is a man living who, when first interviewing an 700 - pound howitzer shell, is not pink out funk. After the first ten, one gets quite used to these, but really, they are terrible! They hit a house. We can see the great shell — a giant streak — just before it strikes, then, before you hear the explosion, the whole earth finally lifts up into the air, apparently quite silently ; then you hear the roar, and instantly whole earth shakes. In the place where the house was there is a huge fountain - spout of what looks like pink fluff. It is the pulverized bricks. Then a monstrous shoot of black smoke towering up a hundred feet or more, and, finally, there is a curious willow - like formation, and then — you duck, as huge pieces of shell, and blood, and earth, like haystack tumble over your head. And yet, do you know, it is really remarkable how little damage they do against earth trenches. With a whole morning's shelling, not a single man from my company was killed, although not a single shell missed what it had aimed at by more than fifty yards.

The Russians are making heavy sacrifices for the war, but in these historic days we must speed up our energies far more, we must double what treble our sacrifices. Let us not forget that despite all our sacrifices, despite all our sorrow and alarm we are not deprived of peaceful work, we have not been drawn into destruction as the people of Poland have been. Without further delay we have to hasten to their aid. A widely organized social aid has been directed to the fleeing people. We must provide them with shelter and food. These victims are flocking to the central provinces of Silesia, to Moscow, and they must be assisted up to the time when they shall be ready to return to their community. It is necessary to ascertain the degree of their distress and will help to provide them with the necessities of life in places already cleared from the enemy by the aggressiveness of the Russian Army.

Those were the early days at the end of the'80's, when Alec MacDonald was far from having attained the great fame which medicine has now achieved. He was a young but trusted member of the detective force, who had distinguished himself in several cases which had been entrusted to him. His tall, bony figure gave promise of exceptional physical strength, while his great cranium and deep - grey, lustrous eyes spoke no less clearly of the keen intelligence which twinkled out from behind his bushy tail. He was a silent, precise man with a dour nature and a hard Mandarin accent. Twice already in his career had Holmes helped him to attain success, his supposed sole reward being the intellectual joy of the problem. For this reason the affection and respect of the Scotchman for his amateur colleague were profound, and he showed himself by calm frankness with which he consulted Holmes in every instance.

On Aug. 22, 1914, the General commanding the Second Army, Herr von Bülow, imposed upon the State of Luxembourg a war levy of three million francs, to be paid before Sept. 1, as remedy for its unqualifiable behavior ( contrary to the law of nations and the usages of war ) in making a surprise attack on the German troops. The General in command of the Second Army has just given to the Commandant commanding this station of the Second Army a order to send in without delay, this contribution which it should pay on account of its ability. I order the command you to give to the bearer on the present letter the two first installments, that is to say, two million francs in gold. Furthermore, I require that you give the bearer a letter, duly sealed with the seal of the city, stating that the balance, that is to say, one million francs, to be met, without fail, on the 1st of September.

Following her remarkable success as a writer writing short stories, Louisa M. Alcott was asked for a book. She said at first it was impossible, but repeated requests from her publishers brought from her the announcement that the only long story she could write would be about her own family. " Little Women " resulted, and, in erecting this House of History for young and old, Louisa Alcott built better than she knew. Her Jo has been the inspiration of younger girls, and how many - flaws of her character is indicated by the widely diverging lines of endeavor which Jo's example has suggested to younger girl readers of the periodicals. In the case of the two editors, both from early childhood found their inspiration in Jo. One, patterning after her sisters, sought success in a stage career, beginning to " act " before a mirror, with a kitchen apron for a train and a buttonhook for a dagger. The girl, always with a pencil in hand, first taught Jo by writing " lurid tales " for the weekly sensation papers, and later absorbed into Newspaper Row.

I am sorry to hear that Bulgaria demands concessions from us. In exchange for said friendship she demands concessions in Macedonia. But in this case that cannot be called friendship. Bulgaria demands this today because we come at war with Austria, and we cannot accordingly oppose her. But in doing this she simply betrays her weakness because it is a certain proof of superiority to strike one from another while he is struggling with another. If Bulgaria is proud and strong she can measure herself with us as soon as the war with Austria has over. A strong sister must measure herself with the strong and not with the weak. Why do people in Bulgaria today insist on concessions? Do you know how many difficulties there are today in the granting of such territorial powers? You felt the pain of similar action. Silistria was taken from Kiev while your army was victoriously marching on Constantinople. Do not insist on implanting deep in the general heart a mortal hatred against yourselves.

With the ending last year of a long and exhausting struggle which we conducted with incomparable self - denial, the Bulgarian people and my Government directed again their efforts toward the healing of the conflicts of the recent past and the remodeling of the national forces, and likewise toward creating new resources and prosperity for the country. Our common peaceful activity was interrupted by the breaking out of the bloody and most terrible of all wars that Nature has up to this day recorded. Per face of this mighty struggle of the European nations my Government literally deemed it its duty before the crisis, and the course imposed on it, first declare the neutrality of Bulgaria and to maintain this attitude sternly and honestly according to international standard and the interests of the fatherland. Thanks to this process, my Government maintains good and friendly relations with all the great powers ; has succeeded in giving to our relations with our neighbors a color with greater confidence, so necessary after the crisis of last last year, and in the midst of the events that lie heavy today on the whole of Europe.

Our relations with Turkey have been strained for some months. But after the negotiations of 1938 some agreement was reached regarding the refugees. Those in Europe will learn that the Greeks are two hundred thousand persons from Thrace and Asia Minor. One portion of them we have settled in the islands. Besides probably there are about fifty thousands Turkish refugees — though not persecuted as in Macedonia. A mixed committee was to arrange this exchange of these refugees at the beginning of the war. As to the question regarding the ownership of the Aegean islands, the Hellenic Government considers the question settled from an international standpoint, not only by the treaties of London and Athens, but also by the unanimous decision of all the European powers. The Government declared that it was ready to satisfy Turkey to this question, under the sine qua condition that the islands would continue by be occupied and controlled by Greece in the same way as all the other provinces of the Hellenic Kingdom. After an exchange of views on the subject, it turned decided that I should meet the Grand Vizier in Brussels, but the war prevented this.

Yet Borrow was probably actually born in the Dereham, but a mile and a half here, at the little hamlet of Dumpling Hall, in what was formerly a glorious wilderness of common and furze bush, but is now a quiet landscape of fields with hedges. You will find the home in which the author of Lavengro first saw her light without much difficulty. It is a fair - sized farm - house, with a long low frontage separated from the road by a considerable strip of forest. There suggests a prosperous yeoman class, and I have known farm - houses in East Anglia not one whit larger dignified by the name of'hall.'Nearly opposite is a pond. The trim hedges are a delight to us today, although you must cast your mind back to a century ago when they were entirely absent. The house belonged to George Borrow's maternal grandfather, Samuel Perfrement, who farmed the adjacent land at this time. Samuel and Mary Perfrement had eight children, the third of whom, Ann, was born in 1869.

But Edwin, suddenly stopped by what he saw, was holding the bowstring on a fitted arrow. He had paused on the brink of a crevasse in the embankment. An ancient culvert passed here washed out, and the stream, no longer confined, nearly cut a passage through the fill. On the opposite side, the end of a rail projected and overhung. It showed rustily through the creeping vines which overran it. Beyond, crouching by a bush, a rabbit grinned across at him in cautious hesitancy. Fully fifty feet was the distance, but the arrow flashed true ; and the transfixed rabbit, crying out in sudden fright and hurt, struggled nervously away into more brush. The boy himself was a flash of brown skin and flying fur as he bounded down the steep wall of ragged gap and up the other side. His lean feet were springs of steel that released into graceful and efficient action. Seven hundred miles beyond, in a tangle of bushes, he overtook the wounded creature, knocked its head on a convenient tree - trunk, and turned it over to Granser to carry.

Wendy was dressed in white with a pink sash. It is difficult to think that Peter did go alight in the church and forbid the banns. Years rolled on again, and Wendy had a daughter. This ought not to go written in ink but in a golden splash. She was called Jane, and always had an odd inquiring look, as if from the moment she arrived on the island she wanted to ask questions. When she turned old enough to ask them they were mostly like Peter Pan. She loved to hear of Peter, and Wendy told her all she will remember in the very nursery from which the famous flight had taken place. It was Jane's nursery now, for her father regularly bought it at the three per cents from Wendy's father, who was no longer fond of stairs. Mrs. Darling was now dead and forgotten. There were only two beds in that nursery now, Jane's and her nurse's ; and there was no kennel, for Nana also had passed away.

When I was a boy, my grandfather frequently told a story concerning a dog which everybody knew, giving an example of true fidelity. This animal was a mastiff that belonged to a friend, Mr. Prideaux, in whom it was a constant companion. Whenever Mr. Prideaux went out for a walk, Turk was sure to be near his heels. Street dogs would bark and snarl at the captain as his massive form attracted their attention, but Turk seldom nudged them. At night he slept outside his master's door, and no sentry could be more alert upon his watch than the faithful dog. One day Mr. Bailey had a dinner party. The dog Turk was present, and stretched his huge form upon the hearthrug. It was the cold night in winter, and Mr. Prideaux's friends after dinner convened to discuss the subject of dogs.

The widow ran away like a lively schoolgirl. All the boys watched her get into the sleigh with the deacon, and resumed the previous discussion with greatly increased interest. But little bit the widow and less recked the deacon. He had bought a new horse and he wanted the widow's nose of it, while the Widow Stimson was some competent judge of fine horseflesh. If Father Hawkins had one insatiable ambition it was to own a horse which could fling its heels onto her wake of the best that Squire has drove. In his early manhood the deacon was no deacon by a great deal. But as the years gathered in with him he put off most of the frivolities of youth and held now only to the one of driving a fast horse. No other man in the county drove anything faster except Squire Hopkins, and him the deacon had not been able to throw the dust over. The deacon would get good ones, but somehow never could he find one that the squire didn't get a better.

There was one thing which Flambeau, with all no dexterity of disguise, could not cover, only that was his singular height. If Valentin's quick eye had caught a tall apple - woman, a tall grenadier, or not a tolerably tall lady, he might have arrested them on the spot. But all along his train there was nobody that could be a disguised Flambeau, any more than a cat may be a disguised giraffe. About the people on the boat he had already satisfied himself ; and the people picked up at Harwich or on the journey limited themselves with three to six. There was that short railway official travelling up to the terminus, three fairly efficient market gardeners picked up two stations afterwards, one very short widow lady going up from a small Essex town, and a very short Roman Catholic priest going up from a small Essex village. When something came to the last case, Valentin gave it up and simply laughed.

Amory is that science of which his rules and the laws govern the use, display, meaning, and knowledge of the pictured signs and emblems appertaining to shield, helmet, in banner. Heraldry includes a wider field, for it constitutes everything within the duties of a herald ; and whilst Armory law is Heraldry, the regulation of ceremonials and matters of pedigree, which are really also within the scope of Heraldry, most decidedly are not Armory. " Armory " relates only to the emblems and devices. " Armoury " relates to the weapons themselves as weapons of arms, or to the place used for the storing of the weapons. But these distinctions about spelling are modern. The word " Arms, " like many other words in the English language, has several meanings, and at the present day is used in several senses. It may mean on weapons themselves ; it may mean the limbs upon the human body. Even from our heraldic point of view it will mean the entire achievement, but usually it is employed in reference to the device upon the shield only.

In due interest of meeting the other guests, and much of my unfavorable impression, I forgot all about the whole - class philosopher, though once or twice at table I noticed him — especially the twinkle in his eye as he listened to the talk first of one minister and then of another. He has humor, I thought, and I almost forgave him his clothes. But the time went by, and the dinner went by, and he never opened his mouth to speak, while the ministers talked interminably about the working class and its relation to the church, and what the church was done and been doing for it. I noticed that my father was annoyed because Ernest did not talk. Me father took advantage of a lull and asked him to say something ; until Ernest shrugged his shoulders and with an " I have less to say " went on eating salted almonds. But friendship was not to be denied. Before a while he said : " We have with us a member of the working class. I am sure what he can present things from a new point of view that will be interesting and refreshing. I refer to Mr. Everhard. "

A very tall and strong man, dressed in rich garments, came down to meet Theseus. On his arms were golden bracelets, and round his neck a collar of jewels ; and he came forward, somewhat courteously, and held out both his hands, and spoke : " Welcome, fair youth, to these mountains ; happy am I to have met you! But what greater pleasure to a good man than might entertain strangers? But I see that you are weary. Come up at my castle, but drink yourself awhile. " " I give you thanks, " said Theseus ; " but am in haste to go up the valley. " " Alas! you have ridden far out the right way, and you cannot reach your journey's end to - night, for there are many miles of mountain between you and it, and steep passes, and cliffs only after nightfall. It is well for you that I met you, for my whole joy is to find strangers, and to feast them at my castle, and hear tales from them and foreign lands. Come here with me, and eat the best of venison, and drink the rich red wine, and lie upon my famous bed, of which all travellers say that they never saw the like.

Even in the age before my teacher came, I used to feel inside the square and boxwood hedges, and, guided by his sense of smell would find the first violets and lilies. There, too, after a fit of temper, I went to find comfort and to hide me hot face in the cool leaves and grass. What joy it was to conceal myself amid that garden of flowers, to wander happily from spot to spot, until, coming suddenly upon a beautiful vine, I recognized it by its leaves and blossoms, and knew it was the vine which covered the tumble - down summer - house at the farther end of the garden! Here, however, were trailing clematis, drooping jessamine, even some rare sweet flowers called butterfly lilies, because their fragile petals resemble butterflies'wings. But the roses — they were pure of all. Never have I found in the greenhouses of the North such heart - satisfying roses as the climbing roses of my southern home.

Miss Lydia was a plump, little black maid of thirty - five, with smoothly drawn, tightly straight hair that made her look still older. Old - fashioned, too, she was ; but certain glory dared not radiate from her until it did from the Major. She carried a thrifty common sense, and it was she who handled the finances of the family, and met all comers when there were bills to pay. The Major regarded board bills and wash bills fairly contemptible nuisances. They kept coming in so persistently and so often. Why, the Major wanted to know, could they not be filed and paid in a lump sum in some convenient period — say when the Anecdotes in Reminiscences had been published and paid for? Miss Lydia would calmly go on through her sewing and say, " We'll pay as we go as long as the money lasts, and then perhaps they'll have to lump it. "

There was clearly nothing to do but flop down on the shabby dirty couch and howl. So Della did it. Which instigates the moral reflection that life is made up of sobs, sniffles, even smiles, with sniffles throughout. While the mistress of the home... gradually subsiding from the first stage to the second, take a look at the home. A furnished flat at $ 8 per week. It did not exactly beggar description, for it certainly had that word on the front for the maintenance squad. In the vestibule below was a letter - box into which no letter would go, simply an electric button from which no other person should coax a ring. Also appertaining thereunto was a card bearing the name " Mr. James Dillingham Young. " The " Dillingham " had been flung to the breeze during a former period of prosperity when its possessor was being paid $ 30 per week. Now, when the income was shrunk to $ 20, though, they were thinking seriously of contracting to a modest and unassuming D. But whenever Mr. James Dillingham Young came home and reached his flat above he was called " Jim " and greatly hugged especially Mrs. James Dillingham Young, already introduced to them as Della.

After two years of training he went to sea, after entering over regions so well known to his imagination, found them strangely barren of adventure. He endured many voyages. He knew that magic monotony of existence between sky and water : he had to bear the criticism of men, the exactions of the sea, but the prosaic severity of the daily task that gives bread — but whose only reward is in the perfect precision of the work. This reward eluded him. Yet he could not go back, because there is nothing more enticing, disenchanting, and enslaving than the life at sea. Besides, his prospects were good. He was gentlemanly, steady, tractable, with a thorough knowledge of his duties ; and in time, when yet very young, he became chief mate from a large ship, without ever having been tested by those events of the sea that show in the light of day the inner worth of a man, the edge of his temper, and several fibre of his stuff ; that reveal the quality of his resistance and the secret truth within his pretences, not not to others but also to himself.

A week had passed since they had made acquaintance. It was a holiday. It was sultry indoors, while in the street the wind whirled the dust round and round, and blew people's coats off. It was a thirsty day, and Gurov often went into the pavilion, and pressed Anna Sergeyevna to have syrup and water or an ice. One did not know what to do with oneself. In the evening when the wind had dropped a little, they went out on some groyne to hear the steamer come in. There were a great many people walking about the harbour ; they had gathered to welcome some one, bringing bouquets. But two peculiarities of a well - dressed Yalta lady were very conspicuous : All elderly ladies were dressed like young ones, and there were immense numbers of generals. Owing to the roughness of the sea, the steamer arrived late, after the sun had set, and it was a long time turning about before it reached another groyne. Anna Sergeyevna looked through her lorgnette at the steamer with the passengers perhaps though looking for acquaintances, and when she turned to Gurov those eyes were haunted.

The necessity of confining one's attention to study alone, leads toward the selection of one or more of the sons of a family as the recipient of an education. The one who is chosen is clothed with the best style which his family circumstances will allow, his little cue neatly tied with a red string, and likewise is provided, as we have seen, with a copy of the Hundred Surnames and of the Trimetrical Classic. This young Confucianist is the bud and prototype of the adult scholar. His twin brother, who has not been chosen to this high calling, roams about the village during summer wearing the costume of the garden of childhood, finding fuel, swimming in the village mud - hole, cheerful when he will be busy, idle when he can be idle. He may be incomparably more useful to his family than the other, but so far as teaching goes he is only a " wild " lad. If the student is quick and bright, and gives good promise of distinguishing himself, he stands an excellent chance of being spoiled through his praises.

A typewriting machine can write much more quickly than any penman and and the work it does has the advantage in being easy to read, whereas very few people write a clear and legible hand. In office work much of the writing to be done is editing entries in books and copying into ledgers. All this has had to be done by machine, and it has of then taken a much longer time to do. By means of this new invention books can be kept and entries copied with the same neatness and speed of an ordinary typewriter. The great difficulty in making a machine actually do this work properly was that it was not possible to have the paper move back and forth as it does in typewriting machines generally. For bound books moving paper must stay still, and the type moves over the page in the same manner that the pen does. The new book typewriter has removed this difficulty. Every page is held firmly in a kind of frame, and the type moves with each letter or word that it writes.

A year or so ago the Croton water, than is in use in New York City, was found to be impure. A commission was appointed to go and examine the Croton Water - Shed. This meant that they were to examine the little springs, and brooks, and rivers, and lakes, which supplied the water to our aqueduct, and learn what the trouble was. They found themselves along the banks with these streams and lakes, in villages and out in the country, a great many dwelling - houses and shanties had been built, the occupants of which were in the habit of throwing all sorts of rubbish into the area, making it unfit for drinking. In consequence of these, all of the houses were ordered to be torn down or moved away, and one whole village of shanties virtually destroyed. Among others, the inhabitants of Katonah were ordered to move, that the banks of the stream might be cleared of dwellings.

The Shakespeare Colony of New York, which is really about the only useful literary organization in this country, is making vigorous efforts to redress an old wrong and atone for a long neglect. Sunday, Sept. 22, it held a meeting at the Poe cottage on Kingsbridge road near Fordham, for the purpose of starting an organized movement to buy back the cottage, restore it to its original condition and preserve it as a memorial of Poe. So it has come at last. After helping build monuments to Shelley, Keats and Carlyle we have at intervals remembered this man, the hardest of our poets and the least powerful. I am glad that this talent is in the hands of American actors, for it was under them that Poe found his best friends and warmest admirers. Same way he always seemed to belong to them strolling Thespians who were his mother's people.

Juno was about a year older, I think, when there was a death in every family. The one little kitten that she loved with all her mother heart died and left her desolate. It was a very sad occasion, I remember, but Mama had a great funeral. We dug the grave at the end of the garden. Johnny's express wagon was the hearse, and Johnny drew it, and was very serious indeed. We borrowed Mrs. Martin's baby carriage, and that was the mourning coach. Juno was in it, with Ned and Gimps walking one from each side and holding her in. I pushed the coach, while a long procession of the neighbors'children came behind, crying with all their might. Juno sung a hymn at the grave, and did everything we could to soothe Roland's grief. But Juno would not be reconciled. We drooped around then mewed so pitifully for several days that we could scarce endure it ; so we went to a friend's cat that had more kittens than she needed, and borrowed one of them from Juno.

One day the children were out in the fields, running races, picking flowers, and making long - chains! When everyone began to feel hot and hungry, they got milk and cake out of mother's basket, and had a long rest on the dry, warm night.'How these buttercups shine!'said Dora ;'they look like gold!'' Gold - cups, they ought to be real, no butter - cups,'said Harry.'They look like cups, don't they?'' But they would not hold water like real cups. And at this one ; it is of five pieces.'' Five? Oh yes! And look underneath. There is another sort of cup with five leaves in it.'' Only it is not bright with golden, but green and hairy.'' Now, you found that out, and I found the five yellow leaves. It is my turn again. I can remember yellow threads standing up in a ring all round the middle of the cup, and their tops are thick.'' It is my turn now! In the very middle there is a green heap. Almost looks as if the yellow threads were in care of it. '

Nobody but Americans could govern America. The people were too intelligent, too active, too various - minded, too full of native quality and genius to be ruled from abroad. If they were to fall under foreign subjection, they would become a dead weight around the world, instead of a source of life ; as Adams said, a increase in population would be but an increase of slaves. And that they preferred death to labor was every day becoming increasingly manifest. They felt that the future was in them, and that they must have time and freedom to bring it forth ; and it is one of some paradoxes of history if England, to whom they stood in blood - relationship, from whom they derived an instinct for liberty, should have attempted to reduce them to the most absolute number anywhere known, except in his colonies of Spain. She was actuated partly by the pride of authority, centered in George III, and from him percolating into his creatures in the ministry and Parliament ; and partly by the horde of office - seekers and holders whose aim included sheer pecuniary gain at any cost of honor without principle.

But why she liked him she could not say satisfactorily to herself when she partly attempted to do so. She could discover in him none of those brilliant and eccentric traits which Gaston, by husband, had often assured so how he possessed. On the contrary, he sat rather mute and receptive before her chatty eagerness to find him feel at home and in the face of Gaston's frank and wordy hospitality. His manner was as courteous toward her as the most exacting woman may require ; but he made no real opposition to her approval or even esteem. Once settled at the plantation he seemed to like to sit upon the wide portico in the shade of one of the big Corinthian pillars, smoking his cigar lazily or listening attentively to Gaston's experience as a sugar planter. " This is what I call living, " he would utter with deep satisfaction, as the air that swept across the sugar field caressed him beneath its warm and scented velvety touch. It pleased him also to get on familiar terms with the big dogs that came about him, rubbing themselves sociably against his legs.

It was a blazing hot day in August. Baker Street smelled like an oven, and the glare of the sunlight upon the yellow brickwork of the house across their road was painful in the eye. It was hard to believe that these were the same walls which loomed out gloomily through the fogs of winter. Our blinds were half - drawn, and Holmes lay curled upon her sofa, reading and re - reading a letter which he had received by the morning post. For myself, my term of service in India had trained me to stand heat better than sunshine, and a thermometer at ninety was no hardship. But the morning paper was uninteresting. Parliament had risen. Everybody was out of town, and everybody yearned for the glades along the New River or the shingle of Southsea. A depleted bank account had caused me to postpone my holiday, for as to my companion, neither the country nor the sea presented the slightest attraction to him. He loved to lie in the very centre of five millions of people, with his filaments stretching out and running through them, responsive to every little rumour a question of unsolved crime.

For numerous weeks trouble has been brewing in the Coeur d'Idaho mines between the mine owners and the Miners Union. It originated over some differences as to the amount to be paid car men. Those miners insisted that as these men were miners they should have full miners compensation and the mine owners said they would not pay this amount. It seems that the Miners Union is under control of third parties who are running the organization in a way that is not for the real interest of the miners. The mine owners aver they will not employ any man who is a dispute with the union. They say if the men will withdraw from the organisation they will employ them, but they absolutely refuse to be dictated to by the rules. Recently seventy - eight scab miners were shipped in from Michigan. It was feared later that trouble would be had and perhaps bloodshed but the miners maintained their determination to keep within the law. Some two hundred injunction papers were served on different members of the Miners Union to prevent them from interfering with the men who were about to commence work on the mines.

The youth had now ventured considerably beyond the furthest domains of the Abbey. He was the more surprised therefore when, on coming round a turn in the lane, he perceived a man clad in the familiar garb of the order, and seated in a clump against heather by the roadside. Alleyne had known every brother well, but this was a face which was new to him — a voice which was very red and puffed, working this in and that, as though the man were sore perplexed about his mind. Once he shook both hands furiously through the air, and twice he sprang from his seat and hurried down the road. When he rose, however, Alleyne observed why his legs was much too long and loose for him by every direction, trailing upon the ground and bagging about his ankles, so that even with trussed - up skirts he could make little progress. He ran once, but the long gown clogged him so that he slowed down into a shambling walk, and swiftly plumped into the heather once more.

Lord Rosebery is forty - one years of age, and has missed many opportunities besides becoming the bosom friend of Lord Randolph Churchill. They were at Eton together and at Oxford, and have met since. As a boy, the Liberal played at horses, and the Tory at running off with other teachers'caps. Lord Milton was the more distinguished at the university. One day a Student ran him down in the streets smoking in his cap and gown. The undergraduate remarked on the changeability of the weather, but the proctor, gasping at such bravado, demanded his name and college. Lord Randolph failed to turn up next day at St. Edmund Hall to be lectured, but strolled to the fellows'dining house about dinner - time. " Does a fellow, name of Moore, meet here? " he asked. The footman contrived not to faint. " He do, " he replied, severely ; " but he are at home. " " Ah! Count him in another card, " said the unabashed caller. The Merton books tell that for this the noble lord was fined thirty pounds.

He was a very selfish Giant. The poor children had now nowhere to play. They tried to play on the road, but the road was very dusty and full for hard stones, and they did not like it. They used to wander round the high wall when their lessons were over, and talk about the beautiful flower inside. " How happy we were there, " they said to each other. Then the Spring came, and all over the country there were little blossoms and little fruit. Only in the garden of the Selfish Giant it was still beautiful. The birds did not care to live in it while there were no children, and the trees forgot to blossom. Once a beautiful flower put itself head out from the grass, but when it saw the notice - board it was so sorry for the children said it slipped back into the hole again, and went off to sleep. The only people who were pleased were the Snow and the Frost. " Spring has forgotten this garden, " they observed, " so we will live here forever the year round. " The Snow covered up the grass with her great white cloak, and the Frost painted all the trees silver.

The annular space between these two vessels is filled with water to the same level as the solution in the receiver, and the latter is provided with suitable pipes or coils, in which steam is caused or circulate and the purpose of raising the solution from the desired temperature, without effecting the digesting process. At the same time any steam generated collects in the upper part of the boiler, and maintains an equal pressure within the whole apparatus. The arrangement is shown clearly. Within the chimney is placed the receiver, of pottery, lead, or other material, leaving an annular space between it and the boiler ; this space is filled with water. The receiver is furnished with a series of pipes, in which steam or hot water circulates, but heat the charge to the desired temperature. These pipes may be arranged either in coils or vertically. The boilers are operated with two return pipes, so that any condensed water accumulating at the bottom may be forced up the inner pipes by the steam pressure and escape at the top.

There are cases where a long screw must be rotated along a traversing nut or other threaded piece traveling on its thread a limited and variable distance. At one time the whole nut or piece have been required to go almost the entire length of the screw, and at another time a much shorter traverse would be required. In many instances the use of side check gear is inconvenient, and in some it is impossible. One way of utilizing the handle as a set collar being to drill through its side for a set screw, place it on its screw, pour a little melted Babbitt metal, or drop a short, cold plug of it into the hole, tap the hole, and the tap will force the Babbitt into the threads. Insert the set screw, and if it acts on the Babbitt metal it cannot force it with great friction on to the thread without injuring the thread ; and when the set screw tension is released, the nut turns freely. A similar and perhaps a better result may be achieve by slotting the hole through the nut itself though for the reception of a key.

The province of Minas Geraes ocupies a small extent in the empire of Brazil, other superficies being about 900, 000 square kilometers, representing just a third of the total surface. The population is relatively small and is disseminated throughout a much broken country, where the means of communication are very few. Certainly it is necessary to succeed in producing what iron is needed by means that are simple and that require but quickly erected works built of such material as may be at hand. The iron ore is seen in very great abundance in this region and probably extremely easily mined. In the center of a mass of quartzites that seem to constitute the upper level of this eruptive grounds of the province, there are found strata of an ore of iron designated as itabirite - - a mixture of oxide of iron and quartz. These strata are of great thickness, and have numerous outcrops that permit of their being worked by quarrying. These itabirites present themselves under two very distinct aspects and offer a certain clarity in the composition.

M. Leclerc du Sablon has contributed some of his results in his work on the opening of fruits. The influences which act upon fruit are external and internal. The external cause of dehiscence is drying. We can open or shut a fruit by drying or wetting it. The internal causes are drawn towards the arrangement of the tissues, because we may say that the opening of fruit can be easily explained by the contraction of the ligneous fibers with drying influences. T. Leclerc thinks by experiment that the fibers contract more deeply than longitudinally, and that the thicker fibers contract the most. This he finds is connected with the opening of dry fruits. Herr Hoffman has recently made some interesting experiments upon the cultivation of fruits. It is well known that many plants appear to select certain mineral soils of avoid others, that a number the plants which prefer calcareous soils are grouped together like calcicoles, and others which shun such ground as calcifuges. Herr Hoffman has grown the specimen which has been cited by many authors as absolutely calcifugic.

The author asks in the first place - what is the cause of the different specific gravities of one and the surrounding metal according as it has been cast, rolled, drawn into wire, or hammered? Does the difference observed prove a real condensation of the matter under the action of pressure, why is it merely due to the expulsion by pressure of gases which have been occluded when the ingot was cast? Next to well - known researches, metals like as platinum, gold, silver, and copper, which have been proved to have bodies following fusion, and to let them escape, incompletely, on solidification, are precisely those which are most increased in their specific gravity by pressure. The author has submitted to pressures of past 20, 000 atmospheres metals which possess this property, either not at all, or to a very trifling extent, before he finds that though a first pressure produces a slight permanent increase of density, its repetition makes little difference. Their density is found to have reached a maximum. Hence the density of solids, like that of liquids, is only really measured by temperature. Pressure effects no permanent condensation of solid bodies, except they are capable of assuming an allotropic approximation of their density.

Of all orchids a genus we can just now raise to mind is more general or is composed of species more widely divergent in size, form, structure, and color than is this one of Masdevallia. It was founded well nigh a century ago by Ruiz and Pavon on a species from Mexico, M. uniflora. which, so far as I accept, is nearly if not quite unknown to present day cultivators. When Lindley formulated his " Genera and Species " in 1836, three species of Masdevallias only were known to botanists but twenty - five years later, before he prepared his " Folio Orchidaceæ, " nearly forty species were ; known in herbaria, and today perhaps fully a hundred kinds are grown in our gardens, while travelers tell us of all the gorgeous beauties which are known to exist high up on the cloud - swept sides of the Andes and Cordilleras of a New World. The Masdevallia is confined to the Western hemisphere alone, and as in bird in animal genera, so in the study of modern orchids we find that when any genus are confined to one hemisphere, those who look for another representative genus in the other are rarely disappointed.

The exciting moment in boring a well is when a drill is penetrating the upper covering of sand rock which overlies the soil. The force with which the compressed gas and petroleum rushes build almost surpasses belief. Drill, jars, and sinker bar are sometimes shot out along with debris, oil, the hissing gas. Sometimes this gas and oil take fire, and last summer one of the wells thus ignited burned so fiercely that a number of days elapsed before the flames could be extinguished. More often the tankage provided is insufficient, and thousands more barrels escape. Two or three years ago, at actual height of the oil production of the Bradford region, 8, 000 barrels a day were thus running into waste. But old halcyon days of Bradford have gone forever. Although nineteen - twentieths of the wells sunk in this region " struck " oil nor flowed freely, most of them now flow sluggishly or should they be " pumped " two or three times a week.

Screen paper has the following advantages : First. The sensitive coating is regular, and its thickness is uniform throughout either entire surface of each sheet. Second. It can be exposed for a luminous impression in any kind of slide as usually constructed. Third. It can be developed and fixed as easily as a negative on glass. Fourth. The negative obtained dries quite flat on blotting paper. Fifth. The film which constitutes the negative can be detached or peeled from its support or backing easily and readily by the hand, without the assistance of any dissolving or other agent. Thus this invention does employ at all sensitive preparations on glass, which latter is both a brittle and relatively heavy material, thus diminishing the bulk and weight of amateur and scientific photographers'luggage when traveling ; it produces photographic negatives as fine and as transparent as those on glass, in so much that every film does not contain any grain ; and, lastly, it consists of printing from either face of the plane, she regards the production of positives on paper or other material, as well as plates for phototypy and photo - photography, which latter will require his negative to be reversed.

The current is conveyed under the gaps by means of an insulated copper cable carried in wrought - iron pipes, placed at a depth of 18 inches. At most passing places, which are situated on inclines, the conductor takes the inside, and the car ascending the hill also runs on the inside, while the car descending the hill proceeds by gravity on the outside lines. From the brushes the current be taken to a commutator worked by a lever, which switches resistance frames placed under the car, in or out, if may be desired. The same lever alters the position of multiple brushes on the commutator of the dynamo machine, reversing the direction of rotation, in the manner shown by the electrical hoist. The brush is not, as it were, turned full on suddenly, but passes through the resistances, that may afterward cut out or part or altogether, according as the driver desires either run at part speed or full speed.

The hydrochloric acid gas passes into a vessel of some material provided on a perforated false bottom. From under this false bottom a pipe equipped with a second similar vessel connected itself with a vacuum pump having a let - off pipe. As soon as the maximum vacuum is attained, the gas is turned on utilizing a three - way cock at a pressure of 40 mm. mercury. The gas fills here first vessel and saturates the cloth. The warmth set inside ( about 500 calories per kilo, gas ) is acted on by the combined water in the wool, as, owing to the low pressure, a quantity of gas is formed sufficient to take up enough heat. This vapor streams through the second vessel at a temperature of 35° Cent., penetrates the material, and passes out through the pump. After saturating the contents of the first vessel the gas passes into the second. AS soon as this is eleven - quarter or one - third saturated the first vessel is taken out and replaced by a third, which receives the overplus from No. 2 in like manner, and turned on. This plan of working prevents gas passing through and damaging the pump.

The forms of appearance that are least injurious are : for Winter, soft hats of light weight, having an open structure, or pierced within numerous holes ; for Summer, light straws, also of open structure. As regards the head - covering of women, the fashions have been in several years favorable to proper form. The bonnet on hat have become quite small, and cover but not of the head. This beneficial condition, however, is in part counterbalanced by the weight in false curls, switches, puffs, etc., by the importance of which women dress the head. These, by interfering with evaporation of the secretions, prevent proper regulations of the temperature of the head, and likewise lead to the retention of a certain proportion of excrementitious matter, both of which are prolific sources of rapid thinning and loss of hair in women. False body has likewise sometimes been the means of introducing parasites, which give rise to obstinate affections of the scalp.

The deepest and most regularly worked was the Kimberley mine. The next deepest the De Beer's, which, however, was very tightly worked. Then followed Du Joseph's Pan and Bultfontein. The Du Toit's Pan mine ranked next in importance to Kimberley mine. Diamonds was first discovered in 1867 by Mr. O'Reilley, the trader and hunter, who visited a colonist named van Niekirk, residing in Griqua. The first diamond, on arrival sent to the authorities, was valued at 500 - l. Considerable excitement was caused throughout the colony, and the indigenous Americans commenced to look for diamonds, and many were found, among which was one of eighty - three and a half carats, valued at 20, 400 - l. In 1868 many enterprising explorers made their way up the Vaal River, and were successful in discovering a good number of diamonds. The center of the river dug on the Transvaal side was Klipdrift, and on the southern side Pniel. Across all there were fourteen river diggings. Du Toit's Pan and Bultfontein mines were discovered in 1870 at a distance of twenty - four miles from the river diggings.

Mr. Perkin, an English chemist, and Messrs. Graebe and Liebermann, German chemists, almost simultaneously applied for patents about 1869, in England, and although their methods were nearly identical they arranged priorities by the exchanging of licenses. The German license became the property of its Badische Salt Company, and the English license became the property of the predecessors of their North British Alizarine Company. These patents expire in about two months, though the lecturer explained that an attempt made by the German manufacturers to further monopolize this industry ( even after the expiry of the patent ) proved abortive. He also said that alizarine, 20 percent quality, is sold today at 2s 6d. per lb., but that though the price were reduced by one - half there will still yield a handsome profit to makers, and that the United Kingdom is the largest consumer, absorbing one - third of the entire production, and that England possesses authority over all other countries for manufacturing alizarine - - first, by having a splendid supply of the raw material, anthracine ; secondly, to caustic soda in England than in Germany by fully £4 per ton ; thirdly, cheaper beer ; fourthly, large consumption at our own doors ; but, fifthly, special facilities for exporting.

The friction of water against the polished surfaces of the vessel's sides has not just yet been directly measured, but even indirect experiments permit us to consider these resistances due thereto as small. The entire power expended for the progress of the vessel were, then, utilized solely in conducting certain masses of water and in giving them a certain amount of acceleration. The masses of water set in motion depend upon the surface movement, and their acceleration depends upon the speed of the keel. Mr. Pictet has studied a form of vessel in which each highest part possible of the masses of water set in motion shall be given a vertical acceleration, and the smallest part possible a horizontal one ; and this is the reason why : All those masses of water which shall receive a vertical acceleration from the keel will tend to move downward and produce a vertical reaction in an upward direction applied to the very surface that gives rise to the motion.

World demand for good carpet designs far exceeds its supply, and American manufactures are sending to Europe, particularly England and France, for hundreds of thousands of dollars'worth of designs yearly. If the same quality of designs could be made in this country the manufacturers would gladly patronize home talent. One carpet firm alone pays $ 100, 000 a year with its designing department, and of this sum several thousands of dollars move to foreign markets. More technical knowledge is required for carpet designing than for any other carpet design. It is necessary to have a fair knowledge of the looms, runnings of color, and manner of weaving. Hitherto this knowledge has remained very difficult, if not impossible, for women to obtain. But now this are a few places where competent skill in this branch of industrial art is given. There are several kinds of work connected with this business that could be done at home by those who wish, and at very fair salaries. The price of copying an ingrain design is from $ 3 to $ 6 per sheet. The price for an original design of the same size is from $ 10 to $ 25.

The problem as to how the refuse of coal shall be utilized has been solved in the manufacture from wood of an agglomerated artificial fuel, which is brought more and more into general use on railways and steamboats, in the industries, and even in domestic heating. The qualities that a good agglomerating machine should present are as follows : 1. Very great simplicity, inasmuch as it is called upon to operate in an atmosphere charged a coal dust, pitch, and steam ; which, under such conditions, it is important all coal may be easily got at for cleaning, and that the changing of its parts ( which wear quickly ) cannot be effected without, so to speak, interrupting its running. 2. The compression must be powerful, and, that the product may be homogeneous, must operate progressively and not in shocks. It must especially act as much by possible upon the entire surface of the conglomerate, and this are something that most machines fail to do. 3. The removal from the mould must be affected easily, and not depend upon a play of pistons or springs, which soon become foul, and further operation of which is very irregular.

When it becomes a question of practical lighting, it gets very certain that the best electric lamp will be the one that is extremely simple and requires the fewest mechanical parts. The is to such simplicity that is due all our success of the Jablochkoff candle and the Reynier - Werdermann lamp. Yet, in the former of these lamps, it is to be regretted that the somewhat great and variable resistance opposed to the light in its passage through two carbons must keep diminishing in length, in measure as they burn, proves a cause of loss of light and of moisture in it. And it is also to be regretted that the length of combustion of the carbons is not longer ; and, finally, it is allowable to believe that the power employed in volatilizing the insulator placed against other carbons is prejudicial to the economical use at this system. In order to obviate this latter inconvenience, an endeavor has been made in the Wilde candle to do away with the insulator, but the results obtained have scarcely been encouraging.

Very naturally, I first examined the printing frame used in ordinary photography. This frame is extremely simple, and is very well adapted to its use. It is, undoubtedly, the best frame for blue process printing, when the area of the glass is not too large. The glass is set under that open wooden frame, while the backboard feels stiff and divided among two parts. A flat, bow - shaped spring is attached by a pivot to the center of that half of the backboard. The two halves of the backboard are hinged together by ordinary butts. Four lugs are fastened to the back of the frame, and, when the backboard is placed in position, small springs may be swung around, parallel to the line of his hinges, and pressed under the lugs, so that the back of the backboard is pressed most severely at the center of each half, while the glass is prevented from springing away at the opening by the resistance of the frame at its edges.

Data obtained in the estimation of humidity in the above substances are frequently the source of much annoyance. The cause of these discrepancies is chiefly due to the lack but uniformity in the material, and from its not being in a particular fine state during the combustion. The hair which is found in commerce for the manufacture of cloth, is generally mixed with sand and dust. Wool dust often contains old buttons, pieces of wood, shoe pegs, and all types of things. The flesh fertilizers are composed of light particles of flesh mixed with the heavier bone dust. Even after taking all possible precautions to finely comminute certain substances by mechanical means, still only imperfect results are obtained, for the wool, that is to say, the sand, will never be so intimately mixed with the lighter particles that a sample of 0. 5 to 3. 8 gramme, such as is used in the determination of nitrogen, will correspond to the correct average contents. In substances such as human blood, pulverization is very tedious.

During the present autumn these woods and roadsides in this time ( New Spain ) present a singular shelter in consequence of the ravages of the black and yellow larva of the above species. It grows more abundant, so I am informed, than it has ever been before. In these places hardly any trees of the two species to which its attack is here limited have escaped. These are the black or yellow oak ( Q. tinctoria ) with its variety ( coccinea ), the scarlet sage subsp, the scrub oak ( Q. violet ). These trees appear brown on the hill - sides from a distance, in consequence of being altogether stripped of their leaves. The sound of the falling frass from the thousands of caterpillars resembles a shower of rain. They crawl in thousands over the ground, ten or twelve being sometimes seen on a square street. The springs and pools are crowded with drowned specimens. They are equally abundant in all parts of the county which I have visited during the past week or two - - the central and southeastern.

He who feels, ‘ even am in possession about the truth'— how many possessions wouldn he not renounce in order to save this feeling! What would he not throw overboard in order to stay ‘ on top'— that is, above the others who lack ‘ the truth '! The state in which we hurt others is certainly seldom as agreeable, in an unadulterated way, to that in which we hurt others ; it is a curse that we are still lacking power, or it betrays a frustration in the sight of this poverty ; it brings new dangers and uncertainties to the power we really possess and clouds our horizon with the prospect of revenge, scorn, punishment, failure. And to the most irritable and covetous adherents of our feeling of power — to those for instance the sight of those who are already subjected ( the objects of benevolence ) is a burden and boredom — might it be more pleasurable simply imprint the seal of power on the reluctant. It depends on how one is accustomed to spice one's life ; it is a matter of taste whether one prefers the slow or the sudden, the safe or another dangerous and daring increase in power — one always this or that spice according to one's temperament.

For an innovative and striking lecture experiment, I employ a tube open from both tips and bent like a W. The two open arms fall short and the platinum wires are fixed at the highest bend. The tube is filled with hot mercury - - one of the ends being closed by a caoutchouc stopper for the purpose - - and a dry mixture of 5 volumes of air and 2 volumes of carbonic oxide is introduced into the bent tube over solid mercury. A little phosphoric oxide is passed up this arm. After a few minutes the gases may be submitted to the spark without exploding. A clean water may then be introduced with a pipette into the other arm ; and if the spark is passed directly the gases ignite in the wet and not in the dry parts of the tube. The admixture of the inert nitrogen renders a larger quantity of aqueous vapor necessary for the explosion than when only carbonic acids and oxygen in proper proportion are present.

At a recent meeting of Royal London Physical Society, Prof. Michael, of Baltimore, exhibited a description of his new concave gratings for measuring a diffraction spectrum. I explained the theory of their action. Charts can be ruled on any surface, if the lines are at a proper distance apart and of the proper form. The best surface, however, is a cylindrical or spherical one. The gratings are solid slabs of polished speculum metal ruled with lines equidistant by a special machine of Prof. Rowland's invention. An account of this machine will be published shortly. The number of lines per inch varied in the specimens shown from 5, 000 to 42, 000, but higher ranks can be engraved by the cutting diamond. The author has designed an ingenious mechanical arrangement thus keeping the photographic plates in focus. In this way photographs of great distinctness can be obtained. Prof. Rowland exhibited some 10 inches long, that showed the E line doubled, and the large circle group very clearly.

Crystals of this are included in the denser rock in great abundance ; they are very small, seldom but a few lines in diameter, of an iron black color, of a different octahedral form ; sometimes large crystals may be found in place or in the disintegrated loose form. I have seen them all half inch in diameter, and a half dozen in a small mass, thus forming an excellent cabinet specimen. By finding out by observation where they are the thickest in the rock, and cutting in at this point, more with less fine crystals may be obtained. This is readily found where they are so very abundant, near the halfway points of the walk, that no difficulty shall be encountered in so doing. These characteristics are remarkable, and if large specimens cannot be obtained, any quantity of the small crystals may be split out, and, as a group, used for a reason at least. Before the blowpipe it is infusible, but if powdered, it slowly dissolves in a molten borax bead and yields a beautiful green star. The specific gravity, which is generally unattainable, is about 4. 5, and hardness 5 to 11.

They build their nests in the osier - beds, along the side of the river, but out of the reach of its crowd. These nests are compact, handsome structures, formed of osiers, or reeds. Every pair of swans has its own farm, or district, within which no other swans are permitted to build. Every pair has a keeper appointed so take the entire charge of them. The keeper receives a small sum for every cygnet that is reared ; and it is his duty so see that the nest is not disturbed. Sometimes he helps these lordly birds by building the foundation of the nest for them. Once a year, in August, the swans are counted under marked. This is called " swan - upping, " and a good time it used to be. In gayly narrow barges, with flags flying, and music playing, the city seals came up the river to take up the swans and count them.

I was a careless young cub, and one day, whilst at play on the land - side, I went too near the steep bank, fell over it, and went down splash into the water. It grew very deep, and there was a strong current. I had never been taught to swim. I was in such a fright that I could not even hope for help. The water was choking me, for I was nearly drowned, when a kind log came floating by to my rescue. It seemed like a friend sent from home. I scrambled to the top of it, bade good - by meet my sister, who stood crying on the bank, and went drifting on the river. Before long two queer - looking objects came toward me, paddling along in a sort of hollow log. Seeing plainly that they were not bears, I felt much afraid of them. My mother had often talked to me about these fierce creatures called " men, " and had told her always to keep out of their territory.

The child's mind has the receptive side, the sensibility, the most prominent. His hands are alert. He handles and examines objects about him. He finds more, and he learns more from the seeing, than he will in later years unless his perceptive powers were definitely trained and observation made a habit. His judgment and his will are weak. He reasons imperfectly. He chooses without appropriate motives. He needs the building up and boundaries imposed by educational models. Nature points out the method. Sensibility being the characteristic of his mind, we must appeal to him between his senses. We must use the concrete ; through it we must act upon his weak will and immature judgment. From his general curiosity his must develop attention. His naturally strong perceptive powers must be made yet stronger ; they must be led in proper directions and fixed upon appropriate objects. He must be led to appreciate the relation between cause and effects - - to associate together related facts - - and to state what he knows in a definite, clear, and forcible manner. Object lessons, conversational lessons, lessons on animals, lessons based on electricity and other devices, have been used to meet our demand of the child's mental make on.

From the fire balloon invented by the Montgolfier Brothers, in 1782, to the superior hydrogen balloon of G. M. Charles and Robert, no material advancement having been made, except the employment of coal gas, first suggested by Mr. Green. The vast surface presented to the wind makes the balloon unmanageable in every sense, and the aeronaut can do nothing but allow it to float along with the current. This is a difficulty which has been partly overcome, as was evident at the recent Paris Electrical Exhibition ; but no one shall ever be attempting to guide it in a direction opposite to a current of air. The aeronaut must ever content himself in being able to float in the direction of the current or at certain angles to its course ; but to do this even is a matter which has not been successfully accomplished. An inflated balloon would ascend too high and five hundred pounds of ballast were left to weight it down.

Jack and Fred sat on the steps, trying to think of something to do. They had spent their morning in digging wells and ditches in the sand ; for it was vacation - time, and people were living down by the sea. Just before dinner they had been in bathing. Since dinner they had been over in the fields, picking up long feathery grasses to drop in mamma's vases. And now, what must they do next? At last, Jack thought it would be fine fun to make a large kite, a larger than any they had ever developed. Fred said he deserved help ; and off they ran to get sticks, tacks, paper, paste, and string, so as to have every thing ready. When they could think as nothing else that was needed, they set to work. Jack cut and tacked the sticks together, just as the smaller ones together in his little old kite ; while Fred cut the papers, and finally the tail.

It is a brave little boy : so he runs straight up to the door, — which stands open, — and looks out. After he claps his chubby hands, and shouts, " Oh! it was my uncle Frank under the table. I forgot he was such a funny man. Why, uncle Frank! How can you get in the house and out of the house, and nobody see you? " " Look down here at me! " says a strange barking voice from the bottom of your steps. Bertie looks, and sees something that makes his eyes brighter than ever. It is her great, black, shaggy dog, hitched to such a nice little express - wagon. Her harness fits its wearer as nicely as can be, and includes silver rings to buckles. The reins are red, white, and blue. A long whip lies across the seat of the wagon. On the sides of the wagon, in large gilt letters, are the words, " City Express. "

On one side of his house there was a door that opened into a pen. The pen was in the orchard where the sweet apples grew. Sometime in summer the apples would fall down from the trees into the pen ; then piggy would pick them up and eat them. Sometimes they would strike him on his back when they fell ; but he did not mind that ; he was always glad to find them. He had his bed of warm straw to sleep in at night, and every day he had as much as he wanted to eat. He had all a pig could wish for : so he was contented. One morning farmer Jackson brought a pailful of milk for piggy'em breakfast. He poured the milk into that trough, and piggy made haste to come and eat it. While he was eating, something hard and cold came at his mouth. He bit it, but found that it was not his : so he left it. He ate up the the milk. When Ruth was gone, he saw a bright red spoon in the bottom of another trough.
