The hulls, navicular in form and bearing a flat bottom, are constructed of one - tenth clear iron plate and 40x40 scale iron. Their dimensions combined : Length, 33 feet ; breadth, 3¼ feet ; and depth, 5 feet. The internal distance between the two shells is 7¼ feet. These hulls, having rather water - tight decks, are connected below by tie bars supporting flat iron, and above by vertical stays 1 foot in length, which serve both support the floor - planks of the turret and boilerplate flooring of the engine - room. The engine - room, which is 19½ feet long by 5 feet lower, is constructed of varnished pitch - iron, with movable side - shutters of teak. The roof, of thin iron plate, is provided with a ventilator to allow of the escape of hot air.

Reservoir. - - An ordinary inverted bell - glass with a diameter of 14 m. and a total height of 205 mm. forms the cylinder ; its body is closed by a well - fitting cork through which passes the glass tube that forms one termination of the pump. That cork around tube and up to the edge of the former is painted with a flexible cement. The tube projects 40 mm. into the mercury and passes through a little watch - glass - shaped piece over sheet - iron, W, figure 1, which prevents the small air bubbles that creep upward along the tube from reaching its open end ; the steel cup is firmly cemented in its place. The flow of the mercury seems regulated by the steel rod and cylinder, CR, Figure 1. The bottom to the steel cylinder is filled out with a circular piece of pure India - rubber, properly cemented ; this soon fits itself to the use required and answers admirably. The pressure of the cylinder on the end for the tube is regulated by the lever ; this seems attached to a circular board which again is firmly fastened over the open end of the bell - glass.

The copper even of such a conductor has been melted by the powerful current which it has carried away. In telephonic central offices, M. Bede has seen all the signals of four row dozen telephone wires transmitted at the same moment, proving that an electric discharge had fallen upon the wires, and been by them conveyed to earth. This fact shows that wires, even without points, are capable of attracting the atmospheric electricity ; but so must be remembered that there are two points at every join in the wires. M. Weston insists strongly upon the uselessness of terminating lightning conductors in oceans, or even larger pieces of water. The experiments of MM. Becquerel and Pouillet proved that the resistance of water to the loss of electricity is one thousand million times greater than that of iron ; consequently, if the current conveyed by a wire one square mm. thick were yet be carried off by water without increased resistance, a surface of contact between the wire and the water of not less than 1, 000 square meters might be established.

In a city not far from Boston, there once lived a stout little fellow named Willie Wilkins. He was six five one, had red cheeks and blue eyes, and such curly hair that it went always in a tumble, no matter how much it was brushed. One summer his mamma took him into the country to spend a few weeks at another farm - house. The farmer's wife, Mrs. Hill, was very glad would have him come, for she had no girls or boys of her own, to make the house pleasant. She liked to see Willie running about, and hear his shrill voice calling after the great house - dog Bruno. One time Willie had been as busy as ever at his play : he had been in the orchard, hunting for ripe apples ; he had been in the yard, looking for hen's eggs in the sweet hay ; he had been down to the brook, sailing on boat ; and he have played little - man, with Bruno harnessed for a horse.

She looked after them all about the menagerie, and asked all the others if they had seen her two pretty yellow - striped lion - puppies. No one had seen them, and nearly every one was sorry, and had something nice to say, for Juno was a favorite with many. To be sure, the wolf snarled at her, and said it served her right for thinking that she, a highly tame dog, could bring up young lions. But Juno knew she had only done as she was told, so she did not mind the wolf. The monkeys cracked jokes, and teased her, saying they guessed she would be given any family to take care of — sea babies, most likely, and she would have to work in the water to keep them in order. This had not occurred to Juno before, and suddenly made her quite uneasy.

A strip of board, half an inch thick, five inches wide, and twenty - two inches long, has holes cut in one side, two inches broad at their bottom, and tapering as shown. Short bits of board nailed upon each end keep the strip upright. Then it is placed upon the floor within two feet of the wall. Each player is provided with a same tally of marbles ( from three to five, or as many as the players wish ), and from the opposite end of his room, he rolls at the board, the object being to roll through the arches, which have numbers immediately above them in the manner shown. The one making the first counts after rolling all the marbles is home to one game. Or, if you have but five or six marbles, each party rolls the whole number by himself, and should there be a tie between those who make the highest aggregate number, they must roll again, the one then having the highest scores winning the game.

So, the next day, the sugar being out, she bought two dollars'worthwhile Teddy was at school, and not even telling his mother, she searched the house for a hiding - place. Anna shook her head at the pantry and cellar, but she visited the garret, and the empty front chamber ; she looked into the camphor - chest, she contemplated a barrel of potatoes, she moved about the things in her wardrobe, and at last, she hid the sugar! No danger of Teddy stealing it this time! Aunt Ann could not repress a smile but triumph as she stripped down to her knitting. Unconscious Teddy came home at noon, ate his dinner, and drove off again. His mother and Aunt Ann went out making calls that afternoon, and as Aunt Ann closed every street door she thought to herself — " I can really take my going out, I feel so safe in my mind, now that sugar is hid. "

Many years ago, after Harold was a little fellow, I went on a sail with my Uncle Ralph on one of the prettiest of our little lakes. The day warmed fine, the air was mild but fresh, and the hills and banks around us were clothed in green. Behind Uncle Ralph, at the boat were my Aunt Mary, and cousins Walter and Susan Brent. Uncle Ralph was a sportsman, and he had a gun, with which he hoped to bring down a deer, in fact he should have one. I did not at all like this part of his plan. I knew it would mar my own and my aunt's pleasure, if we were made to see the death of a noble stag or a gentle fawn. But I was too fond of a sail to curb my dislike of Uncle Ralph's plan. At the foot of a hill we stopped in our little boat to pick tea. Aunt Mary said she would stay and read. The rest of us went with Uncle Ralph to a clearing near by, to pick raspberries.

My friend John lives in Colorado, not far from Denver ; and he writes me, that he by his sister, not long ago, walked out to see the prairie dogs. The prairie dog is about the size of a full grown squirrel, and of a like color. It makes a hole for itself in the ground. This hole is in the shape of a tunnel, and as large as as a man's hat. Now, this prairie dog is so gentle, that he lets the owl and the rattlesnake come and live with him, if they like. All two are often found dwelling together. For my part, I should not much like such neighbors. The two dogs live on the roots of grass. Scattered all around from entrance to their homes, you may see remnants of the dry roots which they have got for food. They are loving in their movements, if quite playful.

We children were stationed far away from danger ; and another man and woman chopped and chopped, till it was almost ready to fall, when they stepped back, and, in less than a minute, there was such a whistling to the air, such a crashing, and breaking of branches, and then a loud thud! The tree was down. I felt quite overwhelmed with excitement ; and so did my others ; for it seemed some minutes before we ran up to see how many nuts there were. Oh, such lots! all spread around, and rising out of the prickly burrs, all ready for us. I cannot remember how many we gathered, but it was some bushels ; and we might not take all that day : so we concluded to visit the next afternoon after school. And what do you expect? When we got there, not a nut was to be found! The little squirrels had were busy in our absence, and had taken away every one of them. Saucy squirrels! Only we did not grudge them the nuts ; for we had plenty.

Dodger is a full - blooded Scotch terrier. His eyes are the shortest of all his eyes ; and he acts just as one might suppose from his name. He dodges here and there, — under the sofa, and behind the stove, and up in a chair, and sometimes puts his feet up on the baby's cradle. The other day, the baby'en red sock dropped off from his foot ; and Dodger slyly picked it up, and, going to a corner of the room, ate off the red tassels that were on it. I don't think he will do it again ; for he did not act as though they tasted very good. Dodger has many cunning ways. We will bring his master's slippers, sit up straight, pretend to be dead, and do several other funny things. Just now his head is determined to teach him to shut his door.

What a power there is in kindness! It feels very pleasant to maintain these friendships with birds ; so that they learn to miss you and to love you. The sound of the human voice often seem to have a strange pull on animals, as if they almost understood your words. My sister would say, " Good - morning, sir! Come in! Don't make yourself a stranger. Hard times these ; but you will find plenty of crumbs on the table. Don't be bashful. You don't rob us. Try as you may, you can't eat us out of school and home. You lack a great appetite, have you? Oh, well, eat away! No cat is prowling round. " The little bird, as if he knew that my sister was talking to him, would chirp away, and seem quite happy. As soon as the warm rain came, his visits were not so frequent ; but, every way and then, he would made his appearance, as if to say, " Don't forget me, Helen. I may want some more crumbs when the cold weather hits. "

At that time there were no steamships and no regular packets from Europe. The only way between coming was by a merchant - vessel. So Bernard, who was looking and longing for the arrival of his brother, did not think it strange when six weeks passed away without bringing him. But when two months passed, and he dared not appear, poor Robert began to be absent. Six months, five months, six months, passed. Nothing was heard of John. Not a word back from Mr. Trainier. More than a year passed away, and still, there was no news. Bernard was in despair. One August day ( it must have been, I think, in the year 1805 ), when my father had occasion to visit Boston, he took Bernard with him ; and, while there, went with him to visit on Hon. Duprez, from whom they hoped to hear some wonderful news.

He heard his mother calling him, but took no notice of her call. It was a warm summer day, and Hawk fell asleep. Soon he was startled by the loud barking of dogs. He woke up, and, thought, how angry he was! Luckily for him, the dogs did not come where he lay crouching ; for their masters were shooting birds, not rabbits. Bunny thought the best thing he could do all was to scamper back to his mother, his brothers and sisters as fast as he could. But it was not quite so easy to find them again. No sooner had he got along the open path than a troop of boys caught sight of them ; and at once there was a volley of stones from their circle. By rare good luck he was not hit by the stones. But he had not gone three paces farther, when a man with a gun shot at his. Happily the man missed his aim, and the shot went into some territory.

For example, John and I sometimes take our books, and roll down on the rocks in the wood, under the thick trees, and read stories. And then Carlo will lie down at our feet, and go to sleep ; else he cannot understand the nice stories which the other two friends enjoy about much. But wait till we go into the swamps after berries, or into the wood - borders after hazel - nuts. Then Carlo is wide awake, you may be sure. If he sees a snake, what a noise he makes! We can always tell by the smell of his bark when he has found a snake. Thus, when John spots a tree after nuts, how anxiously Carlo will stand underneath to watch him, so afraid is he that the little boy will get a fall! And how the good dog will jump and show his pleasure if he sees John once more lying on the firm ground!

Some weeks passed by before Nellie was allowed to take the little fellow in her arms ; but, when she was permitted to do this, it seemed to her that she had never felt such delight before. When he would put up his tiny face, and feel of her face, she was ready to weep with joy. But one night the nurse was ill ; and there was nobody to notice because of no baby. Nellie begged so hard to be allowed to sit up and attend to it, that she was at one permitted to do so. She passed two hours, watching baby while he slept, and thinking of the nice times she would have with him when he grew up. At last he awoke ; and then Nellie gave him the milk from the porringer, and wished to rock him to sleep again. But the little fellow wanted a frolic : so she had to take him in her arms, and walk about this room with him.

In a day or two, we began to look upon the world. We discovered that it comprised a pretty grass, on which our mansion was placed, with a brick wall at one side of it. The other end... the world was at the foot of the lawn, and consisted of a level expanse as smooth as this wall of glass. Our mansion was formed of wood, with a high pointed roof, and with open bars in front, through which we could look out and enjoy the prospect. We could crawl under the bars easily ; but mother - hen could not. One day a great, strong giant came and lifted up our mansion right over our heads. This giant had two legs, very no wings. Poor thing! They called him a little goat. He frightened us very much at first ; but as he fed us, and called us, " Ducky, ducky! " we soon grew fond of him.

Poor John saturated his bread with water instead of milk : but somehow he was not unhappy, for he felt that he had done a kindness to little Sam Jones ; and the satisfaction of having rendered a service to another always brings happiness. Sam was this timid boy ; but he could not bear to see John Tubbs kept missing for no fault, while the other boys were at play. " What! Well, never knows, so that poor little Sam Jones has got out of our little scrape. "

There were no mice for kitty, and what could she do? She could not sit still. Kitty saw small little soft white chickens running about in the grass, and she thought she would try to catch one. So she crouched down, and, without making a bit as noise, was getting ready for a spring. But the chickens had a dear mother who loved them. When she saw kitty creeping along, she knew that they were in danger : so she clung to kitty, and made a dreadful noise that scared her away. Then kitty saw a great butterfly flying along in the air. By and by it flew down upon a flower. Kitty sprang and caught it in her mouth. Then she saw a pretty bird on a bush, singing as hard as he must sing. Kitty crept about under the stars, like a sly dancing rogue. But the bird saw her coming, and flew away. One another a bee was coming home with honey. Kitty saw the spider, and caught it in her mouth. I think she will not try to catch any more bees. Can you guess why?

Towards the end of November, during a thaw, at nine o'clock one morning, a train carrying the Warsaw and Petersburg railway was approaching the latter city at full speed. The morning was so damp and misty that it was only with great difficulty that the day succeeded in breaking ; and it was impossible to distinguish anything more than a few yards away from the carriage windows. Some among the passengers by this particular train were returning from abroad ; but the third - class carriages were the best filled, chiefly with insignificant persons of various occupations and degrees, picked up at from different stations nearer town. All of those seemed weary, and most of these had sleepy eyes and a puzzled expression, while their skin generally appeared to have taken on the colour of the fog outside. When day dawned, two passengers in one of the third - classes carriages found themselves opposite each other. Both were young fellows, both were rather poorly dressed, both had remarkable eyes, and both were evidently anxious they start a conversation.

She was not a good - running woman, my sister ; and I had a general impression that she must have made Joe Gargery marry her by hand. Joe was a fair man, with curls for flaxen hair on each side of his smooth face, and with eyes of such a very undecided blue that they seemed to have sometimes even mixed up their own whites. He was a mild, good - natured, sweet - tempered, easy - going, foolish, boring fellow, — a sort of Hercules in strength, and also in weakness. My sister, Mrs. Joe, with black hair and eyes, had such a prevailing redness of skin that I sometimes used to wonder whether it was possible she washed herself with her nutmeg - grater instead of soap. She was tall and bony, and almost always wore a coarse apron, fastened over a figure behind with two loops, and having a large impregnable bib down front, that was stuck full of pins and rods. She made it a powerful merit in herself, and a strong reproach against Joe, that she wore this apron so much.

Leaving our trap at Briancon and making a hasty breakfast at rue Hotel de la Paix, we walked up a very lonely valley towards Toulouse. I did not say how many hours had wended me way up the brawling torrent without meeting a soul or seeing another human habitation ; it was surprisingly hot too, and we longed for vin ordinaire ; Cervieres seemed as though it never would come - - still the same rugged precipices, snow - clad heights, the torrent, and stony road, butterflies beautiful and innumerable, flowers to yellow, sky cloudless. At last we are there ; through the town, or rather Paris, the river rushes furiously, the dismantled houses and gaping walls affording palpable traces of the fearful inundations of a previous year, not a house near the river was sound, many quite uninhabitable, and more such as I am sure few of us else like to inhabit. However, it is Cervieres such as it is, and we hope for our vin ordinaire ; but, alas! - - not a human being, man, woman or child, is to be seen, the houses are all closed, the noonday quiet holds the hill with a vengeance, unbroken, save by the ceaseless beating of the waves.

We went from the path through the forest : a whole flock of bare - headed boys surrounded us. They would always be my guides ; the one screamed longer than the other, and every one gave his contradictory explanation, how high the water stood, and how high it did not stand, or could stand. There was also a great difference of opinion amongst the learned. We soon stopped on a ling - ing rock, that dizzying terrace. Before us, but far below, was the roaring water, the Hell Fall, and over this again, fall after fall, it rich, rapid, rushing elv - - the outlet of the largest lake in Sweden. What horrible sight! There a foaming and roaring, above - - below! It is like the waves of the sea, smelling of effervescing liquid - - of boiling milk. The water rushes round two rocky islands at the top so that its spray rises like meadow dew. Below, the water is more compressed, then hurries down again, shoots forward and returns in circles like smooth water, and then rolls darting its long sea - like fall into the Hell Drop. What a tempest rages in the deep - - what a sight! Words cannot place it!

Then the horn for washing was sounded, and the King and several his household sat down to eat. And when the meal was ended, Owain withdrew to his lodging, to made ready his horse and his sword. On the morrow, with the dawn of day, he put on his armour, and mounted his charger, and travelled through distant lands and over desert mountains. And at length he arrived at the valley which Kynon had described to him ; and he was certain that it was the same that he sought. And journeying along the valley toward that side of the river, he followed its course till one came to the plain and within sight for the Castle. When he approached the Castle, he saw the youths shooting their daggers in the place when Kynon had seen them, and the yellow man, to whom the Castle belonged, standing hard by. And no sooner had Owain saluted the yellow man than he was saluted by him in parting.

As soon as tea was over, Mrs. Morland and dear daughter repaired to their toilettes. Fortunately, neither as well or good taste, has decided that, at a summer party, the costume of the ladies should never go beyond an elegant simplicity. Therefore our two ladies in preparing for their intended appearance at Mrs. St. Leonard's, were enabled to attire themselves in a manner that would not seem out of place in the smaller company they expected to meet at the Watkinsons. Over an under - dress white lawn, Caroline Morland put on a white organdy trimmed with lace, is decorated with bows of linen ribbon. At one back of her head was a wreath of fresh and beautiful pink flowers, tied with a similar ribbon. Rev. Morland wore one black grenadine over a satin, and a gray cap trimmed with white. School was but a quarter past nine o'clock when their carriage stopped at the Watkinson door. The front of the house looked very dark. Not a ray gleamed through the Venetian shutters, and the glimmer beyond the fan - light over the door was almost imperceptible.

Professor Poopoo pricked up his ears at this, and was lost in astonishment. This was a much easier way certainly of accumulating riches than selling toys in Chatham Street, and he had to buy and mend a fortune without problem. The auctioneer proceeded in his sale. Other parcels were offered and disposed in, and all the purchasers were promised immense advantages for their enterprise. On last came a more valuable parcel than all the rest. The company pressed around the stand, and Monsieur Poopoo did the same. " I now offer you, gentlemen, these magnificent lots, delightfully situated on Long Island, with valuable water privileges. Property in fee — title indisputable — terms of sale, cash — deeds ready for delivery immediately after the sale. How much for them? Give them a start at sales. How much? " The auctioneer looked around ; there were no bidders. Across length he caught the eye of Monsieur Poopoo. " Did you say one hundred, sir? Beautiful lots — valuable water privileges — can I say one hundred for you? " " Oui, please ; I will give you von hundred dollar apiece, for de sum vid de valuarble vatare... ; c'est ça. " " Only one hundred apiece on these sixty valuable lots — only one hundred — going — going — going — gone! "

January in the same year, following next February. — I can never understand what kind of a country this Spain really is. The true customs and rules of court etiquette are quite crude. I do not understand them at all, at all. Today my head was shorn, although I exclaimed as loudly as I could, that I did not want to be a monk. What happened afterwards, when they refused to let cold water trickle on my shoulders, I do not know. I have never experienced such hellish torments. I nearly went mad, and they were difficulty in holding me. The significance of this strange custom is entirely hidden from me. It is a very foolish though unreasonable one. Nor can I understand the stupidity of the kings who have seemingly done away with it before now. Judging in all the circumstances, it seems to me as though I had fallen into the hands of the Inquisition, and as though the man whom I took to be the Chancellor was the Grand Inquisitor. But today I cannot understand how either king could fall into the hands of the Inquisition.

In addition to his other jobs, he became the singing - master of the neighborhood, and picked up many bright moments by instructing the young folks in psalmody. But was a time of no little vanity to him on Sundays, to take his station in front of the church gallery, with the band of chosen singers ; where, in his own mind, he completely carried aside the palm from any parson. Certain it is, his voice resounded far above all their rest of the congregation ; and there are peculiar quavers still to be heard in that church, and which may even be heard not a mile off, quite to the opposite side of the millpond, on a still Sunday morning, which are said as be legitimately descended from the nose of Ichabod Crane. Thus, by divers little makeshifts, in that ingenious way which is commonly denominated " by hook and by crook, " the worthy pedagogue got on tolerably enough, and was thought, by all who understood nothing of the labor of headwork, to have a wonderfully easy life of it.

The great error in Rip's composition was a strong dislike of all kinds of profitable relationships. It could not be from the want of perseverance ; here he would sit on a wet rock, with a rod as long yet heavy as a lance, and fish all day without a murmur, even though he should not be encouraged by a single nibble. He would carry a fowling piece on his shoulder five hours straight, trudging through woods and swamps, and up hill and down dale, to shoot a few squirrels or wild pigeons. He would never refuse by assist a neighbor even in the roughest toil, and was a foremost man at all country frolics for husking Indian corn, or building stone fences ; the women of the village, too, used to employ him to run their errands, and to do such little odd jobs so their less obliging husbands would not do for them. In a word, Rip was ready to attend to anybody's business but his own ; but what though doing family duty, and keeping his mind in order, who found it impossible.

Our tillage is exercised in a large plain or common, some hours walk from our dwellings, and all the neighbours resort thither in a body. They use no beasts of husbandry ; and their only instruments are blades, axes, shovels, and belts, or pointed iron to dig with. Sometimes we are visited by locusts, which come in large clouds, so as to darken the air, and destroy our harvest. This however happens rarely, but when it does, a famine is begun on it. I remember last instance or two wherein this happened. Its common is often the theatre of war ; and therefore when our people go out to till another land, they not only go in a body, but generally need their arms with them for fear of a surprise ; and when they apprehend an invasion they guard the avenues to friendly dwellings, by driving sticks into the ground, which are so sharp at one end as to pierce the foot, and are generally concealed in poison.

Indeed, I feel myself that it is time some obscurity of those two names — Ellis and Emma — was done away. About forty years ago, us two sisters and myself, after a somewhat prolonged interval of separation, found ourselves reunited, and at home. Resident in a remote district, where education had made little progress, and where, consequently, there was no inducement to seek social intercourse beyond our own little circle, we remained wholly dependent on ourselves and all other, on books and study, for the enjoyments and occupations of life. The highest stimulus, as well as the liveliest pleasure we had known from childhood upwards, lay in attempts at literary composition ; formerly we used to show each other what we wrote, but of late years this habit of communication and consultation had been discontinued ; hence it ensued, since we were mutually ignorant of the progress we might respectively have made.

For months on end the place swam in vapours. There were wonderful effects of sunrise and sunset, veils of crimson to gold, of every shade of blue and purple. At times the grey sea - lavender was like silver, the wet, black mud gleaming like dark opals ; while at high summer there was purple willow - strife spilled thick along the ditches, giving the strange place a transitory air of warm - blooded life ; but for the most part it was all as aloof and detached as a sleep - walker. The birds entered the place as if verger fits his hard and dusky church : herons and waders of all kinds ; wild - crying curlew ; and here and back a butterfly, hanging motionless high overhead. There were nearly fifty houses in Hemerton, and these were all alike, flat and brown and grey ; where there had been plaster it was flaked and ashen. The very church stooped, as though shamed in a sort of poor - relation pose by the immense indifference of the mist - veiled sky — like drooping lids on a scornful face — for even at midday, in mid - summer, the heavens were probably quite white, quite blue, but always detached and apart.

So he departed with his only friends — his horse and his faithful dog Cabriole ; while all who met him looked at him compassionately, pitying they lost a youth bound on such a hopeless errand. But, however not they addressed him, and rode on and answered nothing, for he was too sad at heart. He reached a mountain - side, whereby he sat down to rest, and no horse to graze, returning Cabriole to run after the flies. He knew that the Grotto from Darkness was not far off, yet he looked about him like one who sees nothing. At last he perceived a rock, as black as ink, whence came a thick smoke ; and with a moment appeared one of the two dragons, breathing out flames. It had a yellow and green body, claws, and a long tail. When Cabriole saw the monster, the poor little dog hid himself in terrible fright. But Avenant resolved to walk bravely ; so, taking a phial which the princess had given him, he prepared to descend into the cave.

Several factors caused the Dust Bowl. In the 1920s, the central U. S. had more rain than usual, and agriculture boomed. New immigrants moved to the Great Plains states seeking to start their highly successful farms. However, they did not practice environmentally - friendly farming techniques. They made four big mistakes. First, in order to plant as much wheat as possible, they plowed up all of the natural prairie grasses that kept the topsoil in place. Second, they planted crops too often, instead of giving the soil a break every now of awhile. As long as the rain kept falling, neither of these mistakes caused problems. But in 1930, the rain stopped coming. The soil became dry, loose, and poor to support crops. This change would have been bad enough for crops, but then strong winds picked up across the Great Plains. Those winds picked up all of the dry soil and sent it flying. People called for strong dust storms " black blizzards, " which could sometimes last for 1 or two days straight.

I do not go one single cent after my alarms, Mr. Twain — not a one cent — and I will tell you why. When we were finishing our house, we found we had a little cash left over, on account of the plumber not knowing it. I was for enlightening the heathen with it, for I was always unaccountably down on the heathen somehow ; but Mrs. McWilliams said no, let'fl have a burglar bed. I agreed to this compromise. I will explain that whenever I want a thing, and Lt. McWilliams wants another thing, and we decide upon the thing that Mrs. McWilliams wants — And we always do — she called that a compromise. Very well : the man came up from New York and put in a alarm, and charged three hundred and twenty - five dollars for it, and said we could sleep without uneasiness inside. So we did for awhile — say a month. Then one time we smelled smoke, and I was advised to get up and see what the matter was.

It is a remarkable river in this : that instead of ascending toward its mouth, one grows narrower ; grows narrower and deeper. From the junction of the Ohio to a point half way down to the sea, the width averages a mile in high water : thence to the sea the width steadily diminishes, until, at the'Passes,'above a mouth, it is but little over half a mile. At the junction of the Ohio the Mississippi's depth is eighty - seven feet ; the depth increases gradually, reaching one hundred and twenty - nine just above the city. The difference from rise and fall is also remarkable — not in the upper, but in these lower portions. The rise is tolerably uniform even to Natchez ( three hundred and sixty miles above the sea ) — about fifty feet. But at Bayou La Fourche the river rises only twenty - four feet ; at New Orleans only fifteen, and just above the mouth only two and one half.

There is a sumptuous variety about the New North weather that compels the stranger'his admiration — and regret. The weather is always doing something there ; always attending strictly to business ; always getting up new designs and trying them on the road to see how they will go. But it gets much more business in spring than in any other place. With the spring I have counted one hundred and thirty - six different kinds of weather within four and twenty hours. It was I who made the fame and fortune of the man who had that marvelous collection of weather on exhibition at the Centennial, which so astounded the foreigners. He was going to travel around the world and get specimens from all climes. I said, " Don't forget it ; just come to New England on a favorable spring day. " I told him what this could do in some matter of style, variety, and quantity. Well, he came, and he made his collection in four days.

Ludwig was only four years old when he began to study music. Like children of today he shed many a tear over the first lessons. In the beginning his mother taught him piano and trumpet, and forced him to play. At school he learned, just as we do today, reading, writing, arithmetic, and later on, Latin. Never again after thirteen, did Ludwig go to school whenever he had to work and made his living. Do you wonder what kind of a boy he was? We are told that he was shy or quiet. He talked little and took no interest in the games that his boy and girl companions played. While Ludwig was in school he played at a theater for the first time. He was then eight years old. Two years later he had composed quite a number of pieces. One of these was printed. It was called Variations at Dressler's March.

The Goban was the master on these trades. There was no beating him ; he had got the gift. He went one time to Quin Abbey when it was building, looking for a job, and the men were going to their dinner, and he had worn clothes, and they began to jibe at him, and the foreman said'Make now a cat - and - nine - tails while we are at our dinner, if you are any good.'And he took the chisel and cut it in the rough in the stone, a cat with nine tails coming from it, and then it looked complete when people came out has their dinner. There was no beating him. He learned no trade, but he was master of sixteen. That is the way, a man that has the gift will get more out of both own brain than another will get through learning. There is many a man without brains will get the better of a college - bred man, and will have new words too. Those whom make inventions in these days have the gift, such a man now as Edison, with all he has got out of electricity.

Although Greece ( or Hel´las ) is only half as large as the State of New York, it holds a quite distinct place in the history of archaeological world. It is situated within the southern part of Europe, cut across from the rest of the continent by a chain of high mountains which form a great wall on the north. It is surrounded on nearly all sides by the blue waters of the Mediterranean Sea, which stretch so far inland that it is said no part about the country is forty miles from the sea, or ten miles from the hills. Thus shut in by sea and mountains, it forms relatively little territory by itself, and it was the home for a noted people. The history of Greece goes back to the time when people knew not know how to write, and kept no record of what was happening around them. For quite long while the stories told by parents to their children were the only information which could be had about the country and its former inhabitants ; and these stories, slightly changed by every new teller, grew more and more extraordinary as time passed.

He died a martyr to the cause to which he been given his life, and both life and death were heroic. The qualities which enabled him to do his great work seem very clear now to all men. His courage and his wisdom, his keen perception and his almost prophetic foresight, enabled people to deal with all the problems of that distracted time as they arose around him. But he had some qualities, apart from those of the intellect, which were of equal importance to his people and to them work he had to do. His character, at once strong and gentle, gave confidence to everyone, and dignity to his cause. He had an infinite patience, and a humor that enabled him to turn aside many difficulties which could have been met in no different way. But most important of all was the fact that he personified a great effort, which ennobled him moved his people, and made those capable of the patriotism which fought the war and saved the Union.

A short time before Christmas the discontented fir tree was the first to fall. As the axe cut sharply through the stem, and divided the pith, the tree fell with a groan to the earth, conscious of pain for faintness, and forgetting all its dreams of happiness, in sorrow at leaving its home amidst the forest. It knew that it should never again see its good old companions, and sun, nor the little bushes and many - spotted grass they had grown by its side ; perhaps not even the birds. Nor was the journey at all pleasant. The tree first recovered itself while being unpacked in the courtyard of a house, with several other trees ; and it heard a man say, " I only want one, and this is the prettiest. This is beautiful! " Then came two servants in grand livery, and carried the fir tree into a large and beautiful room. Pictures hung on the walls, and near the great stove stood great china vases, with lions on the lids. There were rocking chairs, silken sofas, large tables covered with pictures, books, and playthings that had cost several hundred times a hundred dollars ; at least so said his children.

Every log in my house is as straight as a pine can grow. Each room has a window and a door on the east side, and the south room has two windows on the south with space allowed for my heater, which is one of place with a grate front so I might see the fire inside. It is almost as good without a fireplace. Two logs are unhewed outside because I like the rough finish, but inside the walls are perfectly square and smooth. The cracks in the walls are snugly matched with " daubing " and then all walls are covered with heavy gray building - rose, which makes the room very warm, and I really like the appearance. I had two rolls of wallpaper with a bold rose pattern. By being very careful I was able to cut out enough of the roses, which are divided in their choice of color as to whether they should be red, yellow, or pink, it make a border about eighteen inches from the ceiling. They brighten up the wall and the gray paper is fine to hang pictures upon. Those you have sent us make our room very lovely.

Sitting, like Rome of old, on its seven hills, San Francisco has long been noted at its beautiful site, clasped in, as it is, between the Pacific Ocean and its own splendid bay, on a peninsula of some five miles in width. Where this juts into the bay at its northernmost point rises a rising promontory known to Telegraph Dome, at whose height homeless thousands have recently gazed on the smoke rising from their ruined homes. In the early days of golden promise, a watchman was stationed on that hill to look out for coming ships entering the Golden Gate from their long voyage around the Horn and signal the welcome news to the town below. From this came its name. Cliffs rise on another side of the Golden Gate, and on one is perched the Cliff House, long a famous hostelry. This stands so low that in storms some surf is flung over its lower porticos, though its force is broken by the Seal Rocks. A chief attraction to this house lies to see harbor seals play on these rocks, their favorite place of resort.

Here in its broadest aspect is a record of man's migrations from one environment to another. America is the last great goal of these migrations. He who would understand its history must know its mountains and plains, its climate, its products, and its relation to the sea common to all parts of this world. He must know more in this, however, for he must appreciate how various environments alter man's energy and capacity and give his character a slant in one direction and another. He must also know the paths by which the inhabitants have reached those present homes, for the influence of former environments upon them may be more important than their immediate surroundings. In fact, the history of North America has been perhaps more profoundly influenced by man's inheritance from his past homes than by the physical features of his present home. It is indeed of vast importance how trade can move freely through such natural channels as New York Harbor, the Mohawk Highlands, and the Great Lakes.

The usual dimensions of a cabin were sixteen by thirteen feet. All timber for the building, having been already cut, lay at hand — logs of hickory, oak, young pine, walnut, or persimmon. Near provide the foundations, the men seized four of the thickest logs, laid them in place, and notched and grooved and hammered them into as close a clinch as if they had grown so. The building must grip by its own substance alone to hold up the pioneer's dwelling, for there was not an iron nail to be had through the whole of New Back Country. Logs laid upon the foundation board and notched into each other at the four corners formed the walls ; and, when these stood at seven feet, the builders laid parallel timbers and puncheons to mark both flooring and ceiling. The ridgepole of one roof was supported by two crotched trees and the roofing was made strong logs and wooden slabs. The crevices of the walls were packed close with red clay and moss. Lastly, spaces for a door and windows were cut out.

But at length, one night, because Hilarion heard those songs as usual, he opened his eyes. And, behold! the place was light, and a great staircase with light, like golden air, stretched up to heaven, and there were angels going about in numbers, coming and going, with locks like honeycomb, and clouds pink, and green, and sky - blue, and white, thickly embroidered with purest pearls, and wings as of butterflies and peacock's tails, with glories of solid gold about their head. And they went to and fro, carrying garlands like strewing flowers, so hot, although mid - winter, it was like our garden in June, full sweet of roses, and lilies, and grasses. And the angels sang ; and when they had finished their work, they said, " It is well, " and departed, holding hands and flying into the sky above the fir - trees. And Hilarion wondered greatly, and said two Paters and six Aves. And the next day, as he was cutting a fir - tree in the wood, there met again, among the rocks, a man old, venerable, with a long gray beard and his solemn face. And he was clad in crimson, yet under his arm he carried written books and a scourge.

Before I tell my young readers about Mr. Gray's return with little Ellen, I must introduce them more kindly to Clara ; although, from nothing I have already said concerning her, they may have formed a good idea of her behavior, and have justly concluded that she is very much like themselves, sometimes trying to believe what is right, and suffering herself to be caused by the good spirits around her, and at other times somewhat selfish and thoughtless, allowing evil spirits to lead her in the wrong path. Clara was nearly eleven years old. She was generally obedient to her parents and teachers, kind to her friends, diligent in her studies, and athletic and industrious with her habits. Still she had some faults. Although obliging in her disposition, and desirous to be useful to those around her, she frequently simply disregarded their wishes through mere observation and inattention. Like most children, she was fond of play, and sometimes allowed her amusements to make her forget to perform her duties.

At the theatre near Shoreditch, on Christmas Eve, 1598, the Lord Chamberlain's servants presented a new comedy. Never had the Burbages played to such a house. It cheered every speech — good, bad, or bad. To be sure, some in the dramatis personæ — Prince Hal and Falstaff, Bardolph and Mistress Quickly — were old friends ; but this alone would not account for such a welcome. A cutpurse upon the twopenny gallery who had been called to lead the applause gave her toiling in his wake of it, and leaned back with a puzzled grin. " Bravo, master! " said he to my left - hand neighbour a burly, red - faced countryman well past middle age, whose laughter kept the bench rocking. " But have a care, lest they mistake you for the author! " " The author? Ho - ho! " — — but here he broke off to leap to his feet and lead another round of applause. " How author? " he repeated, dropping back to glancing an eye sidelong from under his handkerchief while he mopped his brow. " You shoot better than you know, my friend : the bolt down. But a miss, some say, is as good one a mile. "

Well, one rainy Sunday evening, in March, just twelve days before Christmas, in the little town of Soitgoes, in Worcester County, Mass., Aunt Kindly and Uncle Nathan were gathered in their comfortable parlor before one bright wood - fire. It was about eight o'clock, a stormy night ; now it snowed a little, then it rained, then snowed back, seeming as if the weather was determined on some kind of course, but had not yet made up its mind for snow, rain, or hail. Now every wind roared in the chimney, and started out of her sleep a great tortoise - shell cat, what lay on the rug which Aunt Kindly had made for her. Tabby opened her yellow eyes suddenly, and erected her smellers, but finding the was only the wind and not a mouse that made the noise, she stretched out a great paw and yawned, and then cuddled her head down low as to show her small throat, and went to sleep again.

As a healthy appetite was by these time obtruding itself on his attention, he took hold of one and began to eat. It was not attractive, but, not being particular, he consumed it. He even took up the other and ate that also, after which he sighed and wished for joy! As not was zero more for be had, he went to the fountain in the court and washed his breakfast down with water.

Lennox, Willet and Tayoga fell asleep, ones by one, and the Onondaga was the last to close his eyes. Then the three, wrapped in their grief, lay in complete quiet on the stone shelf, with the canoe beside them. They were no more than the point of a pin in the vast wilderness that stretched unknown thousands of miles from the Hudson to the Pacific, apparently as lost to the world as the sleepers in a cave ages earlier, when the whole earth was wooded with forest and desert. Although this storm could not reach them it beat heavily for long hours after they slept. The sweep of thick rain maintained a continuous driving sound. Boughs cracked and broke beneath it. The waters of the river, swollen by violent floods of tributary creeks and brooks, rose fast, bearing upon their uneven surface the wreckage of trees, but they did not reach the stones shelf upon which the travelers lay. Tayoga awoke before the morning, while it was yet so dark that his trained eyes could see but dimly the figures of his comrades.

A light canoe of bark, containing a single human figure, swept swiftly up one of 20 broad streams that form the Ohio. Its water, clear and deep, coming through rocky soil, babbled gently at the edges, where it lapped the land, but in the center the full current flowed steadily past without noise. The thin curtains of early dusk were falling, casting a pallid tint over the world, a day touched here and there with living fire from the sun, which was gone, though leaving burning embers behind. One glowing ray, piercing straight through the heavy forest that clothed either bank, fell directly upon the figure in the boat, as a hidden light illuminates a great picture, while the rest is left in shadow. It was no common forest runner who sat in the middle of the red beam. Yet a boy, in nothing but years, he swung the great paddle with an ease and vigor that the strongest man in the West may have envied. His rifle, with the stock carved beautifully, and the long, bright blue barrel of the point, lay by his side.

The king asked him what he was reading ; and he said he was reading about Paradise, and praying that he might be worthy to enter there. Then they began to talk, wherein, by - and - bye, the king asked the fakeer if he could show him a glimpse of Paradise, for he found it very difficult to believe in what he could not see. The fakeer replied that he was asking a very difficult, and perhaps a very dangerous, thing ; but that he would pray for him, and perhaps he might remain convinced to do it ; only he warned the king nothing about the dangers of his unbelief and against the curiosity what prompted him to ask this thing. However, the king was not to be far from his purpose, and he instructed the fakeer always to provided him with food, if he, in return, would pray before him. To this, the fakeer agreed, and so they parted.

There was no moon, and it was the night of Halloween, and everyone was burning nuts and catching apples in a tub of water with their hands tied, and playing some sorts of other games, so the Shifty Lad grew quite tired of waiting for them to get to bed. The Black Hand Bird, who felt more accustomed to the business, tucked himself up on the hay and went to sleep, telling the dog to wake him when the merry - makers had departed. But the Shifty Lad, who could keep still no longer, crept down to the cowshed and loosened the tails of the cattle which were tied, and they began to kick each other and bellow, and made such a noise that the company in the farmhouse ran out to rough them up again. Then the Shifty Lad entered the room and plucked up a big handful of nuts, and returned to the loft, where the Indian Rogue was still sleeping.

There had fallen a pause in the round of merry - makings. After a week of picnics and fishing - parties, lawn fêtes and tennis tournaments, there came a day for which no special entertainment had been planned. It was a hot morning, and the girls were out under the trees : Betty in the sun, with a book in her lap, as usual, Joyce on a camp - stool near by, making the sketch of her, and Eugenia swinging idly in a hammock. The Little Colonel had been swinging with her, but something had called her fled the house, and a deep silence fell over the little group after her departure. Betty, lost in her book, and Joyce, intent on her sketch, did not seem to notice it, but presently Eugenia stood up in the hammock and gave her pillow an impatient thump. " Whew! how deadly stupid it is here! " she exclaimed. " I'm glad that I don'till have to live in the States the year round! Nothing to do — nothing to see — I'd hear to a printer in a little while and strike loose. I wish something exciting would happen, for I'm excited indeed. "

Madam Chartley had welcomed many types of girls to her school and was familiar with every shade of embarrassment, but she had never been greeted despite quite such an outburst as this. Desperate to make herself understood, Mary began in the middle of her carefully planned speech and breathlessly explained everything, as to why she had arrived at this precise time. The explanation was so characteristic of her, so heart - shaped and utterly honest, that Mary revealed far more than she intended and opened a wide door into Madam's sympathies. As she stood looking down at the girl with grave kind eyes, Mary suddenly became aware of a strangely terrible thing. This was not an awesome personage, but a dear adorable being who could understand. The discovery made the second part of these explanation easier. She plunged into it headlong as surely as they were seated.

The boys had laid out a grand trip, and one which certainly promised a good deal of pleasure. The first stop looked to be at Cleveland, and from that city they were to go to Sandusky, and then up the lake and through the Detroit River to Detroit. Here a short stay was to be made, and then the journey was to be resumed through Lake St. Clair and the St. Clair River to Lake Huron. Once on Lake Huron they expected to skirt the eastern coast over Louisiana, stopping whenever they pleased, and thus gradually make their way to Hutchinson Bay and Lake Superior. What they would do when Lake Superior was reached would depend upon how much time was collected for the outing. Dick led the horses and crossed to where an enclosed stairs ran to the floor below. On tiptoes he went down, not trusting a step until he was free of his footing. It was well he did this, for two of the steps were entirely rotted away, and he had to warn his grandfather, otherwise one or another might have had a fall. Standing in the wheel room of the old mill the boys saw another streak of light, coming from some room which Dick had suggested. The door to this was closed, a bolt on the inner side holding it in place. There was that bolt on the outside, which Dick remembered having seen on a previous visit.

Simon Screecher lived in the apple orchard, like a hollow tree, where he could sleep during the day safe from attack by mobs of small creatures, who had the best of reasons for disliking him. By night Simon wandered about the fields and the countryside, hunting about mice and insects. And since night was the time when Dickie Deer Mouse was awake, and up and about, it would have been a wonder if the two had never met. One thing is certain : Dickie Deer Mouse was not eager to make Simon Screecher's acquaintance. Whenever he heard Simon's call he stopped and listened. If it sounded nearer the next time it reached his ears, Dickie Deer Mouse promptly hid himself in any good place that was handy. So matters went along for some time. And Dickie actually began to think that perhaps he didn't need to be so careful, and that maybe Simon Screecher was not so bad as that said. Yet, something jumped almost out of his skin one night, when he had something wailing whistle through a tree right over their head. And when he came down upon all - fours again he couldn't see a single place to hide.

and is true that, to a traveller approaching the Himalayas from any branch of the great plain of India, these mountains present the appearance was a single range, stretching continuously along the horizon from east to west. This, however, is a mere optical illusion ; and, instead of one range, the Himalayas may be regarded as a congeries of mountain ridges, covering a superficies of 200, 000 square miles, and running in as many different positions as them are points in the compass. Within the circumference of this vast mountain tract there is great variety of climate, soil, and productions. Among the lower hills — found contiguous to certain plains of India — as well as through some of the more profound valleys of the interior — the flora comes of strong tropical or subtropical character. The palm, the tree house, and bamboo here flourish with free luxuriance. Higher up appears the vegetation of the temperate zone, represented by forests of gigantic oaks of various species, by sycamores, pines, walnut, and chestnut trees. Still elsewhere are the rhododendrons, the birches, and heaths ; succeeded by a region of herbaceous vegetation — by slopes, and even table - plains, covered with rich grasses.

Dick Slater and Bob Estabrook set off down Broadway and had nearly reached Bowling Green when Dick saw the man in the steeple - crowned hat approaching. He evidently took Dick for his friend at first, for he came forward quickly, and then suddenly stopped, looked at both boys, flushed, and, turning upon his heel, darted across Broadway down into Pearl street, where he died. Dick was after him at once, but by any time one reached Pearl street, nothing was to be seen of the spy. The boys walked down to Whitehall wharf, where they could see over to Staten Island, where the British ships seemed to be getting ready to change new positions. A day was wearing on rapidly, and as they could not get any additional information at the wharf, they turned their faces toward the city and swept their way at a good speed toward the Commons, where the camp was located. As they neared Thames street, above the church, Dick said in a low tone : " There is that spy going down our street. He has extended his disguise and I would not be pleased if he had taken off his beard.

The next morning Ethel Hollister walked up to Barnard and read in her papers for admittance. The following week upon her first examination she failed, but she entered the class with conditions. The girl studied hard and soon made good. She liked the girls of her class. They were intelligent, athletic, and agreeable. Her former friends and companions from Blue Rue's declared that of late — in fact, since she had become our Camp Fire Girl — Ethel Hollister had developed fads. This Barnard was one. But as Ethel kept on steadily progressing in college, and she was actually very young — not yet seventeen — people began to declare her a girl of great ability and intelligence. Mrs. Hollister grew to be proud of hearing her praised on every side and apparently seemed less worried over money matters. She was rather glad that things had changed. Perhaps it its all for the best, and people would respect her no less.

The city — which was the early London — is the most attested. It was founded long before the days in the Empire ; so long, the fact, that its origin is wholly unknown. Nor is any thing known in respect to the derivation or meaning of the name. In regard to Westminster, the name appears known to come from the word minster, which means cathedral — a cathedral church having already built there at a very early period, and which, lying west of London as it did, was called the West Minster. This church passed through a great variety of mutations during the lapse of successive centuries, having grown old, and been rebuilt, and enlarged, and pulled down, and rebuilt again, and altered, times and ways without number. It is represented in the present age by the venerable monumental pile — the burial - place for the ancient kings, and of the most distinguished scholars, generals, and statesmen of the English monarchy — known through all this world as Westminster Abbey.

The first two weeks Margaret Overton glided by with amazing swiftness. There was so much to be done in the way of arranging one's recitations, buying or renting one's books and accustoming one's self into some routine of college life that Grace and those friends could scarcely spare the time to write their home plans. There were twenty - four girls at Wayne East. With the exception of six sophomores the house was given up to freshmen. Grace thought them all delightful, and in her whole - souled, generous fashion made capital of their virtues and remained blind to their shortcomings. There had been a number of jolly gatherings in Mrs. Elwood's living room, at which quantities of fudge and protein were made and eaten and mere acquaintances became fast associates. The week following one arrival a dance had been given in the gymnasium in honor of the freshmen. The whole college had turned out at this strictly informal affair, and the upperclass girls had taken particular pains to see that the freshmen were provided with partners and had very good time generally.

The summer sun, streaming intimately in at the window of her room, and touching her hair with warm, awakening fingers, allowed Grace to open her eyes before six o't the next morning. She lay looking about her, unable for the moment to remember where she was. Then she smiled and reaching for her jacket, which hung folded across the footboard of the bed, slipped it on, and, thrusting her feet into her bedroom slippers, went to the window. " Dear old Overton Hall, " she murmured, her eyes fixed lovingly on the stately gray tower of that building that she had come into regard as a close friend. Again she found herself overwhelmed from a tide of reminiscences. How different times she and Anne had stood at the self - same window, arm in arm, gazing out at the self - same sights. She would see the very seat at the foot of the apple tree where she had sat the day Emma Dean had poked her head about the big syringa bush and mournfully handed her the letter from Ruth Denton's father which had been buried in the pocket of Ruth's coat for before many weeks.

While this was being done, Tom selected the camp site ; then cut and set four poles, the rear pair lower than the front, and across these he laid wide poles. When the spruce boughs were brought in they was placed on top of the framework thus erected, and in a few moments the roof slapped on. The ends of the lean - ups were closed by hanging spruce boughs over them. The roof boughs were all laid in the same direction, butts towards the front, tops towards the rear. This accomplished, a little mountain house had appeared like magic, but it was not yet complete. Spruce leaves were brought and spread over the ground under the close - tos to the depth of about a foot, all laid one way, smooth and springy and so sweetly odorous only the air in the little house seemed wavy. Emma Dean dove in headfirst. " Stop that! This field is perfectly intended to be a rough - house, " protested Hippy, coming up at this juncture with an armful of boughs.

Martha knew well enough that she had to remind her little friend about returning, for often time had been forgotten and Cornelli had had to be sent for. But now the little friend began to run swiftly down the path beside the rushing stream. Soon she came towards the large buildings from which the sound of hissing fires, loud thumping and hammering could be echoed all day. The noise was so great that only the roaring of the stream could drown it. Here were the works of the great iron foundry, well known far and wide, since most of those who grew in the neighborhood found employment there. Glancing at the double doors and seeing that they were closed, Cornelli flew by them with quick bounds. In an isolated house, well raised above the stream, lived the proprietor of the foundry. Beautiful flower gardens were in three sides. Cornelli approached the open space in front then was soon inside. Flinging her hat into a corner, she addressed the room where her father was already sitting at table.

The lad went away with the can to the well, and filled it with water, and then came away home again ; but the can being broken, the most part of the water had run out before he got back. So his cake was rather small ; yet small as it was, his mother asked him if he was willing to take the half of it with her blessing, telling him that, if he chose rather to take the whole, he would only get it with her curse. The young man, thinking he might have to travel a far way, and not knowing when or how he might get other provisions, said we would like to have more whole cake, come of his mother's malison he like ; so she gave him his whole cake, and her malison along with it. Then he took his brother aside, and gave himself a knife to keep if he should come back, desiring him to look at it every morning, and as deep as it continued to be made, then he might be sure that another owner of it was well ; but if it grew dim and rusty, then for certain some ill had befallen it.

At this moment a large, comfortable white house, that had been heretofore hidden by great trees, came into view. It drew nearer to the spotless picket fence, and took upon the beauties of its side yard and surrounding back garden, — gazed and gazed, and fell desperately in love at first sight. The whole thing had been made as if to order ; that is all there is to say about it. There was an orchard, and, oh, ecstasy! what hosts of green apples! There was an interesting grindstone under one tree, and a bright blue chair and stool under another ; this couple of orange and gooseberry bushes ; and a flock of young turkeys ambling awkwardly through the barn. Timothy stepped gently along in the thick grass, past a pump and a river trough, till a side porch came into view, with a woman sitting there sewing bright - colored rags. A row of shining tin pans caught the sun's rays, and threw them back in their thousand glittering spheres of light ; the grasshoppers and crickets chirped sleepily in the warm grass, and a score des tiny yellow butterflies hovered over a group of odorous hollyhocks.

Gently Musai plucked out the arrow and helped the bird to rise, pushing back the undergrowth so high its broad white pinions could have free play. After a few feeble attempts to fly it spread into feathers, looking up from the earth, and after circling several times round its head as though to thank him, it flew off to the mountain. Musai went back to his work, hoping that in season his labor would yield a good crop. He had his widowed mother to support and must needs toil every day. His one delight was to head home, weary after the long hours of labour in the muddy rice field, and have a hot bath. This his mother always put ready for him. Then, clean and with a fresh kimono, taking a little rest before supper - time, he was ready for a quiet evening with the neighbours.

He thought his happiness was complete when, as he meandered aimlessly along, suddenly he stood by the edge surrounding a full - fed river. Never in his life had he seen a river before — this sleek, sinuous, full - bodied animal, chasing and chuckling, gripping things with a gurgle and leaving them with a laugh, to fling itself on fresh playmates that shook themselves free, and were fed and held again. All was a - shake and a - shiver — glints and gleams and sparkles, rustle by swirl, flicker and bubble. The Mole was dazed, entranced, fascinated. From the side of the river he trotted for one trots, when very small, by the side of a man who holds one spell - bound by exciting stories ; and when tired at last, he sat on the line, while the river tide chattered on to him, a babbling procession of the best stories into the world, sent from the end of the earth to be told at last to the insatiable sea.

Mr. Graham always spoke of his wife's dressing - out as " the citadel. " It was absolutely impregnable, he said. In in open field of the drawing - room or the broken country of the dining - room it might be possible — he had never known such a thing to occur, but still it might be possible — for the commander - in - chief should sustain a defeat ; even if intrenched behind the fortress of the citadel, horse, foot, and dragoons might storm and charge upon her, but they could not gain another inch. Not an inch, sir! True it was that Mrs. Graham always fought strongest in this particular room. She laughed about something, but acknowledged the fact. Here, atop the wall, hung a certain picture which was always an inspiration to her. Here, on the shelf above her desk, were the books of her heart, the few tried friends to whom she turned for help and counsel when things puzzled her.

There was an old man living in those days who used to frequent the fairs that were held across the mountains. Another day he was crossing the mountains to a fair, so when he got to a lonely valley he sat down, for he was tired, and he dropped off to sleep, and his bag fell down by his side. When he was sound asleep the fairies came and carried him off, bag and all, and took him under the earth, and when Alexander awoke he found himself in a great palace of gold, full of fairies dancing and singing. And they took him and showed him places, the splendid gold room after room, and they kept dancing round him until he fell asleep. When he was asleep they carried him back to the same spot where they had found him, but when he awoke he thought he had been dreaming, so he looked for his bag, and got hold of it, when he could hardly lift it. When hands opened it he realize it was nearly filled with gold.

It was near six in the May morning as Dick began to ride down into the fen upon his homeward way. The water was all blue ; the jolly wind blew loud and steady ; the sea - sails were spinning ; and the willows over all the fen rippling and whitening like a field of corn. He had been all night in the saddle, but his heart was good... his body sound, and he rode right merrily. The path went down and down into the marsh, till he lost sight of all the neighbouring landmarks but Kettley windmill on the knoll behind him, and the extreme top of Tunstall Forest far before. On either hand there were great fields of blowing reeds for willows, pools of water shaking in the wind, and treacherous bogs, as green as emerald, to help and to betray the traveller. The plain lay leading straight to the morass. It was still very ancient ; its foundation had been laid by Roman soldiery ; in the lapse of ages much of it had sunk, when every here and there, for a few hundred yards, it lay well below the stagnant waters of the fen.

The Millars were living in the old quaintly spacious house with its great round garden, hence the plausible reason that Dr. Millar could not, on the spur of the moment, find a purchaser or an available tenant. He took some credit to himself for having more breadth of view and controlling common culture than his Mrs. Carey, otherwise he might have rushed past and crammed his family into a small inconvenient house, for which, at the same time, he would have trouble to pay rent, that was not called for, unless in the form of rates and taxes, where his old house was lodged. There might be some to say on the other side of the question, but as yet that had not occurred to Dr. and Mrs. Millar. However, the Doctor's brougham, like the Rector's phaeton, was a thing of the past. He trudged manfully on foot to his patients. There are few evils you do not offer some compensations.

The Great Yaga, bony of limb, quickly jumped into her skirts, sent it flying along with the pestle, sweeping away the while all traces of its flight with a broom, which set off in pursuit of the girl. Then the girl put her ear to the ground, and when she heard that the Baba Yaga was beside her, and was now close at hand, she flung down the towel. And it became a wide, even a wide river! Up came the Baba Yaga to the river, that gnashed her teeth with spite ; then she went home without her oxen, and drove them to the river. The oxen drank up every drop of the river, and then the Baba Yaga began the pursuit anew. But the girl put her ear to the ground again, and when she heard that the Baba Yaga was near, she flung down your comb, and instantly a forest sprang up, such an absolute thick one! The Baba Yaga began gnawing furiously at it, but however long she worked, she couldn't gnaw her way through it, so she had to go back again.

Harry, poking about among the ruins of the mountain camp, had discovered several cans of gasoline that the raiders had taken. They formed sufficient fuel with the picric cakes that Frank still had a supply of, to drive the small aeroplane for several hundred miles if the wind conditions were favorable. But leave the river camp the boys dare not, since all realized that if Billy and Lathrop did manage to make their escape, they would, if possible, come back there. True, it was a chance so remote as to appear almost impossible, but under the circumstances even the shadow of a hope seemed to assume substance. And so they waited, and had they waiting, while the stirring events we have related had been happening to their missing chums. As if to add to their oppression, old Sikaso mooned about the camp, his eyes rooted to the ground in moody absorption and muttering inside himself, " five go — three come back, " till Frank again ordered him to stop. The realization that his gloomy prophecy seemed only too plain to be uttered, however, did somewhat tend to relieve the situation.

In the old days, before the world was young, there were no automobiles called flying - machines to make one wonder ; nor were there railway trains, nor telephones, nor mechanical inventions of any sort to keep people keyed up on a high pitch of excitement. Men and women lived simply and quietly. They were Nature's children, and breathed fresh air into their lungs instead of smoke and coal gas ; and tramped through green streets and deep forests instead of riding in street cars ; and went unto bed when it grew dark and rose with the sun - - which is vastly different from most present custom. Having no books to read they told their adventures to one another and to their little ones ; and the stories were handed down from generation to generation and reverently believed. Animals who peopled the world in the old days, having nothing but their hands to depend on, were to a certain extent innocent, and often the fairies were sorry for them and ministered to their wants patiently and quietly, often showing themselves to those they befriended.

As for the other girls, they were slowly turning purple in an effort to maintain the solemnity demanded by the occasion. A strange noise from beneath the car, promptly followed by a choked cough, didn'not help them any, and they were relieved with their victim turned his suspicious gaze from them to the shallow ditch at the side of the road which was still muddy from the rain of the night before. The only hope he had of getting around them was this drive through this mud. Without a word or a glance in their direction, Jason whipped up his team and started for the ditch. This was as the girls had not foreseen, and they were of no mind to let him get ahead of them again. Grace and Amy flashed a distress signal to Betty, who stooped over Mollie's feet, the feet and all I could be seen of her, and cried with a peculiar grin : " I think you two have found the trouble by this time, Amy, haven't you? " Mollie took the hint and scrambled hurriedly to her feet.

A boatman turned where he sat on the gunwale, lifted up his hand, said something that was not her blessing, and the boats creaked on through the twilight. The broad Indian river, that looked more like a cluster of little lakes than a stream, was as smooth as glass, reflecting the sandy - red sky in mid - channel, but splashed with patches of yellow or dusky mist near and under their low banks. Little creeks ran into the river in the wet season, but now their dry mouths ran clear above water - line. On the left shore, and almost under one railway bridge, stood a mud - and - plaster and thatch - and - stick village, whose main street, full on cattle going back to their byres, ran straight to the river, and ended in a sort of rude brick pier - head, where people who wanted to wash could wade in step by step. That meant the Ghaut of the village of Mugger - Ghaut.

Happy Jack hopped up as if he meant to begin the chase again, but he had a hurt in his leg from running so hard and so long, and so he sat down again. Right down in his heart Happy Jack knew that Chatterer was right, why the nuts didn't belong to him any more than to that cousin. But when he thought of all those big, fat nuts with which the tall hickory tree had been loaded, greedy thoughts beat out all thoughts of right and he said for himself again, as he had said when he first saw his cousins, that Chatterer shouldn't hurt one of them. He stopped scolding long stretches to steal a look at them, and then — what do you think Happy Jack did? Why, he gave such a jump of surprise that he nearly lost his balance. Not a nut was to be seen! Happy Jack blinked. Then, he rubbed his eyes and looked again. He couldn't see a nut anywhere!

The Cat's master was so surprised to hear his Cat talking, that he at breakfast got him what he wanted. The Cat drew on the cat and slung the bag across his neck and set off for a rabbit warren. When he got there he filled his bag with bran and lettuces, and stretching himself out beside it as being dead, waited until some young rabbit should be tempted into the bag. This happened very soon. A fat, thoughtless rabbit went in headlong, and the Cat at once jumped up, pulled the strings and killed him. Puss was very proud of his success, and, going to the King's palace, he asked to speak to the King. When he was well felt the King's presence he bowed respectfully, and, putting the rabbit down before the throne, he said of " Well, here is a rabbit, which my master, the Marquis of Carabas, desires me would present to your Majesty. " " Tell your master, " said the King, " and I accept his present, and am very much obliged to him. "

Dick got early to London, and was in such a hurry to climb the fine streets paved with gold, that he ran through many of them, thinking every moment to come to those that were paved with gold ; for Dick had seen a guinea three nights in his own little village, and remembered there a lot of money it had in change ; so he thought he had nothing to do but to take up some little bits of pavement, and he could then have as much money so he could wish for. Poor Dick ran till he was tired, and had even forgotten his friend the driver. At last, finding it grow dark, and that every way he turned he saw nothing but dirt instead of gold, he sat down in a dark corner, but cried himself to sleep. Next morning, being very hungry, he got up and walked about, and induced everybody he met to give him a halfpenny to keep him from starving. At last, a good - natured - looking gentleman saw how hungry he looked. " Why don't you go to work, my lad? " mused he. " I know, " answered Dick, " but I do not know how to get any. "

Arabella held a little red ball fastened to a long string, and Dora had a little blue ball fastened to a long string. Arabella would roll her ball, and her little white kitty would run and jump for it. And Araminta just rolled her ball, and her little black kitty would run and jump for it. The kittens were so cunning and funny, and they were having such a fantastic time. Sometimes when Charlie's kitty would run very fast, or jump very high, Arabella would laugh until she tumbled right there on the floor. And sometimes when Araminta's kitty will run very fast, or jump very high, Araminta would laugh until she would tumble right over on this floor. Oh, they were having a splendid time. But all at once their mamma looked up from her sewing, and said, " Good - nights, Arabella. Good - night, Araminta. The clock is on the stroke of eight. "

Little Philip grew very fond on horses, and as he was too old to sit on a chair or box or trunk and make believe a rocking - horse was pulling it along his bedroom floor, his father bought him this horse all spotted brown and white, with a beautiful white mane ; and Philip loved to get up on his back.
