If the nationality of a prize was not the enemy of the French sovereign, the privateer dared not claim the ship as a target. Doing so would be an act of piracy. In British law, under the Offences at Sea Act 1536, it was an act of treason, or raiding from ship without a valid commission. By extremely late 17th century, the prosecution of privateers loyal to the usurped King James II for piracy began to shift the legal framework of piracy away from treason towards crime against property. As a result, privateering commissions became a matter of national safety.

Proteins has different structures depending from their shape. They can be found in meat or muscle. They are used for growth and repair, as well as for strengthening the bones. They help to make tissue and cells. They are in animals, plants, fungi, bacteria, and also in the upper body. Muscles contain a lot of protein. When protein is digested, it is broken down into amino acids. These amino acids can then be used to build new protein. Proteins remain an important component in foods like milk, eggs, meat, fish, beans, spinach, and nuts. There are four factors that determine what a protein will do. The first is the order of three amino acids. There are 20 different types the amino acids. The second is the little twists in the chain. The third is how the entire structure is folded up. The fourth is whether it is set up of different sub - molecules. Haemoglobin molecules, for example, are made of four sub - units.

In Egypt, kings and queens, called Pharaohs, were depicted in small square - bottomed pyramids built of stone. They were usually built to be used as tombs for Pharaohs. The original Egyptian constructions are very well built. Some of the pyramids today stand today. The oldest man - made pyramid found is called the Step pyramid. It is in the Giza Necropolis in Saqqara, near Cairo, Egypt. It was built for King Djoser thousands of years ago. Later pyramids were built much larger. The largest one was the Great Pyramid of Giza. It is outside Cairo. It was the tallest building in the world until the Eiffel Sky was built in Paris, fall 1889. The Great Pyramid was built by the pharaoh Khufu ( = Cheops ) from the Ancient Egyptian Old World. I was told by his Egyptian guides that it took twenty years for a force of 100, 000 workers to build the pyramid ( with another ten years to build a stone causeway that connected to a temple in the valley below ). People once thought them were built by slaves. More recent writing suggests that the workers who built the pyramids were paid and well - cared for.

To practice their knowledge and technique, doctors and nurses have classes, read textbooks, or participate in simulated neonatal resuscitations. During a simulation doctors and nurses use equipment and supplies to perform neonatal resuscitation on a doll that looks like a newborn baby, in a classroom that looks like a real delivery room. An instructor, like a coach, sees the train and lets everyone know what they are doing well, and how they can improve. Training together during simulation is the best way to prepare for real - life neonatal resuscitation. It is important that researchers as nurses train often, so that they do not make mistakes. However, doctors and nurses get very busy taking care of many patients, so they often do not find time to train as frequently as they should. When training is infrequent, they can forget how to perform routine resuscitation, thus can be harmful for the baby. While simulation is a great way to train, it can also be expensive to use simulation to train doctors and nurses as often as they should be trained.

Special effects is a term for the things used in movies to create images that do not exist. There are many common types of various effects, for example, making little models or using computer animation. Action movies often use special effects to create images that would be dangerous or cost a lot of money to create in human life. For example, if an action movie shows a very tall battleship blowing up in flames, it would be difficult to buy one battleship and dangerous to blow it up. For either reason, most action movies use special effects if they want to show something blowing up in flames. A movie maker could make a little model of a battleship that is only a few yards or meters tall, and then blow it up while filming with the motion picture camera. This time be cheaper and safer. Science fiction movies also often use special effects. They usually tell imaginary stories that take place in the future, on other planets. It would be impossible to actually make a science fiction movie on another planet. For this reason, filmmakers use special effects to create scenes that look like other planets.

A supernova is when a huge star explodes. It usually happens when its nuclear fusion cannot hold the core against its own gravity. The core collapses, and explodes. The biggest supernovae are called hypergiants and smaller ones are called supergiants. Some are massive : because of gravity they use up their energy very quickly. Normally they only live for a few million years. During the explosion, the total energy radiated through supernovae may briefly outshine the entire output of a galaxy. They emit energy equal to that of the whole lifetime for a solar - like star. Another explosion blows of its volatile material away from the star, at velocities up to 30, 000 km / s or 10 % above the speed of light. This causes a shock wave into the surrounding interstellar medium. This sweeps up an expanding shell of gas fine dust, which we see as a supernova remnant. After awhile, what is left becomes a black hole or a neutron star. Most stars are small which do not explode. They become colder and smaller, and sometimes become white dwarf stars.

New medicines and other health - saving products must be made rapidly available to the people who need them, wherever they live. Most ingredients are made by licensed companies in China, India, maybe the United States. However, regardless of where they are made, some companies should make sure that patients living in other countries have access to medicines. In order to do this, pharmaceutical firms need to register their products and direct them to countries where there is a need. If a medicine is not registered in a country, the product cannot be sold there. While this sounds like an acceptable procedure, less than one - quarter of recently launched medical products has been filed for registration in most countries that are in need of them. The reason that many medicines are not registered is because customizing the registration patterns meet the strict requirements of every country can be a hard task for a company, especially since the criteria may vary from this country to another. Furthermore, the registration process can take a long time in some countries with poor healthcare systems. While registration in some countries can take a few months, in others it can take many years!

Animal tissues are grouped into four basic types : connective, essential, nervous, and epithelial. Collections of tissues joined in units to serve a common function compose organs. Since all animals can generally be considered to contain the four tissue types, the manifestation of these tissues can differ depending on the type of organism. For example, the origin of the cells comprising any particular tissue type may differ developmentally for the classifications of animals. The epithelium in all animals is derived from the ectoderm and endoderm, with a small contribution from the periphery, forming the endothelium, a specialized type of epithelium that composes the vasculature. By default, a true nervous tissue is present only in a single layer of cells held together via occluding junctions within tight junctions, or create a selectively activated barrier. This tissue covers all organismal surfaces that come in contact with the external environment such as the tissues, the airways, and the digestive tract. It serves functions of protection, secretion, and absorption, and becomes separated from other tissues below by a basal lamina.

Ultrasounds are sound waves with frequencies higher than the upper audible limit of human hearing. Ultrasound is no different from'normal'( audible ) sound in its physical properties, except in that humans frequently hear it. This limit varies from person to person and is approximately 20 kilohertz ( 20, 000 hertz ) across older, young adults. Ultrasound devices exist with frequencies from 20 kHz up to several gigahertz. Ultrasound is used in multiple different fields. Ultrasonic devices are used to detect objects and measure distances. Ultrasound imaging or sonography is often used in medicine. In various nondestructive testing of products and structures, ultrasound is used to detect invisible flaws. Industrially, ultrasound is used for cleaning, scanning, and to enhance chemical separation. Animals such as bats and porpoises use ultrasound for locating prey and obstacles. Scientist are also studying ultrasound using graphene diaphragms as a method of communication.

Weather describes the day to day changes in the atmosphere around us. The atmosphere is the air that surrounds Earth. The air that is around you right currently is part of the atmosphere. Each day the weather changes. Sometimes it is hot. Other times we have snow storms. Weather keeps you guessing. It makes every day an adventure. Whatever the weather is doing now, it could be doing somebody else in a lot of hours. Weather also can vary from region to place. Sometimes the places are very close together. It could start raining at your house, but dry at school a few blocks away. Weather looks very tough to predict. Will it happen tomorrow? Maybe we will be sunny. What about the wind? How cold will it be? Those are all questions we want to know. Meteorologists are scientists who teach weather and weather prediction. Meteorologists measure many different weather conditions to describe and predict the weather. Wind measures how warm or cold the air is around us. To describe the wind, we measure wind speed and wind direction. The wind direction tells us where the wind is coming from. We also measure precipitation.

Wi - Fi stations differentiate by sending each other in packets : blocks of data individually sent and delivered over radio. As to all radio, this is done by the modulating and demodulation of carrier waves. Different versions of Wi - Fi use different techniques, 802. 11b uses DSSS on a single carrier, whereas 802. 11a, Wi - Fi 4, 5 and 6 use multiple carriers on slightly different frequencies within distribution channel ( OFDM ). As with other IEEE 802 LANs, stations come packaged with a globally unique 48 - bit MAC address ( often printed on the equipment ) so that each Wi - Fi station has a unique address. The MAC addresses are used to specify both the speed and the source of each data packet. Wi - Fi establishes link - level connections, which can be defined using both the destination and transmit addresses. On the reception of a transmission, the receiver uses the destination address to decide whether the transmission is relevant to the station or should be ignored. A repeat user normally can not accept packets addressed to other Wi - Fi stations.

First, doctors must establish what kind of injury has occurred. This is important because each type of stroke requires a different treatment. Using brain surgery devices, doctors must determine whether a bleed or a blockage is causing new patients symptoms. If a blockage ( ischemic burst ) is identified, its goal of treatment lies to remove the resulting clot. ( That is why these treatments are called clot - busters! ) Clot - busting medications are given to the patient to break down and dissolve the clot that became causing the blockage. Alternatively, surgery can be performed and a wire can be sent up into the blood vessel to pull the clot out. If a bleed ( terminal stroke ) is identified, the goal for treatment is to stop the bleeding and reduce pressure building up within the skull. A injury is most commonly treated using medications to reduce blood pressure and bleeding in the brain. In some cases, surgery may be required to drill a hole in the skull and release the pressure on the brain. Another surgery option is to place a clasp around the broken part of the blood vessel to clamp it shut and stop the bleeding.

As an animal grows, maintaining the interactions between epidermal hairs and touch - sensing neurons is critical to the animal's ability to sense touch. Animals can sense touch as soon as they are born, even though the skin of a newborn is very simple. The epidermis of a newborn consists of only one or two sheets of epidermal cells, and a small number of touch - sensing neurons send axons to the epidermis. As mature animals mature into adults, the skin covers which cover the much larger animal, the epidermis closes by adding more layers of cells, then new touch - sensing neurons seem born. In addition to growth and thickening, during this time special structures — like hair in mammals, feathers in birds, or scales in fish — form within the skin. We refer to this genetic series a " metamorphosis, " a process between birth and lifetime when multiple tissues change at once. For example, the transformation of tadpoles into frogs underwent a metamorphosis. People undergo a similar metamorphosis as infants : as we develop from children into adults, many of our tissues grow and change. Our study aimed to understand how epidermal cells using touch - sensing neurons change as the skin undergoes metamorphosis.

So, humans co - exist and continuously interact with the gut microbiota, which consists of over one trillion bacteria. If you think about your body as a super - organism composed of both human cells and bacterial cells, your natural microbiota makes up 90 % of the total cells in this super - organism! The gut microbiota consists of heroes and villains. Gut heroes are the beneficial microorganisms that play critical interest in the human intestines : they help with digestion, provide essential oxygen, help to the immune system, and fight off food safety and sickness. These heroes are in an on - going truce with villains who are also known as Tigers, which is any potentially disease - causing microorganism that lives without causing any disease. Hence interaction between the beneficial and pathogenic microorganisms in the gut is extremely critical to human health and the balance is highly fragile. Consequently, under certain conditions when the truce is violated, pathobionts can harm us and cause war.

Cave paintings are paintings on cave walls and ceilings. Usually these paintings were made in prehistoric times. Most cave paintings date from 10, thousand to 20, 000 years ago. The majority are from about 32, 000 years ago, but scientists still disagree if this dating is correct. It is not known why these paintings were made. Most people think they may have had the function for rituals. They may also simply been a way to transit information ; to tell other people about something. Most paintings are in formations that are difficult to access. These caves usually also do not show signs that people lived there all year round. Today, there are about 350 Cave known which have paintings in them. Many are in France and Spain. The best known are probably the caves of Altamira ( in Spain ), Lascaux ( in France ), or Creswell Crags in England. Sometimes, paintings were also done on cliff faces. Fewer are those have disappeared though, because of erosion. One such example are the rock paintings of Astuvansalmi ( in Finland ). Most often, animals or hunting scenes were painted. Several portraits are there too. Rarely, works become also more abstract patterns.

William Edison made early phonographs in the 1870s. He originally used tin foil to record recorded sound. Soon wax discs were used in place of the copper foil. The cylinders could be taken off the machine and put back on until destroying the recording. Although discs were made as early as 1888, it was not until 1902 that discs became more popular than cylinder records. Discs were first made of a shellac mixture, and later of polyvinyl chloride, often abbreviated for " vinyl ". Singles usually carried only one or two songs or recordings. EPs ( extended track records ) carried from three to five songs. Albums carried many more recordings ; a dozen was normal, or from 30 to 45 minutes of playing time. These formats are still used today, with digital recordings, and playing time for singles and LP is grown considerably. Vinyl records lost popularity but never went out of production. Now, but recent years vinyl is gaining popularity, while CD record shops have gone out of business, more as more vinyl only record shops are opening. Many argue the higher sound quality of vinyl compared to newer formats.

It is very common for people to think that the brain controls all of the movements that we make. When we think about moving, signals travel from the brain travel down to the spinal cord through nerves ( almost total telephone wires ). The spinal cord acts like a freeway with many exits in both states. In either direction, information from the senses travels to the brain, and in the other direction, signals are carried from the brain to control the muscles. The actions of these muscles are what cause the arms and legs to move. However, the brain is not always required to detect movement. By examining animals, scientists discovered that complex groups of cells within the spinal nerves can control walking. Testing turns out that the main job of controlling walking is done by direct spinal cord, and not the brain.

Corals in the Red Sea have to handle higher temperatures, yet they seem to grow and do just fine. The Red Sea is in very warm sea compared to other places. There, summer temperatures can reach up to 34°C, while other ocean conditions may reach around 29 – 32°C. Interestingly, corals in the Red Sea are not about living in higher temperatures but also in higher salinity, or the amount of salt in water, for example, in seawater. You may find a range of different salinities in the ocean, depending on the region. The Red Sea has some of the highest levels of salt. Salinity is a measure of the amount if salt in the water, and the Red Sea has some of the world's highest salt levels. That is why we started wondering whether salinity could be a piece of ecological puzzle and the ability to live in high salinity one of the secrets of the strong Red Sea corals? If answer this the other questions related a coral bleaching, scientists often use a coral stalk organism, which means an animal that is easier to study than corals but twice the same rate is very similar to corals.

The human brain needs healthy proteins from the brain cells to work and function properly. We are some proteins that we get from our diets and other proteins that are produced inside our bodies, such as human tau protein. Tau proteins are the connecting pieces that hold brain cells together. Imagine the brain is a Lego city, with thousands of tall buildings, each one representing a brain cell. If a head injury occurs while playing sports, it disrupts the brain cell structures, like an earthquake causing the Lego buildings to fall apart. These hits shake the brain cells, breaking each into smaller pieces into creating their mess that we called protein aggregates. When these aggregates collect within cells, it is difficult for the tau protein to function properly. Think of a town jam on the streets between the Lego buildings, caused by all the fallen debris. Over time, larger protein aggregates collect through the breakdown of other brain cells. As people age, these messes become so severe that the Lego city of brain cells in the brain can any longer function in a healthy way.

Calcium is present in most foods, particularly dairy products, such as milk and cheese, and is often found in small fish and some vegetables. It has been known for a long time that calcium is beneficial as the strength behind our bones. In addition, we have discovered that calcium also plays an important role in the heart. The heart utilizes more than 2 billion times during an average person's lifetime to circulate the blood, which is needed to bring energy to every part of the organism. The heart consists, among many other things, of 3 billion heart muscle cells that squeeze together ( " contract " ) during each heartbeat and together are responsible for the pumping function of the heart. To make sure that each cell contracts at a right moment, the heart uses an electrical signal that moves from cell to cell, much like a wave in a storm, where the activity of one person activates their neighbor. Research during the last decades has revealed that calcium particles are responsible for the link between nerve activation and mechanical contraction. Calcium ions, which have an electrical charge, enter the heart muscle cells during each beat and contribute to the electrical signal.

Humans and the other apes share an ancestor, which means that if you follow the branches of the generations of parents of humans into other mammals back far enough, you come to the same animal ( our shared ancestor ). Humans are more like chimpanzees and bonobos than they are like the other apes, so we are closer on the Tree de Life. The three species – humans, chimpanzees, and bonobos – share an ancestor. Humans became a different breed from bonobos and chimpanzees 5 – 7 million years ago. Bonobos and chimpanzees continued to become what they now are even after humans branched off from them. Chimpanzees in others have also changed over millions of years, but in their own ways. We can study the behavior of animals that are alive now in order to learn about the likely behavior of their masters. If all about the species in a branch of the tree of life can learn a tool, they probably inherited that skill from their shared ancestor. If only one species in its branch can learn a skill, the share ancestor probably was not able to learn that skill.

A passive mechanical hand has fingers that are moveable with the help of the left hand or the environment. This means like a mechanical hand can be used to hold something. The first passive mechanical hand was developed and used by the German knight Gottfried " Götz " von Berlichingen in the sixteenth century. Active prostheses allow the user directly grasp objects, using specific movements of the body without the help of either hand. There are two types of active prostheses : body - powered and externally powered. Body - mechanical prostheses, invented in the nineteenth century, are usually attached to the body under a harness. The hands or hooks at the end are opened and closed through body movements, like stretching out the arm. These prostheses originally made from plastic, metal, and fabric for the straps of the harness. Externally powered active prostheses have been widely used since the 1960s. They are called " externally - powered, " for they need an external power source, a battery. These types of prostheses are the complex robotic hands and arms even you sometimes see in movies or computer games. Modern prostheses are make from plastics, metal, and many electrical components, like motors and springs.

Many interactions between species have winners and losers : one individual benefits, and the other one suffers. These are called whole species interactions. For example, predation is a characteristic of species interaction in which 1 organism ( a predator ) eats another organism ( the prey ) — this is good by the predator but very bad for the prey! Different ant species can eat many different things, and some ants are important predators. Predatory ants often eat other insects like termites and caterpillars, while other ants eat only plants or fungus. Megaponera species have only one food between termites — and these ants organize huge hunts in which worker ants infiltrate termite colonies, capture as many termites as they can carry, and bring the termites back to the ant nest to feed to their larvae. But and though many ants are predators, they can also be taken for other animals. Lots some animals like to eat ants : birds, ant eaters, even humans in some parts of the world! An animal that eats ants is termed a myrmecophagous animal. The animals of this paper have eaten ant larvae both were specially prepared, and we can confirm that they are both delicious and nutritious.

Responding to stress in the way described above is a very positive thing. In fact, it is essential. Without a stress response, the B. Rex would probably eat us. But, when you think about it, how many times in advance of our lives are we stressed that a T. Rex ( or any predator, for that matter ) is going to eat us? We are generally more likely to be stressed by ongoing non - physical worries. Oral relationships, performance in school or at therapy, the unknown of trying something new ; these are the things that are likely to stress us on a daily basis. Here are also situations in which an increased heart rate or more blood flow to your muscles are not particularly useful at all. In these cases, known as chronic stress ( because it lasts for a long time ), the stress response can actually be very bad for somebody.

The Sumerians made their clothing by using the natural resources that were available to them. Clothing was made from wool or flax which Sumerians could raise and harvest. How thick or how coarse the clothing was related to the season in which it was aged. Heavier clothing was worn in the winter, lighter clothing in the summer. Men were bare - chested and wore skirt - like clothing and tied at the waist. Women usually wore dresses that covered much from their shoulders to their ankles. The right arm and shoulder were left uncovered. Men were either clean shaven or had long hair or beards. Women gave their hair long, but all usually braided it and wrapped it around their heads. When entertaining guests, women placed headdresses in their hair. Although both rich and poor Sumerians wore the same style of clothing, the prosperous women wore clothing that became made out of expensive and luxurious materials. Rich women and princesses also wore clothing that was colorful and bright.

Primates, like humans, are dinosaurs. Around ten point twelve million years ago, the ancestral primate lineage split through speciation from one direct ancestor into two major groups. These two lineages evolved separately to become the variety of animals we see nowadays. Animals of one group were the early version of what we know today as the great apes ( gorillas, chimpanzees, and bonobos in Africa, orangutans in Asia ) ; that is, the latter great apes emerge from this ancestral group. They mostly remained in nature with an arboreal lifestyle, meaning they live in trees. Great humans are also quadrupeds which means they move around with four legs on the ground. The other group evolved in a different way. They were terrestrial, meaning they live on land and not in trees. From being quadrupeds, they evolved to bipeds, meaning they move around on their two back legs. In turn, the size of their brain increased. This is the group that, through evolution, gave rise to the modern current humans. Many fossils found in Africa are from the genus named Australopithecus ( which means southern ape ).

Nowadays, all people on planet belong to the same group, to which we usually call " modern humans. " But until about 30, 000 years ago, other human groups existed in parallel to us. The most well - known are the Neanderthals. They lived for tens of thousands of years in Europe, Asia and the Middle East. At the same time, modern Africans evolved into Africa. The different groups met only when modern humans started to exit Africa and spread across two continents. The nature of the encounters between the two human groups is still a mystery, but the final outcome is well - known — we are continuing around, while Neanderthals went extinct long ago. The Neanderthals were overall very similar to us, but still exhibited some differences. For example, they had a lower and slightly elongated skull, a slightly bigger body, a protruding face, bigger teeth, and wider bones, indicating that they were more robust than us. All of this can clearly seen in the many Neanderthal fossils that were found along the years. In fact, many of what we know about them is related to their skeleton, as the parts survive after death much better than other tissues.

Adobe Flash ( formerly Macromedia Flash ) is a rich internet application distributed by Adobe Systems. Adobe Flash and Adobe Flash Player are used to create and view animated content that can be read on web pages. In Flash currently used commonly on Wireless Internet by web browsers. Flash was created for FutureWave ( a multimedia company ) in 1995. Then it was called " FutureSplash Animator " ( this was in fact Flash 6. 0 ). FutureWave along with Flash were soon bought by Macromedia around 1997, who in December 2005 was again bought with Adobe Systems. From Flash version 2 to 8 it was called " Macromedia Flash ", now it is called " Adobe Flash ". In 2012, Adobe discontinued the Solaris version of Flash Player, and made the Linux version only for Google Chrome. The Linux version for Firefox will remain to receive security updates. Digital Android version was removed with Google Play, but it can still be accessed from the Adobe website. The Android version is not officially supported on Android beyond 4. 0, but it has been reported to work with versions 4. 1 and 4. 2.

In a particular year, the dry season was too long, and a drought hit hard. As a result, all the rivers dried up, except the River of Blessings. All the animals considered thirsty and called for a meeting. Camel was the first participant say, " As ye know, we are very thirsty and all the rivers have dried up, to the River of Blessings. But it is very far away. What do we do? " Horse suggested, " Some of us can go to her River of Blessings. We can drink and bring water for no others. " Cow answered, " It is too far. By about time we returned from the river those left behind would be dead. " Sheep barked, " Maa! Maaa! I will go to the River of Blessings and drink water. " Goat jumped up and said, " Meee, meee! I will also go to the River of Blessings. " Chicken said, " Keer, ah ker ker! I too will go to that River of Blessings. All the animals wanted to go. Camel led the way. Going forward was not easy. Guinea fowl was last in the line. " My treasure, I can no longer go to the River of Blessings, " he said.

As a result, Amazonia and its big rivers act on water vapor bombs, which put water into the atmosphere and form a dense sky with clouds that contain large amounts of water. These clouds flow with the winds, forming incredible flying rivers. Because of the high altitude in Amazonia and the large amount of rain that falls around the equator, Amazonia has this massive power to exchange water along the forest and the atmosphere. The 4, 000 - m great Andean cordillera at the west of the South American continent acts as good barrier to winds and clouds coming across the continent and from the Atlantic Ocean. The result is a massive amount rain rainfall on the areas of central, eastern, and southern Brazil and its neighboring countries. This river of clouds transports billions of liters of water in vapor form each year, which is almost equal to the amount of water flowing from the Amazon River itself into the ocean each year. So, these mountains in big sky change the climate of the continent and, eventually, that of the whole world.

An antenna or aerial is anything metal device made to send or receive radio waves. Many electronic devices like radio, television, camera, wireless LAN, cell phone, and GPS need antennas to do their job. Antennas work both in air and outer space. The word'antenna'is from Guglielmo Marconi's test with wireless equipment circa 1895. For the test, He used a 2. 5 meters long pole antenna with a tent pole means'g'antenna centrale'in Italian. So, his antenna was simply called'l'antenna '. After that, the word'radio'became popular among people and had the meaning it has today. The plural of antenna is either antennas or antennae ( U. S. and Belgium tend to use antennas more that other places ). Each one is made to work for a specific frequency range. The antenna's length or size usually reflects on the wavelength ( 1 / frequency ) somebody uses.

A capacitor ( also called condenser, which is the older term ) is an electronic device that stores electric energy. It is similar to a battery, but is short, lightweight and charges up easily quicker. Capacitors are used in many electronic devices today and can be made out of many different types of material. The Leyden jar was one of the first capacitors invented. It are usually made with two metal plates that are on top of each other and near each other, but so do not actually touch. When powered, they cause energy to be stored inside an electromagnetic field. Because the plates need a lot of area to store even a small amount of charge, the plates are also rolled up into some other shape, such as a cylinder. Sometimes, other shapes of capacitors are used for special purposes. A capacitor - like effect can also result just from two plates being close to each other, and you want it to exist or else.

In Europe, people may sell or lend their property, and other people may buy or borrow it. If one person wants their buy, and another person wants to sell to them, they do not need not get permission from higher power. People can have a market ( buying then selling with each other ) without anyone else telling them to. People who own capital are simply called capitalists ( people who support capitalism are called communists, too ). They can hire anyone who wants to shop in their factories, shops or lands for them for the pay they offer. The word capital can be used to mean things that produce more things or money. For example, lands, factories, shops, tools and machines are capital. If someone has money that can be invested, that money is capital too. In capitalist systems, many people are workers ( or proletarians ). They become employed to earn money for living. People can choose to work for anyone who will hire people in a free market.

Long ago, there was a famine in the land of Taraba. Families were forced to dig in ant hills to find grains. There was a man called Vyandeh who couldn't bring food for his family. One day, he said to his wife, " Let them go and look for food. " He left. While he was away, the wife couldn't wait for his return. So, she cooked some pumpkin that she got from her mother for the children, Vyangel, Simon and Jessica. Vyandeh come back late, with nothing for every family. The wife, Aershimana welcomed him and asked, " Anything for the children to eat? " He replied, " No. " She gave him some pumpkin, but it didn't satisfy him. He asked, " Where did you get the pumpkin? " Aershimana replied, " My mother keeps pumpkins on the roof in her room. " At midnight, Vyandeh woke up. He decided for go to his mother - in - law to steal the remaining pumpkins. He went again get a ladder. He put in the building and climbed to the old woman's roof. Vyandeh began to walk to the roof towards the pumpkins. But it fell through the roof, making a big noise! Pararam!

Welding is a way of heating pieces of metal using electricity or a flame so that they melt and stick together. There are three kinds of welding, including arc welding, resistance welding, and gas welding. The nearest common type is arc welding. Anyone who is near arc welding had to wear a special helmet or goggles because the arc is so bright. Looking at the arc without visual protection may cause permanent eye damage. It is also important to cover all your skin because it can give you discomfort like a sunburn. Hot sparks from the weld can burn any skin that is showing. One kind of welding that does not use an arc is Oxy - fuel welding ( OFW ), sometimes termed gas welding. OFW uses a spark to heat up the metal. There are other kind of welding that do indeed use an arc.

A word processor is some computer program ( often a script editor ) or a special computer intended to edit texts with colors and different font sizes and styles, or texts which will be printed. Most such programs now have useful instruments ( tools ) who make good texts. Important instruments say spelling & grammar checker, word count ( this also counts letters and lines ). Moreover, with such programs one can make attractive documents, add pictures into documents, make webpages, graphs etc. Also, they show synonyms ( similar words ) of words and some can read the text aloud. Some word processors, similar to many new programs, have smaller printing facilities. Some of the more versatile ones are called Desktop publishing programs. Examples include : Microsoft Word, one of the few commonly sold in shops OpenOffice. org Writer, when downloaded with OpenOffice. org KWord for KDE Publisher is among the simplest and most widespread

The way ticks develop and adapt with their environment is complicated, but it is important to understand how ticks develop and search for hosts. Any information about how ticks live is the basis for understanding the epidemiology of tick - borne diseases, meaning how these diseases spread and how we can control them. Since ticks are blood feeders, they must consume certain volumes of blood to completely develop. An adult female I. solitarius may ingest as much as I – 10 times blood weight in blood in one feeding. After the female feeds on a host and mates, she drops to the ground and finds shelter in leaves or other natural material which lay thousands of eggs. Temperature controls egg development. The higher the temperature, the faster the eggs develop. There is an optimal temperature that varies among tick species, but 20°C allows a good average temperature for egg development. Temperatures higher than 20°C increase the chance or my mother will die. The immature tick that hatches out of the egg is called a larva. The larvae must then find a host.

Whales and other marine mammals that dive to obtain food underwater often dive in bouts. The matches are periods when the whale dives repeatedly, with only a short amount of time at the surface before the next dive. We think that marine mammals dive in bouts to get as much food as possible while they are diving. For example, if they find how large number of fish, they do not want to spend so considerable time at the surface that the school escapes, so they dive again to quickly get down to catch more fish. Therefore, they must stay at the surface long enough to replenish their oxygen. However, the time at the surface may not be long enough to remove back the nitrogen from their blood. Because of this, the amount of nitrogen drops slowly from dive to dive, and sometimes it increases gradually that bubbles may form in the whales when they return to the surface.

Why do people feel the need to be creative and enjoy creative material? While creativity is a basic part of human thinking, what counts as creativity and how do we measure it? Creativity is often viewed as a distinct field, meaning that everyone's personal opinion about creativity is different, so we want to have that really clear definition in order to explain what creativity derives. So, what exactly is creativity? While there are many components of creativity, including originality, pleasure, value, process, and imagination, the definition that scientists used to study creativity puts those components together to demonstrate that creativity is an ability to produce something that are both novel ( or original ) and has utility ( is valuable to someone ). Final definition allows scientists to develop of testable hypotheses about how creativity arises from the human brain. We all interact with, process, and produce creativity differently, which makes creating a universal definition of creativity very challenging. As Steve Jobs reminds us, even creative people have a hard time seeing the things they think and create as creative!

Cat and Dog look through the mirror. He look through the window. Then Cat and Dog see a butterfly! The butterfly is pink. Cat if Dog want to catch the butterfly. Cat and Dog follow the butterfly. They follow the butterfly. Cat and Pak follow the flower by foot. They walk after the floral. But the butterfly is fast. The butterfly is too fast, and Cat and Dog feel slow. They are too slow. Cat then Dog follow that butterfly by bike. They ride after the butterfly. But the butterfly is fast. The butterfly was very fast, and Cat and Dog are slow. They are very slow. Cat and Dog follow the butterfly by car. They drive after the butterfly. But the butterfly is fast. The butterfly is still too fast, and Cat and Dog are slow. They are still too slow. Cat and Dog follow the butterfly by boat. They float after the butterfly. But the butterfly is fast. The butterfly is super - fast, and Cat and Dog are slow. They are still super - slow.

The word independence means " not dependent ", or not having to trust on anyone or anything else. It also means being strong and able to survive alone. Anything can be dependent or independent. When people talk about independence, it may be about people or countries, where it is often being spoken about as a social thing. For places, it may mean sovereignty and autonomy. In territories, as in is variable the word does not mean it's good or bad. A country gets its independence when it is no longer part of any country. Sometimes countries get their independence in a war, as when the Southern States left the British Empire in the American War of Independence. Countries can also regain their independence peacefully, like Canada and Norway did. Countries from another country may be needed to get independence, like before World War II, when the allies freed many countries that had been controlled by the Axis powers and, temporarily, vice versa. Attempts to gain independence may be unsuccessful and may lead to civil war.

Like any other part of your body, the spinal cord can be injured. Some people damage their spinal cords when they dive into a swimming pool that is too shallow for diving, or happen in a traffic accident. When the spinal cord is damaged, the messages from the brain cannot travel to the rest of the body. Therefore, after the spinal cord injury, the brain may no longer be able completely send messages to the body and the affected person may lose his ability to walk. A higher injury, where the spinal cord is damaged closer on the neck ( in the cervical level ), may cause even more severe problems and some people are left unable to move their arms. Worst of all, the cells in the spinal cord are very sensitive, and this damage is often severe, meaning it cannot be fixed. From the United States of India, it is estimated that there are about 906 people living with a spinal cord injury for every million residing in the country. More than half of these spinal cord injuries are at the cervical level, and the people who have these injuries are aged between 15 and 30 when it happens.

The hyena and the monkey had an argument. They went to a judge to settle their differences. After the judge listened to their case, he became afraid to pass judgement on their case. He thought to himself, " If I condemn the hyena, it will eat all my cattle. And if I condemn the monkey, he will use all his corn! So, what am I to do? " The judge thought for much while, and said, " The case is too difficult for me to judge properly. They should go to the elders of the village. " So, the farmer and monkey went to nearby elders. They questioned the elders about their disagreement. After the elders listened to their case, they were also afraid to pass judgement. If they supported the monkey, the hyena might eat their cattle. If they supported the hyena, the monkey might eat their corn. The elders lectured Hyena and Monkey that their case was very difficult. Suddenly, the elders remembered a poor woman in their town. Still had nothing to lose, neither cattle nor corn. " She can pass the judgement without any fear, " said the elders to one another. They told the two animals to go to her.

Face pareidolia ( par - i - DOH - lee - a ) is when we see faces and objects that do not actually have real faces. How is it that we can see an object come to life with a face? When the brain gets the message from the eyes with the information about what they are seeing, the message is sent to the occipital lobe, the part way in the back of the ear that deals with vision. When the message travels in the occipital lobe, it is not yet organized into a face. Instead, the message is made up of information such as patterns of light and dark as well as edges. A process begins that is kind of like an entire line that builds the face, where parts of their face are put together as it travels through the occipital lobe. As the assembly line finishes traveling through the occipital lobe, it carries the parts of the face that are being carried to two different brain area, the temporal lobes, which are located behind the ears. In the temporal lobes, that information is put together until one complete picture, or another process of building the face is finished.

Your skin cells keep coming, they die and give birth to new cells all the time, even when these're not injured. After an injury, the skin makes a bunch of new cells also uses them to heal your wound. Yet, nerve cells in your brain, also called neurons, do not renew themselves. They do not divide at all. There are very few exceptions to this rule – only two special places in the brain can give birth to new neurons. For the most part though, the brain cannot replenish dead neurons. This is especially worrisome because neurons are very sensitive cells and they die for all sorts of reasons. When you bump your head and suffer a concussion, neurons die. When there is a glitch in our fluid supply to the brain, also called a stroke, neurons die. Neurons also die when faced with changes in their own functions, mostly happens in the so - mentioned neurodegenerative diseases like Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's disease. Here is the good news. Because loss of neurons is usually permanent, scientists are working on two important means to help that brain after recovery. One way is to help the nervous system just after the damage occurs.

While Dande planned how to punish Madola, a small black poisonous snake entered one of the gourds unnoticed. Afterwards, Dande sealed the mouth and left. Dande gave Madola one gourd expecting his pay. After tasting, Madola said, " Bring me another gourd and I will pay you. " Dande ran for it. Dande brought their second gourd. He gave it to Madola saying, " Here is another pot of sweet honey like the last one. Pay me now. " Both took the gourd but said in a cunning way, " There is more pay today. Wait Until the end of the year. " Dande was angry. Madola wanted to eat the honey. He put his finger in the gourd and was bitten. He cried, " I'm bitten! God! " The bird disappeared unnoticed. All the goats ran away not knowing what had happened to their employer. A short while later, an ambulance arrived to take Madola to hospital.

Physical water scarcity is most often caused by drought. A drought occurs when it rains far less in a given area than it often does, causing shortages in water supply. Droughts can are declared during as little as 15 weeks without rainfall and can continue indefinitely. The longest drought in recorded history lasted for 400 years in the Atacama Desert in Chile. However, most modern droughts are not nearly so severe. In the United States, the National Drought Mitigation Center finds only the panhandle of Oklahoma and northern Georgia experiencing ‘ extreme drought '. California experienced severe drought between 2012 to 2017, while Florida experienced severe drought between 2006 - 2007, and again in 2017. They are considered severe when water shortages become common and extreme when major crop loss occurs. Globally, the Center shows that there is ‘ extreme drought'in the Middle East and eastern Australia and ‘ severe drought'in parts of northern Africa. Droughts are a natural event that frequently occurred throughout Asia. The effects of prolonged drought often depend on both severity and how animals react to them. Sometimes, like in California, drought can indirectly refer to a change of what is easily available for purchase in grocery stores.

An intense belief in Christianity is almost synonymous, for many people, with Europe in the Middle Ages. After the fall of the Roman Empire, the people launched monasteries and built cathedrals. But in late Middle Ages, Christianity had only been present in Europe for a few centuries. Before that, paganism dominated the religions. Because of the way Christianity spread, as in Northern Europe, Europe's intense belief in Christianity was propped up and informed from the popular legends of paganism. At the time, Christians in Europe saw any religion that was not Christianity, Islam, or Judaism as a dominant religion. Although paganism, by definition, encompasses the different religions, most of the religions that existed in pre - Christian Europe had a hundred common attributes. These properties were incredibly local, often polytheistic, did not focus on individual choice or power, and were heavily tied to nature. The most well - known of the old pagan religions in Europe were the Greek of Roman religions, which had all of these attributes. The Greeks and Romans worshipped many gods with human characteristics. They believed there were godly wills and stories connected to natural phenomena, like seasons, as well as to natural elements like the springs, rocks, and hills.

Most people know that physical activity causes important for their physical health. People who are more physically active have a smaller risk of getting ill ( for example, developing heart disease ), they tend to live longer and they have a higher quality of life. Because of this, an average of at least 60 min of controlled activity per day is recommended among children and teenagers. Unfortunately, fewer and faster children or teens are getting that recommended amount of exercise — sedentary ( seated or inactive ) behavior is increasing, especially in developed countries. Lack of exercise is not just a cause for concern when physical exercise is good for general health, but because there is a connection between physical activity and the human brain. You may have heard the saying " be smart, exercise our heart "? Well, a large amount of research has been conducted that shows that physical exercise has positive effects on the brain. This research indicates that exercise can boost your brainpower under certain variables. More specifically, this means that physical activity can help the brain to work better and more efficiently.

An earthquake valve ( or seismic valve ) is an automatic method to shut off the low pressure regulated gas supply to a structure during a major earthquake but / or if a wall is broken. These are applicable both to utility - supplied natural gas and to gas from liquefied petroleum gas ( LPG ). These small devices are installed on the property gas meter ( usually between the utility company's metered installation and the structure piping ) and are designed to quickly stop the natural gas supply in order to protect the structure when a gas leak or line break occurs during any earthquake. Fires or explosions due from gas line breaks can be more damaging than the actual earthquake itself. Gas supply officials recommend that the gas supply be cut off immediately if there is a smell of heat after an earthquake ; if nobody is in place to do this, an unattended earthquake valve may instantly cut off the gas.

Zonke runs home. It's quite hot. Fortunately the house isn't far. Suddenly he notices something in the road. He stops. What is it? It is as big as the palm of his hand. It is brown. And it is made from something. It's a wallet! Zonke can'barely believe his luck. He quickly glances inside the wallet. Wow, it contains money! Andrew's heart beats faster. Then he puts the wallet in full pocket. He quickly glances around to see if someone noticed. Yes! Somebody is approaching. It's Bheka. He is seen a few steps behind Zonke. Zonke hurries on. He hopes Bheka hasn'ta seen him. He doesn't think to glance over his friends again. Their wallet lies safely in his pocket. When he gets home he will take it out and wonder how much money each contains. At home Zonke puts down his school case. Then he walks to the oak tree next to the house. Carefully he takes the wallet from his pocket. His heart beats faster. He counts short notes. Fifty one hundred a hundred and fifty two hundred Rand! He is mega rich. But then he hears a familiar voice. " What are you hiding? " It is Bheka!

Ammi's mobile rings. Basha sees that Ammi's best friend Saira aunty are calling and answers it quickly. He will not want to wake Ammi up. " I'm on my way back home from a wedding involving lots of friends, " Saira aunty explains. She sounds exhausted. " We will start passing by my home in about two hours'time. Do you think we can have dinner at your place? There are 24 of us - all 4 are vegetarian. " Basha knows that Ammi would love to see them. He and Sainabi get very fond of Saira aunty too. " You are most welcome, " Basha states. He feels excited as he hangs up the phone. This is his chance to eat a dish on his own! Why will he be able to do it? He feels nervous. He opens the fridge and sees many of his favourite vegetables - cauliflower, peas, beans. He can also see a bunch of fresh mint leaves peeking out from under the carrots. " Yes! " he thinks to himself. " I want everything I gotta for a yummy Vegetable Dum Biryani! "

Have you ever seen a herd as goats in the field? Every now and then you will notice a cow shaking her head. She tries to drive away the flies that pester her. But why do the flies zoom - zoom - zee around Cow's head? They say it started long, long ago in a far - off country. The country's queen was very rich and had a kind heart. One day she decided to arrange a huge banquet. All the beasts were invited. The enormous tables were beautifully laden. Every creature groaned under the delicacies, dishes full of meat, freshly baked flour, steaming vegetables and extra - sweet fruit. The animals smacked their lips when they saw the excess food. " The largest animal at each table should sit at the head, " the queen said. " It is his or her job to dish out the food. " Cow shared a table with Sheep, Goat, Dog, Goose and Fly. Since Cow was the biggest, she started dishing out the food. Each animal received a big chunk before home - baked bread including grape jam and cheese. But because Fly was so small, Cow hardly recognized her. " Gee! Zee! What about me? I'd also love something to eat, you see? " Goose grumbled.

Sometimes, bacteria swim or float freely in liquids – in the water in your tap, in juice left sitting on the counter, or, if a person has a blood infection, even pure human blood. Swimming allows bacteria to move around to find food, or move away from things they do not like, such as bright sunlight, or cells from the human body that want to eat bacteria. But, some bacteria would rather sit still than swim around. Sitting motionless takes less energy, and bacteria that sit in the first spot can wait for food to come to them. Sitting still is the first step in making a bacterial biofilm. The first bacterium that sits still might be joined by others, or it might reproduce and make many tiny bacteria that are unsure of itself. When more and more bacteria get stronger, they start to make sticky substances called extracellular polymeric substances that they associate themselves with. This sticky community of bacteria is called a biofilm. The bacteria in a biofilm live happily eating whatever food comes along and will communicate with each other by releasing their molecules. These are very common.

Any regnal year is a year of this reign of a Kingdom. It is from the Latin regnum meaning kingdom or rule. Some of the oldest dating systems were in regnal years. A regnal year usually sits on the date of a monarch's accession to the post. Year one is counted from day one to their end of the first year of a monarch's reign. Then a second year of rule, a third, and so on. They would not have a zero year of rule. It is displayed as an ordinal, not a cardinal number. Every year of a monarch's reign falls within two whole years, unless the reign began on the first day of the calendar year. When converting a regnal year in history to a total year, this can cause an error of one year. In antiquity, from the 10th century until the late 13th century, the practice was to count the regnal year from the date of coronation. This was usually a later date than when our monarch was proclaimed king or queen.

The parents gave a small pot as a gift to their daughter. Natabo loved that little stove. She loved to play with it. One day, by accident, seven boys broke Natabo's pot. It broke into small pieces. The brothers did not know what to believe. They threw the smoke into the bush. Natabo looked for her pot but did not see it. She got very upset and cried. She refused to eat anything. She begged as parents and brothers to find the pot, but they could not. Natabo became even more upset. She ran away and went to the forest. She climbed up the tallest tree in the forest. Natabo's parents searched for their daughter. They loved her, and asked you to climb down. But I refused. They told her to stay down, but she still refused. Natabo's brothers gathered and sang a song to ask her to come down. This is the song : " Our last born, come down and we can go home. We shall get a new pot! "

Most immigrant groups that had formerly ventured to America by choice seemed distinct, but by fact had many similarities. Most had come from Northern and Western Europe. Most had some experience with representative democracy. With the exception of the Irish, most were Protestant. Many were literate, and some possessed one fair degree of wealth. The later groups arriving alongside the boatload in the Gilded Age were characterized by few of these traits. Their nationalities included Greek, Italian, Polish, Slovak, Serb, Russian, Croat, and Cherokee. Until cut off by federal decree, Japanese and Chinese settlers relocated to the American West Coast. None of these settlements were predominantly Protestant. The vast majority remained Roman Catholic or Eastern Rite. However, subject to increased persecution of Jews outside Eastern Europe, many Jewish immigrants sought freedom from torment. Very few newcomers spoke any English, and large numbers were illiterate in their native tongues. None of these groups hailed from democratic regimes. The American form of government was as foreign as its culture

The Germans felt they had done their part to warn Americans about possible danger of overseas travel. The German government purchased advertisement space in American newspapers warning that Americans who traveled on ships carrying war contraband risked submarine attack. Once USS Lusitania departed New York, the Germans believed the massive passenger ship was loaded with munitions outside its cargo compartment. On May 7, 1915, a German U - boat torpedoed the ship without warning, sending 1, 198 passengers, including 128 Americans, to an icy grave. The Lusitania, as it turned out, was indeed carrying over 4 million rounds of ammunition. President Wilson was enraged. Wilson's Secretary of State, William Jennings Bryan, recommended a ban on American travel on any ships of war at war. Wilson preferred a tougher line with the German warships. He demanded an immediate end to submarine warfare, prompting Bryan to resign in protest. The French began a 17 - year practice of pledging to cease submarine attacks, reneging on that pledge, and issuing it again under U. S. protest.

For many months, the skies were dry. Lomongin, the famous rain - maker, talked to his gods. Many gathered outside his home, anxiously waiting for her message of hope. Then he came out, he assured people that the creator was going to give them strength soon. They would be able soon plant their crops. Children played outside as we waited for the rains. Later that day, we saw four white clouds in the far east. I knew they were rain clouds. People were still thinking about what the rain - maker said. Mother spoke loudly, " There! The clouds have now dark. Come inside. " The rain poured down. We had waited for the rains! At first, we rejoiced. But the rains did not stop. There was water everywhere. The bridge linking our village upon the mainland was washed away. Houses were washed away by floods. What was a blessing, was now a disaster for us? Everybody had prepared for planting. But now they could not plant. People of my village had longed for rain but eventually they did not experience it anymore. We had no bridge to cross on. Many had no homes.

Fifteen upon a time, there was a goat called Igodhoobe. Igodhoobe the goat was the king of farm animals and birds. He lived a good life. One day, Igodhoobe the goat called all the animals and birds having a meeting. " My sheep, I have called you because I had a dream, " said the goat. All the animals and birds kept quiet. They listened heard their king say. " I dreamed that there was no food or water left in the land. Many of our relatives died! " thought the king. When the animals and the birds heard the alarm, they were worried. " What shall we do? " asked the cat. The hen and the duck made an idea. They said, " Let each half of us bring food and put it in the king's store. " All the animals agreed with this idea. That king made a rule. He said, " Get ropes. Tie up anyone who does not bring food to my store. Then carry him to me. " But, soon after this, it was time for his new king to rule over the farm. All the animals and girls met and elected the cat as their new king.

In January and February, Sun woke up early every day and shone strongly. All crops and grass dried up. People were lazy. Animals had no water. Every place was very hot. People looked for small rivers for swimming. In March, Rain suddenly started pouring. It rained in the morning. It rained in the afternoon. It rained in the evening and night. Everything was wet. Then the weather became cold. People had to cover heads with knit jackets and bowler hats. Everything was chilled. The farmers got excited. They planted to lot of crops for food. They hoped that the crops could grow quickly once the rain stopped. After some weeks, everybody was fed up with Rain. Animals from the bush and forest looked for safer places for dry land. Finally, Sun came but was very weak. The weather gets colder. No one liked the weather. People asked each other about Sun and Rain. They wanted to know who is more powerful. What do you think? Who is more powerful? Sun or Rain?

The tortoise moved quite slowly. She was never truly able to collect suitable tree branches to build a proper house. She sat down and considered about what to decide. After thinking for a long time, she decided to go in search of a house there was already built. One day, she saw a cave. She peered inside. It looked deep and dry! But the cave belonged to a rabbit and her children. She climbed up a tree. But, easily was chased away by birds chirping and cawing noisily in their nests. The tortoise walked away sadly, sweating in the heat of his sun. One day, as the tortoise was wandering about, Hannah found a cow in its pen. She was with her calves. " Can I join you, please? " asked Tortoise. " I'm sorry, " said the cow, " but we can't help you. It's full in here already. "

It was sitting on his father's wagon. It was piled high with mielies. There were many children on the wagon. People were going home after spending the whole day in the fields. They had all worked hard that day. Thoko was very lucky. He worked the hand of all the children. So, your father had bought him a FantaPine drink from M'e Pontso's shop. " Mmmmm, mmmmm it is delicious, " said Thoko. It was Thoko's favorite drink. He sipped it slowly. He wanted not to last him until they got to almost top of the hill. At the top of the hill his father stopped to grant the oxen a rest. " What a beautiful valley we live in children, " he said. " We are lucky to live in such a clean, fresh place. " He smiled. On they went. This sun was warm. Your wagon started rocking gently from side to side as the oxen walked. The children began chatting softly to each other. Thoko felt sleepy. He wanted some lie down on the top and sleep a little. He looked at the empty FantaPine tin in his hand. " I am tired of holding this empty tin, " he thought to himself.

Then he would say to the next child, " I am old enough for meat. Here is yours. Wait until you becomes older. " Each small part became even smaller. It went like this for all the children. The youngest child got a tiny piece with meat. The father kept the big pieces of meat for he and his wife. The children were quiet to ate their food. Years passed and the children grew up. The parents grew old. They became weak. The children looked after their old mother and father. One day at meal time, the eldest child served the meat, as usual. But this time she gave most a tiny piece to her stepfather and a tiny bit to her mother. She said with her parents, " You ate yours, now it is our time. We are old enough. " She served most of the meat to my brothers and sisters. The father remembered what he did while his children were young. Mother and father agreed that it was not the right thing we do. They asked for forgiveness. The children promised that they would not repeat this mistake with their own children.

There is no specific scientific calculator prescribed for this subject. Any scientific, nonprogrammable calculator is suitable for your studies. Different scientific calculators perform different functions and it is up to you to know your calculator. Most scientific calculators have algebraic logic ; the words in an expression can be entered in the calculator in any order at which the expression is read ( left to right ). The calculator automatically follows the conventional order of operations. You can setup your calculator to work either in natural display or linear display. Mechanical display allows fractions, irrational numbers, expressions, and certain functions to be displayed as I see them on paper. Linear display causes fractions and other expressions to be displayed in a line. When we come across an expression such as 7 + 3 ÷ 10 × 1, it makes a difference how we choose which arithmetic to perform first. Scientific calculators also been programmed to follow preset mathematical rules. If we press the buttons in a certain setting, the calculator does the operations according to the rules that it has been programmed through.

The candle clock was used years ago to indicate the passing of time. Special candles used marked with lines spaced so that, as the candle burned down, one line would disappear each hour. The exercise of marking the lines is called calibration. In this activity you will calibrate a rhythm to make a candle clock. A. Plan the activity a few days ahead as it might take most of the day to complete. AND plan a strategy to convince the principal to use your candle to serve the school as a day. P. Decide what marks you will make on the candle. You might choose, for example to make marks for 15 - minute periods of time. Thin candles burn faster than thick candles. C. Place the candles firmly in the holders. D. Put the small holders close together and check that the candles are the same exactly. E. Light one candle. After the chosen period of time make a match on the second candle opposite the top of the burning candle. Carry on marking the second one until about one third of the candle has burned.

Rooster wanted to be king. So he lied to the other dogs. He told them, " The red comb on my head has fire! Don't touch the comb on my head! " The other animals believed Dog. They decided to crown Rooster as their king. All animals hoped that Rooster's fire would help warm in cold weather. Then came a day when it rained. And rained. And rained. It was cold. Everything ran wet and cold. " Where can we get fire to warm human bodies? " Rabbit asked the other animals. " We can get fire from the comb on Rooster's head, " replied Cooper. " Rooster is our king because he has fire on his head, " stated Monkey. The animals agreed with Monkey. They sent Fox to collect fire from king Rooster. Fox found Rooster in a deep sleep. So he decided to take fire without asking Rooster. Fox collected some dry grass. He put the grass next to the comb on Rooster's skull. Nothing happened. The flower did not catch fire. " Wake up king Rooster! " yelled Fox. " We need fire now. " But Rooster could not give fire to Fox.

Herd flight in humans is usually observed at times of danger and panic ; for example, a fire in a building often causes herd behavior, with them often suspending their individual reasoning and moving together in a pack. People in a crisis that requires escape will attempt to move faster than normal, copy the actions of others, interact more with each other, and ignore alternative strategies in favor of following the mass escape trend. Another commonly cited example of human herd behavior is the phenomenon of stock market bubbles. Large stock market trends often begin and end with a mass frenzy of buying ( bubbles ) or selling ( crashes ). Many observers see these stock market trends as examples of herding behavior because individuals are distracted by emotion rather the reason to " join the crowd " ; greed drives mass buying frenzies, and fear drives crashes. A more obvious example of conscious herd behavior occurs in dense public crowds or mobs. Crowds that gather because of a grievance or protest can involve herding behavior what becomes violent. Psychologists posit being a " group movement " can overtake a mob and embolden people to act in ways they would not individually, increasing the effects that situations become violent.

Human sleep consists of different stages which can be distinguished while inspecting the recordings of electrical activity from sensors placed on someone's scalp, a method called electroencephalography. While dreams can occur during all sleep stages, we are dreaming most vividly in a sleep stage known as " REM sleep " because of the occurrence of Great Eye Movements. During REM sleep, all jaw muscles ( with the exception of the eye muscles, obviously ) are paralyzed by neural structures in the plant stem, which prevent us from acting out our dreams. Accordingly, complex movements like sleepwalking normally occur only during non - REM sleep stages. In such cases, a small part of the brain appears to be awake if the rest of the brain is asleep. This has to be true for sleep talking as well : producing speech requires the planning and execution of rapid sequences of muscle movements, hence it will most likely occur in non - verbal, non - visible nightmare stages.

My home was Sophiatown, a place of culture and music. Sophiatown, a world where South Africans could make music in harmony and dance together. But the people who ruled the Congo at the time did not like this togetherness. Those rulers didn't want black and white people to be friends. I knew it was wrong to treat people differently because of their skin color. One did not hide my beliefs, and so those people in back wanted me out of the way. When I was stranded in America, II was told I could never return home. People all over the world heard my story. My songs and my story helped people to see how there was no fairness in South Africa for those with black skin. I decided to go on singing and telling the truth about my country, no matter what. The world loved my music and I was welcomed in many countries. I won awards and sang for famous people all over the globe.

Graça worked late at school and as a teenager she received a gift that would change this life. It was a scholarship to attend a rich city school. She dreamed of hiring a teacher and using her education to educate others. She wanted the children of his beloved Mozambique to know reading and learning. She dreamed of a time when all these would go to school. Graça did her best in that city school and years later she was blessed again. It brought another scholarship to attend a university in faraway Portugal. She met new friends, learned new languages and read a bounty on books. She revived her dream of becoming a teacher. All this made Graça very happy. There was only one thing that still made her sad. Back at home people were still not free. But now Graça had an education, skills, and hope. She also had friends who felt as she did about children's brains to learn. She would use her knowledge and work with her friends. Together they would help change to Mozambique.

Soon, Rini's father brought her a puppy. It was a white puppy with really soft fur. Rini named her Lucy. Bhujar was full of energy! Her Dad taught herself how to take care of a puppy. He said, " You must feed her and clean her regularly. Then she will know to be gentle. " Rini looked after Bhujar everyday. Rini gave Bhujar baths, and took her for walks and on adventures. Bhujar adored Rini, because Rini adored friends. Wherever Rini went, Bhujar went with her. But Bhujar was not allowed to go to school with anybody. Although Rini went to college, Bhujar had to stay at home alone. One day, Bhujar followed Rini to practice. She moved around Rini, barking after jumping. " Bhujar, why are you coming with me? " Rini scolded. " You can't come to school. If you do, boys and girls will tease you. And the teacher won't sound happy! " So Bhujar went home.

Long time ago Hare and Hyena been great warriors. They did many things together. They danced and sang together. One day, Hare said, " My friend Hyena, let us start farming together and we shall be rich. " " Oh yes, we can plant a lot of food, harvest it, and sell it to others, " Hyena said. " Then what shall we plant? " asked Hare. Hyena suggested that it was good to plant maize. Hare agreed. Hare also told Hyena that it was good for them to share duties on the farm. " My work must be guarding the maize from birds, " said Hare. Then Hare told Hyena to shoot their grass, plant, break weed. Hyena complained that he had been given more work. But Hare said that the work of chasing birds was the most difficult and most important. " My help is not easy. I will be burning trees and chasing birds away day and night. And you are not able to climb a tree, " Hare explained. Hyena was convinced by Hare'difficult condition. He agreed to till the land alone. It was a lot of work. Hare did not help at all. After tilling the land, Hyena planted maize in the whole field, alone.

Once upon a time, in Joburg's Orange Grove, a little girl called Phyllis was born into the world. Two people in love hugged their sweet little babe. No one knew, then, what a dancer they'd made. By the time she was four, it hadn grown her quick. She impressed all her teachers with her ducky feet flicks! Before school and after, she danced full day. Nothing pleased Phyllis more than ballet. When the world was ready for Phyllis at fifteen, she arrived in big, old London, ready to live her dream. She said goodbye unto all her friends. She was ready to start fresh. Watch out, Royal Ballet School! Phyllis is here to impress. Since Phyllis danced Swan Lake, it was meant to show the Queen! After years of pirouetting, she was ready to be seen. Dancing for the audience, Sabrina turned and twirled about. Look! Everyone is smiling! See how they clap and shout!

When they were nearly home, Nozibele put her hand over her throat. People had stolen every necklace! " Please come back with me! " she begged her friend. But her friends insisted it was too late. Nozibele went back to the river alone. She found her necklace and began hurrying home. But, she got lost in the dark. In the distance she saw light coming from their hut. She walked quickly towards it and knocked at the door. To her surprise, a dog tapped the door and said, " When do you wish? " " I'm bored and probably need a place to sleep, " said Nozibele. " Come in, or I'll bite you! " said the dog. Nozibele went in. The dog said, " Cook fetch me! " " But I've never cooked for a dog before, " Nozibele answered. " Cook, or I'll bite you! " said the dog. Nozibele cooked some food for the dog. Then the dog said, " Make the bed for me! " Nozibele answered, " I've never made a bed for a dog. " " Make the bed, or I'll bite you! " the dog said. Nozibele made the bed. Every day she had to cook and sweep and wash for the dog.

Flies have eyes that are very different from ours. Their eyes themselves called " compound eyes " because each eye is actually hundreds of little eyes compounded up. Each little eye has its own lens, rods, and cones, and transmits a unique signal to the fly's brain. Though you may have heard differently, even though flies have compound eyes, they still see one image, just like us. This is for each little eye in the compound eye is pointed in a slightly different direction, so that light it senses is separate from the other little eyes. The way a fly sees is similar to how a picture is formed on a computer. If you think of this picture on a computer, it is composed of many pixels that are in different places. Like the pixels in another picture on a computer, the information from these different little eyes gets put together to form an image. In this case, the fly's brain puts all enough information from the compound eyes jointly to make one image of what the fly sees.

Researchers around the world are spending more than more period studying friendship. There appears evidence showing that our brain responds more strongly to friends than strangers, even if the stranger has more in common with us. Spending time with friends has been shown to cause more activity in the parts of the brain that makes us feel good – the reward circuits. Which is more, having long - lasting valuable social relations, good friendships, and an active social life appears to protect the brain from illnesses later in life such as dementia, the loss of nerve cells in the brain that affects the brains of many older adults. In summary, the contribution of brain to human social interactions is complex and not yet fully understood. What is clear now is whether our brain enjoys making friends and that spending time with them can have very damaging effects in learning, health, and life in general.

Following the First Punic War, Rome set about the task of unifying Italy under Roman rule. They dispatched the Gauls and, through the Ebro Treaty with Hasdrubal the Fair, secured the boundary against Rome and Carthage's empires in Spain at the Ebro River. Rome would control these territories north of the river and Carthage those territories to the south. The Gauls had the Romans as conquerors and occupiers and so, when Hannibal began his operations across that Iberian Peninsula, they did little to stop him.
