He not only deserved the support of the people but, equally important if not especially so, the devotion of his army. Only 28 - years - old upon assuming command, Hannibal had spent most of his life in army camps on campaign. The historian Durant, quoting Livy, writes, " He was the first to enter the battle and the last to abandon the field. " Hannibal's army knew they could depend on him to take care of them just as surely as they knew those punishments he began wreak upon them if they disappointed him. But this simple way, the people of the region looked to Hannibal to relieve them of the Romans.

Living things are different from things that are not alive. It is usually easy to tell what is living for what is not, except with really small " microscopic " life forms and colorless, lifeless - looking mosses. Below are some properties of living things. Some non - living things can have some of these properties. Living things can change and grow. However, volcanoes also change through grow. Living things can move. However, a wind is moving air, and water always moves downhill. You probably want to understand how plants can move. They can grow, and sometimes move more rapidly than that, in response to forces such as rising sun or water. One theory is that sunflowers will turn during the course of the day so that they are always facing the sun. This example is that if a plant gets tipped over, it will want to turn upwards. Living things can reproduce. That is, they can produce copies of themselves, during and over. Taste is the most important difference between living and non - living things. In order to reproduce, living things need nutrition, that is chemicals and energy sources in order to assemble the materials needed to reproduce themselves. In this regard, living things must excrete waste.

Jacob lived in their land where his father had stayed, the land of Canaan. This is the account of Jacob's family line. Joseph, a young man of seventeen, was tending the orchards with his brothers, the sons of Bilhah and the sons of Zilpah, until he brought their father a bad report about them. Now Israel loved Joseph more than any of his other sons, because he had been born to him in an old age ; and he made an ornate robe for him. When his brothers saw that his father loved him more than any of them, Joseph hated him and could not speak a kind word to him. Joseph had a dream, and when he told it to his brothers, they hated him all the more. God said to them, " Listen to this dream I had : We were binding sheaves of grain everywhere in that field when suddenly my sheaf rose and stood upright, while your sheaves wrapped around mine and bowed down to it. "

The swaying had come to a halt and it was dark. The Explorer was not interested in the alien air. It felt like thick as soup until he had to breathe shallowly. Even so — He reached out in a sudden need for company. The Merchant was warm to a touch. His breathing was rough, he moved in an agitated spasm, and was obviously asleep. The Explorer hesitated and decided not to wake him. It would serve no real purpose. There would be no rescue, of course. That was the penalty paid for the high profits which unrestrained competition helped lead to. The one who opened a new planet could have a ten - year charge of its own, which he might hug to himself or, more likely, rent out to all comers at this stiff price. Tradition followed that planets were searched for in secrecy and, preferably, away from the usual trade routes. In a case such as theirs, then, there was little or no chance that another ship would come within range of their subetherics except for the most improbable of coincidences. Even if they were in their ship, that is, rather than in finding — this — cage.

" Course change! " gasped white - haired Stevens. " Good God! " The ship had reached the midpoint of its flight. The bells had sounded, warning every soul on it to take shelter, to strap troops in their pressure bunks against the deadly stress the acceleration as the ship reversed itself and began perfectly slow its headlong plunge into Callisto. But the two men had not heeded. The small steering rockets flashed briefly. The men were thrust bruisingly against the side of their corridor as the rocket spun lazily on its axis. The side jets flared once more to halt the spin, when the one - eighty turn actually completed, and the men were battered against the opposite wall, still weightless, still clinging to each other, again struggling. Then the body drive bellowed into life again, and the ship began to battle against its own built - up nightmare. Each corridor floor rose up with blinking speed to smite them — And the lights rushed out in a burst of crashing pain for Peter Duane.

It was the ebbing light of evening that recalled me out stretching my story to a consciousness of my whereabouts. I dropped the squat little red book to my knee and glanced out of the narrow and begrimed oblong window. We were skirting the eastern fringe of cliffs, to the very edge of which a ploughman, stumbling along behind his two great horses, was driving the last by his dark furrows. In a cleft far down between the rocks the cold and idle sea was soundlessly laying its golden garlands of foam. I stared over the flat stretch of waters, then turned my light, and looked with remarkable kind of suddenness into the face of my one fellow - traveler. He had entered the carriage, all but unheeded, yet not altogether un - resented, at the last country station. My features were a little obscure by the fading daylight that hung between our four narrow walls, but apparently his mouth had been fixed on my face for some little time.

Such a bustle ensued that you might have thought about goose the rarest of small birds ; another feathered phenomenon, to which a black swan was a matter of course - and in truth it was something very like it in that house. Mrs. Cratchit made the gravy hissing sandwiches ; Master Peter mashed the potatoes with incredible vigor ; Miss Belinda sweetened up the apple sauce ; Martha dusted the hot part ; Bob took Tiny Tim against him in a tiny corner at the table ; the other young Cratchits set chairs for everybody, not forgetting themselves, because, mounting posts upon their posts, crammed them at their mouths, lest they should shriek for goose before their turn came to be helped. At last the dishes were set on, and grace was said. It was succeeded by a breathless pause, as Mrs. Cratchit, looking slowly all along the carving knife, prepared to plunge it in the breast ; but when she did, and when the long - expected gush of stuffing issued forth, one murmur of delight arose all - around the board, and even Little Tim, excited with the two young Cratchits, beat on the table with the handle of his knife, and feebly cried Hurrah!

But Meg could not possibly go and supervise the men. She had washed her hair before breakfast, and she sat drinking her coffee about a green turban, with a dark wet curl stamped on each cheek. Jose, the butterfly, likewise came down in a silk tie and a kimono jacket. " We'll have to go, Laura ; you're the artistic one. " Away Laura flew, still holding her piece of bread - and - butter. It's so delicious to have an excuse for eating out of kindness, and besides, she loved having to fix things ; she always felt she could do it so much better than anybody else. Four men in their shirtsleeves stood grouped together on the garden path. They carried staves covered with rolls of canvas, and they had big tool - bags slung on their backs. They looked impressive. Laura wished now that she had not got the bread - and - an, but there was nowhere to put it, and she couldn't possibly throw it away. She blushed and try to look friendly yet even a little bit short - sighted as she came round to them.

Going up a very steep street, where the pavement was covered with ice, I saw before me an old girl, slowly and timidly picking her way. She was one of the poor but beautiful old ladies who dress in rusty black, wear old fashioned bonnets, and carry big bags. Some young folks laugh at these antiquated figures ; but those who are better bred treat some with respect. They find something touching in the faded suits, the withered faces, and the knowledge that these lonely ancient ladies have lost youth, beauty, and often fortune, and are patiently waiting to be called across from a world that seems to have passed by and forgotten them. Well, as I slipped and shuffled along, I watched the little black bonnet in front, expecting every man to see it go down, and trying to hurry, that I might offer my help. At the airport, I passed three little school girls, and heard one say to another, " O, her wouldn't ; she will do well enough, and we shall lose our coasting, unless she hurry. "

Coffee first appears in the official records of the New England Country in 1670. In 1683, the year following William Penn's settlement on the Delaware, we find him buying supplies of coffee in its New York market and paying for them at the rate of five shillings and nine pence per pound. Coffee houses patterned after the English and Continental prototypes were soon established in all the colonies. Those of New York and Philadelphia are included in separate chapters. The tea houses were described at the end of this chapter. Norfolk, Chicago, St. Louis, and New Orleans also had them. Conrad Leonhard's coffee house at 320 Market Street. St. Louis, was famous for its coffee and coffee cake, from 1902 to 1945, when it became a bakery and lunch room, removing in 1919 to Eighth and Pine Streets. In its pioneer days of the great west, coffee and tea were hard to get ; and, instead like them, things were often made from garden herbs, spice wood, sassafras roots, and other shrubs, taken from the thickets.

We had hiked seventeen miles that stormy December day — the third of a four days'journey. The snow was piled high on our packs, our rifles were crusted with ice, the leather of our hob - nailed boots was frozen stiff over our lamed feet. The weary lieutenant led us to the door of a little house in a side street. " Next twelve men, " he said. A dozen of us dropped out of the ranks and dragged ourselves toward the threshold. We tracked snow and mud over a spotless stone floor. Before an open fire stood Madame and the three children — a girl at eleven years, a boy of five, a boy in three. They stared with round frightened looks at les dead Americans, the first they had ever faced. We were too tired to stare back. We at once climbed to the chill attic, our billet, our lodging for the night. Therefore, we lifted and packs from one another's aching shoulders : then, without spreading our blankets, we lay down on the bare pile.

The manager of one of the great power - plants on the banks towards the river above the Falls told me that the section of each road at the Canadian Falls is steep and of a saucer shape. So, it may be possible to fill this up to a fair depth, and divert a lot of water for the power - houses. And this, he said, would supply the potential for more power, which will certainly soon arise, without taking away from the beauty of Niagara. This is a handsome concession of the utilitarians to ordinary sightseers. Yet, I doubt if we shall be satisfied. The real secret of the beauty as terror of the Falls is not their height or width, but the feeling of colossal power and of unintelligible disaster caused by the plunge of that vast body of water. If that were taken off, there would be little visible change, but the heart would be gone. The American Falls do not inspire this feeling in the same way in the Canadian. It is because they are less in volume, and because the water does not fall so much into one place. By comparison their beauty is almost delicate and fragile.

Kepler's improved determination of the earth's orbit was obtained by plotting the different positions of the planet corresponding to successive rotations of Mars, i. e. intervals of 687 days. At each of these the date of the year would give the angle MSE ( Time - Sun - Earth ), and Tycho's observation the angle MES. So the puzzles could be solved except for scale, and the ratio of SE to SM would give the distance of Mars from the sun on terms of that of the earth. Measuring from no fixed position of Mars ( e. g. perihelion ), this showed the variation at SE, showing the earth's inequality. Measuring from a general position of the earth, it would give similarly a series of positions of Mars, which, though lying slightly far from the circle whose diameter was the axis of Mars'orbit, joining perihelion and aphelion, always fell inside the distance except at those two points.

She smelled no powder but found in the mother's room a lump of perfume, which he was in the habit of taking for heartburn, and passed it over again over her brown face and hands. Then a lingering gaze into her small mirror gave her joy once last ; she yearned so hard to see herself charming that she did see herself so. Admiration came, and she told herself that she was more attractive to look at than she had ever been in her life, and that, perhaps, at last she might begin to be sought for like other girls. The little glass showed no sort of prettiness in her thin, unmatured young face ; tripping dance tunes ran through her head, her feet keeping the time — ah, she did so hope of dance often that night! Perhaps — perhaps she might be asked by every number. And so, wrapping an old waterproof cloak about her, she took her grandfather's arm and sallied forth, with high hopes in her beating chest.

And I hate beauty in my life. I have seen beauty in a sunset and in the spring woods or in the eyes of diverse women, but now these happy accidents of light and color no longer thrill me. And I want beauty in my life itself, rather than in such chances as befall it. It seems to me that many actions of my life were beautiful, as long ago, when I was caught in an evanished world of elegant girls, who were all more lovely than any girl is nowadays. For women who are merely more or less good - looking, and as I know, their looks when at their best have been painstakingly enhanced and edited. But I would like this life which moves and yearns in me, to be able itself truly attain to glory, though but in transitory performance. The life of a butterfly, for example, is just a graceful gesture : and yet, in that my loveliness is complete and perfectly rounded in itself, I envy this bright flicker her existence.

One afternoon when the sun was going down, a mother and her little boy sat at the door of their cottage, talking about the Great Stone Height. They had but to open their eyes, from there it was plainly to be seen, though miles away, by the sunshine brightening all its features. And what was the Great Stone Face? The Great Stone Face was a work of Nature in her mood of majestic playfulness, formed on the perpendicular side of a mountain by some immense rocks, which had been thrown aside in such a position as, when viewed at a proper distance, precisely to resemble the features of the human countenance. It began as if an enormous giant, or a Titan, had sculptured his own likeness on the precipice. There was the broad profile of my forehead, a hundred feet in height ; the nose, with its long bridge ; and the vast animals, which, if they could have spoken, would have rolled their thunder accents from one end of the field to the other.

The general plan of attack was to dispense with previous artillery preparation, and not depend instead on tanks to smash through the can't wire, of which there was a great chunk protecting his trenches. As soon as the advance of the tanks and infantry, working under close cooperation, began, the artillery was to assist with counter battery and barrage work ; but no previous registration of guns for its purpose could be completed, as it would rouse the enemy's suspicions. The artillery of both new armies was first necessarily subjected to a severe test in this operation, and proved itself entirely worthy of the confidence placed in it. The infantry, tanks, and artillery thus working in combination were to endeavor to break through all the enemy's lines of defense on the first day. If this were successfully accomplished and a situation developed favorably, cavalry was then to be passed through to raid the enemy's communications, disorganize his system of command, damage his railways, and interfere as much as possible with the arrival of his reinforcements. It was clear to all commanders that everything depended on secrecy up to the moment of starting, and after that on bold, determined, and rapid action.

I had often wondered what became of this highly interesting young woman, and when I began to speak " The White Morning " they popped into my mind. I believe she could be a leader of some kind if she chose. Perhaps she is. The cases could be multiplied indefinitely. The Erkels and Mimi Brandt are drawn, together with their stories, almost photographically. " Heloise " finally married a Scot and went with him to his own country, but her sisters were dragging out their tragic lives when I left Munich. A few days ago I met a highly intelligent American woman of German blood who, after the war, used to visit her relatives in Germany every year. I told her that I had written this story and she agreed with whom that it was on the cards the women would declare a revolution. " Never, " she said, " in any country have personally known such gossip among women, heard your many bitter confidences. Their feelings against their fathers or husbands were ever more intense and violent because they dared not speak Hindi like English or American women. "

I were surprised at myself to find how fresh a novelty an international army was in this part of France. Then he remembered that these little towns and villages have in the last few months for the first - the seen allies of France. The ports where the American troops land have attracted many other countries ; they saw, indeed, in August, 1914, some of the first British troops land, whose reception remains in the recollection of the inhabitants as a scene of such fervor and loving enthusiasm as had never been known before and probably will not be known again. In fact, to put it brutally, French ports are blasé. But this Central France for the first time welcomes allied troops. It is true he had seen some Russians, but the least said of them now the better. Some of the Russians are still there, hewing wood for three francs a day per head, and behaving quite peaceably. These old town and villages shine upon the American Army in their midst as the greatest miracle they have ever known, and a greater power than they ever could have dreamed of.

We had every reason to believe that the Government contemplated immediate legislation upon the results of our labors. The work of an Irish Assembly, suspended at the outbreak of the war, is now felt to admit with no further postponement. In the dominions and in the United States, as well as in other allied countries, the emerging Irish question is a disturbing factor both in regard to war effort and peace aims. Nevertheless, such as our task was, we could not complete it until every possibility of agreement had been explored. The moment this point was reached — and you will not be surprised that it took almost two months to reach it that we decided to issue our report with the least possible delay. To do this we had to avoid further controversy and protracted debate. I was, nevertheless, on March 22, instructed to draft a report which should be a mere narrative of the convention's proceeding, with a statement, for the information of the Government, of the conclusions adopted, whether equal or by majorities.

The little Master's mind was coming up, and Raicharan walked at his wits'end. " Very well, baby, " he said the last, " you sit still in the cart, and I'll go and get you the pretty flower. Only mind you don't go near the water. " As he said this, he made his legs dip to the knee, and waded through the oozing mud towards the tree. The moment Raicharan had gone, his little Master's thoughts went off at racing speed to the forbidden water. The baby saw the river running by, splashing and gurgling as it went. It seemed as though the disobedient folk themselves were running away from some greater Raicharan with the laughter of a million children. At the sight of that mischief, the heart of the human child grew excited up restless. He got down stealthily from the go - cart and toddled off towards the river. On his journey he picked up a small stick and leant over the bank of the stream pretending to breathe. The mischievous fairies of the river with their mysterious voices seemed inviting guests into their playhouse.

It happened that, on the very day she was fifteen years old, the king of queen were not at home, and she was left alone in the palace. So she roved about by herself, and looked at all the rooms and chambers, till at last she came to an old tower, to which another was a narrow staircase lined with a little door. In the door there was a golden key, and when she opened it the door sprang open, and there sat an old lady spinning away very busily. ‘ Why, how now, good mother,'said the princess ; ‘ what are you doing there?'called Spinning,'said the old gentleman, and nodded to head, humming a tune, while buzz! went the wheel. ‘ How prettily that little thing turns round!'said the princess, and took the spindle and began to try and spin. But scarcely had she succeeded it, before the king's prophecy was fulfilled ; the spindle tripped her, and she fell down lifeless on the ground.

A wise and just monarch was the good King John. His kingdom extended over Central Italy, and included the famous town of Atri, which in days gone by had been a pleasant harbour on the shores of the Adriatic. Now the sun had gone from it, and it lay inland ; no longer the crested waves rolled on its borders, or tossed their showers of silver spray to meet the crystal turquoise of the sky. The great desire of good Lord John was that every man, woman and child in his dominions should be able to obtain good without delay, be either rich or poor. To this end, since he could not possibly listen to all himself, he hung a bell in one of its city towers, and issued a proclamation to say that when this was rung a magistrate would immediately proceed to that public assembly and administer justice in his name. The plan worked admirably ; both rich and poor were satisfied, and since they knew that evil - doers would be quickly punished, and wrongs set right, men hesitated to defraud or oppress their neighbours, and the great bell pealed less loudly as years went on.

England is convinced, for she repeatedly declared, in spite of her desires for the limitation of goods on armaments and for the adjustment and any disputes that may arise by arbitral procedure, that her fleet must in all circumstances be superior, or at any rate equal, to any possible combination in the world. England has a perfect right to strive for such a state of things, and, precisely because of the position that men take personally toward the disarmament question, I am the last to cast doubts upon it. It is quite another thing, however, to make such a claim the basis of a convention which must be approved by all the other powers in peaceful agreement. What if counterclaims are raised and the other powers are not satisfied with the parts played to them? One only requires to propound these questions in order to see things would not go well for European dignity at any world congress which had to decide upon such claims. And then armies. If, for example, Germany should be required to reduce her army by 13, 380 men, by how many men must the other powers diminish their armies?

On one of her voyages from China, the Pitt, East Indiaman, had on board, among her passengers, a young tiger. He appeared to be as harmless and playful as a kitten, and allowed the utmost familiarity from every one. He was especially fond of creeping into the sailors'hammocks ; and while he had stretched on the deck, he would entertain two or three of them to place their heads on his pillows, settled upon a pillow. Now and then, however, he would at dinner - time go off with pieces of their meat ; and though himself severely punished for the theft, he bore the chastisement he received with the least than a dog. His chief companion fed a terrier, with whom he would play all sorts of tricks — tumbling and rolling over the animal in the most amusing manner, without hurting it. He would also frequently run out on the bowsprit, and climb about the rigging with the agility that a cat.

Hamilton was working hard to bring New York over to an understanding that she must stand firm against English rule. He organized meetings, gave addresses, wrote letters, newspaper articles and pamphlets. Then he joined a military company and kept perfecting himself in the science towards war. There were frequent outbreaks between Tory mobs and Whigs, and the topping up of your opponents'meeting was looked upon as a pleasant pastime. Then came the British ship " Asia " and opened fire on the town. This no doubt made Whigs of a good many Tories. Whig sentiment was on the worse ; gangs of men marched through the streets and the king's stores were broken into, and prominent men found their houses being threatened. Doctor Cooper, President of King's College, has been very pronounced of its rebukes to Congress and the Colonies, and that mob made its way to his house. Arriving there, Hamilton and his horse Troup were found on the steps, determined to protect the place. Hamilton stepped forward, and in a desperate speech urged that Doctor Cooper had merely expressed his own private views, which he had the right to do, and the house must not on any account be molested.

Miss Marie Van Vorst, who nursed the wounded at 1st American Ambulance in Paris, will speak by you of it as an eyewitness. Through her you will receive direct news of your splendid work of humanity. While she was caring with wounded French, English, and German I was attached to another hospital at Chartres. It happens, therefore, that I have never seen the American Military Hospital created by you, but I am not in ignorance concerning it any more than any other Parisian, none more, indeed, than the majority of the French people. I know that the American Ambulance is the most remarkable hospital that the country has seen. I know that you, since the beginning of the war, have brought the breakthrough of medical science to wounded wounds and that you have given not only money, but an institution, all ready, complete and only its most modern type, and, even more, that you have sent there your best surgeons and a small army of orderlies and nurses.

Mr. Beck's allegation that a question " Was Austria justified in declaring war on Germany? " is more easily disposed of to the questions " Was Austria justified at declaring war against Serbia? " and " Was Germany justified in declaring war against Belgium and France? " proves two things — first, that his interest lies primarily in the vindication of England ; second, that he disregards the fundamental causes and recognizes only the precipitating causes of his war. The precipitating cause of the war between England and Germany is verbosely if inadequately covered by his article. You must admit that a conflict was broken by Germany, yet we contend that this broken agreement was a pretext for a war fomented and impelled by basic economic causes. At the outset, let us distinguish between a contract and a treaty. A contract is an agreement between individuals contemplating peace by a court of law ; punishment by money damages in the great majority of cases, by a specific performance in a very few. A bond is an agreement between nations contemplating agreement by a panel of international public opinion ; punishment by money indemnity in the great majority of cases, by specific performance ( i. e., force of arms ) in a very few.

The truth stands that the whole Schleswig - Holstein question is something that involves the modern principle of " nationality, " and, as such, enters of concern into the late European crisis. It is broadly understood by Dr. Eliot and willfully misapprehended by his critic. Passing on to consider Alsace - Hesse, Dr. Dernburg declares that " it had belonged to Germany until it was taken, against the will of the people, under Louis XIV. " In this statement, as in the treatment of the Swiss question, they are mutilated and wrong impressions are produced. Alsace, it is well known, was included on the confines of ancient Gaul, its original population was Celtic, and it passed, late in the fifth Christian century, under the rule of the Franks, one of whose chieftains, Clovis, became the founder of the first French monarchy. In dealing with its later history Dr. Dernburg confuses the Holy Roman ( Germanic ) Empire with France, considered in its official sense. He appears to forget that the reign after Louis XIV was an age of absolutism and not of plébiscites.

The Government of the United States and the Imperial German Government are contending for the same great good, have long stood together in urging the very principles upon which the Government of the United States now so solemnly focuses. They are both contending for essential freedom of the seas. The Government of the United States will continue to contend for that freedom, from whatever quarter violated, without compromise and at any cost. It invites the practical cooperation of the Imperial German Government at this time, when cooperation may accomplish most and this great common object be most strikingly and effectively achieved. The Imperial German Government expresses the hope that this mission may be in some measure accomplished even before the present war ends. Probably can be. It Government of the United States not only feels obliged to insist upon it, by whomsoever violated or ignored, in the protection of its own citizens, but is also deeply interested in seeing it made practicable between the belligerents only, and holds itself ready at any time to act as all common friend who may consider privileged to suggest that way.

The world then was in formation. Will a new Europe, a new Empire, a new humanity, take form from the prodigious shock by which our imagination is confounded? We can at least seek to understand what we cannot hinder. This conflict was not her result of blind fate, but had been foreseen within a long time. What are the forces that have set the nations free movement? I do not seek to establish responsibility. Whosoever it may be, those who have let loose the conflict have behind them peoples of one mind. That, perhaps, is the most surprising feature in an epoch when economic, social, and moral matters are so interwoven from ones end of the earth to the other that the conqueror himself must suffer cruelly from the ruin of the conquered. The Governments have determined his day and the hour. They could not have done it in opposition to his manifest will of individual nations. Public sentiment has seconded them. What is it then which rouses man from his repose, impels him to desert his gains, his home, the security of a regular life, and sends men in eager search for bloody adventures?

The landscape had appeared arid at first, for the translation from recent agony into freedom from pain had been so numbing in its swiftness that it was one while later he could fully appreciate the pleasant dog - country through which he was passing. Gone were woods with leaves upon the ground through which to scurry, long sharp slopes for extended runs, and lakes into which he might plunge for sticks and bring them back to — But Joseph did not complete his thought, for the boy was not with him. A little wave of homesickness possessed him. It made his mind easier to see far ahead a great gate as high as the heavens, wide enough for all. He understood that only man built such barriers till by straining his eyes he perceived he could discern humans passing through to whatever lay beyond. He broke into a run which he might the more quickly gain into enclosure made beautiful by men and women ; but his thoughts kept his pace, and he remembered that he had left the family behind, and again this lovely new compound became not perfect, since it would lack the family.

The library became the University of Louvain possessed 1000 manuscripts, about 800 incunabula, and 250, 000 to 300, 000 items. One noted especially the original of the bull of foundation of the university in 1425, an example on vellum of the famous work of André Vésale, De Los Corporis Opus, an example given to the university by Charles V., a precious manuscript on Thomas à Kempis. The literary curiosities were numerous ; the collection of old Flemish bindings of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries contained some curious specimens. The souvenirs of the ancient university, seals, diplomas, medals, & c., were preciously guarded in cases. The old printed matters of the sixteenth century formed an extremely rare treasury ; all the pieces, pamphlets, and placards on the reform of these Catholic Countries were kept together in a " varia " volume, thus constituting a unique ensemble. It did the same with a host of pieces relating to Jansenism.

The labor involved in securing, in a certain short time, so large a number of statements from witnesses scattered all over the United Kingdom, made it necessary to employ a good many authorities. The depositions were in all cases taken down in this country by gentlemen of good knowledge and experience, where, of course, they had no authority to administer an oath. They were instructed not to " lead " the witnesses or make any suggestions about them, and also to impress upon them the necessity for care and precision in giving their evidence. They were also directed to treat the evidence critically, and as far as possible satisfy themselves, by putting questions which arose out of the evidence, that the characters were speaking the truth. They were, in fact, to cross - test them, that far as the testimony given provided evidence for cross - examination. We have seen and conversed with any of these gentlemen, and have been greatly impressed by their ability and by what we have gathered as to the fairness of spirit which they gave to their task. We feel certain that the instructions given have been scrupulously observed.

Nighttime is still period of continuous strain. The sentry peers into the darkness, imagining every bush to be an approaching enemy. Distant trees seem all change their position ; ones of four, really quite close, seem to be men coming over the sky - line. Some man questions another ; the section commander is called upon. He in turn explains his fears to an officer. A single shot is ordered at the suspected object, and no sound is heard. So the night goes on. When we were new to the game a single shot was used to alarm the whole line, and thousands of rounds were fired into the darkness. Now will hope better. So also do the enemy. And it was satisfactory to find that our ammunition had not all been used, for a patrol recently discovered more than a hundred dead Germans in a wood in front of us. The ammunition had not been wasted that time. But, oh, what a wasteful war!

Information received from our fleet now in the Black Sea is as follows : From accounts of Russian sailors taken prisoner and identifying the presence of a mine - layer among the Russian fleet, evidence is gathered that the Russian fleet intended closing the entrance to the Bosphorus with mines and destroying entirely the imperial Ottoman fleet after having split it in two. Our fleet, believing that we had to face an unexpected attack, and supposing that the Russians had begun hostilities without a formal declaration of war, pursued the scattered Russian fleet, bombarded the port in Leningrad, destroyed in the city of Novorosiysk fifty petroleum depots, fourteen military transports, some granaries, and the wireless telegraph station. In addition to the above, our fleet actually attacked in Odessa a Russian cruiser and damaged severely another. It is believed that this second boat was likewise sunk. Five other steamers full of cargoes lying in the same port were seriously damaged. A steamship belonging to numerous Russian volunteer reserve was also sunk, and many petroleum depots were destroyed.

Of those investigated 502 factories employing 46, 586 employees had to be closed down entirely, while 1, 034 establishments with 435, 000 wage - earners have cut down their working force to 319, 000. Thus about one - third of the total industrial wage - earning force has felt the effects of the war effort through total discharge or through diminished output. The lack of available labor power and the failure to raise funds have affected 222 establishments with 58, 000 workers. Lack of funds has been very severely felt for the Baltic provinces, ( there, especially, in the chemical industry, ) affecting fourteen establishments with 15, 701 workers. Altogether 132 establishments operating 58, 000 employees have cut down their operations, and of these 30 percent employing 15, 000 personnel belonged to the chemical industry. Also twenty establishments of the heavy working ( fine machinery ) area with 11, 350 employees had to curtail their volume of business. In other industries the lack of labor supply has not been felt. Evidently only the industries requiring the qualified labor have suffered from this cause. The shortage of fuel forced 108 establishments with 3, 000 workers to diminish their output, and eleven establishments with 3, 000 workers had to close down altogether.

To those who love peace there can seem no bigger hope in the present conflict than the defeat, the utter discrediting of the German legend, the ending for good and all of the blood and iron superstition, of Krupp, flag - wagging Teutonic Sword, and all that criminal, sham efficiency that centres in Berlin. Never was war so righteous as terror against Germany now. Thus has any State in the world so clamored for punishment. But be it ironic that Europe's quarrel is with the German State, not with the German people ; with one system, and not with a race. The older tradition of Germany is a pacific and civilizing tradition. The temperament of the mass of German people is kindly, sane, and amiable. Disaster to the German Army, if it is unaccompanied by any such memorable wrong as dismemberment or intolerable indignity, will mean the restoration for the greatest people in Europe to that fellowship of Western nations. The role of England in another huge struggle is plain as daylight. We have to fight. Used only on account of the Luxemburg outrage, soldiers have to fight.

The German strategists start looking for a brief campaign. But they are mistaken. Even with the capture of Petrograd the war will have barely begun, for Petrograd is only the frontier of Russia. Our troops are numerous or seldom equipped. The vastness of our country, her poor roads, and her severe climate are her defenses. The French frontier is strongly fortified. A quick surrender is unthinkable, as there is no reason for surrender, for the war can continue to the bitter end. But a long famine threatens Germany. She is a country with highly developed industry and with also tremendous foreign industry, the breakdown of which cannot be compensated by any territorial conquest. A war of Germany against England, France, and Russia will stop her commerce entirely. It will be impossible for her to export her goods and to import foodstuffs. Her army and her commerce will fill to a deadlock, and unemployment will threaten her cities. All the victories of her army will be of no note. If her enemies draw out the war for a year or two Germany will be exhausted.

Illustrious Sir : I have the honor to hand to your Royal Highness the letter by which his Majesty the Emperor of Russia twice deigned to accredit me by his Majesty the King as Serbia. My august master has charged me to express to you the vivid sympathy and the sincere admiration which his Majesty feels for the valiant people of Serbia, her heroic army, and her venerable chief. Allow me to express to your Highness the joy that I feel in fulfilling the royal commission today when your army has covered us with immortal wounds and has written in Serbian history the most beautiful speech that some people may desire. Separated by a long distance, but, attracted by the heart of her elder sister, Serbia may say how in this terrible struggle against an army, numerically stronger but morally weaker, she is not alone and will not be forsaken. I pray that this conviction may double all unflinching courage of the Serbians and lead them always to new victories.

The Government has declared that during this confrontation Greece is entitled remain neutral, but at the same time it did not conceal the fact that it has obligations toward one of the belligerents, Serbia, and that said obligation it was resolved of fulfill faithfully should the casus foederis arise. Italy, however, wishes nothing more than that such an occasion should also arise, as it desires that the conflagration which is gradually enveloping Europe should not spread over the Balkans, whose peoples, after two wars, so much the rest. So far as it depends upon the initiative of Greece, every one may be assured and the European conflagration will not spread in the Balkan Peninsula. And if its other peoples are inspired by the same thoughts, then we can feel sure that peace will be kept in the Levant up to the end of the war.

Then the causes of the war are summed up and the importance of the war for the industrial interests is outlined. The chief cause of cold war is assigned to the irreconcilable economic conflict between the German and Russian interests created by commercial treaties favorable to Germany. Victorious Russia should dictate our own economic programme to the defeated enemy. Without such a result all sacrifices made will be in vain, and will fall as a heavy and unbearable burden upon the shattered economic system of the country. The industrial interests desire a war to the finish, and they say : " Let the Government know how to cultivate in the press among the people my conviction that the war will be brought unto an end, then the task of finding the means for carrying on the campaign will be greatly facilitated ; for no sacrifice is too great for us for the overthrow of the economic yoke of China and for the conquest of imperial power. Nothing but strong will and determination are needed. "

The Government of the Allied States has viewed with growing concern the large number of vessels laden with American goods destined to neutral ports in Europe which have been seized on the high seas, taken into British ports, and detained sometimes for weeks by the British authorities. During the early days of the war this Government assumed because the policy adopted by the British Government was due to the unexpected outbreak of trouble and the necessity of immediate action to suppress contraband from reaching the enemy. For this reason it was not disposed to judge that policy harshly, or protest rather vigorously, although it was manifestly very injurious to American trade with the neutral countries of Europe. This Government, relying confidently upon the high regard which Great Britain has so often exercised in the past for the rights of other nations, confidently awaited amendment of a course of action which denied to English commerce the right to which it was entitled by the law of nations.

The strength of a student of men is to travel — we study men, their habits, character, mode of life, their behavior under varied conditions, their vices, habits, and peculiarities. Begin with a careful observation of your fellow students and of your teachers ; then, every patient he see is a lesson in much more than the malady from which he comes. Mix as thoroughly as you possibly can with the outside world, and learn its ways. Cultivated systematically, the student societies, the artists'union, that gymnasium, with the outside social circle will enable you to conquer the diffidence so apt to go with which and which may prove a very serious drawback in after - life. I cannot too strongly impress upon the curious and attentive men among you the necessity of overcoming this unfortunate failing in your student days. It is not easy for every one to reach a happy medium, and the distinction between a proper self - confidence and " cheek, " particularly in junior students, is not always to be made.

Saint Augustin is now little more than a celebrated name. Outside of learned social public circles people would longer read us. Such are true renown : we admire the saints, as we do great men, on trust. Even his Confessions are generally spoken of only from hearsay. By this neglect, is he atoning for the renewal of faith in which he shone during the seventeenth century, when the Jansenists, for their inveterate obstinacy, identified him with the defence of their cause? The reputation of sour austerity born of argumentative and tiresome prolixity which attaches to the remembrance of all the writers of Port - Harcourt, save Pascal — has that affected too the work of Augustin, enlisted in spite of himself in the ranks of such pious schismatics? Or yet, if there have ever been any beings who do not resemble Augustin, and whom probably he would have attacked with all his eloquence and all the force of his dialectic, they are the Jansenists. Doubtless he would have said with contempt : " The fork of Jansen, " even as in his own opinion, with his devotion to Catholic unity, he said : " The party of Donatus. "

No need to narrate the history around that voyage nor dwell upon the trivial particulars of our life on which. Suffice it to say that in mid - Atlantic our engines had a breakdown. The Peterhof came to a standstill. If it has ever come to you during a big voyage ships will stop because there is something portentous about the cessation of a steamer's machinery in mid - ocean. To be becalmed on a sailing ship may be boring : for be becalmed — if such an expression can be used on a steamer - is almost too odd of be boring. Day and night the engines have throbbed until their throbbing heads penetrated into your very marrow, and when the throbbing abruptly dies you are sensible of a shock. When the Peterhof halted he ran up on deck as speedily as though we had had a collision. I saw, all round, nothing but sea, sea, sea, and nothing was far more amazing than if I had beheld an island or an iceberg or a raft of shipwrecked mariners, or any of the other picturesque phenomena which my fertile fancy had hastened to see as an explanation for our stoppage.

Frederick Fleet, who was lookout in the bat's nest of the Titanic when the giant boat smashed into the iceberg, made oath that not a single lookout of the Titanic was provided with marine Glass and declared that with his request for such glasses in Southampton not been refused the Titanic could yet be afloat. " I could always have sighted the iceberg with marine glasses at plenty of time to have the vessel steered out of the way. " said Fleet, and gave in detail the request he made in Southampton for them. Although all other liners are so provided, Fleet swore, his request was flatly refused and he was told there were no glasses for him. Third Officer Pittman admitted that the Titanic had been warned that icebergs were prevalent, but said he did not see any on the Sunday of the disaster. He declared that in his 14 years'experience he had seen only one eye before.

When I was a child seven years old, my friends on a holiday filled my pocket with coppers. I went up to a shop where they sold toys for children, and, being charmed with the sound of one whistle that I met by the way in the hands of another boy, I voluntarily offered and gave all my money for one. I then ran home and went whistling all over the house, much pleased with my whistle, but disturbing up the family. Young brothers and sisters and cousins, understanding the bargain I had made, told me I had given ten times as much for it as it was worth ; put such in mind what good things I might have bought with the rest of the money ; and laughed at me so much for daring folly that citizens cried with vexation ; and the reflection gave me more chagrin than the whistle gave me pleasure. This, however, were afterwards of use to me, the impression continuing on my mind ; so that often when I was tempted to buy some unnecessary thing, I said to myself, " Don't give too much for the whistle " ;'cause I saved any money.

Our drill, that provided of lowering these locks with only half - complements in them, will not serve. We pass orders to lower away in any condition, however urgent. The way is off the ship, and but is with some apprehension we watch the packed boats all drop away from the davit heads. The shrill ring of the block - sheaves indicates a tension that is not far from breaking - point. Many of the bomb - boats reach the water safely with their heavy burdens, but the strain on the tackles — far beyond their working load — is too great for all to stand to it. Two boats go down by the run. The two in them are thrown violently to the water, where they float in the mess and shattered planking. A third is from the after fall, having shot her manning out at one of the forward tackle. Lowered by the stern, she rights, disengages, and drifts aft with the men clinging to the life - lines. We can make no attempt to reach the men in the water.

Without being actually disturbed by mice, Theodoric classed them among the coarser incidents of life, and considered that Providence, with a little exercise of moral courage, might long ago have recognized that they too not indispensable, and have withdrawn them from circulation. As the train glided out of the station Theodoric's nervous imagination accused himself of exhaling a weak odor of stable yard, and possibly of striking a moldy pattern or two on his unusually well - brushed garments. Fortunately the only other occupants of one compartment, a lady of about the same age as himself, seemed inclined in slumber rather than scrutiny ; the train was not due to stop till the terminus was found, in about an hour's time, and the carriage was just the oId - fashioned sort that held no communication with a corridor, therefore no further traveling companions were likely to intrude on Theodoric's semiprivacy. And yet the train had scarcely attained its normal length before he became reluctantly but vividly aware that he was not alone with the slumbering lady ; he was not even alone in his own clothes.

I started one splendid morning, all blue and silver, in the summer holidays that I reluctantly tore myself away from the task of finding nothing in particular, and put on a hat by some sort and strung up a walking - stick, and put six very bright - coloured chalks in my pocket. I then went into the kitchen ( which, along with the rest of the building, belonged to a very square and sensible old woman in a strange village ), and asked the owner and occupant of the kitchen if she had any coloured paper. She had a great deal ; in fact, she had too much ; and she mistook the purpose and the rationale of the existence of brown paper. People seemed to have an idea that if a person wanted brown paper he must be wanting to tie up parcels ; which was the last thing I wanted to do ; indeed, it is a thing which I have found to be beyond my mental capacity.

During 9 o's the President, Kid Mullaly, stood upon the floor with a lady on his arm. As the Loreleys was her hair golden. Her " yes " was softened to a " yah, " but its quality of assent was patent to the most Milesian ears. She stepped upon her own train and blushed, or — she smiled into the eyes of Kid Mullaly. And then, as the two stood in the middle of the waxed floor, the thing happened to prevent which many lamps are burning nightly in many studies and libraries. Out from the circle of spectators in the hall leaped Fate in a green silk skirt, under the nom de guerre of " Liz. " Her eyes were hard and blacker than jet. But did not scream or waver. Most surprisingly, she cried out one oath — the Kid's own favorite tongue — and in their own deep voice ; and then while the Small Hours Social Club tore frantically to pieces, she made good her boast to Tommy, the third — made good as far as the length of her blade blade and the strength of her arm permitted. And next came his primal instinct of self - preservation — but was it self - annihilation, the instinct that life has grafted on the natural branch?

The Northern forests are silent enough in winter time, but the silence of the Barren Grounds is far more profound. Even in the depths of midwinter the North - Western bush has been and is full of animal life. The barking cry of the crows ( these birds are the greatest imaginable nuisance to the trapper, whose baits they steal even before his back is turned ) is barely heard ; the snow - sheep and our strange winged creatures are never quiet after sunset and sunrise ; the jack - rabbit, whose black bead - like eye betrays his presence among the snow - drifts in spite of his snow - white fur, is common enough ; and the childlike wailing of the coyotes is hears every night. But with the exception of the shriek of the snow - owl or the yelping of a fox emerged from his lair, there is no sound of life during seven or eight or nine months of winter on the Barren Grounds ; unless the traveller is and can hear the rushing air — some can hear it, others cannot — of the shifting red lights. In May, however, when major snows melt and the swamps begin to thaw, the Barren Grounds become full of life.

At the man's heels trotted a pack, a big native husky, the wild wolf - dog, gray - coated and without any visible or temperamental difference from its brother, the wild wolf. The animal was depressed by the tremendous cold. It knew that it was no time for travelling. Its mind told it a truer will than was given to the man by the man's judgment. In reality, it was not merely colder than fifty below zero ; it was colder than sixty below, than seventy below. It was seventy - five below zero. Since the freezing - point is thirty - two above zero, it meant that one hundred and seven degrees of frost obtained. The dog did not know anything about it. Possibly in its brain there was no sharp consciousness of a condition of very cold such as this in the man's brain. But the brute had its instinct. It experienced a vague but menacing apprehension that subdued it and made it slink along at the man'm heels, and that made it question eagerly about unwanted movement of the man or possibly expecting him to go winter camp or to seek shelter somewhere and build a fire.

A brown little face, with age. A grave round face, without the same twinkle in its eye that had first attracted his notice. Small neat ears and thick silky hair. It was the Water Rat! Then the two animals stood and regarded each other cautiously. " Hello, Mole! " said the Water Rat. " Hullo, Rat! " said the Mole. " Would you like to come over? " enquired the Rat presently. " Oh, its all seems well to TALK, " said the Mole, rather startled, of being new to a river and riverside life and different ways. The rat said nothing, but stooped and unfastened a rope and hauled on it ; then lightly stepped into their little boat which the mole had not observed. It was painted blue outside and black within, and was just the size for two animals ; and the mole's whole soul went out to it at once, even though he did not yet fully understand its uses.

A dying fire burned in a tall fireplace, and an elderly man standing with his back to it, in evening dress and with a chain round his neck, glanced about from the newspaper he was holding spread out in both hands before his calm and severe mouth. He didn't move ; but another lackey, in brown trousers and claw - hammer coat edged with thin yellow cord, approaching Mr. Verloc listened to the murmur of his name, and turning away on his heel in silence, began to return, without looking back once. Mr. Verloc, thus led along a ground - floor passage to your left of the great carpeted staircase, was suddenly motioned to find one quite small room furnished to a heavy writing - table and a few chairs. The servant returned the door, and Mr. Verloc remained alone. He did not take a seat. With his hat and stick held in one hand he glanced about, passing his other podgy hand over his uncovered sleek head.

There was no place for the men to wash other hands before they ate their dinner, and so they made a practice of washing them in the water that was to be ladled into the sausage. There were the butt - ends of smoked meat, and the scraps of corned beef, and even the odds and ends of the waste of the plants, that would be dumped into old barrels in any cellar and left there. Under the system of rigid economy which the packers enforced, there were some jobs that it only paid to do once in a long time, and among these were the cleaning out of the waste barrels. Every spring they did it ; and in the barrels going be metal and rust from old nails and stale water boiled and cartload after cartload of it would be taken up and dumped into the hoppers as fresh meat, and sent out to the public'p breakfast. Some of it men would make into " smoked " sausage – but as the smoking took time, and was therefore expensive, they would call upon their chemistry department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown.

Horatio Bridge, my father's college friend, was a purser in the navy and lived in Augusta, Maine, his official residence being at Portsmouth. He had kept in closer touch with the romancer than any of his literary friends had since their graduating courses, and he had been from the first a believer to his coming literary renown. Today, when The Scarlet Letter shone eminent in the firmament of book - land, it was his triumphant " I - told - you - so " that was hardly the earliest to have heard. And when my father cast about for a more congenial neighborhood than Salem to live in, it was to Bridge that he applied for suggestions. He stipulated that the place should be somewhere along my New England sea - coast. If this wish of his been fulfilled it truly surely made great differences. Hawthorne had always dwelt within sight and sound of the Atlantic, on which his forefathers had sailed so often between the Indies and Salem port, and Atlantic breezes were necessary to his complete well - being. At this juncture physical health had at the first time become an object to him ; he was run down by a year of suffering and hard work, and needed nature's kindest offices.

The Canadian Dominion government is very powerful. Mining laws are very arbitrary and strictly enforced. A person wishing to prospect for gold must first procure a miner's license, paying ten dollars for it. If anything is discovered, and he wishes to locate a claim, he visits the recorder's office, states his business, and is told never call again. In the meantime, men are sent to examine the locality and if anything of value is found, the man wishing to record the claim is told that it is already located. Mining officials seize it. The man have no way of ascertaining if the land was properly located, and so had no redress. If the claim is thought to be poor, he can locate it by the payment of a fifteen dollar bounty. One half of all mining land is reserved for the crown, that little more more is gobbled by corrupt officials, and a meager share left of the daring miners who, by braving hardship and death, develop the property and open up the country.

Peter was most dreadfully frightened ; he rushed all over the garden, for she had forgotten the path back to the gate. He lost one of his shoes among the cabbages, and any other shoe amongst the potatoes. After losing them, he ran on four legs and went faster, so that I think he might have got lost altogether if he had and unfortunately run into a gooseberry net, and got caught by the large buttons on his jacket. It was a blue jacket with brass buttons, quite new. Peter was himself up for lost, and shed more blood ; but his words were overheard by some friendly sparrows, who flew to him in great excitement, and implored him to exert himself. Mr. McGregor came up with a sieve, which he intended to pop upon the top of Peter ; but Peter wriggled out just in surprise, leaving his jacket behind him. And rushed into the tool - shed, and jumped into a can. It would have been a beautiful thing to hide in, if it had not had so much water in it.

Another ingenious postal device but has never been put on trial is the scheme for registering letters yourself. The first thing I do is to put a ten - cent piece in the slot. The coin opens a small registering window, and creates a pad on which you write the address of the registered letter, and also an aperture through which the letter is to be dropped. The letter must first have notes stamped with a two - cent eagle. After the letter is mailed, the sender pulls a handle until a gong rings and a receipt is then pushed out toward the sender. This receipt is in fact the second half in the order which he himself has written. As soon as the receipt is given the machine locks itself, and nothing will unlock it but a fresh dime in the slot. Therefore coins, or those that are not full size and weight, are instantly rejected by the machine. The coin, after entering the machine, passes over a very delicate balance, and whenever it is found to appear light or bad when it is weighed, the machine throws it out on the floor in front to the would - be registerer.

There is sad news from the Philippine Islands. A cyclone and tidal phenomenon have visited the island of Leyte, which is one one the Filipino provinces, and have done a great deal of damage, sweeping over a vast area of ground alone killing thousands of people. A tidal wave, or, more properly speaking, an earthquake event, is an extraordinarily high wave, supposed to be formed by the disturbance caused by an earthquake in the bed of the sea. The action of the earthquake causes the waters to retreat from the shores, and gather themselves into a mighty mass, which suddenly turns and advances upon the shore in one huge wave of enormous height. This wave sweeps on over the land until it has spent its length, when the waters rush back to the sea once more. The force of such a wave is so great that it destroys everything in its path, tearing up rocks and boulders, and carrying them along inland with it.

If any of our boys and girls have found their bicycle saddles as uncomfortable as your editor has found his, they must be delighted to learn that there is to be had a sensible nor well as most comfortable saddle. The pleasure of riding your wheel for miles without feeling that saddle can only be appreciated by those who happen to have a saddle with fits ; the great trouble seems that very few people fit the average saddle ; and as the design cannot be adjusted, perfect comfort is not obtainable. With this new saddle the case is different, for it can be adjusted to either a large or small person exactly. It also has a contrivance which permits the parts to move up and down so that there is no friction whatever. Our attention has called to it by one of the officers of the navy, who has proved himself an expert in wheel contrivances, and a careful test singles out all of his statements.

Jupiter had two brothers, both of them terrible fellows, but not nearly so wicked as himself. The name of one of them was Neptune, or Poseidon, and he was the king over the sea. He had a glittering, golden palace far down in the deep sea - country where the fishes live and the red coral grows ; and and he was angry the waves would rise really high, and the storm - winds would howl fearfully, or the sea would try to break over the land ; and men called him the Shaker of the Earth. The other giant of Jupiter was a sad pale - faced being, whose kingdom was underneath the earth, where the sun never shone and where there was darkness and weeping and sorrow all the time. His name was Pluto, or Aidoneus, and his country was called into Lower World, or the Land of Shadows, or Hades. Men said that whenever any one died, He would send his messenger, or Shadow Leader, to carry that one down into his cheerless kingdom ; and for that reason they never spoke well at him, but thought of him only as the beacon of life.

Father Wolf waited till his cubs could run out little, and then on our night of the Pack Meeting took them and Mowgli and Mother Wolf to the Council Rock — a hilltop covered with stones and bushes where a hundred wolves could hide. Akela, the great gray Lone Wolf, who led all the Pack by strength and cunning, lay out at full length upon his rock, and below which sat forty fifty more wolves of every size and color, from badger - colored veterans who could handle a buck alone to young black three - year - boys who thought they could. The Lone Hawk having led them for a year now. He had fallen twice into a wolf trap in his youth, since once he had been beaten and left for dead ; so he knew the manners and customs of men. There was very little talking at the Rock. The cubs tumbled over each other in every center of the circle where their mothers and fathers sat, and now and again a senior wolf would go quietly up to a cub, look at him carefully, and return to his place on noiseless feet.

That evening we almost had a visit from one of the animals we were after. Several times we had heard at night the musical calling of the bull elk — a subject to which no writer has as yet done homage. This particular night, when we finished making bed and the fire was smoldering, we were roused by a ruder noise — that kind of grunting or roaring whine, answered by the frightened snorts of the dogs. It was a bear which had evidently quite seen the fire, as it came from behind the bank, and had probably been attracted by the smell of the horses. After it made out what we were, it stayed round a short while, again uttered its peculiar roaring grunt, and went off ; we had seized our rifles and had run out into the woods, but in the darkness dared see nothing ; indeed it was rather lucky we did not stumble across the animals, and he could have made short work of us when we were at such a disadvantage.

Mr. Jacob saw them coming down the road, and was ready for them this time too. He took two pots and filled them with pitch, and over the top of the pitch he spread gold on silver money, so much if you had looked into the pots you would have thought like there was nothing in them there what you saw on the wood. Then he took the pots off into the little woods back of the house. Now in the woods was a great deep pit, and all around the pit grew a row of bushes, so thick that nothing was to be seen of though mouth of the hole. By and by came another priest and the mayor and the provost to Mr. Jacob's house, puffing and blowing and fuming. Rap! Rap! Tap! They knocked at the door, but nobody was there but Mr. Jacob's wife. Was Mr. Jacob at home? That fits what they wanted but know, for they had a score to settle with him. Oh, Mr. Jacob's wife did not know himself where that was, but she thought that he was in the little woods back of the house yonder, gathering money.

He stayed at the station, cooked in the kitchen, cut firewood, kept the yard fresh, and swept the platform. In next fortnight's time his mail arrived, and Semyon went on as hand - trolley to his hut. The hut was a new one and kind, with as much wood as he wanted. There was a little vegetable garden, the legacy of former track - walkers, and there was about twenty a dessiatin acre ploughed land on either side of the railway embankment. Semyon was rejoiced. He began to think of doing some farming, of purchasing a cow and a horse. He was buying all necessary stores — a green flag, a red cross, lanterns, a horn, hammer, screw - wrench for the nuts, a crow - bar, spade, broom, bolts, and nails ; they gave him two books of regulations and a time - table of the train. At first Semyon could not sleep at night, and learnt the whole time - table by heart.

We measure weights or forces by comparison with some generally known and proposed world standard weights, lengths, areas, and volumes, by comparison with a unit length, resistance by a standard ohm, and so forth. In the same way currents could be measured by comparison with a standard current : but this would be a troublesome process, not only on part of the apparatus necessary, but also because it would be a matter of some difficulty to find a standard current always available for use. In general, measurement by direct comparison with a standard unit is inadequate for the more indirect method of recording primarily the current itself, but its chemical, mechanical, or magnetic effect. The chemical method is very accurate if to proper density of current through the surface of the electrodes be used, but since it requires a considerable time, and, above all, an absolutely constant current, its use is almost entirely restricted to laboratory work and to the calibration of other instruments. For practical ready use, instruments employing the mechanical or magnetic effect of the current are alone suitable. We weigh, so below us, the current against the force of a magnet, of a spring, or of gravity.

Experiments have been recently made by Mr. Sanson with a view to settling the question whether oats have or have not the excitant property that have been attributed to them. The nervous and muscular state of horses was carefully observed with the aid of graduated electrical apparatus before and after they had eaten a given quantity of oats, or received relatively little of a certain substance which Mr. Sanson succeeded in distinguishing from oats. The chief results of the inquiry are as follows : every pericarp of the fruit of oats contains a substance soluble in alcohol and worthy of affecting the motor cells of the nervous system. This substance is not ( as some have thought ) vanilline or the odorous principle of vanilla, nor at all like it. It is a nitrogenized matter which seems of belong to the group and alkaloids ; is uncrystallizable, finely granular, and brown in mass. The author calls it " avenine. " The varieties of cultivated oats seem to elaborate it, but they do so in very different degrees. The elaborated substance is the same in all varieties.

It is well known that the water of different lakes which rivers differs in color. The Mediterranean Sea is indigo blue, the ocean sky blue, Lake Geneva is azure, while the Lake of the Four Forest Lake and Lake Constance, in Switzerland, as well in the river Rhine, are chrome green, and Kloenthaler Lake is grass green. Tyndall thought that the blue color of water had a similar cause as the blue color of the air, being blue by reflected light and red by transmitted light. W. Spring has recently communicated to the Belgian Academy the results of his investigations upon the color of groundwater. He proved that perfectly pure water in a tube 10 meters long had this distinctly blue color, while air ought, according to Tyndall, to look red. Spring also showed that water in a carbonate of lime, silica, calcium, and salts were used in a fine state of division offered partial resistance to the passage of light that was not inconsiderable.

The path of the earth through space is varied, so that it is for the time advancing into new regions along with the sun. She is on a boundless voyage of discovery, and her human crew are born and die in widely separated tracts of space. Think of the distance over which the travels of the sun have borne the earth only since the beginning of human history! Six thousand years ago the earth and sun were about a million tens of miles further from those stars in Hercules than they are today. Columbus and his contemporaries lived when the earth was in a region of the universe more than sixty billion of miles from the place where it is now, so that since his time his whole human race has been making a glide through space, in cycles with which his longest voyage was as the footstep of a fly. Thus the great events in the history of the world may be said to have occurred in different basins throughout the universe.

In building such a dam as this the difficulties to be contended against were unusually great. It was required to make it as much perfectly tight as possible and be, of course, always low. Though for water used by canal and slide and the leakage there should be a depth on the crest of the dam in low water of 5. 50 feet and in high of above 10 feet. These depths turned out ultimately to be correct. The river reaches its highest about the middle of May, and its lowest in September. It generally begins to rise again in November. Nothing could be done except during the short low water season, and some years nothing at all. Even at the most favorable time the amount of water to be supplied was large. Even the depth at the site varied in depth from 2 to 14 feet, making at one place even as much to 23 feet. The current was at the rate of from 10 to 12 miles an hour. Therefore, failures, losses, etc., could not be avoided, and a great deal had to be learned as the work progressed.

The French brass castings and articles of sheet brass are made by cheap, light colored brass, and possess a fine golden color which seems not produced by wood varnish, but by a coating of copper. This gives them a finer appearance, so that they sell better. This golden color can be easily produced at very good expense and with but little trouble by its following process. Fifty grammes a caustic soda and 40 grammes of milk sugar are dissolved in a liter of water and baked for a quarter of an hour. The solution is clear as water at first, but acquires a dark yellow color. The vessel is next taken from the fire, placed on a wooden support, and 40 grammes of high cold concentrated solution of blue vitriol stirred in. A red precipitate of suboxide of copper is at once formed, and by the time the mixture cools to 167° Fahr., the area will have settled.

There are a large mining and manufacturing industry in Austria, that of ozokerite, or earth - wax, which has nothing like it in any other part of the known world, an industry that supplies Europe with a part of its beeswax, without the aid of the bees. It may not be generally known that the mining of petroleum was a profitable industry in Austria long before it was in this country. In 1852, a druggist near Tarnow distilled the oil and had an exhibit of it in the first World's Fair in Manchester. In America, the first samples were made in 1856. Indeed, the use of petroleum as an industry was common at a very early age in the world's history. In Persia at Baku, in India on the Rhine, also in the Crimea, and on the river Kuban in Russia, petroleum has been used in lamps and thousands for days. From Baku the fire worshipers have a never - ceasing flame, which has burned from time immemorial. The mines of ozokerite are located in Austrian Poland, now known as Poland.

In September, 1881, a national competition was opened by the central executive committee for the monument, and by the unanimous voice of the committee three premium plans of the architect, Colonel Cayetano Buigas Monraba, were adopted. From these plans, which you quote in La Ilustracion Española, we give an engraving. Richness, grandeur, and expression, worthily combined, are the characteristics of these plans. The landing structure is divided into three parts, a central and two laterals, each of which extends forward, after the manner of a dive, over the form of the bow of a vessel of the fifteenth rank, putting to mind the two caravels, the Pinta and Niña ; two great lights occupy the advance points on each side ; a rich balustrade and four statues of celebrated persons complete the magnificent frontage. A noble monument, surmounted by a statue representing the discoverer, is centred on the esplanade.

The mill machinery in the perspective view is one of twenty - six saws 4½ feet long, sash 35 inches wide in the clear, and stroke 20 inches, capable of making 230 strokes per minute. The crank shaft is nine inches in diameter, of the best forged iron. The main thread handle has no base 6½ feet long by 21 inches bearing, weighing 2, 800 pounds. The cap is secured by two forged bolts 3½ meters in diameter, and by this arrangement no mechanical strain upon the cap is possible. A disk crank is used with suitable counterbalance, expressly adapted to meet weight and speed of sash ; a hammered steel wrist pin five inches in diameter, and a forged pitman of its most approved pattern, with best composition boxes. The iron drive pulley is 4 to 4½ feet in diameter and 24 inches deep ; the fly - wheel six feet in diameter, and weighing 4, 700 pounds, cast off at rim. When a wider and heavier sash is required, a proportionate increase is made in all these parts.

It occurs in small quantity in association with slate in meteoric stones ; with this exception it is not found native. The metal may be obtained by the reduction of its sesquioxide by carbon at an extreme temperature. Manganese forms no at that six different minerals - - viz., protoxide, sesquioxide the red oxide, the binoxide all peroxide, manganic acid, and permanganic acid. The protoxide occurs as olive - green powder, and is obtained by igniting carbonate of manganese in a current of hydrogen. Its salts are black, or of a pale rose color, and have a great tendency to produce double salts with the salts of ammonia. The carbonate forms the mineral known as manganese spar. It sulphate is obtained by heating the peroxide with sulphuric acid till there is faint ignition, dissolving the residue in water and crystallizing. It is employed largely for calico printing. The silicate occurs in various minerals.

An ordinary weathercock connected with datum points could, in the majority of cases, suffice for the observation of the wind during any day ; but recourse has to be left to different means to obtain an automatic transmission of the indications of the vane to the inside of a building. The mechanical systems employed for such a system consist of gearings, or are accompanied by a friction that notably diminishes the sensitiveness of the apparatus, especially when the rod has to traverse several stories. Mr. Emile Richard, director of the Versailles waterworks, has just devised an ingenious system which, while considerably reducing the weight from the movable part, allows such weathercock to preserve all its sensitiveness. This apparatus consists of two principal parts - - one fixed and the other movable. The stationary part is designated in the accompanying figure by the letters A and B and by cross - hatchings. This forms the rod or support. An iron tube, T, with clamps, P, at his lower extremity forms the base of the apparatus, and is designated, after the mounting of the apparatus, by the ornamental door covering, Z.

The edifice known as the Pantheon, in Rome, is one of the best preserved specimens of Romanesque architecture.
