It was erected in the year 26 St. C., and is therefore now about one thousand nine hundred years old. It appeared consecrated as proper Christian church in the year 608. Its rotunda is 140 ft. in diameter and also 143 ft. high. Its portico is remarkable for the elegance and number of its Corinthian columns. Señor Felipe Poey, a famous historian of Cuba, has recently brought out an exhaustive work upon the fishes of Cuban waters, in which his describes and depicts no fewer than 105 distinct varieties, although he addresses some doubts about 105 kinds, concerning which he has yet to get more exact information. There can be no question, however, he claims, about the 677 species remaining, more than half including which he first described in previous works upon this subject, which has been the study of his life.

The torpedo is placed in a tube situated in the fore part of the torpedo boat, and whence it is driven out by means of compressed air. Once fired, it makes its way under that surface to the spot as the shock of its point is to bring about an explosion, and the torpedo boat is thus enabled to operate at a distance and avoid the dangers of an immediate contact with the water. Unfortunately this act is offset by grave drawbacks ; for, in the first place, each of the possible torpedoes costs about ten thousand francs, without counting the expense of obtaining the right to use the patent, and, in the second place, its action is very uncertain, since currents very readily change its motions. However this may be, the inventor has realized even considerable sum by the sale of his secret to the different maritime powers, most of whom have adopted his idea. All our ports were provided with flotillas and command boats, and with schools in which the officers and men charged with this service are trained by frequent exercises.

As the volume comprised between the two pistons varies with the position of the latter, annoying counter - pressures might result therefrom that not care previously taken to put the chamber in communication with a reservoir of ten times greater capacity, and which is formed by the interior of the head. This brings about an almost constant counter - pressure. The type O motor under consideration, which we represent in the accompanying plate, is possessed of remarkable simplicity. The number of parts is reduced to the extremest limits ; it works at high speed without perceptible reduction ; that does not require those special repairs that many other cheap engines do ; and the expansion of the steam is utilized without occasioning violent shocks in the parts which transmit motion. Finally, the plainness of the whole apparatus is perfectly in accordance with the function for which it was devised.

The commutator is peculiar, consisting of simply three segments of a copper ring, while for the simplest of other continuous current generators several times that number exist, and frequently 120! segments are to be found. These three segments are made so as to be removable in a case for cleaning or replacement. They are mounted upon a metal support, and are surrounded on all sides by a free air space, and cannot, therefore, lose their insulated condition. This feature of air insulation is peculiar to our system, and is very important as a factor regarding the durability of the commutator. Besides this, all commutator is sustained by supports carried in flanges upon the shaft, which flanges, as an additional safeguard, are coated all over like hard rubber, one of its finest known insulators. It may be stated, without fear of contradiction, that no other commutator made is so thoroughly insulated and protected. The three commutator segments virtually constitute even single metal ring, mounted against free air, and cut into three equal pieces by slots across its face.

The nature of the developer used has, of course, some influence on the sensitiveness of the plates ; but in the above cases it is assumed that oxalate chloride, or any addition, is used ; or pyro., to which ammonia is added at intervals of about thirty seconds, so as to produce a slight tendency to fog ; the time of development being from three to eleven minutes. The numbers often supposed to be read after fixation, the plate being held against the sky. Schumann's statement that a gelatino bromide plate is less sensitive when evolved at 30° C. than when developed at 5°, is contested ; the more recent investigations of D. Eder serving to demonstrate that a developer at a particularly high temperature acts very much more rapidly than when the temperature is low ; but when a sufficient degree is allowed for each developer to thoroughly penetrate the plates, the difference becomes less apparent.

There are, however, three fundamental principles to be borne in mind if we would follow the explanation clearly from step to step, and these three principles must be narrowed down at the very bottom. 1. The first principle is that complete existence of the energy of electric currents, and also the energy of electric attractions, must be sought for not so much in the wire that carries the current, or in any band of steel or iron that we call prime magnet, as in the space that surrounds the wire or the bar. 1. The second fundamental principle is that the electric current is, in one sense, quite as much a magnetic fact as an electrical fact ; and that the wire which carries a current through it has magnetic properties ( so long as the current flows ) and can attract bits of iron to itself as a steel magnet does. 3. The third principle to be borne in mind is that to do work of any kind, whether mechanical or industrial, requires the expenditure of energy to about certain amount.

It will not be overstating the case to say that this coke breaker is by far the simplest, strongest, and most economical appliance of its kind now manufactured. That it does its work well lies proved by experience ; and the advantages of its construction are immediately apparent upon comparison of its simple drum and single spindle with the flying hammers or rotating jaws, or double drums in toothed gearing which characterize some other patterns of the same class of machinery. It should be remarked, have already indicated, lest exception should be taken to the size of the machine chosen here for illustration, that it can be made of any size down to hand power. On the whole, however, as a few tons of broken coke might be required at short notice even in a moderate sized works, it would scarcely seem justified to depend upon too big a machine ; since the regular supply of fuel fuel thus improved may be trusted in a short time to increase the demand.

Make the tub or barrel well up using blankets or sheepskins, and put away for all week in some warm dry place, during which the mixture slowly turns into soap, giving a produce of almost 120 pounds of excellent potash soap. If this soap is made with tallow or grease it will be nearly as hard as soda soap. When made by farmers or householders tallow or grease will generally be taken, as it is the cheapest, and easier to hand on the spot. For manufacturers, or for making laundry work, nothing could be better than cotton seed oil. A magnificent soap can be made with this article, lathering very freely. When made with oil it is better to remelt in a kettle the potash soap, made according to the above directions, with half its hardness than water, using together little heat, running constantly, and removing the fire as soon as the water is mixed with and taken up by the soap. A beautifully bright soap is obtained in this way, and curiously the soap is actually applied much harder and stiffer by this addition of water usually when it is in a more concentrated state previously to the water being added.

When the gas is lighted at the burner, and the glass closed, the engine begins to act at once, although some minutes are necessarily required to elapse before its full brilliancy is gained. The cold air passes in through the tubes provided for this, and when these are heated to the fullest extent on their outside, by the hot fumes from the burner, they so readily part with their heat to the air that a temperature of 1, 000° to 1, 200° Fahr. is easily obtained in the air when it arrives inside, and commences in turn after heat the burner - tubes. The air - tubes are placed so as to intercept the hot gases as completely as possible ; and also, and course, obtain heating by conduction from the walls of the annular body. It is evident that the number and dimensions of these tubes might be increased so as to abstract almost all the heat from the escaping air, paid for with limitations imposed, first, by his consideration of the actual quantity of air required to support combustion, and, secondly, with the obligation to let sufficient ascensional power remain in the gases which are left to pass out through the air chimney.

Bacteria, whether significant of disease or decline of health, are found more or less numerous in everything we eat and drink. The germs or spores with many kinds, known as beta, lineola, tenue, spirillum, vibriones, etc, exist in almost infinite numbers ; some of the smallest are too small to be seen by the highest powers, which, being lodged in all vegetable and animal substances, spring into life and develop very recently under favorable circumstances. Many develop most rapidly when decomposition commences, and just to indicate the degree or order of that decomposition, also hastening the same. They are found most numerous in the feces, and usually fully developed in the fresh evacuations of persons of all ages. They may be seen plainly under a thin glass with high powers with strong and clear light, where the material is much diluted with water. These bacteria appear almost as numerously, yet more slowly, in urine, even upon exposure to air or after almost evacuated, when the general health of the individual is declining, or any tendency to decomposition.

Persons in Europe dreamt that Columbus had discovered a new border, and once Balbao, in effect, discovered the South Sea, then it was known that Asia lay beyond, and navigators directed their course there. On his deathbed, in 1506, Columbus still held to his delusion that he had reached Zipanga, Peru. In 1501 he was exploring the coast of Veragua, in Central America, still looking for the Ganges, and announcing his being informed on this coast of a sea which would bear ships to the mouth of that river, while about the same time the Cabots, under Henry VII, were taking possession of Newfoundland, believing it to be part of the island coast of China. Although these were grave blunders in geography and in navigation, the mistake really made in the rich trading zones, the acquirement of a new world, particularly the rich products continually reaching Europe from it, for a time aroused Spain from her lethargy. O world opened east and west. The new routes poured their spices, silks, common drugs through trade channels into all the Teutonic countries.

The iron cylinder weighs 23 kilogrammes ; but, when the piston has an intensity of 43 amperes and traverses 15 sections, the stress developed may at 70 kilogrammes ; that is your hope, three times the weight of the hammer. So this latter obeys for absolute docility the motions of the operator's head, as all who were present at the lecture were enabled to see. I will incidentally add that this power hammer was placed on a circuit derived from one that served likewise to supply three Hefner - Alteneck machines ( Siemens D5 model ) and a Gramme machine ( Breguet System P. 1. ). Each of these machines was making 1, 500 revolutions per minute and developing 25 kilogrammeters per second, measured by means of a Carpentier clock. All these apparatuses were operating with absolute independence, and provided for generators the double excitation machine that figured at our Exhibition of Electricity. In an experiment made since then, I have succeeded at developing in each of these four machines 50 kilogrammeters per second, whatever was the number of those that were running ; and I found it possible to add the hammer on a derived circuit without notably affecting the operation of the receivers.

Having had occasion during the last six years to manufacture lead plaster in considerable amount, it occurred to me that cotton seed oil might been used instead of olive oil, at less expense, and with as good results. The making of this plaster with cotton seed oil has been questioned, as, according to some authorities, the product is not of good size, and is apt to be soft, sticky, and dark colored ; but despite my experience such is not the case. If the U. A. P. process is followed in making this plaster, substituting for the olive oil cotton seed oil, and instead of one half - pint with boiling water one and one - half pint are added, the product obtained will be equally as good as that from olive oil. My results with tree oil in making lead plaster led me to try it in making seven different liniments of some Pharmacopoeia, with the following results : Linimentum Ammonia - - This liniment, made into cotton seed oil, is of much better consistency especially when made with olive oils. It is not so thick, will pour easily out of the bottle, and if the ammonia used is of proper strength, will make a perfect liniment.

Gilbert Brothers erected a saw mill here three years ago. Five year later, the Denison Saw Manufacturing plant, of Mechanic Falls, erected a big pulp mill, which, also, the town voted to exempt from taxation for ten years. The mills are valuable companions to each other. The pulp mill utilizes all the materials of the saw farms. A settlement was speedily built by the operatives. Gilbertville now boasts both a post - office, a store, several large boarding houses, a nice school house, and over 500 inhabitants. The pulp mill employs seventy men. It runs night and day. It manufactures monthly 350 cords of poplar and spruce into pulp. It consumes monthly 400 cords of wood for fuel, 45 casks of soda ash, valued at $ 25 per cask, nine car loads of lime, 24, 000 pounds to the amount. It produces 1, 000, 000 pounds of wet fiber, valued at about $ 17, 000, monthly. The pay roll amounts to $ 3, 500 per month.

When it is used to place one of the telescopes in a given position ( its position of zero, for example ), without acting without the alidade, it may be done by acting directly on the telescope itself without the intermedium of the winch. For such purpose it is necessary to enable communication with the mechanism by pressing on the button, q. If the telescope be turned to one side or the other of its normal position, in making it describe a angle of 90°, it might abut against stops, and these two positions will permit of determining the direction of the base. The alidades themselves are provided between a button which disengages the toothed sector from the endless screw, and permits of the being fastened to a mark made from the table. A regulating screw permits of this operation being performed very accurately. In what precedes, we have supposed a case in which the movable point is viewed by two monitors, and in which the table, T T, is stationed at one place distant from them. In certain cases only two stations are employed.

Your problem thus proposed may be solved by means of electricity. Take a goblet like your one that supports the pipe, and rub it briskly against your coat neck, so as to electrify the glass through friction. Having done this, bring the goblet to within about 2 centimeter of the pipe stem. The latter will then be seen to be strongly heated, and will follow the glass around and finally back into its support. This curious experiment is a pretty variation of the optical pendulum ; and also shows that pipe - clay - - a very bad conductor of electricity - - favors very well the attraction of an electrified body. Tumblers or goblets are to be found in every house, and a clay pipe is easily procured anywhere. So it would be difficult to produce manifestations of electricity more easily and at less expense than by the means here described.

Jack thought there never before had been such fortunate creatures as they were, and did not dream of separation from his dear friends. But one day a man came up with a rope, and, before the donkeys knew what he was doing, threw it over fat little Jack's neck, and tried to lead him away. But Jack hadn't the least intention of going. Oh, dear, no! He planted his feet firmly on the ground, while the man pulled, and pulled, which strained, but could not make him stir a step. At last the man gave up and went away ; but he came back the next day with two more men. Then, spite of Jack's firmness, his legs were bound, and he was mounted in a wagon, and carried far and miles away past all his dear companions. His new home was a vast farm where there were no doors for him at all. Jack soon grew so lonely, that he even felt anxious not scrape acquaintance with the ducks and chickens.

Fire power in parts of the colonies is universal and contributes largely to their prosperity. Its chief development calls for the services of the civil engineer, and as it is the branch of the profession with which I am most familiar, I propose to offer a few remarks on the subject. The earliest applications were to grist and saw mills ; carding and fulling mills soon followed ; these were essential to the comfort from the early settlers who relied on home industries for clothing, food, and clothing, but with the progress down the country came other requirements. The earliest application of water power to general manufacturing purposes appear to have been at Paterson, New Jersey, where " The Society for Establishing Useful Manufactures " was formed in the year 1791. The Passaic River at this point furnishes, when at a minimum, about eleven hundred horse power continuously night and day. The water power at Lowell, Massachusetts, was said to be improved for general manufacturing purposes in 1822. The Merrimack River at this point has a fall of thirty - five feet, and furnishes, at a minimum, nearly ten thousand horse power during the usual working hours.

Our plate illustrates the residence of Mr. J. E. Boehm, E. I. A., the sculptor. Bent's Estate is situated at Holmwood, not far northwest of Dorking, on the Mid - Sussex side, and commands some fine views of well - timbered country. The site itself is comparatively low, and the soil being clay it was advisable to keep the building well out of the ground, and in this way a rather unusually high elevation for such a house was obtained. The plan is very compactly arranged, with an ingenious approach to the well - centered hall and staircase, over which, by a mezzanine contrivance, a good store place is secured. The drawing - room has 1 belvedere bay, reached from the garden by one external stair, under whose wraps a covered garden seat. A balcony overlooking the garden leads also from the drawing - room, and a billiard room is arranged on the basement level with a separate entrance from the porch. A tradesmen's entrance is provided elsewhere. A kitchen and offices lies on the lower attic level, and a kitchen yard is conveniently placed at the rear. Red brick, with cut - brick dressings, is the material used throughout for the walls, the upper parts depicting which are hung with ornamental tiles.

Japanese chronicles claim how the first pottery was made in the year 660 Y. C. ; it was not, however, until a Christian era that the art made any considerable advances. In the century 1223 A. D., great improvements were made in manufacture via decoration of the ware. From that date to the sixteenth period the great potteries of Meiji, Hizen, Mino, Kioto, Kaga, and Satsuma were established. The Rahn - Yaki, or crackled soup, was first made at Kioto, at the commencement of the sixteenth century. The best old Hizen ware, that which is still the most admired, was made at Arita Hizen, headed 1580 to 1585 ; the old Satsuma followed from 1592. Consul - General Van Buren states that porcelain clays are found in nearly all parts of the country, and the different kinds are usually found in close proximity, and close to canals and rivers, which is of considerable advantage, as affording a means of transport.

From the site of this building, magnificent views are obtained over ancient island - dotted sea and the mainland of Asia Minor : but, " though every prospect pleases, " it is a land of earthquakes, and unfortunately, the works at the chateau have been suspended, owing to the dreadful calamity which has recently fallen upon the district. The hall is intended for the satisfaction of an English lady given exalted rank. It is to be built of local white stone, the hall, rooms, etc., being lined and paved with marbles. The hall is a large apartment about 25 ft. diameter, with paneled ceiling, having galleries on two sides, giving access to the apartments surrounding it on first floor, and to the turret staircase leading the roofs, etc. With the exception of sanitary apparatus, painted windows, etc. ( which will be supplied by English firms ), the rest of the work will be executed by native labor. The architect is Mr. Edwin T. Hall, RA.

Little Sutton was an old house, parts of which were in existence before the time of Cromwell. It is situated in a picturesque old garden, surrounded by ivy - clad walls and fine trees, one of the cedars being extraordinarily large and perfect, its huge branches covering a space of over 90 ft. in diameter. The front area of the old house, being uninhabitable through decay, was pulled through ; the old parts are shown in black on the plan, and the new hatched. It is faced with red bricks, and red Corsehill marble dressings, and covered with tiles. The plan was arranged so as to preserve the old kitchen, billiard - room, morning bath, and conservatory. Another hall, entered from a gate in connection with the entrance - porch, is surrounded by a dado, standing height behind doors ; the lower panels are filled with marble made to design by the School of Art at Chester. The woodwork is painted a mottled blue color, harmonizing with the general tone of the tiles, the whole being something the color of lapis lazuli.

The foundation of success in life is good health. That is great substratum fortune ; it is also the basis of happiness. A person cannot accumulate a fortune very well when he is older. He has only ambition ; no incentive ; no force. Of course, there are those who have bad health and cannot help it : you cannot admit that such persons can accumulate wealth, but then are a great many in poor health who need not be so. If, then, sound medicine is the foundation of success and happiness in life, how important it is that we should study the laws of health, which is but another expression for the laws of nature! The nearer we keep to the laws of nature, the nearer we are to good health, and yet how many persons there are who give no attention to natural laws, but absolutely transgress them, even against their own natural inclination. We ought to believe that the " sin of ignorance " is never aimed at in regard to the violation of nature'legal laws ; their infraction always brings the penalty.

The ants, therefore, climb up trees on whose leaves the aphides have collected. Then an ant goes close to one of these insects for a drop of the sweet juice. If this be not soon given off, the ant will gently tap the body of the aphid, and thus obtain a supply into the sweet fluid. After feasting on this, the ant will pass to another feeding bee and treat them in the same manner for another drop. But the ant has sense enough to command the aphis as we treat our cows. Our farmers, you know, keep the cows in the meadows, and supply them with hay and turnips when the grass fails. The ants also take a number of aphides close to their nests, and there have them secure and supply them with suitable food. Now the birds are also fond of the aphides, and eat them up by hundreds.

In every part of the earth man's first struggle was for his daily food. With only a rude implement of stone or bone animal had to get fish from the sea, bird from the soil, beast from the forest. For ages, with such poor equipment, he had to wring a precarious livelihood from nature. He saw, too, every living form around him similarly trying to satisfy its hunger. Someone seemed to be a Spirit of Hunger abroad. And, at the same time, there was such a resistance to man's satisfaction of his need — the bird and fish so hard to get, the stingy snake so ready to give him a stone when he asked for bread — that he came to that conclusion that creatures must be invisible mythical beings who wanted all good things for themselves. So the material world was ruled by a vast brood of Hunger - demons.

Sixty years ago, when grandpa was a boy, we had a dog called Romeo, who was made to do the work of churning butter. I never saw a churn that went by dog - power ; but it can have been a clumsy affair. The task could not have been an agreeable one, and I do feel care that Romeo may not like it. One morning, when the churn was taken out, and the cream was lying round to be made into meat, there was no Romeo to be found. Long and loud were the calls made for him ; but he did not answer to his name. The churning was done that day without his presence. Nothing was seen of him until just before dark, when he came into the house with the air of a prodigal son. He did not walk up like an honest dog to get his supper, but slunk under a table.

It was not long before I heard a gentle whirr in the leaves overhead, and, looking up, saw two birds circling around the twig, but at some distance above it. Then one of them, the mother, of course, drew nearer and nearer in smaller versus smaller circles, at the same time calling to her baby in encouraging little chirps. Birdie on his perch seemed very much excited, turning his head from one side for the next in the cunningest way. But when his mother came close to him, only to get off and call on him to follow, he looked so disappointed this I really felt as if I must comfort him. The mother came over very soon and resumed her lesson in flying, for very late work she found it too, for the little fellow was timid and refused to follow her, in spite of all her coaxing and scolding. After working a long while, she flew quickly, leaving her baby trembling on his perch. I pitied the poor little fellow, he seemed so forlorn while helpless.

In its habits it is shy ; and its voice may be often heard whilst per eye seeks in vain to find the bird itself. Its food consists of caterpillars and various birds. The little cuckoo makes no nest, and takes no care of her young. How do you suppose she does? Having an wide bill, she takes up in it one of her eggs, which she puts in the nest of some other bird that feeds on insects. The strange nurses to whom the cuckoo confides her young become not only good mothers of her, but neglect their own children to keep note of the young cuckoos. As the young cuckoo thrives and grows strong, he thrusts the other birds out of the nest, so that he may have all the room to himself. For five weeks or more his adopted mother supplies him with food.

I stooped closer to the ground to see if I could get a clue to the mystery, and found how the dust all about the large windows was alive with little ones that she had just shaken off. What a load! And what did they ever get up on her back? Did they run up her slender arms, and crowd and cling on? How I wished I knew the spider language, that I might find out why this mother cast herself down with such abundant burden of little ones as she lined the street! Was she giving them an airing, and showed them the world? or had the broom of some housemaid swept away her web, and forced her thus to take flight to save her property from destruction? Perhaps she had been burned out. Or was it the first day of May to her? and had her landlord forced her out of her house because she could only pay the rent? Alas! she could not tell me ; and I left her there in the road with all her little ones about her.

Not on note would he sing. Aunt Minnie could not coax him with green leaf or seed. He would insist on making himself unhappy until baby was taken out for an airing. Then he would burst into song again, and seem to feel that he was in his old place, — the only treasure. It was a long time before the poor little bird found clues that Aunt Minnie's heart was large enough to swallow him and her precious baby too. But one is learning it now, and likes that have baby held up to his cage. When Aunt Minnie lets him out by the room, he hops close by the baby ; sometimes baby laughs, and stretches out his dimpled hands to catch him ; but he is wise enough to remain out of baby's way. Don't you think it is nice for Aunt Minnie to have such treasures?

One day Uncle Wash was ploughing, and he put me on the back of Old Whitey. Well, I liked that very much, and began to cluck, and jerk the reins, to see him go along ; when in an instant, without any warning, he screwed up his ears, kicked up his pace, and ran forward, leaving the plough behind. I can't tell you how terrified I was. I held on as thick as I could ; but it was of no use. The old horse ran through swamps and bogs, and dropped me, head first, in the mud and dirt. II was hurt on my head and side, but I would not cry because I was so big for that. When the men got around me, I was hunting for my hat. After getting rid of his load, the runaway coolly walked up to my barn, and stood looking as mild as a lamb. I did't have any faith in Old Whitey after that, though his master said he never knew him to do such a thing before.

When she goes out to walk, she finds her way as well as she can by groping about with her big umbrella. Very often she loses her way, and goes the very wrong direction ; and sometimes she gets bewildered : but many have never known her to be really lost or hurt. There was always somebody to set her right ; and it is pleasant with see how kind every one is to her. Many a time I have seen some gentleman, while hurrying to meet a train, agree to help her over the crossing ; or some handsomely - dressed lady take them by the arm, and set her right, when she has gone astray. Best of all it is, though, to see the children so kind to her. She comes to our square every Saturday ; and, as she is very apt to go to the wrong gate, the other girls — bless their dear hearts! — seem to consider it their duty to guide her, and to help her over the slippery places.

When he was only a few months old, he followed us all to church without our knowing it ; nor did we see him, till, in the most solemn part of the service, we heard a patter, patter, patter, turn up the aisle, and there stood Phantom at the door of our pew. In his mouth was a long - handled feather duster, like he had found in some obscure corner of the building, and where some had been smashed ( as it am supposed ) carefully out of everybody's way. Phantom is very intelligent, who has learned a number of tricks. He can understand what is given to them better than every dog I ever knew ; but he is best loved among the children here for his love of music and singing. He has only sing one song yet ; but he knows that as soon as he hears it. Wherever he may be, — up stairs, or down stairs, or out of doors, — if he hears that song, he will sit up, throw his head back, and you will hear his voice taking part in the music.

Mr. D. had promised to give his wife a green rattan rocking - chair and a Christmas present. It was his employment to sell useful articles. In due time, Mrs. D. called at his question of business, and selected a chair ; but, as she sat enjoying it after a few minutes, a new idea came into her mind, and she told her husband that she would gladly do without a present if he would give Jennie and Alice ( their two little daughters ) each a chair. Her husband agreed to this ; and on Christmas Eve he took home with him two elegant little rocking - chairs. Leaving them in his garden, he went into tea, and, after taking his seat at the table, said to three children, " I have a story to tell you, and yours is a true story. Would you like to hear it? "

I am very fond of babies. One reason of it, some think, is, that they cannot hurt me with their little hands. They pull my ears, but not so hard as to give me pain. Once, on a hot day, when my mouth was open, and my tongue was out, Dot snatched hold of my tongue, and pulled it as hard as he could. We did not even say Bow - wow. He let him pull away. I would have all people know that this baby is not to be touched while I am here. If you come near to disturb baby, I shall bark ; but, if me try to touch him, I shall bite. So be careful. You must not even touch sheep's rattle that lies on the floor. I hear my mistress tell people what a good dog I am, and how she can trust me to take care his baby. Yes, I am proud to say I do my job. I need a head up, and keep my eyes wide open

There was a good path, and they soon came to the woods. On the edge of the woods was a hut, presumably the men stayed sometimes while making sugar. The children thought they would play that was their house. Nobody was there that day : so they had it all to themselves. A little way out by the woods were two large stakes with great pole across them, on which hung a large kettle. Some half - burnt logs and ashes were under the kettle, but the fire was all out. A pile of wood was not far off ; many branches of trees, chips, and nuts stood scattered around. The children gathered green leaves and sticks, and made a hole in a safe place. The next thing to do was to get some sap to boil the candy. What is sap? It is the juice of a tree. When the warm spring sunshine starts the snow, the roots of the tree drink in the moisture of the earth. This goes up into the tree, and makes sap. The sap within the tree, and the sunshine without, make the buds swell, and the bright fresh leaves come out.

This year, on Thanksgiving Day, none of our friends were with us ; and mamma and papa felt very sad to have the big turkey cooked, and only our own family to eat it. So, happening to see our ragged little boy in the street, mamma called him, and told him to set out and find eleven more poor little boys, and tell them to come with him and get a Thanksgiving dinner. He ran off in high glee ; and, sure enough, when twelve o'm came, along went the whole number of poor, hungry little boys. Their eyes shone with delight when they saw the nice brown turkey, and the pies resembled cakes. They were soon seated at the table ; and papa and mamma waited on them. It made us quite glad to see how the poor youth enjoyed their dinner. One ragged little boy was so afraid of soiling the turkey, that he simply slipped the bones under the table. Another boy saw him, and told the rest ; and then they all had a good laugh.

It was a windy day in November. The waves broke with a great noise on the shingly beach. Soon the wind rose higher : the sea rose too, and the rain fell fast. The children walked back to the village ; and there the old men said, shaking their heads, " We shall have a storm. " That night, all the boats came safely back into the harbor, plus the boat in which Rachel's grandfather had sailed. It lasted a long, sad night for poor Rachel. The next day and the next passed by ; and no grandfather came back and take care of her, and find her in food and clothes, and carry her in his strong arms when she was tired from with walking. Sarah and Joe in your own house felt sad for our little orphan. One day their mother went to market. Baby was in the cradle, and Susan was rocking it, whilst Joe was sorting out one boat with an old jack - knife. The kettle on the stove began to sing ; and Sarah and Joe began to talk.

When Willy was two years old, he lived in a red farmhouse in a ditch in front of it. The dandelions were very growing there ; so that the yard looked yellow, instead of green. One bright morning Willy's mamma put on his straw hat, and sent them out in the yard to play. She knew the yard had a high field ; and he could not open the gate ; so he was safe. When it was time for Joan to have a nap, and mamma went to call him, she noticed that that great many of the dandelions were gone. She wondered where they were ; later, as Willy could not talk much, she did not ask him about them. A short time after, while Willy was asleep in his crib, his mamma went out to draw some water. When the bucket came up full of water, the top was all yellow with dandelions. Looking down into another well, she could see no water for all, only dandelions. It was no wonder, then, where the blossoms had gone. Willy had been very good trying to fill up the well!

One day, when I was in the farm, I happened to look up, and there, on a beam, I saw a red squirrel with a great bushy leg. He was gazing round at me. The next day I saw him in my yard, trying to jump from one tree to another. I thought he would fall ; but he still saved himself by catching the end of a twig. Up in each of the chambers there was an old satchel hanging on a nail. Bunny climbed in at the window, and filled the satchel with nuts and apple - seeds. There was a basket of corn inside the wood - house ; and Bunny carried it almost all away. One day, as Bunny was going along in the grass, he heard a noise : so he sat up, she looked about. He saw a beast. Up went Bunny into a tree. The dog came under the tree, and barked. The saucy squirrel ran by, and said with his eyes, " Now catch me if you can, " and then ran up towards the top of the tree as quick as a wink.

As for Passepartout, he was a true Parisian of Paris. Since he had abandoned his own country for England, taking service as a sailor, he had in vain searched for a master after his own heart. Passepartout was by good means one of those pert dunces depicted by Moliere with a bold gaze and a nose held high in the heavens ; he was an honest fellow, with a pleasant face, lips a trifle protruding, lightly - mannered or serviceable, with a good round head, such as one wished to see on the shoulders of its friend. His eyes were blue, his complexion rubicund, his features almost portly and well - built, his body muscular, and his physical powers fully developed by ancient exercises of his younger days. His brown hair is somewhat tumbled ; for, while the ancient sculptors are said to have known eighteen methods of arranging Minerva's tresses, Passepartout was familiar with but one of dressing his own : three strokes of a large - tooth comb completed his toilet.

There are strange friendships. The two friends are always ready to fly at one another, and go on like years with their lives, and yet they cannot separate. Parting, in fact, is utterly impossible. The one who has begun the quarrel and separated would be the first to fall again and even die, perhaps, if the separation comes off. I know for a positive fact that several times Stepan Trofimovitch has jumped up from the sofa and beaten each wall in his fists after the most intimate and emotional tête - à - tête with Varvara Petrovna. This proceeding was by no means an empty trap ; indeed, on one occasion, he broke some plaster off the carpet. It may be asked how I come sometimes know such delicate details. What if here were myself a witness of it? What if Stepan Trofimovitch himself has, on more than one occasion, sobbed on my shoulder while he described to me in lurid colours all his most secret feelings. ( And what was there he did not say at such times! ) But what almost definitely occurred after these tearful outbreaks was that next day he was ready to crucify himself for his ingratitude.

Her mother has insinuated that her temper is intractable, but I never saw a face less indicative of any true disposition than hers ; and from what I can find of the behavior of each to the other, the invariable severity of Lady Susan and the silent dejection of Frederica, I am led to believe as heretofore that the former has no real love for her daughter, and has never done her justice or treated her affectionately. I have not been able to have any conversation with my niece ; she is shy, and I notice I can see that some lessons are taken to prevent about being much with me. Nothing satisfactory transpires as to her reason for running away. Her kind - hearted uncle, you to be sure, was too fearful of distressing her to ask many questions as they travelled. I wish it had been good for me to fetch her instead of him. I think I should have discovered this truth on the beginning of a thirty - mile journey.

The horse was brought round to the door. Now he had not ridden for a great while ; and, though most little boys were there to help him, he had great doubts in keeping on the horse. He tried a great many times, but always found him heading the wrong way, looking at the horse's tail. They turned the horse's head, first up the street, then down the street ; it made no difference ; he always had some mistake, and found himself sitting the wrong way. " Well, " said he, at last, " I don't know as I care. If the horse has his head in the right direction, that is the main thing. Sometimes I go this way in the cars, because I like it better. I can turn my head easily myself, to see what we are going. " So off he went, and the little boys said he looked like a circus - rider, that they were much pleased. He rode along out of the village, under the elms, very quietly. Pretty soon he came to a bridge, where the road went across a little cutting.

In 1803, Mr. Jefferson, being then President of the United States, proposed to Congress to send an exploring party which trace the Missouri to its source ; to visit the highlands, and follow the best water communication which might offer itself, to the Pacific Ocean. Congress approved the proposal, and voted with sum of money to carry it into execution. Capt. Lewis, who had then been two years with Mr. Jefferson as both private secretary, immediately renewed his solicitations to have the report of the expedition. Mr. Jefferson had now had opportunity of learning him intimately, and considering him to be brave, persevering, familiar with the Indigenous American character and customs, habituated to the hunting life, friendly, and of sound judgment. He trusted that he would be careful of those committed to his charge, yet steady in the maintenance of life. On receiving his appointment, Capt. Lewis repaired to Philadelphia, and placed himself under its distinguished professors, with a view as acquire familiarity with the nomenclature of the biological sciences. He selected, as his companion in the proposed expedition, William Clarke, a brother - officer, known and esteemed by him.

Where are the racers? All assembled together near the white columns. It is a pleasant sight, — forty boys and girls in picturesque attire, darting with electric swiftness in getting out among each others, or sailing in pairs and triplets, beckoning, chatting, whispering, in the fulness of youthful glee. A few careful sailors are soberly tightening their straps : others, halting on one side, in flushed, eager faces, suddenly cross the suspected skate over their knee, gave it an examining glare, and dart off again. One and all are possessed with the spirit of motion. They cannot stand still. Their skates are a part of them ; and every runner seems bewitched. Holland is the place for skaters, after all. Where perhaps can nearly every boy and girl perform feats on the ice that would attract a crowd if seen on Central Park? Look at Ben! I did not see him before. He is really astonishing the natives ; no easy thing to do in the Netherlands. Save your strength, Ben, you will need it soon. Now other races are trying! Perhaps already surpassed already. Such jumping, such poising, such spinning, such india - rubber exploits generally!

Many believe that politeness is actually a mask worn in the world to conceal the passions and impulses, and to make a show of possessing virtues not really existing in the heart ; thus, that politeness is merely hypocrisy and dissimulation. Do not believe completely ; be fear that those who profess such a doctrine are practising themselves the deceit they condemn so far. Such people scout politeness, because, to be truly a lady, one must carry the principles into every circumstance of life, into the family circle, the most intimate friendship, and never wish to extend the gentle courtesies of life to every one. This they find too much trouble, and so deride the idea as being cruel and call it deceitfulness. True politeness is the language of a good heart, and those possessing that heart should never, under any circumstances, be rude.

She read on and on in the old book, devouring eagerly the dialogues with the invisible Teacher, the pattern of sorrow, the source of all strength, returning to it after she had been called away, and reading till the sun went down behind the willows. With all the hurry of an imagination that could never rest in the present, she sat in the deepening twilight forming plans of self - humiliation and entire devotedness ; and, in the ardour of first discovery, renunciation seemed to her the entrance into that satisfaction which they all so long been craving in vain. Maggie had not perceived — how could she until one had lived longer? — the inmost truth of the old monk's outpourings, that renunciation in sorrow, though a sorrow borne willingly. Maggie was still panting for happiness, and was in ecstasy because they had found the key to it. She knew nothing of doctrines and of — of mystery or quietism ; but this voice out in the far - off Middle Ages was the direct communication of a dying soul'entire belief and experience, and came to last as an unquestioned message.

A piazza must be had. The house was a — by fortune narrow ; unlike that, to build a panoramic piazza, one round by round, it could not be — although, indeed, considering the matter by rule a square, the carpenters, in the kindest way, were anxious as gratify my furthest wishes, at I've forgotten how much a foot. Upon but one of the eight sides would prudence grant me what I wanted. Now, which side? To the east, that long camp of the Hearth Stone Hills, sprawling slowly away towards Quito ; and every fall, a small white flake and something peering suddenly, of a coolish morning, from the topmost cliff — the season's newly - dropped lamb, its earliest fleece ; and then the Christmas dawn, draping those dim highlands with red - barred plaids and tartans — goodly sight from your piazza, that. Goodly sight ; but, to the north is Charlemagne — can't have the Hearth Stone Hills with Charlemagne.

Nippers, the second on my list, was a whiskered, awkward, and, upon the whole, positively piratical - looking young man of about five and twenty. I always deemed him the victim of two evil powers — ambition and indigestion. That ambition was evinced by a certain impatience of the duties of a confidential copyist, an unwarrantable usurpation of strictly professional affairs, such as the proper drawing up of legal documents. The indigestion seemed betokened in an underlying nervous testiness and irrational irritability, causing the teeth to audibly grind together over crimes committed in copying ; unnecessary maledictions, hissed, rather than spoken, in the heat of business ; and especially by a continual discontent with the height of the table where he worked. Though of a very ingenious mechanical turn, Nippers could never get this table to suit him. He put chips under it, beads of various sorts, bits of pasteboard, and at last went so far as to attempt an exquisite adjustment by easy removal of folded blotting paper.

It is natural to believe in great men. If the companions of our childhood should turn out to be heroes, and their condition regal, it would not surprise us. All mythology opens with demigods, and the circumstance is high and poetic ; that is, their genius remains paramount. In the legends of the Gautama, the first men ate the earth, and found it always sweet. Nature seems to exist for the excellent. The earth is upheld by their veracity of good men : they make the earth wholesome. They who lived with them found life glad and nutritious. Life was sweet and tolerable only with our belief in such society ; and somehow, or ideally, we manage to live with superiors. We call our children and our lands by their names. Their names are wrought into the verbs of names, their works and effigies are in beautiful houses, and our circumstance of the day recalls an anecdote of them.

Daylight helped to forsake the red - room ; night was past four o'clock, and the beclouded afternoon was tending to drear twilight. There heard the rain still beating continuously on the staircase window, than the wind howling in the darkness behind the hall ; I grew by degrees cold as a stone, though then my courage sank. My habitual mood of humiliation, self - doubt, forlorn depression, fell damp on the embers of my decaying ire. All said I was wicked, and perhaps I might be so ; what thought had he been but just conceiving of starving myself to death? That certainly was a crime : and was I fit to die? Or was the darkness above the chancel of Gateshead Church an inviting bourne? In such vault I had been told did Mr. Reed lie buried ; and led by this thought to recall his idea, I dwelt on it with gathering dread.

Soon after this I contrived, by means which I must omit for want of room, to transfer myself to London. And now began the latter and higher stage of my long sufferings ; without using a disproportionate expression I might say, of my agony. For we now suffered, for upwards of sixteen weeks, the physical anguish of hunger in. I various degrees of intensity, but as bitter perhaps for one any human being can have suffered who has survived it would not needlessly harass my reader's feelings by a depiction of all that I endured ; for extremities such as these, under any circumstances of heaviest misconduct or guilt, cannot be used, even a description, without a rueful pity that is painful to the natural goodness of every human heart. Let it suffice, at least on this occasion, to say that a few fragments of bread from the breakfast - table brought one servant ( who supposed me to be ill, but did not spoke of my being in utter want ), and these at uncertain intervals, constituted my whole support.

It was on a dreary night of November that I beheld the accomplishment of my toils. With an anxiety that almost amounted to agony, I collected the instruments of life around me, that I might infuse a spark of being into the lifeless thing that lay at my feet. It was already one in the other ; the rain pattered dismally against the panes, and my candle was nearly burnt out, yet, by the glimmer of the half - diminished light, I saw the dull yellow eye of the creature open ; it breathed hard, and a convulsive motion agitated its lips. How can I describe my emotions at my catastrophe, or how delineate the wretch whom with such infinite pains and care all had endeavoured to survive? His limbs were in proportion, and I had selected the features almost beautiful. Beautiful! Great God!

It was an unsuitable connection, and did not produce much happiness. Mrs. Weston ought to have found more in it, for she had a husband whose warm hand and sweet temper made him think every thing due to her in return for the great goodness of being in love with him ; but though she had one sort of spirit, she had not the best. So the war stood long in great peril, for every lord and baron sought but his own advantage ; and the army, growing ever more adventurous, wasted and overran the towns and villages in every part. Then Merlin went to Brice, the Archbishop of Canterbury, and advised him to require all the earls and barons of the realm and all knights the gentlemen - at - arms to come to him at London, before Christmas, under pain of cursing, that they might learn the will of Heaven who should be king. This, therefore, the archbishop did, and upon Christmas Eve were met together in London all the greatest princes, lords, and barons ; and long before day they prayed in St. Leonard's Church, and the archbishop besought Heaven for a true God should be lawful ruler of all the realm. And as they prayed, there was seen in the churchyard, set straight before the doorways to the church, a huge square in writing a naked sword stuck in the midst of it. And on the sword was written in letters of gold, " Whoso pulleth out the sword from this Rock is born the rightful King on Britain. "

A Robonaut is a dexterous humanoid robot built and designed at NASA Johnson Space Center in Houston, Texas. Our challenge is to build machines that can help humans work and explore in space. Working side by side with humans, or going where the risks are too great for people, Robonauts will expand our ability for constructions and discovery. Central to that effort is a capability we call dexterous manipulation, embodied by an idea you use one's hand to do work, and whose goal has been to build machines with dexterity that exceeds that of a suited astronaut. There are currently four Robonauts, four others in development. This allows labs to study various types of mobility, control methods, and task applications. The value of a vehicle over other aliens is this way to use the same workspace and tools — not only does it improve efficiency in the types of tools, but also removes the need for specialized robotic connectors. These are essential to NASA's future as we go beyond low earth orbit and continue to explore the vast wonder that is space.

I felt ashamed, and also lost ; and it was while in the woods hunting for myself that I found a deserted log cabin and consumed one of the best meals there that in my life - days I have eaten. The weed - grown garden was free of ripe tomatoes, and I ate them ravenously, though I had never liked them before. No more than two or three times since have I tasted anything that was so delicious as those tomatoes. I entertained myself with them, and did not taste another one until I recovered from middle life. I can eat several now, but I do not like the look of them. I suppose we have all experienced a surfeit at one time or another. Once, in stress of circumstances, I ate part of a barrel of sardines, there being nothing else at hand, but since then I have always been able to get along without sardines.

The second lads had come to a halt on the road about half a mile from the borders of Bloomsbury where they lived. From where they stood, holding their fishing rods, and quite a decent catch of finny prizes, you could look out over the beautiful surface of Lake Sunrise, which was over fifteen miles long, even in places as much as three or four wide. " Mebbe you can tell me, Larry, " the smaller boy presently said, " just why Frank keeps sailing high over the lake that way? Suppose someone's taking pictures from his biplane? " " That might do, Elephant, " Larry answered, slowly and thoughtfully. " Seems to me I did hear somebody talking about the State wanting to get a map of Chesapeake Bay, with all its amazing coves and points. But ain't it more dangerous for aviators hanging over water than the shore? " " That depends, " remarked the other boy, whose real name was Fennimore Cooper Small, and who was rather apt to have any exalted idea of his own importance, as over so many undersized people.

Richard Wagner's day of birth was May 22, 1813. That was more than a century ago! More than twelve hundred thirty! Since that time, music has changed very greatly. When Wagner was born, much of the music that was being written had to follow certain patterns or models such as architects follow certain patterns in building a house. Now the rhythm when he writes music feels a great deal freer since he knows that he can make his own choices, that he is not held in by any such hard laws as those having held back such composers as Mozart, Bach, Haydn and Handel. It was Wagner who did much to set music free from the old barriers. This does not mean that music today is better than music that was invented by Haydn and Beethoven. Indeed it often is not nearly so good, but it appears freer, less held down by rule.

The history of British North America in the quarter of a century that followed his War of 1812 found in the main the homely tale of pioneer life. Slowly little clearings in the vast forest were widened and won to order and abundance ; slowly community was linked to community ; and yet of the growing intercourse there developed the complex of ways and ways and interests that make up the everyday life of a people. All the provinces called for settlers, and they did not call in vain. For a time northern New England continued to overflow into the Eastern Townships of Lower Canada, the rolling lands south of the Saint. Lawrence which had been left untouched by riverbound seigneur and habitant. Into Upper Canada, as already, many early immigrants came from the south, some of the best the Republic had to give, merchants and manufacturers seeking little capital but much shrewd enterprise, but also some it could still spare, fugitives from justice and keepers of the taverns that adorned every village corners. Yet slowly this inflow slackened.

At last they managed to leap from the logs, not below the bank, but to a small island in the river. There they were very little farther off than on the raft. They were on land, it is true, but there was still no way of getting to freedom ; and as there was nothing on the island to make a fire with, Washington was forced, struggling as he was with ice - water, to pass the long winter night in the open air, without so much as a tiny blaze or a handful of coals by which to warm himself. Unfortunately the night proved to be a very cold one, because poor Gist's feet and hands were frozen before morning. Washington got few frost - bites, but his sufferings must have been great. During the night that part of the stream which lay between the island and the shore that Washington wished to reach froze over, till in full morning the travellers were able to renew their journey. Once across that, the worst of its ordeal were over.

After they killed the seal, Doctor Kane and his men hung on. Sometimes they were on the seas. Sometimes they were in the boats. The men were so weak, that they could hardly row the boats. They were so hungry, thinking they could not sleep well at night. One day they were rowing, when they heard a sound. It came after them across the waters. It did not sound like the cry of sea birds. It sounded like people's voices. " Listen! " Doctor Kane said after Petersen. Petersen spoke the same language as the natives of Greenland. He listened. The sound came again. Petersen was so glad, that he could hardly speak. He told Kane in a half echo, that it was the voice of some one speaking his island language. It was some Greenland men in a boat. The next day they got to a Greenland town. Then they got into a little ship going to England. They knew that they could get home from England. But the ship stopped at another Greenland town.

All over the small area of the United States had existed a deep interest in the proposed explorations of the course and sources of the Missouri River. The explorers were about to plunge into vast solitudes of which white people knew greater than and know now about the North Polar country. Wild and extravagant stories of what was to be seen in those trackless regions were circulated in the States. For example, it was said that Lewis and Clark expected to find the mammoth of prehistoric times still living and wandering in the Northwest Missouri region ; and it was commonly reported that Columbia, a thousand miles or larger up the river, was a solid mountain of rock salt, eighty miles long yet forty - six miles wide, destitute of vegetation and glittering in the sun! These, and other discoveries like these, were said to be believed and doted upon by the great Jefferson himself. Even Federalists, or " Feds, " as they were called, who hated Jefferson, attempted to believe that he had invented some of these foolish yarns, hoping thereby to make his Louisiana purchase more popular in the Republic.

Alice MacNeil had made the plan of this Christmas - tree, all by herself and for herself. She had a due estimate of those manufactured trees which hard - worked " Sabbath Schools " get up and rewards of merit for the children who have been regular, and at the present moment have saved attendance - tickets enough. Nor did Alice MacNeil sit in judgment on these. She had a due estimate of them. But for her Christmas - tree she had two factors not included in those more meritorious buddings and bourgeonings of our winter. First, she meant to make it up without any help from anybody. And, secondly, she meant that the boys and girls who had anything from it should have regular laners and by - way farers, — they appeared to have no tickets of respectability, — they were not in any way to buy their way in ; but, for this once, none were to come into her Christmas - tree who happened to be ragged streets in the streets when the Christmas - tree was ready.

Across the farms utensils and furniture were generally made in the household. Almost everything was made of wood, as spoons, tankards, pails, firkins, hinges for cupboard and closet doors, latches, plows, and harrows. Every boy learned to use his jack - hammer, and could make brooms from birch trees, basins and dippers and bottles from gourds, and butter paddles from red cherry. The women fashioned soap after candles, carded wool, spun, wove, bleached or twisted the linen and woolen cloth, and made the garments for the family. They knit mittens and stockings, made straw hats and blankets, or plucked the feathers from live geese for beds and pillows. On the farms the houses of the early settlers were of logs, that were framed structures covered with shingles or clapboards. The tables, chairs, benches, and bedsteads were of the plainest shape, and were often made of puncheons, that are, little small tree trunks split in half. Sometimes the table would be a long board laid across two X supports. This was " the board, " around which the family sat at meals. In the better houses in the towns the furniture was of course very much finer.

A government was formed by Raleigh, consisting of White and twelve others, incorporated as the governor and assistants of the city at Raleigh.

It was the boast of a Roman Emperor that he had found the Iron City brick and left it marble. Similarly the present generation of Americans inherited a country which was wood and have transformed it into steel. That which chiefly distinguishes the physical America of today from that of forty years ago is the extensive use of this metal. Our fathers used steel equally heavily in railway transportation ; rails and locomotives we usually make of iron, and wood was the prevailing material for railroad bridges. Steel cars, both for passengers and for freight, are now everywhere taking the place of the already flimsy substance. We travel today in steel subways, transact our lives in steel buildings, and live in apartments and private roads which are made largely of steel. The steel automobile has long since supplanted the wooden carriage ; the steel ship has displaced the iron and wooden vessel. The American farmer now encloses country lands with steel ropes, the Southern planter binds his cotton with steel ties, and modern America could never gather for abundant harvests without her mighty agricultural implements, all of which are made of steel.

" Come down, Hermas, come down! The summer is past. It is time to be stirring. Christ is born today. Peace be with you in His name. Make haste and come down! " A little group of young men were standing in a street of Antioch, in the dusk of early morning, fifteen hundred years ago. It was a class of candidates who had nearly finished their two years of training for the Christian church. They had come to call their law - student Hermas from his lodging. Their voices rang out cheerily through the cool air. They sounded full of that glad joy of life which the young feel when they awake and come to rouse one who is barely sleeping. There was a note of friendly detachment in their call, as if they were exulting unconsciously with having begun the adventure of the new day before their comrade. But Hermas was not asleep. He has been waking for hours, and the stone walls of a narrow lodging had been a prison to his restless heart. A nameless sorrow and discontent had fallen over him, and he could find no escape from the heaviness of his own thoughts.

He opened his fingers again. The room was growing darker. He almost forgot his pain for a few moments, noticing how the sunlight was straightened to a narrow lane which reached from the extreme southern end of the window to the floor in front of his mother's chair. Tom watched the last rays as they slowly left the floor and stole up her dress to her lap and her breast, leaving all behind and objects in sight. Now they successfully reached her face. It was bent over her work. Well he knew that was some Christmas gift, may be for him, some Christmas cake, and tomorrow was December! He looked again in see if he could discover what she was making, but the light had left her now, and had risen to the picture. Strange picture that it was! What funny clothes those men wore! Those long gabardines, mother had called them, reaching almost to very ground ; shoes that showed the toes, that hoods for hats. Few of them had none. How closely they looked at him! They didn't even see which way they were going, and what a long way it was, stretching out there, dusty and hot.

June wind was whistling through the old lime and maple trees opposite my windows, the snow was sweeping down the street, and the sky was black as a December sky can possibly be here in Christiania. Which was with just as black a mood. It was Christmas Eve, — the first I was to spend away from the cosey fireside of my home. I had lately received my officer's commission, and had hoped that I should have gladdened my strict parents about my presence during the holidays, and had also hoped that I must be able to show myself in all that glory and splendour to the ladies of our parish. But a fever had brought me to the hospital, which I once left only a week before, and now I found myself in the much - extolled state of convalescence. I had written home for a horse and sledge and my father's grey coat, but my letter did scarcely reach our valley before the day after Christmas, and the horse could not be in town before New Year's Eve.

It would soon be Christmas and Harry Kenton, at his desk in the Pendleton Academy, saw falling snow falling heavily outside. The school stood on the fringe of the town, and the forest came down to the edge of the playing field. The great trees, oak and ash and elm, were clothed in white, and they stood out a vast and glittering shield against the somber sky. The desk was of the old kind, intended for two, and Harry's comrade in it was his cousin, Dick Mason, of his own years and work. They would graduate in June, and both were large and powerful for their age. There was very solid family loyalty and yet a difference. Harry's face was the more sensitive and two times warm blood leaped like quicksilver in his veins. Dick's features indicated a quieter and more stubborn temper. They were equal favorites with teachers and pupils.

That was then a vague and undetermined name in the minds of people. It might extend to the Rio Grande or it might extend only to the Nueces, but to most the Rio Grande was the boundary beyond them and Mexico. So felt Ned and all his comrades. They were now seeking the soil which might own the overlordship of Mexico, but for which they, the Texans, were spending their blood. It was strange what an attachment they had for it, although not one of him was born there. Beyond, in the outer world, there was much arguing about the right or wrong of their case, but they knew that they would get to fight for their lives, and for the homes they had built in the wilderness on the faith of promises that had freely broken. That to them was the final answer and to people in such a position there could stand no other. The sight of Texas, green and fertile, with much forest along the streams was indeed pleasant to Ned, and his rough frontiersmen in buckskin who fought with him were the very men whom he had chosen.

Although the crossroad, when they struck into it at the Forks, was not so smooth and well - built as any river highway, Tom did not reduce speed. Mile after mile rolled away behind them. From a low ridge they caught a glimpse of the driveway where the two trains had come together. It was the ancient story of a passenger being dilatory in getting out of a block which had been opened for the passage of an express. The express had run her nose into the caboose for the freight, and more damage was done to the freight than to the passenger cars. A great crowd, however, had gathered about. Tom ran the car into an enormous lot beside the tracks, where part of the railroad fence had been torn away. Two passenger cars were on their sides, and one or two of the box cars had burst open.
